#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-69-3"></span><span id="page-69-2"></span><span id="page-69-1"></span><span id="page-69-0"></span>At a great feast, King Belshazzar commands that temple vessels—which had been taken from Jerusalem—be used for wine and the praise of pagan gods (5:1–4). In response to this act, a hand appears at the feast and writes on the palace wall (v. 5), but none of the king's men can decipher the message (vv. 7–8). The queen suggests Daniel as the most likely interpreter (vv. 10–12), and when he arrives, he rebukes

<span id="page-70-7"></span><span id="page-70-6"></span>Belshazzar for not heeding the lesson about humility that Nebuchadnezzar had learned (vv. 20–22). The writing on the wall is a message of judgment against Belshazzar and the Babylonian kingdom (vv. 24–28).

## *Section Outline*

- II.C'. Judgment on Royal Arrogance (5:1–31)
	- 1. Belshazzar Holds a Great Feast (5:1)
		- 2. Belshazzar Gives a Command concerning Temple Vessels (5:2–4)
			- 3. God Writes a Message on a Wall (5:5)
				- 4. Belshazzar Brings in the Wise Men of Babylon (5:6–9)
					- 5. The Queen Advocates the Abilities of Daniel (5:10–12)
				- 4'. Belshazzar Brings in Daniel (5:13–16)
			- 3'. Daniel Explains the Message on the Wall (5:17–28)
		- 2'. Belshazzar Gives a Command concerning Daniel (5:29)
	- 1'. Belshazzar Dies after the Great Feast (5:30–31)

<span id="page-70-5"></span>Daniel 5 begins and ends with Belshazzar. The opening verse reports a great feast (1), and the final verses report the king's death (1'). The intervening sections explain why Belshazzar does not survive the night of the banquet. On two occasions in the story, he gives explicit commands, one for the temple vessels to be brought to the banquet (2) and the other for Daniel to be rewarded for his help (2').

The drama picks up the pace once a hand appears and writes a message on the palace wall (3). In the literary arrangement of the chapter, the matching section (3') records the interpretation of the cryptic writing. The wise men cannot discern the meaning (4) while Daniel can (4'). The verses in 4 are framed by an inclusio, for verses 6 and 9 both speak of the king's alarm and change of color. In the center of the chiastic structure is the queen's glowing endorsement of Daniel's abilities (5). These are her only words in the story—and in the book as a whole—and their location in the narrative indicates their importance.

<span id="page-70-4"></span>Daniel 5 is the final chapter of the narratives involving Babylon. (The events of chapter 6 take place under Medo-Persian rule.) In these chapters, only chapter 5 features a Babylonian king other than Nebuchadnezzar. However, the connection between the two kings in chapters 4–5 is evident—these two chapters are the center of the Aramaic chiasm (chs. 2–7) and each narrates God's judgment on a Babylonian king:

<span id="page-70-9"></span>Daniel 6–Divine Deliverance from Death

## *Comment*

<span id="page-71-9"></span><span id="page-71-8"></span><span id="page-71-1"></span>5:1 Belshazzar, a successor of Nebuchadnezzar, threw "a great feast" for a thousand lords. Daniel was not present at the festivities (cf. v. 13), either because he had not been invited or because his former prominence did not continue under Belshazzar (cf. vv. 10–12, where the queen informed the king about Daniel). During the feast, Belshazzar "drank wine in front of the thousand," displaying privilege and arrogance.

<span id="page-71-3"></span><span id="page-71-2"></span>5:2 The mention of temple vessels reminds us of chapter 1, in which Nebuchadnezzar besieged Jerusalem, took the temple vessels, brought them to Babylon, and put them in "the treasury of his god" (1:2). These vessels had remained in the pagan temple since that time, but Belshazzar called for them to be brought out so that his wives, concubines, and lords could drink from them—an act that would outrage a Jew. Belshazzar did something that not even "Nebuchadnezzar his father" had done.

Nebuchadnezzar was not Belshazzar's biological father but his ancestor. (The use of "father" could refer to either the immediately preceding king or a more distant predecessor; cf. ESV mg.) Belshazzar's biological father was Nabonidus, with whom he reigned as coregent from 550 to 539 BC.

<span id="page-71-5"></span>5:3–4 Once the vessels taken from "the house of God in Jerusalem" were brought to the feast, everyone present drank from them. Relocation of the vessels to a Babylonian god's temple (1:2) had defiled them already, but the attendees of the banquet defiled them further not only when they "drank wine" from them but also when they "praised the gods of gold and silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone." The banquet guests reveled in blasphemy and idolatry. These elements are identical in name and order to those in Nebuchadnezzar's dream in chapter 2, with the exception of "wood" replacing "clay" (cf. 2:32–33).

<span id="page-71-4"></span>Belshazzar and his guests may have directed their attention to the gods because of the encroaching Medo-Persian army, which—according to the Babylonian Chronicle—had defeated Nabonidus and the Babylonian army merely fifty miles from Babylon two days earlier. In all likelihood, Belshazzar was aware of this defeat, yet he held the banquet in a brazen display of invincibility—and, as it turned out, delusion.

<span id="page-71-7"></span><span id="page-71-6"></span><span id="page-71-0"></span>5:5 The tone of the party changed when "fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the plaster of the wall of the king's palace." Since this happened "immediately" after the guests drank wine from the Jerusalem temple vessels (v. 4), the event was viewed as an ominous response (v. 6). The detached hand wrote on the wall "opposite the lampstand," which illuminated the writing for all to see. This "lampstand" may have been one of the items from the Jerusalem temple. In the actual Jerusalem temple, the bread of the Presence stood opposite the lampstand (1 Kings 7:48–50; Ex. 25:23–26:37) to remind the people of Israel of God's provision and sustenance. If this lampstand was now in Belshazzar's Dani el 5:1–31 72

palace, then instead of illuminating an object of provision, it was illuminating a sign of judgment.

<span id="page-72-7"></span><span id="page-72-2"></span>5:6–7 Outwardly and inwardly, Belshazzar was undone and filled with fear, for he surmised that the writing on the wall was not a favorable sign. As Nebuchadnezzar had done, Belshazzar summoned the Babylonian wise men (cf. 2:2; 4:6), calling "loudly" out of fear and urgency. He promised three rewards to anyone who could interpret the writing on the wall: that person "shall be clothed with purple and have a chain of gold around his neck and shall be the third ruler in the kingdom." The first and second rewards symbolized the regal status of the third; the interpreter would be the "third ruler in the kingdom" because Nabonidus and Belshazzar filled the first and second positions, being corulers at the time.

<span id="page-72-8"></span><span id="page-72-3"></span>5:8 Wise men arrived but could neither read nor interpret the writing on the wall. Their inability had precedent in previous chapters of the book, for Nebuchadnezzar's wise men had failed to discern the meaning of his visions (2:7, 10; 4:7) as well. Unique in this situation was the visibility of what needed to be interpreted: the writing was on the palace wall, where all could see, unlike the visions of Nebuchadnezzar, which were visible only to him in his dreams.

<span id="page-72-9"></span><span id="page-72-6"></span>5:9 Belshazzar remained alarmed, and his lords perplexed. This verse forms an inclusio with verse 6, where the king's fear and color were noted. Verse 9 also mentions a perplexed look shared by the thousand lords as their leader's mind and body pulsed and flushed with fear.

<span id="page-72-10"></span><span id="page-72-5"></span>5:10 The queen entered the banquet hall, presumably because someone had informed her of "the words of the king and his lords." She was not Belshazzar's wife, for his wives were already present at the banquet (vv. 2–3). She was probably Belshazzar's mother, wife of his father, Nabonidus.27

<span id="page-72-12"></span><span id="page-72-11"></span><span id="page-72-4"></span><span id="page-72-0"></span>5:11–12 The queen said, "There is a man in your kingdom in whom is the spirit of the holy gods." Although she did not say the man's name, the reader knows she meant Daniel. He, like Joseph in Genesis, had the spirit of God (4:8–9, 18; cf. Gen. 41:38). Still without explicitly mentioning Daniel's name, the queen gave a brief history of Daniel's relationship with Nebuchadnezzar (Dan. 5:11; cf. 2:48). Her description of Daniel in 5:11 was meant to stir the king's desire to see him before she actually names him in verse 12. The queen commended Daniel's God-given ability "to interpret dreams, explain riddles, and solve problems." She knew Daniel could explain the writing.

<span id="page-72-13"></span><span id="page-72-1"></span>Apparently Belshazzar did not know about Daniel, which provides another link with Joseph, as we recall how a new Pharaoh rose to power who "did not know Joseph" (Ex. 1:8). Under that new Pharaoh, the Israelites were in Egyptian captivity; under Belshazzar, the Israelites were in Babylonian captivity. Despite

<sup>27</sup> Cf. Sidney Greidanus, *Preaching Christ from Daniel: Foundations for Expository Sermons* (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 2012), 164.

the new rulers in both of these situations, an exodus was promised. For the Jews in Egypt, God raised up Moses, who led them toward Canaan. For the Jews now captive in Babylon, their new exodus would mean a return to that same land. God had raised up a leader for them too, a Medo-Persian king who would arrive before the banquet night ended.

<span id="page-73-6"></span>5:13 When Daniel arrived, Belshazzar said, "You are that Daniel, one of the exiles of Judah, whom the king my father brought from Judah." The queen had probably informed Belshazzar of these facts, and he repeated them to remind Daniel of where each stood in relation to the other: Belshazzar was royalty, while Daniel was a captive. It had been decades since Daniel's journey from Jerusalem to Babylon (cf. 1:3–7), and he was now an old man.

<span id="page-73-7"></span><span id="page-73-5"></span><span id="page-73-0"></span>5:14–17 Belshazzar repeated the essence of what the queen had told him about Daniel (cf. v. 11), and he then informed Daniel of the problem: the Babylonian wise men could not "read this writing and make known to me its interpretation." Yet Belshazzar had heard that Daniel could "give interpretations and solve problems." If Daniel could decipher the writing, the king promised the same rewards he had offered to his wise men (cf. v. 7): purple clothing, a golden chain, and status as the third ruler. Daniel told the king to keep the rewards and give them to someone else. He agreed to interpret the writing, but not for profit.

<span id="page-73-8"></span><span id="page-73-4"></span>5:18–21 Before interpreting the writing, Daniel spoke about Nebuchadnezzar's greatness and humiliation, both of which had been granted to him by God. Daniel recalled that "the Most High God" gave Nebuchadnezzar "kingship and greatness and glory and majesty." The fourfold content of God's favor should not be parsed too finely and could be summarized, "God granted Nebuchadnezzar reign over a glorious empire." Because of Nebuchadnezzar's greatness, everyone feared him. He had held (what seemed to be) unassailable power: he decided who would die and who would live, whom he would raise up and whom he would humble.

<span id="page-73-2"></span><span id="page-73-1"></span>Belshazzar no doubt knew of the greatness of Nebuchadnezzar, but Daniel's recollection of his glory and majesty was necessary in order to emphasize his subsequent humiliation: Nebuchadnezzar's heart was lifted up, but God brought him down from his throne and took away his glory (cf. 4:19–25), after which the king, for a time, had thought and lived as a beast (cf. 4:16, 25, 32–33). The goal of such punishment was that Nebuchadnezzar would learn that "the Most High God rules the kingdom of mankind and sets it over whom he will" (5:21). Significantly, Daniel did not mention Nebuchadnezzar's restoration (4:34–37). He covered only the history relevant for Belshazzar, whose life would emulate the pattern of pride leading to demise, but for whom there would be no restoration.

<span id="page-73-10"></span><span id="page-73-9"></span><span id="page-73-3"></span>5:22–23 Belshazzar's failure, said Daniel, was not in knowledge but in application. He knew what had happened to his predecessor Nebuchadnezzar, but he did not humble his heart. He did not modify his behavior in light of the fact

<span id="page-74-5"></span><span id="page-74-3"></span><span id="page-74-2"></span>Having recounted what Belshazzar did not do, Daniel moved to what the king *did* do, and Daniel's boldness shines with prophetic conviction: "You have lifted up yourself against the Lord of heaven" (v. 23). The blasphemy at the banquet dishonored God. Not only did Belshazzar drink from the Jerusalem temple vessels with his lords, wives, and concubines (vv. 2–3), he also praised the gods of "gold and silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone," which were idols unable to see, hear, or know anything (v. 4). The OT regularly characterizes idols in this way (cf. Deut. 4:28; Pss. 115:4–7; 135:15–17; Isa. 44:9–20). These non-gods were unable to do anything because they did not exist, yet these nonexistent non-gods were objects of praise! Daniel saved the most serious charge for last: "The God in whose hand is your breath, and whose are all your ways, you have not honored" (Dan. 5:23). Belshazzar was vulnerable because his very breath rested in God's hand—the hand that had written on the palace wall.

<span id="page-74-7"></span><span id="page-74-6"></span><span id="page-74-4"></span><span id="page-74-0"></span>5:24–25 Daniel explained the detached hand and ominous inscription as God's response to Belshazzar's sin, and he read aloud the writing on the wall: "Mene, Mene, Tekel, and Parsin." Apparently not even the Babylonian wise men could read those words (v. 8), which could perhaps be explained by the fact that the words apparently had no vowels and no spaces between them; knowing where to break up the words could be a dilemma. Daniel, however, was able to read the writing according to the proper breakdown of the letters into the intended words.

<span id="page-74-8"></span>5:26–28 Daniel interpreted each of the Aramaic words on the wall. "Mene" indicated that "God has numbered the days of your kingdom and brought it to an end." A mina was a Babylonian weight or currency, equivalent to 60 shekels, and "Mene" sounded like the Aramaic word for "numbered." God had allotted only a certain amount of time to the Babylonian kingdom, and that time was up.

Focusing on "Tekel," Daniel told Belshazzar, "You have been weighed in the balances and found wanting." Whereas "Mene" pertained to the Babylonian kingdom, "Tekel" pertained to its current king. A tekel was equivalent to one shekel and sounded like the Aramaic word for "weighed." Belshazzar had been weighed by God and had come up short. His time as king was over.

<span id="page-74-1"></span>The third word on the wall was "Parsin," but Daniel used the singular form, "Peres": "Peres, your kingdom is divided and given to the Medes and Persians." Peres was a half-mina and sounded like the Aramaic words for "divided" and "Persia." Daniel's statement thus supports our interpretation of the vision in chapter 2, that Babylon would be followed by the Medo-Persian kingdom and not simply the Medes. Persia had already conquered the Medes c. 550 BC before arriving on Babylon's doorstep in 539. Therefore Belshazzar's reign would end because of the Medo-Persian Empire (table 1.5).

<span id="page-75-6"></span><span id="page-75-3"></span><span id="page-75-2"></span>5:29 In response to the interpretation, Belshazzar commanded that Daniel be given purple clothing, a golden chain, and the position of "third ruler" in the kingdom. Belshazzar had promised these gifts to his wise men if they could read and interpret the mysterious writing, but they had failed (vv. 7–8). When Belshazzar offered the same rewards to Daniel for the same task, Daniel had refused them (vv. 16–17), but Belshazzar imposed the rewards anyway, perhaps because Daniel had already given the interpretation and had earlier made clear that he had no profit motive (v. 17). The concept of rewards accompanying Daniel's successful interpretation parallels each of the previous chapters, which end with someone increasing in blessing and stature or position (1:19; 2:48–49; 3:30; 4:36).

<span id="page-75-7"></span>5:30 The night of the blasphemous banquet was the night Belshazzar died. He "was killed," but we are not told by whom. According to scholars who have correlated ancient records with our calendar, the night of Belshazzar's dinner and death was October 11, 539 BC.

<span id="page-75-9"></span><span id="page-75-8"></span>5:31 The Babylonian king fell, and so did the kingdom: "Darius the Mede received the kingdom, being about sixty-two years old." Darius appears to be the same king as in chapter 6, and his name appears again in 9:1 and 11:1. If Darius was the king of the Medo-Persians who conquered Belshazzar and the Babylonian kingdom, then we must address his relation to another figure, Cyrus the Persian, in 6:28.

<span id="page-75-10"></span>The name Cyrus already appeared in 1:21 and will appear later in 10:1. At first glance, the names "Darius the Mede" and "Cyrus the Persian" might seem to refer to two different individuals. But there is no extrabiblical evidence that a man named Darius ever ruled after Babylon fell,28 and thus Darius the Mede and Cyrus the Persian were most likely the same person.29 The last verse in chapter 6 juxtaposes "the reign of Darius and the reign of Cyrus the Persian" (v. 28), and a possible use of the Hebrew conjunction would be to equate the second phrase with

<span id="page-75-5"></span><sup>28</sup> Steinmann cautions, "However, that is merely an argument from silence and may simply reflect that such historical records of Darius have not survived or come to light yet" (*Daniel*, 290).

<span id="page-75-11"></span><sup>29</sup> The Old Greek and Theodotion have "Cyrus" rather than the MT's "Darius" in Daniel 11:1. Steinmann rightly notes, "Theodotion's version of Bel and the Serpent (Bel 1)" identifies "Darius as the Persian king Cyrus the Great" (*Daniel*, 293). Cf. Joyce G. Baldwin, *Daniel*, TOTC (Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity Press, 1978), 26–28.

the first.30 The same king, therefore, could have been known by either his Median or his Persian name. Cyrus's mother was Median while his father was Persian, a situation that could easily result in the ruler's having two names.31 Some other characters in the book of Daniel also have two names (cf. 1:7).

<span id="page-76-3"></span>The age of Darius is not an irrelevant detail. Since no other character's age is recorded in the book of Daniel, the number warrants close attention. "Sixty-two" (5:31) may be significant because it means Darius would have been born around the same time Daniel interpreted Nebuchadnezzar's first vision (c. 602 BC). That vision concerned a succession of earthly kingdoms and indicated that the Babylonian Empire would one day end. Little did Nebuchadnezzar and Daniel know that the one who would defeat mighty Babylon—Darius the Mede—would be born around that time. When Darius's years reached their appointed number, the kingdom of Babylon would be weighed and found wanting, and then fall.

<span id="page-76-2"></span>An age of "sixty-two years" also supports the identification of Darius the Mede as Cyrus the Persian. Cyrus died in 530 BC at the age of seventy, which means he was about sixty-two years old in 539 when he conquered Babylon. Important for biblical prophecy was how Babylon's defeat would mean the end of exile for the Israelites. As Isaiah had prophesied, the Lord's plan was to use Cyrus as his instrument to free his people (Isa. 44:21–45:13). In addition, prophecies also foretold that the Medes would attack Babylon (Isa. 13:17; 21:2; Jer. 51:11, 28), and thus it makes sense for Darius/Cyrus to be the one king of Medo-Persia who fulfilled these words.

### <span id="page-76-1"></span>*Response*

It is better to learn from the consequences of someone else's foolish choices than to choose foolishness ourselves and face its consequences. It is unfortunate that Belshazzar had not learned from Nebuchadnezzar's mistakes.

<span id="page-76-5"></span>One truth Belshazzar seemed to rebel against was his own vulnerability. He acted as if he were invincible and Babylon would continue forever. We may be made in the image of God, but we are merely human. James asks, "What is your life? For you are a mist that appears for a little time and then vanishes" (James 4:14). People and empires are in the hands of a sovereign God, and their survival is dependent on his will (James 4:15). Daniel accused Belshazzar of dishonoring this God in whose hand was his very breath (Dan. 5:23). God is worthy of our honor, our worship. We should fear him, for he is holy and wise and altogether glorious. He alone is God, and he will not tolerate our idolatry.

<span id="page-76-6"></span><span id="page-76-4"></span>May we be eager to glorify and obey the living God, who has ordained the events of the past and who directs the future toward his appointed ends. He kept his promise when he judged Judah and sent them into exile, and he kept his promise that Babylon's hold on his people would not last forever. From youth to

<span id="page-76-0"></span><sup>30</sup> Cf. Steinmann, *Daniel*, 293, where he points to Daniel 2:28; 3:2; and 1 Chronicles 5:26 as other examples of *waw* (the Hebrew conjunction) functioning in this manner.

<sup>31</sup> According to Herodotus, Cyrus was not the Persian ruler's birth name given by his mother (*Histories* 1.113–114). Perhaps Darius was Cyrus's birth name.

old age, Daniel remained confident in his faithful and benevolent God. He defied the law of the land when obeying it would have meant disobeying God. He spoke to the kings of Babylon with boldness and courage, telling them not what they wanted to hear but the truth as God had revealed it to him. How the character of almighty God should compel us! His sovereignty and faithfulness are foundational glories that should spur on our endurance and rouse our courage.

A detriment to our obedience is our idolatrous heart. We must beware the subtleties of pride and self-exaltation that justify themselves and insist that nothing bad could happen if they are indulged. Belshazzar did not humble his heart (5:22), and this was his undoing. As was the case for Nebuchadnezzar, pride goes before a fall (Prov. 16:18).

<span id="page-77-6"></span><span id="page-77-4"></span>We need people like Daniel so that we do not become people like Belshazzar. Believers need trustworthy people who will speak with conviction and kindness. The warnings and rebukes of godly friends will surely save us from many snares and grievances. We should not pretend we can live in wisdom and godly fear while still clinging to rigid individualism. In the opening section of Proverbs, Solomon warns, "Fools despise wisdom and instruction" (Prov. 1:7). The wicked man "dies for lack of discipline, and because of his great folly he is led astray" (Prov. 5:23). Better to wound a heart by telling the truth than to placate a rebel on the path of destruction (Prov. 27:6).

<span id="page-77-8"></span><span id="page-77-5"></span><span id="page-77-3"></span><span id="page-77-2"></span><span id="page-77-1"></span>True wisdom is worth any price. Lady Wisdom says, "Take my instruction instead of silver, and knowledge rather than choice gold, for wisdom is better than jewels, and all that you may desire cannot compare with her" (Prov. 8:10–11). Our pursuit of wisdom must never be isolated from trusting and following the Lord Jesus Christ, "in whom are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge" (Col. 2:3). The good news for idolaters—for all who, like Belshazzar, have exalted their hearts and gone astray into false worship—is Jesus. Paul reminded the Thessalonians of the gospel's power among them as they "turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God, and to wait for his Son from heaven, whom he raised from the dead, Jesus who delivers us from the wrath to come" (1 Thess. 1:9–10).

<span id="page-77-9"></span><span id="page-77-7"></span><span id="page-77-0"></span>May we humble ourselves and gain wisdom and so gain Christ, lest we lift ourselves up against the Lord of heaven and incur his wrath (Dan. 5:22–23). The Lord holds our breath, so let everything that has breath fear and praise the Lord (Ps. 150:6).

## DANIEL 6:1–28

1Or *came thronging*; also verses 11, 15 2Aramaic *answered and said*; also verse 20

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-79-6"></span><span id="page-79-5"></span><span id="page-79-4"></span><span id="page-79-3"></span><span id="page-79-2"></span><span id="page-79-1"></span><span id="page-79-0"></span>Certain leaders under King Darius conspire to accuse Daniel (vv. 1–5). They convince the king to sign a thirty-day ordinance that prayer be made only to him and that those who refuse be cast into a den of lions (vv. 6–9). Daniel maintains his practice of prayer to God (v. 10), and Darius orders him to be thrown into the den (vv. 10–17). The next morning Darius learns that God has saved Daniel from the lions (vv. 18–22) and then he orders that Daniel be removed from the den and the accusers and their families be thrown into it instead (vv. 23–24). A new decree orders everyone to tremble and fear before Daniel's God (vv. 25–27).

### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-80-5"></span><span id="page-80-4"></span>II.B'. Divine Deliverance from Death (6:1–28)
	- 1. Darius Shows Favor to Daniel (6:1–3)
		- 2. Darius Signs an Injunction (6:4–9)
			- 3. Some Men Go to the King to Accuse Daniel (6:10–13)
				- 4. Darius Is Distressed (6:14)
					- 5. Darius Orders Daniel to the Lions (6:15–17)
						- 6. Darius Asks Daniel If God Has Delivered Him (6:18–20)
					- 5'. God's Angel Has Delivered Daniel from the Lions (6:21–22)
				- 4'. Darius Is Exceedingly Glad (6:23)
			- 3'. The Men Who Accused Daniel Are Sentenced to Death (6:24)
		- 2'. Darius Makes a Decree (6:25–27)
	- 1'. Daniel Prospers during the Reign of Darius (6:28)

The narrative begins and ends with Daniel experiencing favor under the reign of Darius (1 and 1'). Between these descriptions of Daniel prospering are two occasions of Darius issuing a command. Darius signs a document stating that everyone must pray only to him for thirty days (2), but later he decrees that people are to tremble before Daniel's God (2'). Conspirators go to Darius to accuse Daniel of violating the law about prayer (3), but in an ironic and fitting end to the story, the accusers themselves are thrown into the lions' den (3').

King Darius cannot renege on his ordinance to punish anyone who prays to someone other than him, so he is greatly distressed when the conspirators accuse Daniel (4). The king's distress turns to great relief and gladness, however, when he learns that Daniel has been spared from death (4'). Even though Darius had reluctantly ordered Daniel's death (5), God had sent an angel to close the mouths of the lions and thus deliver Daniel (5').

The center of the chiasm is Darius's sleepless night and hasty return to the den the next morning (6). These verses (vv. 18–20) may have been placed at the center of the chapter because they indicate the king's hope that Daniel would survive: "O Daniel, servant of the living God, has your God, whom you serve continually, been able to deliver you from the lions?" (v. 20). The previous events in chapter 6 lead up to that suspenseful and hopeful question, and everything that happens afterward proves that the power of God has indeed delivered his servant.

<span id="page-80-6"></span><span id="page-80-2"></span><span id="page-80-0"></span>Chapter 6 is the first narrative in the book that takes place under the Medo-Persian Empire. The events of chapters 1–5 were under Babylonian kings; now the Medo-Persians rule. Chapter 6 is also part of the book's Aramaic chiasm (chs. 2–7), strategically matching chapter 3, where another divine deliverance took place:

<span id="page-80-3"></span><span id="page-80-1"></span>Daniel 2–Vision of Four Kingdoms Preceding an Eternal Kingdom Daniel 3–Divine Deliverance from Death

<span id="page-81-4"></span><span id="page-81-3"></span><span id="page-81-2"></span>Daniel 4–Judgment on Royal Arrogance Daniel 5–Judgment on Royal Arrogance Daniel 6–Divine Deliverance from Death Daniel 7–Vision of Four Kingdoms Preceding an Eternal Kingdom

### <span id="page-81-9"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-81-5"></span>6:1–2 King Darius installed "120 satraps" and "over them three high officials." This authority structure was probably in place within the first year after Darius's arrival and included Daniel as one of the three high officials (or presidents); to Daniel, "these satraps should give account, so that the king might suffer no loss."

A satrap was a protector of the kingdom, so Darius's appointment of Daniel shows the king's great trust in the Hebrew prophet. Darius likely believed Daniel could stave off signs of political corruption, especially financial loss. He probably learned about Daniel's faithful service to Nebuchadnezzar, which explained his confidence. Furthermore, if he learned of Daniel's prediction regarding Belshazzar's downfall, he presumably would have trusted Daniel even more.

<span id="page-81-6"></span><span id="page-81-0"></span>6:3 Now in his eighties, Daniel still stood out from others, just as he had as a teenager (1:17–20). His "excellent spirit" probably refers to his humble and wise demeanor. Darius was so impressed with Daniel that he planned to promote him to his highest rank yet: a position "over the whole kingdom."

<span id="page-81-7"></span>6:4–5 Once it became clear how much favor Daniel had garnered with King Darius, the other high officials and satraps "sought to find a ground for complaint against Daniel with regard to the kingdom." They wanted to turn Darius against Daniel; with Daniel out of the way, one of them could fill the vacancy. Their jealousy parallels the animosity of "certain Chaldeans" toward "the Jews" in 3:8–12.

<span id="page-81-1"></span>The problem for the jealous leaders was that they could find no fault in Daniel to expose. His faithfulness was so constant and evident that they had no grounds on which to accuse him before the king. Their jealousy led them to agree, "We shall not find any ground for complaint against this Daniel unless we find it in connection with the law of his God." If Daniel's faithfulness was unwavering, they could use that faithfulness against him.

<span id="page-81-8"></span>6:6–9 The high officials and satraps conspired together and came to the king, who remained unaware of their plan. They addressed him with the common expression "O King Darius, live forever!" The leaders hoped to manipulate him unwittingly to facilitate Daniel's demise. They claimed that all the important people the king valued had agreed that a royal ordinance should be made concerning prayer: "Whoever makes petition to any god or man for thirty days, except to you, O king, shall be cast into the den of lions."

The nature of their request accomplished two goals. First, it flattered the king, as prayer would be made to him for thirty days, and such flattery increased the likelihood of his consent. For thirty days he would be the people's god! Second, by focusing on the matter of prayer, the leaders could use Daniel's faithfulness against him. They were confident that if Darius issued an order contrary to Daniel's devotion, Daniel would remain faithful to "the law of his God" (v. 5).

<span id="page-82-2"></span>The conspirators knew that an incentive for obedience might be necessary, so they suggested that violators "be cast into the den of lions." With the fear of death hanging over them, the people would comply.

The high officials and satraps insisted that Darius "establish the injunction and sign the document, so that it cannot be changed, according to the law of the Medes and the Persians, which cannot be revoked."32 What appealed to the leaders was the irrevocable nature of Medo-Persian injunctions; otherwise the king might change his mind, when he discovered that Daniel was a violator. The conspirators successfully manipulated Darius (v. 9); all they needed now was time for Daniel to violate this royal injunction.

<span id="page-82-5"></span><span id="page-82-4"></span>6:10 The law became public knowledge. Daniel's behavior is described with great detail, noting his knowledge of the law and his place and habit of prayer. First, Daniel "knew that the document had been signed." Either the king spoke directly to his leaders about it—since probably not all 120 satraps had been present for the meeting with Darius in verses 6–9—or Daniel found out indirectly from a royal representative.

Second, Daniel "went to his house where he had windows in his upper chamber open toward Jerusalem." Windows facing Jerusalem were a symbol of hope for return from exile. Solomon had prayed that if God's people were ever exiled and then repented "with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their enemies, who carried them captive, and [prayed] to you toward their land" (1 Kings 8:48), then God would hear from heaven and forgive them and grant them compassion (vv. 49–50). Daniel knew the curse of exile was temporary. Moreover, he knew that since Babylon had been conquered, the return was imminent.

<span id="page-82-6"></span><span id="page-82-1"></span><span id="page-82-0"></span>Third, facing Jerusalem in his upper room, Daniel "got down on his knees three times a day and prayed and gave thanks before his God, as he had done previously." During one of those previous times, Daniel had received the revelation of the seventy weeks (Dan. 9:1–3, 20–27), a revelation that would have strengthened his resolve during exile. "As he had done previously" shows that Daniel did not alter his behavior after finding out about the royal injunction. It is not specified how long Daniel had been practicing such prayerful devotion, but it is reasonable to assume he maintained such practice throughout his decades in this foreign land. No matter what ruler he served, no matter what empire was in power, no matter what rank he held, no matter how many friends or enemies he made, no matter how acceptable or risky his devotion, Daniel was a man of prayer.

<span id="page-82-3"></span><sup>32</sup> The "Medes and the Persians" (v. 8) is further textual testimony to the unity of Medo-Persia at this time in history.

<span id="page-83-6"></span><span id="page-83-2"></span><span id="page-83-1"></span>Daniel 6:10–13 is framed by an inclusio: Daniel violated the injunction by praying three times a day (v. 10), and the conspirers informed Darius that Daniel had violated the injunction by praying three times a day (v. 13).

<span id="page-83-3"></span>6:11 The conspirators knew where Daniel lived, and they agreed to go to his home and catch him praying to God. It would be difficult to universally enforce the new royal injunction regarding prayer, but the jealous leaders were not interested in the prayer habits of the masses. They cared only about Daniel. Since Daniel's habit was to pray three times a day with his windows open, the conspirers needed only to observe whether Daniel maintained his practice. Evidence of his thrice-daily prayer pattern would have been visible to onlookers below and, given his character, it was unlikely he would deny the charge.

<span id="page-83-5"></span>6:12–13 The high officials and satraps who had previously manipulated Darius now came to him and inquired whether they correctly understood the injunction. The king confirmed their understanding, insisting the injunction could not be revoked. The conspirators had the king right where they wanted him; it was time to expose Daniel as a lawbreaker: "Daniel, who is one of the exiles from Judah, pays no attention to you, O king, or the injunction you have signed, but makes his petition three times a day." They accused Daniel of knowingly ignoring not only the injunction but the king himself.

<span id="page-83-7"></span>6:14 The king's reaction may have surprised the accusers, who surely hoped that knowledge of betrayal would provoke rage and swift action. On the contrary, Darius "was much distressed and set his mind to deliver Daniel." He did not want Daniel to die, and he spent the rest of the day seeking a way to rescue him.

<span id="page-83-8"></span><span id="page-83-4"></span><span id="page-83-0"></span>6:15 The accusers would not tolerate the king's reluctance. Using words similar to verse 8, they reminded him that Medo-Persian ordinances could not be revoked, and Darius himself had already used the language of irrevocability (v. 12); despite his desire to spare Daniel, doing so would be going against "the law of the Medes and Persians."

<span id="page-83-9"></span>6:16–17 Bound by the wording of the royal injunction, Darius ordered that Daniel be cast into the lions' den. He told Daniel, "May your God, whom you serve continually, deliver you!" This statement recognized Daniel's devotion to God and expressed Darius's hope that the punishment would fail. Darius had kept his end of the matter by ordering Daniel, an exile from Judah now in his eighties, to be thrown to the lions. If Daniel's God happened to intervene and deliver the faithful servant, it was out of the king's hands.

To secure the lions' den, "A stone was brought and laid on the mouth" of it, and then Darius sealed it with his signet and the signet of the lords. No one would chance trying to rescue Daniel, and Daniel himself certainly could not escape: breaking the king's seal without authorization would warrant death.

<span id="page-84-6"></span>6:18–19 Darius returned to his palace and "spent the night fasting" and avoiding any diversions. His fasting was not for religious reasons; he was simply too overwhelmed to eat. His mind was occupied with Daniel's predicament, and nothing could distract him from these thoughts, not even sleep. Finally, at daybreak, Darius went to the den. His concern for Daniel was evident: he did not send a messenger but rushed there himself.

<span id="page-84-7"></span>6:20 Darius neared the lions' den and cried out in anguish to Daniel: "O Daniel, servant of the living God, has your God, whom you serve continually, been able to deliver you from the lions?" Darius knew that Daniel worshiped "the living God," yet he was unsure if Daniel's God had the power to deliver him from the lions. The issue of God's ability was previously voiced in the narrative of the three faithful friends of Daniel, who declared to Nebuchadnezzar, "Our God whom we serve is able to deliver us from the burning fiery furnace" (3:17). Chapters 3 and 6, each evoking God's ability to deliver his servant(s) from death, are paired in the Aramaic chiasm of the book, and furthermore, the two chapters are arranged chiastically, with each central section (3:16–18 and 6:18–20) reporting dialogue concerning God's ability to deliver.

<span id="page-84-8"></span><span id="page-84-1"></span><span id="page-84-0"></span>6:21–22 Daniel greeted the king and answered his question: "My God sent his angel and shut the lions' mouths, and they have not harmed me, because I was found blameless before him; and also before you, O king, I have done no harm."

<span id="page-84-10"></span><span id="page-84-2"></span>As in the deliverance of Daniel's three Jewish friends (3:25, 28), God had used an angel to rescue Daniel. The lions spared Daniel not because they lacked an appetite but because an angel shut their mouths (cf. Heb. 11:33). Daniel's lack of harm corresponded to his lack of blame: before God and before the king, Daniel had committed no act worthy of death in the lions' den.

<span id="page-84-9"></span><span id="page-84-5"></span>6:23 The king's distress (vv. 14, 18) gave way to exceeding gladness. The Judean exile had survived the night, as Darius had hoped, so the king ordered Daniel to "be taken up out of the den," much to the chagrin of the high officials and satraps who had conspired to put him there. When Daniel emerged, "no kind of harm was found on him, because he had trusted in his God." This degree of protection parallels the story of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, who emerged from the fiery furnace without singed hair, damaged cloaks, or the smell of smoke on them (3:27).

<span id="page-84-4"></span><span id="page-84-3"></span>It may seem that Darius violated his own royal injunction by removing Daniel, but in fact the king had followed the letter of the new law precisely. The injunction stipulated that violators would be cast into the den of lions (6:7, 12), but it did not instruct the king on what to do if the violator survived! Darius followed the law, and acted in response to a circumstance the law did not address. This whole ordeal demonstrated his commitment "to the law of the Medes and Persians" while at the same time displaying his authority as king.

Daniel's rising from the den is a picture of resurrection from the dead, just as Isaac's deliverance from near-sacrifice is described as a figurative resurrection by <span id="page-85-13"></span><span id="page-85-12"></span>the author of Hebrews (Heb. 11:19). The same concept is found in Jesus' interpretation of the story of Jonah (Matt. 12:40; cf. Jonah 2:1–10).

<span id="page-85-7"></span><span id="page-85-0"></span>6:24 Darius ordered Daniel's accusers to be thrown into the den of lions—"they, their children, and their wives." Their demise was an example of the justice we sometimes see in the OT (cf. Est. 7:7–10). They hoped Daniel would die in the lions' den, yet that fate was theirs instead. As soon as the accusers were thrown into the den, "The lions overpowered them and broke all their bones in pieces" before their bodies could even hit the ground! This carnage confirms that Daniel's protection was not due to any natural cause, such as any lion's inability or lack of appetite. His survival could be explained only by divine deliverance.

<span id="page-85-8"></span><span id="page-85-2"></span>6:25 Darius wrote a message to "all the peoples, nations, and languages that dwell in all the earth." Such universal language appeared earlier (3:4, 7, 29; 4:1) and indicated a comprehensive application of "Peace be multiplied to you" (6:25), a typical wish for peace. What came next would distinguish the king's decree from the other message he had written.

<span id="page-85-9"></span>6:26–27 Darius decreed, "In all my royal dominion people are to tremble and fear before the God of Daniel." The king was so impressed by God's intervention and his protection of Daniel that he wanted everyone to respond in a way he deemed appropriate: before a God who rescued his servant from lions, trembling and fear was warranted.

<span id="page-85-6"></span>Darius explained his new decree: "He is the living God, enduring forever; his kingdom shall never be destroyed, and his dominion shall be to the end." He had already called the Lord "the living God" (v. 20), and now he wanted everyone to know more about this deity. Since God endured forever, it made sense that his kingdom and dominion would last forever as well. It was significant that Darius an emperor, no less—acknowledged that God's kingdom would endure, implying that the Medo-Persian kingdom would not. Nebuchadnezzar had made similar statements about God's kingdom (4:3, 34).

<span id="page-85-10"></span><span id="page-85-4"></span>Elaborating on the reasons people should tremble and fear Daniel's God, Darius wrote, "He delivers and rescues; he works signs and wonders in heaven and on earth, he who has saved Daniel from the power of the lions" (6:27). The last phrase clarifies that Darius was not thinking of some abstract notion of deliverance. Instead, he had specifically in mind Daniel's deliverance from the den of hungry lions. Nebuchadnezzar had extolled God's power in rescuing Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego from the fiery furnace (3:28–29), and he also spoke of "signs" and "wonders" (4:3). In chapter 6, God continued displaying his mighty power, prevailing over the conspiracy of the high officials and straps, the concession of the reluctant king, and the appetite of savage beasts. All should fear and tremble before this mighty God.

<span id="page-85-11"></span><span id="page-85-5"></span><span id="page-85-3"></span><span id="page-85-1"></span>6:28 At or near the end of each narrative in chapters 1–6, at least one person is promoted or prospers in some way (table 1.6).

<span id="page-86-18"></span><span id="page-86-17"></span><span id="page-86-16"></span>It is noted specifically that Daniel prospered during "the reign of Darius and the reign of Cyrus the Persian" (6:28). These two names most likely refer to the same person (cf. comment on 5:31). Daniel was transported to Babylon as a teenager in 605 BC, and if the event of the lions' den occurred in 539, after the Medo-Persian Empire conquered the Babylonians, Daniel would have been in his eighties as he prospered during the reign of King Darius.

With the entirety of chapter 6 before us, at least twelve parallels can be discerned between it and the fiery furnace episode of chapter 3 (table 1.7).

## <span id="page-86-27"></span><span id="page-86-26"></span><span id="page-86-25"></span><span id="page-86-24"></span><span id="page-86-15"></span><span id="page-86-13"></span><span id="page-86-12"></span><span id="page-86-11"></span><span id="page-86-9"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-86-28"></span>Believing the truth of Peter's words may be challenging: "Rejoice insofar as you share Christ's sufferings, that you may also rejoice and be glad when his glory is revealed. If you are insulted for the name of Christ, you are blessed, because the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you" (1 Pet. 4:13–14). The people of God <span id="page-87-2"></span>have always faced opposition, and the cost of following God's will sometimes led to persecution even in the OT. In Daniel's case, he knew King Darius had signed a document forbidding prayer to anyone but the king for thirty days, and he knew that violating this injunction would result in death in the lions' den (Dan. 6:7–10). Yet he went home and prayed and "gave thanks before his God, as he had done previously" (v. 10).

<span id="page-87-3"></span>Daniel remained grateful to God, even though his disciplined piety was under assault by conspirators manipulating the king's ear. Daniel still had God's ear, and so he prayed. He would not permit a royal injunction to nullify his faithful intercession. God could not be manipulated or fooled, and he reigned sovereignly and completely over the Medo-Persian Empire.

<span id="page-87-0"></span>Daniel was committed to obeying God, even when that obedience conflicted with service in Darius's administration. After all, Daniel was the target of the conspiracy because of his reputation for faithfulness. The "high officials and the satraps" who "sought to find a ground for complaint against Daniel" sought in vain (v. 4). Daniel was not known for compromise. He was known for faithfulness, especially "in connection with the law of his God" (v. 5). As the apostle Peter wrote, if believers are going to suffer, let it be because of their identity as a follower of Christ and not because they committed any actual wrongdoing (1 Pet. 4:15–16).

<span id="page-87-9"></span><span id="page-87-6"></span><span id="page-87-4"></span><span id="page-87-1"></span>Christians should not presume that obedience will necessarily lead to earthly vindication as in the case of Daniel, who "prospered during the reign of Darius" (Dan. 6:28). But ultimate vindication will come. Some saints conquered kingdoms and quenched the power of fire and put foreign armies to flight (Heb. 11:33–34), but others were mocked and tortured and imprisoned and killed (vv. 35–36). Still, they will "rise again to a better life" (v. 35): they will be vindicated through resurrection from the dead.

<span id="page-87-8"></span><span id="page-87-7"></span><span id="page-87-5"></span>In the second century AD, when Polycarp faced martyrdom and received the command to identify Caesar as "Lord," his response was courageous and to the point: "Eighty-six years I have served Christ, and he never did me any wrong. How can I blaspheme my King who saved me?" Some believers may admire the boldness of Polycarp but doubt that they could ever take such a stand. But Christ is mighty to save and to sustain his saints. Courage like Polycarp's does not come by digging deep into our soul's recesses and mustering up bravado. Christ is our strength. He has grace for the weak and the wavering. He told his disciples, "When they deliver you over, do not be anxious how you are to speak or what you are to say, for what you are to say will be given to you in that hour. For it is not you who speak, but the Spirit of your Father speaking through you" (Matt. 10:19–20). We may think our weakness will undermine our witness, yet it is in weakness that God shows himself to be strong.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-90-0"></span>Daniel receives a vision of four beasts rising out of the sea, the fourth beast being more fearsome than the others, and its little horn evoking concern (7:1–8). Shifting from the sea to heaven, Daniel's vision continues with the Ancient of Days judging the fourth beast (vv. 9–12). Then "one like a son of man" receives everlasting dominion over all (vv. 13–14). An angel explains that the four beasts are kings and that the saints will receive an everlasting kingdom (vv. 15–18). Daniel learns more about the fourth beast and its little horn (vv. 19–27).

## <span id="page-90-7"></span><span id="page-90-4"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-90-5"></span><span id="page-90-3"></span><span id="page-90-2"></span><span id="page-90-1"></span>II.A'. Vision of Four Kingdoms Preceding an Eternal Kingdom (7:1–28)
	- 1. Daniel Sees a Vision of Four Beasts from the Sea and Two Figures in Heaven (7:1–14)
		- a. Daniel Sees Four Beasts like Animals Who Exercise Dominion (7:1–8)
			- b. Daniel Sees the Ancient of Days Judge the Fourth Beast (7:9–12)
		- a'. Daniel Sees One like a Son of Man Who Receives Everlasting Dominion (7:13–14)
	- 2. An Angel Interprets Elements of the Vision for Daniel (7:15–28)
		- a. Daniel Is Alarmed by What He Sees (7:15–16)
			- b. The Angel Interprets the Beasts and the One like a Son of Man (7:17–18)
				- c. Daniel Inquires More about the Fourth Beast and Its Horns (7:19–22)
			- b'. The Angel Elaborates on the Fourth Beast and Its Horns (7:23–27)
		- a'. Daniel Is Alarmed by What He Thinks (7:28)

In the first half of the chapter (vv. 1–14), sections a and a' provide an important contrast: the four beasts have dominion, but the one like a son of man is given *everlasting* dominion. The event connecting those two realities is the Ancient of Days' judgment. In a heavenly courtroom scene, God gives a verdict of destruction against the blasphemous beast (b).

<span id="page-90-6"></span>In the second half of the chapter (vv. 15–28), Daniel is alarmed at both the beginning (a) and the end (a') of the interpretation (b and b'). This inclusio means Daniel is bothered by both the vision he *sees* (a; vv. 1–14) and the interpretation he *hears* (a'; vv. 17–27). When the angel speaks about the vision (b), he identifies the

<span id="page-91-17"></span><span id="page-91-16"></span><span id="page-91-14"></span><span id="page-91-13"></span>four beasts as four kings (v. 17) and the "one like a son of man" as the saints who will receive an everlasting kingdom (v. 18). When the angel speaks again (b'), he elaborates on the fourth beast (v. 23), its ten horns and the little horn that arose after them (vv. 24–25), the judgment against the fourth beast (v. 26), and the saints' everlasting kingdom (v. 27). The angel's brief interpretation (b) is followed by a longer one (b') because of Daniel's inquiry about the fourth beast and its horns (c).

<span id="page-91-18"></span><span id="page-91-15"></span><span id="page-91-12"></span><span id="page-91-11"></span>When the two chiasms of chapter 7 are compared, the center of each (vv. 9–12 and vv. 19–22) involves judgment on the fourth beast by the Ancient of Days. In the section of interpretation (vv. 15–28), only in verses 19–22 does the title "Ancient of Days" appear. This confirms the writer's intention to match the center of the second chiasm (vv. 19–22) with the center of the first (vv. 9–12).

<span id="page-91-10"></span><span id="page-91-2"></span>This chapter begins with a third-person point of view, but verse 2 to the end is from Daniel's first-person view. His record of the vision and interpretation forms the final Aramaic chapter of the book, and in the chiastic arrangement of the Aramaic section (chs. 2–7), it is significant to note that chapter 7 matches chapter 2 with its vision of four kingdoms followed by everlasting dominion. This match will influence the following argument about what the four beasts mean: the four beasts (ch. 7) and metals (ch. 2) refer to the same four kingdoms:

<span id="page-91-5"></span><span id="page-91-4"></span><span id="page-91-3"></span><span id="page-91-1"></span>Daniel 2–Vision of Four Kingdoms Preceding an Eternal Kingdom Daniel 3–Divine Deliverance from Death Daniel 4–Judgment on Royal Arrogance Daniel 5–Judgment on Royal Arrogance Daniel 6–Divine Deliverance from Death Daniel 7–Vision of Four Kingdoms Preceding an Eternal Kingdom

<span id="page-91-20"></span><span id="page-91-9"></span><span id="page-91-6"></span>Chapter 7 is also a transition to the exclusively visionary section of the book (chs. 7–12). Daniel was the sole recipient of these visions, with no report of a king receiving them first. They incorporate symbols, metaphors, numbers, and cosmic activity. This last half of the book consists of four visions: chapters 7, 8, 9, and 10–12. Each vision occurred in a different year (cf. 7:1; 8:1; 9:1; 10:1) and location (cf. 7:1; 8:27; 9:3, 21; 10:4), but they did not occur chronologically following the events at the end of chapter 6. Rather, the four visions in chapters 7–12 occurred *concurrently with* the events of chapters 1–6 and are given in chronological order (table 1.8). (Note, once again: we are assuming that Darius and Cyrus were the same person.)

<span id="page-91-22"></span><span id="page-91-21"></span><span id="page-91-19"></span><span id="page-91-7"></span>

| The Vision   | The Year of the Vision                                 | Where Daniel Was       |
|--------------|--------------------------------------------------------|------------------------|
| Daniel 7     | "the first year of Belshazzar king of Babylon" (7:1)   | In his house (7:1)     |
| Daniel 8     | "the third year of the reign of King Belshazzar" (8:1) | In his house (8:27)    |
| Daniel 9     | "the first year of Darius the son of Ahasuerus" (9:1)  | In his house (9:3, 21) |
| Daniel 10–12 | "the third year of Cyrus king of Persia" (10:1)        | By a river (10:4)      |

<span id="page-91-8"></span><span id="page-91-0"></span>TABLE 1.8: Years and Locations of the Visions of Daniel 7–12

<span id="page-92-15"></span><span id="page-92-0"></span>Since the content of chapter 7 most closely matches the vision in chapter 2, it is worth considering how the remaining visions of the book (chs. 8–12) relate to each other. The visions in chapter 8 and in chapters 10–12 seem to form a frame around chapter 9 in an A-B-A' pattern:

- <span id="page-92-17"></span><span id="page-92-13"></span>A. Daniel 8
	- B. Daniel 9
- <span id="page-92-18"></span>A'. Daniel 10–12

This chiasm is evident as the visions in chapter 8 and in chapters 10–12 address Medo-Persia and Greece and are narrower in scope than the visions in chapters 2 and 7 (which address four kingdoms). Also separating chapters 8–12 from chapter 7 is their language: chapters 8–12 are in Hebrew, while chapter 7 is in Aramaic. Thus, not only do the Aramaic chapters form a chiasm (2–7), but the Hebrew vision-chapters form a chiasm as well (8–12).33

<span id="page-92-9"></span><span id="page-92-3"></span><span id="page-92-1"></span>Chapter 7 does double duty by both completing the Aramaic section of the book (chs. 2–7) and transitioning to the exclusively visionary portion (chs. 7–12). This placement suggests it may be the book's most important chapter. Moreover, when all of the visions and riddles of the book are laid out (chs. 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10–12), they are seven in number, with chapter 7 in the center. This chapter has been described as "the key to understanding the major themes that run throughout the book."34 In the canonical sweep of Scripture, the significance of Daniel 7 is evident in the frequency with which the NT characters/writers make reference to it.35

#### <span id="page-92-6"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-92-11"></span><span id="page-92-10"></span>7:1 Daniel had a vision in "the first year of Belshazzar king of Babylon," around 550 BC. Daniel had been in Babylon for more than fifty years and would have been in his late sixties when he received this vision. The vision consists of activity in the sea (vv. 1–8) and in heaven (vv. 9–14). A situation with the fourth beast (vv. 7–8) provokes God's response (vv. 9–14). In verses 1–8, Daniel gives the year of the vision and then describes four beasts that rose up from the sea. The fourth beast receives the most attention (vv. 7–8).

<span id="page-92-12"></span><span id="page-92-4"></span>Belshazzar was the last king of Babylon; the night of his blasphemous banquet was both the night of his death and the night the Medo-Persians seized control of Babylon (5:30–31). In the Aramaic chiasm of the book (chs. 2–7), a comparison of chapters 2 and 7 reveals that the vision in the former occurred under Nebuchadnezzar (2:1), the first king of Judah's exile, while the vision in the latter occurred under Belshazzar (7:1), the last Babylonian king of Judah's exile (cf. 5:31). Thus, during the first and last Babylonian kings of Judah's exile, God gave visions of

<span id="page-92-16"></span><span id="page-92-14"></span><span id="page-92-5"></span><span id="page-92-2"></span><sup>33</sup> For confirmation of the chiasm of Daniel 8–12, see Greidanus, *Preaching Christ from Daniel*, 20; Steinmann, *Daniel*, 25. Goldingay says, "It is with chapter 8 that chapters 10–12 have most detailed points of contact. Reminiscences of almost every verse of chapter 8 reappear here" (*Daniel*, 283).

<span id="page-92-7"></span><sup>34</sup> Steinmann, *Daniel*, 332. He calls Daniel 7 "the pivot around which the entire book turns."

<span id="page-92-8"></span><sup>35</sup> The appendix of one common Greek NT lists about sixty places where Daniel 7 is either cited or alluded to.

four earthly kingdoms. Other visions in the book pertain to only some of these kingdoms.

<span id="page-93-2"></span><span id="page-93-1"></span>In chapter 7, even though Belshazzar was king, God gave the vision directly to Daniel (contrast with 2:1 and 4:5, where the king received the dream and subsequently sought interpretation, which Daniel provided). Daniel saw the vision at night, "as he lay in his bed" (cf. 7:2, 7, and 13 for reference to "vision by night" or "night visions"). He then "wrote down the dream," which formed the record of the dream found in verses 2–28.36

<span id="page-93-12"></span><span id="page-93-6"></span><span id="page-93-5"></span><span id="page-93-0"></span>7:2–3 Daniel saw "four winds of heaven" stirring up the great sea. These were winds from the north, south, east, and west. The "sea" was classically viewed as a realm of chaos and disorder (cf. Job 38:8–10; Ps. 104:6–7), and now that realm was pulsing with activity. The winds roused four different beasts from the waters. The origin of the beasts is not contradicted by the interpretation in Daniel 7:17: "These four great beasts are four kings who shall arise *out of the earth*." The beasts arising from the waters in verse 2 were merely a picture of the actual kings, who naturally arose out of the earth, as verse 17 attests. The images of "sea" and "earth" are not contradictory but complementary.37

<span id="page-93-9"></span>Daniel wrote about these beasts in the subsequent verses (vv. 4–8). Each beast was numbered and described, and then some activity is described (table 1.9).
