	- b. Gabriel Explains His Reason for Coming (9:22–23)
	- c. Gabriel Gives a Message about Seventy Sevens (9:24–27)
- (1) Gabriel Lists the Six Results of the Seventy Sevens (9:24)
- (2) Gabriel Speaks of the First Seven Sevens (9:25a)
- (3) Gabriel Speaks of the Next Sixty-Two Sevens (9:25b)
- (4) Gabriel Speaks of the Seventieth Seven (9:26–27)

<span id="page-120-7"></span>As in some earlier sections of the book, we find Daniel praying, encountering a heavenly figure, and receiving revelation about future events. Yet chapter 9 consists mostly of prayer (vv. 4–19). Gabriel's message (vv. 24–27), which usually receives the most attention because of its fascinating timeline, is only a few verses long. The importance of the chapter is evident in its placement between the visions of chapters 8 and 10–12, forming an A-B-A' pattern. The chiasm is evident as the visions in Daniel 8 and 10–12 both address the Medo-Persian and Greek kingdoms.56 In the Hebrew vision-chapters, Daniel 9 is featured in the center.

- <span id="page-120-4"></span><span id="page-120-2"></span>A. Daniel 8
	- B. Daniel 9
- <span id="page-120-8"></span>A'. Daniel 10–12

The prophecy of chapter 9 warrants central placement in Daniel's literary design, for it foretells the famous "seventy sevens" (cf. vv. 24–27) that reached fulfillment in the redemptive work of the Messiah and the judgment on the Jerusalem temple. The vision of chapter 9, therefore, covers the period from 539 BC (a year before the Jews returned to Jerusalem) to AD 70 (the destruction of the temple during the Roman Empire).

## *Comment*

<span id="page-120-5"></span><span id="page-120-1"></span>9:1–2 The events of chapter 9 took place in "the first year of Darius the son of Ahasuerus, by descent a Mede, who was made king over the realm of the Chaldeans." This king conquered the Babylonians (cf. 5:31) and was the same person as Cyrus the Persian. He "was made king" by God, who raises up and brings down rulers according to his will (cf. 2:21). The Medo-Persians conquered Babylon in 539 BC, the same year as Gabriel's message to Daniel in this chapter.

<span id="page-120-0"></span>During the first year of Darius's reign (539 BC), Daniel "perceived in the books the number of years that, according to the word of the Lord to Jeremiah the prophet, must pass before the end of the desolations of Jerusalem, namely, seventy years." The "books" Daniel was reading must have included books of the OT, for he mentioned one in particular: Jeremiah. Daniel believed God had spoken to Jeremiah and that what Jeremiah recorded was accurate and authoritative revelation. Daniel called Jeremiah a "prophet," thus recognizing his status as God's mouthpiece.

<span id="page-120-6"></span>The exile is described here as "the desolations of Jerusalem" (Dan. 9:2), and Daniel learned of the amount of time that had to pass before the exile would

<span id="page-120-3"></span><sup>56</sup> To cite Goldingay again, "It is with chapter 8 that chapters 10–12 have most detailed points of contact. Reminiscences of almost every verse of chapter 8 reappear here" (*Daniel*, 283).

end and the desolations would be over. Jeremiah had said, "This whole land shall become a ruin and a waste, and these nations shall serve the king of Babylon seventy years. Then after seventy years are completed, I will punish the king of Babylon and that nation, the land of the Chaldeans, for their iniquity, declares the Lord, making the land an everlasting waste" (Jer. 25:11–12).

<span id="page-121-6"></span><span id="page-121-3"></span><span id="page-121-2"></span>Daniel 1:1–7 reported the arrival of King Nebuchadnezzar in Jerusalem and his deportation of Daniel to Babylon, in 605 BC. Using the time frame of the opening verse of chapter 9, Daniel had now been in exile approximately sixty-six years (605–539). He was confident, therefore, that the exile would soon end. This truth stirred Daniel to prayer.

<span id="page-121-5"></span><span id="page-121-4"></span>9:3 We have already seen Daniel as a man of prayer (2:17–23; 6:10–11), but only once previously was one of his prayers recorded (2:20–23, a prayer of praise and thanksgiving). Now the reader encounters a second recorded prayer, the longest prayer of the book, covering most of the chapter (9:3–19).

<span id="page-121-8"></span><span id="page-121-0"></span>Daniel prayed with his "face to the Lord," which means he prayed toward Jerusalem—demonstrating, no doubt, his longing for return from exile. At the dedication of the temple, Solomon had prayed for God to hear from heaven if his captive people repented from the heart and prayed toward the Promised Land (1 Kings 8:46–50). Because Daniel believed what he read in Scripture, he prayed toward Jerusalem. His heart longed for restoration and was grieved over the sin of Israel. His "pleas for mercy" (Dan. 9:3) would be made explicit in verses 4–19. To represent the contrition of the Jews in exile, Daniel fasted and put on "sackcloth and ashes," outward signs of repentance (cf. 2 Kings 19:2; Isa. 37:1; Lam. 2:10; Jonah 3:5–7).

<span id="page-121-13"></span><span id="page-121-12"></span><span id="page-121-10"></span><span id="page-121-7"></span><span id="page-121-1"></span>9:4–19 Most of Daniel's prayer was confession. He asserted that God's people had sinned, done wrong, acted wickedly, rebelled, ignored the prophets, committed treachery, disobeyed God's voice, and transgressed the law (vv. 5–7, 10–11) and thus deserved open shame and the law's curse (vv. 7–8, 11–14). On the other hand, God had demonstrated steadfast love, had sent ample warnings through faithful prophets, could dispense mercy and forgiveness, had kept his promise of judgment, was righteous in all his works, was remembered for his mighty power in delivering Israel from Egypt, and alone could hear the pleas of his penitent people (vv. 4, 6, 9, 12, 14–15, 19).

<span id="page-121-11"></span><span id="page-121-9"></span>9:4 Daniel confessed the sin of his people. He began his prayer by describing the Lord as "the great and awesome God, who keeps covenant and steadfast love with those who love him and keep his commandments." God not only does great things; he himself is great and worthy of worship and awe. God's character displays a covenant-keeping zeal, and keeping covenant is synonymous with showing steadfast love to his people. This verse also refers to "those who love him and keep his commandments," and the idea of keeping (or failing to keep) what God has commanded will resurface throughout the chapter.

<span id="page-122-3"></span>9:5–6 Daniel's opening admissions intentionally overlap: "We have sinned and done wrong and acted wickedly and rebelled." This rebellion was manifested by their "turning aside from your commandments and rules." Of all nations in the world, God had chosen Israel to be his people and to receive his law. He loved them and entered into covenant with them, yet they disobeyed his commands. This rebellion of privileged and chosen Israel against God was devastating and unconscionable.

<span id="page-122-4"></span>God had sent mouthpieces to exhort his people and warn them of coming judgment, but his people had not "listened to your servants the prophets, who spoke in your name to our kings, our princes, and our fathers, and to all the people of the land" (v. 6). The ministry of the prophets was sufficient testimony that God was not silent while the people strayed. The voices of Isaiah, Hosea, Jeremiah, Ezekiel—and many others!—declared to the people, "Thus says the Lord!" God's oracles were given even to kings, showing the comprehensiveness of his warnings and commands. The eventual exile showed that he held his people accountable to the oracles they had not heeded.

<span id="page-122-9"></span><span id="page-122-5"></span>9:7–8 There was a gulf between the holy God and his sinful people: "To you, O Lord, belongs righteousness, but to us open shame, as at this day." God did and does what is right, but the Judeans did what was wrong, and thus the open shame they received was warranted. They had become a byword among the nations (v. 16), for God had given them into the hands of their enemies. Shame was shared by *everyone* ("to the men of Judah, to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and to all Israel") *everywhere* ("those who are near and those who are far away, in all the lands to which you have driven them"). The shame they bore was "because of the treachery that they have committed against you," treachery Daniel had outlined in verses 5–6.

<span id="page-122-6"></span>9:9–10 The imminent end of exile confirmed God's undeserved mercy to the Jews. To God belonged "mercy and forgiveness," while Israel's unworthiness of these gifts was clear in that "we have rebelled against him and have not obeyed the voice of the Lord our God by walking in his laws, which he set before us by his servants the prophets." Daniel's logic was flawless: God spoke through the prophets, so when the people rejected the message of the prophets, they rejected God. By disobeying the prophets, God's people did not walk "in his laws" but instead walked contrary to them. The people of Israel had not deserved such a merciful season of warnings, but God had been longsuffering and gracious. When the Persians conquered the Babylonians and permitted a return to the Promised Land, the people would again see that God's mercy far exceeded their sin and guilt.

<span id="page-122-8"></span><span id="page-122-7"></span><span id="page-122-2"></span><span id="page-122-1"></span><span id="page-122-0"></span>9:11 Daniel asserted that all Israel had transgressed God's law, and thus "the curse and oath that are written in the Law . . . have been poured out upon us, because we have sinned against him." Since God's "prophets" were called "servants" in verse 10, calling Moses God's "servant" implied his prophetic status as well (cf. Deut. 18:18). The "curse" and "oath" of the Law refers to such passages as Leviticus 26:14–45 and Deuteronomy 28:15–68 that outline the judgments for disobedience—including <span id="page-123-3"></span>judgment by exile (cf. Lev. 26:33–39; Deut. 28:36–41, 49–52). The people of Israel did not keep the commands of the covenant, so God did what he had promised: he applied the curses of the covenant.

<span id="page-123-4"></span>9:12 The calamity of the exile was "great" because, "under the whole heaven there has not been done anything like what has been done against Jerusalem." Certainly calamitous events had befallen other nations as well, but what happened against Israel was the result of covenant violations against the God who had shown steadfast love and had been remarkably longsuffering, but who now may seem to have forsaken his people.

<span id="page-123-5"></span><span id="page-123-2"></span>9:13 Daniel again appealed to the "Law of Moses" as the basis according to which "all this calamity has come upon us" (cf. Lev. 26:14–45; Deut. 28:15–68). In their state of exile, the people needed divine favor, and since only Yahweh could grant such grace, they should implore him for it. The result of "gaining insight by your truth" would be the ability to walk in wisdom; the time immediately preceding the exile had been characterized by much foolishness.

<span id="page-123-6"></span>9:14 Yahweh had stored up the curse of the covenant, ready at the appointed time to be poured out on his disobedient people. He finally brought it upon Israel due to the fact that he "is righteous in all the works that he has done, and [Israel had] not obeyed his voice." God was righteous; the people were unrighteous. Part of God's expressing his righteousness was his covenant-keeping, curse-outpouring act of expelling his people from the Promised Land.

9:15 Israel did not defy just anyone; they defied the very God who had redeemed them from Egyptian captivity. The exodus loomed large in the history of Israel as a pivotal event, one to which later writers looked back for hope, reassurance, and empowerment. They needed to remember. At the same time, this reminder placed Israel's rebellion in an awful light, for they should have responded to God's redemptive act with single-minded devotion and a zealous covenantal love that did not fizzle out at the first experience of weariness or impatience (Ex. 32:1–6).

<span id="page-123-10"></span><span id="page-123-7"></span><span id="page-123-1"></span><span id="page-123-0"></span>God had "made a name" for himself (Dan. 9:15) when he delivered Israel from Egypt (cf. Josh. 2:10–11) with his "mighty hand" (cf. Ex. 15:6, 12, 16; 32:11). Since God associated his name with Israel, however, their rebellion had now dishonored his name. Later in the prayer, however (Dan. 9:18–19), Daniel will appeal to God's associating his name with Israel as the reason why he should now show mercy: if God's name was dishonored by Israel's rebellion, what might it mean for his name if they were to be restored and revived!

<span id="page-123-9"></span><span id="page-123-8"></span>9:16 Verse 15 was a transition from confession to petition, and verses 16–19 are all petition. Affirming God's righteousness, Daniel asked him to turn away his anger from Jerusalem, "your holy hill." God's people were experiencing shame and condescension from pagan nations. Now that Medo-Persia was in power, Daniel pleaded for God to change things so that Israel might no longer be a "byword."

<span id="page-124-2"></span>9:17 Daniel called upon Yahweh to "listen to the prayer of your servant and to his pleas for mercy." Despite living in a foreign land, Daniel had not served other gods. He had remained Yahweh's faithful "servant." Daniel had served in the royal court, but he had not allowed that service to compromise his devotion to God. Daniel described the action he hoped God would take: "make your face to shine upon your sanctuary, which is desolate." The notion of God's shining face recalls Numbers 6:24–26, the blessing of Aaron to the people of Israel: "The Lord bless you and keep you; the Lord make his face to shine upon you and be gracious to you; the Lord lift up his countenance upon you and give you peace." The high priest had important roles in God's temple ("your sanctuary"; Dan. 9:17). The Lord would be acting for his own sake because, according to Numbers 6:27, his name was on the people of Israel. A restored nation and temple would certainly be for the people's sake too, although in a lesser sense, because ultimately what mattered most was the glory of God among the nations.

<span id="page-124-7"></span><span id="page-124-4"></span><span id="page-124-3"></span>9:18 Again Daniel prayed for Yahweh to "incline your ear and hear," and to "Open your eyes and see our desolations, and the city that is called by your name." Daniel's plea for God to hear and see echoes Hezekiah's prayer in 2 Kings 19:16: "Incline your ear, O Lord, and hear; open your eyes, O Lord, and see; and hear the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to mock the living God." The greater context of Hezekiah's prayer illumines the reason for his request: "The kings of Assyria have laid waste the nations and their lands and have cast their gods into the fire, for they were not gods, but the work of men's hands, wood and stone. Therefore they were destroyed. So now, O Lord our God, save us, please, from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you, O Lord, are God alone" (2 Kings 19:17–19). Just as the Assyrians had brought devastation in Hezekiah's day, so the Babylonians had brought devastation in Daniel's day. Hezekiah pleaded for Yahweh to act so that the kingdoms of the world would know who the true God was, and Daniel believed the same would be true if Yahweh now restored his people from a foreign land.

<span id="page-124-8"></span><span id="page-124-6"></span><span id="page-124-5"></span>Daniel did not call upon God to see and hear "because of our righteousness" (Dan. 9:18). Already in the prayer Daniel had boldly confessed that Israel had rebelled, had committed wickedness, and was worthy only of open shame for its treachery (vv. 4–8). Daniel knew God was merciful, however. And on that basis he made his request. Wrath removed would be mercy. A land once again filled with worshipers would be mercy. City walls erected would be mercy. The temple brimming with God-honoring sacrifices would be mercy. Daniel prayed for mercy because he believed what Scripture taught about God (cf. Ex. 34:6–7). God could show mercy whenever he willed to do so (Ex. 33:19).

<span id="page-124-9"></span><span id="page-124-1"></span><span id="page-124-0"></span>9:19 The end of Daniel's prayer was also its climax. Several repetitions should be noted: the call for God to hear and pay attention, the call for God to act for his own sake, and the language of the city and people being called by his name. Daniel prayed specifically for forgiveness, which would lead to the shining of God's face and the removal of wrath. God had appointed a temporary period of captivity, and Daniel pleaded that there be no delay in ending it!

<span id="page-125-3"></span><span id="page-125-2"></span><span id="page-125-0"></span>9:20–21 Something happened during Daniel's prayer. He had been praying a confession and plea on behalf of Israel, asking God to show mercy to Jerusalem, "the holy hill of my God," and while he was speaking the angel Gabriel appeared "in swift flight." Gabriel is called "the man" because he appeared in that form. Daniel had seen Gabriel earlier, "in the vision at the first," which may refer to 8:16–17 or possibly 7:16. Gabriel arrived "at the time of the evening sacrifice," which does not imply that Jewish sacrifices were being offered in Babylon but merely indicates an evening encounter. The notion of "evening sacrifice" also recalls the vision of chapter 8, where in verse 14 the evening and morning sacrifices were in view. Sacrifice will also play a role in the revelation Gabriel will give in 9:27.

<span id="page-125-9"></span><span id="page-125-4"></span><span id="page-125-1"></span>9:22–23 Gabriel made clear why he had come: "I have now come out to give you insight and understanding." This understanding was what Daniel had been seeking by reading Jeremiah and by praying for mercy. As Daniel had begun to pray, "a word went out" from God, and Gabriel now came bearing that word. This word will be explained in the "vision" of verses 24–27.57

9:24–27 For many readers, 9:24–27 is the most challenging section of the book and one of the most difficult in the Bible. According to Greidanus, "Reading commentaries on the last four verses of Daniel 9 is akin to entering a bewildering maze: so many choices of ways to take, so many blind alleys and dead ends."58 We will seek to carve as straight a path as possible through the maze.

<span id="page-125-8"></span><span id="page-125-7"></span>In verse 24 Gabriel listed six purposes of a prophesied "seventy sevens" (cf. ESV mg.), and in verses 25–27 he addressed this time period, in three parts: seven sevens (v. 25a), then sixty-two sevens (v. 25b), and finally a seventieth seven (vv. 26–27). The seventieth seven received the most elaboration of any of the sevens. Table 1.13 summarizes the breakdown of the sevens and the corresponding interpretation that will be suggested in the subsequent comments:

|                       | The First Seven                                                                                                        | The Next Sixty-Two                                                                                                      | The Seventieth                                                                                                             |
|-----------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| From when<br>to when? | From Cyrus's decree<br>permitting exiles<br>to return, to the<br>rebuilding of the<br>temple and city of<br>Jerusalem. | From the days when<br>the temple and city of<br>Jerusalem were rebuilt,<br>to the arrival of Jesus<br>the Anointed One. | From the redemptive work of<br>Jesus' death on the cross, to<br>the judgment of Jesus on the<br>Jerusalem temple in AD 70. |

<span id="page-125-6"></span>TABLE 1.13: The "Sevens" of Daniel 9:24–27

<span id="page-125-5"></span>9:24 Gabriel announced, "Seventy weeks are decreed about your people and your holy city." The objects of God's decree are the Jews and Jerusalem. The number

<sup>57</sup> Cf. Greidanus, *Preaching Christ from Daniel*, 330.

<sup>58</sup> Ibid., 285.

"seventy" is essential for the remaining verses, which divide it threefold, so understanding the source of this number is vital to a proper interpretation.

The number "seventy" appeared earlier in chapter 9 when the prophet was reading in the book of Jeremiah about the desolations of Jerusalem ending after "seventy years" of captivity (v. 2). Gabriel's message played upon the "seventy" and promised "seventy sevens" or "seventy weeks." And if the "seventy" in Gabriel's message played on the "seventy" from Jeremiah 25:11–12 (cf. Dan. 9:2), it is reasonable to assume the "sevens/weeks" played on the years of Daniel 9:2 as well. A decree of "seventy sevens/weeks" probably meant 490 years (70 × 7).

<span id="page-126-3"></span>Another issue is whether we should take the 490 years literally or symbolically. Observe first that even though Jeremiah wrote about seventy years of captivity, the Jews were actually in exile less than seventy years. If Gabriel's message then used that number, perhaps we should expect a figurative or symbolic meaning rather than applying 490 with strict literalism, for not even the number seventy was applied with the sort of precision often expected today. Further pointing us in the direction of nonliteral interpretation of the "seventy sevens" is the probable source of the "sevens." Seven is a number of completion and perfection, and Leviticus 25:8–12 most likely informed Daniel's understanding of Gabriel's message:

<span id="page-126-2"></span>You shall count seven weeks of years, seven times seven years, so that the time of the seven weeks of years shall give you forty-nine years. Then you shall sound the loud trumpet on the tenth day of the seventh month. On the Day of Atonement you shall sound the trumpet throughout all your land. And you shall consecrate the fiftieth year, and proclaim liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants. It shall be a jubilee for you, when each of you shall return to his property and each of you shall return to his clan. That fiftieth year shall be a jubilee for you; in it you shall neither sow nor reap what grows of itself nor gather the grapes from the undressed vines. For it is a jubilee. It shall be holy to you. You may eat the produce of the field.

<span id="page-126-6"></span><span id="page-126-5"></span><span id="page-126-0"></span>In Leviticus 25 a multiplication of "seven weeks of years" (v. 8) resulted in fortynine years. The fiftieth year was jubilee, a time of freedom and climactic observance. That Gabriel's message should be understood in light of the jubilee passage in Leviticus 25 is evident by the first division he gives to Daniel in Daniel 9:25: seven sevens/weeks. Next, sixty-two more sevens are given (v. 25b), and then the climactic seven/week receives the most attention (vv. 26–27). The seventy sevens in verse 24 denote jubilee; if seven sevens in Leviticus 25:8 led to jubilee, then seventy sevens in Daniel 9:24 is a tenfold and ultimate jubilee!

<span id="page-126-7"></span><span id="page-126-4"></span><span id="page-126-1"></span>The reason for a tenfold jubilee is evident in the six results Gabriel listed: God decreed the seventy sevens "to finish the transgression, to put an end to sin, and to atone for iniquity, to bring in everlasting righteousness, to seal both vision and prophet, and to anoint a most holy place" (v. 24). The mention of transgression, sin, and iniquity is significant in light of Daniel's prayer, which confessed Israel's sin (vv. 4–15) and pleaded for mercy and forgiveness (vv. 16–19). God was saying to Daniel, "I will take care of the sin. Atonement will be accomplished." This future work would bring in everlasting righteousness, a permanence that worshipers of Yahweh longed for. "Vision and prophet" probably refers to God's revelation until this atonement was accomplished. Once sin had been dealt with in this future redemptive work, prior revelation would be fulfilled, and eclipsed, by the jubilee event God would accomplish. If understood as a hendiadys (two words conveying a single concept), "vision and prophet" may be understood as a "prophetic vision" and may have Jeremiah's prophecy of return from exile in view. Gabriel was giving Daniel insight into how Jeremiah's words would ultimately be "sealed" or "confirmed." Part of God's atoning plan included anointing a "most holy place" or, probably more accurately, "most holy *one*." No anointing was ever reported for Solomon's temple or the rebuilt temple under Ezra. An individual, not a structure, is meant. The work of this anointed individual would appear shortly in the breakdown of the seventy sevens (vv. 25–27).

<span id="page-127-8"></span><span id="page-127-7"></span><span id="page-127-6"></span><span id="page-127-3"></span>Given the stupendous effects of the seventy sevens, it is worth noting that the first sixty-nine sevens do not mention the kind of effects listed in verse 24. The seventieth seven, though, includes an anointed one being cut off, destruction of city and sanctuary, and desolations that have been decreed (v. 26). Furthermore, a covenant will be made and sacrifices will end (v. 27). The six remarkable outcomes in verse 24, therefore, would not be accomplished gradually throughout the first sixty-nine weeks. They would come to pass because of what takes place in the seventieth seven.

<span id="page-127-5"></span>9:25a Gabriel began telling Daniel what he should understand: "From the going out of the word to restore and build Jerusalem to the coming of an anointed one, a prince, there shall be seven weeks." The next "sixty-two weeks" (which will be dealt with in the following subsection) specify that Jerusalem "shall be built again with squares and moat, but in a troubled time." The first "seven" and next "sixty-two" weeks seem to deal with the whole span of time envisioned in verse 25, which encompasses the "going out of the word to restore and build Jerusalem to the coming of an anointed one, a prince."

<span id="page-127-4"></span><span id="page-127-2"></span><span id="page-127-1"></span><span id="page-127-0"></span>As history unfolded, "the going out of the word to restore and build Jerusalem" turned out to be the decree of Cyrus permitting the return of the Jews in 538 BC. Having conquered Babylon in 539, Cyrus released the Jewish exiles the following year. Isaiah reported the Lord's plan to use Cyrus in this manner: "I am the Lord, . . . who says of Cyrus, 'He is my shepherd, and he shall fulfill all my purpose'; saying of Jerusalem, 'She shall be built,' and of the temple, 'Your foundation shall be laid'" (Isa. 44:24, 28). Later, Ezra recorded, "In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the Lord by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfilled, the Lord stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia, so that he made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom and also put it in writing" (Ezra 1:1), and the proclamation specified a return to Jerusalem to "rebuild the house of the Lord, the God of Israel—he is the God who is in Jerusalem" (v. 3).

<span id="page-128-3"></span><span id="page-128-1"></span>Arguments for dates earlier or later than 538 BC fail to account for the specific texts in Isaiah and Ezra linking the fulfillment of Jeremiah's words to Cyrus's decree for a return from exile. When Daniel received this message from Gabriel, Daniel was in "the first year of Darius" (Dan. 9:1), whom we have equated with Cyrus the Persian (cf. comment on 5:31), and thus Daniel received the revelation from Gabriel shortly before the royal decree was given. Daniel would not only see the Babylonian captivity come to an end; he would also live through the inauguration of the "seventy sevens" that led ultimately to a tenfold jubilee when the anointed one would come and put an end to sin. The anointed one is mentioned before the "seven weeks" (v. 25a) and again after the "sixty-two weeks" (v. 26). This suggests that the arrival, and atoning work, of the anointed one was the grand goal of the "seventy sevens," but he would not come until the sixty-two weeks were complete (cf. v. 26).

<span id="page-128-6"></span><span id="page-128-0"></span>If the "seven weeks" (v. 25a) began at the decree of Cyrus in 538 BC, a literal calculation would put their completion around 489. Because no significant biblical or prophetic event occurred in that year, the "seven weeks" were probably not meant as a literal forty-nine years. Rather, we should see the "seven weeks" (or "seven sevens") as alluding to Leviticus 25:8, where Yahweh told Moses, "You shall count seven weeks of years, seven times seven years, so that the time of the seven weeks of years shall give you forty-nine years." The first "seven weeks" in Daniel 9:25a, therefore, prepared Daniel and the reader for an expectation of jubilee. The "seven sevens," begun in 538 BC, probably extended through the rebuilding of the temple and the city walls during the ministries of Ezra and Nehemiah. The temple was completed and rededicated in 515, while the city wall was finished in 444.

9:25b Referring to Jerusalem, Gabriel told Daniel that "for sixty-two weeks it shall be built again with squares and moat, but in a troubled time." There is no indication that a gap of time should be inserted between the first seven sevens and the next sixty-two. Since verse 26a says the "anointed one" would come after the sixtytwo sevens, clearly the first seven did not culminate with the anointed one's work.

<span id="page-128-7"></span>Relating the sixty-two sevens (v. 25b) to the seven (v. 25a) is not as difficult as may be initially thought. The sevens are consecutive and uninterrupted. The period of sixty-two sevens probably extended from the time of Nehemiah to the time of Jesus (the anointed one). As with the first seven sevens, we should not press the sixty-two sevens with strict literalism with the intent to specify exactly 434 years. It is a round number, symbolic of the time period from Nehemiah to Jesus.

<span id="page-128-5"></span><span id="page-128-4"></span><span id="page-128-2"></span>There may be further significance to the "sixty-two sevens" of verse 25b. The only other time the number "sixty-two" appeared in the book of Daniel was in 5:31, where it says Darius conquered Babylon, "being about sixty-two years old." Strengthening the connection between 9:25b and 5:31 is the fact that the episode of chapter 9 occurred during "the first year of Darius the son of Ahasuerus, by descent a Mede" (9:1a), and the only prior occurrence of "Darius the Mede" was in 5:31.

<span id="page-129-2"></span><span id="page-129-1"></span><span id="page-129-0"></span>Darius/Cyrus would decree freedom for the captives in Babylon. Cyrus was a type of the Messiah, for the latter would also give freedom to captives—to captives of sin and death, out of the deepest exile by way of a new and greater exodus. The book of Isaiah gave prior biblical precedent for viewing Cyrus typologically: he is God's anointed shepherd in Isaiah 44:28–45:1. Cyrus would deliver the captive Israelites as their political savior. In the same section of Isaiah foretelling the work of Cyrus (Isaiah 40–55), God promised a spiritual savior, a suffering servant who would take Israel's iniquities and bear their punishment (Isa. 42:1–9; 49:1–7; 52:13–53:12). The liberation through Cyrus would one day be surpassed by a far greater liberation through the suffering servant, Jesus Christ, whose work of atonement would be an ultimate jubilee. Perhaps, then, the age of Cyrus when he conquered Babylon ("sixty-two"; cf. Dan. 5:31) served as the basis for the symbolic period leading to the antitype of Cyrus, the anointed one who would suffer in the place of sinners and, in doing so, would conquer sin and death through his resurrection.

<span id="page-129-3"></span>For "sixty-two weeks" the city of Jerusalem (including its temple) would remain rebuilt "with squares and moat, but in a troubled time" (9:25b). Gabriel's words probably denote that from Nehemiah to the Messiah, the city would remain standing. The "squares and moat" were mentioned probably to indicate complete restoration. Gabriel did not elaborate on the "troubled time," but it may refer to the atrocities committed by the Greek Empire under Antiochus IV Epiphanes (cf. ch. 8).

<span id="page-129-9"></span><span id="page-129-4"></span>9:26–27 These verses are best understood in an A-B-A'-B' pattern. They tell about the seventieth week, which received the most attention in Gabriel's message to Daniel:

- <span id="page-129-7"></span>A. "And after the sixty-two weeks, an anointed one shall be cut off and shall have nothing." (v. 26a)
	- B. "And the people of the prince who is to come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary. Its end shall come with a flood, and to the end there shall be war. Desolations are decreed." (v. 26b)
- <span id="page-129-10"></span><span id="page-129-8"></span>A'. "And he shall make a strong covenant with many for one week, and for half of the week he shall put an end to sacrifice and offering." (v. 27a)
	- B'. "And on the wing of abominations shall come one who makes desolate, until the decreed end is poured out on the desolator." (v. 27b)

<span id="page-129-11"></span>In this structure, A and A' refer to the same event: the sacrificial work of the anointed one. Sections B and B' each have a single event in mind as well: the destruction of Jerusalem and its temple. Below we will contend that the seventy sevens of chapter 9 reach fulfillment in the vicarious death of Jesus Christ and in the destruction of the Jerusalem temple.

<span id="page-129-6"></span><span id="page-129-5"></span>9:26 Gabriel's next words, "after the sixty-two weeks," indicate the seventieth week is now in view. He declared that "an anointed one shall be cut off and shall <span id="page-130-8"></span><span id="page-130-3"></span><span id="page-130-2"></span>have nothing." This "anointed one" is the prophesied Messiah, a figure fulfilled by Jesus, the "Christ" (i.e., the anointed one; cf. Luke 2:11). Some interpreters have suggested that the "prince who is to come" (Dan. 9:26b) is the future Antichrist.59 There could be no greater contrast between potential referents! We should opt for understanding both figures as "Christ," however, making the "anointed one" and "prince" identical. First, when Gabriel mentioned "anointing" two verses earlier, it was in relation to a most holy person who would end sin and make atonement (v. 24), and the apposition "a prince" after "an anointed one" in verse 25 suggests we should equate the titles. Second, it is unlikely that the "prince" of verse 25 and the "prince" of verse 26 refer to different people. More naturally, the reader should understand "prince" to have the same referent in verses 25 and 26: he is the Messiah, not the Antichrist. Third, no time gap is specified before the seventieth week, yet many Antichrist views require a gap of thousands of years. Such a passing of time has no textual warrant in Daniel 9. Just as we should not project a time gap between the seven sevens and the sixty-nine sevens, so we should not project a gap between the sixty-ninth and seventieth sevens.

<span id="page-130-7"></span><span id="page-130-6"></span><span id="page-130-1"></span><span id="page-130-0"></span>The prediction that this anointed one would be "cut off and shall have nothing" was fulfilled when Jesus died on the cross. He was taken outside the city gate and crucified, abandoned by his disciples and forsaken by the Father (Matt. 26:31; 27:60; Heb. 13:12–13). The seventieth week of Daniel, then, included the redemptive work of Jesus. Given the six remarkable goals of Daniel 9:24, this "cutting off" of the anointed one would be the means of finishing transgression, ending sin, atoning for iniquity, ushering in everlasting righteousness, confirming the prophetic vision, and anointing a most holy person.

A prophecy concerning Jerusalem's city and temple came next: "The people of the prince who is to come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary. Its end shall come with a flood, and to the end there shall be war. Desolations are decreed." As we have seen, the "prince who is to come" is the same "prince" (or "anointed one") as in verse 25: the Messiah, Jesus. This means "the people of the prince" were the Jews. The prophecy may seem outrageous, then, when it says the Jews will destroy Jerusalem and the temple! After the redemptive work of Jesus, the temple was destroyed in AD 70, and the Jews had a role in it. The Romans, led by Titus, were involved in the destruction, but the transgression of the Jews—particularly their rejection of the Messiah—led to the Messiah's judgment on their temple and city, just as they were complicit when the first temple was destroyed in Daniel's own day. The account of this event given by Josephus, in *The Wars of the Jews*, "is adequate historical proof that the destruction of Jerusalem was entirely the fault of the Jewish people, just as Dan 9:26b predicts."60

<span id="page-130-5"></span><span id="page-130-4"></span>Jesus prophesied the temple's destruction (Matt. 24:1–2), and said that his contemporary generation would not pass away before it happened (v. 34). Jerusalem would be surrounded by armies, which meant "its desolation has come near"

<sup>59</sup> Cf. Miller, *Daniel*, 268.

<sup>60</sup> Peter J. Gentry, "Daniel's 70 Weeks and the New Exodus," *SBJT* 14/1 (2010): 39.

<span id="page-131-10"></span>(Luke 21:20). Gabriel's words were fulfilled in AD 70: the sanctuary's end came like a flood, with war to the end, for God had decreed its desolation. The imagery "with a flood" pictures the total destruction of the Romans' victory over Jerusalem.

<span id="page-131-3"></span>9:27 Having looked at the A and B sections of Daniel 9:26, we will now see how Gabriel's words take us through the same events again, first the redemptive work of the Messiah and then the judgment on Jerusalem and the temple (A' and B', respectively).61

Speaking of the anointed one, the prince who would come, Gabriel declared, "He shall make a strong covenant with many for one week, and for half of the week he shall put an end to sacrifice and offering." The "one week" in view is the seventieth seven. Gabriel was referring to the Messiah's redemptive work as taking place in the climactic period of the "seventy sevens." Gabriel's words did not predict a temporary covenant. In conjunction with prophecies in Isaiah and Jeremiah, this "strong covenant" was probably the new covenant (cf. Isa. 53:10–12; Jer. 31:31–34). The book of Hebrews explains that the anointed one's vicarious offering has put an end to the sacrificial system (Heb. 9:11–10:25).

<span id="page-131-11"></span><span id="page-131-2"></span><span id="page-131-0"></span>The Messiah would make this covenant with "many" (Dan. 9:27; cf. Isa. 53:11– 12), which seems to denote not universality but diversity:62 the new covenant would include Jewish and Gentile believers. Jesus alluded to Daniel 9:27 and Isaiah 53 when he said of the cup at the last supper, "Drink of it, all of you, for this is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins" (Matt. 26:27–28). The Son of Man "came not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many" (Matt. 20:28).

<span id="page-131-9"></span><span id="page-131-8"></span><span id="page-131-7"></span>Gabriel prophesied that "for half of the week he shall put an end to sacrifice and offering." This specification meant the seventieth week would involve more than just the Messiah's work of redemption. As Daniel 9:27b prophesies, the seventieth week would also involve the Messiah's work of judgment on Jerusalem. The seventieth seven, then, is divided in half, with the first three and a half years referring to the work of redemption. Just as the seventieth week in verse 26 consisted of the anointed one being cut off (v. 26a) and the city and sanctuary being destroyed (v. 26b), so verse 27 recapitulates these two ideas and divides the seventieth week in half.

<span id="page-131-5"></span><span id="page-131-4"></span>Likely the second three and a half years is reflected implicitly in the language of verse 27b: "On the wing of abominations shall come one who makes desolate, until the decreed end is poured out on the desolator."63 In keeping with the A-B-A'-B' structure of verses 26–27, this prophecy would be fulfilled in the destruction of the

Jerusalem temple in AD 70. A desolator would cause abominations until his own destruction occurred. "Wing" may mean "extremity," and thus extreme abominations would be in view (cf. 11:31; 12:11), brought about by a swiftly attacking army.

<span id="page-132-2"></span><span id="page-132-1"></span><span id="page-132-0"></span>Jesus referred to "the abomination of desolation spoken of by the prophet Daniel" (Matt. 24:15), and surely Jesus had in mind Daniel 9:26–27. Significant for interpreting 9:26–27 is Matthew's observation that Jesus was addressing the coming destruction of Jerusalem and the temple (Matt. 24:15). In Luke 21:20 Jesus referred to Jerusalem's approaching "desolation" by the (Roman) armies. The "desolator" was probably a corporate way of depicting the Roman legions, or perhaps Titus (the Roman general) himself fulfilled this role. Jesus prophesied that such days would be "days of vengeance, to fulfill all that is written. . . . For there will be great distress upon the earth and wrath against this people. They will fall by the edge of the sword and be led captive among all nations, and Jerusalem will be trampled underfoot by the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled" (Luke 21:22–24). Jesus also specified the time frame: "Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all has taken place" (Luke 21:32). In AD 70 the temple was destroyed. The seventieth seven—a period encompassing the work of redemption for the many, as well as the work of judgment against Jerusalem and the temple—had reached completion.

<span id="page-132-4"></span><span id="page-132-3"></span>Peter Gentry provides a perfect summary:

The vision of Daniel's Seventy Weeks, then, can be explained simply. It refers to a period of seventy sabbaticals or periods of seven years required to bring in the ultimate jubilee: release from sin, the establishment of everlasting righteousness and consecration of the temple. During the first seven sabbaticals the city of Jerusalem is restored. Then for sixty-two sabbaticals there is nothing to report. In the climactic seventieth week, Israel's King arrives and dies vicariously for his people. Strangely, desecration of the temple similar to that by Antiochus Epiphanes in the Greek Empire is perpetrated by the Jewish people themselves, resulting in the destruction of Jerusalem. These events are fulfilled in the person of Jesus of Nazareth. He is the coming king. His crucifixion is the sacrifice to end all sacrifices and the basis of the New Covenant with the many.64

## *Response*

Daniel prayed to a sovereign God, and so do we. Daniel's theology viewed God as ruler of all things, superintendent of kingdoms and their rulers, and propeller of history toward appointed goals. But for Daniel the all-encompassing sovereignty of God did not negate the role of prayer. If anything, the sovereignty of God confirmed Daniel's confidence in praying! Also motivating Daniel's prayer was his knowledge of God's mercy and forgiveness. God reconciles sinners to himself, and such a gracious God is worthy of our trust and appeal.

<sup>64</sup> Gentry, "Daniel's 70 Weeks and the New Exodus," 41.

Although Daniel and his friends were exiled in Babylon, he did not interpret his circumstances as meaning that God was not in control or good or worthy of trust. Daniel's God-centered and Bible-saturated theology prepared him for these decades of exile, and he believed God's promise-keeping pattern would not fail. Believers should prepare for suffering and trial and hardship by learning and believing the truths about God from his Word, as its theology shapes how we view our circumstances instead of our circumstances shaping the convictions we hold.

If God is sovereign, we should pray. If God sovereignly grants mercy and forgiveness, we should pray. If God keeps his promises both to save and to judge, we should pray. He is worthy of our allegiance. His Word is worthy of our meditation and reflection. Daniel's reading of Jeremiah helped prompt certain things he prayed, and the content and aim of his prayer were shaped by God's Word. We should devote ourselves to the Bible with the hope that it transforms how we think and pray about God, our lives, and the world around us. Even in Babylon, Daniel operated from a biblical worldview.

<span id="page-133-1"></span>We have an even greater reason than Daniel did to hope in God and be faithful to him: the prophecy of seventy sevens, which lay in his future, was fulfilled in our past through the sin-atoning and sacrifice-ending work of Jesus, the anointed one. God made promises, and those promises came to pass. As Paul put it, all God's promises are "Yes" in Jesus (2 Cor. 1:20). Jesus not only accomplished redemption on the cross for unworthy sinners; he also judged the temple of Jerusalem in AD 70. Desolations were poured out, and the prophecy of the seventy sevens reached complete fulfillment.

The gospel message of Jesus' person and work is a word of jubilee, of liberation from the power of sin and its wages. Through a new and greater exodus, Jesus led his people from the greatest captor and deepest exile. Because he conquered, we conquer. His victory and vindication become ours by grace through faith. If God has lavished such grace and drenched sinners with such mercy, we should trust him with our uncertainties, our anxieties, our fears, our weaknesses, our present, and our future. If this sovereign God, who holds the whole world in his hands, is both perfectly good and incomparably wise, then the suffering and exilic status of the saints is not because of his carelessness, ignorance, cruelty, or confusion. God is on his throne and does all things well.

<span id="page-133-0"></span>When we feel the urge to worry, we should pray instead. When we feel complaint rising within and about to pour forth, we should pray. Jesus prayed, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?" (Matt. 27:46), but no suffering saint will ever be in such a situation. We are forgiven because he was forsaken in our place. When the night seems at its darkest hour, God is still our light. His wrath no longer burns against us, and his grace in us works in such a way that trials test and refine our faith. The cross is the place where our sin was finished, our iniquity drowned in atoning blood. As pilgrims bound for the Promised Land of the new heavens and new earth, we can even now say, "It is well with my soul."

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-135-5"></span><span id="page-135-4"></span><span id="page-135-3"></span>Weakened by weeks of fasting and prayer, Daniel is overwhelmed when a glorious being appears to him (10:2–3, 8–9). God had heard Daniel's prayer and sent the heavenly messenger, but the messenger had battled three weeks with the spiritual prince of Persia (10:11–13). Finally, however, the messenger arrives with a word of revelation concerning the future of God's people and earthly kingdoms (10:14; 11:2–12:3). Daniel becomes mute and weak at the messenger's words (10:15–18) and needs strength and reassurance (10:18–19). The heavenly figure then discloses the fact of present and future spiritual warfare (10:20–11:1).

## <span id="page-135-8"></span><span id="page-135-7"></span><span id="page-135-6"></span>*Section Outline*

<span id="page-135-2"></span>III.A'. Medo-Persian and Greek Kingdoms (10:1–12:13)

- 1. Daniel Sees a Vision of a Heavenly Figure (10:1–11:1)
	- a. Daniel Receives a Vision and Revelation in the Third Year of King Cyrus (10:1)
	- b. Daniel Is Mourning and Fasting when He Sees a Heavenly Figure (10:2–7)
		- (1) Daniel Is Mourning and Fasting for Three Weeks (10:2–3)
		- (2) Daniel Has a Vision of a Man Clothed in Linen (10:4–6)
		- (3) Daniel's Men Do Not See the Vision and Flee (10:7)
	- c. Daniel Falls to the Ground and Is Strengthened by the Heavenly Figure (10:8–11:1)
		- (1) Daniel Is Strengthened by the Heavenly Figure (10:8–14)
		- (2) Daniel Is Strengthened Again by the Heavenly Figure (10:15–17)
		- (3) Daniel Is Strengthened a Third Time by the Heavenly Figure (10:18–11:1)

<span id="page-135-9"></span><span id="page-135-1"></span><span id="page-135-0"></span>The final section of Daniel (10:1–12:13) is the longest of the book, almost eighty verses. Its unity is clear in that the heavenly figure who appears to Daniel (10:1–11:1) and speaks a word of revelation about the future (11:2–12:3) also gives closing instructions and hope (12:4–13). From its first to its last verse, we must hold Daniel 10–12 together as a single unit. Its content pertains mainly to future Greek kings and, most importantly, to a blasphemous king who would one day arise: Antiochus IV Epiphanes. Given the fact that the visions of chapters 8–12 are <span id="page-136-8"></span><span id="page-136-5"></span>arranged in an A-B-A' format, we should note that the message of chapters 10–12 parallels chapter 8, though in a much lengthier fashion.

<span id="page-136-14"></span><span id="page-136-11"></span>Daniel 10:1–11:1 is the first main section of chapters 10–12. After mourning and fasting, Daniel encounters a heavenly figure who appears to him (10:2–7) and strengthens him (10:8–11:1). The encounter was probably a preincarnate appearance of the Son of God. Much of 10:1–11:1 is spent on the debilitating and overwhelming effects of the encounter on Daniel. Probably only one heavenly figure is in view throughout this encounter.

### *Comment*

<span id="page-136-9"></span>10:1 Daniel's final vision in the book occurred in "the third year of Cyrus king of Persia," approximately 536 BC.65 This was the Medo-Persian ruler who conquered Babylon and granted the Jews a return to their land in 538. If Daniel had been deported as a young teenager in 605, he would have been in his eighties in 536. The mention of "Belteshazzar" recalls the fact that Daniel had been renamed according to the name of Nebuchadnezzar's god (1:7; 4:8).

<span id="page-136-15"></span><span id="page-136-7"></span><span id="page-136-3"></span>Chapter 10 begins with third-person narration: "A word was revealed to Daniel, who was named Belteshazzar." The "word" refers primarily to the content of 11:2–12:3. The author tells the reader that "the word was true" (reliable) and concerned "a great conflict." The section 11:2–12:3 will describe this coming conflict in great detail. The assertion that Daniel "understood the word and had understanding of the vision" is placed at the beginning of the chapter in light of what follows. Daniel's understanding would be limited: with the help of the heavenly figure, Daniel would know that the word concerned the future and foretold coming conflicts, that God's people would be wrapped up in these conflicts, and that the wicked would be judged and the saints vindicated.

<span id="page-136-10"></span>10:2–3 The narration shifts to the first person: "In those days I, Daniel, was mourning for three weeks." He expressed his mourning by abstaining from meat and wine ("delicacies") as well as from personal maintenance ("nor did I anoint myself") for those three weeks. Oil was part of daily hygiene, and after a period of mourning was completed, the mourner would resume the use of oil on his head and body (cf. 2 Sam. 14:2; Isa. 61:3). Fasting from meat and wine probably meant he subsisted on water and other food.66 In light of the time noted in Daniel 10:4 ("the twentyfourth day" of Nisan), Daniel's three-week fast would have involved abstaining from meat and wine during Passover, which was Nisan 14–15 (cf. Ex. 12:1–6).

<span id="page-136-13"></span><span id="page-136-12"></span><span id="page-136-1"></span><span id="page-136-0"></span>10:4–6 On the twenty-fourth day of Nisan, Daniel "was standing on the bank of the great river (that is, the Tigris)." The only other mention of that river in the OT

<span id="page-136-6"></span><span id="page-136-4"></span><span id="page-136-2"></span><sup>65</sup> The vision of chapter 9 was set in the *first* year of that king, assuming Darius and Cyrus are the same person. 66 The notion of abstaining from meat and wine may be meant to recall the first chapter of the book, where, after arriving in Babylon, Daniel rejected meat and wine from the king's table (Dan. 1:8–15). But since 10:3 specified that he abstained from meat and wine for three weeks, he apparently ate and drank such fare on earlier and later occasions. In chapters 1 and 10, therefore, when he abstained from meat and wine for a period of time, it was for a specific spiritual reason.

<span id="page-137-0"></span>is in Genesis 2:14, a connection that may be important due to the Adamic experience Daniel will have later in this chapter.

<span id="page-137-11"></span><span id="page-137-7"></span>Beside this river Daniel beheld "a man clothed in linen, with a belt of fine gold from Uphaz around his waist" (Dan. 10:5). This first description concerns the figure's apparel. The man was clothed literally in "linens," and elsewhere in the OT the plural "linens" occurs in Ezekiel 9–10 (cf. 9:2–3, 11; 10:2, 6–7), where a glorious angelic figure is also described. The location "Uphaz" occurs in Jeremiah 10:9, where it is again mentioned as a source of fine gold. The golden sash (or belt) around the waist appears on one other person in Scripture: the risen and exalted Christ as he appears to the apostle John in the book of Revelation (1:13).

<span id="page-137-17"></span><span id="page-137-8"></span><span id="page-137-5"></span><span id="page-137-3"></span>Daniel shifted his focus from the priestly figure's attire to its appearance. He saw a body like beryl, a face like lightning, eyes like torches, arms and legs like burnished bronze, and a voice like the sound of a multitude. The term translated "beryl" could also refer to yellow jasper. The high priest wore this gem on his breastplate (Ex. 28:20), and it appeared in the garden of Eden as well (Ezek. 28:13). The figure's face appeared glorious, majestic, even frightening. Lightning often accompanied a theophany (cf. Ex. 20:18), which may suggest divinity here in Daniel 10. The flaming eyes denoted a piercing gaze and all-encompassing vision. The arms and legs appeared strong, and the "sound of a multitude" indicated a powerful and mighty voice (cf. Ezek. 1:24).

<span id="page-137-10"></span><span id="page-137-9"></span><span id="page-137-6"></span><span id="page-137-2"></span>By way of identifying this figure, note that Daniel has never described what an angel wore or looked like (cf. 7:16; 8:16–17; 9:21). The description of 10:5–6, therefore, is unprecedented if the figure is an angel. Furthermore, according to 9:21, the figure Daniel encountered in 7:16 was Gabriel, the figure in 8:16 is called Gabriel, and in 9:21 the bearer of revelation is again Gabriel. Significantly, there is no identification of the figure in 10:5–6 as Gabriel.

<span id="page-137-15"></span><span id="page-137-14"></span><span id="page-137-4"></span><span id="page-137-1"></span>According to 10:20–21, the figure who appeared to Daniel in verses 5–6 was a warrior. While not identified as Gabriel, the figure was clearly not Michael, for he spoke of "Michael, your prince," in verse 21. Possibly the heavenly figure in verses 5–6 was the angel of Yahweh. Since the angel of Yahweh may be rightly understood as a divine figure (cf. Gen. 16:7–11; Ex. 3:2–6; Judg. 2:1; 6:11–14; 13:3–22), Daniel was encountering not a mere angelic messenger but the preincarnate Son of God. If this was the preincarnate second person of the Trinity, John's use of Daniel 10:5–6 in Revelation 1:14–15 is most appropriate, because John encountered the risen Jesus: "His eyes were like a flame of fire, his feet were like burnished bronze, refined in a furnace, and his voice was like the roar of many waters." Knowing the book of Daniel, John described Jesus by alluding to Daniel 10:5–6. Such usage may be sufficient to identify the figure in 10:5–6 as the divine Son of God.

<span id="page-137-16"></span><span id="page-137-13"></span><span id="page-137-12"></span>10:7 Daniel was not alone by the Tigris River; there were other men with him. Yet "I, Daniel, alone saw the vision," and the men did not. But they knew something supernatural was afoot, so "they fled to hide themselves." In Acts 9:3–7, Saul also <span id="page-138-11"></span>experienced an encounter that his companions did not fully share. Interestingly, it was the risen Jesus whom Saul encountered (Acts 9:4–5; cf. 22:9–11).

<span id="page-138-0"></span>10:8–9 As the sole seer of the vision, Daniel lost his strength and radiant appearance, and the encounter filled him with fear. The sound of the words sent him into a deep sleep, with his face to the ground. If the Tigris River and the image of beryl already evoked the garden of Eden, the depiction of Daniel in a deep sleep would surely remind the reader of Adam (Gen. 2:21). Earlier, in the vision of chapter 8, Daniel had fallen into a deep sleep and had to be awakened by the one he encountered (Dan. 8:18). Daniel's reaction in 10:8–9 was more severe and extreme, however, than in any previous vision encounter with a heavenly being, and this strong reaction cohered with the overwhelming presence of a divine person.

<span id="page-138-7"></span><span id="page-138-3"></span><span id="page-138-2"></span>10:10–11 The figure touched Daniel and propped him up on shaking limbs. With weeks of fasting behind him, Daniel was already weakened, and now this theophany proved difficult to endure. This scene is similar to what the apostle John, who wrote of encountering the exalted Christ, experienced centuries later: seeing Christ, John fell down as though dead, and Jesus touched him in response (Rev. 1:17).

<span id="page-138-10"></span><span id="page-138-5"></span>The figure spoke words of reassurance to Daniel. As in Daniel 9:23, he was assured of God's love. The figure had "been sent" to speak the forthcoming revelation (11:2–12:3), so Daniel needed to stand up and receive it.67 And, after hearing the words of reassurance, Daniel rose, still trembling.

<span id="page-138-8"></span>10:12 The heavenly figure told Daniel to "fear not," for God had heard his prayers. Daniel's "words" of prayer had probably continued for the entire three weeks of mourning. The heavenly figure was God's answer to those persistent prayers.

<span id="page-138-9"></span><span id="page-138-4"></span><span id="page-138-1"></span>10:13–14 Daniel's encounter with this heavenly figure didn't occur until three weeks after he had started praying, because of the messenger's spiritual engagement with the "prince of the kingdom of Persia," who had "withstood [him] twenty-one days." "Prince" refers at times to an earthly ruler (cf. 9:6), but here a spiritual being is meant. "Of the kingdom of Persia" is consistent with the idea that kingdoms or nations have presiding angels (cf. Deut. 4:19; 32:8). The "prince of the kingdom of Persia" was probably a demonic angel who tried to prevent the answer to prayer. Nevertheless, Daniel's prayer was a factor, as seen by the overlapping time period: Daniel had been mourning and praying for three weeks, and the heavenly figure who appeared to him had been contending with the "prince of . . . Persia" for twenty-one days.

Apparently a demonic spirit had sought to intervene in what God was doing on earth, so we must consider what significant events were taking place during

<span id="page-138-6"></span><sup>67</sup> In Trinitarian terms, we understand in the NT that the Father sends the Son and the Son obeys the Father (cf. John 5:19–23). Reading this relationship into scenes like Daniel 10, it is possible to conceive of the heavenly figure as "sent" by the Father to Daniel as the preincarnate Son of God. With this lens in place, the fact that the figure is "sent" should not be used to nullify the plausibility of the figure's divine status.

<span id="page-139-2"></span><span id="page-139-1"></span>the period of Daniel's prayer (536 BC). In 538 BC the king of Medo-Persia (Cyrus/ Darius) allowed captive Jews to return to their land, and many did so (Ezra 1–2). But those who returned and commenced a rebuilding of the temple experienced opposition (Ezra 3–4), and unfortunately the rebuilding stopped. It would take the ministries of Haggai and Zechariah to spur on the project to completion. In the third year of Cyrus, then, a period of discouragement set in for the former exiles, and not just for them but for Daniel as well. Perhaps Daniel had heard that the returnees were not rebuilding the temple, and so his abiding concern for Jerusalem and God's people (Dan. 9:1–19) led him to mourn, fast, and pray.

<span id="page-139-4"></span><span id="page-139-0"></span>But no spiritual opposition could succeed against God's plan. His will would be done on earth as it was in heaven. Just as the angel of Yahweh was involved in the success of the Israelites who were once captive to Egypt but headed to the Promised Land as liberated people (Ex. 32:34; 33:2; Josh. 5:13–15), this figure would ensure victory for those who were once captive to Babylon. This new exodus could not be thwarted.

<span id="page-139-13"></span><span id="page-139-12"></span><span id="page-139-11"></span><span id="page-139-7"></span>The figure conversing with Daniel reported, "Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me, for I was left there with the kings of Persia" (Dan. 10:13). In the OT, Michael is mentioned by name only in the book of Daniel (cf. 10:21; 12:1), while in the NT he is named in the books of Jude and Revelation (Jude 9; Rev. 12:7–11). In Jude 9 Michael is called "the archangel." If the archangel Michael came to assist the heavenly figure who appeared to Daniel, then that figure was probably superior to Michael, a rank that further supports identifying the figure of Daniel 10:5–6 as the angel of Yahweh (as which we will subsequently refer to him). Michael would be helpful in the battle against the spiritual prince of Persia because of his role as "the great prince who has charge of your people" (12:1). This further substantiates understanding the conflict (10:13) as involving the nation of Israel, and the present difficulty facing the nation was probably their rebuilding project that had faced opposition and then had ceased.

<span id="page-139-5"></span>The angel's report that "I was left there with the kings of Persia" (10:13) may indicate he had prevailed over spiritual opposition throughout the reigns of multiple Persian kings. The warfare had reached a peak at this point, however. Perhaps Michael was handling the spiritual opposition while the angel of Yahweh appeared to Daniel in answer to prayer. The heavenly figure came to give understanding about "what is to happen to your people in the latter days. For the vision is for days yet to come" (10:14). The revelation in 11:2–12:3 encompassed distant events that would involve Israel.

<span id="page-139-9"></span><span id="page-139-8"></span><span id="page-139-6"></span>10:15–17 When Daniel heard that something would happen to his people in the latter days, he turned his face toward the ground "and was mute," again showing a physical reaction to what the figure said (cf. vv. 8–9, 11). Then "one in the likeness of the children of man touched my lips" (v. 16), enabling him to speak (cf. Isa. 6:7).

<span id="page-139-10"></span><span id="page-139-3"></span>A disputed issue is whether this "one in the likeness of the children of man" (Dan. 10:16) is the same figure who appeared in verses 5–6. Possibly the one who <span id="page-140-18"></span><span id="page-140-10"></span><span id="page-140-7"></span><span id="page-140-4"></span>two notions found in verse 13 connecting the reader to the figure of verses 5–6.

<span id="page-140-5"></span><span id="page-140-0"></span>Daniel admitted to the heavenly being, "O my lord, by reason of the vision pains have come upon me, and I retain no strength" (v. 16). The distress of what Daniel had heard and seen once again left him severely weak (cf. v. 8). He confessed that he was too weak to converse with the figure, for he had no strength, nor even any breath. The address "my lord" is common in the OT, but other contextual factors may suggest a specific allusion to Joshua 5:14. In that scene, Joshua said "my lord" upon encountering the angel of Yahweh, fell down with his face to the ground, and referred to himself as the angel's "servant." Note that in Daniel 10:16–17, the prophet referred to the heavenly figure as "lord" and himself as a "servant," and multiple times Daniel put his face to the ground (vv. 9, 15). If Daniel indeed encountered the angel of Yahweh in chapters 10–12, this provides one further connection to Joshua 5:14, for Joshua met the angel as well.

<span id="page-140-14"></span><span id="page-140-13"></span><span id="page-140-12"></span><span id="page-140-6"></span><span id="page-140-3"></span><span id="page-140-2"></span>10:18–19 Having already touched Daniel's lips (v. 16), the person in the vision touched Daniel again to strengthen him (v. 18; cf. v. 10). Never had an encounter with an angel left Daniel so debilitated and weakened (cf. 7:16; 8:17–18; 9:21), and this extremely vulnerable and distraught condition further supports the idea that Daniel had encountered a divine figure.

<span id="page-140-9"></span><span id="page-140-8"></span><span id="page-140-1"></span>The figure once again assured Daniel of God's love (10:19; cf. v. 11) and commanded him to "fear not" (cf. v. 12). For the first time he pronounced "peace be with you" and called Daniel to "be strong and of good courage" (v. 19). This language (especially the combination of "peace" and "fear not") may recall Gideon's encounter with the angel of Yahweh: "Peace be to you. Do not fear; you shall not die" (Judg. 6:11–23). In the NT, Jesus pronounced peace to his disciples on multiple occasions (Luke 24:36; John 20:19, 21, 26). When the heavenly figure had touched Daniel for the third time, Daniel was strengthened and said, "Let my lord speak, for you have strengthened me" (Dan. 10:19). The revelation would come in 11:2–12:3, but first the heavenly being had a question and answer for Daniel (10:20–11:1).

<span id="page-140-20"></span><span id="page-140-19"></span><span id="page-140-17"></span><span id="page-140-16"></span><span id="page-140-15"></span><span id="page-140-11"></span>10:20 The angel of Yahweh asked a rhetorical question: "Do you know why I have come to you?" According to verse 12 he had come in response to Daniel's prayer, and according to verse 14 he had come to reveal aspects of the future to Daniel. He added in verse 20, "I will return to fight against the prince of Persia; and when I go out, behold, the prince of Greece will come." Apparently the spiritual opposition would continue, and the role of this warrior would be integral to the success of God's plan. That this speaker referred to returning to fight the prince of Persia

<span id="page-141-4"></span>indicates he was identical to the one who spoke in verse 13, the man-like figure from verses 5–6.

The "prince of Greece" probably referred—like the "prince of the kingdom of Persia" in verse 13—to the evil demonic spirit over that earthly kingdom. Spiritual forces would continue warring in unseen ways, and the effects of those battles would have earthly consequences. The day would come when Greece would conquer Medo-Persia (cf. 8:7, 20–21).

<span id="page-141-5"></span><span id="page-141-1"></span>10:21 The heavenly figure prefaced the imminent revelation by saying, "I will tell you what is inscribed in the book of truth." Nowhere else in the Bible is the phrase "book of truth" used. It was probably equivalent to God's unwavering plan for the future, a book no one may open but into which God would occasionally grant insight or understanding. Part of what the book of truth disclosed was this: "There is none who contends by my side against these except Michael, your prince." Michael the archangel was called "your prince," referring to the angel presiding over Israel. He contended beside the angel of Yahweh in spiritual warfare.

<span id="page-141-6"></span><span id="page-141-2"></span>11:1 The heavenly figure reported, "In the first year of Darius the Mede, I stood up to confirm and strengthen him." This time reference confused people in the Middle Ages, who created a chapter division at this verse, although the vision that began in chapter 10 had not ended. The time reference ("in the first year of Darius the Mede") was not indicating a new subject or vision, although previous time references did function in that way (2:1; 7:1). Rather, the speaker was still speaking to Daniel, mentioning the first year of Darius to clarify when he (the heavenly figure) had strengthened Michael. In 10:21 the figure had spoken about Michael and then continued speaking of him in 11:1.

<span id="page-141-3"></span><span id="page-141-0"></span>The first year of Darius/Cyrus was when the Medo-Persians conquered the Babylonian Empire and permitted captive Jews to return to Jerusalem. These earthly events apparently had heavenly counterparts, for Michael was in the spiritual realm engaging in warfare and advancing God's plan. The heavenly figure of 10:5–6 had confirmed and strengthened Michael during that crucial time period. Michael, the archangel, was probably not strengthened by someone of lesser rank but by his superior—and the preincarnate Son of God would certainly be superior to the great archangel Michael.

## *Response*

<span id="page-141-7"></span>There is more to this world than meets the eye. Paul instructed the Ephesians, "Put on the whole armor of God, that you may be able to stand against the schemes of the devil. For we do not wrestle against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the cosmic powers over this present darkness, against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly places" (Eph. 6:11–12). Spiritual warfare, veiled yet consequential, is unavoidable and must be engaged—and engaged with the weaponry Paul describes. He calls his readers to "stand" against

<span id="page-142-8"></span><span id="page-142-7"></span>the Devil's schemes with defensive armor (vv. 14–17) and the offensive "sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God" (v. 17).

<span id="page-142-1"></span><span id="page-142-0"></span>In Daniel 10 we are reminded that spiritual warfare is not an exclusively NT phenomenon. In response to Daniel's prayer, God immediately sent a heavenly messenger to bring a word of revelation, but the "prince of the kingdom of Persia" held up this messenger for three weeks (v. 13). The messenger said he would return to fight "against the prince of Persia" once more, and soon the "prince of Greece will come" (v. 20). Daniel's visitor also called the angel Michael "your prince" (v. 21). These spiritual princes refer to angels warring in the heavenly places, a warfare with earthly consequences. Even in Daniel's day the struggle was against more than flesh and blood.

<span id="page-142-13"></span><span id="page-142-2"></span>At first glance, this section in the book of Daniel seems to validate the popular notion of "territorial spirits," for an evil "prince" (or angel) presided over Persia and another over Greece. How widespread are such spirits today? The Bible does not state that every territory on earth has an evil spirit that dominates it. Yet the actions of nations can involve devilish schemes and can be stimulated by devilish activity (cf. Rev. 13:2). Believers should not presume to spot a demon behind every bush, but neither should we assume that demons are dormant. It is important to remember that major events of Israel's history were unfolding in Daniel's day, and it seems such actions met demonic resistance. The ministry of Jesus was certainly a pivot point in salvation history, as promises and prophecies were finding their fulfillment—and consider the frequency with which Jesus encountered demonic spirits in the Gospel accounts (e.g., Matt. 4:24; 8:28–34; 9:32–34; 10:1, 7–8; 12:22–23; 17:14–20)!

<span id="page-142-10"></span><span id="page-142-4"></span><span id="page-142-3"></span>Being post-cross and post-resurrection, believers may rejoice in Paul's declaration that God has "disarmed the rulers and authorities and put them to open shame, by triumphing over them in" Christ (Col. 2:15). And though the Devil may presently prowl around like a roaring lion, seeking to devour God's image-bearers (1 Pet. 5:8), the "God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet" (Rom. 16:20).

<span id="page-142-12"></span><span id="page-142-11"></span><span id="page-142-9"></span><span id="page-142-6"></span><span id="page-142-5"></span>Prior to the final crushing of Satan, a key element in our spiritual warfare is prayer; we are to be "praying at all times in the Spirit, with all prayer and supplication" (Eph. 6:18). Daniel did not see the heavenly messenger battling the prince of Persia for three weeks, but Daniel persevered in prayer nonetheless. We do not see behind the spiritual veil in our daily lives, and we should not expect such an opportunity. The opportunity we do have every day, however, is to pray for God's strength, mercy, and compassion, because our great high priest in the heavens, the Lord Jesus Christ who came to defeat the Devil (Heb. 2:14), offers grace for our time of need (4:16). No principality can withstand Christ's power or overthrow his throne. In this world we will have trouble, but take heart: Jesus has overcome the world, the flesh, and the Devil (cf. John 16:33).
