## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-145-3"></span><span id="page-145-2"></span><span id="page-145-1"></span><span id="page-145-0"></span>The heavenly figure who appeared to Daniel (10:1–11:1) now reveals a word of revelation concerning the future of God's people and earthly kingdoms (11:2–12:3): more kings of Persia will rise (11:2), but the kingdom of Greece will eventually come to power and divide fourfold (11:3–4). This divided Greek kingdom will witness battles between the kings of the south and north (11:5–20), ultimately leading to the rise of a contemptible king (11:21) who will cause great turmoil for the Jewish people (11:21–45). But God will accomplish deliverance, even an end-time rescue from the dust through resurrection (12:1–3).

#### <span id="page-145-6"></span><span id="page-145-5"></span><span id="page-145-4"></span>*Section Outline*

- III.A'.2. Daniel Hears a Word of Revelation about the Future (11:2–12:3)
	- a. Persian Kings Shall Rise (11:2)
	- b. The Greek Empire Shall Rise and Split (11:3–4)
	- c. Greek Kings of the North Shall War against Kings of the South (11:5–20)
		- (1) The King of the South Shall Be Strong (11:5)
		- (2) The Kings of the South and North Shall Make an Alliance (11:6)
		- (3) The King of the South Shall Prevail over the King of the North (11:7–9)
		- (4) The King of the North Shall Raise a Multitude and Conquer (11:10–19)
- (5) The King of the North Shall Be Broken (11:20)
- d. A Contemptible Greek King Shall Persecute, but God Shall Deliver (11:21–12:3)
	- (1) The King Shall Rise, Plunder, Defile, and Fall (11:21–11:35)
	- (2) Recapitulation: The King Shall Rise, Plunder, Defile, and Fall (11:36–12:3)

<span id="page-146-15"></span><span id="page-146-12"></span><span id="page-146-11"></span><span id="page-146-9"></span><span id="page-146-4"></span><span id="page-146-2"></span>The center of Daniel 10–12 is the word of revelation (11:2–12:3), framed by the heavenly figure strengthening Daniel (10:1–11:1) and issuing final instructions (12:4–13). In 11:2–12:3, the heavenly figure provides the most detailed prophecy in the book. Its fulfillment lies in the distant future and pertains primarily to the Greek Empire and its various kings (cf. 11:3–45). Greek kings from the north and south will war against each other for many decades (11:5–20), culminating in the rise of a despicable and contemptible king: Antiochus IV Epiphanes (11:21). Most alarming will be his assaults against the Jewish people (11:21–35). The importance of this king to the vision will be evident by the amount of space allotted to his atrocities (11:21–35), and the final part of the vision (11:36–12:3) reinforces his importance by recapitulating those verses.

### <span id="page-146-14"></span><span id="page-146-13"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-146-6"></span><span id="page-146-5"></span><span id="page-146-3"></span>11:2 Saying "Now I will show you the truth," the heavenly figure alluded to the "book of truth" (cf. 10:21) soon to be partially disclosed to Daniel. Daniel learned that "three more kings shall arise in Persia, and a fourth shall be far richer than all of them" (11:2). After Cyrus, who was ruling Medo-Persia at the time of this prophecy (cf. 10:1), the next three kings were Cambyses (530–522 BC), Gaumata (522), and Darius I Hystaspes (522–486). The "fourth" after Cyrus was Xerxes I (486–465), known as Ahasuerus in the book of Esther. An established and wealthy king, Xerxes battled against "the kingdom of Greece" (11:2) but could not conquer it because the Greek city-states mounted strong resistance under Philip of Macedon (359–336).

<span id="page-146-8"></span><span id="page-146-7"></span><span id="page-146-1"></span>11:3–4 After the death of his father, Philip, Alexander the Great ("a mighty king") rose to power, ruling "with great dominion" and acting "as he wills." (v. 3). According to the vision of 8:7 and the interpretation in 8:20–21, this mighty Greek king would defeat the Medo-Persians. Coming to power in 336 BC, Alexander had conquered Persia by 331.

<span id="page-146-10"></span><span id="page-146-0"></span>After Alexander's death in 323 BC at age 32, "His kingdom shall be broken and divided toward the four winds of heaven, but not to his posterity, nor according to the authority with which he ruled, for his kingdom shall be plucked up and go to others besides these" (11:4). Alexander's kingdom was divided posthumously among four of his generals (cf. 7:6; 8:8, 22): Ptolemy, Seleucus, Lysimachus, and Cassander. These generals were not Alexander's descendants, and because of the empire's divisions, the rule of the respective generals was not as vast or great as Alexander's had been.

<span id="page-147-1"></span><span id="page-147-0"></span>The mention of a division "toward the four winds of heaven" (11:4) prepares the reader for the kings of "north" and "south" who will dominate much of chapter 11. Seleucus I Nicator ruled Syria and Mesopotamia ("the north"), and Ptolemy I Soter ruled Egypt and Palestine ("the south"). The kings of the north would be the Seleucids, while the kings of the south would be the Ptolemies. In the decades ahead, these dynasties would battle each other, with the territory of Judah caught in the middle.

<span id="page-147-2"></span>11:5 Beginning in this verse, only two of the four parts of the Greek kingdom will be in view. The heavenly figure spoke of "the king of the south" who would be strong but not as strong as one of his princes, who would rule with great authority. In history, this first king of the south was Ptolemy I. One of his generals (or "princes") was Seleucus I, who helped him in battle before becoming king himself. Seleucus acquired territory by defeating and killing Antigonus (in 301 BC) and became the first "king of the north." Seleucus's kingdom became even greater than Ptolemy's.

<span id="page-147-3"></span>11:6 Years passed before the kings of the north and south finally made an alliance. Seleucus and Ptolemy were no longer ruling, but their dynasties continued with two of their successors, Antiochus II and Ptolemy II, respectively. The alliance in 250 BC between the two kings involved "the daughter of the king of south." Ptolemy II's daughter was Berenice, and the agreement was that she would marry the king of the north, Antiochus II, and bear the next Seleucid ruler for the north. But the plan for an alliance fell apart when, in 246 BC, Antiochus II took back his former wife, Laodice (whom he had left for Berenice), who allegedly poisoned him. Laodice also arranged the murder of Berenice and Berenice's son. Berenice's father (Ptolemy II) died that year as well. In the words of this verse, "She [Berenice] shall not retain the strength of her arm, and he [Antiochus II] and his arm shall not endure, but she [Berenice] shall be given up, and her attendants [who brought her from Egypt], he who fathered her [Ptolemy II], and he [either Antiochus II or Ptolemy II] who supported her [Berenice] in those times."

<span id="page-147-5"></span><span id="page-147-4"></span>11:7–9 Though Berenice's father, Antiochus II, was dead, someone in her family ("from a branch from her roots") would rule in his place (v. 7). Her brother, Ptolemy III, rose to power in 246 BC. He waged war against Laodice's son, Seleucus II Callinicus, who had become king of the north (v. 7). Ptolemy III came against the north out of retaliation for the death of his sister Berenice. He prevailed over the Syrian capital, Antioch, and in his campaign captured and killed Laodice.

<span id="page-147-7"></span><span id="page-147-6"></span>Ptolemy III, the "king of the south," also took spoils of war from the north: "their gods with their metal images and their precious vessels of silver and gold" (v. 8). He returned to Egypt to handle a rebellion, so "for some years" he refrained from attacking "the king of the north." As a result of Ptolemy III's return to Egypt, Seleucus II was able to regain territory, and in 242 BC he tried to invade Egypt ("shall come into the realm of the king of the south") but was not successful ("shall return to his own land"; v. 9).

<span id="page-148-0"></span>11:10 When Seleucus II died, two of his sons ruled after him: first, Seleucus III (227–223 BC), and second, Antiochus III (223–187). Seleucus III had a short reign and was assassinated during a military campaign by members of his own army. But, like his murdered brother, Antiochus III worked to "wage war and assemble a multitude of great forces, which shall keep coming and overflow and pass through." The language denoted successful military campaigns. Antiochus III became known as "the Great."

In the south, in 221 BC, the king was no longer Ptolemy III but now Ptolemy IV. Antiochus III, the king of the north, decided to come against Ptolemy IV and "again shall carry the war as far as his fortress." Antiochus III's campaign in Palestine during this time fulfilled the prophecy that he would carry the war as far as the fortress of the king of the south (Ptolemy III).

<span id="page-148-2"></span><span id="page-148-1"></span>11:11–13 In response to the provocations of the northern king, "the king of the south, moved with rage, shall come out and fight" (v. 11). Ptolemy IV ("the king of the south") launched such a counterattack in 217 BC. Though Antiochus III ("the king of the north") had a "great multitude," his army was given into the hands of Ptolemy IV (v. 11). The passive "it shall be given" reminds us that God was sovereign over the skirmishes between the Greek kings. Ptolemy IV prevailed over the king of the north.

<span id="page-148-3"></span>After Ptolemy IV's victory, his heart became exalted (v. 12). According to Polybius, Ptolemy suffered rebellions in Egypt, which may have fulfilled the prophecy that "he shall cast down tens of thousands" (v. 12). But his reign would not last. In 204 BC, under mysterious circumstances, Ptolemy IV died at the age of 35. This was the opportunity that the king of the north, Antiochus III, was looking for. According to the heavenly figure's words, "The king of the north shall again raise a multitude, greater than the first. And after some years he shall come on with a great army and abundant supplies" (v. 13). Antiochus III was more than ready to invade and conquer, and his new nemesis, Ptolemy V, was only five years old. As a result of a decisive battle in 200, Antiochus III seized control of southern Syria and Palestine. That territory would thereafter be under Seleucid power.

<span id="page-148-4"></span>11:14 The angel of Yahweh explained to Daniel that things would not go well for the king of the south. With the victory of the king of the north imminent (cf. v. 13), the last years of the king of the south would be plagued with rebellion: "In those times many shall rise against the king of the south, and the violent among your own people shall lift themselves up in order to fulfill the vision, but they shall fail" (v. 14). Rebellions began in Egypt before Ptolemy IV had died, and they continued into the reign of young Ptolemy V. Even violent Jews ("among your own people") would be involved in siding against the king of the south.

<span id="page-148-6"></span><span id="page-148-5"></span>11:15 The exploits of the king of the north became more specified: he "shall come and throw up siegeworks and take a well-fortified city." As events unfolded in the career of Antiochus III, the "well-fortified city" was probably Sidon. He besieged

the city and forced it to surrender in 198 BC. As the heavenly figure predicted, "The forces of the south shall not stand, or even his best troops, for there shall be no strength to stand." The siege resulted in a famine, leaving the Sidonians without strength to combat the onslaught of Antiochus and his forces.

<span id="page-149-2"></span><span id="page-149-1"></span><span id="page-149-0"></span>11:16–17 The heavenly figure described the king of the north in terms reminiscent of Alexander the Great: "He who comes against him shall do as he wills, and none shall stand before him" (v. 16; cf. v. 3). The king of the south would go against him, but none could resist the king of the north. Antiochus III would enter Israel and be victorious: "He shall stand in the glorious land, with destruction in his hand" (v. 16; cf. 8:9 for the language of "glorious land" and Ezek. 20:6, 15 for similar language). Now the Jews were under Seleucid, not Ptolemaic, rule. This change of power would mean terrible things for their future, because a descendant of Antiochus III would arise and commit atrocities in the land, a man named Antiochus IV Epiphanes.

<span id="page-149-3"></span>Antiochus III would need a strategy for dealing with opposition in Egypt. According to the angel of Yahweh, "He shall set his face to come with the strength of his whole kingdom, and he shall bring terms of an agreement and perform them" (Dan. 11:17). Rather than invading Egypt, Antiochus III offered his daughter, Cleopatra, to Ptolemy V as a wife. He gave her to Ptolemy V "to destroy the kingdom, but it shall not stand or be to his advantage." Antiochus's plan did not succeed, for Cleopatra was loyal to Ptolemy V, her husband. When Ptolemy died in 182 BC, Cleopatra became the leading power in Egypt.

<span id="page-149-5"></span><span id="page-149-4"></span>11:18–19 Antiochus III refused to be stopped, despite the failure of his plan for Cleopatra. "Afterward he shall turn his face to the coastlands and shall capture many of them" (v. 18)—in 196 BC he went toward Thrace (a peninsula in modern-day Turkey, Greece, and Bulgaria). This activity caught the attention of Rome, who sent warnings not to attack Greece itself. Ignoring the Roman warnings, Antiochus III maintained his course. In response, Rome sent a consul named Lucius Cornelius Scipio, "a commander" who "shall put an end to his insolence" (v. 18). Antiochus III was defeated at Thermopylae in 191 and at Magnesia in 190 and was made a vassal of Rome in 188 according to the Treaty of Apamea. According to the arrangement, he was to send twenty hostages to Rome, one of which was his son Antiochus IV. Antiochus III turned back toward his own land, just as the heavenly figure had predicted (v. 19). In 187 he attempted to pillage a temple of Zeus at Elymais (in modern-day Iraq) in order to pay his tribute to Rome, but the local populace defended the sanctuary and killed Antiochus (v. 19).

<span id="page-149-7"></span><span id="page-149-6"></span>11:20 Two of Antiochus III's sons would eventually rule his kingdom: Antiochus IV and Seleucus IV. The former was a hostage in Rome, so Seleucus IV became king (187–175 BC) when Antiochus III died. According to the prophecy of the angel of Yahweh, Antiochus III's successor "shall send an exactor of tribute for the glory of the kingdom. But within a few days he shall be broken, neither in anger nor in battle." Because he inherited his father's debt, Seleucus IV sought to pay it. He sent his finance minister, Heliodorus, to Jerusalem to seize wealth from its treasury. Heliodorus was unsuccessful, supposedly thwarted by angelic intervention (cf. *2 Macc.* 3:14–40). Seleucus's reign ended "neither in anger nor in battle" in 175, when Heliodorus poisoned him. These events set up the rise of the terrible king, whom the heavenly figure would prophesy about next.

<span id="page-150-0"></span>11:21 In place of Seleucus "shall arise a contemptible person to whom royal majesty has not been given." This person was Antiochus IV Epiphanes, who ruled from 175 to 164 BC. "He shall come in without warning and obtain the kingdom by flatteries," a prophecy fulfilled when people who should have ruled after Seleucus were removed. At first Antiochus was coregent with another son of Seleucus, but the latter was murdered in 170, leaving Antiochus solely in power.

<span id="page-150-2"></span><span id="page-150-1"></span>11:22–24 The picture of "armies" being "utterly swept away before him and broken" depicted the seemingly unstoppable spread of Antiochus IV's power. And "even the prince of the covenant" would be broken, probably referring to the Jewish high priest. Under the previous reign of Antiochus III, Jews had been granted the right of self-government according to Jewish law. The particular "prince of the covenant" of verse 22 was probably Onias III, whom Antiochus IV despised for resisting the influence of Hellenism in the land. When Onias's brother Jason professed support for Hellenization and offered Antiochus IV a bribe, Antiochus deposed Onias and installed Jason in his place (*2 Macc.* 4:7–10). Then, in 172 BC, Menelaus, who was not from a high priestly family, presented an even larger bribe to Antiochus, and as a result he replaced Jason as high priest (*2 Macc.* 4:23–26).

<span id="page-150-3"></span>This contemptible king (Antiochus IV) would make "an alliance" and then "act deceitfully," becoming "strong with a small people" (Dan. 11:23). From what can be discerned historically, it is not certain which alliance is meant, for Antiochus both made and broke many. But perhaps his deals for the high priesthood (with either Jason or Menelaus) fulfilled this prophecy. The "small people" may refer to Jews in Jerusalem who apostatized and sided with him.

Antiochus raided treasuries ("He shall come into the richest parts of the province"; v. 24), acting more greedily than his forebears ("He shall do what neither his fathers nor his fathers' fathers have done"). He also spread spoils around, "scattering among them plunder, spoil, and goods" (v. 24; cf. *1 Macc.* 3:30). The campaigns of Antiochus's forces would involve "plans against strongholds, but only for a time" (Dan. 11:24), probably referring to the region of Egypt that would be dealt with in subsequent verses. "Only for a time" denoted God's sovereignty over the horrific career of Antiochus, a reign that, despite its terrors, would not exceed what had been divinely decreed.

<span id="page-150-6"></span><span id="page-150-5"></span><span id="page-150-4"></span>11:25–28 Antiochus IV "shall stir up his power and his heart against the king of the south with a great army" (v. 25); he would set his sights on Egypt in 170–169 BC. Though the "king of the south" (Ptolemy VI, son of Cleopatra) <span id="page-151-2"></span><span id="page-151-1"></span>would battle against Antiochus with a great army, his efforts would not be successful; Ptolemy's plans were leaked to the opponents, and he was captured while attempting to flee (v. 25). Due to poor counsel and disloyal subjects, Ptolemy VI was no match for the aggression and assaults of Antiochus IV. The prophecy that "Even those who eat his food shall break him" (v. 26) was probably fulfilled when two of Ptolemy's counselors, Eulaeus and Lenaeus, advised him to seize Palestine back from Seleucid control. Ptolemy's army would be swept away in this attempt, with many slain (v. 26).

Though Antiochus IV controlled most of Egypt, he did not control Alexandria, where the people declared Ptolemy VII (the younger brother of Ptolemy VI) king. In a plan to expand his Egyptian control, Antiochus decided to collude with the defeated Ptolemy VI. The "two kings" planned "on doing evil," sitting at the same table and speaking lies to each other regarding agreements they had no intention of keeping (v. 27). Antiochus IV's plans fell through when Ptolemy VI and Ptolemy VII were unexpectedly reconciled and became coregents in Egypt. The heavenly figure told Daniel that Antiochus IV's plan would be "to no avail, for the end is yet to be at the time appointed" (v. 27).

<span id="page-151-4"></span><span id="page-151-3"></span>Nevertheless, Antiochus IV plundered Egypt, concluding his first successful campaign there in 169 BC without capturing Alexandria. As he went to Syria, he passed through Jerusalem and sensed an insurrection; in response, he stole treasure from the temple (*1 Macc.* 1:20–24). He would return to his land with great wealth indeed (Dan. 11:28). But his heart was set against the Jewish people because the insurrection apparently involved Jason's trying to reinstitute himself as high priest, having heard a rumor that Antiochus was killed in Egypt. Antiochus stopped the rebellion, massacring eighty thousand people (cf. *2 Macc.* 5:12–14). He worked his will before returning to his own land (Dan. 11:28)—invading, plundering, and massacring.

<span id="page-151-6"></span><span id="page-151-5"></span>11:29–30 Antiochus IV invaded Egypt again in 168 BC, just as the prophecy had predicted hundreds of years earlier: "At the time appointed he shall return and come into the south" (v. 29), but this time the campaign would not be successful. In Egypt, the united coregent brothers (Ptolemy VI and Ptolemy VII) were against him, and "the ships of Kittim" came against him as well (v. 30), referring to Rome, which arrived at Egypt's request.68 The Roman proconsul Gaius Popillius Laenas confronted Antiochus IV and told him to leave Egypt alone. Antiochus left humiliated and "enraged" and decided to strengthen his grip on Palestine by taking action against the Jews (v. 30). Specifically, he would "pay attention to those who forsake the holy covenant": apostate Jews. He used dissension to his advantage (cf. *1 Macc.* 1:29–35), bringing severe persecution to the Jewish people from 167 to 164 BC.

<span id="page-151-0"></span>Only one other place in the OT had connected "ships" with "Kittim" (Dan. 11:30): Balaam's oracle (Num. 24:24). Most likely the heavenly figure in Daniel 11 deliberately alluded to that oracle. In the historical events involving Antiochus, the

<span id="page-151-7"></span><sup>68</sup> The Septuagint of Daniel 11:30 translates "Kittim" as "Romans."

prophesied "ships of Kittim" turned out to be Rome, as noted above. The Roman Empire would be significant as the one during which the Messiah lived and died. And the very oracle that mentioned "ships of Kittim" earlier in the OT (Num. 24:24) prophesied a star coming out of Jacob and a scepter rising out of Israel (v. 17). Jesus was that rising star and scepter.

<span id="page-152-5"></span><span id="page-152-2"></span>11:31 During the Jewish persecution of 167–164 BC, Antiochus IV's forces profaned the temple fortress, ending the daily sacrifices and setting up "the abomination that makes desolate" (cf. 8:13). He sought the thorough Hellenization of Jerusalem and Judea. He forbade the Scriptures, circumcision, Jewish festivals, and sacrifices, all upon penalty of death (cf. *1 Macc.* 1:41–51, 56–67). On December 6, 167, the "abomination" was set up in the temple (*1 Macc.* 1:54). This was probably an idol of Zeus (cf. *2 Macc.* 6:1–2). Ten days later, on December 16, sacrifices—including pigs—were offered on the altar (*1 Macc.* 1:47, 59; *2 Macc.* 6:4).

<span id="page-152-11"></span><span id="page-152-10"></span><span id="page-152-9"></span><span id="page-152-3"></span><span id="page-152-1"></span>In Matthew 24, Jesus spoke about the coming destruction of the temple in AD 70 (Matt. 24:1–3). In this Olivet Discourse he alluded to "the abomination of desolation spoken of by the prophet Daniel" (Matt. 24:15). His language reflected passages such as Daniel 9:27 and 11:31. The important point is that while 11:31 was fulfilled when Antiochus IV Epiphanes desecrated the temple in 167 BC, Jesus saw that desolation as typological of what would happen under the Roman Empire in AD 70. Jesus had biblical precedent in the book of Daniel to view the two temple desecrations in that way, for, as we have seen, Daniel 8 spoke of a "little horn" in the Greek Empire, while Daniel 7 spoke of a "little horn" in the Roman Empire; and, as we have seen, the former "little horn" was a type of the latter. The language in 9:27 spoke of abomination and desolation, and we concluded there that the fulfillment of those words occurred in AD 70. Jesus knew that the coming destruction of Jerusalem was the fulfillment of the type laid out in chapters 8 and 11.

<span id="page-152-8"></span><span id="page-152-7"></span><span id="page-152-6"></span><span id="page-152-4"></span><span id="page-152-0"></span>11:32–33 The ruler (Antiochus IV) "shall seduce with flattery those who violate the covenant" (v. 32), as Jewish apostates would side with him even as he forbade Jewish practices. But not every Jew would capitulate: "The people who know their God shall stand firm and take action" (v. 32). Such faithful people preferred death to violating God's law (cf. *1 Macc.* 1:61–63). The actions of the faithful would include instructing the people, making them understand the abominable ways and impositions of Antiochus and encouraging them to remain faithful (Dan. 11:33). But this resistance would not be easy, for many would die ("stumble") by sword and fire, while others would be taken captive. Key resistance came from the priest Mattathias and his five sons: John, Simon, Judas (sometimes called Maccabeus, which may mean "the hammer"), Eleazar, and Jonathan. They headed the Maccabean rebellion (166–164 BC), which resulted in Jerusalem's recapture by the Jews and the temple's reestablishment. The recaptured temple was cleansed and then rededicated on December 14, 164—an event that became known as Hanukkah.

<span id="page-153-1"></span>11:34–35 During the Maccabean rebellion, the faithful who died were not the only ones holding to God's law; the movement was helped by others who were steadfast in obedience. However, those who joined the rebellion may have done so for reasons other than biblical faithfulness. The Maccabees began to kill those who had aligned themselves with the Seleucids (cf. *1 Macc.* 2:42–48).

<span id="page-153-2"></span>The heavenly figure revealed to Daniel one of God's purposes in decreeing persecution: those who led by example and were obedient ("the wise") died "so that they may be refined, purified, and made white, until the time of the end, for it still awaits the appointed time" (Dan. 11:35). The persecution would purify the people as the unbelievers forsook Yahweh while the believers held fast to him. The persecution by Antiochus IV became a threshing floor separating wheat from chaff. And, on the last day, all believers will be dressed in white, depicting faithfulness and allegiance to God (Rev. 3:5; cf. 4:4).

<span id="page-153-9"></span>Table 1.14 shows the Greek kings discussed so far, divided into the kings of the south (the Ptolemies) and of the north (the Seleucids):

| Kings of the South (Ptolemies)  | Kings of the North (Seleucids)      |  |
|---------------------------------|-------------------------------------|--|
| Ptolemy I Soter (323–285 BC)    | Seleucus I Nicator (312–280 BC)     |  |
| Ptolemy II (285–246)            | Antiochus I (280–261)               |  |
|                                 | Antiochus II (261–246)              |  |
| Ptolemy III (246–221)           | Seleucus II Callinicus (246–226)    |  |
|                                 | Seleucus III (226–223)              |  |
| Ptolemy IV Philopator (221–204) | Antiochus III (223–187)             |  |
| Ptolemy V (204–181)             | Seleucus IV (187–175)               |  |
| Ptolemy VI (181–145)            | Antiochus IV Epiphanes<br>(175–164) |  |

<span id="page-153-0"></span>TABLE 1.14: Greek Kings Discussed in Comments on Daniel 11:2–35

<span id="page-153-8"></span><span id="page-153-7"></span><span id="page-153-6"></span><span id="page-153-5"></span><span id="page-153-4"></span><span id="page-153-3"></span>11:36–45 This is the most difficult section of the vision, for several reasons. First, the subject in verses 36–39 is "the king," a title not heretofore used by itself, and then in verse 40 the language of "king of the south" and "king of the north" resumes. Second, although Antiochus IV has been in view from verses 21–35, the content of verses 36–45 is difficult to line up with what is known historically of Antiochus's career (if the verses pick up chronologically after vv. 36–39), so perhaps another figure is being introduced. Third, if a different figure is being introduced in verses 36–45, the fulfillment would be later than the Greek Empire, perhaps in the Roman Empire or even in a future Antichrist. Fourth, the heavenly revelation continues to 12:3, so determining the time period of 11:36–45 is significant because 12:1 points to a deliverance by Michael "at that time. . . . of trouble, such as never has been since there was a nation till that time," and reference to this future "time" will be followed by a promise of resurrection (12:2–3).

Admittedly, navigating 11:36–45 is a thorny journey, so let us offer some preliminary conclusions before looking at the verses more closely. First, as we will contend, "the king" of verses 36–45 is Antiochus IV Epiphanes. Second, the uncertainty of some referents in verses 36–45 does not justify a future Antichrist interpretation, a reading assuming fulfillment thousands of years after Daniel wrote his prophecy — indeed, since Antichrist proponents argue that the Antichrist has not yet appeared, the fulfillment of verses 36–45 is, according to their view, still to come. Third, because of certain parallels between 11:36–12:3 and 11:21–35, we will demonstrate exegetically that 11:36–12:3 is a recapitulation of that earlier passage. Daniel 11:36–12:3 covers the same content as 11:21–35, condensing certain parts and elaborating on others.69 Recognizing the use of recapitulation will prevent us from concluding that 11:36–45 was false prophecy concerning the career of Antiochus and will render unnecessary the instinct of many interpreters to project fulfillment of 11:36–45 to the era of a future Antichrist.

<span id="page-154-7"></span><span id="page-154-5"></span><span id="page-154-2"></span>11:36 This and the following verses occur in the context of the persecuting king of verses 21–35, and there is no indication that a new ruler—besides the one we have identified as Antiochus IV—is now in view.70 Nor is any new time indicator given at the start of the verse. The articular "the king" probably refers to the ruler previously described. This king "shall do as he wills. He shall exalt himself and magnify himself above every god, and shall speak astonishing things against the God of gods" (v. 36). Antiochus IV took the name "Epiphanes," meaning "God manifest," suggesting his attitude of self-importance and self-exaltation.

<span id="page-154-1"></span>The practice of doing "as he wills" matches that of a predecessor in verse 16, Antiochus III. The language ultimately echoes verse 3, however, which may suggest that Antiochus III and IV would both be in the mold of mighty Alexander the Great, doing whatever they pleased. Antiochus IV continued to prosper until his indignation was accomplished, for what God had decreed would come to pass. This "indignation" was probably fulfilled with the atrocities against, and desecration of, the Jerusalem temple in 167 BC.

<span id="page-154-9"></span>11:37–38 In order to more strongly emphasize the self-worship of the blasphemous king, the heavenly figure explained further, "He shall pay no attention to the gods of his fathers, or to the one beloved by women" (v. 37). Antiochus

<span id="page-154-3"></span><sup>69</sup> Steinmann argues that the descriptions of the figures in 11:21–35 and 11:36–45 are parallel, for both begin with a general description of reign and events largely unrelated to warfare; in both cases this is followed by descriptions of warfare; in both passages there is an assault against Egypt and an entrance into Palestine, followed by a second engagement with Egypt and entrance into Palestine (Steinmann, *Daniel*, 545). Yet he does not believe both passages speak of Antiochus IV Epiphanes. He insists that 11:21–35 is about Antiochus IV but 11:36–45 is about an eschatological Antichrist. If we grant that 11:36–12:3 is a recapitulation and slight compression of what is prophesied in 11:21–35, identifying the figure in both passages as Antiochus IV Epiphanes is not only more plausible but also more probable.

<span id="page-154-10"></span><span id="page-154-8"></span><span id="page-154-6"></span><span id="page-154-4"></span><span id="page-154-0"></span><sup>70</sup> Tremper Longman notes, "There is no clear transitional statement between verses 35 and 36 or later between verses 39 and 40. In the earlier part of the chapter, there are clear signals that the narrator moves from one king to the next (cf. vv. 2, 7, 20–21), but not in the present section. Here we have the primary textual reason why we cannot simply rule out of court the argument that verses 36–45 continue the 'prophecy' of Antiochus Epiphanes" (Tremper Longman III, *Daniel*, NIVAC [Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 1999], 281).

<span id="page-155-1"></span>replaced Apollo with Zeus as the god of the Seleucids. The god beloved by women may be Tammuz, a deity worshiped by women (cf. Ezek. 8:14), or perhaps one specially favored in Egypt, such as Adonis or Dionysus — gods that Antiochus minimized. More than attending to idols, though, this king would magnify himself (Dan. 11:37).

<span id="page-155-9"></span><span id="page-155-8"></span>Antiochus's false worship would also involve honoring "the god of fortresses" a god "his fathers did not know"—with "gold and silver, with precious stones and costly gifts" (v. 38). This may suggest the king would honor an unconventional deity, although verse 38 could be depicting his idols to be military power and dominion (cf. Hab. 1:11). If the king worshiped himself and the spread of his military power, then the "gold and silver" and "precious stones and costly gifts" might represent his financial and material investment in building his empire.

<span id="page-155-11"></span><span id="page-155-10"></span>11:39 The depiction of the self-exalting king going against "the strongest fortresses with the help of a foreign god" may have been fulfilled by Antiochus's various acts against Jerusalem and Judea. Some Jews apostatized and sided with him. If these Jews acknowledged Antiochus (who blasphemed Yahweh), this transfer of allegiance meant turning against their God as well. People like Jason and Menelaus sought to bribe Antiochus IV for the high priesthood (cf. v. 22), which may have fulfilled the prophecy that "He shall make them rulers over many and shall divide the land for a price" (v. 39). Antiochus also won over the Tobiads, who furthered his cause in Jerusalem, and he made it possible for them to hold civil and religious power there.

With the previous comments in view, it is plausible to consider verses 36–39 to be a recapitulation of verses 21–24. These sections have at least the following seven elements in common (table 1.15).

<span id="page-155-0"></span>TABLE 1.15: Possible Parallels between Daniel 11:21–24 and 11:36–39

<span id="page-156-9"></span><span id="page-156-1"></span>These parallels are not incidental but are meant to highlight a pattern of recapitulation. Having already described the blasphemous king in verses 21–24, the heavenly figure described him again in verses 36–39.

<span id="page-156-10"></span><span id="page-156-8"></span><span id="page-156-5"></span><span id="page-156-4"></span>11:40 The heavenly figure now began a recapitulation of Antiochus's deeds and conquests that verses 25–35 had delineated. These verses are set at the "time of the end," a concept seen in verse 27 ("the end is yet to be at the time appointed") and in verse 35 ("until the time of the end, for it still awaits the appointed time") as well. In verse 40 the heavenly revealer was probably referring to the period of persecution against the Jews that would lead to the destruction of many and the desecration of their temple.

<span id="page-156-2"></span>As in verse 25, the speaker in verse 40 mentioned "the king of the south." This king attacked "him," identified in the next phrase as the "king of the north." who would "rush upon" the king of the south "like a whirlwind, with chariots and horsemen, and with many ships." This parallels verse 25, in which the king of the north came against the king of the south "with a great army" (fulfilled in 170–169 BC). In verse 40, we read that the king of the north "shall come into countries and shall overflow and pass through," language describing his continual movement. If the events of verses 25–27 are in fact being recapitulated, this must describe Antiochus IV passing through Judea on his way back to Syria.

<span id="page-156-11"></span><span id="page-156-3"></span>11:41 Heading to Syria, Antiochus came "into the glorious land"—Judea and, specifically, Jerusalem. When he saw an insurrection developing, he stopped it. According to the heavenly figure, "tens of thousands shall fall," which was fulfilled when Antiochus massacred eighty thousand people (cf. *2 Macc.* 5:12–14). When the heavenly figure declared that "these shall be delivered out of his hand: Edom and Moab and the main part of the Ammonites" (Dan. 11:41), the point was probably that the Jewish people would be the focus of Antiochus's fury, while recognized enemies of Yahweh would escape destruction.71 In Jeremiah 25:21, "Edom, Moab, and the sons of Ammon" are mentioned as those who would face the destruction of Yahweh, but now in Daniel 11:41 the enemies of Yahweh would see the Jews, God's people, persecuted.

<span id="page-156-12"></span><span id="page-156-7"></span><span id="page-156-0"></span>11:42–43 The king of the north (Antiochus IV) "shall stretch out his hand against the countries, and the land of Egypt shall not escape." The king would come against the south again, recapitulating the events of verse 29, in which he returned to Egypt in 168 BC for further invasion and dominion. He would "become ruler of the treasures of gold and silver, and all the precious things of Egypt, and the Libyans and the Cushites shall follow in his train" (v. 43). Antiochus had plundered Egypt in 169 BC (cf. v. 28). He was the ruler of their treasure, and he may have plundered more during this second engagement with that territory. Further, his presence

<span id="page-156-13"></span><span id="page-156-6"></span><sup>71</sup> At the time of Antiochus's reign, Moab was no longer a nation, but that fact does not contradict this point. The name Moab, along with Ammon and Edom, is employed here to represent enemies of God's people.

and reputation apparently led people from nearby regions (Libya and Ethiopia) to align with him ("follow in his train").

<span id="page-157-3"></span>11:44 While Antiochus IV would gain followers from Libya and Ethiopia, which were located west and south of Egypt, "news from the east and the north shall alarm him." To the east were Judea and Syria, while to the north was Rome. Rome intervened when its representative, proconsul Gaius Popillius Laenas, confronted Antiochus IV and told him to leave Egypt alone. The words of verse 44 have recapitulated verse 30, in which "the ships of Kittim" came against him and forced him to withdraw and turn back.

"News from the east and the north" may have another plausible interpretation. If the directions were to be combined into a single source of news, then from Antiochus's position in Egypt the northeast would probably have been Jerusalem. The "news" that may have disturbed him was the fact that Jason—believing a rumor that Antiochus had been killed in Egypt—had returned to Jerusalem and led a rebellion against Menelaus and the Tobiads (cf. *2 Macc.* 5:5–10). Jason's action was an attempt to undermine the authorities Antiochus had appointed.

<span id="page-157-0"></span>Continuing the recapitulation of Daniel 11:30, Antiochus IV "shall go out with great fury to destroy and devote many to destruction" (v. 44). After his humiliation in Egypt, Antiochus went to Palestine and took action against the Jews. The years of 167–164 BC were a period of intense persecution. Antiochus forbade Jewish practices like circumcision and festival observances, outlawed copies of the Scriptures, set up an idol in the Jerusalem temple, and offered unclean animals on the altar. The people were oppressed and their temple desecrated. Some Jews apostatized and joined Antiochus's regime, while others remained faithful to Yahweh and refused to compromise their faith; as punishment, many of these faithful died.

<span id="page-157-6"></span><span id="page-157-2"></span>11:45 The prophecy that the king of the north "shall pitch his palatial tents between the sea and the glorious holy mountain" continued the terrible news of verse 44 that Antiochus IV would come against God's people with fury and the intent to destroy. The language of "glorious holy mountain" echoed the "glorious land" from verse 41. Not merely the city but the function and holiness of the temple as well were in his sinister sights. He set up his encampment, denoted here as "palatial tents," against God's people, who suffered years of oppression and persecution. But the fury of Antiochus IV would be short-lived. Indeed, "He shall come to his end, with none to help him." While warring against the Parthians, Antiochus IV died of disease in 164 BC.72

<span id="page-157-8"></span><span id="page-157-7"></span><span id="page-157-5"></span><span id="page-157-4"></span><span id="page-157-1"></span><sup>72</sup> For some scholars the statement of the king's death in 11:45 precludes an identification of Antiochus IV because they believe the encampment of verse 45a must be the place of death in verse 45b, and everyone knows Antiochus did not die in Palestine. This seems to rest on an unnecessary assumption. If verses 44–45 are a recapitulation and compression of verses 30–33, it may be a gross overreading of the text to demand that the death reported in verse 45b happen in the region mentioned in verse 45a. It seems more reasonable to take verse 45b as a promise that Antiochus, despite his raging and blasphemy and destructive designs, would die. But note carefully that verse 45b *does not say where* he would die. The period of Jewish persecution was from 167 to 164 BC (which fulfilled vv. 44–45a), and his death occurred in 164 (which fulfilled v. 45b).

<span id="page-158-3"></span>12:1 During the terrible persecution inflicted by Antiochus IV Epiphanes, "Michael, the great prince who has charge of your people," shall arise. Michael was mentioned earlier in the vision when the angel of Yahweh told Daniel, "Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me" when the "prince of the kingdom of Persia" engaged in spiritual warfare for twenty-one days (10:13). That previous engagement was during the Medo-Persian reign, but the heavenly figure had said that "when I go out, behold, the prince of Greece will come" (10:20), suggesting spiritual warfare would continue into the reign of the next empire. The prophecy of 12:1 said that Michael would arise to defend Israel, and Israel certainly needed to be defended against the terrible suffering and outrageous desolation committed by Antiochus.

<span id="page-158-9"></span><span id="page-158-4"></span>The heavenly figure described that time as "a time of trouble, such as never has been since there was a nation till that time." This language portrayed the horror of the years 167–164 BC. Since Jesus employed the "abomination of desolation"—set up by Antiochus IV—as a precursor for and type of the judgment against Jerusalem and its temple in AD 70, it is important to note that the language of 12:1 also appeared in the Olivet Discourse: "Then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world until now, no, and never will be" (Matt. 24:21; cf. Mark 13:19). This extreme description is consistent with how past judgments against the temple were framed. In Jeremiah 30:7, Yahweh spoke concerning the fall of Jerusalem to the Babylonians: "Alas! That day is so great there is none like it; it is a time of distress for Jacob; yet he shall be saved out of it." Just as Yahweh then promised deliverance (Jer. 30:8), the heavenly figure in Daniel 12:1 spoke of deliverance after an unprecedented distress, and Jesus in the Olivet Discourse promised deliverance after a time of great tribulation (Matt. 24:21–22, 30–31).73

<span id="page-158-10"></span><span id="page-158-8"></span><span id="page-158-6"></span>As noted, Jesus spoke about this "great tribulation" after foretelling "the abomination of desolation spoken of by the prophet Daniel, standing in the holy place" (Matt. 24:15). The proximity of the language of an "abomination of desolation" and "great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world until now" (Matt. 24:15, 21) supports the idea that Jesus was alluding to Daniel 11:21–12:3, a section that prophesied the tyrannical deeds of the king of the north (fulfilled by Antiochus) and the deliverance God provided at that crucial time.74

<span id="page-158-5"></span><span id="page-158-1"></span>With Michael defending Israel, the heavenly mediator promised, "At that time your people shall be delivered, everyone whose name shall be found written in the book" (12:1). The names in "the book" were the elect of God in the book of life (cf. references to this "book" in Ex. 32:32–33; Ps. 69:28; Rev. 3:5; 13:8). The promise was that God would deliver his people from the rage of Antiochus IV Epiphanes. If they were not spared from death, they would one day be delivered from death by bodily resurrection (Dan. 12:2). The rebellion of the Maccabees was probably the earthly expression of this spiritual battle. Mattathias and his sons led this

<span id="page-158-7"></span>73 Sam Storms rightly notes, "Neither those who used these terms in the Old Testament nor Jesus himself ever intended for such language to be pressed in such a way that it precluded the possibility for subsequent periods of equal or even more intense judgment to occur" (Sam Storms, *Kingdom Come: An Amillennial Alternative* [Fearn, UK: Mentor, 2013], 255). Cf. Exodus 11:6; 9:18; 10:14; Ezekiel 5:9; Daniel 9:12; 12:1; Joel 2:2.

<span id="page-158-2"></span><span id="page-158-0"></span><sup>74</sup> Of course, Daniel 9:27 may also be in view, but the relationship between 11:31 and 9:27 is typological and thus connected.

rebellion (166–164 BC), resulting in the city of Jerusalem being recaptured and its temple being renewed and reconsecrated.

<span id="page-159-12"></span>When Jesus used the language of 12:1 in the Olivet Discourse as he foretold the coming Roman destruction of Jerusalem, he also spoke of God's "elect" (Matt. 24:22, 24, 31) after speaking of an unprecedented time of "great tribulation" (24:21), and this order surely reflected Daniel 12:1, which spoke of God's elect after predicting "a time of trouble."

<span id="page-159-9"></span><span id="page-159-4"></span><span id="page-159-3"></span>If 11:36–12:3 is a recapitulation of 11:21–35, then the deliverance in 12:1 may correspond to the reassurance in 11:32, that "The people who know their God shall stand firm and take action," and in verse 34, that when the faithful stumble, "They shall receive a little help." The archangel Michael arose to defend the people, and the people rose up in resistance and in zealous commitment to God and his law.

<span id="page-159-14"></span><span id="page-159-11"></span><span id="page-159-1"></span><span id="page-159-0"></span>12:2–3 Compelling evidence for seeing recapitulation of 11:21–35 in 11:36–12:3 is the final verses of each section, which speak of what would happen to "many" and to the "wise." In 12:2, "Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt." Sleeping in the dust is a picture of death that harks back to Genesis 3:19 (for sleep as a metaphor for death, cf. Job 14:12; Pss. 13:3; 76:5; 90:5; Jer. 51:39, 57; 1 Thess. 4:14). According to the previous section, faithful believers during this time of tumult would die (Dan. 11:33–35), and thus the picture of people in the dust was appropriate. God's purposes in this tribulation were good: the faithful would be "refined, purified, and made white" (11:35). Daniel 12:2 held out ultimate hope for the vindication of these purified people: resurrection from the dead. God's good purpose would involve refining and raising his people.75

<span id="page-159-8"></span><span id="page-159-7"></span><span id="page-159-6"></span><span id="page-159-5"></span>The "many" of 12:2 may have initially referred to the faithful and unfaithful Jews during the persecution of Antiochus. Some Jews would walk wisely in obedience (11:32–33), but others would only seem to be following God when their hearts were in fact compromised (11:34). The final judgment would vindicate the righteous and punish the wicked, for some would be raised to everlasting life and others to everlasting shame (12:2). These resurrected states would be final.

Yet the promise that faithful and unfaithful Jews would be raised does not preclude the notion of all the faithful and unfaithful—Jews *and* Gentiles—being raised on the last day. God is no tribal deity; all nations of the earth are accountable to him. Indeed, Jesus made this very application of 12:2 when he declared, "An hour is coming when all who are in the tombs will hear his voice and come out, those who have done good to the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil to the resurrection of judgment" (John 5:28–29).76 Paul likewise clearly believed that Daniel 12:2 was not exclusive to Jews, for he spoke of a general resurrection

<span id="page-159-13"></span><span id="page-159-2"></span><sup>75</sup> Other OT passages such as Isaiah 26:19 and Psalm 49:15 also teach a hope of resurrection from the dead. For an exploration of how the hope of resurrection was rooted in Israel's worldview as early as the book of Genesis, see Mitchell L. Chase, "The Genesis of Resurrection Hope," *JETS* 57/3 (2014): 467–480.

<span id="page-159-10"></span><sup>76</sup> The fact that Jesus mentioned two groups—faithful and unfaithful—who would be raised from the dead is without question an allusion to Daniel 12:2, for no other OT text puts the hope so plainly for the righteous and the wicked.

<span id="page-160-4"></span>"of both the just and the unjust" (Acts 24:15). In Daniel 12:2, the language of "many"—divided into "some" who would rise to life and "some" who would rise to shame—probably assumed a general resurrection of the dead, even though "the many" was tailored to the particular situation the Jewish people would face under the terrible reign of Antiochus IV Epiphanes.77

The Maccabees evidently believed the hope of 12:2 was for them; we read of seven brothers who remained faithful unto martyrdom when Antiochus IV was imposing suffering and death. The language of these brothers explicitly reflected a hope for resurrection (*2 Macc.* 7:9, 11, 14, 23). The hope of vindication through end-time resurrection would compel the faithfulness of God's people in a period of terrible tribulation. God, not Antiochus IV Epiphanes or even death, would have the last word.

<span id="page-160-5"></span><span id="page-160-2"></span>In reference specifically to the resurrected faithful, Daniel heard that "Those who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the sky above; and those who turn many to righteousness, like the stars forever and ever" (Dan. 12:3). The two parts of the verse are parallel: "those who are wise" are those "who turn many to righteousness," and shining "like the brightness of the sky" is described also as shining "like the stars forever and ever." Both halves speak of the same hope. "Those who are wise" and "who turn many to righteousness" (12:3) are the "wise among the people" in 11:33 who "shall make many understand." God's people would not only remain faithful; they would also exhort others to stay true to Yahweh. The hope held out was not that God's people would actually become stars or angels. The brightness of stars depicts the glory in store for the bodies of God's resurrected people. The reference to "stars" also evokes passages such as Genesis 15:5, where Abraham was told his offspring would be as countless as the stars of the night sky. Jesus used the language of Daniel 12:3 when he declared, "The righteous will shine like the sun in the kingdom of their Father" (Matt. 13:43).

<span id="page-160-13"></span><span id="page-160-12"></span><span id="page-160-9"></span><span id="page-160-7"></span><span id="page-160-0"></span>The promise of resurrection and shining was inaugurated by the Lord Jesus Christ and will be fulfilled at his triumphant return. Paul called Jesus' bodily resurrection the "firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep" (1 Cor. 15:20). When Jesus returns, he will "transform our lowly body to be like his glorious body, by the power that enables him even to subject all things to himself" (Phil. 3:21). Yet even now believers "shine as lights in the world" (Phil. 2:15), probably an allusion to Daniel 12:3 that introduces an already-but-not-yet aspect to our shining like stars. By grace through faith, we have been made alive and raised spiritually and so we shine in that sense (John 5:21, 24; Phil. 2:15), but our bodies will be raised physically as well (2 Cor. 5:1–4), and this raised and glorified existence will be a weight of glory that far exceeds the cost and grief of the "light momentary afflictions" endured in these earthly bodies (2 Cor. 4:17–18).
