<span id="page-161-0"></span>TABLE 1.16: Parallels between Daniel 11:25–35 and 11:40–12:3

<span id="page-161-23"></span><span id="page-161-22"></span><span id="page-161-21"></span><span id="page-161-15"></span><span id="page-161-14"></span><span id="page-161-12"></span><span id="page-161-5"></span><span id="page-161-4"></span>The sheer number of parallels (combined with the previous chart showing seven others between 11:21–24 and 11:36–39) argues decidedly against seeing 11:36–12:3 as prophecy of a different king than the one described in 11:21–35. Adding support to the conclusion that Daniel used the device of recapitulation is the fact that in chapter 8, which also foretold the events surrounding Antiochus IV Epiphanes, the persecution of the Jewish people and the desecration of the temple were framed in an A-B-A'-B' pattern that also utilized recapitulation: see 8:9–10a (A), 8:10b (B), 8:11a (A'), and 8:11b–12 (B'). Being part of a much longer vision, the section of 11:21–12:3 is understandably a much longer piece of prophecy and recapitulation.

### <span id="page-161-6"></span><span id="page-161-2"></span><span id="page-161-1"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-161-3"></span>The purpose of the vision and revelation in chapters 10–12 is not to overwhelm the reader with historical detail, although that may happen. The purpose, rather, is for the historical detail to overwhelm the reader with the assurance of God's sovereignty and meticulous guidance of this world. God does not make educated guesses about the future; he decrees it. The detailed engagements of the northsouth kings have led some skeptical scholars to place the dating of the whole book in a Maccabean time period, for these details seem too precise to have been revealed ahead of time. Yet from a faithful perspective, a sixth-century-BC account of these prophecies strengthens our confidence in our God, who reigns over the earth.

Despite how things would appear in those dark days of tribulation, the prophecy confirmed that God was in control. Mighty empires would conquer and subdue <span id="page-162-0"></span>their foes, but the nations are like a drop from a bucket or like dust on the scales (Isa. 40:15). Before God Almighty, the world's rulers and kingdoms are as nothing, so God's people should hold fast and endure, despite generations of trial and opposition. The faithful of those generations would be the "wise" who turned others to righteousness and walked in righteousness themselves—no matter the cost—before tyrannical kings.

<span id="page-162-4"></span><span id="page-162-3"></span><span id="page-162-2"></span><span id="page-162-1"></span>The stories in the earlier parts of the book also encourage readers as they showcase deliverance by God's mighty arm. God's preservation of Daniel and his friends in chapter 1 should compel us to endure even when compromise would be easier. The provision of wisdom to Daniel in chapter 2 should strengthen our confidence that God will grant us what we need to be faithful witnesses amid grim circumstances. The miraculous rescue of chapter 3 should leave us in awe that God is with his people, even in the heat of persecution. The humbling of King Nebuchadnezzar in chapter 4 should remind us that all who are mighty in their own eyes, and in the eyes of the world, are expendable and vulnerable before almighty God, who humbles the proud. The ominous writing on the wall in chapter 5 should sober any who doubt the power and willingness of God to judge the wicked. The remarkable deliverance from death in chapter 6 should stimulate our hope that God will one day vindicate his people by raising them physically from the dead, typified by Daniel's spending a night in a den of lions and living to testify of God's power.

<span id="page-162-10"></span><span id="page-162-9"></span><span id="page-162-8"></span><span id="page-162-7"></span><span id="page-162-6"></span><span id="page-162-5"></span>The visions of the book of Daniel should encourage readers as well, even though alarm at the prophecies of tribulation is reasonable. The scene in chapter 7, of the Son of Man coming in victory to the Ancient of Days, was fulfilled at the ascension and session of Jesus Christ, who defeated death and will return to complete what he inaugurated. In chapter 8, the cunning and malice of the "little horn" was broken and crushed according to God's will and wisdom, a reminder that God brings to pass what he promises. In chapter 9, the hope for a climactic jubilee that would atone for iniquity and establish a strong (and new) covenant was realized in the death of Jesus the Messiah, who led a new and greater exodus from our deepest captivity and exile. And the dark vision of chapter 11, which promised conflict and battle and persecution, nevertheless predicted the light of faithful and wise saints, as many who were wise stood firm against the schemes of Antiochus and rested in the dust at their deaths, awaiting their day of resurrection. The visions of the book strengthen our resolve to follow God faithfully because he is a vindicating God. He uproots and builds, destroys and restores, tears down and raises up.

## <span id="page-163-3"></span>DANIEL 12:4–13

**<sup>4</sup>** "But you, Daniel, shut up the words and seal the book, until the time of the end. Many shall run to and fro, and knowledge shall increase."

**<sup>5</sup>**Then I, Daniel, looked, and behold, two others stood, one on this bank of the stream and one on that bank of the stream. **6**And someone said to the man clothed in linen, who was above the waters of the stream,*<sup>1</sup>* "How long shall it be till the end of these wonders?" **7**And I heard the man clothed in linen, who was above the waters of the stream; he raised his right hand and his left hand toward heaven and swore by him who lives forever that it would be for a time, times, and half a time, and that when the shattering of the power of the holy people comes to an end all these things would be finished. **<sup>8</sup>** I heard, but I did not understand. Then I said, "O my lord, what shall be the outcome of these things?" **<sup>9</sup>** He said, "Go your way, Daniel, for the words are shut up and sealed until the time of the end. **10**Many shall purify themselves and make themselves white and be refined, but the wicked shall act wickedly. And none of the wicked shall understand, but those who are wise shall understand. **11**And from the time that the regular burnt offering is taken away and the abomination that makes desolate is set up, there shall be 1,290 days. **12**Blessed is he who waits and arrives at the 1,335 days. **13**But go your way till the end. And you shall rest and shall stand in your allotted place at the end of the days."

1Or *who was upstream*; also verse 7

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-163-2"></span><span id="page-163-1"></span><span id="page-163-0"></span>The heavenly figure who appeared to Daniel (10:1–11:1) and gave a word of revelation concerning future tribulation for Israel (11:2–12:3) now instructs Daniel to seal the prophecy (12:4). The events Daniel has heard about will take place in the distant future, beyond his own lifetime. When Daniel asks about the outcome of the events, the figure tells him to go his way (12:8–9). Daniel will rest in death, rise in due time, and receive his inheritance with all the people of God (12:10, 13).

### <span id="page-163-5"></span><span id="page-163-4"></span>*Section Outline*

III.A'.3. Daniel Receives Final Instructions and Encouragement

(12:4–13)

- a. The Heavenly Figure Instructs Daniel (12:4)
	- b. An Angel Asks a Question of the Heavenly Figure (12:5–6)
		- c. The Heavenly Figure Swears an Oath and Speaks of Future Trial (12:7)
- b'. Daniel Asks a Question of the Heavenly Figure (12:8)
- a'. The Heavenly Figure Instructs Daniel (12:9–13)

The last part of the book (12:4–13) involves final instructions and questions in light of what has just been revealed. In keeping with a device used frequently in the book, 12:4–13 is best arranged chiastically. In the opening and closing verses (a and a'), the heavenly figure instructs Daniel. These sections also speak of sealing the book until the time of the end, and in both sections the heavenly figure calls Daniel by name. Sections b and b' contain questions for the heavenly figure: an angel asks how long it will be until the wonders end (b), and Daniel asks what the outcome of the things will be (b'). The center of the chiasm highlights the heavenly figure's oath concerning the future suffering of God's people (c).

<span id="page-164-3"></span><span id="page-164-2"></span><span id="page-164-1"></span>In the three parts of Daniel 10–12 (10:1–11:1; 11:2–12:3; 12:4–13), the first and third parts frame the central prophecy. In each framing section, the heavenly figure is a man clothed in linen (10:5; 12:6–7), the figure calls Daniel by name twice (10:11, 12; 12:4, 9), and a body of water is observed (10:4; 12:5, 7). One further commonality between 10:1–11:1 and 12:4–13 is that in the former the figure raises Daniel from deep sleep on the ground, while in the latter the figure promises Daniel he will share in a future resurrection from the sleep of death in the dust.

### *Comment*

<span id="page-164-0"></span>12:4 Having finished telling Daniel the word of revelation, the heavenly figure gave him a directive: "shut up the words" and "seal the book" (the two statements are synonymous). The reference is probably not merely to the vision and revelation just received in chapters 10–12 but to the whole "book" of stories and disclosures and mysteries (chs. 1–12). Since the time of fulfillment (the appointed "end") of these visions was beyond Daniel's lifetime, the message should be preserved ("sealed") for future readers. The people of God would need the hope of God's Word in their seasons of suffering, and Daniel's visions exalted the sovereign plan and power of God over earthly kingdoms and blasphemous opposition. The readers would need to know of God's certain triumph, which would compel their endurance and goad them in paths of righteousness.

<span id="page-164-5"></span><span id="page-164-4"></span>Though the details of fulfillment were unclear to Daniel at this time, the unfolding of historical events would provide greater understanding for readers of these detailed prophecies and visions (esp. of ch. 11). This promise of increased understanding was probably what the heavenly figure meant by "Many shall run to and fro, and knowledge shall increase" (12:4). Though some modern readers might speculate that this promise is foretelling a drastic increase in mobility and in scientific and technological knowledge in the last days, a better meaning is established when we recognize that "running to and fro" in Amos 8:12 was the action of people seeking a word (or revelation) from Yahweh but being unable to find it. Daniel heard the comforting promise that, according to Daniel 12:4, people in the future would seek a word from Yahweh and subsequently grow in understanding because the book had been preserved ("sealed") for them.

<span id="page-165-12"></span><span id="page-165-8"></span>12:5–6 Daniel next reported what he saw and heard. He looked, "and behold, two others stood, one on this bank of the stream and one on that bank of the stream." The mention of the "bank of the stream" recalls the beginning of the final vision, in which Daniel was "standing on the bank of the great river (that is, the Tigris)" (10:4). We have suggested that from 10:5 to 11:1 a single heavenly being appeared to Daniel, spoke to him, restored him physically from debilitating fear, and made known to him the final word of revelation (11:2–12:3). Now "two others" appear, one on each side of the stream, and they are probably angels, although their names are not mentioned. In chapter 8 two angels had been present after a revelation was given (8:13–14), and now again two beings are present (12:5) after a word of revelation.

<span id="page-165-9"></span><span id="page-165-5"></span><span id="page-165-4"></span><span id="page-165-1"></span><span id="page-165-0"></span>Then "someone" spoke, probably one of the angels beside the river. The being spoke "to the man clothed in linen, who was above the waters of the stream" (12:6). The description matched what Daniel had seen in 10:5 ("behold, a man clothed in linen"), so that heavenly figure was still in view in 12:6. The figure's location "above the waters" implies an exalted divine being. In Genesis 1:2 and Psalm 29:3, e.g., God's Spirit and voice were above the waters, but more important for the scene of Daniel 12:6 is the previous report in 8:16: "I heard a man's voice between the banks of the Ulai, and it called, 'Gabriel, make this man understand the vision.'" In that scene, the voice was between the banks and thus over the water, directing the angel Gabriel. The "voice between the banks" in 8:16 belonged to a divine figure, so this parallel with 12:7—someone who is about to speak between the banks of a river and thus above the waters—confirms that Daniel encountered a divine figure in 10:5 (the angel of Yahweh), an encounter continuing even in 12:6.

<span id="page-165-14"></span><span id="page-165-6"></span><span id="page-165-3"></span><span id="page-165-2"></span>An angel asked the divine being, "How long shall it be till the end of these wonders?" (12:6). This question further echoed elements in chapter 8, for in 8:13 an angel had asked "how long" the desolation described in the vision of 8:2–12 would last, and the Hebrew word for "wonders" also appeared in both 8:24 and 11:36.78 The angel was probably asking about the time frame of the revelation in 11:21–12:3, a season that had much tumult and tragedy in store for God's people.

<span id="page-165-11"></span><span id="page-165-10"></span>12:7 The "man clothed in linen, who was above the waters," heard the question and was ready to answer. Taking a solemn oath, "He raised his right hand and his left hand toward heaven and swore by him who lives forever that it would be for a time, times, and half a time, and that when the shattering of the power of the holy people comes to an end all these things would be finished." Note the raising of both hands, which was unique when compared with other solemn oaths (cf.

<span id="page-165-13"></span><span id="page-165-7"></span><sup>78</sup> The word for "wonders" does not occur in the book of Daniel outside of 8:24 ("fearful"); 11:36 ("astonishing things"); and 12:6. Since 11:36 is part of a revelation recapitulating the prophecy about Antiochus IV Epiphanes, 11:36 has the same referent as 8:24 did, for the latter spoke of Antiochus as well. Most certainly, then, 12:6 alludes to the "wonders" that would take place during this specific period of persecution under that specific ruler.

<span id="page-166-1"></span><span id="page-166-0"></span>Deut. 32:40). Since the Lord swears oaths elsewhere in the OT (cf. Gen. 22:14; Ex. 6:8; Ezek. 20:5), the use of an oath in Daniel 12:7 does not disprove the deity of the speaker. Rather, it affirms that he is trustworthy.

<span id="page-166-3"></span><span id="page-166-2"></span>The period of "a time, times, and half a time" recalls 7:25, where it is said that the saints would suffer for a season under the Roman Empire. And, as in 7:25, the phrase is probably approximate rather than strictly literal. "A time, times, and half a time" probably corresponds to roughly three and a half years, which fits well with the period of upheaval and opposition from 167 to 164 BC under the reign of Antiochus IV Epiphanes.79 During those years, the "holy people" of Israel (cf. Deut. 7:6) experienced a "shattering" of their "power" by that tyrannical king. But God promised an "end" to that season of tribulation. The referent of "all these things" (Dan. 12:7) was probably the historical persecution prophesied specifically in 11:21–45 (as Antiochus opposed and massacred Jews, desecrated the temple, and forbade obedience to the law of Moses), because the "wonders" in 12:6 echoed the language of 11:36, which was part of the recapitulation of 11:21–35.

<span id="page-166-12"></span><span id="page-166-8"></span><span id="page-166-7"></span><span id="page-166-6"></span><span id="page-166-4"></span>12:8 Daniel did not understand what he heard, a response identical to his response to the vision of chapter 8 (vv. 15–16, 27), which prophesied the same events as 11:21–45, involving Antiochus IV Epiphanes. Daniel asked, "O my lord, what shall be the outcome of these things?" (12:8). He wanted to know God's purposes for this period of trial for his people.

<span id="page-166-13"></span>12:9–10 The divine figure clothed in linen replied, "Go your way, Daniel, for the words are shut up and sealed until the time of the end." Daniel was not to worry about what he did not know, for the vision had been and would be preserved for future readers. For now, Daniel was to move on with his life. No more revelation would be given to him.

Perhaps as a partial answer to Daniel's question, the heavenly figure said, "Many shall purify themselves and make themselves white and be refined, but the wicked shall act wickedly." One outcome of the persecution, then, would be purification. The heavenly figure contrasted the "many," who were devoted to God, with the "wicked," who were not. The language of being purified and made white and refined probably recalled 11:35, where those three terms also occurred.

<span id="page-166-14"></span><span id="page-166-11"></span>The figure continued the contrast: "None of the wicked shall understand, but those who are wise shall understand" (12:10). The wicked do not walk wisely or in obedience to God's law. The wise, on the other hand, walk in the fear of Yahweh. They have understanding because of their knowledge of and obedience to God's Word. They trust his providence and believe his promises. The language of the "wise" who "understand" also recalls 11:33, where "the wise among the people shall make many understand," and 11:35, where the "wise" were purified and refined by the trial of persecution. Seeing 12:10 in light of the statements in 11:33–35,

<span id="page-166-10"></span><span id="page-166-9"></span><span id="page-166-5"></span><sup>79</sup> This time period also matches the prediction in 8:14: "For 2,300 evenings and mornings. Then the sanctuary shall be restored to its rightful state." The period from the temple's desecration in 167 BC to its first sacrifice on the newly consecrated altar in 164 was almost 1,150 days (the equivalent of 2,300 evening and morning sacrifices).

<span id="page-167-8"></span>we note the verse is arranged chiastically: the figure spoke about the wise and then the wicked (12:10a) and then, reversing direction, spoke about the wicked and then the wise (12:10b).

<span id="page-167-10"></span><span id="page-167-9"></span><span id="page-167-6"></span><span id="page-167-4"></span>12:11 The angel of Yahweh, still above the waters, made another statement concerning the time of persecution to be endured under Antiochus IV Epiphanes: "From the time that the regular burnt offering is taken away and the abomination that makes desolate is set up, there shall be 1,290 days." Scholars are not sure what to make of this number, which seems to relate to the events of 11:31–35 (cf. also 8:9–12), but the most compelling answer seems to be one that evokes the length of the Egyptian captivity. The Israelites were captive in Egypt for 430 years (Ex. 12:40–41), and 430 multiplied by 3 is 1,290. The glaring difference is that in Exodus the reference to 430 was to years, while in Daniel it is to days. Nevertheless, the use of 430 could denote a period of captivity. Under Antiochus IV Epiphanes, the people of Israel would once again be a people oppressed by a foreign power. But, as in the days of Pharaoh, God would triumph, and his people would be delivered (cf. Dan. 12:1–3). A figurative allusion to Egypt would not be unprecedented, for a literal mention of Egypt was made in 11:8 and 11:42–43. The depiction of Antiochus's reign of terror as captivity may mean we should view him as more vile and oppressive than the pharaoh of Exodus, for his captivity figuratively lasted three times as long.

<span id="page-167-7"></span><span id="page-167-5"></span><span id="page-167-3"></span>12:12 The heavenly speaker pronounced a beatitude, the only one in the book of Daniel addressed to someone other than God: "Blessed is he who waits and arrives at the 1,335 days" (cf. 2:20; 3:28; 4:34). The significance of this number is unclear. The number 1,335 is 45 more than 1,290 (cf. 12:11). It is unclear why the reader would need to wait 45 more days, but the figure may allude to the number of years mentioned by Caleb to Joshua:

I was forty years old when Moses the servant of the Lord sent me from Kadesh-barnea to spy out the land, and I brought him word again as it was in my heart. . . . And now, behold, the Lord has kept me alive, just as he said, these *forty-five* years since the time that the Lord spoke this word to Moses, while Israel walked in the wilderness. And now, behold, I am this day eighty-five years old. (Josh. 14:7, 10)

<span id="page-167-1"></span>The period of forty-five years was significant for Caleb because it spanned the time he was in the wilderness to the time he received his inheritance after the conquest (cf. Josh. 14:13–15).

<span id="page-167-2"></span><span id="page-167-0"></span>In light of Israel's captivity in Egypt and eventual conquest of the Promised Land, the numbers 1,290 and 1,335 play on that history and hold out hope that the future persecution of the Jews under Antiochus would be only a temporary oppression, followed by conquest and restoration. The people of God, therefore, needed to persevere in full confidence of God's faithfulness and power. Those who persevered would be "blessed" (Dan. 12:12). In Joshua 14, shortly after Caleb's <span id="page-168-3"></span><span id="page-168-1"></span>reference to forty-five years in Joshua 14:10, "Joshua *blessed* him, and he gave Hebron to Caleb the son of Jephunneh for an inheritance" (v. 13).

<span id="page-168-8"></span>12:13 With the divinely revealed assurance that Israel would regain its inheritance after a temporary oppression, Daniel heard one final command and promise: "Go your way till the end. And you shall rest and shall stand in your allotted place at the end of the days." Daniel was to live out the rest of his days in faithfulness, "the end" referring to his death. There is no report in the book that Daniel ever returned to Jerusalem, so it is reasonable to assume that he, in his eighties by this point, died in Babylon.

<span id="page-168-7"></span><span id="page-168-6"></span>But Daniel's death outside the Promised Land would not exclude him from inheriting what God had in store for his people. Daniel was told he would "rest" (die) but afterward "shall stand in your allotted place at the end of the days." If Daniel rested in death, standing was a promise of resurrection. The good news of resurrection hope (cf. v. 2) applied to him. He would share in resurrection life, shining as the stars forever (v. 3). The language of an "allotted place" was used in Joshua 14–21 as the tribes received portions of the Promised Land (cf. Josh. 15:1; 16:1; 17:1), and thus Daniel was included among those who would inherit all that God promised his people. Allusion to the "allotment" theme in Joshua strengthens the claim that the previous verse (Dan. 12:12) had as background that section of Joshua as well (cf. Josh. 14:10–13).

<span id="page-168-5"></span><span id="page-168-4"></span><span id="page-168-2"></span><span id="page-168-0"></span>The ending of the book of Daniel is especially appropriate in light of its beginning. In the first chapter, Nebuchadnezzar deported Daniel and his friends (in 605 BC) from their home in Judah to the foreign land of Babylon. In the final chapter, even though Daniel still dwelled in the land of Judean exiles, he was promised resurrection and inheritance. He would rest in death but would rise with the saints to everlasting life at the end of days. This book, which reported harrowing tales of threat and deliverance, extolled the God of all nations, who holds in his hand every breath of every creature everywhere. Exiled as a teenager and now an old man purified by trial, Daniel knew firsthand the might and majesty of the world's true Lord. His many visions proved that God's wise timetable was the track of the trains of worldly kingdoms. Rulers rise and fall, nations come and go, but the course of history will unfold to its appointed goal: the display of God's glory in salvation through judgment.80

## *Response*

The contents of the book of Daniel addressed readers during a particularly dark period of Israel's history and prepared them for future tribulation as well, when dark paths would again lie before them. The book intertwines accounts of God's power to judge and to deliver, opening with teenagers going into exile and ending with the promise of the dead coming up from the dust. The book shows us

<sup>80</sup> For a biblical-theological treatment of God's glory being the goal of all he does, see James M. Hamilton Jr., *God's Glory in Salvation through Judgment: A Biblical Theology* (Wheaton, IL: Crossway, 2010), 37–65, 553–563.

that God keeps his promises, even amid the changing of empires, the succession of kings, and the span of many centuries. We have every reason to look Godward with unwavering confidence. The twelve chapters of this book exalt the Most High God, whose purposes never fail.

The stories and visions in the book of Daniel all declare to the reader: you can trust God. Daniel and his Judean companions serve as examples to those who walk by faith. But their faithfulness, no matter how great and admirable, was a shadow compared to the substance of Jesus' person and work. Jesus was the consummate faithful Israelite, speaking with wisdom and being the very Wisdom and Word of God. Rather than seeking understanding, he spoke with authority and revelation. The furnace of the cross and the den of the tomb were no match for the power of God, for on the third day his death was undone by a glorious resurrection. He was the triumphant stone that rivaled all other kingdoms, and he boldly announced that all authority in heaven and on earth belonged to him (Matt. 28:18). His death sealed the new covenant, which ushered in the jubilee of jubilees, for he—the anointed one—had finished the transgression, put an end to sin, and atoned for iniquity (cf. Dan. 9:24).

<span id="page-169-3"></span><span id="page-169-2"></span><span id="page-169-1"></span>There is none like Jesus, though previous people, institutions, and events prepared his way by serving as types and shadows and signs. He inaugurated God's kingdom and is the firstfruits of resurrection for all who believe. His risen life is a guarantee that all who sleep in the dust of death will also awake, believers rising to everlasting life and the wicked to shame and contempt (Dan. 12:2; John 5:29). We can trust the God of the book of Daniel because Jesus, the "son of man," is now exalted over all things and is subjecting all enemies under his feet (1 Cor. 15:25). Jesus the true and better Adam will establish dominion in the world and overcome every opposition, visible or invisible. He has triumphed over sin, Satan, and every evil principality. He is worthy of our trust, worship, and unwavering allegiance.

<span id="page-169-4"></span><span id="page-169-0"></span>All hail the power of Jesus' name, for only in his name is there salvation for sinners and hope for the saints. Let us also go our way like Daniel to the "rest" of death when our days are done. But we who sleep in the dust shall awake, and shall rise to shine. On that glorious day of resurrection, we will receive an inheritance of new heavens and a new earth, and with new eyes we will behold the truth of Daniel 7:14: "His dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away, and his kingdom one that shall not be destroyed."

# HOSEA

*George M. Schwab Sr.*

## INTRODUCTION TO HOSEA

### *Overview*

"The Book of Hosea is the most scandalous book of the Bible." When I say this to Christians, they nod knowingly, readily accepting the premise. I suppose they are thinking of the escapades of Gomer, the prophet's nymphomaniac wife. But that is not what I mean at all. Instead I am referring to the book's theology. The precarious marriage of Hosea and Gomer is used to picture the broken covenant between Yahweh and Israel. The scandal is in the unbelievable lengths to which the metaphor is pushed. Like a jealous husband, Yahweh is portrayed as having conflicted thoughts. He wants to punish Israel, but he also tenderly wants to take her back.

There is much more to Hosea than that, however. If one wants to read an OT book that shows the heart of God, this is the book. His people care nothing for him. If they believed their prosperity came from him, they would not mistreat their fellow Israelites to advance themselves. They would not enter into foreign treaties in order to feel secure. They would not foolishly bow down to wretched homemade gods to thank them for what their covenant Lord has given. What must Yahweh do to get their attention? What will it take to make things right? These are issues the book of Hosea explores. In doing so, it puts the passionate heart of God on clear display.

### <span id="page-173-0"></span>*Title and Author*

The book bears the name of the prophet Hosea, son of Beeri, to whom Yahweh imparted his urgent message at a critical time—during the last generation of the northern kingdom of Israel, before final judgment fell. The word of the prophet held out to them their last chance for salvation. In addition to being given prophetic oracles, Hosea was also called to image God—to reflect in his own person the distress and grief and exasperation that Israel's God felt toward Israel.

<span id="page-173-2"></span><span id="page-173-1"></span>While the book makes clear that its main message was given to Hosea (1:1), it does not identify who wrote it down in its final form. Because chapter 3 is written in the first person, it seems plausible to suggest that Hosea himself wrote it, though this is the only chapter of the book in which he speaks in the first person. As far as who recorded the rest of the book, suggestions range from Hosea himself to disciples who copied down his messages.

Another question concerns how many of these oracles Hosea actually publicly preached. We are not told where or when these messages were proclaimed publicly, making it hard to know if they were. It is thus possible that this literary work was always just that—a written (rather than spoken) appeal. (It is convenient, however, to refer to Hosea as "preaching" his sermons.) It seems plausible to suggest that his messages were carried in written form to the southern kingdom of Judah, where they were cherished alongside other inspired works. The book's divine character was recognized there, and it was eventually incorporated into the prophetic collection of the Bible.

## *Date and Occasion*

According to the title, Hosea's ministry of receiving and conveying the word of God took place from the reign of King Uzziah to the reign of King Hezekiah in Judah, and during the reign of King Jeroboam II in Israel—roughly from before 753 to after 728 BC. During that time Israel transitioned from peaceable prosperity to the verge of unrecoverable ruin. Israel's capital city, Samaria, was destroyed in 722 BC, just a few years after Hosea issued his last warnings. Hosea saw the day of reckoning looming closer and closer and sought to warn the people to escape their doom, but instead they spurned the word of God and swaggered along their obstinate ways toward inevitable destruction and death. As dreadful as this was for Hosea to endure, it was even more painful for God.

## *Setting and Audience*

The book of Hosea deals almost entirely with the northern tribes of Israel. This is its first audience. If the book had remained the sole possession of the north, however, it would have perished with Samaria. At some point, faithful scribes must have brought it south to Judah, perhaps as they fled the coming judgment. His warnings then served as a template for how Judah should have comported herself in relation to her God. Indeed, Judah is mentioned ten times in the book.

In the end, Judah also perished as a nation. But unlike in Israel, a remnant of Judah survived to continue as God's people. This tiny community owned and internalized the prophecy of Hosea. The word of God did not fall to the ground but found a place with a new generation of faithful worshipers. They eventually grouped Hosea with eleven other shorter books of prophecy into a single collection, which today is called the Minor Prophets.

## *Theology of Hosea; Its Relationship to the Rest of the Bible and to Christ*

## THE IMPORTANCE OF FAITHFULNESS TO THE COVENANT

<span id="page-174-0"></span>In the book of Exodus, the Lord enters into covenant relationship with the nation of Israel (Exodus 20–24). Generally speaking, "the word 'covenant' (*berit*) refers to God's relationship with another entity that is initiated by God and established by his solemn word (promise or oath)."1 God's covenant with Israel was to be much

<sup>1</sup> J. Andrew Dearman, *The Book of Hosea*, NICOT (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 2010), 51.

more personal than a contract and much more permanent than an ordinary relationship.2

In light of this covenant relationship, the primary task of a prophet in the OT was not to predict the future but to enforce this covenant among the Lord's people. Prophets "considered themselves spokespersons for Yahweh, who through them called his people *back* to obedience to the covenant he had given them many centuries before, and reminded them of its curses and blessings, which Yahweh had sworn to honor."3

Like the other prophets, Hosea frequently reminds the people of these covenant curses and blessings as he calls the nation to turn from other gods and to the Lord. In terms of blessing, in several passages Hosea speaks of future bliss, a day in which the Lord's people will be restored in their relationship to him and enjoy peace and prosperity in their land, under his loving and watchful eye (Hos. 1:10–2:1; 2:14–23; 3:5; 6:1–3; etc.).

<span id="page-175-1"></span><span id="page-175-0"></span>However, the immediate focus of the book of Hosea is on the coming curses (2:9–13; 4:1–6; 5:1–7; etc.). And unlike blessings, which seem to be coming at a time in the distant future, the curses are spoken of as being just around the corner. The reason is not hard to see: by worshiping other gods, Israel has been so unfaithful to the covenant that the punishments for covenant disobedience are about to break out against them.

As Israel's history continues, the covenant curses do come to fruition, seen most graphically in the covenant curse of exile that fell on Hosea's audience—the northern kingdom of Israel—in 722 BC. Those who abandon covenant faithfulness can expect covenant curse.

<span id="page-175-3"></span>The NT bears similar warnings for the people of God. The book of Hebrews looks back to examples of faithlessness in the history of the nation of Israel and the terrible curses that came as a result, exhorting those who claim to be Christians not to imitate Israel's example, lest they too suffer God's judgment (Heb. 3:1–4:13). God is fully aware when faith is not real. Hebrews is particularly adamant that turning away from Jesus is the supreme act of faithlessness and will be met with a fearful response: "Anyone who has set aside the law of Moses dies without mercy on the evidence of two or three witnesses. How much worse punishment, do you think, will be deserved by the one who has trampled underfoot the Son of God, and has profaned the blood of the covenant by which he was sanctified, and has outraged the Spirit of grace? . . . It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God" (Heb. 10:28–29, 31). Hosea's call to repentance and covenant faithfulness is thus not simply for a bygone era; it is a message that rings with equal importance today.

#### <span id="page-175-4"></span>THE LORD'S PEOPLE AS HIS "HOUSEHOLD"

<span id="page-175-2"></span>In Hosea, the Lord's relationship to Israel is sometimes compared to that of a husband and wife (chs. 1–3, esp. 2:16, 19–20); at other times, it is compared to

<sup>2</sup> Cf. Timothy Keller, *Preaching: Communicating Faith in an Age of Skepticism* (New York: Viking, 2015), 104.

<sup>3</sup> Douglas Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, WBC (Waco, TX: Word, 1987), xxxii.

<span id="page-176-0"></span>that of a parent and child (1:10; 11:1, 3–4, 10). Both of these metaphors come from the realm of the household.4 In the ancient world, the household was the basic building block of society, and faithfulness to the relationships within the household was of fundamental importance. Thus Hosea's household metaphors would have been particularly powerful ways to underscore Israel's treachery. But Hosea does not use these metaphors only to convict; he uses them to encourage as well, especially as he speaks of the Lord's commitment of love and faithfulness toward the members of *his* household.

<span id="page-176-4"></span>What must not be missed is that the Lord is the one who takes the initiative with his wayward children. He is the one who is faithful, even amid their unfaithfulness. He continues to show himself to be the God of mercy, compassion, and love. He shows this above all in sending Jesus, the one through whom he reconciles his creation to himself. It is in Jesus that we now experience adoption as children of God (Eph. 1:5); it is in relationship to Jesus that we are made a bride washed clean, as he is the groom who lays down his life that we might be saved (Eph. 5:23, 25–27). It is in Jesus that God restores mankind to his household, returning prodigal sons and daughters to the loving embrace of their father.

#### <span id="page-176-5"></span>GOD LOVES HIS PEOPLE BUT MUST PUNISH EVIL

<span id="page-176-1"></span>In keeping with the metaphor of the household, the picture of the Lord that emerges in Hosea is of a God who loves his people as a husband loves his wife, or as a parent loves his child, but who also must punish their evil. Seeing his people's faithlessness, he laments, "What shall I do with you, O Ephraim? What shall I do with you, O Judah?" (Hos. 6:4). This is the cry of a conflicted parent who loves his faithless child and yet, because of that love, must bring discipline to bear. The thought is repeated in 11:8: "How can I give you up, O Ephraim? How can I hand you over, O Israel? . . . My heart recoils within me; my compassion grows warm and tender."

<span id="page-176-2"></span>How does the Lord reconcile this deep love for his people with the need to bring justice to bear for the evil they have done? These two passions of God that stand out so clearly in Hosea find their ultimate resolution at the cross of Jesus Christ. There the just punishment for sin and the deep love of God meet: "God shows his love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us" (Rom. 5:8). The book of Hosea thus yearns for the cross and seeks Jesus to fulfill it.

#### <span id="page-176-3"></span>*Preaching from Hosea*

Throughout this commentary, the Response sections provide ideas and suggestions for how Hosea's various passages apply to today's church. There is one aspect of the book, however, of which it may be helpful to speak more broadly: its use of imagery.

The book of Hosea is rich in its use of images. Sometimes the prophet uses similes, comparing one object to another using the word "like" or "as": "What shall I do with you, O Ephraim? What shall I do with you, O Judah? Your love is like a

<sup>4</sup> Dearman, *Hosea*, 44; cf. his fuller discussion on 44–50.

<span id="page-177-2"></span><span id="page-177-1"></span>morning cloud, like the dew that goes early away" (Hos. 6:4). Or again, "Ephraim is like a dove, silly and without sense, calling to Egypt, going to Assyria" (7:11). At other times the prophet uses metaphors, comparing one object to another without using "like" or "as." In Hosea, God is a husband who expects fidelity from his spouse (2:16). He is a lion who will easily kill and leave his prey for dead (5:14). He is a nurturing parent, taking Ephraim tenderly in his arms (11:3).

<span id="page-177-4"></span><span id="page-177-0"></span>Images are used for various reasons. First, they allow a great deal of information to be conveyed using few words. Comparing God to a parent can be done in a few words, and yet this comparison teaches a great deal concerning who God is and how we are to relate to him. Second, images communicate powerfully. By using objects and events from our everyday lives, images resonate deeply with our hearts and minds. Third, images help us to understand what is otherwise incomprehensible. God is the great unknowable Being, infinite in his nature and person. He thus often uses images—taken from our finite world—to help us understand what he is like.

<span id="page-177-3"></span>In preaching passages that make use of images, there are two dangers to be avoided. The first is to sanitize an image, to blunt its force, because it sometimes feels too raw. For example, in Hosea 11 the Lord compares himself to a parent who is conflicted about the evil behavior of his child, Israel. On the one hand, he knows they deserve severe discipline. At the same time, he loves them, and this pains his heart: "How can I give you up, O Ephraim? How can I hand you over, O Israel? . . . My heart recoils within me; my compassion grows warm and tender" (11:8). Such emotion and passion does not always fit into the categories we use to describe God, but we must not bend the image to fit our categories; we must bend our categories to fit the image. In this case, because of the extent of God's love for his people, he feels like a conflicted parent who knows punishment is due and yet seeks to show mercy instead. This is the God Hosea is describing.

<span id="page-177-5"></span>The second danger to avoid is to read too much into an image. When an image is used to compare one object to another, there is usually a very limited point of comparison, and the text itself typically makes the comparison clear. In Hosea 11 God is a parent to Israel and, like a parent, is conflicted when he must punish his child; this is the point of the comparison, as the text itself emphasizes. But there are other things that are true about parents that are not true of God: they can be short-tempered or unjust, they have a partner with whom they birthed the child, they need their sleep if they are going to parent well, and so forth. All of these things are true when it comes to parents, but none should be mentioned when speaking of God as a parent in Hosea 11.

In short, there are three questions that are important to ask of any image: What is the person/thing/event being compared? What person/thing/event is it being compared to? What point of similarity is being made? It is the last question that is especially important to answer, and this will require close attention to the image's context. But when we answer these questions well, we have the key to unlocking the image and making its meaning clear.

## HOSEA 1:1

<span id="page-180-0"></span>1 The word of the Lord that came to Hosea, the son of Beeri, in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, and in the days of Jeroboam the son of Joash, king of Israel.

#### *Section Outline*

I. Title: Uzziah–Hezekiah, Jeroboam II (1:1)

#### *Comment*

1:1 Although Hosea was a prophet to the northern tribes, curiously this title lists only one king from the north but four from the south. Other northern kings of Hosea's time included Zechariah, Shallum, Menahem, Pekahiah, and Pekah. These were generally short-lived administrations in which the usual mode of advancement was assassination. To omit them from the title seems enigmatic, as if the tacit message of the editor is that these unnamed kings were illegitimate and that before Samaria actually fell, the story of God's people had already passed exclusively to Judah. Note the comments in the Introduction on Date and Occasion.

<span id="page-180-1"></span>In a similar way, God later removed idolatrous kings and corrupt prophets from Jerusalem and replaced them after the exile with a new set of leaders—such as Ezra and Nehemiah—who were committed to the covenant of Moses. Later still, Jesus told his disciples that they would replace the current spiritual leaders of the Jews. In the kingdom, they and not the Sanhedrin would rule (Matt. 19:28). Of course, on the day of Pentecost the Spirit came upon Jesus' disciples, and the NT church was founded on the apostles and prophets (Eph. 2:20). The religious leadership of that generation of Israel had no role in God's kingdom without the Spirit of Jesus to transform them.

<span id="page-180-2"></span>The true King of Israel is the one who always keeps covenant and was faithful in all things unto death: Jesus. The history of these kings of Israel and Judah, and their leaving-much-to-be-desired leadership, presses forward to and yearns for Jesus—the Word of God sent to a sinful people.

#### *Section Overview*

This chapter introduces a metaphor that is foundational to the book of Hosea and serves as the Minor Prophets' introduction to the relationship between God and Israel. The prophet is called to image Yahweh by marrying a woman who will break his heart. Not only does he marry a sexually deviant woman, but his children, whose paternity is disputed, are eventually disavowed—just as the Lord here threatens to do with Israel.

But just as Yahweh reaches the peak of his repudiation, claiming to have run out of patience with the northern kingdom, refusing to save them, and disinheriting them, he performs a turnaround practically in midsentence, promising to take them back and bless them.

This opening of the book reveals the conflicted heart of God. He is portrayed exactly like a betrayed husband. He wants to punish his unfaithful wife—but he still loves her and desires to take her back. Something about the feelings of a betrayed husband communicates Yahweh's disposition toward Israel.

	- C. Lo-ruhama (1:6–7)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-182-0"></span>1:2–3 Yahweh commands Hosea to marry a "wife of whoredom [*zenunim*]." This Hebrew term indicates illicit sexual behavior. Moses uses the word in Genesis 38:24 to refer to Tamar's posing as a shrine prostitute in order to entice Judah. Hosea's wife, Gomer, bears this label, not necessarily because she is a prostitute but because she is (or will become) a woman characterized by sexual infidelity.

<span id="page-182-4"></span>The ESV translates the last phrase of Hosea 1:2, "for the land commits great whoredom by forsaking the Lord." The Hebrew idiom woodenly reads, "for the land commits great whoredom from after the Lord." This is the first of a series of expressions in Hosea where God puts himself in the place of a forsaken human lover (cf. comment on 2:2–5 [esp. v. 5]). Hosea does as Yahweh instructed and marries Gomer, who then bears him a son (1:3).

<span id="page-182-8"></span><span id="page-182-6"></span><span id="page-182-1"></span>1:4–5 Hosea's firstborn is named "Jezreel." This name is revealed to be a prophetic judgment: the "blood of Jezreel" will be visited upon the house of Jehu, and the power of Israel will be broken. "Blood of Jezreel" refers to the violent acts that took place there. In order to acquire Naboth's vineyard in Jezreel, Jezebel orchestrated his murder. Because of this, Elijah pronounced a terrible judgment against her and her husband, Ahab (1 Kings 21:17–24). Jehu struck down their heir, King Joram, and disposed of his body on Naboth's land in Jezreel. He then killed another descendant of Ahab—King Ahaziah of Judah. At Jezreel, Jezebel was thrown out of a window, her blood spattering against the wall on her way down, and she was trampled by horses (2 Kings 9:30–37). Finally, all seventy sons of Ahab were killed and their heads piled up at the entrance of the Jezreel gate (2 Kings 10:1–11). This is the "blood of Jezreel."

<span id="page-182-3"></span><span id="page-182-2"></span>There is some debate concerning the phrase "I will punish the house of Jehu for the blood of Jezreel." The Hebrew wording for this phrase is "I will visit the <span id="page-183-0"></span>blood of Jezreel on the house of Jehu," which may be understood in two different ways. The word for "blood" can refer to "bloodguilt" (Lev. 20:9), so that the sense would be that the Lord will punish the house of Jehu on account of all the blood they shed at Jezreel. This does create some tension, however, since the Lord elsewhere says to Jehu, "Because you have done well in carrying out what is right in my eyes, and have done to the house of Ahab according to all that was in my heart, your sons of the fourth generation shall sit on the throne of Israel" (2 Kings 10:30). In other words, this approach would mean that what is praised in 2 Kings is condemned here.

<span id="page-183-3"></span><span id="page-183-2"></span>One possible explanation of the tension argues that Hosea is addressing a different element of the massacre than does 2 Kings 10. In 2 Kings, the emphasis is on Jehu's going to war against Baal, thereby cleansing the land from his horrible influence. This is commendable. But God did not sanction the bloodthirstiness of how this was accomplished, and in Hosea, the emphasis is on the way in which this violence was an offense against the Lord.

<span id="page-183-1"></span>A second approach, which avoids this tension, is simply to say that the prophecy against the house of Jehu (specifically, King Zechariah) is not a punishment for the carnage perpetuated by Jehu at all. The word for "blood" can refer not only to "bloodguilt" (Lev. 20:9) but also to "bloodshed" (1 Kings 2:5), so that the sense of the verse would be, "I will visit the bloodshed of Jezreel on the house of Jehu": Jehu's wicked house will meet the same kind of violent end that it inflicted on Ahab's house at Jezreel.

<span id="page-183-5"></span>In either case, Hosea 1:5 makes clear that God will bring an end to the northern kingdom. He will break their "bow"—their military power. He will be toyed with no longer. The Valley of Jezreel, where the dynasty of Jeroboam got its start, will be emblematic of its violent end.6

<span id="page-183-6"></span>1:6–7 Gomer next gave birth to a girl, whom Yahweh named "No Mercy" (*Lo-ruhama*). Gone are the days of forgiveness and mercy to Israel. The tenderness one would expect of a parent toward a child is now gone. This kind of mercy, says Yahweh, will no longer characterize his treatment of Israel.

<span id="page-183-7"></span>The southern tribe of Judah, however, will continue to enjoy God's favor (v. 7). He will save them "by the Lord their God," not through military means. Soon after Hosea's ministry, the Assyrian army did destroy Samaria. But when they came up against King Hezekiah in Jerusalem, they were soundly defeated without an arrow being shot (2 Kings 17–19). The promise came true: for Israel there was no compassion, but for Judah there was supernatural salvation.

<span id="page-183-8"></span><span id="page-183-4"></span>1:8–9 Again Gomer gave birth, and this time her baby son was named "Not My People" (*Lo-ammi* ). The reason for this name is explained in a sort of negative covenant formula. Instead of the usual "I will be their God and they will be my people," the Lord declares, "You are not my people, and I am not your God." The

<sup>6</sup> Thomas McComiskey calls this the "ultimate irony" (*Minor Prophets* [Grand Rapids, MI: Baker, 1992], 1:21).

Hebrew can also be read, "I am not I am for you."7 Thus the divine covenantal name for God is no longer appropriate for Israel to use. He is not theirs; his ever-present reality, his "I am–ness," is now inaccessible to them.

<span id="page-184-3"></span>1:10–11 At this point, an oracle breaks out that asserts the exact opposite of what has just been said.8 The reversals are striking. Instead of disowning Israel, as he has just done, God now blesses them with the promise of great numbers, like the immeasurable sand of the seashore. Those who had just been declared "not my people" are now named "Children of the living God." While Israel and Judah had been sharply distinguished just three verses earlier, now together they will unite under one head, perhaps a future Davidic king (v. 11). Thus this oracle overrides the earlier point made by the naming of Hosea's children. Everything said against them is taken back. And this joyous day will happen where else but in Jezreel, which means "God sows"! Israel will once again be a bountiful harvest (cf. 2:23).

<span id="page-184-6"></span><span id="page-184-5"></span><span id="page-184-4"></span>2:1 Therefore it follows that they will be called "You are my people" and "You have received mercy." After being alienated from Yahweh, they will be restored. In this promise of restoration, God's own heart is on display. He desires to withhold forgiveness and mercy because of their infidelity—but he also seeks to provide these graces. He wants to punish Israel, but also to take her back.

### *Response*

This first chapter of Hosea—featuring children given awful names in order to make theological points—starts with judgment and ends with grace. The phrases "I am your God," "you are my people," or some form of these are found many times in Hosea (1:9; 2:23; 3:5; 4:12; 13:4; etc.). This is relational language that echoes the relationship between both husband and wife and father and son.9

<span id="page-184-2"></span>In chapter 1, God threatens to divorce/disown Israel but also envisions a future forgiveness and restoration. This future is connected with taking on a new "head"—presumably of Davidic lineage. It is not hard for a Christian to see in this a prophecy of Jesus, who personally fulfills the prophecy on behalf of Israel. Jesus on the cross suffered the ultimate punishment on behalf of his people, showing that even the exile of Judah and their subsequent restoration did not suffice to atone for their sins. Often prophecies such as this, which originally addressed the nation, are appropriated and adopted by the nation's anointed King, the Messiah, who accomplished redemption for them. Another example would be Daniel 7, where Jesus ("one like a son of man"; Dan. 7:13) individually endures what all the saints corporately are said to face.

<span id="page-184-1"></span><span id="page-184-0"></span>To Paul, the meaning of this prophecy is a matter of election. God can choose to elect even undeserving Gentiles. In the light of Pentecost and the subsequent

<sup>7</sup> Carl Ehrlich, "The Text of Hosea 1:9," *JBL* 104/1 (1985): 13–19.

<sup>8</sup> James Nogalski labels this "YHWH changes YHWH's Mind" (James Nogalski, *The Book of the Twelve: Hosea– Jonah* [Macon, GA: Smyth & Helwys, 2011], 43). The contrast with the preceding verse is so strong that in Hebrew the chapter break occurs here.

<span id="page-185-0"></span>unfolding of the history of the church, in which God sent his Spirit into the hearts of non-Jews, a whole new vista of meaning opened up for Paul. Those of whom it was said "not my people" are now declared to be "Children of the living God" (cf. Hos. 1:10; Rom. 9:22–26). This refers to Gentiles. Paul sees in this a prophecy of the Gentiles' coming to faith through Jesus. God surprisingly elects some for salvation who were previously enemies of God.

<span id="page-185-8"></span><span id="page-185-2"></span>What then should be the Christian's response to this? One lesson that can be drawn is that Christians should live faithfully as God's people. God broke off dead branches to make room for the Gentile church. Only by continuing in his kindness will a believer continue to enjoy the great fruits and blessings of this salvation. So we must seek humility, put off pride, and revere this God who brooks no rivals for our hearts (Rom. 11:17–24).

## OVERVIEW OF HOSEA 2:2–3:5

<span id="page-185-1"></span>After the introductory chapter 1, this first major section begins with a repeated call to "plead" with God's ex-wife, Israel (2:2–5). The Hebrew word for "plead" is *rib* and often indicates strife or contention in a legal sense. Chapter 2 thus begins with an oracle detailing the exact complaint the Lord has against Israel and what he will do about it.10

<span id="page-185-4"></span><span id="page-185-3"></span>But it moves on from there, envisioning a time in which God will tenderly take Israel back after punishing her (2:6–23). Again, the conflicted passions of God are vibrantly expressed: the urges to punish her (2:6–15) and to win her back (2:16–23).

<span id="page-185-6"></span><span id="page-185-5"></span>In the final section of this passage (3:1–5), the prophet's own life becomes an object lesson one last time to illustrate spiritual realities. He covenants once more with a woman who seems pathologically incapable of good behavior. This reflects the extremity of God's commitment to Israel. Apparently this woman had suffered consequences for her poor choices and actions, but Hosea, at great cost to himself, redeems her.

<span id="page-185-7"></span><sup>10</sup> The same word (*rib*) occurs at the beginning of other major sections; cf. 4:1 and 12:2.

## HOSEA 2:2–5

- **<sup>2</sup>** "Plead with your mother, plead for she is not my wife, and I am not her husband that she put away her whoring from her face, and her adultery from between her breasts;
- **<sup>3</sup>** lest I strip her naked and make her as in the day she was born, and make her like a wilderness, and make her like a parched land, and kill her with thirst.
- **<sup>4</sup>** Upon her children also I will have no mercy, because they are children of whoredom.
- **<sup>5</sup>** For their mother has played the whore; she who conceived them has acted shamefully. For she said, 'I will go after my lovers, who give me my bread and my water, my wool and my flax, my oil and my drink.' "

## *Section Overview*

In this oracle, God vents his epic fury against his cheating spouse. He vividly goes over the details in his mind, rehearsing what he will do to her unless (until?) she shows remorse. He will strip her of all her gifts. He will publicly shame her. He will make her like a barren desert and kill her with thirst. He is a very jealous husband, justifiably full of hot and ardent wrath, having been cheated on and taken for granted and scorned for the last time. It is unconscionable that she has actually credited his rivals for the things he gave her. He has had it with her! Her penalty is destruction, and he relishes the thought of executing her sentence. Historically this did happen to Israel (2 Kings 18:9–12), and, as predicted, there was none to save her (Hos. 2:10).

## <span id="page-186-2"></span><span id="page-186-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- III. The Case of the Jilted Husband (2:2–3:5)
	- A. Plead with Your Mother (2:2–5)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-186-1"></span>2:2–5 The first major section begins with the adjuration to "Plead." This is meant in a legal sense, as in pleading a case in court. The command is naturally understood as being directed to the Israelites—or, at the least, to any faithful Israelites who remain. The one they are to bring charges against is their "mother," which many commentators agree is also a reference to Israel.11 Thus "Plead with your mother, plead" is a call for the faithful in the land (if there are any) to plead with the rest of the people. In this regard, it may be read as a call for all faithful believers, in whatever age, to join with the prophet in condemning all who hypocritically or ignorantly perpetrate ungodly and unethical behaviors in the name of God.

God repudiates Israel; no longer can she claim to be his "wife." Once more she (Samaria and therefore all Israel) is called to "put away" or "turn aside" from her deviant sexual behavior: fornication and "adultery" from "between her breasts" (v. 2), a quite explicit sexual image. This imagery continues into verse 3, where the threat is that she will be stripped naked and exposed as on the day she was born.

The next image has nothing to do with the female body. She will be abandoned like a desert, parched and barren. Note that Yahweh intends to kill her, horribly and painfully. This is a death sentence—assuming the people will not turn back to him. Death by neglect, death by drought, death by exposure, death by slow dehydration in the desert.

<span id="page-187-3"></span><span id="page-187-2"></span><span id="page-187-1"></span><span id="page-187-0"></span>Repeating the message of 1:8, God declares that he will not show compassion on the children of spiritual adultery (2:4). Samaria and all Israel shamefully and profligately pursue lovers other than their God (v. 5). Yahweh's first accusation was that Israel did not pursue him, they whored "from after" him (1:2 AT). Now, this language is employed to designate whom she did "go after": many other lovers. What truly outrages Yahweh is that Israel credits these lovers—who are unnamed here but who later we learn include Baal (2:8)—with all of the good things that he has given her. This simply cannot stand. God's honor demands the ultimate sanction. By the time God is finished, no one will be able to claim that Baal has ever benefited Israel.

#### <span id="page-187-4"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-187-8"></span><span id="page-187-7"></span><span id="page-187-5"></span>The rage of God against betrayal is vividly portrayed in this section. The NT goes even further concerning this aspect of God: the whole unbelieving world awaits a lake of fire and final judgment (Rev. 20:15). But the NT also shows the unbelievably excessive grace and love of the Father in that the King of Israel took responsibility for his people and willingly assumed their debt (Col. 2:14). He even took upon himself their thirst (John 19:28). Thus this terrible penalty is paid for all who are his. It is therefore vitally important for sinners to identify with Jesus instead of with any other savior or pretender such as Baal, if they are to avoid the just punishment their sins deserve (Acts 4:12).

**<sup>15</sup>** And there I will give her her vineyards and make the Valley of Achor*<sup>2</sup>* a door of hope. And there she shall answer as in the days of her youth, as at the time when she came out of the land of Egypt."

1Hebrew *your* 2*Achor* means *trouble*; compare Joshua 7:26

## *Section Overview*

In contrast to the previous section, in which God declared an unmitigated sentence against Israel of judgment and death, he now wants her back. It will be difficult, but in the end he will restore her to himself.

## *Section Outline*

- III.B. Harsh Measures (2:6–15)
	- 1. I'll Hedge Her Up! (2:6–8)
	- 2. I'll Take It All Back! (2:9–13)
	- 3. It Will Be Like It Was Before (2:14–15)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-189-1"></span>2:6–8 This pericope (unit of text) captures an entirely different mood of Israel's covenant partner. Gone is the language of hostility and punishment. His emotions suddenly turn toward a strategy of "tough love" in order to win her back. It is as if the previous paragraph — seething with enmity and reveling in comeuppance — has been forgotten. Now the goal is to restore the relationship. The sudden shifts in mood match the sudden shifts in feeling a husband might experience toward a faithless wife. This conveys something true about God's attitude toward Israel. He is not portrayed as cool and calculating; his emotions are deeply involved.

<span id="page-189-0"></span>God plans to restrict Israel's freedom uncomfortably. She will experience a decreasing array of choices until her ability to connect with Yahweh's rivals is beyond her reach (vv. 6–7). Think of Israel as a donkey, hemmed in by walls and thorns so as to be unable to follow its natural instincts. In the same way, God will economically, politically, and militarily render the northern kingdom powerless to derive benefit from gods or political alliances.

<span id="page-189-3"></span>Her addiction to other gods will not save her, nor will the nations help. She has not acknowledged that good things come from God—land and water as well as grain, wine, oil, wool, and flax (vv. 8–9). Yahweh has also provided silver and gold, which she has put to the service of Baal (v. 8). Such is the profundity of her ignorance.

<span id="page-189-4"></span><span id="page-189-2"></span>But she will realize that she was better off with her "first husband" and will return to him (v. 7). This is the first of twenty-three times that the word "return" (Hb. *shub*) occurs in Hosea (e.g., 3:5; 5:4; 6:1). It often connotes repentance, a turning of heart and mind back to Yahweh.

<span id="page-190-4"></span><span id="page-190-3"></span>2:9–13 Like the previous unit, this one also begins with "therefore." Here, God details his plan to hedge Israel in and cause her to return (cf. vv. 6–7). Through a painful process she will be separated from her gods. She will seek them but not find them. She will lose the benefits for which she trusted them. Only after she gives up on their provision will she consider returning to Yahweh.

<span id="page-190-0"></span>The text of verse 9 reads literally, "Therefore I will turn [*shub*] and I will take back . . ." Here is an example of God's turning from one stated intention to another (cf. 1:8–11; 5:14–6:2; 11:9; 14:4). He will systematically take from Israel all of the good things that had beguiled her. If her grain and wine cannot be separated from Baal, then the grain and wine will have to go. By taking away (Hb. "rescuing") Israel's wool and flax, her folly will be exposed. Naked she will stand, with no reason or evidence that her faith in Baal was justified (v. 10). He will "rescue" goods from her grasp (v. 9), but no one will "rescue" her from *his* grasp (v. 10). Her "lovers" will stand silently by as spectators, unable to act, as Yahweh exposes her shame. Such will be the extent of the rough intervention she needs.

<span id="page-190-6"></span><span id="page-190-5"></span>In addition, God declares, "I will put an end to all her mirth" (v. 11). The Hebrew phrase is, woodenly, "I will turn all her mirth"—the word *shub* again. An idolatrous thread is woven throughout the fabric of Israelite society. Something of Baal and the fertility cult touches every religious event—even those done in the name of Yahweh. Thus, it all has to go. Israel must be separated with finality from this terrible addiction. She must no longer think of her lovers. The benefits she believed came from her gods must be removed. Yahweh has to amputate in order to save the patient.

<span id="page-190-7"></span>God will (woodenly glossed) "visit the days of the Baals upon her" (v. 13), meaning the guilt accumulated by her false worship will be punished. Indeed, her faithlessness is metaphorically described as dressing up, putting on jewelry, and going after other lovers while forgetting the Lord. God desires her to love and pursue him exclusively (v. 13). The harsh measures are necessary if he is to "turn" this difficult people back to himself.

<span id="page-190-8"></span><span id="page-190-2"></span>2:14–15 This passage also begins with "therefore" (cf. 2:6, 9). God will allure Israel once more. He will "speak tenderly to her" (lit., "speak to her heart"). It will be as when he redeemed Israel from bondage in Egypt, brought her to the wilderness, and covenanted with her.

<span id="page-190-9"></span>The Valley of Achor (v. 15) is important in Joshua 7. Israel had been defeated due to one man's disobedience. Once the sin was punished—requiring the man's death with his family at the Valley of Achor—Israel went on to victory. Hosea 2:15 references this event and reveals that the site will become something different, an entryway into a positive future. This is parallel to how Jezreel, a place of judgment, became a symbol of future blessing as well (1:11).

<span id="page-190-1"></span>On that day, Israel will "answer"—respond—like the generation redeemed from Egypt. At Sinai, Yahweh covenanted with them. The future relationship between God and Israel will be like that all over again. She will love him back. She will have eyes only for him.

<span id="page-191-4"></span><span id="page-191-2"></span>Take note that this passage is as much an emotional reaction to being betrayed as was the earlier one in which the Lord expressed his righteous desire to execute his people (2:3). There, he would make her like a parched desert. The "wilderness" was a curse. Here, he has reversed that curse and transformed the wilderness into a blessing. He loves Israel very much. He imagines she will feel the same eventually. It will be like the good old days, early in the relationship, when they were young lovers. Perhaps this is why even a harsh section like 2:7–9 is couched in language reminiscent of the Song of Solomon (Song 3:1–4; 5:2–7). Perhaps this is also why the wilderness wanderings seem to be remembered through rose-colored glasses. Although the wilderness experience was often a period of frustration and anger for Yahweh, requiring at times its own brand of tough love, his own tenderness for his people causes him to focus on the positive aspects even of those difficult times.

## <span id="page-191-1"></span>*Response*

The Baal cult was concerned with fertility and prosperity, not with living righteously. This raises the possibility that idolatry and a worldly mind-set could infiltrate the hearts and minds of modern-day Christians as well. Is the church today distracted from the gospel mission by worldly considerations? What false gods or alternate sources of blessing do Christians trust in today, for security or a sense of well-being? Must the Father today bring back a wayward people through harsh measures, such as by removing material prosperity that is so seductive?

<span id="page-191-5"></span><span id="page-191-0"></span>The Lord does still operate this way. Paul argues that sicknesses and even several deaths in the Corinthian church were directly attributable to a corruption of their worship and thinking: "When we are judged by the Lord, we are disciplined so that we may not be condemned along with the world" (1 Cor. 11:32). Hebrews 12 teaches that this is a constant spiritual principle of how God admonishes his people. Quoting Proverbs 3:11–12, Hebrews argues that God disciplines his children in order to make them fit for his service (Heb. 12:3–11). How, then, must God chastise us? What in our lives must be removed in order for us to live a life worthy of our calling? It is on this that every Christian must meditate. If we fail to live under God's discipline, he will defend his honor with harsh measures. He must.

<span id="page-191-6"></span><span id="page-191-3"></span>But the story does not end there. Note the shift from Hosea 2:6–13 to what follows in verses 14–15: judgment is replaced with mercy. The Bible is the story of a God who brings justice to bear against sin and yet loves and has mercy on sinners. There is no greater demonstration of this than what transpired at the cross. Because Jesus stood in the place of those who had earned judgment, God's just wrath was fully satisfied, and he could for Jesus' sake accept and sanctify the people he loves. The heart of God on display in Hosea is thus seen with even greater clarity in the gift of his Son.

## HOSEA 2:16–23

And I will abolish*<sup>1</sup>* the bow, the sword, and war from the land, and I will make you lie down in safety. **19**And I will betroth you to me forever. I will betroth you to me in righteousness and in justice, in steadfast love and in mercy. **<sup>20</sup>** I will betroth you to me in faithfulness. And you shall know the Lord.

| and they shall answer the earth,                      |
