- **<sup>22</sup>** and the earth shall answer the grain, the wine, and the oil, and they shall answer Jezreel,*<sup>2</sup>*
- **<sup>23</sup>** and I will sow her for myself in the land. And I will have mercy on No Mercy,*<sup>3</sup>* and I will say to Not My People,*<sup>4</sup>* 'You are my people'; and he shall say, 'You are my God.' "

1Hebrew *break* 2*Jezreel* means *God will sow* 3Hebrew *Lo-ruhama* 4Hebrew *Lo-ammi*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-192-2"></span>The phrase "in that day" recalls the prophetic theme of the "day of the Lord," an especially common theme in the Minor Prophets. Each prophet views it from a slightly different angle. To Joel, the "day of the Lord" is a terrible day, akin to a locust plague, a day of darkness and judgment, yet whoever calls on Yahweh will be saved (Joel 2:30–32). To Amos, it is a day that Israelites (Hosea's contemporaries) should dread, not desire (Amos 5:18–20), as it will involve terrible climactic judgment. Similarly, Malachi asks, "Who can endure the day of his coming?" (Mal. 3:2), implying that it is a day to be dreaded. Zephaniah foresees a day so severe that nothing will survive (Zeph. 1:2–18).

<span id="page-192-5"></span><span id="page-192-4"></span><span id="page-192-3"></span>In this chapter of Hosea, however, the focus is on positive aspects of that day. We read of a future time of wedded bliss between Israel and the Lord. A renewed marriage contract is envisioned that will last forever.

<span id="page-192-0"></span>Two levels of meaning can be discerned in Hosea 2:16ff. On the one hand, the passage addresses historical Israel, the people who abandoned Yahweh in order to worship Baal. They are promised restoration as a religious-political entity on their

traditional plot of land, which was fulfilled when Judah returned from exile. On another level, however, this passage is a picture of something much grander and more far-reaching. The scope of the new covenant is universal. According to Paul (quoting from this passage), it will encompass the whole earth and every people group (Rom. 9:25–26). Every Christian can rejoice in this fuller meaning, for he or she is a demonstration of its ongoing fulfillment.

## <span id="page-193-6"></span>*Section Outline*

III.C. In That Day (2:16–23)

- 1. On That Day She Will Know My Love (2:16–20)
- 2. On That Day She Will Be Mine (2:21–23)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-193-2"></span><span id="page-193-1"></span><span id="page-193-0"></span>2:16–20 The Lord declares that on "that day," Israel will call him "My Husband" instead of "My Baal" (v. 16). This is a Hebrew play on words. On the one hand, it would be very natural for the Israelites to refer to the Lord as "baal," for this word can mean "husband" (as in Prov. 31:28; Est. 1:17), and one of the main points of Hosea is that the relationship between the Lord and Israel is like that of a husband and wife in covenant relationship. But the word "baal" can also refer to the false gods worshiped in Canaan—the very ones the Israelites had begun to worship. As a result, the Lord uses a different word for "husband" (*ish*) as a way to say, "On that day, they will be faithful to me and describe me as their Husband [*ish*], not confusing me with the false god of this land, Baal [*baʻal*]." No confusion between the Baal cult and the true worship of Israel's one true God will be allowed on "that day."

<span id="page-193-3"></span>The covenant will be not only with Israel but apparently with every living thing (Hos. 2:18); it is depicted as a cosmic renewal. Even "beasts" and "birds" will be included in the new arrangement between God and his people on that day.

The (new) covenant will bind the people in justice and righteousness, and they will "know" the Lord. To "know" is often a marital term, a euphemism for conjugal bliss. They will be intimate with their God—they will be true to the covenant and in their hearts will love him.

<span id="page-193-4"></span>2:21–23 The cosmic scope of the restored relationship is envisioned here: the heavens and earth are included. God will answer the need of heaven, and it will rain again. The rain will answer the need of the land, and it will be productive again. The earth will answer the need of grain and oil, and they will flourish again. God will sow Israel, fulfilling the name "Jezreel," which means "God sows." Sowing is a fertility image, which in this context means the population will increase as the land produces abundant food.

<span id="page-193-5"></span>The final beatitude of this future state is the promise that those who had been excluded from the covenant will be included (v. 23). Gomer's son "Not My People" will be renamed "my people," and he will reply, "You are my God." Thus the breached relationship will be restored.

### *Response*

The tension in Hosea between the future punishment of unbelieving Israel and the future establishment of Israel as a worshiping community is echoed in the book of Romans. There, Paul struggles with how it can be that his beloved people have largely abandoned the salvation provided for them, while the barbarians and profane peoples who cared nothing for God—and were his enemies in times past by plundering and devastating the people of the covenant—are now taking Jesus as their own and enjoying a salvation never imagined or envisioned. Paul's was an upside-down world, where those destined for glory found judgment, while those destined for judgment found glory.

Paul explains this by citing the book of Hosea, in which those who were not God's people now are, while those who were his people no longer are:

What if God, desiring to show his wrath and to make known his power, has endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction, in order to make known the riches of his glory for vessels of mercy, which he has prepared beforehand for glory — even us whom he has called, not from the Jews only but also from the Gentiles? As indeed he says in Hosea,

"Those who were not my people I will call 'my people,' and her who was not beloved I will call 'beloved.'" "And in the very place where it was said to them, 'You are not my people,' there they will be called 'sons of the living God.'" (Rom. 9:22–26)

<span id="page-194-2"></span><span id="page-194-1"></span><span id="page-194-0"></span>As Paul goes on to say, the Gentiles experience such things because they have faith in Jesus (Rom. 9:30–33). It is only through him that we can know the Lord, enter into relationship with him, and boldly proclaim, "You are my God!"

## HOSEA 3:1–5

3 And the Lord said to me, "Go again, love a woman who is loved by another man and is an adulteress, even as the Lord loves the children of Israel, though they turn to other gods and love cakes of raisins." **<sup>2</sup>** So I bought her for fifteen shekels of silver and a homer and a lethech*<sup>1</sup>* of barley. **3**And I said to her, "You must dwell as mine for many days. You shall not play the whore, or belong to another man; so will I also be to you." **4**For the children of Israel shall dwell many days without king or prince, without sacrifice or pillar, without ephod or household gods.

**<sup>5</sup>**Afterward the children of Israel shall return and seek the Lord their God, and David their king, and they shall come in fear to the Lord and to his goodness in the latter days.

1A *shekel* was about 2/5 ounce or 11 grams; a *homer* was about 6 bushels or 220 liters; a *lethech* was about 3 bushels or 110 liters

#### *Section Outline*

III.D. Gomer Once More (3:1–5)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-195-2"></span><span id="page-195-1"></span>3:1–5 In this autobiographical sketch, the prophet tells his story, as once more he is called to image Yahweh. But is the woman he now pursues his wife, Gomer? The text does not explicitly identify her. She is an adulteress, and "another man" loves her (v. 1). But it would hardly make sense if this woman were not Gomer. The whole point seems to be that her estranged husband sought her out, did what was needed to redeem her from her lover, and brought her back into his house, at great cost to himself (silver and foodstuffs; v. 2). This extraordinary expression of love reflects how God has loved Israel. She, too, is faithless, and betrays her husband (the Lord) through her worship of other gods. Raisin cakes (v. 1)—which are mentioned along with "other gods"—were apparently an element of pagan religion, and their mention here underscores Israel's faithlessness. She loves her promiscuity.

<span id="page-195-4"></span><span id="page-195-3"></span>Hosea lays down the law to Gomer: she is to be celibate for a season. Her nymphomaniacal addiction must be cured through abstinence "for many days" (v. 3). Of course, he promises to abstain as well ("so will I also be to you"). This is a picture of the nation, which for "many days" would be bereft of idolatrous kings (v. 4). At the very least, this means that Israel would no longer be a sovereign nation. It may also be that her political leadership is mentioned in particular because it was the engine of false religion and is thus specifically targeted in order for false religion to stop as well. In either case, the destruction they will experience will be sufficiently thorough to wipe out political structures and worship practices ("without sacrifice or pillar, without ephod or household gods"; v. 4).

<span id="page-195-5"></span><span id="page-195-0"></span>Soon after Hosea prophesied, Israel was ravaged, destroyed, and carried off to Assyria (2 Kings 18:9–12). But this was not to be the end for God's people in the land, as a return is promised (Hos. 3:5), which was fulfilled when exiled Judah returned from Babylonian captivity to "seek the Lord their God, and David their king, and . . . come in fear to the Lord." This word for "fear" usually implies dread or terror: Israel will have learned that the Lord truly does deal with sin harshly. Of course, this prophecy does not refer to the literal king David; instead, it looks to the hope for an anointed king sitting rightfully on David's throne in Jerusalem. Those estranged both from Yahweh and from his established king will seek them out and find well-being in a renewed relationship with their God.

### *Response*

<span id="page-196-4"></span><span id="page-196-3"></span><span id="page-196-2"></span><span id="page-196-1"></span><span id="page-196-0"></span>Hosea 2:2–3:5 is breathtaking in its scope. The passage begins with Yahweh utterly incensed over the crime of infidelity (2:2), determined to mete out an agonizing punishment (2:3) and to do away with this worthless spouse once and for all (2:3–5). From there the mood switches to the Lord's tenderhearted desire to win back Israel's love (2:6–8). Then God lays out a plan to make this a reality, including harsh but needed measures that will force her to change her attitude (2:9–13). He is portrayed as a jealous husband, musing about how it might be when his wife loves him exclusively (2:14–15). Finally, the prophet acts this out by buying back his lost wife and reinstating their vows (3:1–5).

<span id="page-196-6"></span><span id="page-196-5"></span>From an earthly perspective, if seems that this envisioned happy ending utterly failed to materialize, for either the northern or the southern kingdom. The northern kingdom only experienced God's wrath. And when the remnant of the southern kingdom returned from Babylonian exile, they did not appoint a Davidic king. From the time of their return to the time of Jesus, there was no king of David's lineage to command the loyalty of the faithful. Instead there were only terrible wars that resulted in tyrant after tyrant subjugating the land.

The tragic irony is that, after having gone through such pain and loss, when the Son of David finally did arrive, this same nation rejected him. They did not have him as their king. They did not follow him. And they did not enjoy his goodness in the latter days. Instead, there was rebellion after rebellion until the people of Israel were driven from the land by Rome and forced to wander in exile once again.

But some did have Jesus as their Lord and King. A remnant of Israel believed. And with them, streams of Gentiles from every nation turned from their false gods to embrace Jesus and his revealed Father. Those who were not the people of God, who were not numbered with the elect, are now welcomed into the kingdom of God. Thus the ultimate fulfillment of Hosea's prophecy goes far beyond anything expected or hoped for by the original hearers or perhaps even by the prophet himself.

<span id="page-196-9"></span>Consider Hosea's buying back his wife for a price. Note how this parallels the gospel. Paul wrote, "You are not your own, for you were bought with a price. So glorify God in your body" (1 Cor. 6:19b–20). This is from a larger section in 1 Corinthians concerning sexual purity in the church. As Hosea bought his wife and demanded her chastity, so also, instructs Paul, all Christians owe their Master heartfelt moral virtue and obedience. Thus Christians have an obligation—as surely as did ancient Israel—to live true to the covenant, including even in their sexual behavior.

<span id="page-196-8"></span><span id="page-196-7"></span>Perhaps at the end of this section of Hosea a Christian might pause and consider how very like Gomer or the idolatrous Israelites he or she might be. A person's loves defines that person. The Pharisees "loved the glory that comes from man more than the glory that comes from God" (John 12:43). Someone who cares too much about what other people think or about winning their approval or respect or affection will be diminished in their valuation of the Father. Two masters cannot be served. Jesus declared, "Whoever loves his life loses it" (John 12:25). Whatever a person loves determines what motivates that person—either love for God or love

for other things. Remember, we have been bought with a price, like Gomer, and therefore we owe our Lord all our heart.

<span id="page-197-1"></span>The Father will discipline us in order to loosen the grip of these idolatries in our hearts. This process will be painful. But a day is coming in which all of those things that compete with our love for God will be put in proper perspective. On that day we will in full measure bask in the goodness of our salvation.

## OVERVIEW OF

## HOSEA 4:1–11:11

The next major section of Hosea begins by calling out Israel. Yahweh "has a controversy" with his people. His accusation unfolds in a series of oracles directed at every stratum of society, starting with those who claim to speak for God: prophets and priests. This section, encompassing roughly half of the book, can be divided into seven subsections:

- <span id="page-197-0"></span>A. Israel Is a Whore! (4:1–5:7)
- <span id="page-197-3"></span>B. Death Sentence and Beyond (5:8–6:3)
- C. What Shall I Do with You? (6:4–7:16)
- D. Israel Has Forgotten His Maker (8:1–14)
- E. Woe When I Depart from Them! (9:1–17)
- F. The Calf and the People (10:1–15)
- G. My Heart Recoils within Me (11:1–11)

The historical narratives chronicling Hosea's pursuit of Gomer as an illustration of how Yahweh will deal with Israel are now finished, having served as the foundation upon which the ensuing oracles will be built. When continuing on, the reader must keep in mind the estranged relationship between Israel and her Maker. For example, the estrangement surfaces again in Yahweh's accusation that "they have left their God to play the whore" (4:12); Israel is wanton in her adulterous ways.

<span id="page-197-2"></span>This theme of whoredom is especially evident in the first subsection (4:1–5:7), which describes how the people have turned from God to false deities. This fundamentally misplaced faith is fertile ground for all sorts of sin, such as unethical dealings and bloodshed.

<span id="page-197-4"></span>In the second section, Yahweh unleashes his fury against his people's sin (5:8–6:3). Foolishly, they will turn to other nations for deliverance—nations that cannot save them. Salvation will come only by turning back to the Lord with a repentant heart, and the section ends with some hope that they will do so (6:1–3).

<span id="page-198-3"></span>The very next section again emphasizes the failure of the Lord's people to truly return to him (6:4–7:16). Wickedness still abounds, and when the Lord's discipline comes, they do not turn to him in repentance but instead attempt various political fixes in order to save their skin.

<span id="page-198-4"></span>This continues in the section that follows (8:1–14). The Lord's people continue to rebel against his covenant, and when the Lord's justice comes, they do not come to him in repentant faith but instead look to the nations for salvation. The Lord thus makes clear that they are headed for dissolution: away to Assyria they will go forever. It will be as if Yahweh never rescued them from Egypt in the first place.

<span id="page-198-5"></span>The theme of spiritual adultery's leading to exile continues in the next section (9:1–17). Hosea emphasizes that Israel will be removed from the land, their relationship to Yahweh severed and the nation wiped out. Israel had turned to Baal and the Canaanite cult for fertility, and so, in a punishment that fits their crime, the Lord will ensure that they have no progeny. Theirs will be the last generation, and they will wander among the nations.

<span id="page-198-6"></span><span id="page-198-2"></span>The section that follows makes clear that the central problem of Ephraim (i.e., Israel; cf. comment on 4:17–19) is that the true and living God of their fathers, Yahweh, has been rejected for various substitutes (10:1–15). Their golden calf signals their resistance to godly counsel and prophetic warning, and other counterfeits are in operation as well. The people trust in treaties and political intrigue. They trust in their own abilities and competencies, in their military might and fortresses. All of these false refuges and spurious gods must go (10:1–15).

<span id="page-198-7"></span><span id="page-198-1"></span><span id="page-198-0"></span>Having said all of this, the Lord then reveals his inner ambivalence in the last section (11:1–11). He is like the father of a felon who deserves capital punishment. What should a father do? Love his son, or let justice destroy him? In the end, having wrestled with this inner conflict, Yahweh decides that he will not destroy his son after all but will instead bring him back after a period of chastisement. It is on this note that the great major section in Hosea, chapters 4–11, closes.

## *Section Overview*

As does every major section in Hosea following the introduction, this one begins with "a controversy" (Hb. *rib*), that is, an accusation or legal case against Israel. In Israel's day, as in our own, formal lawsuits would involve certain elements, such as the calling of witnesses and cross-examination. It is therefore no surprise to find such elements included in the Lord's lawsuit against Israel here, and the comments below will use legal terminology as appropriate in order to make these elements clear.12

<span id="page-200-0"></span><sup>12</sup> For similar examples of the lawsuit genre in the Minor Prophets see Amos 3 and Micah 6.

<span id="page-201-5"></span>This passage is bound together by the theme of whoredom/harlotry. The "spirit of whoredom" (4:12; 5:4) is spoken of in various ways. Israel is said to cherish it. They are led by it. They are joined to idols. Their leaders are no better. They have become alien to God.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-201-2"></span>IV. The Case against Israel (4:1–11:11)
	- A. Israel Is a Whore! (4:1–5:7)
		- 1. No Faithfulness in the Land (4:1–3)
		- 2. Rejecting Knowledge (4:4–6)
		- 3. Cherishing Whoredom (4:7–11)
		- 4. A Spirit of Whoredom Leads Them (4:12–14)
		- 5. A Stubborn Heifer (4:15–16)
		- 6. Joined to Idols (4:17–19)
		- 7. Judgment on Priest and King (5:1–2)
		- 8. A Spirit of Whoredom within Them (5:3–4)
		- 9. Alien Children (5:5–7)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-201-1"></span>4:1–3 Hosea cries out, "Hear the word of the Lord, . . . for the Lord has a controversy with the inhabitants of the land" (v. 1). His accusation is simple: "There is no faithfulness or steadfast love, and no knowledge of God in the land." The term translated "faithfulness" can also be translated "truth": there is no fidelity, no honesty, no commitment to the truth of God in the land. "Steadfast love" translates the Hebrew term *hesed*, which connotes covenant fidelity or loyalty. The passionate God desires such love from his beloved and is righteously angered when they are lukewarm toward him. Finally, the "knowledge of God" refers to more than correct theology; it describes those who show they know God through their faithfulness to his covenant (6:6; cf. also 4:6; 5:4). Yet these traits are absent among God's people.

<span id="page-201-4"></span>Instead, the people of God break his Ten Commandments by swearing (the 3rd commandment), lying (9th), murdering (6th), stealing (8th), and committing adultery (7th).13 Notice that God's first complaint is not that Israel is worshiping Baal; instead, he addresses Israel's moral compass. To deviate from the revealed moral code is to lose any connection or relationship with the Lord. Bloodshed has become a defining characteristic of God's people. Near the end of the northern kingdom (and Hosea's ministry), kings followed kings in rapid succession, usually through assassination. Violence had become the order of the day.

<span id="page-201-6"></span><span id="page-201-3"></span>In light of this sin, the Lord brings his justice to bear. The consequences are severe enough that the land "mourns" (4:3), which is the usual use of this word, although in some contexts it can refer to drought in particular (cf. Amos 1:2). If the same is true here, this is a direct swipe at the storm god Baal. In any case, the

<span id="page-201-0"></span><sup>13</sup> Cf. Exodus 20:7, 13–16. In this context, "swearing" refers to misuse of the Lord's name (Ex. 20:7), perhaps by taking an oath in his name and then lying or otherwise breaking it.

<span id="page-202-0"></span>punishment will be so severe that even the animals will experience its consequences (cf. Deut. 28:18).

<span id="page-202-6"></span>This passage may be considered the opening statement of a legal case, in which the defendant is called to the stand and charges are read (Hos. 4:1–3). Next is a list of suspects, with more specific charges against them (vv. 4–6). What is driving this trial is the heart of God, who desires love and fidelity from him people.

<span id="page-202-9"></span><span id="page-202-8"></span><span id="page-202-5"></span>4:4–6 The verbal form of the term translated "controversy" in verse 1 (Hb. *rib*) is used twice in verse 4, highlighting that the ongoing monologue is in the context of legal accusation. There is some question concerning how to translate the second part of verse 4. The main text of the ESV involves a slight emendation of the Hebrew, with the result that the Lord begins to address the priests in particular. In favor of this, the word "you" clearly refers to the priests in verse 6, and the priests seem to be the focus of this section.

<span id="page-202-1"></span>The so-called priests of the northern kingdom had been appointed by Jeroboam at the founding of the nation many generations before (1 Kings 13:33). This non-Levitical caste had never served in accordance with the law of Moses, instead ministering before golden calves representing Yahweh and established by Jeroboam at Bethel and Dan. Scripture is united in its witness that this was a counterfeit cult, worthy of nothing but contempt from a true worshiper of God (2 Kings 17:21–22; 2 Chron. 11:14).

<span id="page-202-10"></span><span id="page-202-4"></span><span id="page-202-3"></span><span id="page-202-2"></span>The judgment of the Lord is then announced: the priest "shall stumble by day," and the prophet "shall stumble with you by night" (Hos. 4:5). The word "stumble" is often used to refer to the Lord's judgment that comes on the unfaithful in such a way that their ultimate end is to fall and be destroyed (Isa. 3:8; 31:3). "Day . . . [and] night" is a figure of speech called a *merism*, in which two opposites convey a complete whole. The phrase is used here to indicate that priests and prophets will have no chance to escape their deserved fate.

<span id="page-202-13"></span>Prophets are lumped together with priests as those who claim to know but in fact only deceive. Both Israel and Judah were filled with false prophets. Their spiritual state of affairs was so bad that, in the Minor Prophets, Amos was embarrassed to be called a prophet (Amos 7:14), while Micah soundly critiqued them (Mic. 3:11). Zephaniah also treated prophets and priests as particularly guilty before God (Zeph. 3:4). Zechariah predicts a time when prophets will be ashamed to call themselves prophets (Zech. 13:4–5).14

<span id="page-202-16"></span><span id="page-202-15"></span><span id="page-202-14"></span><span id="page-202-12"></span>The passage then returns to the priests in particular and gets to the heart of the issue: a fundamental rejection of true knowledge of God (Hos. 4:6). A substitute savior, a cheap knockoff of the real thing, is all they represent to the people. The very officials who took upon themselves the mantle of teachers do not know the truth about God, and as a result the people suffer: "My people are destroyed for

<span id="page-202-11"></span><span id="page-202-7"></span><sup>14</sup> The phrase "I will destroy your mother" (v. 5) is highly debated. Some understand this to describe a punishment of the actual mothers of the priests; some see it as a metaphorical way to describe the land (cf. v. 3) or a royal city in which the priests lived; still others emend the text to give a different sense altogether ("you will perish in terror" [Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, 70]).

lack of knowledge." Thus the spiritual adultery and religious guilt accrued by the nation can be laid at their door. God's response is that since they have forgotten his law, he will "forget [their] children": he will disown the priests from participation in his promises and protection.

These verses condemn priest and prophet, the people and the nation. The whole religious and political system has failed to preserve the knowledge of God and has in fact rejected him. The defendants have been named, and specific crimes delineated, in this lawsuit.

<span id="page-203-1"></span><span id="page-203-0"></span>4:7–11 The previous passage featured second-person direct address, while here the priests are spoken of in the third person. Consider how deeply the living God despises the "ministry" of those who purport to speak for him: he will convert their "glory" (v. 7)—the honor and respect they enjoy in the community—into shame. In the end, their misrepresentations and foolish assertions will be exposed for what they are. They spoke of divine matters about which they had no real knowledge.

<span id="page-203-2"></span>The priests are said to "feed on the sin of my people" (v. 8)—they eat from the worthless sacrifices (probably offered at the shrines of the golden calf). This iniquity literally is their bread and butter. The people and the priest are alike, the Lord declares; together the whole culture is corrupt and must go. Israel's jealous lover will make sure they face the consequences of their deviant behavior. Indeed, as a judgment for sin, the activities they engage in will not have their normal effects: they will "eat" but find no satisfaction; they will fornicate "but not multiply" (v. 10).

<span id="page-203-4"></span><span id="page-203-3"></span>The priests have abandoned the One who loves and provides for them and have instead kept faith with spiritual whoredom and wine—ruining the understanding of God's people (v. 11).15 It is as if an unscrupulous marriage counselor, the priest, has for his own benefit ruined the marriage by lying about the husband. Jesus declared that special judgment was in store for anyone who "causes one of these little ones who believe in me to sin" (Matt. 18:6). Those with authority over others will face increased scrutiny for the ways in which they use that authority.

<span id="page-203-11"></span><span id="page-203-7"></span><span id="page-203-6"></span>4:12–14 The terms "piece of wood" and "staff" (v. 12) may allude to the worship of Asherah, the Canaanite goddess of erotic love often represented by a wooden pole. The phrase "spirit of whoredom" probably does not imply the work of literal spirits but instead most likely refers to a shared attitude that influences the people in a certain deviant way, leading them to spiritual unfaithfulness and to seeking guidance from cultic objects, perhaps Asherah poles.

<span id="page-203-9"></span><span id="page-203-8"></span>Apparently, actual fornication and harlotry are occurring at some places of worship (vv. 13–14). It has been suggested that prostitution was an element of cultic worship practice, and verse 13 thus connects cultic activities with women who "play the whore." But they are not the only guilty ones. Male worshipers are the ones who hire the prostitutes as part of their idolatry (v. 14). These activities

<span id="page-203-10"></span><span id="page-203-5"></span><sup>15</sup> The first word in the Hebrew of 4:12 may belong at the end of 4:11, yielding, ". . . which take away the understanding of my people"; 4:12 would then begin, "He consults a piece of wood . . ."

<span id="page-204-2"></span>show that the people lack "understanding" (v. 14; cf. v. 6), and the result of such activities will be utter "ruin" for those who practice them.

<span id="page-204-9"></span><span id="page-204-3"></span>4:15–16 These verses include a rare mention of Judah in the book of Hosea. Apparently, Judah is not (yet) guilty of this particular form of idolatry. Although a calf is not specifically cited, the illegal cult of the golden calf is mentioned here for the first time (on the golden calf in Hosea, cf. comment on 8:4b–6). In order to make the heinous nature of the sin clear, the name of the city housing the shrine has been purposefully changed from "Bethel" ("House of God"), to the more accurate "Beth-aven" ("House of Iniquity"). Another shrine has apparently been set up in Gilgal. Yahweh wants nothing to do with this idolatrous worship, in which he is represented as a calf: "Swear not, 'As the Lord lives!'" The true and living God rejects this idolatry; he simply cannot stand their so-called worship. Their cult and their conduct is so far from what the holy God desires in his people that he wants nothing to do with them.

<span id="page-204-5"></span><span id="page-204-4"></span>It is not God who is like a calf—it is Israel (4:16). Like a heifer, they are stubborn and headstrong. It would be better if Israel were compliant like a lamb, allowing her master to lead her (v. 16b). Instead, because of Israel's waywardness, stubbornness, idolatry, and spirit of whoredom, she cannot be pastured or led to a better condition. God will not bless such a recalcitrant people. The accused criminal will have no plea to make before the court.

<span id="page-204-6"></span>4:17–19 Here, for the first of thirty-two times in the book, Hosea uses his favorite synonym for Israel: "Ephraim." Ephraim was a "half-tribe" that stretched across the center of the Promised Land, serving as the heartland of Israel. Near its border was Bethel (the shrine of the golden calf) and Shiloh, where the tabernacle had been set up in earlier days. Ephraim represented the wayward heart of the people; it was the stubborn stronghold of prevailing idolatry and appropriately described as being "joined to idols."

<span id="page-204-7"></span>5:1–2 Judgment is pronounced specifically against the priesthood, king, and (apparently) the nobles of Israel. These leaders have spiritually entrapped people throughout the land (namely at Mount Tabor and Mizpah, perhaps sites where Israel worshiped false gods). The privileged class led the land in apostasy.

<span id="page-204-8"></span><span id="page-204-1"></span><span id="page-204-0"></span>The first part of verse 2 is difficult to translate. The ESV renders it as "And the revolters have gone deep into slaughter," while the RSV reads, "And they have made deep the pit of Shittim." In this latter reading, the listing of place names from verse 1 is continued. Shittim is where Israel "began to whore" by joining themselves with Baal (Num. 25:1–5). Thus the evil of this idolatry has been compounded with murder ("slaughter"), warranting a harsh response. The worthless, rebellious priesthood and the short-lived kings will be treated as they deserve: the Lord will discipline them all (Hos. 5:2). The word for "discipline" used here (*musar*) often refers to instruction designed to correct bad behavior, using painful means (cf. Isa. 26:16; Jer. 5:3; Job 5:17; Prov. 3:11).

<span id="page-205-2"></span>5:3–4 This unit is set apart by the device of inclusio, whereby the same word in Hebrew ("know") begins and ends the unit. Yahweh knows Ephraim/Israel, but they do not "know" him. He knows their deeds, which prevent their returning (*shub*) to the Lord. Due to their spirit of whoredom, the Israelites are incapable of either knowing or pursuing their covenant partner.

Theologically speaking, this may be labeled "total depravity," in the sense that no aspect of the people's collective personality is untouched by the spirit of spiritual apostasy. Their inner minds lead to visible deeds, which make impossible any sense of repentance or turning to God. It is this state of reprobation that they cannot change and, apart from an act of providential grace on God's part, can never change. At this stage, no simple appeal to listen will be heard, for they cannot listen. In other words, the call to hear in verse 1 stands as a rhetorical witness against the people. Their inability to heed is part of the complex of hardened rebellion. It is as if they were criminally insane, psychopaths with no conscience, unable to function normally. It takes more than prophetic appeal to reason with such people. Other measures are required to wake them from their deathly stupor.

<span id="page-205-4"></span><span id="page-205-3"></span><span id="page-205-1"></span>5:5–7 The "pride" of Israel "testifies" against it (v. 5)—yet another witness to the guilt of the accused. The sentencing portion of the trial is stated here in part: Israel will fall and will take Judah with it.

<span id="page-205-5"></span>The worst part of this judgment is that when it falls, Israel will seek after Yahweh in vain. The people will take flocks and herds to make sacrifices and seek the Lord but will be unable to find him (v. 6). He will have left, sick of their treachery and their religious festivals that ignored his revealed truth. Because of their unfaithfulness, God's people have become an "alien" generation (v. 7). They are foreign to God and for all practical purposes are Gentiles.

<span id="page-205-6"></span>The section ends with an obscure word of judgment: "the new moon shall devour them with their fields." Perhaps the subject of the verb is implied to be Yahweh himself, yielding, "Now he will consume their portion at the new moon."16 In this alternative reading, a judgment of God is prophesied for the very near future, perhaps at the time of an idolatrous holy day connected with the new moon. However verse 7b is translated, this section as a whole makes clear that the people are completely alienated from the Lord.

### <span id="page-205-7"></span>*Response*

Not every religion is alike, nor do all faiths produce the same fruit. There is an inner connection between abandoning Yahweh for Baal and abandoning morality and ethical dealings with one's neighbor. People become like that which they worship, and Baal and his pantheon are disgusting, immoral, violent personalities.

<span id="page-205-0"></span>One example of this in Scripture is the account of Naboth's vineyard in 1 Kings 21. In true faithfulness to the Lord, Naboth would not relinquish his

<sup>16</sup> Andersen and Freedman, *Hosea*, 396–397; with reference to the problems with the current Hebrew text, they note, "No one has ever explained how the new moon could eat fields" (396).

land, which he considered his family's inheritance from God. But Jezebel, a Baal worshiper, apparently could not comprehend this attitude. Land to her was a commodity to be bought and sold at will, without sacred meaning. To acquire it, she arranged Naboth's death. This story is recorded in the Bible not as an isolated incident but in order to show that Baal worship produces this sort of greedy, bloodthirsty behavior, and that a government that has abandoned respect for Yahweh cannot be trusted to respect Yahweh's citizens. At issue was not only which deity to serve, but also by which political and economic system to live.17 In the same way, Hosea critiques not only the false god the people worship but also the ethical and moral corruption that necessarily followed (Hos. 4:1–3).

<span id="page-206-0"></span>It is not hard to transfer this basic insight into the modern world. Throughout the twentieth century, governments that explicitly embraced atheism treated their citizenry with similar contempt, causing death by the scores of millions. The crumbling of the "moral fabric" of a society committed to secular humanism is just as inevitable. The charge that God leveled against ancient Israel could just as easily be leveled against the whole of Western civilization today.

<span id="page-206-3"></span><span id="page-206-2"></span><span id="page-206-1"></span>The great question becomes, how will God's people, the church of Jesus Christ, respond in the midst of this? In Hosea's day, it was the leaders of the people who earned God's particular ire (4:4–10). Similarly, Jesus condemned the religious leaders of his day as hypocrites (Matthew 23). James warns that not many should aspire to be teachers (James 3:1). Leaders in the church are charged with calling the people of God to his truth. In the light of the gospel, all Christians, but especially their leaders, should be visibly distinguished from the apostasy of the world as it now is. The ethical and moral caliber of those who call on the name of Jesus should be recognizable as a cut above. The church is the bride of Christ and as such should be head-over-heels in love with him. As mentioned, this is particularly true of leaders: if they are unable or unwilling to lead their people on this difficult path, they will also warrant God's ire and his condemnation of their works.

There were two major spiritual problems with Israel. One was out-and-out Baal worship. Baal was the anti-Yahweh, the alternative religion. As an element of his fertility cult, the people were led astray by sex and money. Baal worship was concerned with nothing besides sensuality and power. There was no mention in the Baal epic of a covenant being made with his people, whereby he expected obedience and righteousness of them.

The other spiritual problem of Israel was subtler and harder to identify and critique. It was a corruption of legitimate Yahweh worship. Yahweh was represented by golden calves at shrines maintained by priests. No doubt many of the traditions of Israel were taught and cherished—their worship partially followed what Moses specified—but pagan elements were added. This is called *syncretism*, and it calls for a sober review of Christian worship today.

<sup>17</sup> Judith Todd, "The Pre-Deuteronomic Elijah Cycle," in *Elijah and Elisha in Socioliterary Perspective*, ed. Robert Coote (Atlanta: Scholars, 1992), 1–35.

Have syncretistic elements of an unbelieving culture been adopted by various denominations and churches, incorporated into today's worship experience? The ruling body of any church should carefully and prayerfully seek wisdom and discernment on these matters, lest the parishioners imbibe a mixed message concerning the character of God.

<span id="page-207-0"></span>In every Christian's heart are also elements of sub-Christian thinking. These need to be weeded out through sound teaching, sober meditation on the Word of God, and a willingness to change accordingly.

## HOSEA 5:8–6:3

- **<sup>8</sup>** Blow the horn in Gibeah, the trumpet in Ramah. Sound the alarm at Beth-aven; we follow you,*<sup>1</sup>* O Benjamin!
- **<sup>9</sup>** Ephraim shall become a desolation in the day of punishment; among the tribes of Israel I make known what is sure.
- **<sup>10</sup>** The princes of Judah have become like those who move the landmark; upon them I will pour out my wrath like water.
- **<sup>11</sup>** Ephraim is oppressed, crushed in judgment, because he was determined to go after filth.*<sup>2</sup>*
- **<sup>12</sup>** But I am like a moth to Ephraim, and like dry rot to the house of Judah.
- **<sup>13</sup>** When Ephraim saw his sickness, and Judah his wound, then Ephraim went to Assyria, and sent to the great king.*<sup>3</sup>* But he is not able to cure you or heal your wound.
- **<sup>14</sup>** For I will be like a lion to Ephraim, and like a young lion to the house of Judah. I, even I, will tear and go away; I will carry off, and no one shall rescue.
- **<sup>15</sup>** I will return again to my place, until they acknowledge their guilt and seek my face, and in their distress earnestly seek me.
- 6 "Come, let us return to the Lord; for he has torn us, that he may heal us; he has struck us down, and he will bind us up.
- **<sup>2</sup>** After two days he will revive us; on the third day he will raise us up, that we may live before him.
- **<sup>3</sup>** Let us know; let us press on to know the Lord; his going out is sure as the dawn; he will come to us as the showers, as the spring rains that water the earth."

1Or *after you* 2Or *to follow human precepts* 3Or *to King Jareb*

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-208-2"></span><span id="page-208-0"></span>In this section, Yahweh has determined to unleash his fury. The people call for the horn to be blown, for the enemies are at the gates (5:8). God's people have realized they cannot stand without help. But to whom have they turned? Not to the one who could save them. No, they have turned in their folly to Assyria (5:13). The great irony of this is, of course, that it is Assyria who historically terrorized the Lord's people and carried them into exile. Perhaps this is how God tore his people as a lion would (5:14). None will rescue. None *can* rescue. The Lord's discipline will be heavy on his people until "they acknowledge their guilt" and "earnestly seek" him (5:15). He does not desire their death; he desires their repentance.

<span id="page-208-5"></span><span id="page-208-4"></span><span id="page-208-3"></span>A picture of repentance is indeed the very next thing we see. Hosea gives voice to the people's turning, seeking after God, and looking to him for healing (6:1–3). It is a hopeful picture, a strong affirmation that when the Lord's people truly repent, he restores them to life—he brings them back from the dead (6:2).

## <span id="page-208-6"></span>*Section Outline*

IV.B. Death Sentence and Beyond (5:8–6:3)

- <span id="page-208-1"></span>1. Blow the Horn! (5:8–9)
- 2. I Am a Moth; I Am Rot (5:10–13)
- 3. I Am a Lion (5:14–15)
- 4. Come, Let Us Return (6:1–3)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-208-9"></span><span id="page-208-8"></span><span id="page-208-7"></span>5:8–9 A call is issued to blow the trumpet and shout, citing specific military installations and strongholds (v. 8). This rhetoric invokes the panic of an invasion, the anticipation of imminent battle. Joel 2:1–11 uses similar language, graphically depicting an invading army and what it will mean for the inhabitants of Zion. Nahum 2 describes Nineveh's imminent fall, complete with chariots rushing through the streets, the vain cry of "Halt! Halt!," and the image of lions with their prey (Nah. 2:11–12). The same sense of distress is invoked by Hosea here in his presentation of what it will be like for Israel on the last day.

Gibeah and Ramah were in the southern part of the northern kingdom, as were Bethel (Beth-aven)18 and Benjamin. Apparently, Benjamin is envisioned as the front line, after which Ephraim follows. The placement of the cities suggests an invasion from Judah, but historically the real danger was not Judah but Assyria. Eventually the terror-inspiring, sadistic Assyrian forces overran the nation and utterly destroyed its culture.

<span id="page-209-6"></span>These verses end with a haunting phrase: "I make known what is sure" (Hos. 5:9). What is "sure"? The armies of Israel were not sure, reliable, dependable, or trustworthy. Their fortifications, political alliances, ability to pay tribute, or wherewithal were not sure. Trusting in man, trusting in fortresses, trusting in money, or trusting in one's own strength is not sure. These are the things in which wayward Israel trusted. But the Lord will reveal in the day of punishment what is sure—and what is not.

<span id="page-209-8"></span><span id="page-209-7"></span><span id="page-209-1"></span>5:10–13 This passage speaks to a time when both Judah and Israel have offended their God, as both are mentioned throughout. To "move the landmark" (v. 10) is to undermine the social and ethical order of society. It is to tamper with a foundational aspect of civilization. The ancient landmarks were generational standards on which matters of inheritance and land rights were based (Deut. 19:14). Similar meddling might involve using dishonest scales in business transactions (Prov. 20:23) or committing perjury in a trial that depends on the truth to make just judgments (Num. 30:2). The political leadership ("princes") of Judah committed an analogous crime, possibly by annexing land belonging to Israel, thus literally moving a political boundary. Because of this, God will pour out his wrath like water. Judah will be deluged in the coming judgment.

<span id="page-209-9"></span><span id="page-209-4"></span><span id="page-209-3"></span><span id="page-209-0"></span>Yet Ephraim deserves no better treatment. They asked for it. Before their final demise, they felt crushing oppression at the hands of Assyria because they went after "filth" (Hos. 5:11). The Hebrew word is not exactly "filth." It is pronounced something like a sneeze, perhaps with a "z" sound at the start. In Isaiah 28:10–13 it is glossed "precept" but might instead simply be a nonsense word, used to depict the babbling of the prophets. Perhaps it could be expressed as the sound of putting one's tongue out and blowing. Thus this phrase would be rendered, "Ephraim was pleased to go after brrrpt!" This is in contrast to going after Yahweh (Hos. 11:10).

<span id="page-209-10"></span>In 5:12 we find two startling images for the great creator of heaven and earth: he describes himself to be like "a moth" and like "dry rot." These both gnaw away at originally new and pristine material. Moth larvae chew holes in clothing and leave worms in foodstuffs, spoiling it. The word for "dry rot" can be used also to refer to sickness and decay in general. Job 13:28 uses the same words in parallel to describe a man who is wasting away. In short, the Lord will erode and dilapidate these two nations; they will suffer as with a festering disease.

<span id="page-209-11"></span><span id="page-209-5"></span><span id="page-209-2"></span>It is thus no surprise that the next verse speaks of the nations' "sickness" and "wound" (Hos. 5:13). Perhaps these two nations wounded each other through war and then looked to Assyria to "cure" them of their "wound" and "sickness," that is, to help them militarily. Of course, the king of Assyria could not help them. How could he, since Yahweh was the one who had afflicted them?

The king of Assyria is given an obscure title here. As in 10:6, the Hebrew reads, "King Jareb" (cf. ESV mg.); the ESV aptly glosses "the great king."19

<span id="page-210-6"></span>5:14–15 These verses emphasize both the discipline of the Lord and its purpose in turning his people back to him. Previously the images for divine discipline involved putrefaction and decomposition, but here God is the most powerful carnivore, a lion seeking its prey. He promises to tear up his people like a predator would, leaving their carcass exposed to scavengers and vermin. He will then apparently carry the kill to his den, from whence there is no return. No hope remains for a lifeless and torn carcass.

<span id="page-210-10"></span><span id="page-210-2"></span><span id="page-210-1"></span>The phrase "no one shall rescue" can be found eleven times in Scripture, often using the image of a lion or other aggressive species. Isaiah, for instance, declares of the surrounding nations, "Their roaring is like a lion, like young lions they roar; they growl and seize their prey; they carry it off, and none can rescue" (Isa. 5:29; cf. Mic. 5:8, which uses the image in a positive light).20 There is finality to this image. It is like Daniel's being cast into the lions' den (Daniel 6)—he had passed the point of no return, into the sphere of death. Humanly speaking, there was no possibility of deliverance. But the situation in Hosea is worse than that. Unlike Daniel, in Hosea the victim is actually ravaged and torn open. Thus a better analogy would be Daniel's accusers, who were thrown into the den after him and crushed (Dan. 6:24). They perished—as Israel will soon perish, when the Lion strikes.

<span id="page-210-5"></span><span id="page-210-3"></span>The first-person pronoun is repeated to emphasize that this is Yahweh himself who promises with a certainty that such judgment will happen: "I, even I, will tear and go away; I will carry off, and no one shall rescue" (Hos. 5:14). God will personally and unreservedly ruin them.

<span id="page-210-7"></span>But destruction is not the ultimate goal. All of the discipline God brings on his people is meant to lead them to "acknowledge their guilt" (v. 15). Just as a child sometimes needs severe discipline in order to help him understand the severity of his wrong and to turn from it, so it is with the people of the Lord. In this case, the discipline will be a time of great distress, but the goal is that in this distress they will earnestly seek him.

<span id="page-210-9"></span><span id="page-210-8"></span><span id="page-210-4"></span>6:1–3 The prophet now desperately calls the people to respond in faith to the terrible threat of judgment just unleashed. In language as clear and evocative as the earlier call to "Blow the horn in Gibeah" (5:8), Hosea models the verbiage of a humbled people: "Come, let us return [*shub*] to the Lord" (6:1). Hosea gives voice to a penitential prayer, the proper response to God's final word of warning.

<sup>19</sup> The root of this Hebrew word could be *rib*, "to contend." Thus Cornelis van Leeuwen suggests that Hosea used a nickname, "King Bellicosity." If this is correct, Hosea may be rebuking Israel and Judah for involving the king of Assyria. They are playing with fire by inviting him into their contention ("Meaning and Structure of Hosea X 1–8," *VT* 53/3 [2003]: 375).

<span id="page-210-0"></span><sup>20</sup> See also Judges 18:28; 2 Samuel 14:6; Job 5:4; Psalms 7:2; 50:22; 71:11; Isaiah 42:22; Daniel 8:4.

The prophet makes clear the purpose of their suffering: "He has torn us, that he may heal us." It is clear that Yahweh is the one who brings his punishment to bear, just as he is the one who can bring healing and hope. He is therefore the one to whom they must look.

<span id="page-211-5"></span>The promise of healing and helping to recover from injury blossoms into an expectation of full restoration of life: "He will *revive us*; . . . he will *raise us up*, that we may *live* before him" (v. 2). The phrase "after two days . . . on the third day" follows a common poetic device of naming a certain number of things ("two days") and then in the very next breath adding one to the number ("third day"). Compare Amos 1:3: "For three transgressions of Damascus, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment" (cf. also Prov. 30:15–31). In this case, the length of time might not refer to two or three actual days but could be a way of saying that Israel can hope for such healing in the very near future—a pattern realized in Jesus Christ, who indeed arose on a literal "third day."

<span id="page-211-4"></span><span id="page-211-0"></span>This section ends with the hoped-for speech of a people who have, in their hearts, returned to their God. "Let us press on," they are imagined as saying (Hos. 6:3). The Lord's coming is as certain as the sunrise and will be life-giving. He will refresh them as showers of rain—exactly what they used to expect from Baal. They are imagined as sweetly returning to the Lord, recognizing in him all they ever wanted from their false gods, especially from Baal, the bringer of rain. But sadly, as the next verses will show, this type of repentance never took place in that era.

### *Response*

<span id="page-211-2"></span>God says that his people "go after filth" (5:11). What Ephraim trusted and invested in was "brrrpt!" How close to home is this indictment for Christians today? Do we, like Ephraim, chase after things that amount to nothing? Are we distracted by nonsense and frivolity from our mission as God's people to reach the lost, build his kingdom, and live as his church? If so, what will it take to wake us up to the seriousness of the times in which we live?

<span id="page-211-1"></span>It was suggested above that God's people, having experienced severe discipline, may someday fully expect to live again. But when? This anticipated national resurrection will happen after two days. On the third day, "He will raise us up, that we may live before him" (6:2). Isaiah 26:19 predicts that Israel's dead shall live again; "their bodies shall rise." Jonah was as good as dead in the heart of the sea, yet on the third day he returned to the land of the living.

<span id="page-211-7"></span><span id="page-211-3"></span>Perhaps Paul had Hosea 6:2 in mind when he wrote that Jesus "was raised on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures" (1 Cor. 15:4). Jesus also said, "Thus it is written, that the Christ should suffer and on the third day rise from the dead" (Luke 24:46). There is no text more anticipatory of this in all of Scripture than Hosea 6:2.

<span id="page-211-6"></span>Jesus stood in the place of his people and took their punishment. The fury and hurt of God due to his people's infidelity was unleashed in full upon this one man. But, after three days, this one man did literally rise again in the place of the people. Thus the suffering set before Ephraim and Judah due to their sin, and the blessing to follow, did in fact come to pass—in some measure through the Babylonian exile and subsequent restoration but in full measure in Christ. The heartfelt two-sided passions of God find their ultimate resolution not in the history of Judah but in the gospel of Jesus. Jesus puts on display the wisdom of God, who skillfully and masterfully orchestrated such a great salvation for an undeserving people (1 Cor. 1:26–31).

<span id="page-212-1"></span><span id="page-212-0"></span>What should be the response of Christians to this? Let us press on to know the Lord, for his great salvation and blessings to us are as sure as the dawn, as refreshing as the spring rains. Let us also put away any vain thought of finding refuge or security in anything else, be it political alliances or our own pocketbooks. Let us no longer trust in other people for our well-being, but in faith let us look to Jesus.

1Septuagint *mercy* 2Or *in his presence* 3Or *to the Most High*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-214-0"></span>Here again the perspective of Hosea toward Judah is on display: together with Israel, Judah is held to account (cf. 5:5, 13–14). Again and again God has tried to get their attention, to no avail. The harsh words from his spokesmen have had no effect (6:5). The extent of their pollution is here spelled out in detail.

<span id="page-214-4"></span><span id="page-214-3"></span><span id="page-214-2"></span>The priests in particular are murderers and robbers, either literally or metaphorically (6:9). As for the people, they have become rotten to the core, from the east (Adam) to the west (Shechem) (6:7, 9), in the nations of both Israel/Ephraim and Judah (6:10–11). God's blessing becomes just another opportunity to commit acts of injustice, from which the establishment profits.

<span id="page-214-5"></span>In desperation Ephraim (Israel), when Assyria ran amok through the land, attempted various political fixes, such as paying tribute or forming alliances to stave off utter destruction. Their kings and leaders did not generally last long, as the throne in Israel had become a prize for opportunists with no thought for God or his people (7:3–7). All the way until the time of their final destruction, they did not turn to the Lord for help. The tragedy is that he was there all along and would have saved them if only they had known him.

<span id="page-214-8"></span><span id="page-214-7"></span><span id="page-214-6"></span>Not only did they not know him; they also spoke lies about him (7:13). In their folly and ignorance they trusted in other things to save them, such as Egypt's help or their ability to pay tribute (7:11). This led directly to Israel's destruction as a nation and their assimilation with pagans. Never again would they be the people of God. In the end, even Egypt—the land from whence they had been redeemed would hold them in contempt (7:16).

### <span id="page-214-9"></span>*Section Outline*

IV.C. What Shall I Do with You? (6:4–7:16)

- <span id="page-214-1"></span>1. I Want Love! (6:4–6)
- 2. Like Adam (6:7–11)
- 3. Thieves and Bandits (7:1–2)
- 4. Parable of the Heated Oven (7:3–10)
- 5. Birdbrained Ephraim (7:11–16)

### *Comment*

6:4–6 Once again in the book of Hosea the heart of the Lord is revealed as the reader is made privy to the inner deliberations of the infinite God. Despite the fact that he is the Creator who knows the end from the beginning, this depiction of God is intended to convey something true about his dealings with his people <span id="page-215-5"></span>when they sin against him. God's feelings toward Israel are analogous to exasperation toward a faithless spouse: "What shall I do with you?" One thing is certain: even when this people express their love toward God (cf. 6:1–3), he will not put any confidence in their words as long as their deeds betray him.

<span id="page-215-6"></span>"Your love [Hb. *hesed* ] is like a morning cloud," the Lord declares (v. 4). *Hesed*  denotes covenant loyalty or fidelity and thus is most often translated as "steadfast love" in the ESV (cf. v. 6). The trait of *hesed* is the opposite of Israel's spirit of whoredom; their interest in Yahweh lasts only a short time before they break his heart once again. The indictment of verse 4 is thus juxtaposed with the ending of verse 3: the Lord's refreshing goodness is like spring rain watering the earth, but their loyalty is like short-lived dew on the ground.

<span id="page-215-7"></span>In verse 5, the Lord speaks of the harm he will bring to Israel. He does this either to get their attention or to punish them, perhaps even as a final judgment against them. Sometimes he raises up powerful nations against them, who ravage them materially, and literally kill many. At other times he sends natural disasters, such as drought, to shake them up and break the hold of other gods over them. But he also "hews" and "slays" them through the words of the prophets.

<span id="page-215-3"></span>This is more than hyperbole. Jeremiah 1:9–10 claims that, by the word of the prophet, kingdoms rise and fall—they are established or they perish. God pronounces judgment against Israel through his spokesmen, and thus judgment is assured. Note the parallel drawn between the prophets and "the words of my mouth." True prophets speak the very words of God and carry as much weight and force as he does.

<span id="page-215-8"></span>God's judgment is like the sun, which dries up the morning mist, revealing Ephraim's true character. There are numerous areas of corruption in Israel. One is, of course, outright idolatry, worship of Baal and the Canaanite pantheon. Another is the perverted worship of Yahweh at the shrines of the golden calf in Bethel. Yet another is the ethical and moral behavior that renders all forms of worship loathsome to a holy God, even those performed in accordance with the instructions of his Word (Hos. 6:6). Without knowledge of God (a covenant term implying love; cf. 2:20) and steadfast love (*hesed* ), their religious activities are rejected. Their religion is empty, even if they think they are serving Yahweh. In their heart of hearts, they do not want a God who confronts them with their sin. This indictment is a theme throughout the prophets (e.g., Isa. 1:11–17; Amos 5:21).

<span id="page-215-10"></span><span id="page-215-9"></span><span id="page-215-4"></span><span id="page-215-2"></span><span id="page-215-1"></span><span id="page-215-0"></span>6:7–11 The word "Adam" (v. 7) is sometimes understood as a reference to a person, so that "transgressed the covenant" would refer to the action of Adam in Genesis 3. But the use of the word "there" in the second half of verse 7 suggests that a place is in view. "Like Adam" would thus mean "Like [they did at] Adam." The town of Adam was on the east bank of the Jordan River in Gilead, about one-third of the way north between the Dead Sea and the Sea of Galilee, near the Jabbok tributary. It is mentioned in Joshua 3:16 as the place where the waters stood in a heap when the Jordan parted.

<span id="page-216-2"></span>"They transgressed the covenant" is more woodenly translated "they broke covenant," that is, they were treacherous against covenant faithfulness, which the Lord takes as an act of treachery against him. But what is the treachery to which he refers? Hosea 6:8–9 might provide the answer, if we understand verse 8 as referring to Adam—which was in the region of "Gilead"—as the "city of evildoers" and verse 9 as describing the act of evil committed there: priests murdering Israelites on their way to Shechem.21 This would indeed be treachery against the covenant under which Israel lived (Ex. 20:13).

<span id="page-216-3"></span><span id="page-216-0"></span>"Ephraim's whoredom" is in the "house of Israel"—defiling it like a brothel (Hos. 6:10). This is called a "horrible thing," an unthinkable evil, the ultimate revulsion: the house of God's people has become a bordello of idolatry.

This passage ends where it begins, with a passing reference to Judah. Verse 11 can be understood in two different ways. The declaration that a "harvest is appointed" may signal that a judgment awaits Judah as well. Those understanding the verse this way sometimes argue that the second half of the verse goes with 7:1: "When I restore the fortunes of my people [6:11b], when I would heal Israel [7:1a], . . ."

<span id="page-216-7"></span><span id="page-216-5"></span><span id="page-216-4"></span>Alternatively, both halves of 6:11 can be kept together and understood to highlight that, historically, Judah did not suffer the same fate as Israel; rather, a remnant was restored to continue on in covenant with the Lord. Thus the "harvest" would be a blessing, a restoration of fortunes, and the promise of such would be especially meaningful to the people of Judah during the exile.

<span id="page-216-8"></span><span id="page-216-1"></span>7:1–2 These verses contain the first of Hosea's five references to Samaria. Samaria was the capital city of Israel (1 Kings 16:29) and is probably in mind specifically when feminine imagery of God's people is used (Israel and Ephraim are usually portrayed as masculine).

<span id="page-216-6"></span>The picture of Israel here is characterized by unbridled preying on the vulnerable. To "heal" Israel would be to restore some measure of peace and prosperity to the land (Hos. 7:1). If and when God did this, Israel's alter ego, Ephraim, and their capital, Samaria, would merely use it as an opportunity to run wild. But their injustices perpetrated against one another, their lies and perjuries, their thievery and robbery, have all been committed before the face of God, even though they are not aware of it (v. 2). God "remembers" it, that is, he takes note of their evil acts and will do something about it.

<span id="page-216-11"></span><span id="page-216-10"></span><span id="page-216-9"></span>7:3–10 This passage is a parable of a baking oven. It is used here to describe wickedness occurring at a national level (vv. 3–7) and also at an international level (vv. 8–10).

<span id="page-216-12"></span>At the national level, the wickedness appears to center around assassination plots. To understand how the parable applies, it is helpful to note that, in ancient Israel, the type of oven described here would have had a fire inside of it, stoked until the oven was roaring hot. The oven would then have been sealed and its heat would have lasted for hours, with bread baking inside. This is a fitting parable from the perspective of what was going on in Hosea's day, as the faithless and wicked activities of the assassins burned continually and strongly, like the heat of an oven, "baking" their plots until they came to murderous fruition. Stated differently, a hot oven is a fitting image for aroused emotions of "regicidal fury."22 It is also a fitting parable from a linguistic perspective, since the Hebrew word for "baker" (v. 4) sounds like the words for "adulterer" (v. 4) and "anger" (v. 6).

<span id="page-217-6"></span><span id="page-217-5"></span><span id="page-217-4"></span>The word "adulterers" (v. 4) picks up the idea of being faithless to the covenant; the word is used elsewhere in Hosea in the context of idolatry (2:4; 4:13, 14) but perhaps here is used more generally to describe the wickedness of those plotting evil (cf. Jer. 9:2–3). The heat of their wickedness is strong, like the heat of an oven heated so hot that the baker no longer needs to fan the flame; it is hot enough to bake bread, just as the heat of those plotting evil is hot enough to fulfill their murderous plots.

<span id="page-217-7"></span>There is much debate concerning Hosea 7:5. The phrase "heat of wine" continues the metaphor of a baking oven, in this context applied figuratively to the heated drunkenness that results from drinking too much. It is less clear what the "day of our king" refers to, who it is that has "stretched out his hand with mockers," and what exactly that phrase means (it occurs only here in the Bible).

<span id="page-217-9"></span><span id="page-217-8"></span>There is also debate surrounding verses 6–7, although here the overall sense is perhaps clearer. With hearts stoked hot, the plotters draw near to their "intrigue" (or "ambush") (v. 6). They lie in wait, their passion burning blisteringly hot (v. 7). Their political leaders are consumed like fuel in the oven's fire (v. 7).

<span id="page-217-1"></span><span id="page-217-0"></span>Although one particular assassination may have been in mind originally, assassination in general had become the order of the day, encompassing the deaths of most kings of that era. King Zechariah did not call on the Lord. He ruled six months—it took that long for the "bread" (murderous plots) to "rise" against him. Shallum killed him and seized the throne (2 Kings 15:10). Shallum did not call on the Lord. It took only one month for the bread to rise against him. Menahem struck down Shallum in order to rule instead (2 Kings 15:14). Menahem did not call on the Lord. His son Pekahiah ruled after him (2 Kings 15:23). Pekahiah did not call on the Lord. It took two years for the bread to rise against him. Pekahiah's general, Pekah, assassinated him in a power grab (2 Kings 15:25). Thus, at a national level, red-hot wickedness led again and again to kings and rulers being consumed by violent men; during the entire time, no one called on the Lord for help.

<span id="page-217-10"></span><span id="page-217-3"></span><span id="page-217-2"></span>The parable of the oven is then applied to wickedness at an international level (Hos. 7:8–10). Here, Ephraim is "mixed" or "kneaded" among the nations (v. 8). As a baker kneads dough, Ephraim is blended (ethnically or spiritually) with various peoples so as never again to be distinguishable as the people of God. This is not even a judgment God imposed forcibly; they did it to themselves.

They have made themselves an unpalatable mess, like an unturned cake in the oven, one side burned and the other doughy. Despite this failure of cookery,

<sup>22</sup> Shalom Paul, "Image of the Oven and the Cake in Hosea 7:4–10," *VT* 18 (1968): 114–120.

<span id="page-218-5"></span>strangers (Assyria) devour any edible morsel (v. 9). It seems that Israel has made foreign alliances but is unaware of how destructive these alliances will be. This lack of awareness is emphasized by the next metaphor: "Gray hairs are sprinkled upon him, and he knows it not," completely unaware of how weak he has become.

<span id="page-218-3"></span>Such weakness and judgment should have led Israel to return to the Lord and seek him, but pride prevented their doing so (v. 10). As in 5:5, such pride will lead to their downfall.

<span id="page-218-7"></span><span id="page-218-6"></span>7:11–16 These verses continue to describe the Lord's people foolishly looking to the nations for help instead of to the Lord, but the metaphor switches from that of a baking oven to that of a silly dove. Birdbrained Ephraim turns to Egypt instead of the Lord and thus is taken to Assyria (v. 11). The image is of a dove that comes foolishly to the ground for food, unaware of its surroundings, and is captured by a net. Historically, Assyria was the net with which God ensnared Israel—just as he said he would (v. 12; cf. 2 Kings 17:6).23

<span id="page-218-9"></span><span id="page-218-1"></span>God and his spouse suffer from an estranged relationship. Not only have his people wandered from the truth and rebelled; they also perpetrate lies about him (Hos. 7:13). These falsehoods in particular hold God's redemption at bay. Perhaps "lies" is a reference to the golden calves that were supposed to represent God, or to some other corrupted act of worship or wrongheaded belief. Perhaps they flow from the simple and common misunderstanding that God would save them if they followed some religious ritual and outwardly honored him without inwardly conforming to his ethical and moral requirements. Whatever it is, they have slandered their covenant partner and King.

<span id="page-218-10"></span><span id="page-218-0"></span>What is more, they refuse to call out to him in sincerity and truth (v. 14). Desperate for grain and wine, "they gash themselves," imitating the Canaanite method of praying (1 Kings 18:28), and thus rebel against the Lord. He had loved them and taught them as a parent does a child ("trained and strengthened their arms"; cf. Hos. 11:1), but they were utterly disloyal and rebellious (7:15).

<span id="page-218-12"></span><span id="page-218-11"></span><span id="page-218-2"></span>All along, Hosea has been declaring that the Israelites should "return" (*shub*) to the Lord. Here they do "return" (v. 16), but not to their God. They are like an unreliable bow, an image used elsewhere in the context of treachery, describing those who fail to do as they are supposed to (Ps. 78:57). Destruction will result, and their allies in Egypt will despise them for it. Yahweh, and Yahweh alone, could have saved them, but he is the one person on whom they refused to call.

### *Response*

<span id="page-218-4"></span>"What shall I do with you, O Ephraim? What shall I do with you, O Judah?" (Hos. 6:4). The same inner turmoil of the Lord is later echoed in 11:8: "How can I give you up, O Ephraim? . . . My heart recoils within me." This revelation of conflict within

<span id="page-218-8"></span><sup>23</sup> If the Hebrew text is maintained, the meaning of verse 12b is unclear. Others suggest emending the text to read, "I will punish them sevenfold for their evil" (Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, 115–116), or, "I will chastise them according to the report of their treaties" (Andersen and Freedman, *Hosea*, 471). Certainty in translation is not possible here.

the heart of God is paradigmatic for the book of Hosea. His people put him in a bind; he is torn between two passions, justice and mercy. But the gospel is that this conflict has been resolved on the cross by Jesus, who willingly took the judgment his people earned so that a just God did not have to "give them up." It is this Jesus who came to reveal the Father, who desires compassion and mercy in his people.

<span id="page-219-0"></span>Some of the most well-respected religious leaders of Jesus' time, those who (in the people's eyes, at least) exemplified how to keep the law and please God, were the sect of the Pharisees. And yet, like the wayward people of God described in Hosea, these spiritual leaders did not sincerely understand or know the true and living God they purported to serve. Hosea 6:6 declares, "I desire steadfast love and not sacrifice, the knowledge of God rather than burnt offerings." Jesus twice quoted this verse to the Pharisees and told them that they needed to comprehend what it meant.

<span id="page-219-4"></span><span id="page-219-3"></span>On one such occasion, Jesus reclined at table with unsavory members of society—tax collectors and other sinners. The spiritual elites did not understand how a prophet could be friendly with such people (Matt. 9:10–13). On another occasion, Jesus and his disciples were plucking grain to eat on the Sabbath, and the Pharisees condemned them for doing so (Matt. 12:1–8). Both times, Jesus quoted Hosea 6:6 to them, saying that if they had known its meaning, they would have understood his actions. The leaders Jesus rebuked did not grasp the character of God. They did not understand the meaning of righteousness. God desired steadfast love (*hesed* ) from the Pharisees, but all he found was hypocrisy.24 The Father desires mercy in his children. Disciples of Christ are those who, like him, reach out to the unsavory in mercy and bring them along into the fold. He desires not religiosity but love (*hesed* ). This is the proper response to the love of God we have so freely received in Jesus.

<span id="page-219-5"></span>Sadly, Israel did not respond to the Lord's love by showing faithful love toward him. In the parable of the oven, Ephraim had rendered itself indistinguishable from pagan peoples. They had so mixed themselves that they were unrecognizable as the people of God. God's people are always in danger of assimilation and must remind themselves in every generation of who they are. Jesus said that he would rather Christians be either cold or hot. But if they are lukewarm, he will spit them out (Rev. 3:15–16). This is similar to God's declaration that Israel was an unturned cake, half burnt and half uncooked (Hos. 7:8). God desires a people who know him and whose actions are motivated by love for him. Following his warning of spitting out lukewarm Christians, Jesus declares, "You say, I am rich, I have prospered, and I need nothing, not realizing that you are wretched, pitiable, poor, blind, and naked" (Rev. 3:17). His counsel is to be rich in good deeds and not distracted by earthly allurement (v. 18).

<span id="page-219-7"></span><span id="page-219-6"></span><span id="page-219-2"></span><span id="page-219-1"></span>Hosea 7 ends with a warning concerning whom we trust for peace and security (7:11). Ephraim trusted in Egypt and in their own ability to pacify Assyria with
