### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-221-0"></span>"Set the trumpet to your lips!" (8:1) is another clarion call to pay attention and be alert, for the enemy is at the gate, swooping in against the house of the Lord like a bird of prey. Israel has assumed they were on good terms with their Maker, but this was self- deception. Far from being dependent on Yahweh as his faithful servants, they sanctioned kings who did not meet with his approval. Further, they set up idols, which he scorns. Israel put their trust in anything and everything except their one true God.

The difficulty with legitimate biblical faith is that the real God, the living Father of Israel, expects his people to respond in obedience to his gracious favor. Worshipers cannot autonomously ignore his commands forever and be blessed by him. Idols and false gods, on the other hand, do not require an inner change of heart. They do not demand a monogamous relationship. Why would they care how many other gods are worshiped? But Israel's Maker considers all other objects of faith to be rivals for the hearts and minds of his people and thus an evil influence, a source of spiritual adultery.

This includes not only worship of false gods but also looking to other nations for deliverance. These other "lovers" were for hire but were not actually beneficial to Ephraim. The tribute paid to them would ultimately be Israel's undoing. Not content with tribute, Assyria would soon move in and consume the entire kingdom in one gulp. The only savior for Israel, the only possible help, was this one God, who demands moral, ethical, and spiritual compliance. He would have them only on his own terms. But they were pathologically incapable of being faithful to him. They were convinced that salvation was to be found elsewhere—in palaces,

fortified cities, strongholds, political alliances, tribute, and golden calves. They were lost. "Set the trumpet to your lips!" Samaria's end has come.

## *Section Outline*

IV.D. Israel Has Forgotten His Maker (8:1–14)

- 1. Spurning the Good (8:1–4a)
- 2. The Samarian Calf (8:4b–6)
- 3. Reaping the Whirlwind (8:7–10)
- 4. Altars for Sinning (8:11–13)
- 5. Strongholds and Palaces (8:14)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-222-5"></span><span id="page-222-4"></span>8:1–4a The section begins by invoking an imagined scene of an enemy approaching the walls to besiege it (v. 1). The "trumpet" is thus to be blown in order to warn of an "ominous threat of impending destruction."25 The enemy is compared to a "vulture" (*nesher*), a word that may also be translated "eagle" (as the term is often rendered in the ESV).

<span id="page-222-9"></span>What is the "house of the Lord" (v. 1) in this context? The phrase seems to parallel "the land of the Lord" in 9:3–4. More specifically, Samaria is mentioned in the following verses, as are Israel and Ephraim—seemingly equating both the city of Samaria and the tribe of Ephraim with the northern kingdom. In short, the Lord will bring judgment against this land because they transgressed his covenant and rebelled against his law.

<span id="page-222-7"></span>Ironically, amid such faithlessness, the people claim to "know" the Lord (8:2); in the book of Hosea, this term implies faithful relationship. But they seem unaware of how deeply they have offended him and betrayed their relationship. In reality, Israel has "spurned," or "cast off," the "good" (v. 3), which may be a way of saying that they are disobedient and thus have given up the "good" that comes to the Lord's faithful people (cf. Deut. 6:24; 30:15), although the phrase could also be a reference to the Lord as "the good One." In either case, it suggests a rejection of the Lord and his ways, and for this reason the enemy will pursue Israel like a bird of prey.

<span id="page-222-8"></span><span id="page-222-3"></span><span id="page-222-2"></span><span id="page-222-1"></span><span id="page-222-0"></span>The people's spurning of God extends to their appointment of rulers (Hos. 8:4a). God was to determine who would be their king by appointing the first in a monarchic line. He chose Saul (1 Sam. 9:17), and later appointed David (1 Sam. 16:13). Even among the northern kings he was active, supporting such kings as Jehu (2 Kings 9:6). But in the dark days of assassination, opportunists were not interested in the choice of the living God. Violently seizing political power had nothing to do with justice or righteousness. And the people of Israel seemed to approve. They claimed to "know" God—that is, to acknowledge him as God (Hos. 8:2)—but their approval of such rulers pointed in the opposite direction, and the

<span id="page-222-6"></span><sup>25</sup> Robert D. Bergen, "Calling Forth Yahweh's Curses: Hosea's Judgment of Israel in 8:1–10:15," *CTR* 7 (1993): 42.

Lord makes this clear by stating that he "knew" not their rulers (v. 4)—that is, he did not acknowledge them as legitimate.

<span id="page-223-6"></span><span id="page-223-5"></span><span id="page-223-2"></span><span id="page-223-0"></span>8:4b–6 The people had taken the gold and silver from God (2:8) and made idols of them (8:4b), doing so "for their own destruction." This Hebrew idiom woodenly reads, "therefore, he will be cut off." The phrase "to be cut off" occurs regularly in the OT to describe the sanctions of the covenant (Ex. 31:14; Lev. 7:20; etc.). The verb "to cut" is also used to describe the making of a covenant (Hos. 2:18; 10:4), leading to a potential play on words: the covenant that was cut between Yahweh and Israel had been violated; thus, they will be cut off.

<span id="page-223-4"></span><span id="page-223-3"></span>Israel had "spurned" the good (8:3). Now the same verb is used in relation to Israel and the calf (v. 5). This is the first direct reference to a golden calf in the book of Hosea. Although it is not called "golden" here, it is immediately preceded by God's complaint that gold was used in the construction of idols like it.

There is some question concerning how to translate the phrase rendered "I have spurned your calf, O Samaria." The Hebrew is more woodenly translated, "He has spurned your calf, Samaria" (cf. ESV mg.), as if Hosea himself interjects his own comment. The Greek translation reads, "Get rid of your calf, Samaria!" Yet another option is, "Your calf has spurned you, Samaria." This last reading would, of course, be sarcasm. (It may be noted that "Samaria" here refers to the inhabitants of the land in general, not the city of Samaria in particular, as the calf was not located there; cf. 10:5.) In any case, it is clear that the legitimacy of their calf worship is being denied.

<span id="page-223-11"></span><span id="page-223-8"></span><span id="page-223-7"></span>Hosea's charge continues: Israel is "incapable of innocence" (8:5b). What will it take for this situation to change? Verse 6 may be an insight into the psychology of idolatry. As long as the image remains, it will influence the people in a certain way. The calf had become a universal psychosis: the people imagined that it represented God. They knew that a craftsman made it; they knew it was their own creation. But as long as it remained, they were unable to conceive of God apart from it—they could not be "innocent" before him. The only cure for this spiritual situation was to forcibly remove the idol. Thus, it will be "broken to pieces."

<span id="page-223-13"></span><span id="page-223-10"></span><span id="page-223-9"></span>8:7–10 Hosea next uses a series of metaphors to describe Israel. First, "They sow the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind" (v. 7). It is a biblical principle that a person reaps what he sows (Gal. 6:7). To "sow wind" is a picture of futility and folly; what can one hope to gain from a harvest of wind? In this context, the image appears to be a way of describing how Israel is playing international politics in vain hopes of security and prosperity. But instead of no harvest whatsoever, the sowing of wind yields a whirlwind, which refers elsewhere to God's judgment (Amos 1:14). For their foolish and rebellious actions, Israel will reap a crop of proverbial storm that blows the wicked away (Job 21:18; Prov. 10:25).

<span id="page-223-12"></span><span id="page-223-1"></span>The next metaphor also involves sowing, picturing planted grain that grows into a malformed stalk, with no edible part. This is an analogy for Israel: God planted and watered the nation, but when it came time for harvest, there was nothing worth <span id="page-224-1"></span>reaping. Isaiah 5:1–7 uses a similar image of Israel as a vineyard yielding only rancid grapes. But Hosea adds that, in the end, it does not matter if the stalks are nourishing; if they were, strangers would only devour them. In other words, nothing in Israel is worth having or wanting, but the little that is there will be taken away (Hos. 8:7b); the political actions Israel has taken to advantage itself have yielded nothing but delusion and loss. Israel has already been swallowed up by the nations (v. 8a). They are a "vessel" desired by none (v. 8b). The nation is fit only to be discarded.

<span id="page-224-5"></span><span id="page-224-4"></span><span id="page-224-3"></span><span id="page-224-0"></span>The people "have gone up to Assyria" (v. 9); that is, they seek help from a pagan nation instead of from the Lord. They are immediately compared to a "wild donkey wandering alone." As similar words in Hebrew, "Ephraim" and "donkey" form a pun; the word "donkey" is used elsewhere as a metaphor to describe those who are hostile to others and living apart from them (Gen. 16:12), which may be the sense here as well. They are alone on the international scene. This could also explain why they have "hired lovers" (Hos. 8:9); that is, why they have paid money for a political alliance with Assyria.

<span id="page-224-12"></span><span id="page-224-7"></span><span id="page-224-6"></span>Their alliance will do no good. No matter whom they hire, the Lord's judgment will come (v. 10). The word for "gather" occurs in the next chapter to refer to those gathered for punishment (9:6), and that understanding fits the context well here also. Their judgment will be the heavy tribute they must pay, causing their leaders to "writhe" in pain.26 In following a course of political alliances and cunning, trusting in their own resources ("hire allies among the nations"), Israel has squandered their substance.

<span id="page-224-9"></span><span id="page-224-8"></span>8:11–13 Ephraim will suffer this burden because they have multiplied "altars for sinning" (v. 11). The thought is repeated to emphasize rhetorically the multiplication. Altars are places of religious devotion and service. One might expect that they evince the people's desire to worship Yahweh, but Hosea calls them "altars for sinning" because God's people are worshiping false gods with them, because they have mixed the worship of the Lord with the worship of other gods, and/ or because they committed evil acts at them. Whatever the reason(s), everything about these altars is offensive to the Lord. The people's religious practices have led to condemnation, not forgiveness.

<span id="page-224-10"></span>Continuing the theme of multiplication, God says that if he were to multiply laws for his people, those laws would be reckoned "strange" (v. 12)—the same word used for the "strangers" who would devour Israel's strength (v. 7). Everything is upside down: Israel is dissolved into what is foreign and strange, so as to be indistinguishable as a people of God, yet if God were to speak to them with volumes and volumes of revelation, they would reckon that revelation as foreign and strange. His word has become alien to them.

<span id="page-224-11"></span>The result of their religion of sacrifices is that Yahweh will return (*shub*) them to Egypt (v. 13). This Hebrew verb is sometimes used in the sense of repentance, turning back to God (e.g., 2:7; 3:5; 5:4; 6:1; 7:10). It is a sad and tragic reversal that

<span id="page-224-2"></span><sup>26</sup> It is also possible to translate, "And they shall soon writhe because of the tribute of the king of princes," that is, because of the tribute imposed upon them by the king of Assyria. The endpoint is the same.

a verb of restoration is used here to convey the opposite result: they will "return" to Egypt, to the land of bondage and harsh servitude. The altars for sinning that they serve with endless religious zeal and ritual will serve only to remind God of their offense until they are banished forever—fulfilling the worst and final aspect of the covenant curses (Deut. 28:68).

<span id="page-225-0"></span>Of course, Egypt would not be the literal place of their exile; the northern tribes were removed to Assyria. Later, the southern kingdom was exiled to Babylon. The name "Egypt" speaks to the character of that banishment: it turns the clock back to the time before the honeymoon between God and Israel, when he rescued her from Egypt (Hos. 2:15). It will be as if they were never his covenant people at all.

<span id="page-225-6"></span><span id="page-225-1"></span>8:14 The section ends with a summary that includes Judah in its scope. In place of their Maker, Israel and Judah have made temples and fortified cities, which provide a false sense of security. But Israel and Judah are not allowed a secular existence. God chose them to play out the history of redemption, to illustrate to the world what a relationship with the living God is like. Thus, the palaces, temples, fortified cities, and strongholds must go, just as surely as the golden calf must go. They have a spiritual grip on the hearts and minds of Yahweh's people, and a jealous God will brook no rivals.

The occasional references to Judah must have helped later Judeans to adopt and own the message of Hosea for themselves. Although almost all of specific complaints and judgments and expressions of affection in the book are directed to Israel/Ephraim, Judah's relationship is governed by the same equation of fidelity and law, and thus the principles expressed in Hosea apply equally to the south.

#### *Response*

Israel did not know the real God, yet they deluded themselves into thinking that he was pleased with them. The real God had revealed himself through his laws (and, of course, in other ways as well). They should have known better. But, because they became worthless to him, God determined that they would cease to exist as a people.

Hosea's generation models anti-repentance. Yahweh had brought an earlier generation out of Egypt. This was salvation for them, and in this they were a picture of the greater salvation Christians experience in Christ. But the judgment on Hosea's generation was that as a nation they would revert to their pre-saved state. They typify those who have felt in some way the graces of salvation and yet fall away, making impossible any return to saving faith (Heb. 6:1–8).

<span id="page-225-7"></span><span id="page-225-5"></span><span id="page-225-2"></span>The text is clear that Israel thought of themselves as very religious. Their cry was mimicked by Yahweh: "My God, we—Israel—know you" (Hos. 8:2). They multiplied altars (v. 13). The prophet has to point out to them that the calf of Samaria was not in fact God (v. 6), yet they thought they were worshiping something real, someone who was pleased with them.

<span id="page-225-4"></span><span id="page-225-3"></span>The true and living God was not impressed with their religiosity. In fact, he was disgusted with it. In the eyes of God, they ignored him (v. 4) and spurned what was <span id="page-226-2"></span><span id="page-226-0"></span>actually good (v. 3). They forgot who their Maker really was (v. 14). They became incapable of knowing him. Even if God were to have revealed tens of thousands of laws, they would not have been moved from their willful ignorance (v. 12). Because of this, they no longer had a unique relationship with God, and thus they were lost.

Like Hosea, Jesus also speaks of the coming judgment for those who are outwardly religious but do not really know the Lord:

Not everyone who says to me, "Lord, Lord," will enter the kingdom of heaven, but the one who does the will of my Father who is in heaven. On that day many will say to me, "Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and cast out demons in your name, and do many mighty works in your name?" And then will I declare to them, "I never knew you; depart from me, you workers of lawlessness." (Matt. 7:21–23)

<span id="page-226-5"></span><span id="page-226-1"></span>"Lord, Lord" seems to be the new mantra of self-deceptive religion. It is possible to give Jesus lip service just as surely as it was possible for OT Israel to put its faith in the outward trappings of faith. But without inner conformity to the values of Christ's kingdom, without a transformed heart and a new birth, one's religion is so many altars of sin (Hos. 8:11). What Jesus calls for is a faith that acknowledges him, and him alone, as King—and serves him with joyful and wholehearted obedience. This is the natural response to a King who has saved us in his matchless power and unspeakably great love.

<span id="page-226-4"></span><span id="page-226-3"></span>Samaria—and later, Jerusalem—experienced the final judgment ahead of time in order to foreshadow the end of the world. The prophet's work was to call them to the way of escape from this judgment. Some suggest it is Hosea the prophet who is called by God to blow the trumpet.27 After all, Hosea teaches that prophets are watchmen, commissioned to warn the people (9:8). Today, Christians also proclaim to the world the way of salvation, laboring at this mission until Jesus returns.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-228-1"></span>This section continues the theme of exile for the people of God because of spiritual adultery. Here, Hosea reiterates that Israel is headed for ultimate ruin; in other words, they will be removed from the Promised Land, and their relationship with God will be severed (9:3). He treats their sin as a historic pattern, going back to the days of Gibeah (v. 9). Then Yahweh joins in and argues that he knew something was wrong as far back as the incident at Baal-Peor (v. 10). The judgment on Israel is specifically a failure of fecundity: they will have no progeny. Theirs will be the last generation.

### *Comment*

<span id="page-229-5"></span><span id="page-229-4"></span><span id="page-229-3"></span>9:1–2 Having left their one true lover, Israel—whom God still calls "my people" beds every available god and pagan nation (v. 1). Hosea calls on them to stop reveling in the abundance they have enjoyed from their harvest, since the threshing floors, their corn and wine, will not "feed" them (v. 2). They live at the Lord's mercy, and he will soon cause their abundance to disappear.

<span id="page-229-6"></span><span id="page-229-1"></span>9:3–6 In light of such unfaithfulness, the Israelites "shall not remain in the land of the Lord" (v. 3), which was not to be defiled by such wickedness (Lev. 18:24–30). Because they failed to "return" to the Lord (again the verb *shub*, which implies repentance), they will "return" to Egypt—as if they had never left or come to know the Lord. It is a punishment that fits the crime. The same is true with regard to eating "unclean food in Assyria": by failing to be people of purity in the Lord's land, they will be exiled to a land in which they will be forced to eat impure food, becoming just like the nations in their diets (as they had become in their practices as well). Their addiction to deviancy renders them despicable to their divine husband, and he will annul his union with them.

<span id="page-229-7"></span>Nothing they will do in exile will relate to Yahweh (Hos. 9:4). None of the practices they were able to perform to the service of the God who brought them out of Egypt will be allowed. They will not pour out drink offerings for him. They will eat bread because they are hungry, but none will be reserved for "the house of the Lord." Yahweh's "house" (v. 4) could be a reference to the "land of the Lord" (v. 3) or to a religious center in it—the shrine in Bethel, for example. The point is that they will be unable to enjoy whatever "appointed festival" or feast days that previously connected them to God (v. 5). Their end is damnation. They will die unredeemed and be buried in a foreign land devoid of Yahweh (v. 6). The Lord had once saved them from Pharaoh, but now he will give them back to an oppressor, and nature—nettles and thorns—will destroy their property in judgment (v. 6; cf. Isa. 5:6; 7:23–25).

<span id="page-229-12"></span><span id="page-229-11"></span><span id="page-229-10"></span><span id="page-229-9"></span><span id="page-229-8"></span><span id="page-229-2"></span>9:7–9 Hosea proclaims that the "days of punishment have come"—judgment is imminent; the time for repentance is now or never (v. 7a). And what of Israel's response? The text momentarily gives voice to the rebellious people: they accuse Hosea of being out of his mind and at odds with the community (v. 7b). They call him mad.28 They seem to be accusing Hosea of great hatred toward them, and of great sin.

<span id="page-229-13"></span>Prophets are supposed to be watchmen, ready to warn of danger at the behest of God (v. 8). But the people would not listen. Their enmity ("hatred") toward their God and his prophet in the land caused their "ways" to be so ensnared that it is the people of Israel who are revealed in the end as fools and madmen, for they are the ones who embraced a misleading spirit.29

<span id="page-229-14"></span><span id="page-229-0"></span>The word translated "corrupt" (v. 9) first appears in Scripture at Genesis 6:11–13, where we read that the world was corrupt and filled with violence. The

<sup>28</sup> Hans Wolff, "Prophets and Institutions in the Old Testament," *CurTM* 13/1 (1986): 5.

<sup>29</sup> Esther Hamori, "The Spirit of Falsehood," *CBQ* 72/1 (2010): 27.

<span id="page-230-3"></span><span id="page-230-2"></span>corruption Hosea mentions is that of Gibeah. Perhaps Hosea alludes to Judges 19– 21, where we read that the Gibean citizenry gang-raped a Levite's concubine to death (Judges 19). The rest of the tribes (except for Benjamin) gathered to bring judgment against the people of Gibeah for this great wrong. Here it is the Lord who will remember the great wrongs the Israelites of Hosea's day have committed and will punish them for their sins.

<span id="page-230-9"></span><span id="page-230-7"></span>9:10–12 The identity of the speaker shifts from Hosea to Yahweh, who speaks again in the first person. God remembers Israel when they first met: she was like a savory, delicious, attractive vine in the desert. Rescuing her was like finding the first fig of the season (v. 10a). His relationship to the previous generation was fondly remembered, as they went together through the wilderness. He was their one God, and they were his people.

<span id="page-230-8"></span><span id="page-230-5"></span><span id="page-230-0"></span>But this monogamous harmony was disrupted when Israel went to the Baal of Peor (the "thing of shame"; v. 10b). Like Hosea's citation of Gibeah, Yahweh now reminisces about an even earlier event. While still led by Moses, Israel encountered Moabites and joined in worship of their god, Baal of Peor (Num. 25:1–3). This took place in Shittim (cf. comment on Hos. 5:1–2). Israel easily and eagerly abandoned the covenant between themselves and Yahweh there, and since that time, says the Lord (9:10), things have never been the same between them. They became as ugly as the thing they loved.

<span id="page-230-10"></span><span id="page-230-6"></span>Thus Ephraim's "glory" will "fly away like a bird" (v. 11). Their glory in this case is primarily their progeny: they will be left childless. This is a fitting judgment, since Baal was credited with, among other things, fertility. They sow to Baal for fecundity, but they reap childlessness. Whatever children they do have will be taken through violence (v. 12). They will die off as a people. If they will not be the people of God, they will be no people at all.

<span id="page-230-13"></span><span id="page-230-12"></span><span id="page-230-11"></span>9:13–17 Verse 13 is difficult. Most commentators follow the ancient Greek translation or assume a transmission error and reword it. McComiskey translates, "Just as I have chosen [judgment] for Tyre, planted in [its] place, so [I have chosen for] Ephraim to lead forth its sons to the murderer"30 (cf. ESV mg.). However the verse is intended, the judgment is clear: the present generation of Ephraim is the final generation.

<span id="page-230-15"></span><span id="page-230-14"></span><span id="page-230-4"></span>Apparently the prophet interjects a prayer in verse 14, asking the Lord to indeed bring the people to an end. The Lord's speech then resumes. Having mentioned their faithlessness at one place in the past (Baal-Peor; v. 10), he now mentions their sin somewhere else in the present: at Gilgal (v. 15), which has already been identified in Hosea with illicit worship (4:15). Their evil is so great that it has led the Lord to "hate" them, a word used elsewhere to describe the attitude of a husband seeking divorce (Deut. 22:13; 24:3), not necessarily because visceral hatred is involved but because he rejects his wife. The point is that God will no longer

<span id="page-230-1"></span><sup>30</sup> Thomas Edward McComiskey, "Hos 9:13 and the Integrity of the Masoretic Tradition in the Prophecy of Hosea," *JETS* 33/2 (1990): 159.

<span id="page-231-2"></span>show his love to Israel. Like a wife he is divorcing, he will "drive them out" of his "house" (the land; cf. Hos. 8:1). He also makes clear that some of the blame rests with Israel's leaders, those who should have been leading them in righteousness but in reality were leading them to rebellion.

<span id="page-231-6"></span>Israel's Lord repeats: whatever children they manage to bear will be killed (9:16). This is the last generation of Israel. Their time is up. It's over.

<span id="page-231-7"></span>Finally, Hosea again clarifies (v. 17). Although not every last child will be killed, and the population will not be completely exterminated, they will be integrated with the nations and will aimlessly wander, banished from the land of Yahweh. They will be lost, as good as dead.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-231-4"></span><span id="page-231-0"></span>God says that Israel has become "detestable like the thing they loved" (Hos. 9:10). Fixating upon something other than the true and living God, organizing one's life around it, will change a person until he or she resembles that thing, that idol. Psalm 115:4–8 (cf. 135:15–18) details how idols are deaf, dumb, blind, immobile, and inanimate. The passage then concludes, "Those who make them become like them; so do all who trust in them" (Ps. 115:8). From a spiritual perspective, idolaters become as lifeless and impotent as what they serve. This is a strong call and warning to turn from putting our hope in the things of this world to instead placing it in the true and living God.

<span id="page-231-9"></span><span id="page-231-8"></span><span id="page-231-3"></span><span id="page-231-1"></span>When Hosea preached against idolatry, he was mocked for it (cf. Hos. 9:7). Jesus warns that the same will be true for those who are faithful to his word (Matt. 5:11), and Paul explains that "The word of the cross is folly to those who are perishing" (1 Cor. 1:18). But just as Hosea was faithful to the word of the Lord, so too must we be faithful. The apostle Peter reminds Christians, "If you are insulted for the name of Christ, you are blessed, because the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you. . . . Yet if anyone suffers as a Christian, let him not be ashamed, but let him glorify God in that name" (1 Pet. 4:14, 16).

<span id="page-231-12"></span><span id="page-231-11"></span><span id="page-231-10"></span><span id="page-231-5"></span>Hosea 9 ends with a sober warning: Israel's continual refusal to repent of their wicked ways will lead to their rejection as the Lord's people (vv. 10–17). Whether in the OT, as here, or in the NT, as in Hebrews 3–4, the Lord consistently warns that those who continue in full-hearted rebellion and sin should not think of themselves as the people of God who will one day inherit the covenant promises. The Promised Land—whether Canaan or the new heavens and new earth—is not for apostates. For this reason, Christians are commanded to "exhort one another every day" (Heb. 3:13), reminding one another that we follow a faithful High Priest and Savior, Jesus, the one who will lead us finally and safely into God's blessed Promised Land of rest.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-233-5"></span><span id="page-233-4"></span><span id="page-233-2"></span>Hosea 10:1–8 is a third-person speech sandwiched between two first-person soliloquies, forming one unit of text (9:17 looks both forward and backward, serving to unite the previous unit with this one). The center of the speech seems to be 10:5–6, which speaks of the golden calf being plundered and taken to Assyria in exile and the people who worshiped it suffering tremendous judgment. This core material is framed by prophecies concerning kings (vv. 3–4, 7), which are likewise enclosed by condemnations of doomed high places and altars (vv. 1b–2, 8a).31 In the opening line, Israel is productive, but the more prosperous they become, the deeper they pursue false religion (v. 1). Thus in the closing line Israel in despair cries to the mountains to fall on them (v. 8).

<span id="page-233-6"></span><span id="page-233-3"></span><span id="page-233-1"></span><span id="page-233-0"></span>After Hosea's speech, the Lord brings up (again) the sin of Gibeah (recorded in Judges 19) (Hos. 10:9–11). That event is paradigmatic for the nation. They have misbehaved but up to now have been spared the full consequences for their actions. However, the time has now come for Ephraim (and Judah) to be spared no longer; they will be disciplined severely as the nations gather against them in judgment.

<sup>31</sup> Leeuwen, "Meaning and Structure of Hosea X 1–8," 377.

The prophet then takes up his burden again and calls upon his kinsmen to turn to Yahweh (vv. 12–15). If they do not begin to live differently, a terrible end is inevitable, including judgment on their children. The house of the golden calf is an ever-present offense before the living God.

IV.F. The Calf and the People (10:1–15)

- <span id="page-234-2"></span>1. The Calf Will Go (10:1–8)
- 2. Because of the Calf, Terrible Things (10:9–11)
- <span id="page-234-7"></span><span id="page-234-1"></span>3. They Will Lose Everything (10:12–15)

## *Comment*

10:1–8 Although there is some question concerning the first half of verse 1,32 the second half is clear: Israel's advancement in prosperity has only furthered their crimes. The more they harvested, the more they built altars for illicit worship; the more the country improved, the more they improved their sacred stones ("pillars") for idolatry.

<span id="page-234-3"></span>Their lifestyle was oriented toward false worship, and it seems there is no motivation to change. "Their heart is false" (v. 2), so God must annihilate what is the product of, and the sustaining force for, their waywardness: the altars and other cultic objects.

The king whom they denounce, do not fear, and dismiss (v. 3) is perhaps Yahweh.33 To paraphrase, "Yahweh is not our king. We do not fear him; as for this King—he would do nothing for us anyway." The Hebrew in verse 3 is definite: "the king"; that is, a specific king is at issue. One may be reminded of the Jews' assertion to Pilate, "We have no king but Caesar" (John 19:15).

<span id="page-234-9"></span><span id="page-234-4"></span>Alternatively, the spurned king of Hosea 10:3 could be the Israelite king as he would be perceived after judgment had fallen and the people exiled. Hosea articulates their imagined speech, perhaps envisioning the thoughts of a people who wake up too late to their true situation. From a foreign land they will recognize that they should have feared the Lord.

<span id="page-234-5"></span>Verse 4 describes different types of faithless behavior. While it is debated whether it is the kings or the people who are being described, the type of behavior is generally clear. The verse begins by describing sin committed with the mouth and concludes by describing sin committed in acts of justice, acts that should have been righteous but in fact have been so wicked that they are more like poisonous weeds (cf. Amos 5:7; 6:12).

<span id="page-234-8"></span><span id="page-234-6"></span><span id="page-234-0"></span>Hosea 10:5 returns to the theme of idolatry, mentioning "the calf of Beth-aven," that is, the golden calf set up by Jeroboam (cf. comment on 4:15–16). This false god, which they considered glorious, will in fact be taken from them into exile by

<sup>32</sup> Most modern translations read "luxuriant vine," following the Greek as well as the meaning of an Arabic word built on the same root. Normally the Hebrew term means "to empty, lay waste, disturb," although this does not seem to fit the context well.

<sup>33</sup> Andersen and Freedman, *Hosea*, 457.

<span id="page-235-4"></span><span id="page-235-3"></span><span id="page-235-1"></span>Assyria (v. 6a; for "the great king," cf. comment on 5:10–13 [at v. 13]). There is no glory in other gods, and those who put their hope in them do not experience glory but only shame (v. 6b). Samaria's king will perish (v. 7) and their cultic centers will be destroyed, becoming wastelands filled only with thorn and thistle (v. 8a). So thorough will be the destruction that Israel will cry out for the mountains to bury them (v. 8b). Death would be preferable to the intense judgment to be unleashed on them.

<span id="page-235-7"></span><span id="page-235-6"></span><span id="page-235-5"></span><span id="page-235-2"></span><span id="page-235-0"></span>10:9–11 Yahweh now resumes his denunciation, again referencing Gibeah (v. 9; cf. comment on 9:7–9). The last part of 10:9 probably refers to the unjust Benjaminites and the terrible judgment that befell them (Judges 20; cf., again, comment on Hos. 9:7–9). Yahweh cites this as a warning that a similar "war against the unjust" is coming; although it has not yet ruined them, it soon will. Perhaps 10:10 continues to reference this war: as the tribes of Israel gathered at God's behest against the original perpetrators in Judges 20, so will the "nations" do the same in order to subject Israel to God's discipline and punishment. The term "double iniquity" (Hos. 10:10) is debated; some suggest that it refers to sins in the past and present or to two different idols worshiped by Israel, or that it is a general way to emphasize the depth of Israel's sin.

<span id="page-235-9"></span><span id="page-235-8"></span>In an earlier and happier time, Ephraim was a domesticated heifer (v. 11), working in harmony with its owner. But now both Ephraim and Judah need stricter discipline (a "yoke"; v. 11).

<span id="page-235-11"></span><span id="page-235-10"></span>10:12–15 Here once again the prophet picks up where Yahweh left off. He calls upon his people to heed the words of the Lord and believe, redeploying agricultural metaphors in new ways. Hosea calls them to sow not literal seed for a harvest of grain but "righteousness"—fidelity to the law, wholehearted love for the God of Israel (v. 12). To sow righteousness is to reap "steadfast love"—in Hebrew, *hesed*, covenanted loyalty or fidelity. The difficult task of breaking up fallow ground symbolizes whatever social change is required to produce a society characterized by righteousness and integrity toward Yahweh.

The prophet urges the people to seek the Lord until he responds by blessing their repentance; he will "rain righteousness upon you." The prophet is perhaps employing a pun, as the Hebrew verb "to rain" can also mean "to teach." To "rain righteousness" may be, in reality, to "teach" or instruct the people in the ways of the law. A way out of their predicament is thus suggested: as they seek the Lord and his righteousness, Yahweh will cooperate with that effort and move it along.

Hosea then reviews the sad reality of Israel's recent history up to this point, as well as the consequences that will follow if they do not turn. In strong contrast to verse 12, Israel has "plowed iniquity" (not "righteousness") and "thus reaped injustice" (not "steadfast love") (v. 13). Their only harvest has been "the fruit of lies," that is, the consequences of their disastrous national agenda. For example, they have placed their trust in their "own way." They have trusted that the size of their army would suffice. They have undervalued the God of their fathers while overestimating their own strength.

<span id="page-236-4"></span>As a result, their military power will inevitably be overrun (v. 14). They have trusted in fortresses just as surely as they trusted in the golden calf—and thus the fortresses have to go. Hosea refers to an event not mentioned elsewhere in the Bible—but surely known to his audience—as a historical template for Israel's vulnerability ("as Shalman destroyed Beth-arbel"). What is clear is that the same Hebrew word for "destroy" used in verse 2 in reference to the sacred pillars is used in verse 14 to refer to their fortresses: as the calf was defaced and then carried away, so their strongholds will be breached and atrocities allowed. To trust in fortresses in place of God is to leave one's own infants without protection (v. 14b).

<span id="page-236-6"></span><span id="page-236-5"></span>The center of the problem is located in Bethel (v. 15), the house of the golden calf, the central lie that Israel has internalized, the binding force of their whole alternative religion. The king who patronizes this noxious cult will be "utterly cut off."

### *Response*

Consider the insights concerning idolatry revealed in this chapter. This topic has far-reaching spiritual and psychological ramifications, deeply and profoundly applicable to Christians in the twenty-first century. People's basic motivations and faith commitments have not changed in character over the millennia; the same way of thinking at work in ancient Israel still moves hearts today.

At first, idolatry seems limited to cultic objects: golden calves, altars, and sacred pillars. Of course no Christian, nor most non-Christians, in Western society has ever participated in this sort of religion. But the plethora of self-deceptions goes far beyond mere stone and wood totems. The true test of what a person believes is seen in what he trusts, in what he finds to be his refuge, security, or hope. What is believed to protect the future? What is necessary to be acceptable and at peace? It is here that modern civilization overlaps the ancient world.

<span id="page-236-3"></span><span id="page-236-0"></span>Israel's functional theology is seen in what they trusted. This is not the religion they would have confessed, but it is nevertheless what motivated them. They "trusted" in their "own way" (v. 13). This is reminiscent of the story of Gibeah in Judges 19–21. There, Israel at first did as God instructed in upholding the cause of the victim. But soon they stopped inquiring of God, and as he dropped out of their reckoning their actions went further and further afield, resulting in atrocities even greater than the original offense. A sense of autonomy—of being sufficient in oneself to follow one's own agenda and live by one's own rules—is clearly on display in that narrative.

<span id="page-236-2"></span><span id="page-236-1"></span>Of course, nothing could be more modern than such an attitude. Autonomy from religion—and thus from God—in one's calculations is as natural today as it was for the wayward Israelites. But trusting in oneself has grave consequences. To trust in oneself is to behave as if one had the authority of God; hence the crooked, counterfeit "justice" meted out in Judges 20–21, and also the injustice and iniquity characterizing Israel in Hosea 10. The list of atrocities committed in modern times in the name of atheistic and fascist ideologies need hardly be cataloged here. But

a sense of autonomy from God's moral code has led to unbridled iniquity among the citizenry in every nation that embraces secular humanism. This is the motto of trusting in the self: "I can do anything I want; no God will judge me; I am my own law."

<span id="page-237-3"></span>However, trusting oneself proves to be a false hope. Hosea connects this attitude with shame and loss, finally issuing in a previously self-confident people's crying to the hills to fall on and cover them (10:6, 8). Trusting in oneself leads in the end to despair. The job is too difficult. The task is too great. The sense of being overwhelmed feels like being a twig on the water, helplessly carried into the unknown (v. 7).

<span id="page-237-4"></span>The Israelites also placed their trust in military strength. This likewise characterizes the modern age. Their naive hope in strongholds and numbers of warriors would later fail them, resulting in loss, atrocity, and ruin, says Hosea.

<span id="page-237-1"></span>Israel had taken the fruit of the land, its overflowing produce, and put it to the service of a strange cult (v. 1). To what do people lend the fruits of their labor today? To know what a person spends much money on is to know what that person worships. An idolater invests in his idol. A nation of idolaters supports with their substance the national idol.

<span id="page-237-2"></span>Israel mourned because her national hope had lost its luster (v. 5). Her existence became characterized by fear, shame, hardship, ruin, and separation. Having repudiated Yahweh, Israel substituted for him by making worthless treaties. Utter despair is the natural consequence of losing one's religion. When one's object of trust fails, one is left without recourse.

<span id="page-237-7"></span><span id="page-237-0"></span>The obvious challenge of Hosea 10 is to consider in what way one's own inner assumptions and unexamined motivations are out of accord with the faith that one confesses. Jesus said that one cannot serve both God and money (Luke 16:13). What rules our hearts? Greed? The respect or love of others? Trust in our own abilities and competencies? Whatever it is, it is in competition with the gospel of Jesus and will eventually create a spiritual conflict in our lives.

<span id="page-237-8"></span><span id="page-237-6"></span><span id="page-237-5"></span>The alternative that Hosea presents is to seek God and sow what is right in his sight. "Break up your fallow ground" (Hos. 10:12), and he will shower us with knowledge of how to live rightly before him. This happens today as we heed the call of Jesus to take his yoke upon us and to learn from him, the one who is gentle and lowly in heart, the one who can give us true rest for our souls (Matt. 11:29) and who fills us with the fruit of righteousness, to the glory and praise of God (Phil. 1:11).

- and out of Egypt I called my son.
- **<sup>2</sup>** The more they were called, the more they went away; they kept sacrificing to the Baals and burning offerings to idols.
- **<sup>3</sup>** Yet it was I who taught Ephraim to walk; I took them up by their arms, but they did not know that I healed them.
- **<sup>4</sup>** I led them with cords of kindness,*<sup>1</sup>* with the bands of love, and I became to them as one who eases the yoke on their jaws, and I bent down to them and fed them.

- **<sup>6</sup>** The sword shall rage against their cities, consume the bars of their gates, and devour them because of their own counsels.
- **<sup>7</sup>** My people are bent on turning away from me, and though they call out to the Most High, he shall not raise them up at all.
- **<sup>8</sup>** How can I give you up, O Ephraim? How can I hand you over, O Israel? How can I make you like Admah? How can I treat you like Zeboiim? My heart recoils within me; my compassion grows warm and tender.
- **<sup>9</sup>** I will not execute my burning anger; I will not again destroy Ephraim; for I am God and not a man, the Holy One in your midst,
- and I will not come in wrath.*<sup>3</sup>*
- **<sup>10</sup>** They shall go after the Lord; he will roar like a lion; when he roars,
- his children shall come trembling from the west;
- **<sup>11</sup>** they shall come trembling like birds from Egypt, and like doves from the land of Assyria, and I will return them to their homes, declares the Lord.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-239-10"></span><span id="page-239-3"></span><span id="page-239-2"></span>The great corpus of chapters 4–11 began with the call to "Hear the word of the Lord" (Hos. 4:1) and ends with the statement, "declares the Lord" (11:11). It climaxes with this section, where God's heart is once again revealed clearly. He is emotionally bound to this wayward people and is of two minds about them.

This material "is as tender as any in the Bible"—its intimacy is almost maternal.34 "Hosea 11:1–11 gives as clear and personal [a] picture into the heart of God as any illustration in all of Scripture."35 God loved Ephraim, adopted him, taught him to walk, held him in his arms, healed him, bound himself to him with "cords of kindness," bent down to feed him (vv. 1–4). One could not ask for a more attentive parent. He really loved his boy.

The next two sections address the immediate future situation and God's ambivalence. First, once again God expresses his disappointment and righteous indignation against his people (vv. 5–7). But then, almost miraculously, he reveals how this hurts him more than it does them (vv. 8–9). Yahweh is inwardly conflicted. Israel has offended him to the point that he desires to reject them forever. He wants to punish. He wants to get their attention by whatever harsh means are necessary. But in the end, he just cannot bring himself to do it.

This leads to the final portion of this section of Hosea, which looks to the more distant future (vv. 10–11). With almost rose-colored glasses, in a deeply emotional mood, Hosea envisions the people's return when God roars at them like a lion. They will hear Yahweh's too-deep-for-words utterance and will come trembling to him. The final thought of this great corpus is the Lord's declaration, "I will return them to their homes" (v. 11). God and prophet recognize that Israel's story will have a happy ending after all.

## <span id="page-239-4"></span>*Section Outline*

IV.G. My Heart Recoils within Me (11:1–11)

- <span id="page-239-5"></span>1. I Love Them (11:1–4)
- <span id="page-239-7"></span>2. I Will Kill Them! (11:5–7)
- <span id="page-239-8"></span>3. No, I Won't (11:8–9)
- <span id="page-239-9"></span>4. They'll Come Back (11:10–11)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-239-1"></span><span id="page-239-0"></span>11:1–4 God picks up the narrative and again speaks in the first person. "Loved" and "called" (v. 1) is the language of election (Deut. 7:6–8): God is again reminiscing on the early days, when Israel was called from Egypt (Hos. 2:15). But amid this expression of parental affection, recalling Ephraim's infancy and toddler days (11:3–4), a seemingly out-of-place verse is found (v. 2). If this verse were before or after this section, it would not convey the same degree of dissonance and tension.

<span id="page-239-6"></span><sup>34</sup> Frederick Gaiser, "Preaching God: Hosea 11:1–11," *WW* 28/2 (2008): 204.

<sup>35</sup> Richard Lloyd and Debbie Lloyd, "An Example of the Shared Praxis Model Based on Hosea 11:1–11," *RevExp* 107/2 (2010): 239.

But right in the middle of God's looking, as it were, through the photo album of Ephraim's preschooler days, his eyes shining with sentiment, is an ugly and alien verse that mars the loving memories. Israel's response to Yahweh, even back then, was to spurn him and favor Baals and idols.

God is describing the past fully; he is not romanticizing it. From the beginning, Israel was not content with him. Their original sin was that in their hearts they never left Egypt. They did not realize who had "healed" them. All of Yahweh's gifts (including redemption), all of his provision, all of his providential care and pledged love had never moved them to want him.

<span id="page-240-3"></span><span id="page-240-2"></span>11:5–7 While some understand the opening line of verse 5 as declaring that Ephraim will return to Egypt (cf. ESV mg.), the ESV's translation makes perfect sense: Israel will not go back to literal Egypt but will be oppressed in Assyria. This is in full agreement with the idea of 8:13.

<span id="page-240-1"></span><span id="page-240-0"></span>The mood of 11:1–4, despite the discordant verse 2, was positive. In this section, that radically changes. Suddenly, the Lord vents his anger and exasperation, as if he has experienced a sudden shift in emotion. This is part of the imagery of Hosea: the theology that explores God's relationship with his people is communicated using the imagery of a parent at the end of his rope. The time has come for severance and dissolution of the relationship. If Israel will not *act* like the people of God, then they will not *be* the people of God. Let them be disinherited! Give them to the Assyrian king, who will conquer them in terrifying war (v. 6)!

<span id="page-240-5"></span><span id="page-240-4"></span>"Returning/turning" (*shub*) is a leading motif in this section, repeated in various forms three times in three verses. Israel will return not to Egypt but to Assyria (v. 5), for they refused to return to the Lord (v. 5); they are bent on turning away from him (v. 7). Verse 7 presents special difficulties; Ritschl calls it "untranslatable."36 Speiser suggests that the sense of the first few words is something like, "My people are addicted to turning away from me."37 Perhaps the verse continues with this thought: "Together, they call him to the One on high; he will not exalt him." Paraphrased, "Together, the prophets call Ephraim to Yahweh, but Ephraim will not exalt him." Whatever the precise meaning, the overall message is very clear: Israel and God have become irreconcilably estranged.

<span id="page-240-7"></span>11:8–9 Once again God's emotional state abruptly and enormously shifts. Having stated his intended purpose, having served notice, the Lord now has second thoughts. This is imagery drawn from the psychological state of a grieving father, who loves his deviant son even while recognizing that his antisocial behavior requires a just and definitive response. "How can I give you up?" God asks himself (v. 8). "How can I hand you over?" Although justice seems to demand it, the tender heart of God, who remembers Ephraim as an infant and a toddler, seeks another way.

<span id="page-240-6"></span><sup>36</sup> Dietrich Ritschl, "God's Conversion: An Exposition of Hosea 11," *Int* 15/3 (1961): 291.

<sup>37</sup> E. A. Speiser, "TLW'YM LMŠWBTY, Hosea 11:7," *JBL* 44 (1925): 190.

<span id="page-241-2"></span><span id="page-241-1"></span><span id="page-241-0"></span>The cities of Admah and Zeboiim are listed in Genesis 14:2 along with the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah, and their mention in this verse is perhaps a way of saying, "How can I destroy you as I did Sodom and Gomorrah?" These cities were "overthrown" (Gen. 19:25)—the very word used in Hosea 11:8 ("recoils") to speak of God's heart. The verb is used in Jonah's oracle that Nineveh would be "overthrown" (Jonah 3:4), and also in Lamentations 1:20: "My heart is wrung within me." The sense is that God is inwardly conflicted; Israel has put him in a double bind. He is a loving parent whose son has committed a terrible and unforgivable crime. This metaphor conveys something true about how the holy God relates to his criminal and reprobate children.

<span id="page-241-6"></span>The end result of God's inner dialogue is that he has decided—at least for the moment—not to unleash on Israel the full wrath they deserve. Judgments he has determined against them will not fall. Why? Because he is holy (Hos. 11:9), utterly distinct, and thus—unlike humanity—does not simply act out his anger in mean and vindictive ways. He is both a God who has strong emotions and a God who is not ruled by them. He will not simply come and unleash his "wrath" in uncontrollable anger.

<span id="page-241-7"></span>11:10–11 Inspired by Yahweh's speech, Hosea exults in a vision of God's roaring like a lion and the sons of Israel's trembling like birds, returning to the Promised Land from Egypt and Assyria. From wherever God's people will be scattered, Hosea envisions their return.

<span id="page-241-3"></span>The book opened with the fact that Israel had whored "from after" Yahweh (1:2 AT), but here they will "walk after" him (AT). In the eschatological future, in the climax of history, the people of God will do what they should have done all along.

<span id="page-241-4"></span>Finally, Yahweh himself closes the great corpus of chapters 4–11 with the promise, "I will return them to their homes." Instead of destroying them, he will chastise and discipline them until they learn to fear and love him. Then he will call them home.

## *Response*

Early in its history, Israel had for centuries been in bondage in Egypt for no fault of its own. The people originally went down to Egypt as a means of salvation from starvation, God having graciously sent Joseph ahead of them to prepare the way. They were not there as punishment for any sin. They were unjustly enslaved and mistreated, but God identified them as his son, those who inherited the covenant promises made to Abraham, and called them up out of Egypt (11:1).

<span id="page-241-8"></span><span id="page-241-5"></span>Many years later, Jesus would be taken as a young child down to Egypt in order to escape the murderous intentions of King Herod. After relating how Herod died and the Lord told the parents of Jesus to come home, it is this very verse that Matthew quotes and applies to Jesus: "Out of Egypt I called my son" (Matt. 2:15). This is not because Matthew is unaware that the verse is speaking of the nation of

<span id="page-242-1"></span>Sadly, Israel was not at all faithful to such a task, despite all that the Lord did for them. The complaint in Hosea 11:1–4 is that all of God's gifts did not move Israel to want him. This is a challenge for modern-day believers. What is Christianity for? Why do we follow Jesus? Is it for various gifts, such as a ticket to heaven? Or is it because we want to know him and live a life pleasing to him, in his service? After describing all the Lord has done for us in Jesus (Romans 9–11), Paul shows us the proper response: "Present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and acceptable to God, which is your spiritual worship" (Rom. 12:1). Wholehearted obedient love is the proper response to the goodness we have received in Jesus.

<span id="page-242-5"></span><span id="page-242-4"></span><span id="page-242-2"></span><span id="page-242-0"></span>Israel's response to the Lord's goodness in delivering them from Egypt should have been the same, but it was very different, and the Lord describes his response in incredibly human terms. He loves them—so much so that he is like a parent whose heart is torn over a rebellious child, who knows the child needs strong discipline and who will eventually bring it (Hos. 11:5–6). He cannot give up on the child (v. 8). It is thus true that God knows the end from the beginning (Isa. 46:10), and that he operates on an eternal plan conceived in decrees made between the Father and the Son before the foundation of the earth. He is completely holy, not subject to his emotions' controlling him as humans' emotions do (Hos. 11:9). But it is also true that the imagery of Hosea forcefully presents a very impassioned deity, inwardly divided and torn. And he wants his people to know this about him; he wants them to know that the depth of his anger at their rebellion, and the depth of his love despite it, is just like that of a parent toward a child who rebels.

<span id="page-242-3"></span>What this means for Israel is clear. On the one hand, they should learn to avoid sin, so that they might not experience the discipline of the Father. At the same time, they should learn that when they do rebel, the proper response is to come back to him with humble hearts, knowing that their Father will forgive them. And if this is true for Israel, how much truer it is for believers in Jesus today. In Jesus, the Lord has shown not only how seriously he takes sin—his own Son had to die for it on our behalf—he also shows how far he will go to receive us back—his own Son died so that we might become his sons and daughters! And this calls us to avoid sin with all our hearts and, when we have sinned, to return to the Lord with all our hearts—to the One who will take us back into his loving arms.

## HOSEA 11:12–12:1

<span id="page-243-4"></span>**12** *1* Ephraim has surrounded me with lies, and the house of Israel with deceit, but Judah still walks with God and is faithful to the Holy One. 12 Ephraim feeds on the wind and pursues the east wind all day long; they multiply falsehood and violence; they make a covenant with Assyria, and oil is carried to Egypt.

1Ch 12:1 in Hebrew

#### *Section Outline*

V. Bridge: No, They Won't; Well, Judah Will (11:12–12:1)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-243-3"></span>11:12–12:1 These two verses form a bridge between the climactic end of the great central movement in Hosea and the opening of the next movement. The critique of the northern kingdom (Ephraim) is very strong: they are characterized by "lies" and "deceit" (11:12a) and continue their habit of pursuing alliances with the nations (12:1), having entered into a treaty with Assyria. This is parallel to the obscure idiom that they "carried oil to Egypt," perhaps a reference to tribute they gave in order to secure an alliance. What is clear is that they trusted in Egypt and Assyria, and this is utter folly—like trying to nourish oneself on the wind or catch it in one's hand.

<span id="page-243-0"></span>Judah is also mentioned here (11:12), and there is debate concerning whether the reference should be understood positively or negatively. The ESV translates, "Judah still walks with God." The verb rendered "walk" is quite rare, found only four times in the Bible. One instance is in Genesis 27:40, where Isaac condemns Esau to serve his brother until he grows "restless" (same word) and breaks his yoke. Some understand Hosea 11:12 to carry this same negative nuance, translating the clause, "Judah is unruly against God, even against the faithful Holy One" (NIV). If so, this would be a way of saying that the Lord is surrounded by the faithless, whether by Israel in the north or by Judah in the south.

<span id="page-243-2"></span><span id="page-243-1"></span>In another instance, however, the verb here rendered as "walk" refers to roaming (cf. Hb. of Jer. 2:31), and the word at the end of Hosea 11:12 ("faithful") can be naturally applied to Judah grammatically (so ESV). This positive perspective of Judah would reflect the historical reality that it displayed periods of faithfulness that the northern kingdom did not. In contrast to Israel, they walked with God.

## <span id="page-244-1"></span>OVERVIEW OF HOSEA 12:2–14:8

Once again, and for the final time, a major movement of Hosea begins with a "charge" or "indictment" against Israel using the Hebrew word *rib*. 38 Using fresh arguments and illustrations, the prophet and his God attempt to get the point across to a recalcitrant audience that times are desperate and change is urgently needed. The metaphors of husband-wife and father-son are finished. To awaken the conscience of the people, chapter 12 recites various well-known and treasured episodes from sacred history. In chapter 13, the Lord reasons with his people. Part of the judgment had already fallen; will they be so stupid as not to act, when God has already shown them what he is willing to do? Death is in store for them if they fail to respond to his last appeal. But then—immediately after final death is assured the mood once again abruptly shifts, and nothing but grace and forgiveness is promised (ch. 14). The book ends on this positive note as one last eloquent appeal is made to Ephraim to turn from idols and political treaties and to the living God.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-245-9"></span><span id="page-245-7"></span>The people of Israel no doubt revered the patriarch Jacob, and Hosea here assumes that they know his story. As Jacob struggled and wrestled with God (12:3) and identified with him (vv. 4–5), so also his descendants should surrender to Yahweh and return to him (v. 6). Using Jacob as an archetype, Hosea constructs a "paradigm of repentance" for Israel.39 But Ephraim is self-satisfied (vv. 7–8); they believe they are faultless and above criticism.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-245-10"></span>VI. The Case against Jacob (12:2–14:8)
	- A. Jacob and His Posterity I (12:2–8)
		- 1. Jacob Strove and Prevailed (12:2–6)
		- 2. Power and Iniquity (12:7–8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-245-2"></span>12:2 This is the opening verse of the last movement in Hosea, and it includes "Judah" in its indictment. The people of Judah need to understand that the same indictment is warranted against them if they pursue the same idolatrous and unjust path as Israel. Both kingdoms (Judah and Israel/Jacob) will experience the Lord's justice because of their wickedness.

<span id="page-245-5"></span><span id="page-245-3"></span><span id="page-245-0"></span>12:3–6 The name "Jacob," meaning "grasper of the heel," is taken from the verb used here (v. 3). Jacob competed and struggled with his brother from the womb (Gen. 25:26) and as an adult struggled with God (Gen. 32:28).40 The two observations in Hosea 12:3 can be considered a merism, a figure of speech that refers to a totality: e.g., "day and night" means "all the time"; "heaven and earth" means "all creation." Here, "in the womb" and "in his manhood" connote that Jacob was characterized by contention his entire life. In the words of his brother, "Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has cheated ("jacobed") me these two times" (Gen. 27:36).

<span id="page-245-6"></span><span id="page-245-1"></span>Note that the last word of Hosea 12:4 is "us." This is not a review of patriarchal history for its own sake; it is the history of the people that is at issue. At Bethel God spoke with Jacob, and there he speaks with "us" too—if we are listening.

<span id="page-245-8"></span>There are various questions regarding the translation of verses 4–6. What seems clear is that Jacob's encounters with the Lord are in focus, as is the Lord

<span id="page-245-4"></span><sup>39</sup> Lyle M. Eslinger, "Hosea 12:5a and Genesis 32:29: A Study in Inner Biblical Exegesis," *JSOT* 18 (1980): 94. 40 In verses 3–4, God and the "angel" are synonyms.

<span id="page-246-1"></span>himself (esp. v. 5). This leads to the command of verse 6: listen, then, says Hosea, and turn to Yahweh, as Jacob your father was redirected from encountering his foe, Esau, alone, to meeting him as a servant of God. This turning to God entails a commitment to "love and justice"—covenant fidelity, honest dealings, and waiting on their true God at all times for his favor and blessing. What this "love and justice" looks like is treated in verses 7–8.

<span id="page-246-4"></span><span id="page-246-3"></span><span id="page-246-2"></span>12:7–8 The prophet has called upon the people to turn to God and to hold fast to love and justice (v. 6). Instead, Ephraim is a cheating merchant who does not love Yahweh but loves to oppress (v. 7). Ephraim credits himself with his wealth, claiming to have no culpability and to be above criticism (v. 8). The people have their own positive mantra that lulls them into a false sense of security, and so the prophet's appeal falls on deaf ears. They simply will not hear it.

## *Response*

<span id="page-246-0"></span>The prophet's indictment is that God's people are unfaithful, untrue to their God and treacherous in their dealings with each other—all the while being selfsatisfied and believing themselves to be above criticism. This indictment is against not only Israel, or even Israel and Judah together. It is against the whole world, as all will likewise be judged "according to his deeds" (12:2). Although modern man may go about his life in a secular way, giving no thought to God, there is a lawsuit that awaits him. The court will sit, the charges will be read, and all who have no relationship with God in this life will have no savior in the next.

<span id="page-246-6"></span><span id="page-246-5"></span>It is of vital importance, then, to listen when God speaks, to turn with his help, and to hold fast to his gospel. Christians should not be like Ephraim, who credited himself with his own prosperity and would not accept guilt for any sin. "It is time for judgment to begin at the household of God; and if it begins with us, what will be the outcome for those who do not obey the gospel of God?" (1 Pet. 4:17).

- **<sup>10</sup>** I spoke to the prophets; it was I who multiplied visions, and through the prophets gave parables.
- **<sup>11</sup>** If there is iniquity in Gilead, they shall surely come to nothing:

 in Gilgal they sacrifice bulls; their altars also are like stone heaps on the furrows of the field.

- **<sup>12</sup>** Jacob fled to the land of Aram; there Israel served for a wife, and for a wife he guarded sheep.
- **<sup>13</sup>** By a prophet the Lord brought Israel up from Egypt, and by a prophet he was guarded.

13 When Ephraim spoke, there was trembling; he was exalted in Israel, but he incurred guilt through Baal and died. **<sup>2</sup>** And now they sin more and more, and make for themselves metal images, idols skillfully made of their silver, all of them the work of craftsmen. It is said of them, "Those who offer human sacrifice kiss calves!" **<sup>3</sup>** Therefore they shall be like the morning mist or like the dew that goes early away, like the chaff that swirls from the threshing floor or like smoke from a window.

## *Section Overview*

This section exhibits a repeating pattern. In the first part of the section (vv. 9–11), the Lord speaks of his past provision for Israel: he multiplied visions. This sets the contemporary situation in sharp relief: the people multiply illegal altars. In the second part of the section (vv. 12–14), Hosea references how Jacob kept sheep while the Lord kept Jacob. This again highlights the heinousness of the people's current state of affairs and explains the enmity between themselves and their Lord. Finally, Hosea continues in a third part of the section, emphasizing again the evil of the people's idolatry (13:1–3). The result is that Israel as a national entity will evaporate and disappear from the earth.

VI.B. Jacob and His Posterity II (12:9–13:3)

- <span id="page-247-1"></span>1. I Multiply Prophets, They Multiply Altars (12:9–11)

- <span id="page-247-0"></span>3. Kissing Calves (13:1–3)

## *Comment*

12:9–11 The last section ended with Ephraim's assertion, "I am rich" (v. 8). This section begins with an emphatic, "I am the Lord your God." The Lord's presence and greatness eclipses and deflates Ephraim's self-aggrandizing pronouncements. God declares himself to be Yahweh, their God since Egyptian days. In their days before any claim to greatness, they were nomads, tent dwellers. The Feast of Tabernacles ("the appointed feast") celebrated this, but it now also serves as a warning. In response to their self-importance, God will reduce Israel to again being a nation of nomads.

<span id="page-248-4"></span><span id="page-248-2"></span>Ephraim has spoken rebelliously (v. 8) claiming to be autonomously responsible for their prosperity and beyond Yahweh's censure. In contrast, Yahweh spoke to the prophets of old (v. 10). He multiplied visions, while Ephraim multiplied falsehood (v. 1). In the literal idiom, God put parables "in the hand" of the prophets (v. 10). In verse 7, false balances are "in" Ephraim's "hand."41 Thus Yahweh is three times compared with Ephraim, demonstrating both God's loving care and patience and Ephraim's disdain and evil.

<span id="page-248-5"></span><span id="page-248-3"></span>Various other regions besides Ephraim also are cited in order to force the realization that the indictment is against the whole land (v. 11). The Hebrew word for Gilead's "iniquity" was probably pronounced the same as the word for Ephraim's "wealth" in verse 8. They see wealth and power; God sees guilt and punishable idolatry.

Gilgal (v. 11) was the first city occupied by Joshua, and was the staging area for the conquest. To mention it here invites comparisons to this earlier period. In Gilgal, illegal altars were as common as stones piled in "furrows of the field" (cf. 10:4).

<span id="page-248-7"></span><span id="page-248-1"></span><span id="page-248-0"></span>12:12–14 The first verse of this section recites another piece of sacred history. After deceiving his father, Jacob fled to stay with Laban, for whom he worked fourteen years for Rachel by guarding sheep (Genesis 29). In a similar way, the Lord tended to Israel (by means of a prophet) and also did so in a foreign land, bringing Israel up from there. The last word in Hosea 12:13 is the same as the last word in the Hebrew of 12:12 ("guarded"). Jacob kept sheep, and his descendants were kept by Yahweh.

<span id="page-248-8"></span><span id="page-248-6"></span>No doubt the "prophet" that Hosea has in mind here (v. 13) is Moses. But why does he use this cryptic reference to an unnamed prophet instead of specifying Moses as the prophet who brought Israel up from Egypt? Hosea seems to be stressing the similarities between Israel at the time of the exodus and Israel in his own day. As God brought the nation from bondage in the days of Egypt through a prophet, so now he has sent his prophet to them for their good, to save them from being enslaved again and taken to a new Egypt—Assyria. Hosea is then the new Moses to this new generation.

<span id="page-248-9"></span>What is Ephraim's response? He has irritated and exasperated his Lord to the point where nothing is left except bloodguilt and reproach (v. 14). The people celebrate Jacob in their ceremonies and call themselves his descendants, but the God of Jacob will no longer guard Ephraim as he did their patriarch. Instead, he

<sup>41</sup> Robert B. Coote, "Hosea XII," *VT* 21/4 (1971): 397.

<span id="page-249-5"></span><span id="page-249-3"></span>will "repay" them. The Hebrew term translated "repay" is *shub*, the same word that elsewhere carries the sense of "turn, return." Since Israel will not return (*shub*) to the Lord (v. 6), the Lord will return (*shub*) Israel's reproach back onto the nation (v. 14).

<span id="page-249-6"></span><span id="page-249-1"></span>13:1–3 "Ephraim" and "Israel" refer to the same religio-political entity throughout the book (5:3–9; 7:1; 8:8–9; 10:6; etc.), and 13:1 should be read in the same way. The first part of verse 1 is difficult to translate. The ESV faithfully renders the current Hebrew text, but it is not clear why Ephraim's speech would result in trembling. There was never a time in which Ephraim as a tribe was highly regarded. The book of Judges treats the tribe as dangerously foolish, hotheads who are not around when work needs to be done but who complain later that they were left out. Thus some have proposed a very slight change that would result in the speaker of the verse being God: "When [God] spoke, Ephraim trembled. . . . He [God] was exalted in Israel."42

<span id="page-249-0"></span>The phrase "through Baal" can also be read as "in Baal"—i.e., at Baal-peor, the paradigmatic site of Israel's great rebellion.43 Twenty-four thousand Israelites died there (Num. 25:1–9). While Ephraim may have at first revered God, this quickly turned to rejection of him, leading to grave consequences.

If history repeats itself, what sort of death awaits the nation of Israel? The kingdom will fail and the people will be disseminated throughout the earth. This is the death awaiting them. They will be cut down to a nomadic existence, fading away into nonexistence.

<span id="page-249-2"></span>Since Baal-peor, they have added idol to idol and made themselves onerous (Hos. 12:2). Human sacrifice seems to be in view here. This may explain further the motif of death in 13:1: the people continue to die due to idolatry.

Because of this sort of sin, Israel will die as a nation. Four images in rapid succession signify Israel's shortened lifespan (v. 3). They are like dew at daybreak and will evaporate into nothing by midmorning. Like mist or smoke, they will disappear as if they had never been. Just as the smallest breeze blows away chaff (agricultural dust), so it will be with Ephraim.

There is no hope in these verses. The people have made their choice. Between Baal, the calf, and innumerable idols, they have refused to follow the lead of God's prophet. Thus he will not save them when the time of judgment comes.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-249-7"></span><span id="page-249-4"></span>Jacob tended sheep (12:12). Yahweh tended Israel (12:13), eventually sending his Son to be the Great Shepherd for us all. It is because Jesus tends to us that we are not like morning mist or chaff in the wind (13:3). This is true of each one of us personally, but even more so in matters pertaining to the mission of the church. Christ ensures that we will succeed in the end, bringing every thought captive to him and making disciples of all nations.

<sup>42</sup> Cf. Andersen and Freedman, *Hosea*, 629.

<sup>43</sup> Ibid., 630.

<span id="page-250-2"></span><span id="page-250-0"></span>To guide and care for Israel, God sent them prophets, even providing parables to the nation to frame the issues for them (12:10). God saved them from slavery in Egypt through a prophet (12:13). From the time of the patriarch Jacob, God materially and spiritually provided for his people. He guarded them, saved them, spoke to them, and blessed them. It was God's guidance through a prophet that set them free from bondage in Egypt. The same is true for us today. It is Jesus who teaches us and the Bible that guides us. As it was for ancient Israel, so it is for us: all we need do is believe and trust, and all else will follow.

<span id="page-250-7"></span><span id="page-250-5"></span><span id="page-250-1"></span>Israel was led into freedom by the prophet (12:13). Today, the truth of the gospel is what sets us free (John 8:32). Thus we must be careful not to reject this truth, as Israel did and therefore died (Heb. 12:25). In Hosea, Israel is admonished to look to Jacob for inspiration (Hos. 12:12). Today, Christians are admonished to look to Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith, and follow his example (Heb. 12:2). He endured the cross, despising its shame, and attained the seat at the right hand of God.

<span id="page-250-6"></span><span id="page-250-4"></span><span id="page-250-3"></span>Likewise, Christians should be willing to suffer the loss of pleasures and luxuries, and even be willing to suffer pain and death, for the sake of the gospel. To do this, one must foster a close relationship with Christ, living dependently and worthy of one's calling. Let us not be distracted like Ephraim, messing about with silver and gold while missing out on our glorious Lord (Hos. 13:1–3).
