## *Comment*

<span id="page-276-16"></span><span id="page-276-13"></span>1:13 The leaders of God's people carried heavy responsibilities; in addition to performing rituals associated with sacrifice, the priests were also responsible for instructing the people (cf. Mal. 2:7: "The lips of a priest should guard knowledge, and people should seek instruction from his mouth"). They are called "ministers of the altar" here because of their special responsibilities at the place of sacrifice, where they are to serve the Lord (cf. "ministers of the Lord"; Joel 1:9). The priests are to "put on sackcloth," the traditional clothing of those in mourning (Gen. 37:34; 2 Sam. 3:31; Job 16:15), and are also called to "lament," a verb often associated with weeping in bereavement (Gen. 23:2; 1 Sam. 25:1; 1 Kings 13:29). They are to mourn because of the absence of grain offerings and drink offerings (cf. Joel 1:9). The relationship of the people to God still continues, however, as the Lord is called "*your* God."

<span id="page-276-8"></span><span id="page-276-2"></span><span id="page-276-1"></span><span id="page-276-0"></span>1:14 Deep sorrow was to be shown in other ways as well, including fasting, which implies self-denial in order to encourage deeper devotion to God and his ways. The only obligatory fast in ancient Israel occurred on the Day of Atonement (Lev. 16:29–31; however, after the exile four additional fasts were also instituted—cf. Est. 9:1–32; Zech. 7:3; 8:19). To "consecrate a fast" was to set aside a holy day of fasting, and the parallel phrase, "solemn assembly," reinforces the idea of a formal gathering before the Lord. In such an assembly, the elders and all the people were to "cry out" to their God. This verb is used almost exclusively to describe crying out in time of great need and seeking help when in distress (e.g., Judg. 6:6–7; 1 Sam. 4:13; Jer. 47:2). Corporate prayer to God was what was most needed, just as when Israel gathered over Achan's sin (Josh. 7:13–16) or went up to Bethel to ask who was to lead the fight against the Benjaminites (Judg. 20:18).

<span id="page-276-10"></span><span id="page-276-7"></span><span id="page-276-6"></span><span id="page-276-5"></span><span id="page-276-4"></span><span id="page-276-3"></span>1:15 Suddenly Joel introduces a new concept, "the day of the Lord," with a cry of dismay: "Alas." If Joel's date of writing is early (cf. Introduction: Date and Occasion), this may be one of the earliest occurrences of the important concept of "the day of the Lord." Just as the expression "the day of Midian" (Isa. 9:4) referred to victories achieved there (Judges 6–8), so the expression "the day of the Lord" refers to victories the Lord will achieve. He is the warrior king who overcomes his enemies in dramatic fashion. While earlier passages in the OT did not use the term "the day of the Lord," they nevertheless depicted a day in which God's rule would be celebrated and his righteous judgment executed (Pss. 96:7–13; 98:4–9). It seems that people focused on the aspect of joy but neglected the threat of judgment. Joel, however, warns that "as destruction from the Almighty6 it comes" (Joel 1:15; cf. Isa. 13:6). The destroyer, the Lord, is going to bring destruction.

<span id="page-276-15"></span><span id="page-276-11"></span><span id="page-276-9"></span><sup>6</sup> The Hebrew word for God here is *shadday*. Western European languages typically translate with "Almighty," following the pattern of the Greek and Latin translations, although the literal meaning of *shadday* is obscure.

<span id="page-277-5"></span><span id="page-277-4"></span>1:16 Sorrow and grief were not merely possibilities of the future but were in fact already present in the land. The locust plague had devastated the country, and the house of God, which was meant to be a place of joy (cf. Ps. 122:1–4), had become a place of gloom because of the lack of offerings. A dearth of food led to the absence of joy and gladness.

<span id="page-277-6"></span>1:17 The first part of this verse ("The seed shrivels under the clods") is difficult to translate (cf. ESV mg.), as the three main terms appear only here in the OT. The ESV translation fits the context well (although the presence of a Hebrew suffix could yield "*their* clods"; cf. NKJV, NASB). The picture is of a drought so severe that the ground has dried up into clods, seeds have shriveled beneath them, and storehouses and granaries decay because of disuse.

<span id="page-277-7"></span>1:18 The picture of famine continues, although now cattle and sheep, not humans (v. 16) or crops (v. 17), are in focus. Both herds of cattle and flocks of sheep are distressed because their normal pastures provide no feed. Even when there is no grass for cattle, sheep can survive on roots, but now even that source of food is gone. Just as Israel groaned when under bondage in Egypt (cf. Ex. 2:23), so now the beasts groan in their present distress.

<span id="page-277-10"></span><span id="page-277-8"></span><span id="page-277-0"></span>1:19 Amid such distress, Joel directs his prayer to the redeeming God. The word "call" is a common verb indicating approach to God in prayer, often employed in the fuller expression "to call on the name of the Lord" (cf. 2:32). The order of words, "*to you* . . . I call," emphasizes to whom Joel's cry is made: the prophet knows there is only One who can answer his prayer. The reference to "fire" could be a metaphorical expression denoting the severity of the drought and the absence of fodder. However, it could also refer to literal fires that spread over the barren landscape. "Pastures of the wilderness" and "trees of the field" are parallel expressions indicating how widely the distress has covered the land.

<span id="page-277-9"></span><span id="page-277-3"></span>1:20 The concept of appealing to God is continued with personification of the animals, who are pictured as echoing the prayer of the prophet as they too long for the Lord—the language is very close to Psalm 42:1 ("pant," "water brooks," and "for you" echo "pants," "flowing streams," and "for you"). No streams flow, and even the wilderness, whose pastures often provided some nourishment for cattle and sheep, has been consumed by fire.

## *Response*

<span id="page-277-2"></span><span id="page-277-1"></span>Spiritual leaders fill a very important place in a community as they carry out their role as ministers of God. In the biblical text, true spirituality is expressed in times not only of individual devotion but of communal devotion as well. At various occasions in the OT, the leaders assembled the people to worship the Lord and praise his name (examples include David in 1 Chron. 29:10–13; Solomon in 2 Chron. 1:2–6; Hezekiah in 2 Chron. 30:1–27; Ezra in Neh. 8:1–8). Here Joel instructs the priests and elders of his day to demonstrate leadership in addressing the dire situation in Judah. Communal worship at a time of calamity was meant to direct the people back to God; out of deep need the people were to cry to the Lord, a mark of true spirituality.

<span id="page-278-3"></span><span id="page-278-2"></span><span id="page-278-0"></span>The mission of Joel, as he sought to disabuse the people of his day of their false ideas, came to even greater expression in the ministry of Jesus. In answering a question from his disciples about the end of the age, Jesus warned against being deceived (Matt. 24:4; Mark 13:5). He proceeded to teach about the cataclysmic events that would follow his ascension. Some of the same phenomena Joel and other OT prophets mention—such as the trumpet call and dramatic events in heaven and earth (Isa. 24:17–23; 27:13; Jer. 4:5, 19, 21; Amos 2:2; 3:6)—will precede his own return (Matt. 24:29–31; Mark 13:24–27). The warnings given by Joel become even stronger in the NT as the apostles draw attention to the dangers of sin and encourage preparation in order to be "blameless in holiness before our God and Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus with all his saints (1 Thess. 3:13).

## JOEL 2:1–11

<span id="page-278-4"></span><span id="page-278-1"></span>2 Blow a trumpet in Zion; sound an alarm on my holy mountain! Let all the inhabitants of the land tremble, for the day of the Lord is coming; it is near, **<sup>2</sup>** a day of darkness and gloom, a day of clouds and thick darkness!

 Like blackness there is spread upon the mountains a great and powerful people; their like has never been before, nor will be again after them through the years of all generations.

## **<sup>3</sup>** Fire devours before them, and behind them a flame burns. The land is like the garden of Eden before them, but behind them a desolate wilderness, and nothing escapes them.

**<sup>4</sup>** Their appearance is like the appearance of horses, and like war horses they run.

**<sup>5</sup>** As with the rumbling of chariots, they leap on the tops of the mountains, like the crackling of a flame of fire devouring the stubble, like a powerful army drawn up for battle.

- **<sup>6</sup>** Before them peoples are in anguish; all faces grow pale.
- **<sup>7</sup>** Like warriors they charge; like soldiers they scale the wall. They march each on his way; they do not swerve from their paths.
- **<sup>8</sup>** They do not jostle one another; each marches in his path; they burst through the weapons and are not halted.
- **<sup>9</sup>** They leap upon the city, they run upon the walls, they climb up into the houses, they enter through the windows like a thief.
- **<sup>10</sup>** The earth quakes before them; the heavens tremble. The sun and the moon are darkened, and the stars withdraw their shining.
- **<sup>11</sup>** The Lord utters his voice before his army, for his camp is exceedingly great; he who executes his word is powerful. For the day of the Lord is great and very awesome; who can endure it?

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-279-3"></span>This section begins and ends with mention of a special day, "the day of the Lord" (vv. 1 and 11). A trumpet blast from Zion will alert the people to this day and its surprising features: darkness, fire, and an invading "army" of locusts overrunning their houses. These "warriors" will enter the city without any deviation from their route of attack and will carry out their planned approach with military precision. What was like the garden of Eden will be reduced to desolation. Even heaven and earth will respond to these events as part of the demonstration of God's mighty power, for the day of the Lord will be "very awesome."

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-279-4"></span>III. The Day of the Lord (2:1–17)
	- A. Impending Judgment (2:1–11)
		- 1. The Alert Sounded (2:1–2)
		- 2. The Invading Locusts (2:3–11)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-279-2"></span><span id="page-279-1"></span><span id="page-279-0"></span>2:1–2 Blowing the trumpet (*shofar*) was a way of signaling to the people some important happening, whether military (e.g., Judg. 3:27; 2 Sam. 20:1; 1 Kings 1:34) or religious (e.g., Lev. 25:9; Pss. 81:3; 98:6). The role of the prophet could thus be likened to the watchman's use of the *shofar* (Isa. 58:1; Jer. 6:17; Ezek. 33:3–6).

<span id="page-280-8"></span><span id="page-280-0"></span>Here the prophet Joel is announcing the Lord's call that goes out from his holy mountain, Zion (Joel 2:1). While "the mountain of God" refers to Mount Sinai (e.g., Ex. 3:1), "holy mountain" refers to Mount Zion (cf. Pss. 3:4; 43:3; 87:1–2; Isa. 27:13), the mountain God chose for his earthly dwelling place (Ps. 132:13).

<span id="page-280-9"></span><span id="page-280-7"></span><span id="page-280-4"></span><span id="page-280-1"></span>The call is for the people to tremble because of the nearness of the day of the Lord (cf. Joel 1:15). The surprise for them is not merely the day's imminence but also its character (2:2). As in Amos 5:18, the message is that instead of light, the day of the Lord will be characterized by darkness. "Clouds and thick darkness" were associated with God's revelation of himself at Sinai (Ex. 20:21) and later in the temple in Jerusalem (1 Kings 8:10–12), but what is coming now is a massive invasion of locusts that will darken the face of the land. Never before has such an episode occurred, nor will it again for generations to come. The description is clearly meant to startle the people, for disaster is rapidly approaching.

<span id="page-280-10"></span><span id="page-280-3"></span><span id="page-280-2"></span>2:3 The reference to fire preceding the invading locusts is difficult to interpret but is probably best understood in relation to other passages in the OT that speak of fire going before the Lord (e.g., Ps. 50:3; Zeph. 1:18). The invading army of locusts is, in fact, both preceded and followed by fire. The picture is thus of desolating judgment transforming a place of beauty into wilderness; total destruction is the lasting effect.

<span id="page-280-13"></span><span id="page-280-12"></span><span id="page-280-11"></span><span id="page-280-6"></span>2:4–5 As the locusts advance, they appear like an army of horsemen and chariots (v. 4). The Hebrew terms for "war horses" (often translated "horsemen") and "chariots" are often paired in descriptions of ancient armies (e.g., Isa. 31:1). The locusts not only resemble horses in general; they share other characteristics of cavalry as well (Joel 2:5). It is not surprising that the noisy locusts are compared to the rumbling chariots of an army or to the noise of a fire as it burns dry vegetation, for they are indeed an army arrayed for battle. This description is echoed in Revelation 9:7, where John writes of locusts arising out of the smoke of the great furnace: "In appearance the locusts were like horses prepared for battle."

<span id="page-280-19"></span><span id="page-280-14"></span><span id="page-280-5"></span>2:6 The people dread the outcome of the invasion, realizing its consequences and reacting accordingly. They are like a woman in travail; the Hebrew verb translated "are in anguish" is often used of labor pains (Isa. 13:8; 23:4; 45:10). The "pale" nature of the people's faces is a possible but uncertain translation, as the adjective occurs only here and in Nahum 2:10. It is generally agreed, however, that the adjective describes some sort of negative reaction to the coming onslaught.

<span id="page-280-18"></span><span id="page-280-17"></span><span id="page-280-16"></span><span id="page-280-15"></span>2:7–9 The following portrayals fit descriptions of human armies, emphasized by the repeated "like . . . like" construction. The locusts resemble soldiers running into battle, climbing walls, and keeping doggedly to the path they have chosen. When invading, they maintain battle order and do not interfere with one other, maintaining their places on the path; tight ranks are kept as they advance (v. 7). Verse 8 reiterates the point that the locusts are not easily diverted from their selected paths, nor do defensive weapons or positions hinder them. Their attack <span id="page-281-4"></span>on the walls is characteristic of locusts, not of human soldiers (v. 9). Once they are on the walls of the city, there is no way they can be stopped. Their access into the city resembles the way thieves enter houses by squeezing through windows.

<span id="page-281-5"></span><span id="page-281-3"></span>2:10 The mass of locusts causes an effect almost like an earthquake; heaven and earth are affected. The description then reverts to the theme of the beginning of this prophecy (v. 2), describing the day of darkness and gloom. The darkness Joel describes can clearly be caused by insect plagues, as there are many firsthand accounts of such phenomena.

<span id="page-281-6"></span>2:11 The Hebrew idiom for uttering one's voice (lit., "the Lord gives his voice") can be used of a variety of situations. In this context, it appears to be a reference to the Lord's voice as the commander of his army, thus making clear that this was his judgment. (At least some of those affected by the locust plague would not have been aware it was the Lord who was directing this massive army.) The reference to the execution of his word is ambiguous. The ESV text ascribes it to the Lord ("he [the Lord] . . . executes his word"), which is probably correct, although it is grammatically possible that it should be understood as referring to the army of locusts carrying out the Lord's will ("it [the locust army] . . . executes his [the Lord's] word"). In either case, it is again clear that the Lord is behind the invasion.

<span id="page-281-8"></span><span id="page-281-2"></span><span id="page-281-1"></span><span id="page-281-0"></span>The concluding words of the verse resemble Amos's reaction to Israel's impending judgment (Amos 7:5). Specific mention of the day of the Lord (already referred to in Joel 2:1) is again introduced. God is often described as "great" (e.g., Neh. 8:6; Jer. 10:6) and "awesome" (e.g., Ex. 15:11; Isa. 64:3), and also as "great and awesome" (Deut. 7:21). It is not surprising, therefore, that this special day can be designated "great and very awesome." The final question—"Who can endure it?"—points to the impossibility of enduring God's wrath as it will be displayed on that great day (for similar use of the verb "endure," cf. Amos 7:10; Mal. 3:2; in the NT, cf. Rev. 6:15–17).

### <span id="page-281-9"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-281-14"></span><span id="page-281-13"></span><span id="page-281-12"></span><span id="page-281-11"></span><span id="page-281-10"></span><span id="page-281-7"></span>Joel's hearers and readers should not have been surprised by the locust plague. Their preconceptions of the day of the Lord were exposed by the prophet's ministry as he set out God's intentions for the nation. He does not act in secret but reveals his will through "his servants the prophets" (Amos 3:7). Through the teaching of Scripture, God informs the mind so that his people can be challenged by his Word and respond accordingly. There are many examples in both the OT and the NT of those speaking for God having to disabuse their hearers of false ideas. This was so with Jesus himself (cf. esp. Matt. 5:17–48) and with the apostle Paul (cf. 1 Thess. 4:13–5:11). It is also true that God's judgment does not come unannounced in Scripture. He forewarned in OT times and does so in the NT period as well (e.g., 2 Thess. 1:5–12). We must pay attention to God's messages, both those of kindness and those of severity (Rom. 11:22). The consequences of failure to heed his warnings are severe, for "How shall we escape if we neglect such a great salvation?" (Heb. 2:3).

## JOEL 2:12–17

- <span id="page-282-1"></span>**<sup>12</sup>** "Yet even now," declares the Lord, "return to me with all your heart, with fasting, with weeping, and with mourning;
- **<sup>13</sup>** and rend your hearts and not your garments." Return to the Lord your God, for he is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love; and he relents over disaster.
- **<sup>14</sup>** Who knows whether he will not turn and relent, and leave a blessing behind him,
- a grain offering and a drink offering for the Lord your God?
- **<sup>15</sup>** Blow the trumpet in Zion; consecrate a fast;
- call a solemn assembly; **<sup>16</sup>** gather the people. Consecrate the congregation; assemble the elders; gather the children, even nursing infants. Let the bridegroom leave his room, and the bride her chamber.
- **<sup>17</sup>** Between the vestibule and the altar let the priests, the ministers of the Lord, weep and say, "Spare your people, O Lord, and make not your heritage a reproach, a byword among the nations.*<sup>1</sup>* Why should they say among the peoples, 'Where is their God?' "

1Or *reproach, that the nations should rule over them*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-282-0"></span>One of the distinctive features of the prophets is the way they constantly call for repentance and faith. That is what Joel is doing here: encouraging his compatriots to repent of their sin and seek God's favor. That God will be gracious is confirmed by reference to his prior self-declaration of his character at Mount Sinai (Ex. 34:6–7). The people are encouraged to gather in worship and pray that God will spare them, with assurance that true sorrow, demonstrated in a return to obedience to him, will be followed by a cessation of judgment. If such does not happen, God himself will be mocked by the Gentiles.

## *Section Outline*

III.B. A Call to Repentance (2:12–17)

- 1. Mercy Offered (2:12–14)
- 2. An Invitation to Worship (2:15–17)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-283-7"></span>2:12–13 The words "yet even now" translate a Hebrew phrase that includes a particle often serving as a transition marker in the text. The words that follow— "declares the Lord"—point unmistakably to this as a message from God, for they are often used in the prophets as an introduction to authoritative declarations (e.g., Hos. 2:16; Amos 2:11; Mic. 4:6).

<span id="page-283-4"></span>The call is for the people to come back to the Lord, not with mere outward display but with an inner change of heart. No other passage in the OT contains such an instruction regarding rending the heart. Such deep repentance would be linked to several practices associated with grief: fasting, weeping, mourning.

<span id="page-283-6"></span><span id="page-283-1"></span>The sinful people are then reminded yet again that their sovereign Savior is indeed the Lord (cf. "your God," Joel 1:14; "our God," v. 16). He is still the God who revealed himself to Moses as "the Lord, the Lord, a God merciful and gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness, keeping steadfast love for thousands" (Ex. 34:6–7). This self-revelation of God became enshrined in the minds of his people and is often echoed in OT books (cf. Num. 14:18; Ps. 86:15; Nah. 1:3; and esp. Jonah 4:2). Here and Jonah 4:2 are the only two passages that quote the creedal formulation of God's character taken from Exodus 34 with the addition, "and he relents over disaster." This clause indicates that God will respond to his people's repentance by relenting from the harm he had purposed for them. This is in keeping with what the Lord promises in Jeremiah 18:7–8, where he makes clear that his announcement of judgment is often made for the purpose of spurring his people toward repentance.

<span id="page-283-9"></span><span id="page-283-8"></span><span id="page-283-5"></span><span id="page-283-3"></span><span id="page-283-2"></span><span id="page-283-0"></span>2:14 The question this verse poses is very similar in both form and content to the question raised in Jonah 3:9 (cf. 2 Sam. 12:22). It is likely a rhetorical device intended to draw attention to the hope that, by means of repentance, disaster could be averted and blessing could result instead. Previously Joel has commented on the absence of grain and drink offerings (Joel 1:9, 13), and now such offerings are cited positively as the content of the promised blessing. This particular element of hope is injected here because a cessation of the locust plague is in view; with a new harvest, these offerings will again be possible. Once more God is called "the Lord, your God" (cf. 2:13). It is not some new deity to whom appeal is made, but Israel's covenantal God, who maintains his relationship with them.

<span id="page-284-11"></span><span id="page-284-10"></span><span id="page-284-8"></span><span id="page-284-4"></span>2:15–17 The prophet's response to the situation is to call the people to prayer (v. 15). The trumpet was important because of its use as a signal in religious, civic, and military affairs. The place where this prayer is to take place is Zion, God's chosen abode (Ps. 132:13), the place to which the ark of the covenant was brought and on which the temple was built. A special fast is to be appointed, as the only obligatory fast for Israel occurred on the Day of Atonement (Lev. 16:29, 31). The people are to gather together in a special assembly, called both a "solemn assembly" and a "congregation" (Joel 2:15, 16). No exception is to be made for anyone in Israel; elders and children, young men and old men, bridegroom and bride are all to join in this great gathering, and the priests are to gather as well (v. 17). The "vestibule" was the outer porch of the temple (cf. 1 Kings 6:3; Ezek. 40:7–9), while the altar was the place of sacrifice (cf. Ex. 40:26–27), standing opposite the veiled Most Holy Place. It is there, in that public yet sacred space, that the priests are to offer tearful prayers. The priests are designated as "ministers," a term used in the OT of civil servants (e.g., Gen. 39:4, where Joseph "attended" [i.e., ministered to] Potiphar) but also, as here, of those tasked with representing the people before God (cf. Ex. 28:12, 29).

<span id="page-284-12"></span><span id="page-284-6"></span><span id="page-284-5"></span><span id="page-284-3"></span><span id="page-284-2"></span><span id="page-284-1"></span><span id="page-284-0"></span>The prayer focuses on two things. It is a cry for mercy, asking God to act compassionately toward his erring people. It is also an urgent request for God's people not to become a thing of mockery among the Gentiles. One of the special expressions for God's people was "heritage" or "inheritance" (cf. Ex. 34:9; Deut. 4:20), and this became a basis for appeals to God (Deut. 9:26; Ps. 28:9). For Israel to be a "reproach" was to be a "scorn" or "disgrace," and to be a "byword" was to be a public example, an object lesson, for her neighbors. If God did not show compassion to his own people, they would be taunted for their God's absence from their lives and circumstances. The same general attitude is expressed throughout Psalms 74 and 79.

## <span id="page-284-7"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-284-13"></span><span id="page-284-9"></span>Returning to the Lord is a major theme of the OT prophets, one very closely connected with the covenantal relationship. It was especially prominent among the earlier prophets (for the positive command, cf. Hos. 6:1; 14:1–2; for the negative "you did not return," cf. Amos 4:6, 8, 9, 10, 11), while the later ones may not have used it so often because by then they knew that judgment, in the form of exile, was inevitable. The call to repent presupposes a prior turning away from God and consequently the need to reject sin and return to him.

<span id="page-284-16"></span><span id="page-284-15"></span><span id="page-284-14"></span>The NT expresses the same concept using terms related to "repentance." To repent means to start a new life; its presence is a mark of faith. Frequently in the NT repentance and forgiveness of sins are linked together (Luke 24:47; Acts 5:31). The promise underlying the call to repent is that God is gracious and compassionate and will never turn away a repentant sinner. Jesus' ministry was aimed at calling sinners to repentance (Luke 5:32), and the apostles proclaimed the same message, giving assurance that those repenting would find forgiveness for their sins (Acts 2:38; 26:16–18).

## JOEL 2:18–27

- <span id="page-285-0"></span>**<sup>18</sup>** Then the Lord became jealous for his land and had pity on his people.
- **<sup>19</sup>** The Lord answered and said to his people, "Behold, I am sending to you grain, wine, and oil, and you will be satisfied; and I will no more make you a reproach among the nations.

**<sup>20</sup>** "I will remove the northerner far from you, and drive him into a parched and desolate land, his vanguard*<sup>1</sup>* into the eastern sea, and his rear guard*<sup>2</sup>* into the western sea; the stench and foul smell of him will rise, for he has done great things.

- **<sup>21</sup>** "Fear not, O land; be glad and rejoice, for the Lord has done great things!
- **<sup>22</sup>** Fear not, you beasts of the field, for the pastures of the wilderness are green; the tree bears its fruit; the fig tree and vine give their full yield.
- **<sup>23</sup>** "Be glad, O children of Zion, and rejoice in the Lord your God, for he has given the early rain for your vindication; he has poured down for you abundant rain, the early and the latter rain, as before.
- **<sup>24</sup>** "The threshing floors shall be full of grain; the vats shall overflow with wine and oil.
- **<sup>25</sup>** I will restore*<sup>3</sup>* to you the years that the swarming locust has eaten, the hopper, the destroyer, and the cutter, my great army, which I sent among you.
- **<sup>26</sup>** "You shall eat in plenty and be satisfied, and praise the name of the Lord your God, who has dealt wondrously with you. And my people shall never again be put to shame.
- **<sup>27</sup>** You shall know that I am in the midst of Israel, and that I am the Lord your God and there is none else. And my people shall never again be put to shame."

## *Section Overview*

This passage presents another stage in Joel's prophecy. The impending crisis has been described in great detail, and now we see the Lord's response to the prayers of his people. In his grace he has intervened, and the effects of the devastation caused by the locusts will be reversed; the land will enjoy his blessing. The army of locusts will be removed, and once again the land will produce abundant food. Whereas the supply of grain, wine, and oil had been stopped (1:10), now again there will be plenty. This will be an exhibition of the "great things" that only God can perform (2:20–21). Abundant provision will make up for "the years the . . . locust has eaten" (v. 25). Not only will the people have plenty to eat, but they will also engage in thankful acknowledgment of the Lord. At that time there will be no doubting that the Lord is truly the only God, and his people will never again suffer shame (vv. 26–27).

## <span id="page-286-8"></span><span id="page-286-7"></span><span id="page-286-6"></span>*Section Outline*

- IV. Divine Compassion (2:18–3:16)
	- A. Divine Mercy (2:18–20)
	- B. Rejoicing in the Lord (2:21–27)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-286-4"></span><span id="page-286-3"></span><span id="page-286-0"></span>2:18–19 God is a jealous God (Ex. 20:5) who has particular love and concern for his people. The verb "became jealous" is parallel to "had pity" (Joel 2:18). The first verb points to an attitude that finds its outward expression in the manner indicated by the second. The sinful nation has not been cast off by God, for its people are still "his people." That same thought is repeatedly expressed by other prophets as well (cf. Isa. 49:25–26; 54:4–9; Jer. 30:1–3; 31:1–6). The words of the Lord depict a restoration of the land to its condition before the locust plague, with crops again yielding grain, wine, and oil. The earlier report of famine that described a lack of such produce (Joel 1:10) is reversed, with assurance given of hunger being satisfied. The presence of God's hand in all that happens is emphasized in the final clause of 2:19. The prayer of the people (v. 17) will be answered, for the Lord in his sovereignty will ensure that the people are no longer mocked by the surrounding Gentile nations. His "heritage" will not become a reproach.

<span id="page-286-5"></span><span id="page-286-2"></span><span id="page-286-1"></span>2:20 The Lord's words for the people continue in this verse. The word translated "northerner" occurs only here in the OT. Many writers have suggested that it refers to an army coming from the north. However, if the references to the locusts earlier in this book are taken literally, then this term most likely relates to that plague as well. Well-documented instances of locusts coming from the north support the continuing interpretation of an insect plague, not an actual army. God, who in his sovereignty brought the locusts, is also the one who will remove them from the land. They will be driven away into the eastern (Dead) and western (Mediterranean) seas, and the dead locusts will emit a powerful stench. The last sentence does not

<span id="page-287-9"></span>indicate who it is that has "done great things." While ancient versions made "the army" the subject of this verb, it is better to link this verse with the following one (v. 21) and understand the subject to be "the Lord," who explicitly is named in that verse. The identical expression occurs elsewhere to describe the Lord's mighty deeds (cf. Ps. 126:2–3).

<span id="page-287-10"></span><span id="page-287-2"></span>2:21–22 These two verses begin with the same standardized expression ("Fear not") found approximately seventy-five times in the OT. The expression is normally followed, as here, by an explanation for the reassurance given. The first occurrence of the expression (v. 21) states that the Lord has done great things; God's intervention on behalf of his people calls forth festive joy. The second identical command (v. 22) specifies particular demonstrations of his favor. The animals will no longer be deprived of food (cf. 1:20) and will enjoy abundant pastures, fruitful trees, and vineyards yielding a plentiful crop.

<span id="page-287-11"></span><span id="page-287-6"></span><span id="page-287-5"></span>2:23 The positive commands of verse 21 are repeated in the plural ("Be glad . . . and rejoice"). To the imperatives is added the object in whom they are to rejoice: "the Lord your God." In spite of their sins, God has not cast away his own covenantal people but is reversing the effects of the plague of locusts. The joy and gladness of which the people were deprived (1:16) are to be restored. The following clause, "He has given the early rain7 for your vindication," declares that the covenantal curse of withheld rain and dew (Lev. 26:18–20; Deut. 28:23–24) is to be annulled, and divine blessing will again be displayed (Lev. 26:3–4; Deut. 11:13–14); both early rain (October/November) and latter rain (March/April) will be restored.

<span id="page-287-14"></span><span id="page-287-13"></span><span id="page-287-12"></span><span id="page-287-4"></span><span id="page-287-1"></span><span id="page-287-0"></span>2:24–25 Restoration means full threshing floors and vats (v. 24). What the locust destroyed (1:5–12) will again be present as a result of God's blessing. None of Joel's listeners or readers should misunderstand how such reversal of fortune is to occur. Just as the Lord is removing the locust plague—his army (2:20, 25)—so also is he restoring former blessings ("*I* will restore"; v. 25). Curse and blessing both come from him. The years of the locust are past,8 and renewal for the land is ahead. This is God's answer and his demonstration of pity for his people (cf. 2:18–19).

<span id="page-287-15"></span><span id="page-287-8"></span>2:26–27 With the locusts gone and regular harvests restored, the message to the people is that their food supply is secure into the future (v. 26). Hunger will be satisfied and the people will be led to praise the name of the Lord, "your God, who has dealt wondrously with you." In spite of Judah's sin, they remained God's people (v. 17), and he their God (vv. 23, 26). The covenantal bond held them together even though judgment had come. With the restoration of God's favor, the people can acknowledge his graciousness in acting so "wondrously" toward them. This

<span id="page-287-7"></span><sup>7</sup> The phrase translated "early rain" has spawned various interpretations. Some early versions (Targum, Old Latin, Syriac) understood the Hebrew to refer to a person, "the teacher of righteousness," while others probably had a different Hebrew text, rendering the term using a word denoting "food" (LXX). On balance, the ESV text should stand, an interpretation supported by the NKJV, NASB, NIV, and NRSV.

<span id="page-287-3"></span><sup>8</sup> The reference to specific species of locusts uses the same terms as in 1:4 (cf. comment there), although in a slightly different order.

expression contains a Hebrew term used mainly of God in the OT and conveys the idea that wondrous or surprising things belong to him (for similar passages, cf. Deut. 28:59; Judg. 13:19; Isa. 29:15). Marvels of love are his alone (cf. Ps. 31:21).

<span id="page-288-4"></span><span id="page-288-3"></span>Another effect of the restored fortunes is that Judah will not be forced to suffer shame. This refers not to inner feelings of shame but to public disgrace, parallel to not being a "reproach among the nations" (Joel 2:19). The outcome for Judah will be genuine understanding of the Lord's presence in their midst (v. 27). The declaration "I am the Lord your God and there is none else" is very close to Isaiah 45:22, "I am God, and there is no other." Personal experience of God's grace and power convince that he is unique. The words at the end of the previous verse are repeated exactly at the end of Joel 2:27 to form a refrain exalting the fact that Judah will be subject to derision no longer.

#### <span id="page-288-8"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-288-12"></span><span id="page-288-1"></span>What compassion God shows to his erring children! "Long ago, at many times and in many ways, God spoke to our fathers by the prophets, but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed the heir of all things" (Heb. 1:1–2). Joel was among those prophets who spoke God's word. With judgment pending, he appealed to the people to repent and turn to God again. The use of Exodus 34:6–7 in Joel 2:13 is a poignant reminder of an incident of grave rebellion against God (the golden calf) that was followed by God's forgiveness. God's people in every age and location are a witness to the world, and repentance is required if they fail to live truly as his people. The call to the church at Ephesus, "Remember therefore from where you have fallen; repent, and do the works you did at first" (Rev. 2:5), is a constant reminder to Christian believers that if they fail to meet God's standards, they must confess and seek God's pardoning mercy when confronted by their sin.

<span id="page-288-13"></span><span id="page-288-7"></span><span id="page-288-6"></span><span id="page-288-5"></span>Repentance on the people's part will result in divine intervention on the Lord's part. The stress in this section of Joel's prophecy is on God's mercy to Judah, called here the "children of Zion" (Hb. "sons of Zion"; Joel 2:23). Sorrow is turned to joy when God overturns opposing forces. He assures his people that he is able to do great things for them (v. 21), to act wondrously on behalf of those who trust in him (v. 26). The concluding verse of the section picks up on an important theme from the book of Exodus. The Lord's promise was that he would dwell with Israel and that they would know he was the one who had redeemed them from Egypt (Ex. 29:45–46). Now the assurance is given again that God, their God, the only God, is in their midst (Joel 2:27). Gracious promises from God enable us to enjoy peace of heart and mind and cause us to praise the name of our Savior.

<span id="page-288-11"></span><span id="page-288-10"></span><span id="page-288-9"></span><span id="page-288-2"></span><span id="page-288-0"></span>God's presence with his people was symbolized in the OT by the tent of meeting (cf. Ex. 40:34–38). The NT reveals that Jesus' coming in human flesh was the fulfillment of that truth: God's Son came and pitched his tent with us (John 1:14). The gospel brings assurance that he is in the midst of his people still (2 Cor. 6:16) and will be so to the end of the age (Matt. 28:20).

<span id="page-289-3"></span>**<sup>28</sup>** *<sup>1</sup>* "And it shall come to pass afterward, that I will pour out my Spirit on all flesh; your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, and your young men shall see visions. **<sup>29</sup>** Even on the male and female servants

in those days I will pour out my Spirit.

**<sup>30</sup>** "And I will show wonders in the heavens and on the earth, blood and fire and columns of smoke. **31**The sun shall be turned to darkness, and the moon to blood, before the great and awesome day of the Lord comes. **<sup>32</sup>**And it shall come to pass that everyone who calls on the name of the Lord shall be saved. 1Ch 3:1 in Hebrew

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-289-1"></span><span id="page-289-0"></span>Further information is given concerning the coming day of the Lord. The Spirit will be poured out (emphasized by repeated mention in vv. 28 and 29), dispensing transforming power on young and old, man and woman. Again (cf. vv. 1–2, 10), mention is made of the darkness associated with the day of the Lord. Yet, amid such darkness and distress, those who call on the name of the Lord will be saved. The escapees from Zion will be those whom the Lord calls, even as he promised.

## *Section Outline*

IV.C. The Outpouring of the Spirit (2:28–32)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-289-4"></span><span id="page-289-2"></span>2:28–29 The time frame for the coming events is "afterward," a general expression modified to "in the last days" by Peter in his quotation of this passage on the day of Pentecost (Acts 2:17). Because the events spoken of in the previous section are near at hand, Joel's use here of "afterward" indicates the events of this section should not be expected until later. This promise will be fulfilled far outside his own time.9

<span id="page-289-5"></span><sup>9</sup> This may also explain why Peter can quote Joel but change "afterward" to "in the last days": that later time has now arrived (Acts 2:19)!

<span id="page-290-5"></span><span id="page-290-1"></span>The promise is that the Spirit will be poured out indiscriminately—"on all flesh" (Joel 2:28). The Hebrew word for "spirit" (*ruakh*) has a range of meaning (wind, breath, spirit), including reference to the Spirit of God/the Lord (e.g., 1 Kings 18:12; 2 Kings 2:16; Ezek. 37:1), the Holy Spirit (Ps. 51:11; Isa. 63:10, 11). This passage should be compared to other Prophetic Books in which notification is given of a coming eschatological day on which God's Spirit will be poured out abundantly (cf. Ezek. 39:29; Zech. 12:10). The effect of this outpouring, says Joel, will be communication of knowledge to young and old, male and female. In contrast to the limited group of people to whom God revealed himself in OT times, he will now reveal himself much more fully to all his people. No one will be left out. In verse 29, Joel speaks for the second time of the Spirit being poured out, this time on male and female servants. These words for "servants" include foreign slaves who were either captured in battle or sold by their captors. Hence even Gentile slaves were to be blessed by a sudden and dramatic outpouring of God's Spirit.

<span id="page-290-10"></span><span id="page-290-8"></span><span id="page-290-2"></span><span id="page-290-0"></span>2:30–31 The coming of supernatural events is described in imagery taken from the account of the signs and wonders at the time of the exodus from Egypt. "Wonders" translates a Hebrew word often used in parallel with another term meaning "signs" or "portents" (Deut. 4:34; 7:19; 29:3) and at times in conjunction with "judgments" (1 Chron. 16:12; Ps. 105:5). The use of the exodus account here is no surprise, as the prophets utilize it both to describe the coming salvation realized in the return from exile (Isa. 43:16–21; 51:9–11; Jer. 16:14–15) and to warn of impending divine judgment (Hos. 13:4–8; Nah. 1:2–5). As at the exodus, the "signs" are not merely demonstrations of God's power but also portents of the salvation he will accomplish for his people.

<span id="page-290-15"></span><span id="page-290-14"></span><span id="page-290-13"></span><span id="page-290-11"></span><span id="page-290-9"></span><span id="page-290-6"></span><span id="page-290-4"></span>Both earth and sky will manifest these wonders (Joel 2:30). In the heavens, the sun will cease to shed light and instead will be dark, while the moon will become blood (v. 31). Possibly, in light of Peter's use of these words on the day of Pentecost (Acts 2:16–21), the prophet is predicting the convulsion of nature that began on the day Jesus was crucified (Luke 23:44–45). Jesus also predicted that similar events would occur before the end of the age (Luke 21:11). This verse picks up the earlier description in Joel 2:11 of a "great and very awesome" day; this day is among the events that will manifest the greatness of God and cause spectators to stand in awe of him. In Revelation, John echoes such passages when referring to impending judgment (cf. Rev. 8:12).

<span id="page-290-16"></span><span id="page-290-12"></span><span id="page-290-7"></span><span id="page-290-3"></span>2:32 Two types of calling are mentioned in this verse. The first is that of people calling upon the name of the Lord, resulting in salvation. The catastrophic events set out in the previous verses will be part of God's judgment. Deliverance from such judgment will be shared by those who approach God in prayer, seeking his intervention and help. To "call on the name of the Lord" is a frequent OT expression, especially in the Psalms (e.g., Pss. 105:1; 116:4, 13, 17). The second calling in this verse is the Lord's calling of those who have escaped the coming disaster ("those whom the Lord calls"). At the heart of the kingdom of Judah will be those in Mount Zion and Jerusalem whom the Lord will call. Such a calling by God always brings his purposes to fulfillment.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-291-1"></span><span id="page-291-0"></span>Many of God's statements concerning his future actions are similar to this one, referencing a gap between a prophecy and its fulfillment. The prophet simply states, "It shall come to pass afterward" (2:28). This lack of precision regarding future dates is typical of both OT and NT prophecies (cf. Isa. 7:18–25; Amos 9:13–15; Matt. 24:1–14; 1 Thess. 4:13–18). Expectation is an important element in the lives of believers, but knowing ahead of time the precise date of a future event would lessen such expectation, as well as the resolve to be ready lest we get caught unprepared.

<span id="page-291-4"></span><span id="page-291-3"></span>The imagery of "pouring out" is a reminder that God acts in a bountiful way toward his people. While "pouring" usually refers to inanimate objects as recipients of God's actions, here the objects are people. God does not act in a stingy way but pours out his grace. The promise given through Joel's ministry is that God will lavish his saving grace on those who call upon him, and who then display by their actions that they are those whom God has called. Paul's use of this passage when writing about the proclamation of the gospel (Rom. 10:13) assists our understanding of it. In that context, this calling on the name of the Lord is equated with believing from the heart that Jesus is Lord.

## JOEL 3:1–8

<span id="page-291-2"></span>3 *<sup>1</sup>* "For behold, in those days and at that time, when I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem, **<sup>2</sup>** I will gather all the nations and bring them down to the Valley of Jehoshaphat. And I will enter into judgment with them there, on behalf of my people and my heritage Israel, because they have scattered them among the nations and have divided up my land, **<sup>3</sup>** and have cast lots for my people, and have traded a boy for a prostitute, and have sold a girl for wine and have drunk it.

**<sup>4</sup>** "What are you to me, O Tyre and Sidon, and all the regions of Philistia? Are you paying me back for something? If you are paying me back, I will return your payment on your own head swiftly and speedily. **5**For you have taken my silver and my gold, and have carried my rich treasures into your temples.*<sup>2</sup>* **<sup>6</sup>**You have sold the people of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks in order to remove them far from their own border. **7**Behold, I will stir them up from the place to which you have sold them, and I will return your payment on your own head. **<sup>8</sup>** I will sell your sons and your daughters into the hand of the people of Judah, and they will sell them to the Sabeans, to a nation far away, for the Lord has spoken."

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-292-5"></span>Before speaking of wonders in store for Judah and Jerusalem, Joel describes a future judgment of the nations. God's rule over them is a theme often introduced by the prophets, and here Joel depicts the administration of God's justice specifically on the Philistines and on Tyre and Sidon. These two cities were independent but at times allied with the Philistines (Jer. 47:4). This judgment is primarily because of their attitude and actions toward God's people. They had scattered his flock and broken up their unity by dispersing them among the nations. These events had already taken place, but insufficient detail prevents any specific identification of them.

## *Section Outline*

```
IV.D. The Nations Judged (3:1–16)
```
1. Forced Exile Repaid (3:1–8)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-292-7"></span><span id="page-292-4"></span>3:1 Joel's presentation begins with a time reference: "For behold, in those days and at that time . . ." These phrases appear also in Jeremiah 33:15; 50:4, 20 and are always linked to future blessing and promised consolation for God's people. The promise is of restoration of fortunes, which in similar contexts implies restoration from captivity (cf. similar expressions in Deut. 30:3; Ps. 126:1; Amos 9:14). Thus this expression is tied to the reference to the scattered people of God in the next verse; the desolation of Judah and Jerusalem is to be reversed.

<span id="page-292-10"></span><span id="page-292-9"></span><span id="page-292-8"></span><span id="page-292-1"></span>3:2–3 The nations are to be assembled for judgment in the "Valley of Jehoshaphat" (v. 2). No known place bearing this name has been identified, but the phrase was clearly understood to refer to a place of judgment. The name "Jehoshaphat" means "Yahweh judges," and the very next phrase—"I will enter into judgment with them"—contains the same verb ("to judge"). What is more, this valley is later called "the valley of decision" (v. 14). The judgment, as God declares, is "on behalf of my people and my heritage Israel" (v. 2). This connects to the prayers of the priests mentioned in 2:17 and the statement in 2:18 that God was jealous for his land and pitied his people Israel. This is essentially an application of the principle stated in the covenant with Abraham: whoever dishonors Abraham and his descendants will be cursed by God (Gen. 12:3).

<span id="page-292-6"></span><span id="page-292-3"></span><span id="page-292-2"></span><span id="page-292-0"></span>Several reasons are given for this judgment against the nations. The first is that they are responsible for the dispersion of Israel. This is not necessarily a reference to the fall of Jerusalem, for at various other times captives were also taken. One such example is the Israelite girl who was taken captive by the Syrians to work for Naaman's wife (2 Kings 5:1–5). A second reason relates to a loss of the territorial integrity of Judah's land, claimed here by God as "my land" but divided up and apportioned among invaders. The casting of lots to apportion the land was clearly acceptable when done by God's people (Joshua 14–19), but not when done

by enemy nations. The third reason is that human life was regarded so lightly that young men could be traded for the use of a prostitute and a young girl sold in payment for wine.

<span id="page-293-3"></span><span id="page-293-1"></span>3:4 The question that begins this verse asks what the peoples of Tyre and Sidon and of Philistia have against the Lord. Tyre and Sidon were Phoenician seaports (situated on the southern Mediterranean coast of present-day Lebanon), while the Philistines (from the Mediterranean coastal strip south of modern Joppa) bedeviled Israel and Judah for centuries, at least to the time of Ahaz (cf. Isa. 9:8–12). Swift retribution is threatened against these groups if their opposition is intended as payback for deeds done by the Lord or his people.

<span id="page-293-10"></span><span id="page-293-4"></span>3:5 The offense of Tyre, Sidon, and the Philistines is their theft of Israelite/Judean gold, silver, and "rich treasures." These belonged to the Lord, though it need not be presumed they were temple valuables, as all the wealth of the land was his (cf. Hag. 2:8). In any case, the invaders took them and placed them in their sacred places, temples, and/or palaces, and the use of the Lord's property in heathen worship or human revelry was a mockery of their intended purpose.

3:6 The enemies of God's people also sold to the Greeks (lit., "the sons of Yavan") captives taken from Judah and Jerusalem. That this was trade *in humans* is brought out in the Hebrew text by the repetition of the word "sons of": "*sons of* Judah and *sons of* Jerusalem" (AT). While there has been much discussion concerning the word "Yavan," the translators of the LXX clearly thought it was a reference to Greece, translating it as *hellas*. The loss of able-bodied Israelites would weaken Judah, and sending them as far away as Greece would ensure they could not return in the future to confront the enemies of God's people. Amos similarly accuses the Philistines and the Phoenicians of being involved in the slave trade (Amos 1:6, 9).

<span id="page-293-9"></span><span id="page-293-7"></span><span id="page-293-2"></span><span id="page-293-0"></span>3:7–8 The good news for Judah and Jerusalem is that God will soon stir up those who have been sold into slavery. The verb "stir" is frequently used of God in the OT, especially to denote his sovereign actions in rousing people to act in ways that fulfill his will (cf. Tiglath-pileser, king of Assyria, 1 Chron. 5:26; the Babylonians, Ezek. 23:22–23; the Medes, Isa. 13:17). His people will be aroused from their exilic slumber, with the implication that they will be brought home. By doing so, God will recompense the Philistines and the Phoenicians for their action in selling his people to distant lands (Joel 3:7). God's judgment will go further, in fact, as the Philistines and the Phoenicians will lose their sons and daughters (cf. comment on the use of "sons" in 3:6) to the people of Judah, who will in turn sell them to the Sabeans, "a nation far away" (v. 8).

<span id="page-293-8"></span><span id="page-293-6"></span><span id="page-293-5"></span>The term "Sabeans" denotes the people of Sheba, a country probably situated near present-day Yemen. Those who shipped captives far off will themselves be subjected to the same fate. The geographical aspects of this prophecy are significant. While slaves from Judah had been sold off to the north, now men of Judah will be involved in sending off slaves in the opposite direction, to the far southeast, as <span id="page-294-0"></span>fulfillment of the covenantal curse—now applied to Judah's enemies!—of being scattered among the nations (Lev. 26:33; Deut. 28:64).

<span id="page-294-2"></span>This section concludes with the declaration, "for the Lord has spoken." These words, found also in Obadiah 18, are an assertion of the divine origin of Joel's message. Joel was the messenger; the message itself came from the Lord.

## *Response*

God has always been committed to the welfare of his people. In Joel's day the people needed reassurance. They faced a severe crisis in the locust plague and had suffered incursions into their territory and the removal of fellow citizens, men and women, to places as far away as Greece. Displacing conquered people was a cruel process, widely practiced in the ancient Near East. But now Joel's message reminds those of Judah and Jerusalem that their God is sovereign—not only over them and their territory but over other countries as well. He is also a just God who will bring judgment on those who act so unrighteously against his people. This truth is a constant source of comfort to believers who may suffer unjustly; they have the assurance that in the end God's righteous rule will prevail. The song of the twenty-four elders in Revelation is a reminder that God has taken his "great power and begun to reign," and he will both reward his servants and destroy "the destroyers of the earth" (Rev. 11:17–18). The book of Revelation also depicts the role Jesus will have in the judgment process. He will act in righteousness toward the unbelieving nations and in doing so will proclaim that he is "King of kings and Lord of lords" (Rev. 19:11–16).

## <span id="page-294-3"></span>JOEL 3:9–16

- <span id="page-294-4"></span><span id="page-294-1"></span>**<sup>9</sup>** Proclaim this among the nations: Consecrate for war;*<sup>1</sup>* stir up the mighty men. Let all the men of war draw near; let them come up.
- **<sup>10</sup>** Beat your plowshares into swords, and your pruning hooks into spears; let the weak say, "I am a warrior."
- **<sup>11</sup>** Hasten and come, all you surrounding nations, and gather yourselves there. Bring down your warriors, O Lord.
- **<sup>12</sup>** Let the nations stir themselves up and come up to the Valley of Jehoshaphat; for there I will sit to judge all the surrounding nations.

**<sup>13</sup>** Put in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe. Go in, tread, for the winepress is full. The vats overflow, for their evil is great.

- **<sup>14</sup>** Multitudes, multitudes, in the valley of decision! For the day of the Lord is near in the valley of decision.
- **<sup>15</sup>** The sun and the moon are darkened, and the stars withdraw their shining.
- **<sup>16</sup>** The Lord roars from Zion, and utters his voice from Jerusalem, and the heavens and the earth quake. But the Lord is a refuge to his people, a stronghold to the people of Israel.

1Or *Consecrate a war*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-295-6"></span><span id="page-295-0"></span>The confrontation between God and the nations is announced by calling upon the nations' warriors to prepare for battle. Their preparations include making swords from plows and spears from pruning hooks. This is the reversal of the imagery of Isaiah 2:4 and Micah 4:3. The nations are to come to the Valley of Jehoshaphat, twice called "the valley of decision" (Joel 3:14), and face the Lord's justice in full force. The day of the Lord will be marked by darkness, with no light visible from the sun, moon, or stars. Again the Lord will roar from Zion (cf. the earlier reference to the trumpet sound in 2:1), and his thundering voice will cause earth and sky to tremble. However, a marked contrast is drawn concerning the people of God. To his and his people's enemies the Lord will be the supreme judge, while to his own he will be both a refuge and a stronghold.

#### <span id="page-295-2"></span>*Section Outline*

IV.D.2. The Lord Roars from Zion (3:9–16)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-295-5"></span><span id="page-295-4"></span><span id="page-295-3"></span><span id="page-295-1"></span>3:9–10 The theme of judgment in the Valley of Jehoshaphat (cf. v. 2) is taken up again, with the call being issued to the Gentile nations to gather together and prepare for war. The term "consecrate" (v. 9) has already been used in 1:14 to call the people together in solemn assembly. Now the Lord again issues a call that may continue to bear religious overtones. All due preparations, perhaps including offering sacrifices, must be completed. Once again the verb "stir" (cf. 3:7) is used, this time of mighty warriors, men of war called to "come up" (v. 9). The nations are to

<span id="page-296-0"></span>prepare for battle, and hence the instruction is given for plowshares and pruning hooks to become weapons of war (v. 10). This is a reversal of the message of Isaiah 2:4 and Micah 4:3. Even the weakling must declare himself ready for battle, asserting, "I am a warrior" (Joel 3:10).

<span id="page-296-10"></span><span id="page-296-9"></span>3:11 No time is to be lost in gathering together "there," a place identified in the following verse as the Valley of Jehoshaphat. This gradual introduction of the place where judgment will be administered is similar to how Isaiah only gradually announces that it will be the Assyrians who come and attack Judah (Isa. 5:26–7:25). In both cases, expectation is aroused before the identification is clarified.

<span id="page-296-11"></span><span id="page-296-1"></span>There is a sudden switch in Joel 3:11b to a call for the Lord to bring his "warriors" down. This is virtually a prayer by the prophet himself. No information is given to enable the reader to discern who these warriors are. It has been suggested that they are the angelic host, but a different interpretation is preferable, as the context (vv. 9–12) suggests a battle of human forces in the Valley of Jehoshaphat. In any case, the Lord is beseeched to bring together his forces, whether human or angelic, to participate in the judgment of the nations.

<span id="page-296-12"></span><span id="page-296-8"></span><span id="page-296-7"></span><span id="page-296-4"></span>3:12 This verse is central to this section of the prophecy. The call to the nations has been given (vv. 9–11). Now the judgment scene is set, similar to that described in Daniel 7:9–10. Though the Gentile nations are assembling their forces, no threat can be made against the Lord and his forces, for he sits on the judgment throne. Once again (cf. v. 7) the verb "stir" is used of the nations as they make their military preparations, but in coming to the Valley of Jehoshaphat they are approaching their own doom.

<span id="page-296-13"></span><span id="page-296-6"></span><span id="page-296-3"></span><span id="page-296-2"></span>3:13 The metaphor changes as the Lord calls his servants, the warriors, to swing the sickle and reap the harvest. Both the OT and the NT use this metaphor to depict divine judgment (cf. Isa. 63:1–6; Matt. 13:36–43; and esp. Rev. 14:14–20). However, only here and in Jeremiah 51:33 does the grain harvest serve as a negative image. Further, as the grain crops are ripe, so are the grapes. Just as the reapers can bring in the sheaves, so treaders can press out the grapes in the overflowing vats. The last line of the verse emphasizes that the iniquity of the nations is great, and for this reason the Lord's judgment is at hand.

<span id="page-296-14"></span><span id="page-296-5"></span>3:14 The scene moves on to the final judgment itself, and although the Valley of Jehoshaphat is not mentioned again (cf. vv. 2, 12), the context requires it to be identified with the new term, "the valley of decision." The Hebrew word for "decision" may contain a play on words; it can mean both a legal judgment and also something dug out or excavated. Perhaps the latter meaning is more to the point here, referring to a deep valley. The word translated "multitudes" can mean a large crowd but also conveys the idea of uproar or commotion. Both ideas are probably intended here, as the nations are jumbled together in this valley as they await the final verdict from the Lord, whose day is "near."

<span id="page-297-6"></span><span id="page-297-3"></span><span id="page-297-2"></span>3:15 No actual description of the destruction of God's enemies is given. Instead, accompanying phenomena are presented to indicate the cosmic dimensions of God's judgment. The wording is identical to 2:10, where it describes the locust plague as the heavenly bodies fail to fulfill their function of giving light. The account in Matthew 27:45 records what happened when Jesus bore the judgment of God for his people on the cross: "Now from the sixth hour there was darkness over all the land until the ninth hour." Darkness is an appropriate manifestation of God's judgment.

<span id="page-297-5"></span><span id="page-297-4"></span><span id="page-297-1"></span>3:16 Several OT prophets depict the Lord roaring in judgment to indicate a divine visitation about to take place. This is especially true of those prophesying in the eighth century BC (cf. Isa. 31:4; Hos. 5:14; Amos 3:4, 8; the language here is identical to that in Amos 1:2). Like a lion roaring before it attacks, the Lord is providing a warning from Zion, thundering from Jerusalem. The Hebrew idiom "utters his voice" is to be understood as denoting thunder. Rather than Jerusalem and Zion being places of safety, they are the sources from which the judgments originate.

The latter part of the verse begins with a strong adversative, "*But* the Lord." These descriptions of God as "refuge" and "stronghold" are both common OT expressions; by acting in judgment on behalf of his people, the Lord demonstrates the security he affords them. The use of the divine name, "the Lord" (*Yahweh*), is also noteworthy, for he is speaking to "his people," "the people of Israel." This last term is significant, for although the northern tribes had arrogated to themselves an exclusive claim to the title "Israel," here Judah is recognized as still being part of the true nation.

#### *Response*

The consistent biblical message is that when people turn from the living God and fail to live up to the standards he has set, they can be sure to face a final reckoning with him. Every judgment of God recorded in the OT is a precursor to that final great judgment.

Another significant component of biblical teaching that finds support in Joel's prophecy is the link between God's judgment on sinners and the salvation of his people. Judgment and redemption are two sides of God's intervention on their behalf. The confidence of God's people rests in his character, for he is a "refuge" and a "stronghold" for them. Words such as these convey important concepts of what God is to those who trust in him. He is the keeper of Israel (Ps. 121:4, 5, 7).

<span id="page-297-10"></span><span id="page-297-9"></span><span id="page-297-8"></span><span id="page-297-7"></span><span id="page-297-0"></span>The NT gives us, in Jesus' own words, the confidence that he is the Good Shepherd who knows his sheep and keeps them unto eternal life (John 10:1–18). In his special prayer to his Father he assures all who come to him that they will be protected and kept safe (John 17:12). The NT message is that whenever God begins a good work in the heart and life of a believer, he will carry on and complete that work (Phil. 1:6). That work includes keeping believers from falling and ultimately presenting them without fault before God's presence (Jude 24).

<span id="page-298-2"></span>**<sup>17</sup>** "So you shall know that I am the Lord your God, who dwells in Zion, my holy mountain. And Jerusalem shall be holy, and strangers shall never again pass through it.

**<sup>18</sup>** "And in that day the mountains shall drip sweet wine, and the hills shall flow with milk, and all the streambeds of Judah shall flow with water; and a fountain shall come forth from the house of the Lord and water the Valley of Shittim.

- **<sup>19</sup>** "Egypt shall become a desolation and Edom a desolate wilderness, for the violence done to the people of Judah, because they have shed innocent blood in their land.
