- II. Guilt and Judgment of Israel (3:1–6:14) . . .
	- D. Injustice Punished (4:1–3)
	- E. False Worship Condemned (4:4–5)
	- F. Failure to Return to the Lord (4:6–13)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-330-7"></span>4:1–3 The imperative "Hear" begins the third oracle in a string of three that began in chapter 3 (vv. 1, 13). These oracles incriminate the people of Israel for their mistreatment of fellow countrymen and their idolatrous practices. The speech that begins in 4:1 carries the indictment further by calling attention to a subset of the nation and their callousness and rebelliousness.

The epithet "cows of Bashan" (v. 1) is most likely a reference to wealthy elite women in the city of Samaria. Some have suggested that the phrase refers to the city leaders, while others note an allusion to the Baal fertility cult. However, most commentators interpret this as a reference to the high society women of the capital. "Cow" in Hebrew is feminine in gender, and the Hebrew participles for "oppress" and "crush" occur in feminine form here as well. Along with mention of these cows' "husbands," the evidence suggests that God is singling out this sector of Israelite society. They are not the only guilty party, but Amos employs them as an example of the ruthless disorder among the nation.

<span id="page-330-6"></span><span id="page-330-2"></span><span id="page-330-1"></span><span id="page-330-0"></span>The phrase "cows of Bashan" is a revealing symbol of the rich women of this time. In the OT, Bashan evokes the idea of agricultural prosperity, as it was known for its opulent pastureland (Jer. 50:19; Mic. 7:14). Livestock from this Transjordanian area were known for their fatness and size (Deut. 32:14; Ps. 22:12; Ezek. 39:18) and provided amply for feasts and sacrifices. Thus these affluent women are being compared to cows that graze constantly on the abundance of the land. The women's lives of indulgence have made them voluminous, slothful, and demanding. They "oppress the poor" and "crush the needy" (Amos 4:1), the same

<span id="page-331-12"></span><span id="page-331-5"></span><span id="page-331-3"></span>Notably, these women are guilty of maltreatment not only of inferiors but also of superiors. They command their husbands (lit., "lords"), "Bring, that we may drink!" (4:1). These women defiantly and selfishly take advantage of others, using them for their own ends. Their concern is not for what is morally right or socially acceptable. Instead, they live unto themselves; their god is their belly (cf. Phil. 3:19). It is worth noting how these affluent and domineering women present a picture of Israel as a whole as guilty of oppressing the poor and needy, and defiant of the authority structure of marriage (women to husbands [lit., "lords"] and Israel to Lord Yahweh; cf. Hosea 1–3).

<span id="page-331-6"></span><span id="page-331-2"></span><span id="page-331-1"></span>In response to their callous behavior, Yahweh makes an oath, swearing by "his holiness" (Amos 4:2). This indicates an especially strong oath. For example, in Psalm 89:35 the Lord swears by his "holiness" *never* to violate his covenant with David. This oath formula in Amos 4 thus accentuates God's relentless commitment to bringing about his judgment.

<span id="page-331-11"></span><span id="page-331-10"></span><span id="page-331-4"></span>The phrase "the days are coming" is an eschatological expression pointing forward to the day of the Lord, when God will come in judgment (Amos 8:11; 9:13). The day of the Lord can refer to imminent temporal judgment or to a future final judgment, or both. In this context, an imminent judgment is clearly in view. The "cows of Bashan" will be taken away with "hooks" and "fishhooks."16 Fishing imagery is employed in ancient Near Eastern reliefs to portray one nation's conquering another and leading their captives away like fish on a string. For instance, an Assyrian relief shows captives led into exile with hooks in their lips or noses, connected to each other by rope.17

<span id="page-331-7"></span>The oppression these ruthless women have shown toward the poor and needy will thus come back upon them in the form of oppression by a foreign power. They will be led out of the city (in which they wallowed in their immorality) through "breaches" made in the walls by the enemy (4:3). There will be so many breaches that it will be as if there were no wall, so that "each one" will simply go out "straight ahead"18 as they depart in exile to Harmon. The term "Harmon" occurs only here in the OT, and its meaning is unknown. Many associate it with Mount Hermon and see it as pointing to the regions "beyond Damascus" (5:27). While its meaning may be uncertain, the point of the entire text is clear: the luxurious self-indulgence of these Samarian women will end in horror as they are dragged to a foreign land.

<span id="page-331-9"></span><span id="page-331-8"></span>4:4–5 The preceding oracle is followed by a sarcastic invitation for the people of Israel to continue in their false worship. God had commanded Israel to worship

Their current forms refer elsewhere to "shields" and "pots," though there are related words built on the same roots that refer to "thorns." "By extension from this meaning, many translators render the terms as hooks for dragging away corpses or to fasten captives together" (Smith and Page, *Amos, Obadiah, Jonah*, 86). Cf. Paul, *Amos*, 130–134, for full discussion.

<sup>17</sup> James B. Pritchard, ed., *The Ancient Near East in Pictures Relating to the Old Testament* (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1954), 152.

<span id="page-331-0"></span><sup>18</sup> The Hebrew expression is basically equivalent to Joshua 6:5, 20 ("everyone straight before him") regarding the conquering of Jericho. This may suggest a reversal of the roles of Israel as the ones who will now be conquered.

<span id="page-332-8"></span><span id="page-332-7"></span>him in Jerusalem, but Bethel19 and Gilgal20 had become religious centers in the northern kingdom. Now the Lord calls Israel to come to these places to worship to offer morning sacrifices, tithes, thanksgiving sacrifices, and freewill offerings (vv. 4b–5). But he prefaces this by saying, "Come to Bethel, *and transgress*; to Gilgal, *and multiply transgression*" (v. 4a). In other words, their worship was viewed as sinful rebellion. They loved to practice religion ("for so you love to do") but did not do so according to the Lord's commands, nor did they match their worship with obedience. The sarcasm of the Lord's command makes clear that no matter how much they multiply their worship, God will not accept it, nor will he relent from his coming judgment.

<span id="page-332-13"></span><span id="page-332-11"></span><span id="page-332-3"></span>4:6–11 These six verses contain five short descriptions of various punishments Israel has experienced. The repetition of "I" throughout the passage makes clear that the Lord himself has brought these punishments to bear. He has taken away food (v. 6), rain (vv. 7–8), produce (v. 9), and human and animal life (v. 10), overthrowing21 the people like Sodom and Gomorrah (v. 11). Such discipline should have led his people to repentance (Deut. 30:1–10), but Israel did not listen! The Lord ends each of these five descriptions with the blistering assertion "yet you did not return to me"! This is both a critique and an expression of dismay that Israel has remained unrepentant after the various calamities. One would expect human beings to cry out to God when life turns dire, but instead the people persisted in their rebellion against him.

<span id="page-332-9"></span>A few phrases from these verses may be briefly expounded. "Cleanness of teeth" (Amos 4:6) refers to God's withholding food from the people by way of famine. Unable to chew because of lack of food, their teeth remained clean. The "stench of your camp" (v. 10) implies that death from disease and warfare filled their camp with malodor. Finally, to refer to Israel as a "brand plucked out of the burning" demonstrates that even amid punishment, God graciously saved some from certain destruction (cf. Zech. 3:2; Jude 23). In wrath, God continued to remember mercy (Hab. 3:2), but the people still did not return to him.

<span id="page-332-16"></span><span id="page-332-15"></span><span id="page-332-10"></span><span id="page-332-5"></span><span id="page-332-0"></span>Taken together, the punishments of Amos 4:6–11 reflect the curses of the Mosaic covenant (Leviticus 26; Deuteronomy 27–28),22 underscoring Israel's violation of the covenant relationship with God and continuing the covenantal motif seen previously in Amos 2:9–11; 3:1–2. The Lord has judged them in the same manner as he did their great enemy, Egypt (4:10). This allusion to the punishment of Egypt places the northern kingdom in the same category as Egypt: they are God's enemy. Israel's stubborn rebelliousness is the central point of this passage. Just like

<span id="page-332-12"></span><span id="page-332-6"></span><span id="page-332-4"></span><sup>19</sup> Cf. comment on 3:13–15.

<span id="page-332-14"></span><span id="page-332-2"></span><sup>21</sup> Every occurrence of the Hebrew word "overthrow" (v. 11) in the OT appears in a context referring to Sodom and Gomorrah (Deut. 29:23; Isa. 1:7–10; 13:19; Jer. 49:18; 50:40). The comparisons of Israel with Sodom and Gomorrah are meant to be a shocking condemnation of God's people, and help to explain the severity of God's judgment.

<span id="page-333-2"></span><span id="page-333-1"></span>their forefathers in the wilderness, they remain a "stiff-necked" people (cf. Ex. 32:9; 33:3, 5; 34:9), refusing to learn from God's chastisement. As they have hardened their hearts against God, he now gives them over to their idolatrous ways, which will end in destruction (cf. Rom. 1:18–32).

<span id="page-333-8"></span><span id="page-333-5"></span><span id="page-333-4"></span>4:12–13 The Lord's faithfulness to the covenant requires punitive action against Israel in the fullest measure. Since they have not heeded his warnings ("therefore"; v. 12), God will do "this" to them. "This" refers to his personal visitation: "Prepare to meet your God, O Israel!" This powerfully haunting statement evokes the image of the holy God entering into the midst of Israel in order to destroy them. This appears to be an allusion to Exodus 19, where the nation assembled at Sinai to enter into covenant with the Lord. Before God gave them the law by speaking directly to them, they had to prepare to encounter the Holy One (Ex. 19:7–15). Ironically, Amos indicates that now they are to prepare to meet God for punishment, not blessing. And the previous sample punishments (Amos 4:6–11) do not come close to what is now coming. This time, the Lord's visitation will bring the nation to an end. To quote Stuart, "You haven't seen anything yet."23

<span id="page-333-6"></span><span id="page-333-0"></span>"Your God" is described in verse 13, which has often been called a doxology. He is the Creator who "forms the mountains" and "creates the wind." He reveals who he is ("declares to man what is his thought"), controls everything ("makes the morning darkness") and is everywhere present ("treads on the heights of the earth"). There is no escaping this God, and Yahweh, "the God of hosts, is his name!" "Hosts" (*tseba'ot*) refers to armies (3:13; 5:14, 15, 16, 27; 6:8, 14; 9:5), evoking militaristic imagery regarding God's coming. The coming judgment is seen in the Lord's sovereign employment not merely of earthly armies but, ultimately, of his heavenly armies.

### <span id="page-333-7"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-333-3"></span>Israel's covenantal relationship with God plays out in this chapter as the Lord chastises the people for their unfaithfulness, a chastisement purposed to turn them back to him. The Lord keeps his part of the covenant (e.g., by being faithful and punishing sin), even though the people refuse to repent. God keeps his word, and he will do exactly what he says. His swearing by "his holiness" (4:2) stresses the certainty with which he will act. This is true equally regarding both curses and blessings. God will judge all mankind for sin, but he will also save all who repent and turn to Christ. Wonderfully, the book of Hebrews highlights this very thing:

When God made a promise to Abraham, since he had no one greater by whom to swear, *he swore by himself*, saying, "Surely I will bless you and multiply you." And thus Abraham, having patiently waited, obtained the promise. For people swear by something greater than themselves, and in all their disputes an oath is final for confirmation. *So when God desired to show more convincingly to the heirs of the promise the unchangeable character of his*  *purpose, he guaranteed it with an oath*, so that by two unchangeable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled for refuge might have strong encouragement to hold fast to the hope set before us. We have this as a sure and steadfast anchor of the soul, a hope that enters into the inner place behind the curtain, where Jesus has gone as a forerunner on our behalf, having become a high priest forever after the order of Melchizedek. (Heb. 6:13–20)

<span id="page-334-6"></span>God has sworn by himself to save his people, which he has done fully in Jesus Christ.

<span id="page-334-1"></span>We also see that God's warnings should lead us to repentance. Just as God sent punishment against Israel (Amos 4:6–11) in order to lead them back to himself, so God shows human beings their sins and calls them to turn from the wrath to come. It is the responsibility of men and women to turn to God, for his patience does not last forever. It is possible for people to harden their hearts against God to the extent that he gives them over to their wickedness. Paul speaks of God's giving mankind up "in the lusts of their hearts" (Rom. 1:24), "to dishonorable passions" (1:26), and "to a debased mind" (1:28). Thankfully, the Lord is able to save us out of our depravity, but he may also leave us in it instead. Just as he gave Israel over to their wickedness (Amos 4:4–6), so he may do to those who continue to refuse him.

<span id="page-334-5"></span><span id="page-334-4"></span><span id="page-334-0"></span>Notably, the Israelites frequented shrines in order to offer worship. They were going through the motions—performing rituals, paying tithes, offering praises but it meant nothing because it was not from hearts that loved God and desired to keep his commandments. In contrast, Jesus highlights the nature of true worship when he says to the Samaritan woman, "The hour is coming, and is now here, when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for the Father is seeking such people to worship him. God is spirit, and those who worship him must worship in spirit and truth" (John 4:23–24).

<span id="page-334-8"></span><span id="page-334-7"></span><span id="page-334-3"></span><span id="page-334-2"></span>The prospect of meeting God while yet in our sin is a sobering thing. When the Lord warned, "Prepare to meet your God, O Israel" (Amos 4:12), terror should have struck their rebellious hearts—and the same is true for us if we are in rebellion against him. As the author of Hebrews states to those who have turned away from Jesus, "It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God" (Heb. 10:31). But the threat of judgment is removed for those who embrace Christ from the heart. That means putting our trust in him, the One who has taken the judgment that our sin and rebellion deserve. In Christ we meet God and are not undone. We know the blessing of God's presence, not the curse of his judgment. Such a glorious truth leads to true worship: "Therefore let us be grateful for receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, and thus let us offer to God acceptable worship, with reverence and awe, for our God is a consuming fire" (Heb. 12:28–29).

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-337-1"></span>Amos 5 consists of two main sections. The first comprises 5:1–17, the last oracle that begins with the imperative "Hear!" The unity of this section is especially evident due to its chiastic nature (in which the main points of the passage are repeated in reverse order):

- A. Lamentation (vv. 1–3)
	- B. Call to Seek the Lord (vv. 4–6)
		- C. Indictments (v. 7)
			- D. Hymn (vv. 8–9)
		- C'. Indictments (vv. 10–13)
	- B'. Call to Seek the Lord (vv. 14–15)
- A'. Lamentation (vv. 16–17)

<span id="page-337-4"></span>The second section of this passage is 5:18–27, the first of two "woe" oracles (cf. 6:1–7), consisting of an announcement of the day of the Lord (5:18–20) and the rejection of Israel's hypocritical worship (5:21–27).

<span id="page-337-5"></span>Taken together, the two sections in chapter 5 underscore the certainty of God's judgment. The first section is a lamentation, but an ironic one, since this lamentation is not so much a grieving over the fall of the nation as a denouncement against it. Similarly, the woe oracle of the second section depicts the coming day of the Lord—to which the Israelites were apparently looking forward as a day of deliverance—as a day of darkness, not light, a day in which they would be held accountable for their idolatries and injustices. The judgment in view is exile "beyond Damascus" (v. 27); they had abandoned the covenant and could no longer remain in the covenant land.

## <span id="page-337-6"></span>*Section Outline*

- II. Guilt and Judgment of Israel (3:1–6:14) . . .
	- G. Seek the Lord and Live (5:1–17)
	- H. First Oracle of Woe (5:18–27)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-337-3"></span><span id="page-337-2"></span><span id="page-337-0"></span>5:1–3 The imperative "Hear!" begins the chapter (v. 1), linking this passage with the previous two chapters (3:1, 13; 4:1), but it is unclear whether the immediate speaker is Amos or the Lord himself. Regardless, "this word" to which the people must listen is the "lamentation" that follows. A "lamentation" is an elegy or a dirge said or sung upon the death of an individual. It usually conveys grief and sorrow over

<span id="page-338-6"></span>loss (8:10), but this lamentation in 4:1–17 does not. Instead, it functions more as a prophetic denouncement of the nation and an announcement of its coming death.

<span id="page-338-8"></span>The lamentation begins (5:2) by announcing that Israel has fallen as though dying, lacking the strength or ability to get back up. This expression of certain collapse is accentuated by referring to the nation as "the virgin Israel," conveying a sense of tragedy that the nation has fallen in the prime of her life. She is a like a young girl with so much potential and possibility, her life cut short before marriage or childbearing. It is a tragic picture of a people who did not achieve their God-intended purpose in life.

<span id="page-338-9"></span><span id="page-338-2"></span>What is more, she is forsaken in her own "land." Israel's home turf, the divine gift of Canaan, is the very ground upon which she will be destroyed. No one is able to help her ("with none to raise her up"). In verse 3, this "fall" is presented in militaristic terms: multiples of ten are military units (2 Sam. 18:1).24 The diminishing numbers of those who exit the city ("thousand" → "hundred" → "ten") portray a dwindling army, cut down by the enemy, until very few remain. The message of these verses is clear: the defeat of Israel will be devastating.

<span id="page-338-16"></span><span id="page-338-15"></span><span id="page-338-14"></span><span id="page-338-13"></span><span id="page-338-11"></span><span id="page-338-4"></span>5:4–7 The chapter continues with the formulaic expression "For thus says the Lord . . ." (cf. vv. 3, 16). Now the Lord directly addresses "the house of Israel" (v. 4), pleading, "Seek me and live." These terms occur again in verse 6, and a third imperative in verse 14 is synonymous ("Seek good, and not evil, that you may live"). Some interpret this call to "seek God" as contradictory to the certainty of judgment seen in the previous verses.25 Others see the call as addressing not the whole nation but the righteous remnant still faithful to the Lord (cf. 5:15).26 In the light of Jeremiah 18:1–18, etc., others believe that until judgment comes there is always a chance that the Lord might still show mercy to the people.27 Admittedly, there is an inevitability of judgment in the prophetic message of Amos. However, the first two interpretations just summarized appear to be too strong in their view of the certainty of judgment. Verse 4 should be read not as contradictory to verses 1–3 but as complementary. Also, God's call to respond does not appear to be limited to one sector of Israel, the righteous. This call in verse 4 is made to all who would hear and respond. To say that this is a call only to the faithful seems to diminish the compassion of God, who calls all to seek him and live (Isa. 55:6–7; Ezek. 18:23; Jonah 3:4–5, 10; Acts 17:30). He desires mankind to turn to him to avoid his judgment and to experience life under his good pleasure.

<span id="page-338-12"></span><span id="page-338-10"></span><span id="page-338-5"></span><span id="page-338-3"></span>The object of Amos 5:4 stands out: "Seek *me* and live." The people are to seek the Lord himself, which should be understood as knowing God and keeping his word (cf. vv. 14–15). God commands them in verse 5 not to go to Bethel, Gilgal, or Beersheba.28 It is clear from 4:4 that Bethel and Gilgal were places of sinful wor-

<span id="page-338-7"></span><sup>24</sup> Ibid., 346.

<sup>25</sup> Wolff, *Joel and Amos*, 237.

<sup>26</sup> Gary V. Smith, *Hosea, Amos, Micah*, 313–314.

<sup>27</sup> Smith and Page, *Amos, Obadiah, Jonah*, 98.

<span id="page-338-1"></span><span id="page-338-0"></span><sup>28</sup> For Bethel, see Genesis 12:8; 35:1; for Gilgal, see Joshua 4:19–5:10; for Beersheba, see Genesis 21:33; 26:23–25; 46:1. Beersheba had become a place of religious pilgrimage (2 Kings 23:8; Amos 8:14).

ship, suggesting the same was true of Beersheba. Indeed, Gilgal and Bethel will be destroyed: Gilgal will "go into exile"29 and Bethel will "come to nothing" (lit., "come to disaster/sorrow"). They will not find the Lord by continuing in their sinful ways.

<span id="page-339-8"></span><span id="page-339-6"></span>The second imperative, "Seek the Lord and live" (5:6), provides a rationale for doing so: so that he will not "break out like fire in the house of Joseph." The "house of Joseph" should be viewed as referring not only to the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh but to the entire northern kingdom (cf. v. 4, "the house of Israel"). The purpose of this fire is to "devour" Bethel because of the false worship that takes place there. Fire was the recurring judgment declared against the Gentile nations and Judah in the first two chapters (1:4, 7, 10, 12, 14; 2:2, 5). Now the Lord calls Israel to seek him so that this judgment will not come upon them. The mention of Bethel three times in 5:5–6 highlights the central role it played in the aberrant religious practices of the northern kingdom. It has become synonymous with idolatry itself.

<span id="page-339-9"></span><span id="page-339-7"></span><span id="page-339-3"></span>The indictment of verse 7 comes right on the heels of the imperative of verse 6 and should be read as a continuation of the previous verses. In other words, the call to seek the Lord (in v. 6) is directed toward the wicked (in v. 7) "who turn justice to wormwood and cast down righteousness to the earth." Wormwood produces exceptionally bitter oil and functions as a metaphor for bitterness in the OT. Justice should be sweet, but when corrupted it becomes bitter. This verse summons those engaged in injustice and unrighteousness to seek the Lord while he may be found and to turn from their immoral ways.

<span id="page-339-11"></span><span id="page-339-10"></span><span id="page-339-5"></span>5:8–9 These verses form the center of the chiasm of 5:1–17 (cf. Section Overview). Their hymnic nature has led some to suggest that they were originally part of an ancient hymn, adapted by Amos for this passage. These verses exalt the Lord as the maker of the heavenly constellations, the one who controls the waters of the seas and brings destruction upon the land. Verse 8 contributes to this theme by describing the Lord as the creator and sustainer of the universe ("He who made . . . and turns . . ."). The constellations Pleiades and Orion represent the creational work of God (Job 9:9; 38:31; Isa. 40:26), and their mention may also be a polemic against astral worship. If so, the clear implication is that these constellations are not gods but entities created by the Lord.

<span id="page-339-2"></span>The Lord also controls the patterns of time ("turns deep darkness into the morning and darkens the day into night") and nature ("calls for the waters of the sea and pours them out on the surface of the earth").30 Thus he providentially sustains the events of creation. Functioning like a refrain, "The Lord is his name" stands as the climax of this passage. The Lord is the one with whom the Israelites must reckon (cf. Heb. 4:13). This statement, along with the motifs of creation, light, and darkness, connects this hymnic passage with the doxology in Amos 4:13 and the hymn in 9:5–6.

<span id="page-339-13"></span><span id="page-339-12"></span><span id="page-339-4"></span><span id="page-339-1"></span><span id="page-339-0"></span><sup>29</sup> There is a play on words here in Hebrew, as the words for "Gilgal" and "go into exile" sound very similar. 30 These statements could also be echoes of God's judgments in the ninth plague against Egypt (Ex. 10:21–29) and in the flood (Genesis 6–8), respectively.

<span id="page-340-4"></span>Verse 9 concludes this passage by describing the Lord as the one who destroys "the strong" and "the fortress." The God who created and sustains all things is also the one who judges, and no matter how strong and fortified a nation may appear, it cannot stand in his way.

<span id="page-340-6"></span><span id="page-340-3"></span>5:10–13 The indictments introduced generically in verse 7 become more specific in these four verses. The "gate" (vv. 10, 12) of the city was the place of business and legal transaction. It represented the place where all parties stood on equal footing before the law, and the offended party (often the poor) could expect justice to win the day through the decree of an impartial judge. But the corruption of the legal system had become so great in Amos's day that even honesty in a court of law had become loathsome to people. The unjust are accused of hating and rejecting those who are truthful and stand for righteousness (v. 10). Verse 12 highlights similar abuses: the people "afflict the righteous," "take a bribe," and "turn aside the needy in the gate." Abhorrence of truth and perversion of the legal system are always marks of injustice.

<span id="page-340-8"></span><span id="page-340-7"></span>Verse 11 explains the consequences of their treachery ("Therefore . . ."). Since they have trampled upon the poor and levied unfair taxes on them, these offenders will face ironic justice. The opulent amenities they have purchased with their unjust wealth will be lost. They will not enjoy the "stone" (i.e., luxurious) houses they built or the "wine" from the "pleasant vineyards" they planted. Someone else will rob them of these treasures, and they will experience the afflictions they imposed upon others. These judgments are reminiscent of the covenant curses in Deuteronomy 28:30, 39: "You shall build a house, but you shall not dwell in it. You shall plant a vineyard, but you shall not enjoy its fruit. . . . You shall plant vineyards and dress them, but you shall neither drink of the wine nor gather the grapes, for the worm shall eat them."

<span id="page-340-13"></span><span id="page-340-9"></span><span id="page-340-5"></span><span id="page-340-0"></span>The final verse of this unit (Amos 5:13) has been understood in different ways. Some view it as a powerful statement of the equity of God's retribution against Israel, that the "prudent" or wise will remain silent when judgment comes because they know that what the nation has sown, it will now reap (Gal. 6:7–10). A different approach is that of Billy Smith, who suggests that, in view of the people's rejection of truth (Amos 5:10), the "point could be that the times were such that wise men, who in better times would be consulted for their wisdom, were silent because no one would listen" (cf. Matt. 7:6). Or, in a related way, it could mean that the wise man "knew how to avoid trouble, in which case silence would be the best policy in such evil times."31

<span id="page-340-12"></span><span id="page-340-11"></span><span id="page-340-2"></span><span id="page-340-1"></span>5:14–15 These verses contain the final call, in the lamentation of 5:1–17, to respond to God. Similarly to verses 4 and 6, God calls his hearers to "seek." In those verses, he exhorted the Israelites, "Seek me and live. . . . Seek the Lord and live!" In verse 14, however, he exhorts, "Seek good [*tob*], and not evil [*raʻ*], that you

<span id="page-340-10"></span><sup>31</sup> Smith and Page, *Amos, Obadiah, Jonah*, 105.

<span id="page-341-6"></span><span id="page-341-4"></span>may live." This is clearly parallel to the earlier commands (cf. Section Overview), underscoring the fact that seeking the Lord (vv. 4, 6) is not a mystical endeavor or a simple engagement in religious ritual but is done by means of righteous living, i.e., loving God and keeping his commands (seeking "good"; v. 14). Sadly, the people were doing the opposite; their evil ways revealed they did not know God or love him. As a result, their worship rituals were futile, and the Lord was not "with" them as they claimed (v. 14). However, if they would truly seek him, "the God of hosts"—the Divine Warrior King (cf. 3:13)—would be in their midst, for their good and not their harm.

<span id="page-341-11"></span><span id="page-341-1"></span>This is further reiterated in 5:15 by the command to "Hate evil [*raʻ*],and love good [*tob*]." Note the reversal of "good" and "evil" from verse 14 to verse 15. To seek "good" means to forsake "evil," and to hate "evil" means to love "good." No middle ground exists between the two. The people are either for God or against him (cf. Matt. 12:30). If they are for him, they will seek to obey his righteous commands. A third imperative in Amos 5:15 shows practically what it means to hate evil and love good: "Establish justice in the gate." God calls the Israelites to turn to him and reform their ways by bringing equity back to the legal system of the land (cf. comment on 5:10–13).

<span id="page-341-7"></span><span id="page-341-5"></span><span id="page-341-2"></span>The possibility of mercy marks the end of this call (v. 15). If they seek the Lord, hate evil, and return justice to "the gate," then "the God of hosts" may show mercy to "the remnant of Joseph." Even at this point, the Lord's graciousness and compassion abounds. In the light of Israel's unfaithfulness and rebellion, Exodus 34:6–7 still rings true:

<span id="page-341-0"></span>The Lord, the Lord, a God merciful and gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness, keeping steadfast love for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin, but who will by no means clear the guilty, visiting the iniquity of the fathers on the children and the children's children, to the third and the fourth generation.

<span id="page-341-9"></span><span id="page-341-3"></span>5:16–17 The final section of the lamentation (5:1–17) begins with the formula, "Therefore thus says the Lord, the God of hosts, the Lord . . ." Note the threefold reference to God: "the Lord" (Yahweh), "the God of hosts," and "the Lord" (*'adonay*). The fullness of this title seems to underscore the gravity of the message to follow. The title "God of hosts" (*tseba'ot*) occurs for the third time in three consecutive verses (v. 16; cf. vv. 14, 15), accentuating the image of God as military conqueror (cf. comment on 3:13).

<span id="page-341-10"></span><span id="page-341-8"></span>It is so obvious that Israel will reject the plea to seek the Lord (5:14–15) that God announces in verses 16–17 that lamentation will be heard throughout the land. The term "wailing" occurs three times in these verses, along with three additional expressions or terms of lament: "Alas! Alas!," "mourning," and "lamentation" (v. 16). This theme of lamenting in verses 1 and 16–17 frames the entire lamentation of 5:1–17, bringing unity to the passage. The wailing will be heard throughout the land: in town squares, farms (v. 16), and vineyards (v. 17). There <span id="page-342-9"></span>will be so much death that farmers (who usually sing at the harvest) must be summoned to aid professional mourners in their singing of dirges (v. 16).

<span id="page-342-0"></span>God declares that his visitation is the reason for all the lamentation over the dead: "For I will pass through your midst" (v. 17). The Egyptian Passover event in Exodus provides the background for this statement. In Exodus 12:12, the Lord states, "For *I will pass through* the land of Egypt that night, and I will strike all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both man and beast; and on all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgments: I am the Lord." When the Lord "passed through" the midst of Egypt, only those with the blood of the Passover lamb on their doorposts were "passed over" and spared from God's wrath: "The blood shall be a sign for you, on the houses where you are. And when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and no plague will befall you to destroy you, when I strike the land of Egypt" (Ex. 12:13). Now, in Amos, God will not "pass over" the Israelites (cf. Amos 7:8); he will "pass through" their midst, and mourning will follow. This is a devastating picture, once again comparing the northern kingdom to God's ancient enemy—Egypt (4:10).

<span id="page-342-11"></span><span id="page-342-7"></span><span id="page-342-6"></span><span id="page-342-1"></span>5:18–20 God's coming visitation mentioned in 4:13 and 5:17 is now referred to as "the day of the Lord" three times in verses 18 and 20. However, there appears to be a clear misconception regarding this "day" among the Israelites of Amos's time. The prophet pronounces "woe" upon those who expectantly look forward to the day of the Lord. The "woe" of verse 18 begins the first of two woe oracles in the book of Amos (5:18–27; 6:1–7), and it is a threatening cry of grief. The people's "desire" to see this day shows that they believe God will save Israel and deliver her from her enemies on that day. Amos, however, corrects this wrong theology by declaring that the day of the Lord entails Israel's own destruction.

<span id="page-342-12"></span><span id="page-342-5"></span><span id="page-342-4"></span>The day of the Lord has both negative and positive connotations in the OT. It can refer to God's coming salvation (Jer. 30:3; 31:31; Zech. 14:9) or to his coming judgment (Joel 2:1–2; Obad. 15), both temporally and eschatologically. In these verses of Amos the day of the Lord patently refers to God's punishment of the covenant people for their unfaithfulness. Those who long for that day are ironically longing for destruction.

<span id="page-342-13"></span><span id="page-342-10"></span><span id="page-342-3"></span><span id="page-342-2"></span>This passage stresses the nature of that day by contrasting darkness and light. In the OT, "light" points to life and salvation (Pss. 27:1; Isa. 9:2), while "darkness" indicates death and destruction (Ps. 88:18; 91:6; Isa. 8:22). Amos calls this day "darkness, and not light" twice in these verses (Amos 5:18, 20). In between these two statements, he emphasizes the inevitability of the coming judgment (v. 19). It will be like a man who escapes from a lion, only to be confronted by a bear, or like one who goes into the safety of his home, only to be killed by a snake within it. Such pictures point to the certainty of death. There will be no hope for Israel in that day, for the day of the Lord will be the day of reckoning.

<span id="page-342-14"></span><span id="page-342-8"></span>5:21–24 These verses address the unacceptable worship of Israel (cf. vv. 4–5). God vigorously rejects their religious rituals: "I hate, I despise . . . I take no delight . . . <span id="page-343-4"></span><span id="page-343-1"></span>I will not accept . . . I will not look upon . . . Take away from me . . . I will not listen." The people's numerous religious activities may have been vibrant and even commanded by the law (Leviticus 1–3; 23), but they were both mixed with pagan idolatry and undermined by the people's wicked treatment of the poor. Thus the Lord spurns their hypocritical worship and calls them to holiness instead: "But let justice roll down like waters, and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream" (Amos 5:24). In Israel, wadis or riverbeds would overflow in the rainy seasons and then dry up soon after the rains had ceased. In terms of justice and righteousness, the nation is pictured as a bone-dry wadi; they have been guilty of corrupting "justice" and "righteousness" (5:7; 6:12). So, God calls for a permanent flow of justice and righteousness in Israelite society ("like an ever-flowing stream") rather than a drought of godliness. The Lord desires them to repent of their injustices and live in covenant faithfulness with him and one another. In other words, God seeks not their perpetually vain rituals but their consistent loving obedience.

<span id="page-343-6"></span><span id="page-343-3"></span>5:25–27 These verses have proved to be a great challenge for scholars—both their translation and their interpretation. Two main ways of interpreting verse 25 have been suggested. According to the first, the expected answer to the question of verse 25 is "no," not because Israel never presented sacrifices to the Lord, but because their relationship with God was not solely (or even primarily) about sacrifice; it was about covenant love for the Lord (Jer. 7:21–23).32 Some in this camp understand the sense to be, "Did you *only* bring sacrifices? No! You brought love and faithfulness, justice and righteousness! That is true covenant religion! And that is what you need now!"

<span id="page-343-2"></span><span id="page-343-0"></span>According to the second way of understanding this passage, the expected answer to the question is also "no," but because the sacrifices the Israelites offered were idolatrous and thus not made properly to the Lord (as with the golden calf in Exodus 32 and the incident at Baal-peor in Numbers 25). In other words, the people in the wilderness quickly turned away from the Lord and corrupted the worship he had commanded. This interpretation, which is less common, suggests that Amos 5:25 highlights the covenant unfaithfulness of the nation even from its conception.33

<span id="page-343-7"></span><span id="page-343-5"></span>There are further difficulties in verse 26, especially in terms of translation. With only slight changes, the word "Sikkuth" could be read as "booth/tabernacle," while the word "your king" could be read as "Moloch." This is what the Septuagint translators did: "You took up the tent of Moloch . . ."34

Nevertheless, it seems best to follow the Hebrew text. Kiyyun was an Assyrian god identified with the planet Saturn, and some view Sikkuth as a parallel

<sup>32</sup> Gary V. Smith, *Hosea, Amos, Micah*, 327.

<sup>33</sup> See ibid., 326–328, for Smith's discussion on the difficulties and options regarding these verses.

<span id="page-343-8"></span><sup>34</sup> Stephen quotes the Septuagint version in his speech in Acts 7 (vv. 42–43). It was common, however, for the Septuagint—which is in Greek—to be quoted in the Greek NT. NT authors are not necessarily endorsing every translational choice the Septuagint made; sometimes they are simply seeking to get their main point across. In this instance, even though there are differences between the two, both the Septuagint and the Hebrew text are clear in condemning Israel's past pagan worship.

<span id="page-344-5"></span><span id="page-344-2"></span>reference, since he is identified as the Mesopotamian god Ninurta (a god also associated with Saturn).35 The description of Kiyyun as "your star-god" in the text further supports the idea that astral worship is in view. In addition, the possible polemic against astral worship in the mention of God's creation of the Pleiades and Orion (v. 8) further supports the notion that verse 26 refers to the worship of heavenly bodies. The Israelites will take up their idols of astral deities—which they made with their own hands—and carry them on their journey into exile "beyond Damascus" (v. 27). The phrase "beyond Damascus" points to the captivity they will experience in the foreign land of Assyria. It is a punishment fitting the crime: the people will worship their Assyrian astral gods in the land of Assyria! The gravity of the message is underscored by the closing words, where a fairly full title is again used to describe "the Lord," the one "whose name is the God of hosts" and who will thus bring about this defeat of Israel (cf. vv. 16–17).

### <span id="page-344-3"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-344-1"></span>One of the central tenets of this chapter is the need to "seek the Lord and live." Even though Israel had abandoned the Lord, God called them to seek him and thereby find life. The grace and patience of God stand out amid rebellion and wickedness; until judgment finally comes, the Lord receives all who will turn to him. What a wonderful picture of the love of God for sinners in the middle of a prophetic book full of doom! God's mercy is great and his compassion beyond words. As the Lord states in Ezekiel 18:23, "Have I any pleasure in the death of the wicked, declares the Lord God, and not rather that he should turn from his way and live?" Isaiah 55:6–7 similarly declares, "Seek the Lord while he may be found; call upon him while he is near; let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts; let him return to the Lord, that he may have compassion on him, and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon." The Lord Jesus himself said, "I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will not walk in darkness, but will have the light of life" (John 8:12; cf. Amos 5:18–20).

<span id="page-344-4"></span><span id="page-344-0"></span>A second theme in this chapter is the hypocritical and idolatrous worship of Israel. The people did not worship God according to his word, and their disobedience to God's law (especially seen in their mistreatment of their fellow human beings) revealed the emptiness of their worship. Those who truly know God will also seek to live according to his word, in both worship and practice.

<span id="page-344-6"></span>In our present day, emphasis on obedience in the Christian life is often avoided for fear of legalism or moralism. Certainly, emphasis upon obedience apart from the context of grace becomes moralistic and oppressive. But the Scriptures never downplay or mince words concerning the necessity of faithfulness. Obedience is the fruit of true faith, and love for both God and man is the basis of the moral law (Matt. 22:34–40). If we correctly understand justification as being by faith alone, then our pursuit of obedience (i.e., sanctification) becomes the consequence of our <span id="page-345-3"></span><span id="page-345-2"></span><span id="page-345-1"></span>salvation in Christ, not the means of it.36 Faith and obedience are not mutually exclusive: faith without works is a dead faith (James 2:17, 26), and works apart from justifying faith are futile (Gal. 2:16). Those who are truly God's children will look increasingly more like Christ as they grow in the grace and knowledge of him. But those who claim to worship God while living in unfaithful rebellion are actually like the Israelites of Amos's day. The Lord of hosts, whom they claim to worship, is the very one to whom they will give an account (Heb. 4:13).

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-346-1"></span>The dreadful nature of Amos 6 begins with its first word: "Woe!" This initial expression of lament simply introduces what is perhaps the darkest and most terrifying chapter in this prophetic book. Accusation against the complacency of the capital cities (vv. 1–7) leads to an extreme expression of the Lord's hatred of the people's arrogance and an ominous picture of the aftermath of God's wrath (vv. 8–14). The devastation revealed in verses 9–10 will be thorough and will come as a result of the Lord's raising up a foreign nation against Israel to tyrannize them throughout the land (vv. 11–14).

## <span id="page-346-10"></span><span id="page-346-9"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-346-8"></span><span id="page-346-4"></span>II. Guilt and Judgment of Israel (3:1–6:14) . . .
	- I. Second Oracle of Woe (6:1–7)
	- J. The Lord's Oath (6:8–14)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-346-5"></span><span id="page-346-3"></span><span id="page-346-0"></span>6:1–3 As with the previous oracle (5:18), the use of the lament "Woe," as customary in Amos, commences this oracle, which begins by addressing the careless indifference of Israel's elite. While there is a shift in focus from security to complacency in 6:4, the entirety of 6:1–7 should be viewed as a unified passage with two complementary parts. The repetition of the root meaning "first, finest" in verses 6:1 (*re'shit*), 6:6 (*re'shit*), and 6:7 (*ro'sh*) binds the text together as God condemns Israel for its self-confidence and self-indulgence.

<span id="page-346-7"></span><span id="page-346-6"></span><span id="page-346-2"></span>The false sense of security of the people is highlighted in verse 1, which describes "those who are at ease in Zion, . . . who feel secure on the mountain of <span id="page-347-8"></span><span id="page-347-3"></span><span id="page-347-2"></span>Samaria." "Zion" refers to Jerusalem, which seems odd in a book predominately addressing the northern kingdom of Israel. However, the prophets have been known to speak to both the northern and southern kingdoms while nevertheless primarily addressing one kingdom or the other (Hos. 5:12, 14; 6:4–11; Amos 2:4–5). Amos's words apply to the self-confident nobility ("the notable men") of Samaria, and such transgressors in the southern capital of Jerusalem are equally liable to judgment (cf. Mic. 1:2–9). To be "at ease" conveys a sense of careless comfort in the belief that there is no cause for concern. The feeling of being secure on the "mountain of Samaria" underscores this comfort. Both capital cities were built on a mountain, which significantly increased their fortification and sense of security. However, God insinuates that these fortified cities, especially Samaria, will fall.

The people are commanded to look at three cities that were once great, secure places but are no longer so. Calneh and Hamath were eastern cities of Syria, while Gath was formerly one of the great five Philistine strongholds. By Amos's time each had fallen into the hands of other nations. God hypothetically asks if Israel is greater than these previous strongholds. The clearly implied answer is "no." Just as these powerful cities have fallen, so will Israel. Amos 6:3 then addresses the selfassured leadership's rejection of these warnings. They "put far away" the coming judgment by denying its possibility, but the fall of these other great cities bears witness to the pending doom of Israel.

<span id="page-347-4"></span>Denial of the coming disaster actually serves to "bring near the seat of violence." The meaning of this phrase is debated. It could mean that by denying the coming disaster (and refusing to repent), the people hasten the arrival of the day of the Lord (and thus the violence of the judgment they will receive from the nations he sends against them). Alternately, it could mean that by denying the coming disaster (and refusing to repent), the people are encouraging further wicked and unjust behavior (violence). In either case, denying the Lord's coming judgment will have a tremendously negative impact on society.

<span id="page-347-7"></span><span id="page-347-6"></span><span id="page-347-5"></span><span id="page-347-1"></span><span id="page-347-0"></span>6:4–7 In the Hebrew, verse 4 begins simply with a reference to "those who lie on beds," but since this verse is a continuation of the woe oracle, the ESV has added the word "woe" to make the connection clear. The oracle is now directed toward the self-indulgent decadence of Israel's elite. They are pictured as sprawled out on their luxurious furniture ("beds of ivory" and "couches"), feasting on the choicest meats available. Most of the population ate meat only a few times a year, particularly at feasts, because it was so expensive. These privileged few, however, gave themselves to continual feasting and hedonistic pleasure. And since they were extravagantly wealthy, they used their abundant free time to sing "idle songs" and invent "instruments of music," just like the most notable royal of all—David (v. 5). In other words, they partied like the greatest of royalty, but the irony here should not be missed: David employed music to worship the Lord (2 Sam. 23:1; 2 Chron. 7:6), not in order to engage in unrestrained debauchery.

<span id="page-348-6"></span><span id="page-348-0"></span>The people may have had the material blessings of King David, but they did not share his spiritual inclinations toward God (1 Sam. 13:14; 16:7). Furthermore, their engagement in these decadent festivities ("drink wine in bowls and anoint themselves with the finest oils") occurs without the slightest concern for the condition of their land (Amos 6:6). They are so self-consumed in their revelry that they "are not grieved over the ruin of Joseph"—that is, over their own coming ruin.37 Because of its wanton apathy and narcissistic hedonism, the nobility will lead the way into exile, and their "revelry . . . shall pass away." In this case, the first shall not be last; the first shall be first!38

<span id="page-348-12"></span><span id="page-348-8"></span><span id="page-348-2"></span>6:8–10 These verses provide the exclamation point of the chapter by describing God's abhorrence of Israel's immoral condition and the devastating aftermath of his judgment. In the form of an oath, the Lord declares that he will destroy the city, and the death toll will be catastrophic. Verse 8 ("The Lord God has sworn by himself") is the second of three oath formulas in the book of Amos. In 4:2 God swore by "his holiness," and in 8:7 he will swear by "the pride of Jacob." In order to grasp the monumental message of this verse, the resoluteness with which oaths were taken in the ancient Near East should not be overlooked. As Gary Smith comments, "Oaths were taken seriously. A person was required to carry out an oath no matter how painful it might be."39 And since the "God of hosts" swears by himself, the unchangeable nature of this oath becomes even more explicit (cf. 4:2; Heb. 6:13–20).40

<span id="page-348-13"></span><span id="page-348-7"></span><span id="page-348-5"></span>The Lord abhors and hates (cf. Amos 5:21) the militaristic conceit of Israel. In 6:8, the phrase "the pride of Jacob" (cf. 8:7) is parallel to "his strongholds," indicating that the nation's confidence is not in the God of hosts who fights for them but in their own defensive prowess. The double statement of the Lord's hatred of Israel's arrogance stresses the intensity of his judgment. He promises to shatter their "pride" by delivering up "the city" and everything in it. The city in view is Samaria, but as the capital, its fate reflects that of the entire nation.

<span id="page-348-10"></span><span id="page-348-9"></span><span id="page-348-4"></span>Amos 6:9–10 should be read as a figurative illustration portraying the horrifying outcome of God's visitation in judgment (i.e., the day of the Lord; cf. 5:18–20). The "if" in 6:9 marks these verses as an example of the type of devastation that will be experienced: "If ten men remain in one house, they shall die." These "ten men" could be a reference to the smallest military unit in Israel, implying utter desolation of the army. However, this could refer instead to ordinary citizens who may have made it through part of the disaster but will nonetheless meet their end. In either case, the point is that death will be comprehensive when judgment comes.

<span id="page-348-11"></span>Verse 10 provides a "what is more . . ." elaboration on this outcome. When those responsible for burying the dead come to the house, they will ask, "Is there still anyone with you?" Some commentators have been concerned to identify the

<span id="page-348-3"></span><sup>37</sup> "Joseph" refers to the northern kingdom; cf. comment on 5:4–7 (at v. 6).

<sup>38</sup> Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, 356.

<sup>39</sup> Gary V. Smith, *Hosea, Amos, Micah*, 341.

<span id="page-348-1"></span><sup>40</sup> See comment on 4:1–3 (at v. 2) and the Response section for 4:1–13.

<span id="page-349-7"></span>figure being addressed. Was he already in the house? Or, since verse 9 says that all in the house will die, did he accompany the relative to the house? There is no need, however, to be overly concerned with this question, since the illustration is figurative and not meant to be minutely parsed. The purpose of the imagery is to reveal that death will be extensive, and those who search for the bodies will see its full extent.

The person's response is startling. He says simply, "No." No one remains. Then he interjects, "Silence! We must not mention the name of the Lord." This prohibition is not to imply that saying the actual name of God is forbidden; the responder himself uses the name "the Lord." Instead, it may mean that it is too late to invoke the name of the Lord in the form of lamentation or pleading. The deed has been done. Alternatively, it could be interpreted as a statement of fear of calling out to him in prayer: "Yahweh will have become foe, not friend. Survivors will want him to stay away, not come back."41 Either way, the severity of this calamity provokes a sense of terror in those who witness the aftermath of God's wrath.

<span id="page-349-10"></span><span id="page-349-9"></span><span id="page-349-8"></span><span id="page-349-6"></span>6:11–14 These verses grab our attention ("For behold") following the ruinous portrait of the land in verses 9–10. The devastating fall has clearly come from the Lord, at whose command great and small "houses" alike are shattered into "fragments" and "bits." The term "house" (vv. 9, 10, 11[2x], 14) helps to tie this second half of the chapter together (vv. 8–14). The idea is not merely that judgment will come upon individual houses of every size (vv. 9, 10, 11), but that the nation—the "house" of Israel—will be toppled as well (v. 14). Both scenarios emphasize the same point: the destruction will be complete and overwhelming.

<span id="page-349-13"></span>Two hypothetical questions then follow in verse 12. The idea of horses running on rock or oxen plowing rock is ludicrous—it would be unthinkable to do such things. How much more, implies the Lord, has Israel done the unthinkable: they "have turned justice into poison and the fruit of righteousness into wormwood" (cf. 5:17).42 It is beyond belief that those who have received both the grace and the law of God would corrupt the legal system to meet their own sinful ends, but such is the case (5:10–13). This is the exact opposite of what should have happened.

<span id="page-349-4"></span><span id="page-349-3"></span><span id="page-349-2"></span><span id="page-349-0"></span>Note that the phrase "fruit of righteousness" (6:12) refers to the outworking of justice in the land, both morally and practically (cf. 5:15). This is what Israel was supposed to do, leading to blessing in society. As Proverbs 11:30 states, "The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life." It may further be noted that the NT actually employs the exact phrase of Amos 6:12 twice in reference to the sanctified lives of believers being filled with "the fruit of righteousness" through Jesus Christ (Phil. 1:11; James 3:18). In both OT and NT times, God calls his people to embody his righteousness.

<span id="page-349-15"></span><span id="page-349-14"></span><span id="page-349-12"></span><span id="page-349-11"></span><span id="page-349-5"></span>Amos 6:13 then returns to the issue of the pride Israel took in its military prowess (cf. v. 8). They "rejoice" in having captured Lo-debar and Karnaim, Transjordanian cities conquered by Jeroboam II. Lo-debar (lit., "not a thing")

<sup>41</sup> Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, 364.

<span id="page-349-1"></span><sup>42</sup> For discussion on "wormwood," cf. comment on 5:4–7 (at v. 7).

<span id="page-350-7"></span><span id="page-350-6"></span><span id="page-350-1"></span>was a town near the border of Gilead, while Karnaim was between Samaria and Damascus. Even though the nation boasted in achieving these conquests "by our own strength" (v. 13), the Lord actually gave Israel these victories (2 Kings 14:25–28). Their trust in their own strength is misplaced, which will become apparent when the Lord raises up another nation against them (Amos 6:14). "The God of hosts"—the Divine Warrior-King—will employ a foreign military force (i.e., Assyria) to "oppress" them, from their northernmost point (Lebo-hamath) to the southernmost (Brook of the Arabah). In other words, the entire land of the northern kingdom (2 Kings 14:25) will be destroyed.

### <span id="page-350-0"></span>*Response*

The oracles of woe in Amos and other OT prophets present an intimidating and ominous message of God's wrath against sin. The judgments Israel and Judah experienced in the Assyrian and Babylonian conquests, respectively, are nearly impossible to describe and quantify adequately. The temporal punishment they underwent can be read about in specific biblical passages (e.g., Jer. 39:1–10; 52:1– 30; Lam. 4:1–22), but only those who underwent it knew fully its horror.

<span id="page-350-12"></span><span id="page-350-10"></span><span id="page-350-3"></span><span id="page-350-2"></span>Nevertheless, the final punishment to which these conquests ultimately point will far exceed the terrors of the past. And notably, woes do not end with the coming of Jesus Christ. The NT announces "woes" of its own. In the Gospels, Jesus pronounces seven woes on the scribes and Pharisees of his day for their wicked hypocrisy (Matt. 23:1–36; cf. Luke 11:37–54). He pronounces woes on those who love the world and acclimate themselves to it (Luke 6:24–26). He pronounces woes on Chorazin and Bethsaida because they do not heed the signs and wonders done in them (Matt. 11:21). He pronounces woes on those through whom temptation comes (Matt. 18:7). And he pronounces woe on the one who will betray him— Judas (Mark 14:21). As the Great Prophet, Jesus carries on the prophetic role of declaring God's wrath against sin. His words warn every generation to flee from the wrath to come by fleeing to him.43

<span id="page-350-15"></span><span id="page-350-13"></span><span id="page-350-11"></span><span id="page-350-9"></span><span id="page-350-8"></span><span id="page-350-5"></span><span id="page-350-4"></span>The devastation of God's visitation in Amos 6 points to the final day of the Lord, at the end of time. The terrifying picture in verses 9–10 is far surpassed by the imagery of punishment in the book of Revelation. It is worth comparing the pictures of judgment in Revelation with the severity of the Lord's judgment in Amos, so that we might see God's hatred against our sins and those of the world (e.g., Rev. 6:12–17; 9:13–21; 14:17–20; 19:11–21). As the book of Hebrews tells us, "It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God" (Heb. 10:31). But believers in Jesus Christ may have comfort and assurance that they have fallen into the forgiving hands of the loving Judge who received their judgment upon himself at Calvary. So let the redeemed of the Lord say, "Hallelujah! What a Savior!"

<span id="page-350-14"></span><sup>43</sup> See other pronouncements of woes against sin in the NT (Jude 11; Rev. 8:13; 9:12; 11:14; 12:12).

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-352-2"></span><span id="page-352-1"></span>The final section of the book (chs. 7–9) contains a series of visions spread throughout these chapters (7:1–3, 4–6, 7–9; 8:1–3; 9:1–4). Three of these visions constitute the first half of chapter 7, and each reveals a judgment of the Lord against Israel. The first two (vv. 1–3, 4–6) follow the same pattern: introduction, vision of judgment, Amos's intercession, and the Lord's relenting of the judgment revealed. The third vision (vv. 7–9) varies somewhat, with an introduction, vision of judgment, and the Lord's explanation of judgment; Amos does not intercede for Israel, nor does God relent from the judgment. Likewise the fourth vision, in 8:1–3, follows the same arrangement as the third. This suggests that there are two pairs of visions in Amos 7–8 (visions 1 and 2; visions 3 and 4). God relents from the judgments seen in the first two visions but not from the second two. (The fifth and final vision in 9:1–4 stands on its own.)

<span id="page-352-5"></span><span id="page-352-0"></span>Following the first three visions of judgment, 7:10–17 contains the only narrative section of the book. Amaziah, the priest at Bethel, confronts Amos regarding a prophecy against King Jeroboam II. The priest tells Amos to go back south from whence he has come and prophesy there. The prophet is no longer welcome in Bethel. In response to this challenge, Amos prophesies the coming fall of Amaziah's family and Amaziah's own exile and death. This passage provides the only record of response to Amos's ministry, and it is a revealing response indeed.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-352-4"></span><span id="page-352-3"></span>III. Destruction but Hope (7:1–9:15)
	- A. Vision of Locusts (7:1–3)
	- B. Vision of Fire (7:4–6)
	- C. Vision of Plumb Line (7:7–9)
	- D. Confrontation with Amaziah the Priest (7:10–17)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-353-9"></span><span id="page-353-6"></span>7:1–3 The first two visions in this chapter begin with the introductory phrase "This is what the Lord God showed me" (vv. 1, 4). The word translated "Lord" is a title used for a sovereign or ruler, and the word for "God" is his proper name (Yahweh); together, they highlight his sovereign position and rule: he is Lord Yahweh.

<span id="page-353-4"></span><span id="page-353-3"></span>The vision he shows Amos is not something happening naturally at the time but is a future event of his own making. The participle indicating that God is "forming the locusts" evokes his role as Creator, highlighted also in the doxology of 4:13 (the same Hebrew root for "to form" is present in both passages). The Lord creates the locusts (i.e., the judgment) that will soon overtake the land (cf. Deut. 28:42; Joel 1:4–20). The creation of the locusts is specifically timed to fall around April, in the Israelite growing season. This is just before the "latter growth" (Amos 7:1). The first growth, "the king's mowings," was for the monarchy, providing the royal household with grain for food and hay for livestock. This indicates that the king has gotten his due, but the peasant farmers and the rest of the land will suffer immensely because of the locust plague.

<span id="page-353-7"></span><span id="page-353-5"></span>When Amos sees the destruction the locusts bring in the vision, he cries out to the sovereign Lord, invoking his covenant name and imploring him, "Please forgive!" (v. 2). The Hebrew construction conveys earnestness, as Amos is clearly distraught over what he has seen, and his compassion for the people rises to the foreground: "How can Jacob stand? He is so small!" In a Moses-like manner (cf. Exodus 32–33), Amos intercedes on behalf of the people, asking the Lord to show them forgiveness and not bring about something that would certainly crush them.

<span id="page-353-1"></span>It is important to note that Amos's compassion appears to be toward the farmers and common people of Israel. The leadership will not initially suffer from the locust plague (although they will in the long run, being as theirs is a primarily agricultural economy). Amos laments on behalf of the peasants. In doing so, he refers to Israel as "Jacob," the patriarch to whom God reiterated his covenant (Gen. 28:13–16). It is as though the prophet appeals to the Lord's covenant love toward the forefathers as the basis for forgiveness now.

<span id="page-353-10"></span><span id="page-353-8"></span><span id="page-353-2"></span><span id="page-353-0"></span>The intercession works, and the Lord relents from this judgment, saying, "It shall not be" (Amos 7:3). He chooses not to bring about the punishment portrayed to Amos. The statement that God "relented" describes the Lord in very human terms. Such "anthropomorphisms" occur frequently in the Bible as a way of making God's infinite character understandable to finite human beings. In this case, to say that God has "relented" is to say that he will pursue a different action than the one he has announced, and will do so in response to his prophet's prayer (cf. also Ex. 32:11–14). This does not in any way impugn the doctrine of the immutability of God (Mal. 3:6). It simply communicates the manner in which God relates to his people. He warns, forgives, judges, etc., based on the response of human beings. All of these things take place under his sovereign decrees and providence, which are often a mystery to us. But it is a wonderful truth that the Lord hears the pleas of his people and compassionately responds.

<span id="page-354-7"></span><span id="page-354-6"></span><span id="page-354-4"></span><span id="page-354-3"></span>7:4–6 The second vision follows the same pattern as the first: introduction, vision of judgment, Amos's intercession, the Lord's relenting. In this case, the announced judgment is more terrifying than the first, as the Lord calls for a "judgment by fire" to devour "the great deep" and consume the "land" (lit., "portion") of Israel (v. 4). The punishment of devouring fire is a recurring theme in the book of Amos (1:4, 7, 10, 12, 14; 2:2, 5; 5:6), but here the severity of the penalty is especially strong. The word for "great deep" (*tehom*) in the OT refers to the sea in various ways: the primeval ocean (Gen. 1:2), the abyss (Job 38:16), subterranean waters (Gen. 7:11), and the sea (Ex. 15:5). Taken together with mention of "the land," the picture is of a comprehensive consumption of the created order, particularly the "portion" of Israel (cf. 2 Pet. 3:10).

<span id="page-354-12"></span><span id="page-354-5"></span><span id="page-354-2"></span><span id="page-354-1"></span><span id="page-354-0"></span>Note the Lord's prophetic statement regarding Israel's future unfaithfulness in Deuteronomy 32:22: "A fire is kindled by my anger, and it burns to the depths of Sheol, devours the earth and its increase, and sets on fire the foundations of the mountains." A similar horror leads Amos to intercede on behalf of the nation a second time. This intercession has the same earnestness as that in Amos 7:2, but here the request is not to "forgive" but to "cease." Amos appears to be so overwhelmed that he can only cry to God, "Stop, please!" The compassion of the prophet comes forth again: "How can Jacob stand? He is so small!" Mercifully, the Lord hears Amos's intercession and chooses to relent concerning this calamity: "This also shall not be" (v. 6).

<span id="page-354-10"></span><span id="page-354-9"></span><span id="page-354-8"></span>7:7–9 The third vision and response do not contain an intercession by the prophet or a relenting from the Lord, signifying the certainty of fulfillment. Amos sees the Lord "standing beside a wall built with a plumb line, with a plumb line in his hand" (v. 7). The exact form of the Lord's appearance goes unmentioned; the main focus of this picture is on what the Lord is holding. The word translated "plumb line" is rare, appearing only here in the OT. This has led to much discussion regarding its meaning.44 In context, however, the term indeed seems best translated as "plumb line."45 Amos sees a wall constructed with the use of a plumb line—it was initially built level and straight. The Lord now stands next to the wall with a plumb line in his hand to measure its present condition.

<span id="page-354-11"></span>This becomes clear in verse 8, where the Lord explains that he is measuring the condition of Israel—and the implication is that they have become totally misaligned. Even though he established his covenant with the nation and gave them his law, they have turned from him and become corrupt. The Lord finds that Israel is crooked and cannot be fixed. The remedy, or rather the consequence, is to destroy it. He communicates this with another allusion to the Passover (v. 8; cf.

<sup>44</sup> Cf., e.g., Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, 374–373; Jeffrey J. Niehaus, "Amos," in Thomas Edward McComiskey, ed., *The Minor Prophets: An Exegetical and Expository Commentary* (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker, 2009), 455–457; Paul, *Amos*, 233–234; Smith and Page, *Amos, Obadiah, Jonah*, 132.

<sup>45</sup> For more discussion, cf. Benjamin J. Noonan, "There and Back Again: 'Tin' or 'Lead' in Amos 7:7–9?" *VT* 63 (2013), 299–307; H. G. M. Williamson, "The Prophet and the Plumb-Line: A Redactional-Critical Study of Amos 7," in Robert P. Gordon, ed., *The Place Is Too Small for Us: The Israelite Prophets in Recent Scholarship* (Winona Lake, IN: Eisenbrauns, 1995), 453–477.

<span id="page-355-4"></span><span id="page-355-3"></span>comment on 5:16–17), stating that he "will never again pass by [i.e., over] them" as he did in Egypt; instead he will destroy their "high places" and "sanctuaries" (7:9). "High places" were shrines on hilltops at which the people engaged in syncretistic worship, while "sanctuaries" were temples in the cities, like those in Bethel and Dan. God will reduce their religious sites to rubble (cf. Lev. 26:30–31).

<span id="page-355-2"></span><span id="page-355-0"></span>In addition, the monarchic dynasty of Jeroboam II will fall "with the sword" (cf. 2 Kings 15:8–10). This is the only reference in the book to Jeroboam II with regard to judgment, but it prepares the reader for the confrontation between Amaziah and the prophet in the immediately following verses (Amos 7:10–17).

<span id="page-355-7"></span><span id="page-355-6"></span>7:10–13 The narrative of verses 10–17 contains an account of Amos's confrontation with Amaziah the priest. Even though this account is written from the thirdperson point of view, it seems best to understand it as autobiographical. As the "priest of Bethel," Amaziah was likely the high priest there, as he apparently held a position of prominence in that religiopolitical environment. He "sent" word to King Jeroboam regarding the prophecy of Amos, revealing his political allegiance to the monarchy and his desire to bring an end to the prophet's mischief (v. 10). The message sent to the king shows that Amaziah knew the prophecy of Amos, especially regarding God's judgment against the house of Jeroboam (v. 13).

<span id="page-355-11"></span><span id="page-355-5"></span>However, Amaziah's words exhibit manipulative intent. He charges the prophet with conspiring against the king within his own kingdom ("in the midst of the house of Israel"). The word translated "conspired" has the sense of plotting against someone. In this context, it is clearly political. Additionally, by saying that the "land" cannot "bear" Amos's words, Amaziah communicates that the economic and political stability of Israel is under threat. This rabble-rousing "seer" is a menace to society.

<span id="page-355-8"></span>The priest accuses Amos of scheming against the king, quoting the prophet as saying that "Jeroboam shall die by the sword" (v. 11). Technically, the earlier prophecy only stated that "the *house* of Jeroboam" would face "the sword" (v. 9). Nothing was directed toward the king himself, but the priest alters Amos's words to suit his own political ends. And, while Amaziah's summary of the prophet's message of Israel's coming exile from the "land" more accurately reflects the truth, the conveying of this information to Jeroboam comes from the priest's own political motivations. This is seen in Amaziah's command to Amos to leave Israel (v. 12). He addresses Amos as "seer," which is not necessarily a derogatory term. Amos has seen visions (vv. 1–9), and other prophets are given this title as well (1 Sam. 9:9).

<span id="page-355-12"></span><span id="page-355-10"></span><span id="page-355-9"></span><span id="page-355-1"></span>However, by telling Amos to go back to Judah, "eat bread there," "prophesy there," and "never again prophesy at Bethel" (Amos 7:12–13), Amaziah impugns the motivations of the prophet. The priest insinuates that Amos is a careerist prophet who prophesies in order to make a living (as becomes clearer in Amos's response, in vv. 14–15). Here, Amaziah tells him to go back to his own land (Judah) to make his living. There is no mention as to whether this command comes on the authority of King Jeroboam, but the priest obviously sees himself as a protector of both "church and state" ("it is the king's sanctuary, and it is a temple of the kingdom").

<span id="page-356-6"></span>7:14–17 In Hebrew, the beginning of Amos's response is very tersely worded, leading to different understandings of the particulars of what he is saying. In terms of the general point, however, it seems best to understand Amos's words in the context of Amaziah's insinuation that he is a career prophet, i.e., a prophet for hire. He is not "a prophet" in the sense of being a prophet paid to prophesy good or ill, nor is he "a prophet's son," carrying on the family business. He is an *actual* prophet called by God.

<span id="page-356-3"></span>Amos shows this by noting his agricultural background as "a herdsman and a dresser of sycamore figs." This is underscored by the superscription at the beginning of the book, where he is called "a shepherd" (1:1). In short, he is not among the professional prophets of Israel or Judah. He disassociates himself further from this category by highlighting God's election of him to this ministry: the Lord "took me from following the flock" (7:15). The Lord commanded him, "Go, prophesy to my people Israel." It was not Amos's choice to engage in this prophetic endeavor. The covenant Lord chose him and has given him authority to speak. Therefore, Amos will not flee from Amaziah's opposition.

<span id="page-356-10"></span><span id="page-356-9"></span><span id="page-356-8"></span><span id="page-356-7"></span>Amos follows this self-vindication with a personal message from the Lord to Amaziah (vv. 16–17). The priest has not merely challenged Amos; he has challenged the Lord himself. By rejecting the prophet and his message (v. 16), the priest reveals his rejection of God and his authority. "Therefore" God will judge him and his household, and the judgment is extensive (v. 17). Without a husband, his wife will have to make her living as a prostitute, which is a degrading and unthinkable fall for the wife of the prominent high priest at Bethel. His sons and daughters "shall fall by the sword" (cf. v. 9), and his land will be divided up. He himself will "die in an unclean land," that is, outside the land of Israel, and the nation itself will also go into exile. Rejecting God's word always leads to destruction, no matter how prominent one's position or political connections.

#### <span id="page-356-5"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-356-2"></span><span id="page-356-0"></span>The visions in this chapter present a fearful picture of God's wrath against the wickedness of humanity. The Holy One of Israel is completely righteous in his evaluation of human beings (Gen. 18:25), and his condemnation and punishment of sinners cannot be questioned (Job 9:12: "Who will say to him, 'What are you doing?'"). In the end, ". . . every mouth may be stopped, and the whole world may be held accountable to God" (Rom. 3:19). Nevertheless, two things stand out in the first two visions that should bring us encouragement and peace if our hearts are turned toward him.

<span id="page-356-11"></span><span id="page-356-4"></span><span id="page-356-1"></span>First, the Lord may relent from his judgment (Amos 7:3, 6), in perfect keeping with his character as "the Lord, the Lord, a God merciful and gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness, keeping steadfast love for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin" (Ex. 34:6–7). It is this same mercy and grace he has now shown in the profoundest of ways by sending Jesus, the One in whom full and final forgiveness of sins is possible. Those who put their trust in him have the joy of knowing that the justice due their sins has been fully satisfied at the cross. Paul writes, "For our sake he made him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God" (2 Cor. 5:21).

<span id="page-357-2"></span>Second, the compassionate intercession of the Lord's prophet on behalf of the people shows that God listens to the mediatory prayers of his people. For both ministers and church members, prayer on behalf of others is an essential means of ministry. Because the Lord has chosen to accomplish his purposes through the prayers of his people, we must never believe that our intercessory prayers are offered in vain. We should instead be encouraged to pray boldly for the lost as we plead with God on behalf of those who need to turn to him.

<span id="page-357-5"></span><span id="page-357-4"></span><span id="page-357-3"></span><span id="page-357-1"></span>The confrontation between Amos and Amaziah provides encouragement as well, and even exhortation. Those who are called by God to proclaim his word are not "professional prophets." They may make their living from gospel ministry (1 Cor. 9:14), but they always do so as servants of Christ, not of themselves. Those who minister out of selfish ambition will compromise God's word (Phil. 1:15–17; 1 Tim. 6:3–5), but those who like Amos serve because they have so great a Master will stand upon his word in the face of challenge (2 Tim. 4:1–5). In a day of much compromise, let us be faithful to the word of Christ by the power of the Holy Spirit.

"So many dead bodies!" "They are thrown everywhere!" "Silence!"

- **<sup>4</sup>** Hear this, you who trample on the needy and bring the poor of the land to an end,

- that we may make the ephah small and the shekel*<sup>4</sup>* great and deal deceitfully with false balances,
- **<sup>6</sup>** that we may buy the poor for silver and the needy for a pair of sandals and sell the chaff of the wheat?"
- **<sup>7</sup>** The Lord has sworn by the pride of Jacob: "Surely I will never forget any of their deeds.
