<span id="page-358-0"></span>1The Hebrew words for *end* and *summer fruit* sound alike 2Or *palace* 3Or *The singing women of the palace shall wail* 4An *ephah* was about 3/5 bushel or 22 liters; a *shekel* was about 2/5 ounce or 11 grams

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-358-3"></span><span id="page-358-2"></span><span id="page-358-1"></span>Amos 8 begins with the fourth vision (vv. 1–3) of this final section of the book (chs. 7–9), and it, along with the remainder of the chapter (vv. 4–14), pronounces the end of Israel. The "day of the Lord" motif (cf. 5:18–20) continues in Amos 8, and the chapter itself is bound together by the recurring word "day(s)" (vv. 3, 9, 10, 11). The day(s) is coming when the Lord will visit the nation in judgment for its unfaithfulness and will terminate its existence.

<span id="page-358-4"></span>The indictments against Israel in this chapter largely reflect the social injustices previously mentioned in the book. However, Amos is more specific in his application, such as in his charge against businessmen who hypocritically observe feasts <span id="page-359-12"></span><span id="page-359-11"></span><span id="page-359-4"></span>and Sabbaths while longing for their quick completion so that they might get back to their work of swindling the poor (vv. 4–6). However, the Lord "will turn their feasts into mourning" and bring a bitter end to life as they know it (v. 10). Consequently, the nation shall "never rise again" (v. 14). As the book nears its close, the inescapable nature of Israel's fall becomes more evident, and the mood of the text becomes more dismal. The dark destiny of the nation is imminent as the coming of the Lord draws near (9:1–6).

## <span id="page-359-13"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-359-7"></span>III. Destruction but Hope (7:1–9:15) . . .
	- E. Vision of Basket of Summer Fruit (8:1–3)
	- F. Judgment for Sin (8:4–14)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-359-6"></span><span id="page-359-3"></span>8:1–3 The fourth vision passage follows the same pattern as the third vision (7:7–9), thereby making them a pair (cf. comments on Amos 7). Unlike the first two visions, neither of these latter visions mentions the prophet's intercession or God's relenting from judgment (7:1–3; 4–6); the judgment revealed in these final two visions is inescapable. In 8:1 the Lord shows Amos a "basket of summer fruit." This was a basket used to harvest ripened produce, and it symbolizes that the "end" (v. 2) of the nation has come. The play on words in the Hebrew text is important to note: the words "summer fruit" (*qayits*) and "end" (*qets*) closely resemble each other, even sounding alike. The use of these terms immediately associates the image of harvest with destruction.

<span id="page-359-9"></span><span id="page-359-8"></span>The Lord describes this destruction in verses 2–3. He explains, "The end has come upon my people Israel; I will never again pass by them"; that is, he will not pass them by when it comes to judgment. They will certainly experience it! Note how God calls them "my people," highlighting their covenantal relationship, and note that Passover imagery again occurs in this judgment context. God already stated in the third vision that he would "never again pass" them by in judgment (7:8; cf. comment on 7:7–9). He also declared earlier that he would "pass through" their midst in judgment (5:17; cf. comment on 5:16–17). This latest allusion to the Passover/exodus shows the reversal of Israel from being a blessed people to now being cursed, once again comparing the northern kingdom to God's ancient enemy, Egypt (cf. 4:10; 5:17; 7:8).

<span id="page-359-10"></span><span id="page-359-5"></span><span id="page-359-2"></span><span id="page-359-1"></span><span id="page-359-0"></span>The songs sung in worship will become "wailings in that day" (8:3). This reference to "wailing" when the day of the Lord comes (cf. 5:18–20) should be understood in the sense of "howling," or an "inarticulate, shattering scream such as is found in primitive funerary laments and in the face of sudden catastrophe."46 The irony should not be missed. The people who engage in false worship, of which singing was apparently a part, will instead cry out at the visitation of the Lord of <span id="page-360-11"></span><span id="page-360-7"></span>hosts (cf. 4:13). They will wail over the mass of dead bodies piled up and scattered everywhere (8:3). At such a traumatic sight they will howl, "Silence!" This interjection conveys a sense of awe and terror in light of the aftermath of God's wrath (cf. 6:10). The Lord has come, and there is nothing else that can be said.

<span id="page-360-18"></span><span id="page-360-13"></span><span id="page-360-10"></span><span id="page-360-8"></span><span id="page-360-4"></span>8:4–6 After the vision in verses 1–3, the remainder of the chapter functions as a unified speech, noting both the reasons for (vv. 4–6) and the outcome of (vv. 7–14) the coming destruction. Social injustice is again the indictment against Israel (cf. 3:6–8; 4:1; 5:10–12). The imperatival statement "Hear this" (cf. 3:1, 13, 4:1; 5:1) addresses those who mistreat the "poor" and "needy" (8:4), i.e., the vulnerable members of society. In particular, the guilty parties are merchants who are anxious for religious observances (e.g., the "new moon" festival and the Sabbath) to end so that they can resume increasing their wealth unfairly (vv. 5–6).47

<span id="page-360-19"></span><span id="page-360-15"></span>Their worship is superficial as they are consumed with greed on these holy days, and their greed is evidence of their idolatrous hearts (Col. 3:5). They desire to sell "grain" and "wheat," and in so doing they "make the ephah small." An ephah is a measurement of volume, and by decreasing its size, a merchant can cheat the buyer on the amount sold.

<span id="page-360-2"></span>A second expression similarly conveys the swindling of consumers: the evildoers make "the shekel great." A shekel is a measurement of weight. By increasing the size of a shekel—e.g., by writing "5 shekels" on a weight that is only 3 shekels—a seller can mislead a buyer into thinking that the shekel being used to measure weighs more than it actually does, and the buyer is charged more than the material is worth. Similarly, the merchants seek to deceive their customers by using false balances (Prov. 11:1) in order to increase their wealth. In doing so, they "buy the poor for silver and the needy for a pair of sandals" (Amos 8:6; cf. also 2:6). They even propose to sell "the chaff" (lit., "the refuse") of the wheat as though it were pure grain itself. By doing so, they rob the poor while increasing their own fortune. God's laws are very specific regarding the generous and fair treatment of the poor (Deut. 10:17–26; 24:19–22), but these businessmen overtly disregard God's concern for the weak members of society.

<span id="page-360-17"></span><span id="page-360-16"></span><span id="page-360-9"></span><span id="page-360-6"></span><span id="page-360-3"></span><span id="page-360-1"></span><span id="page-360-0"></span>8:7–10 The previous indictment leads to another oath by the Lord, who swears "by the pride of Jacob" (v. 7). Scholarly debate surrounds this phrase. It could refer to the land of Israel (Ps. 47:4) as a prized possession, or to the city of Samaria (as a fortified power), as in Amos 6:8.48 It seems best, however, to interpret "the pride of Jacob" as a reference to God himself. In 4:2 the Lord swore "by his holiness," and in 6:8 he swore "by himself" (cf. comments on 4:1–3; 6:8–10). These two previous occurrences of the Lord's swearing by his own person suggest the same here. In addition, when the Lord swore by himself in 6:8, "the pride of Jacob" referred to

<span id="page-360-14"></span><span id="page-360-12"></span><span id="page-360-5"></span><sup>47</sup> The verb translated "bring . . . to an end" in verse 4 is likely a play on the word "Sabbath" that follows in verse 5.

<sup>48</sup> If the latter, it is an ironic statement: just as surely as they are proud of their might (the pride of Jacob), God will act to destroy it!

Samaria in terms of its military prowess. Now God is given this title because ultimately he has been the true pride/majesty of Jacob all along.

<span id="page-361-16"></span><span id="page-361-10"></span><span id="page-361-9"></span><span id="page-361-2"></span>The Lord swears he will "never forget" the wicked actions of the people, their persecution and oppression of the needy among them (8:4–6). This promise heightens the seriousness of God's judgment. He "will by no means clear the guilty" (Ex. 34:7); every unjust action will be brought to account (2 Cor. 5:10). The tenacity of God's pursuit of justice continues as he asks a rhetorical question in Amos 8:8: Since God will never forget, "shall not the land tremble"—natural language to describe an earthquake of judgment (cf. Nah. 1:5)—and shall not all its inhabitants "mourn" in response? Of course they will. Just as the Nile rises and falls each season in Egypt—and does so under the Lord's sovereign control (Amos 9:5)—so will God's wrath against Israel certainly flow upon the land, causing it to heave up and down when the earthquake of judgment strikes. (For other references and allusions to Egypt in the book of Amos, cf. 2:9–11; 3:1, 9; 4:10; 5:17; 7:8; 8:2; 9:5, 7.)

<span id="page-361-15"></span><span id="page-361-11"></span><span id="page-361-7"></span><span id="page-361-6"></span><span id="page-361-5"></span><span id="page-361-1"></span>"And on that day" (8:9) is another reference to the day of the Lord, and the remainder of verses 9–10 largely echoes the imagery of 5:18–20. Light will turn to darkness as the sun sets at "noon," and the earth will darken when there should instead be "broad daylight." Darkness signifies God's coming in judgment, which leads ultimately to death. In light of the Passover allusions in Amos discussed above, the ninth plague upon Egypt is a fitting illustration of the day of the Lord (Ex. 10:21–29). The sheer terror the Egyptians experienced over three days of darkness symbolized the death of their chief deity (the sun god Amun-Re) and their own descent into the abyss. Death symbolically encompassed the land of Egypt, and then the final plague came as God struck all the firstborn of Egypt (Ex. 11:1–10; 12:29–32). Notably, Egypt's judgment has now become Israel's judgment. God's own covenant people have become his enemy.

<span id="page-361-12"></span><span id="page-361-8"></span><span id="page-361-4"></span><span id="page-361-3"></span><span id="page-361-0"></span>In that day, the Lord himself will turn Israel's idolatrous religious festivals into "mourning" and their "songs" into "lamentation" (Amos 8:10). This theme of mourning replacing religious singing was introduced in verse 3 and continues in verse 10 with the imagery of "sackcloth" and "baldness." These elements were traditional expressions of grief and lament in the ancient Near East (Ezra 9:3; Isa. 22:12; Joel 1:8, 13; Jonah 3:5–9), employed as outward expressions of the misery a person felt within. The word "mourning" occurs again as Amos 8:10 concludes, likening Israel's grief to that of losing an "only son." A son represented the posterity of one's house and hope for those who would depend upon him for support and provision (e.g., wife, children, and aged parents). To lose one's only son would not only cause grief but would also signify the extinction of the entire family. The "end" of God's wrath will be like a "bitter day." As opposed to the sweetness of the Lord's covenant blessings, Israel will experience the bitterness of his covenant curses.

<span id="page-361-14"></span><span id="page-361-13"></span>8:11–14 The final section of the chapter has two parts (vv. 11–12 and vv. 13–14), each introduced by references to the day of the Lord: "Behold, the days are coming" (v. 11) and "In that day" (v. 13). Together, these verses round out the message of the nation's coming end.

<span id="page-362-6"></span><span id="page-362-3"></span>The "days are coming" when God will bring a "famine on the land" (v. 11), implying a lack of the essentials basic for survival. The Lord had previously sent famine to bring Israel to repentance, but they did not return to him (4:6). Yet this famine in 8:11 is not typical; it is not a lack of grain or water. Rather, it is the absence of "the words of the Lord" from the people's midst. The people of the land will long to hear from the Lord and will "wander" (or "stagger") "from sea to sea, and from north to east," searching for God (v. 12).

<span id="page-362-7"></span><span id="page-362-0"></span>In other words, they will look everywhere, but without success. They will "run to and fro, to seek the word of the Lord, but they shall not find it." This statement reveals the epitome of judgment (1 Sam. 14:37; 28:6, 15–16). The Lord makes his will and his presence known through his word, namely by means of his prophets. But there will be silence from the Lord in that day, the ultimate sign of his displeasure. This famine will lead the people to search everywhere for God and his word, like searching for food and water in order to live. Yet they will find no sign of the Lord but will instead be left in despair.49

<span id="page-362-9"></span><span id="page-362-8"></span>When this famine comes, the weak members of society will not be the only ones to "faint for thirst" (Amos 8:13). "In that day," even the strongest and healthiest members of society ("lovely virgins" and "young men") will collapse under the judgment. Those who swear by idols will "fall, and never rise again" (v. 14). The judgment will be final. The oath takers in this verse may refer to the hypocritical worshipers of verses 4–6 or may simply be all who bind themselves to false deities. The "Guilt of Samaria" evidently contrasts with the "pride of Jacob" in verse 7. This contrast suggests that "Guilt" refers to the false god(s) worshiped in Samaria.

<span id="page-362-5"></span>This conclusion is further supported by the parallel oaths in verse 14: "As your god lives, O Dan," and "As the Way of Beersheba lives." The words "Guilt" and "Way" in verse 14 are parallel to "god," suggesting that all three terms refer to deities and that Israel was making oaths and promises in the name of pagan gods. The uses of "Samaria" the capital, "Dan" in the north, and "Beersheba" in the south suggest that the "whole circle of gods"50 throughout both Israel and Judah is in view. In other words, the faithlessness of the people was spread throughout the land, and the judgment would be equally comprehensive: all those who swore by foreign gods would "fall, and never rise again." Hopelessness and destruction await the covenant people who have turned away from their heavenly King and have gone after idols their own hands have made.

### *Response*

<span id="page-362-4"></span>As this chapter addresses the hypocritical worship of the merchants in Israel (8:4–6), it calls God's people to true, non-hypocritical worship. Lives that observe

<span id="page-362-2"></span><span id="page-362-1"></span><sup>49</sup> Many psalms were written in response to the silence of God (e.g., Psalms 42; 43; 79; 88; 89 [vv. 38–52]; 90). Although the psalmists were not necessarily experiencing judgment for sin (as in Amos's day), the psalms still convey the agony of life without God's word and presence.

<sup>50</sup> Andersen and Freedman, *Amos*, 830.

<span id="page-363-8"></span><span id="page-363-6"></span>religious rituals and practices but lack godly obedience reveal hearts that are far from the Lord. Jesus said, "Why do you call me 'Lord, Lord,' and not do what I tell you?" (Luke 6:46). Salvation in Christ will manifest itself in obedience to his word. If we love him (John 14:15), we will seek to be honest in work and business (Prov. 11:1); we will be gracious to and protective of the weaker members of society (James 1:27; 2:1–13); we will love one another as Christ has loved us (John 13:34). Actions reveal whether we truly worship the Lord.

<span id="page-363-11"></span><span id="page-363-9"></span><span id="page-363-7"></span><span id="page-363-2"></span><span id="page-363-1"></span><span id="page-363-0"></span>Furthermore, God's vow that he will "never forget" the wicked deeds of unrepentant Israel (Amos 8:7) highlights his character as the righteous Judge of the earth. The apostle Paul writes, "We must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may receive what is due for what he has done in the body, whether good or evil" (2 Cor. 5:10). Such a sober reality should cause a sense of dread to fill those who have "eyes to see and ears to hear." For, "None is righteous, no, not one; no one understands; no one seeks for God. All have turned aside; together they have become worthless; no one does good, not even one" (Rom. 3:10–12). If left in our sin, we are without hope. But in Jesus, there is great hope! For believers, the Lord has promised, "I will forgive their iniquity, and *I will remember their sin no more*" (Jer. 31:34; Heb. 8:12; 10:17). Christ has taken away all of our evil deeds, and the Lord will never again remember them. What a comfort this is! And how deeply this message of mercy is needed in our day. Our world needs the word of Christ (Rom. 10:13–17) so that sinners might repent and believe, before the end comes. In that day, the famine of God's presence and word (Amos 8:11–12) will overwhelm the wicked as they are cast into outer darkness (Matt. 25:30–46)—far away from God and his life-giving word.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-365-7"></span><span id="page-365-5"></span><span id="page-365-4"></span><span id="page-365-3"></span><span id="page-365-2"></span>The last chapter of Amos begins with the fifth and final vision of chapters 7–9. The format of 9:1–4 bears no resemblance to the previous four visions, however, and the passage abruptly begins, "I saw the Lord . . ." (v. 1). It does, nevertheless, convey the certainty of judgment expressed in visions three (7:7–9) and four (8:1–3). In this way, it stands as a final decisive statement that God's wrath will not be abated. The hymn in 9:5–6 presents a magisterial picture of the Lord as the one who rules over creation. This God, whom the prophet has seen in a vision, will "shake" the nation and drive it into oblivion (vv. 7–10). As a final declaration of judgment, the entire passage (vv. 1–10) provides an exclamation point for all of the oracles of doom contained in the book.

<span id="page-365-11"></span><span id="page-365-9"></span><span id="page-365-8"></span><span id="page-365-1"></span>However, this condemnation is not the last word of the book of Amos. Chapter 9 ends on a surprisingly positive and hopeful note. Apart from a brief call to seek the Lord for his favor toward the remnant of Israel (5:14–15), verses 11–15 of chapter 9 furnish the only clear statement of eschatological hope in Amos. The Lord promises to rebuild the "booth of David" (v. 11) and to "restore the fortunes" of his people (v. 14). In view of Amos's dismal message, Israel is reminded that God's favor will not ultimately be removed from them. He will be faithful to his covenant promises—his promises both to curse the people for their unfaithfulness and to redeem them from their sin. Salvation will come to the people of God.

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-365-10"></span><span id="page-365-6"></span>III. Destruction but Hope (7:1–9:15) . . .
	- G. The Lord Standing by the Altar (9:1–10)
	- H. Restoration Promised (9:11–15)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-365-0"></span>9:1–4 In this final vision, Amos sees the Lord (*'adonay*) "beside/on/against the altar," likely referring to the temple in Bethel (cf. 3:14; 4:4; 5:5, 6; 7:10, 13). Amos does not describe the Lord's appearance, but his presence is unmistakable to the prophet.

The altar was the place of worship where the worshiper offered his sacrifice in order to be accepted by God. But this vision reveals that the Lord was present for the purpose of *rejecting* the worshiper, not for accepting him. He commands the "capitals" be struck so that the "thresholds" would "shake." The capitals were the tops of the pillars serving as the main support structure for the building, while the thresholds were cut-stone bases for its doors. This shaking may refer to an earthquake, but the main idea is that from top ("capitals") to bottom ("threshold") the destruction of the temple will be comprehensive. The falling of the building upon the "heads of all the people" signifies a deathblow to the entire congregation. This imagery is reminiscent of Samson's destroying the Philistine temple in Judges 16:29–30. As God's wrath was meted out upon the wicked Philistines in the past, so now his own wicked people will face the same manner of judgment.

<span id="page-366-5"></span><span id="page-366-0"></span>The exhaustive nature of the destruction is further emphasized in Amos 9:1. The Lord will "kill with the sword" any survivors, signifying destruction by a foreign military power. If the destruction of the temple does not get them, the enemy will. Wordplays are present in the Hebrew text at the end of this verse, revealing that no one will escape the judgment. The text in effect says that the one who "flees" will not be able "to flee," nor will "the escapee" be able "to escape."

<span id="page-366-7"></span>Verses 2–4 contain five conditional statements beginning with "if." Each presents possible places where the people could hide from God, before concluding with the inevitability that he will find them in the end. In others words, they can run, but they cannot hide. The first four "if" statements involve a literary device known as *merism*, which describes opposite ends of a spectrum as a way to refer to a comprehensive whole. In this case, the merism reveals that no matter what the people do, God will punish them. They may "dig into Sheol" (i.e., the abode of the dead) or "climb up to heaven" (i.e., the abode of God), but the Lord will gather them from either place (v. 2).

<span id="page-366-9"></span><span id="page-366-8"></span><span id="page-366-6"></span>Instead of hiding in spiritual realms, the people may flee to the remote places of the earth, such as the top of Mount Carmel, or they might hide from God "at the bottom of the sea" (v. 3). Nevertheless, God will capture them from the heights of the earth or instruct "the serpent" (i.e., the beast of the deep) to "bite them" in the abyss of the oceans. In the fifth "if" statement, the Lord states that even in exile, he will "command the sword" to kill his people (v. 4). There is no escape: God's judging presence will overtake them. God declares that he will fix his "eyes upon them for evil and not for good." "Evil" in this verse refers to calamity (not morality), but the contrast with 5:14–15 should not be missed. In chapter 5, the Lord called them to "seek good, and not evil," to "hate evil, and love good." However, since they did not listen to God, he will now show them "evil" and not "good."

<span id="page-366-12"></span><span id="page-366-11"></span><span id="page-366-10"></span><span id="page-366-4"></span><span id="page-366-3"></span><span id="page-366-2"></span><span id="page-366-1"></span>9:5–6 Along with 4:14 and 5:8–9, many scholars believe that 9:5–6 was originally part of an ancient hymn, adapted by Amos for this book. This hymn exalts the Lord as creator and sovereign of the universe, beginning with the familiar picture of God as the Divine Warrior—"the Lord God of hosts." He is the commander of his heavenly armies, and when he comes in conquest, the earth "melts" (or "wavers") natural language to describe the effects of an earthquake (Nah. 1:5)—and its inhabitants "mourn" in response (Amos 1:2; 5:16; 8:8, 10). Earthquake imagery occurs in 9:5 again, as the earth rises and falls like the Nile during flood season. Note this verse's clear connection with 8:8 (cf. comment on 8:7–10).

The God who shakes the earth in judgment is also the Creator who has established "his upper chambers in the heavens" and "his vault upon the earth" (9:6), language that portrays the entire universe as God's heavenly house or palace. This imagery ultimately highlights God's sovereign control over all creation—he even summons the "waters of the sea" and "pours" them upon the earth. This refers to more than his provision of water for the land; the context of judgment suggests a catastrophe like the great flood of Genesis 6–9. The power of the God of hosts over his world is displayed not only in its formation but also in its judgment. Who is this one who does these awesome things? "The Lord is his name" (Amos 9:6; cf. 4:13; 5:8, 27).

<span id="page-367-9"></span><span id="page-367-8"></span><span id="page-367-7"></span><span id="page-367-4"></span><span id="page-367-0"></span>9:7–10 Two rhetorical questions identify Israel with the nations as a way of stating that the Israelites should not expect any special treatment. God first compares them with the "Cushites" (v. 7). Cush refers to Ethiopia and Nubia, south of Egypt and the second cataract of the Nile. Before God, Israel and Cush are alike: because of Israel's sin, they will no longer be treated as his special people. The Lord emphasizes this by revealing that Israel was not the only nation to undergo an exodus from another country: the "Philistines" came out of "Caphtor" (cf. 1:6–8), while the "Syrians" departed from "Kir."51 The Lord thus puts Israel on the same level of these nations.

<span id="page-367-3"></span><span id="page-367-2"></span>These statements perhaps include a further note of warning: since the Lord has already declared judgment on these nations—he will drive the Syrians back to Kir (1:5) and will bring punishment on the Philistines (1:6–8)—Israel can expect the same. While Israel has a special calling, such a calling does not excuse their sin or imply that they are morally superior to foreign nations.

<span id="page-367-10"></span><span id="page-367-6"></span>The interjection "Behold" (9:8) calls the hearers to a frightening reality: the "eyes of the Lord God" (cf. v. 4) gaze upon the "sinful kingdom" of Israel. The phrase "sinful kingdom" occurs only in this verse within the entire OT canon and stands out as a dramatic evaluation of a people who were called to be a "kingdom of priests and a holy nation" (Ex. 19:6). Because of their rejection of this calling, the Lord will destroy the nation from the "face of the ground" (AT). However, there is a small kernel of hope in this verse, anticipating the message of 9:11–15. God will "destroy" Israel, but he "will not utterly destroy the house of Jacob." Despite the inevitable judgment from which no one will escape (vv. 1–4), the covenant faithfulness of God will prevail. The judgment will be comprehensive, but the Lord will preserve Jacob's seed.

<span id="page-367-12"></span><span id="page-367-11"></span><span id="page-367-5"></span>The coming judgment is pictured with agricultural imagery in verse 9. Billy Smith explains:

God's shaking of Israel is compared to one shaking grain in a sieve. The function of the grain sieve was to trap what was undesirable so that it could be thrown away. Undesirable elements would include pebbles, husks, and

<span id="page-367-1"></span><sup>51</sup> See Deuteronomy 2:1–25, which describes how the Lord gave various nations the territories they inhabited.

pieces of stalks. The grain would fall into a container. Just as no pebble would fall to the ground, so thorough would be the screening process of God's judgment that none of the "sinners" (v. 10) would escape. God's judgments sift his people to remove the bad from the good.52

<span id="page-368-0"></span>Furthermore, while the particular judgment in view for Israel is the Assyrian conquest of the northern kingdom, this text may be speaking again of God's judgment against the sin of surrounding peoples (cf. chs. 1–2), as the phrase "among all the nations" could equally be translated "with all the nations."

<span id="page-368-9"></span><span id="page-368-8"></span><span id="page-368-6"></span>Amos 9:10 keeps the focus, however, squarely on Israel and her rebels. The occurrence of "sinners" (*khatta'*) links this verse with the reference in verse 8 to the "sinful (*khatta'*) kingdom." A "sword" is the repeated picture of judgment in this chapter (vv. 1, 4, 10), unifying verses 1–10 and highlighting the military nature of the coming punishment. The "sinners" in this verse refer to the complacent Israelites condemned throughout the book. They have rejected God's word and arrogantly boast, "Disaster shall not overtake or meet us." "Disaster" is the same word translated as "evil" in verse 4. God has declared that "evil/disaster" is coming to them, whether they believe it or not. Their confidence in themselves is drastically misplaced, and they will be overwhelmed in the day of the Lord's visitation. The words of 4:12 echo loudly at this point: "Prepare to meet your God, O Israel!"

<span id="page-368-12"></span><span id="page-368-10"></span><span id="page-368-7"></span><span id="page-368-4"></span><span id="page-368-2"></span>9:11–12 The closing passage of the book (vv. 11–15) presents a positive picture of a future day of the Lord that will follow Israel's judgment. Verses 11 and 13 begin "In that day" and "Behold, the days are coming," respectively. This is in sharp contrast to the judgment declared in 8:11 ("Behold, the days are coming") and 8:13 ("In that day"). As mentioned earlier, the "day of the Lord" motif in Scripture is employed negatively for punishment and positively for salvation, depending on the context (cf. comment on 5:18–20). So far, the day of the Lord in Amos has been largely unfavorable. But according to this final text, the day will also reveal God's mercy.

<span id="page-368-5"></span><span id="page-368-3"></span><span id="page-368-1"></span>At that undisclosed time, God promises to do several things (note the firstperson verbs in 9:11–15). He will "raise up" the fallen "booth of David" (v. 11). Even though Jerusalem has not yet been conquered by the Babylonians (587/586 BC), the Davidic monarchy is on the decline, and God has already declared his judgment against Judah (2:4–5). Thus this passage looks beyond the immediate historical context to a time of future restoration. Its messianic nature is clear: the Davidic promise will be fulfilled as the Lord raises up the "booth of David" in order to "repair its breaches, and raise up its ruins and rebuild it as in the days of old." This restoration will involve the inclusion of the Gentiles into Israel. Thus the "remnant of Edom" is representative of "all the nations" (they are parallel to one another here), and to be "called by" God's name "implies God's ownership of the unnamed nations and their submission to him (cf. Mal. 1:11)."53 This grand restoration is the act of the Lord himself ("declares the Lord who does this"; Amos 9:12).

<span id="page-368-13"></span><span id="page-368-11"></span><sup>52</sup> Smith and Page, *Amos, Obadiah, Jonah*, 162.

<span id="page-369-9"></span><span id="page-369-8"></span>That this passage refers to the inclusion of the nations in the people of God is made clear in Acts 15. At the so-called Jerusalem Council, James quotes Amos 9:11–12 to validate God's intention to save the Gentiles (Acts 15:13–17). While he quotes from the Septuagint, which is slightly different from the Hebrew, in either version the passage indicates that God has purposed to include the Gentiles among his chosen people through the work of the Messiah. James sees the gospel's spreading to the nations as (at least partial) fulfillment of the prophecy of Amos.

<span id="page-369-5"></span><span id="page-369-4"></span>9:13–15 The hope of Israel's future restoration is further described using agricultural imagery to convey an overabundance of blessings awaiting God's future people. The first two images of verse 13 picture an overlapping of seedtime and harvest. In the first image, the one who plows the ground in order to sow seed ends up overtaking "the reaper" (v. 13), who is not yet done collecting the harvest from the previous season. In ancient Israel the time between harvest and planting was about six months, so this implies that the harvest will be so great that there will not be enough time during those months to bring in all the fruit!

The second image reveals something similar: "The treader of grapes [shall overtake] him who sows the seed." The vineyards will be so fertile that the grapes will be ready to be made into wine before the sower has even finished planting the new seed. The third image displays the outcome of this abundance: the bounty of "sweet wine" will be known throughout the land as "the mountains shall drip" and "the hills shall flow" with such wine. This earthy depiction communicates a glorious reality: there will be no more curses for Israel—only the eternal blessings of God.

<span id="page-369-6"></span><span id="page-369-0"></span>The Lord himself will restore Israel's "fortunes," and her "cities" will be rebuilt (v. 14). Their peaceful existence is pictured in their being able to "plant vineyards" and "gardens" and in their drinking "their wine" and eating "their fruit." This abundance and tranquility communicates an Eden-like redemption (Genesis 2). As Stuart notes, "A basic enjoyment of the fruit of one's labor is a favorite prophetic way to express the serenity of the restoration (e.g., Isa. 37:30; 65:21–22; Jer. 29:5, 28; Ezek. 34:27; 36:10, 33; Zech. 8:12)."54

<span id="page-369-7"></span><span id="page-369-2"></span><span id="page-369-1"></span>Notably, there will be harmony between God and his people, with no risk of being exiled from the inheritance: the Lord "will plant them on their land" (Amos 9:15). This promise implies that the land of Canaan is in view, but the expression "their land" likely "indicates the ground itself."55 In other words, the focus is that each member of God's people will again have an allotment of land/ground on which to plant his vineyards and gardens. To be never again uprooted from the "land/ground" indicates a future reversal of 5:2 ("Fallen, no more to rise, is the virgin Israel; forsaken on her land, with none to raise her up"). As Stuart states, "They will no longer be sojourners but landed citizens, deeply rooted in the place God has given them."56 In this way, the exaltation of the Lord's covenantal faithfulness

<span id="page-369-3"></span><sup>54</sup> Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah*, 399.

<sup>55</sup> Ibid.

<sup>56</sup> Ibid., 414.

<span id="page-370-9"></span>concludes the book. He who has promised is faithful (Heb. 10:23), even when his people are not.

### *Response*

<span id="page-370-7"></span><span id="page-370-4"></span><span id="page-370-1"></span>Partial fulfillment of the promise of restoration in Amos 9 was realized in the return of exiles from Babylon thanks to the decree of Cyrus in 538 BC. Further fulfillment came with the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ as David's greater Son (Acts 15:1–21). The consummation of this promised restoration will be seen in the eschatological new heavens and new earth (Isa. 65:17–25; 66:22–23; Revelation 21–22). *In that day*, God's people (both Jew and Gentile) will inherit their new "land/ground" as the new Jerusalem descends to earth (Rev. 21:1–2). The throne of God and of the Lamb (i.e., the Son of David) will be in the midst of the city, and there will be abundance and complete peace (Rev. 21:1–4; 22:1–5).

<span id="page-370-12"></span><span id="page-370-11"></span><span id="page-370-10"></span><span id="page-370-8"></span>The person and work of Jesus Christ has procured this everlasting salvation for God's people, for all who are united to Christ by faith are "Abraham's offspring, heirs according to promise" (Gal. 3:29). In this way, the glorious gospel of Jesus Christ was wonderfully promised beforehand through the mouth of a sheepherding, tree-tending prophet named Amos.

<span id="page-370-3"></span>Oracle after oracle of the coming judgment prepares us for the amazing grace of the merciful and loving God declared at the end of the book. Without a clear understanding of humanity's wickedness and rebellion, we will not appreciate or sense our dire condition. Nor will we have the impetus that drives us to Christ in repentance. Hence the book of Amos condemns sinners but also promises salvation to God's remnant—all who seek him will live (5:4, 6, 14). A contemporary of Amos declared, "Seek the Lord while he may be found; call upon him while he is near; let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts; let him return to the Lord, that he may have compassion on him, and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon" (Isa. 55:6–7). The Lord does not delight in the destruction of the wicked (Ezek. 18:23, 32); instead he offers mercy to all who will receive it.

<span id="page-370-6"></span><span id="page-370-5"></span><span id="page-370-2"></span><span id="page-370-0"></span>What is even more amazing is that the Lord himself has come in the person Jesus Christ to actively seek after sinners: "The Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost" (Luke 19:10). The beauty of our Savior reveals the immeasurable love of the God of Israel: "God so loved the world, that he gave his only Son, that whoever believes in him should not perish but have eternal life" (John 3:16). This Savior is worthy of our love, worship, and obedience all the days of our lives. Therefore, let us love Jesus Christ and live for him, looking forward to the *great and final day of the Lord*, upon which we will be forever with him in the new earth!

# OBADIAH

*Max Rogland*

## INTRODUCTION TO OBADIAH

## *Overview*

<span id="page-373-9"></span><span id="page-373-8"></span><span id="page-373-7"></span><span id="page-373-6"></span><span id="page-373-3"></span>The book of Obadiah is chiefly a prophecy of judgment against Edom (e.g., vv. 4–9, 16–18), although at points this judgment is extended to non-Edomite territories surrounding Judea (vv. 19–20). Indeed, the book looks ahead ultimately to the "day of the Lord" of judgment upon "all nations" (vv. 15–16). The Edomites are singled out because of their harsh treatment of Judah, their "brother" (v. 10), in aiding an invading force that ransacked Jerusalem (vv. 10–14). Edom will be repaid for their deeds and will be utterly wiped out (vv. 8–9, 18–19). Yet the book's message does not entirely concern punishment; Obadiah also prophesies salvation for Judah (vv. 17, 21), the reclaiming of her ancestral land (vv. 19–20), and the emergence of rulers over the Edomites under the kingship of the Lord (v. 21).

## <span id="page-373-10"></span><span id="page-373-5"></span>*Title*

<span id="page-373-4"></span><span id="page-373-0"></span>The book is the "vision" (*khazon*) of Obadiah (v. 1), indicating that Obadiah was the recipient of a dream or vision, as is typical of prophetic revelation (Num. 12:6–8).

## *Author*

<span id="page-373-1"></span>Apart from the name "Obadiah," which means "servant of Yah[weh]," nothing is known about the author. Some ancient and modern interpreters argue this is the same Obadiah who served King Ahab (1 Kings 18).1 There is no evidence for such an identification, however, and the probable dating of the book after the fall of Jerusalem makes this unlikely—Obadiah was a common name in both biblical texts and extrabiblical inscriptions. The interpretation of Obadiah's message does not depend on biographical details of the prophet's life.

## *Date, Occasion, and Historical Background*

The identity of the invading enemy assisted by Edom is not explicitly stated, but it is most likely the Babylonians, who sacked Jerusalem in 586 BC. There is little evidence to link Edomite activity with earlier incursions by, e.g., the Assyrians, whereas their association with Babylon is attested elsewhere (e.g., Ps. 137:7–8;

<span id="page-373-2"></span><sup>1</sup> See Babylonian Talmud, Sanhedrin 39b; also Ehud Ben Zvi, *A Historical-Critical Study of the Book of Obadiah*, BZAW 242 (Berlin/New York: Walter de Gruyter, 1996), 17.

<span id="page-374-16"></span>Ezek. 25:12; 35:5; cf. Lam. 4:21–22). Edom initially sent envoys to a possible international coalition resisting the growing Babylonian threat, but perhaps they were dissuaded by Jeremiah's warnings (Jer. 27:1–11).

<span id="page-374-14"></span><span id="page-374-2"></span>An understanding of the origin of Edom and the history of Edomite-Israelite relations is essential for appreciating Obadiah's message. The nations of Edom and Israel were descended from Isaac's twin sons, Esau and Jacob, whose relationship as brothers was frequently tense (Gen. 27:32). While still in the womb it was prophesied that the "older shall serve the younger" (25:23), and so it played out: Jacob, the younger, received the firstborn's birthright and blessing instead of Esau (25:29–34; 27:27–29).

<span id="page-374-7"></span><span id="page-374-6"></span><span id="page-374-5"></span><span id="page-374-4"></span><span id="page-374-3"></span><span id="page-374-1"></span><span id="page-374-0"></span>Two nations emerged from the descendants of Esau and Jacob (Genesis 36; Exodus 1), and the ancient oracle that the "older will serve the younger" was confirmed by the oracles of the mysterious seer Balaam, who foretold Israel's dominance over Edom (Num. 24:18–19). Nevertheless, the Lord assigned a small mountainous territory southeast of Judah to Esau's descendants as their inheritance. When the Israelites were refused passage through Edom (Num. 20:14–21), God made it clear that Israel was not to contend with them (Deut. 2:1–8). Over time, the ancient prophecies found further fulfillment as Israel gained political and military dominance over Edom (1 Sam. 14:47; 2 Sam. 8:11–14; 1 Chron. 18:11), placing a vassal king on their throne (1 Kings 22:47). Despite the injunctions of Deuteronomy, the Israelites' treatment of Edom was harsh at times (1 Kings 11:15; 2 Chron. 25:12). Eventually, Edom revolted and crowned its own king (2 Kings 8:20; 2 Chron. 21:8–10), although Tiglath-pileser III (r. 745–727 BC) later made Edom a vassal state of Assyria.

<span id="page-374-12"></span><span id="page-374-11"></span><span id="page-374-10"></span><span id="page-374-9"></span><span id="page-374-8"></span>Given this historical backdrop, one can readily imagine the ill will harbored by the Edomites toward their "younger brothers," the Judeans. When enemy forces invaded and ransacked Jerusalem, the Edomites were only too glad to be of assistance, whether by participating in the destruction or by assisting the Babylonians (cf. comment on Obad. 10–11). Thus they profited from Judah's misfortune, and the Lord condemned them strongly for their actions (e.g., vv. 12–14).

## <span id="page-374-21"></span><span id="page-374-20"></span>*Genre and Literary Structure*

<span id="page-374-18"></span><span id="page-374-15"></span><span id="page-374-13"></span>As noted above (Introduction: Title), the book is the record of a "vision," a title also given to other Prophetic Books (e.g., Isa. 1:1; Nah. 1:1). In basic form and content Obadiah is much like other prophetic oracles, proclaiming judgment against foreign nations and salvation for the people of God (e.g., Jeremiah 46–51; Amos 1–2). Certain poetic devices such as parallelism (Obad. 3), repetition (vv. 4–5, 12–14), verb-gapping (v. 8), and wordplay (*'edom* [vv. 1, 8] vs. *'edam* [v. 13]) are utilized sporadically. On the whole, however, the book exhibits a limited use of Hebrew poetic techniques and does not seem to be a clear example of biblical poetry. It is more accurately characterized as "heightened . . . rhetoric" or "impassioned speech."2

<span id="page-374-22"></span><span id="page-374-19"></span><span id="page-374-17"></span><sup>2</sup> Daniel I. Block, *Obadiah: The Kingship Belongs to YHWH* (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 2013), 35–37.

<span id="page-375-5"></span><span id="page-375-4"></span>The significant overlap between Obadiah and the oracle against Edom in Jeremiah 49:7–22 (cf. Obad. 1–4 with Jer. 49:14–16; Obad. 5–6 with Jer. 49:9–10; Obad. 8 with Jer. 49:7) raises the possibility that one prophet borrowed from the other or that both prophets drew upon a third (currently unknown) source. Arguments can be made for each of these positions, but a conclusive answer is difficult to determine. On the whole, it is prudent simply to interpret the message of Obadiah on its own terms.

### *Theology of Obadiah; Its Relationship to the Rest of the Bible and to Christ*

The basic theme of the book is clear: "Edom—and the nations—will be judged, and through that judgment Israel will be saved, while Yahweh is glorified for his justice and mercy."3 A number of more specific motifs can also be seen.

#### ZION THEOLOGY

<span id="page-375-3"></span>Much has been written about the "Zion theology" of the OT. "Zion," referring to a hill or ridge in Jerusalem, came to be used for the temple complex located on this "holy mount" (Ps. 87:1) and, by further extension, to the holy city of Jerusalem more broadly. "Zion theology" represents several intertwining themes: the selection of Zion/Jerusalem as the Lord's earthly abode (Pss. 78:68; 132:13) in conjunction with his victory over the nations (Psalms 46; 48; 76), and Jerusalem's association with an eternal Davidic dynasty (2 Samuel 7; Ps. 2:6).

<span id="page-375-7"></span><span id="page-375-6"></span><span id="page-375-2"></span><span id="page-375-1"></span><span id="page-375-0"></span>There is no mention of the Davidic dynasty in Obadiah; indeed, the book presents Judah as having returned to the pre-monarchical era of the judges (cf. comment on Obad. 21). Nevertheless, the exaltation of Mount Zion (vv. 16, 17, 21) over "Mount Esau" (vv. 8, 9, 19, 21; cf. vv. 3–4) is emphatic. Despite the sacrilegious treatment it has received, Zion remains central to God's redemptive plan (v. 17) and will be restored.

#### ESAU IN BIBLICAL PERSPECTIVE

The troubled nature of Edomite-Israelite relations and Israel's favored status were not merely historical accidents but reflected the eternal decrees of the Lord. Indeed, the choice of Jacob over Esau is presented as conclusive proof of the Lord's sovereignty in election, taking place either before birth or before one has done anything to deserve one's fate (cf. Rom. 9:10–16; also Mal. 1:1–4).

<span id="page-375-8"></span>As profound as this biblical theme is, Obadiah's prophecy of the destruction of Edom was fulfilled in a surprising way. The Nabonidus Chronicle (1.17) attests that in 553 BC Edom fell to the Babylonians, but while this undoubtedly was a partial fulfillment of Obadiah's oracle, Edom continued for some time after that defeat. Arab peoples encroached upon Edom from the fifth to third centuries BC, causing Edom to shift westward into the Negeb of Judea. Their territory came to be known as "Idumea" and its residents as "Idumeans." Under the leadership of John Hyrcanus (134–104 BC), the Idumeans were subjugated and compelled to

<sup>3</sup> James M. Hamilton, Jr., *God's Glory in Salvation through Judgment: A Biblical Theology* (Wheaton, IL: Crossway, 2010), 246.

receive Jewish circumcision (Josephus, *Antiquities* 13.257). As a result, over time they began to be absorbed into the Jewish nation, losing their distinct ethnic identity. In a surprising twist of God's providence, it was precisely that loss that proved to be the salvation for some: by losing their identity as "Edomites/Idumeans" and being incorporated into the covenant community, some had the opportunity to encounter Jesus the Savior and follow him during his earthly ministry (Mark 3:7–8). In a remarkable but unexpected way, Obadiah's prophecy of deliverance on Mount Zion (Obad. 17) came to pass.

### <span id="page-376-7"></span><span id="page-376-4"></span>THE DAY OF THE LORD

<span id="page-376-1"></span><span id="page-376-0"></span>It is evident that "day" (*yom*) functions as a key word in Obadiah (vv. 8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15), with the "day of the Lord" (v. 15) being the culmination of the theme. This rich and multifaceted concept, found throughout the OT prophets, is intimately connected with the consummation of God's redemptive plan. Willem VanGemeren says, "The goal of the Day of the Lord is the total transformation of all creation."4 He continues,

The Day of the Lord (*yôm Yahweh*) is the era in which the Lord judges, purifies a remnant for himself, avenges his name, vindicates his people, renews his creation, brings in the full deliverance, and establishes his rule on earth. . . . Thus, the Day of the Lord was a framework for interpreting history, for understanding the present under divine control, and also for projecting a final day of reckoning (the eschatological Day of the Lord). . . . The Day of the Lord is past, present, and future.5

While the "day of the Lord" is an eschatological reality, Obadiah and the other prophets indicate that intrusions of this day may occur even in the present age (cf. comment on v. 15a).

<span id="page-376-11"></span><span id="page-376-10"></span><span id="page-376-8"></span><span id="page-376-2"></span>The concept of the "day of the Lord" is further developed by NT references to the "day of Jesus Christ" (e.g., Phil. 1:6; cf. Mark 13:32; Luke 17:31; 1 Thess. 5:4; 2 Thess. 1:10; 2:3). All of history finds its ultimate "goal" (*telos*) in Christ. As the Alpha and Omega (Rev. 1:8; 21:6; 22:13), Jesus will usher in the consummation of God's plan of redemption. With respect to the book of Obadiah, it emerges that the universal judgment to take place on the "day of the Lord" (Obad. 15–16) will be carried out by Jesus Christ himself (Matt. 7:22; Luke 10:12; Acts 10:42; Rom. 2:16; 2 Tim. 1:12, 18; 4:1, 8).

## <span id="page-376-9"></span><span id="page-376-6"></span><span id="page-376-3"></span>THE KINGSHIP OF THE LORD

<span id="page-376-5"></span>Obadiah exalts the kingship (*melukah*; v. 21) of God, which refers ultimately to Christ, who was "determined to be the Son of God in power . . . by his resurrection from the dead" (Rom. 1:4 AT). Obadiah 21 indicates that kingship will belong to the Lord, even as human "saviors" (*moshiʻim*) arise to rule over Edom. All leadership roles

<sup>4</sup> Willem A. VanGemeren, *Interpreting the Prophetic Word: An Introduction to the Prophetic Literature of the Old Testament* (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 1990), 220. 5 Ibid., 222.

<span id="page-377-2"></span><span id="page-377-1"></span>among God's people (e.g., 1 Tim. 3:1–16) are ultimately subordinate to Christ himself, who ascended in triumph and "gave the apostles, the prophets, the evangelists, the shepherds and teachers" for the building of the church (Eph. 4:7–14, esp. v. 11).

## *Outline*

Obadiah has proved difficult to outline since it exhibits few formal markers of literary structure (e.g., prophetic formulas), and its sections seem to overlap. The following bipartite outline is based primarily on the book's content rather than on particular literary or discourse features.

- I. The Day of Judgment for Edom (vv. 1–14)
	- A. Superscription (v. 1a) and Summons to Battle (v. 1b)
	- B. Edom's Pride despite Its Humble Circumstances (vv. 2–3)
	- C. Edom to Be Destroyed (vv. 4–9)
	- D. Edom's Crimes against Judah (vv. 10–14)
- II. The Day of the Lord (vv. 15–21)
	- A. Judgment upon All Nations (vv. 15–16)
	- B. Deliverance on Mount Zion (v. 17a)
	- C. Restoration of the People of God and a "New Conquest" (vv. 17b–20)
	- D. The Rule of "Saviors" under the Kingship of the Lord (v. 21)

## *Section Overview*

The main focus of verses 1–14 is Edom: despite their relationship as "brothers" to the people of Judah, they failed to treat Judah with the basic respect and kindness due a family member. On the contrary, they committed serious crimes against the Judeans by supporting the Babylonian sack of Jerusalem in 586 BC. Accordingly, God pronounces judgment on them.

## *Section Outline*

- I. The Day of Judgment for Edom (vv. 1–14)
	- A. Superscription (v. 1a) and Summons to Battle (v. 1b)
	- B. Edom's Pride Despite Its Humble Circumstances (vv. 2–3)
	- C. Edom to Be Destroyed (vv. 4–9)
	- D. Edom's Crimes against Judah (vv. 10–14)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-379-2"></span>1a Obadiah receives a "vision," a common medium of prophetic revelation (cf. Introduction: Title). Though some maintain the oracle is addressed "to" Edom, the ESV correctly understands it as "concerning" them.

<span id="page-379-11"></span><span id="page-379-3"></span>1b In his vision the prophet hears an envoy bringing a message from the Lord, summoning the hearers to rise up for battle. Ultimately, the judgment to come upon Edom is the Lord's doing, even though the nations—including Judah—play a role in carrying it out (cf. vv. 7, 18). The nations' involvement does not imply the Lord's approval of their ways, and later judgment will be announced upon them as well (vv. 15–16).

<span id="page-379-13"></span><span id="page-379-5"></span><span id="page-379-4"></span>2–3 These verses address Edom's current circumstances and prideful attitude. Verse 2 does not refer to a future humbling but rather utilizes a Hebrew past tense verb (*netattika*) to indicate the modest status the Lord decreed for Edom (cf. ESV mg.). The Lord had assigned a particular territory to Edom as its heritage (Deut. 2:4–5), one of modest size and significance. Rather than being grateful for the Lord's provision, however, the Edomites grew proud in their mountainous dwelling and felt virtually unassailable (Obad. 3).

<span id="page-379-7"></span><span id="page-379-6"></span><span id="page-379-0"></span>4 Despite the Edomites' lofty strongholds, the Lord promises to "bring [them] down," the very thing they claim is impossible (v. 3).

<span id="page-379-12"></span><span id="page-379-10"></span><span id="page-379-9"></span><span id="page-379-8"></span><span id="page-379-1"></span>5–7 Here the prophet narrates the utter destruction of Edom as seen in his "vision" (v. 1). For this reason he speaks of it as an event already completed, even though other verses make clear the judgment is yet to come (e.g., vv. 4, 8–10, 18–19, 21). The vision depicts complete devastation: in contrast to common thieves or plunderers, who take valuable items but leave other things behind (v. 5), the Lord will cause Edom to be pillaged totally (v. 6). Surprisingly, much of the destruction comes at the hand of Edom's own "allies" (lit., "the men of your covenant"), who laid a trap for Edom even while they were "at peace" and shared meals with them (v. 7). As noted above (Introduction: Theology of Obadiah: Esau in Biblical Perspective), in

<span id="page-380-0"></span>553 BC Babylon attacked Edom, their former partners in crime. Covenant partners or allies could be called "brothers" (e.g., 1 Kings 20:32–34), and hence Babylon's treachery is poetic justice for Edom, who likewise betrayed his "brother" Judah. As Obadiah 15 remarks, one's deeds return on one's own head.

<span id="page-380-20"></span><span id="page-380-7"></span><span id="page-380-6"></span><span id="page-380-5"></span><span id="page-380-2"></span>8–9 In verses 8–9 the Lord promises the destruction of particular causes of Edomite pride, specifically their "wise men" and their "mighty men." Many scholars have posited an established Edomite wisdom tradition, attested not only in verse 8 and Jeremiah 49:7 but also in Job, which displays a number of Edomite associations (e.g., Job is identified as Idumean in the LXX expansion of Job 42:17). Thus, in addition to the physical advantages of their mountain strongholds, the Edomites had sufficient intellectual prowess and military might for survival. Nevertheless, the Lord will destroy these things, and "every man from Mount Esau will be cut off by slaughter" (Obad. 9). The complete destruction of the Edomite nation is thus foretold (cf. v. 18).

<span id="page-380-21"></span><span id="page-380-12"></span><span id="page-380-11"></span><span id="page-380-8"></span>10–11 In verses 10–14 the oracle begins to give the reasons for Edom's punishment. This had previously been left unexplained in the text, though undoubtedly the original audience would have already known the basic reasons.

<span id="page-380-13"></span><span id="page-380-9"></span>The section begins by laying the charge of "violence" against Edom: it was complicit in acts of violence against Judah (v. 10a). This may have consisted of passive support of the Babylonian invasion or active participation in its brutality. The latter option seems more likely: while verse 11 faults Edom for standing "aloof" as strangers invaded Jerusalem, it goes on to say they were "like one" (*ke'akhad* ) of the Babylonians, implying a close association. In fact, the term translated "aloof" (*minneged* ) could possibly indicate the Edomite forces stood "opposite" the Babylonians, lined up in battle formation. Their deeds were inexcusable, in any event, and Edom will experience shame and destruction as a result (v. 10b).

<span id="page-380-22"></span><span id="page-380-19"></span><span id="page-380-18"></span><span id="page-380-17"></span><span id="page-380-16"></span><span id="page-380-15"></span><span id="page-380-14"></span><span id="page-380-10"></span><span id="page-380-4"></span><span id="page-380-3"></span><span id="page-380-1"></span>12–14 In verses 12–14 the oracle presents Edom with a series of prohibitions as a creative rhetorical device for enumerating further charges against Edom. First, they are not to "gloat" or "rejoice" over Judah's misfortune (vv. 12, 13b). The Lord tells his people not to rejoice over an enemy's downfall (Prov. 17:5; 24:17; cf. Job 31:29); how much more will he be displeased when Judah's foes delight in the calamities that have overtaken his own people (cf. Mic. 7:8). Second, Edom must not "enter the gate" of God's people (Obad. 13a)—undoubtedly Jerusalem—to loot and plunder (v. 13c), which would defy the many biblical prohibitions against seeking "unjust gain" by violent means (e.g., Prov. 1:10–19). These wicked deeds are dramatically compounded when committed against the holy city founded on Mount Zion, and the Lord cannot let such sacrilegious acts go unpunished. Third, the prohibitions charge Edom with acts of violence against Judeans escaping the Babylonian invaders, cutting them down as they fled (Obad. 14a) or capturing and handing them over to the Babylonians (v. 14b).

## *Response*

<span id="page-381-1"></span>This first section of Obadiah invites response on several levels. On one level, it can be taken as a warning not to commit the same crimes as Edom, such as gloating over the downfall of others, taking advantage of others' misfortune, and so on, which are forbidden by God's Word (cf. comment on vv. 12–14). Even though the Babylonian invasion and resulting exile were the climactic judgment of God on his people's persistent sin (Deut. 28:25–64), Obadiah does not directly address Judah's behavior. The book's spotlight falls squarely on Edom's sin and punishment. Any application for God's people must therefore be drawn from the text's implications.

<span id="page-381-4"></span><span id="page-381-3"></span><span id="page-381-0"></span>The post-resurrection church is "transformed Israel" (Rom. 9:6–8; Gal. 6:16); to put it another way, the people of God in the OT era were God's "church" and had been given the gospel (Heb. 4:2), just like the church of the NT era. While the progress of redemptive history has brought much light to the specifics of God's plan, and has therefore clarified some of the church's priorities (e.g., international mission) and altered some of her practices (e.g., not imposing ceremonial or civil laws distinctive to Israel upon Gentiles), there is a fundamental continuity between the two Testaments. Therefore, the church today can take instruction from Obadiah's message.

<span id="page-381-2"></span>First, while the church should expect persecution (John 15:18–20), Obadiah prepares her to be unsurprised when she is betrayed and persecuted by her "brothers"—entities seemingly closely allied with her. There have been any number of nations, institutions, civic organizations, and political parties that seemed closely aligned with the church's values only to depart from them and then to promote a moral agenda at odds with biblical Christianity. Some organizations, e.g., have swung from espousing a general Judeo-Christian ethic to undermining a biblical understanding of marriage. Similarly, many European countries had or still have an official state church possessing, at least formally, a Christian basis. Yet currently that association has little effect on political decisions made, and many such decisions run counter to the way of Christ. Obadiah prepares Christians for such realities so that they will not be surprised or capitulate to despair when such disappointments happen.

Second, as John Calvin aptly observes in the preface to his commentary on Obadiah, the book "threatens the Idumeans for the sake of administering consolation to the chosen people." The church can be assured that, however much she is made to suffer by her enemies, she will never be completely abandoned. The Lord will bring judgment on those who mistreat the church, the bride of Christ. This applies equally to those who perpetrate physical violence on God's people and those who seek to harass the church by nonviolent means.

## <span id="page-382-1"></span>OBADIAH 15–21

- **<sup>15</sup>** For the day of the Lord is near upon all the nations. As you have done, it shall be done to you; your deeds shall return on your own head.
- **<sup>16</sup>** For as you have drunk on my holy mountain, so all the nations shall drink continually; they shall drink and swallow, and shall be as though they had never been.
- **<sup>17</sup>** But in Mount Zion there shall be those who escape, and it shall be holy,
- and the house of Jacob shall possess their own possessions.
- **<sup>18</sup>** The house of Jacob shall be a fire, and the house of Joseph a flame, and the house of Esau stubble; they shall burn them and consume them, and there shall be no survivor for the house of Esau, for the Lord has spoken.
- **<sup>19</sup>** Those of the Negeb shall possess Mount Esau, and those of the Shephelah shall possess the land of the Philistines; they shall possess the land of Ephraim and the land of Samaria, and Benjamin shall possess Gilead.
- **<sup>20</sup>** The exiles of this host of the people of Israel shall possess the land of the Canaanites as far as Zarephath, and the exiles of Jerusalem who are in Sepharad shall possess the cities of the Negeb.
- **<sup>21</sup>** Saviors shall go up to Mount Zion to rule Mount Esau, and the kingdom shall be the Lord's.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-382-2"></span><span id="page-382-0"></span>In verses 15–21 the prophet's focus expands from Edom's day of punishment to judgment on all nations on the "day of the Lord." On that day, the Lord will repay evildoers according to their deeds (vv. 15–16). At the same time, he will provide a means of salvation for his people (v. 17a–b). Moreover, they will experience restoration from their weak and dispersed state (vv. 17c–20), led by deliverers under the kingship of the Lord (v. 21).

## <span id="page-382-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- II. The Day of the Lord (vv. 15–21)
	- A. Judgment upon All Nations (vv. 15–16)
- B. Deliverance on Mount Zion (v. 17a)
- C. Restoration of the People of God and a "New Conquest" (vv. 17b–20)
- <span id="page-383-7"></span>D. The Rule of "Saviors" under the Kingship of the Lord (v. 21)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-383-3"></span>15a The prophet continues to address Edom while broadening his gaze to declare, "The day of the Lord is near upon all the nations." The punishment of Edom in verses 1–14 is thus part of a larger cataclysm of judgment. This immediately raises questions concerning the oracle's fulfillment, since Edom's judgment began within roughly one generation (cf. Introduction: Theology of Obadiah: Esau in Biblical Perspective), while the day of retribution for all nations has not yet arrived. To make sense of this, one must appreciate the common phenomenon of "prophetic foreshortening" or "telescoping": in prophetic visions, future events are often compressed (or "telescoped") together and thus appear to take place simultaneously, even though in reality they may be separated in time. In Obadiah's vision, it *appears* that Edom's judgment occurs when the "day of the Lord" brings wrath upon all nations because the events have been telescoped together. A complementary perspective would be to say that Edom's "day" of judgment is a preview or intrusion of the final "day of the Lord." In either case, Edom's judgment in verses 1–14 and verses 18–19, 21 has been fulfilled, while the universal judgment of verses 15–16 still awaits fulfillment.

<span id="page-383-9"></span><span id="page-383-6"></span><span id="page-383-1"></span>In what sense would the original readers have understood the day to be "near"? The OT and NT make clear that what human beings consider "near" need not be the same for God, for whom a "thousand years" are "as a watch in the night" (Ps. 90:4; cf. 2 Pet. 3:8–9). A great deal of misguided speculation on the "end times" would be avoided by paying heed to this straightforward biblical theme. Moreover, it should also be noted that the term "near" (*qarob*) quite often expresses physical rather than temporal proximity. Obadiah 15a communicates that judgment is nigh, looming over the nations, without implying it will occur in the span of a few years or even decades. One can compare the NT's assertions that God's kingdom "is at hand" or "has drawn near" (Gk. *ēngiken*; Matt. 3:2; 4:17; 10:7; Mark 1:15). As VanGemeren says, "The Day of the Lord overshadows all human history and hence is always near."6

<span id="page-383-8"></span><span id="page-383-5"></span><span id="page-383-4"></span><span id="page-383-2"></span><span id="page-383-0"></span>15b The Lord promises to repay evildoers according to their deeds ("As you have done"). Similar expressions occur throughout the OT (e.g., 1 Kings 2:32; Jer. 50:29; Ezek. 16:43) and indicate true justice will be served; the punishment will fit the crime.

16 Edom celebrated its triumph over Judah by drinking and carousing on Mount Zion. While the victory tasted sweet at first, the aftertaste will be bitter, as the Lord promises to force all nations (including Edom) to drink the cup of his wrath to its <span id="page-384-8"></span>dregs and suffer complete destruction. For the image of the ungodly drinking the cup of God's wrath, cf. Jeremiah 25:15–29 and Revelation 14:10.

17a All nations will be judged on the day of the Lord, yet there is hope for deliverance on Mount Zion, the mountain on which the temple was built. Zion represented the heart of the covenant community as the location of God's special presence (cf. Introduction: Theology of Obadiah: Zion Theology). Salvation will be available to all who align themselves with the people of God by turning to him. Mount Zion's being "holy" (*qodesh*) implies the restoration and renewal of the house of God, which had been defiled by the Babylonians, with Edom's assistance.

<span id="page-384-12"></span><span id="page-384-11"></span><span id="page-384-10"></span>17b–20 The Lord's work of redemption begins on a restored Mount Zion (v. 17a–b) and spreads outward from there. This expansion is signaled when the prophet declares that the house of Jacob "shall possess their own possessions" (v. 17b). God's people will reclaim the land promised to the patriarchs but conquered by foreign powers. The houses of Jacob and Joseph will execute judgment upon Edom, leaving no survivors (v. 18). As several scholars have pointed out, passages such as Psalm 77:15; Ezekiel 37:16; Amos 5:6; and Zechariah 10:6 indicate that "house of Joseph" most likely represents the northern tribes, among whom the descendants of Joseph (Ephraim and Manasseh) played a leading role. Thus the references to "house of Jacob" and "house of Joseph" in Obadiah 18 indicate a reunited people of God, as envisioned by other prophets (e.g., Ezek. 37:15–17).

<span id="page-384-14"></span><span id="page-384-13"></span><span id="page-384-9"></span><span id="page-384-7"></span>With the restoration of Zion, the reunion of the twelve tribes, and the destruction of Edom comes a "new conquest" of the Promised Land in Obadiah 19–20. The residents of the southern region of the Negeb and of the foothills of the Shephelah and centrally located Benjamin will reconquer surrounding territories. The participants in this new conquest will include even more far-flung exiles, such as those in "Sepharad" (v. 20). Much modern scholarship understands this to be in western Turkey, though ancient Jewish tradition (the Aramaic Targum; cf. the Vulgate) identified it as Spain.

<span id="page-384-15"></span><span id="page-384-6"></span><span id="page-384-5"></span><span id="page-384-4"></span><span id="page-384-3"></span><span id="page-384-2"></span><span id="page-384-1"></span><span id="page-384-0"></span>21 The prophet mentions the leaders of this new conquest—"deliverers" or "saviors" (*moshiʻim*)—who will ascend Mount Zion to "rule" (lit., "judge") Edom. The terminology of this verse, as well as the conquests of verses 19–20, intentionally evoke the book of Judges, where the Lord raised up "saviors" (Judg. 3:9, 15) to "judge" (*shpt*; Judg. 3:10; 4:4; 10:2–3; 12:7–14; 16:31) and deliver his people from enemies such as the Philistines (Judg. 3:31; 13:1, 5, etc.) and the Canaanites (Judg. 1:1, 3–5, 9–10, etc.). A point emphasized in the book of Judges, however, is that the "saviors" were only a temporary solution. The Israelites' troubles were in part because "there was no king in Israel" (Judg. 17:6; 18:1; 19:1; 21:25), and a monarchy headed by a godly king was needed (cf. Deut. 17:14–20). A monarchy was eventually established (1 Samuel 8), but the majority of Israel's kings were an additional source of trouble for God's people. At the time of Obadiah's oracle, the Davidic heir had been deposed from the throne of Israel, and the region would be ruled by foreign-appointed governors for much of the rest of Israel's existence. Strikingly, in Obadiah's vision of Israel's restoration, the ultimate resolution for this situation is not the re-enthronement of a Davidic king but rather the reappearance of judges under the Lord's "kingship" (*melukah*).

### *Response*

<span id="page-385-6"></span><span id="page-385-5"></span>It is important that Obadiah's promised restoration be understood in a proper biblical perspective. Some Christians would interpret its prophecies of a reclaimed Promised Land (vv. 17c–20) in a literal fashion, foretelling the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. The full canon of Scripture indicates, however, that the Promised Land was a theological "type" pointing to something greater than itself. As the writer of Hebrews makes clear, Abraham faithfully obeyed the God who promised him land, looking forward to a "better country, that is, a heavenly one" (Heb. 11:16), and he sought not an earthly city but a "city that has foundations, whose designer and builder is God" (Heb. 11:10). In the OT itself, the Promised Land is depicted in idyllic terms free from the effects of sin and the fall, such as illness and barrenness (e.g., Deut. 7:14–15). Such promises could truly be fulfilled only in a new heaven and earth, where death will be no more (Revelation 21–22). Thus, the defeat of evil and the promises of restoration in Obadiah 17c–20 will find their complete fulfillment when the "day of the Lord" ushers in the age to come, although in his justice and mercy the Lord causes intrusions of that day into the present age.

<span id="page-385-7"></span><span id="page-385-2"></span><span id="page-385-0"></span>The certainty of judgment on all enemies who seek to harm God's people, and the promise of the church's ultimate restoration and renewal, provide an unshakable source of hope for the Christian, based not on wishful thinking but on the inerrant utterances of God. Paul mentions "hope" as one of the three cardinal virtues (1 Cor. 13:13), indicating its central importance to the Christian life. Despite the dire circumstances faced by God's people in every generation, they always possess the promises of ultimate salvation.

<span id="page-385-3"></span><span id="page-385-1"></span>This final section of Obadiah depicts God's people as agents of divine destruction (Obad. 18), as Scripture does elsewhere (e.g., Ps. 149:6–9). To avoid misunderstanding or misapplying this biblical theme, it is vital to recall how Obadiah's prophecy regarding Edom's destruction came to fulfillment (cf. Introduction: Theology of Obadiah: Esau in Biblical Perspective). The church "destroys" or "consumes" her enemies not through violence but by winning them over to Christ: as people are "baptized into Christ" (Gal. 3:26–29), there is no longer Jew, Greek, Barbarian, Scythian, or, one might add, Edomite. While this involves a loss of one's natural identity in one sense, an incomparably greater identity is found in Christ.

<span id="page-385-4"></span>John Calvin's prayer at the end of his commentary on Obadiah aptly sums up the message of the book:

Grant, Almighty God, that as we are so scattered in our pilgrimage in this world, that even a dreadful spectacle is presented to our eyes, when we see thy Church so miserably rent asunder, O grant, that being endued with the real power of thy Spirit, and gathered into one, we may so cultivate brotherly kindness among ourselves, that each may strive to help another, and at the same time keep our eyes fixed on Christ Jesus; and though hard contests may await us, may we yet be under his care and protection, and so exercise patience, that having finished our warfare, we may at last enjoy that blessed rest, which thou hast promised to us, and which is laid up for us in heaven, and which has also been purchased for us by the blood of Christ thy Son, one Lord. Amen.

# JONAH

*Jay Sklar*

## INTRODUCTION TO JONAH

## *Overview*

<span id="page-389-4"></span><span id="page-389-3"></span><span id="page-389-2"></span><span id="page-389-1"></span>The theme of the book of Jonah is the Lord as a God of worldwide grace, mercy, and love who desires to save all people. Thus he rescues the sailors in chapter 1, Jonah in chapter 2, and the Ninevites in chapter 3. In sharp contrast is Jonah, who delights to experience the Lord's mercy and salvation for himself (ch. 2) but does not want to share it with evil Gentiles (ch. 4). The book closes with the Lord using a question to reveal Jonah's misunderstanding of the Lord's mercy and love. He asks, in effect, "Jonah, is it not right for me to show these things to all people, even those you do not think deserve it?" No answer is given; the question is left for the reader to answer.

## *Title, Author, and Date of Writing*

The book is named after its main human character, Jonah, a prophet in the northern kingdom of Israel. The book is one of "the Twelve," the traditional Jewish title for the Minor Prophets.

We are not told who wrote the book or when it was written. The presence of details only Jonah would have known—such as his prayer in chapter 2—could imply it was written shortly after the events it narrates by Jonah himself (after his repentance?), or by a contemporary prophet who knew him. It could also have been written at a later point by an inspired author working with sources describing the events, or by a prophet to whom they were revealed. That the "twelve prophets" are named in *Sirach* 49:10 (written shortly after 200 BC) means Jonah was written before that time, leaving a very broad range of possible dates, from any time during Jonah's life to many centuries later (therefore, c. 750–250 BC). There is simply not enough evidence to narrow the date further.1

## *Date of the Book's Events; Occasion*

<span id="page-389-0"></span>A much narrower range of dates may be proposed for the book's *events*. We know that Jonah lived during the reign of Jeroboam II (cf. 2 Kings 14:25), who ruled for most

<sup>1</sup> It has sometimes been argued that the book's language, customs, or (supposed) historical inaccuracies favor a date of writing during or after the exile of 586 BC. For a critical examination of these arguments, see T. Desmond Alexander, "Jonah," in *Obadiah, Jonah, Micah* (Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity, 1988), 52–61; Douglas Stuart, *Hosea–Jonah* (Waco, TX: Word, 1987), 432–433.

of the first half of the eighth century BC.2 But we do not know how Jonah's life and ministry overlapped with Jeroboam's rule. If he was alive before Jeroboam's reign and these events took place early in his life, they may have occurred in the second half of the ninth century BC. If he was alive after Jeroboam's reign and these events took place later in his life, they may have occurred in the second half of the eighth century BC. They also could have happened anytime between these two extremes, leaving us with a range of 843 to 705 BC in which the events of this book could have taken place.3

Nineveh was a chief city (and later capital) of Assyria, whose power and significance grew considerably from 883 to 826 BC, went through a period of decline for about seventy years, and then began to grow again when Tiglath-pileser III came to the throne in 745/744 BC. It was under this renewed Assyria that Israel was defeated and carried off into exile in 722 BC. As for Nineveh in particular, "Its great moments took place in the early first millennium, beginning with Shalmaneser I and Assurnasirpal II (9th century)," with its full glory being reached during the reign of Sennacherib (704–681).4 Thus during Jonah's life Nineveh was a place of great enemy power, filled with those who worshiped gods other than Yahweh. Significantly, it was also associated with great wickedness (cf. comment on 1:1–2), which may help explain Jonah's attitude toward it.

<span id="page-390-2"></span>Why was Jonah written? The book itself does not explicitly provide a reason, but its content seems to emphasize at least three reasons for its composition (see table 6.1).

<span id="page-390-3"></span>These three reasons are closely connected. Those who are spiritually proud are the quickest to forget their own need of God's mercy and compassion, and therefore
