## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-446-1"></span>To this point in the book, few reasons have been given for the judgment of Judah, but this lack is quickly remedied by this judgment oracle, which takes aim at wealthy landowners who devise ways and means to fulfill their covetous desires. They scheme up plans during the midnight hours to rob poor farmers of their houses and drive them from their land (Mic. 2:1–2). The indictment of these criminals is followed by another sentence by Yahweh in which the punishment equals the crime (cf. 1:7b). Yahweh himself devises judgment against these ancient opportunists and drives them from their land (2:3–4). What is more, they will never be able to reclaim their land nor their status in the congregation of Yahweh (v. 5).

## <span id="page-446-4"></span><span id="page-446-3"></span><span id="page-446-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- I.A. The Divine Epiphany of Judgment (1:2–2:11) . . .
	- 3. Dead Men Walking: Reasons for Judgment and Exile (2:1–5)
		- a. Indictment of the Covetous (2:1–2)
		- b. Sentence Passed on the Covetous (2:3–5)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-447-6"></span>2:1–2 The biblical prophets often used judgment oracles in which an indictment was followed by a verdict. Here the indictment describes covetous wealthy landowners staying awake in order to imagine ways in which they can acquire more and more. At the crack of dawn they are up, seeking to fulfill their plans. They are probably involved in expropriating land because of unpaid debts, which may be due to crop failure (cf. also Isa. 5:8). Their wickedness is thus clear: instead of helping those who are suffering, they take advantage of them. The language of the text indicates that there is a regular predictability to their evil thoughts and actions:

<span id="page-447-4"></span> They covet fields and seize them, and houses, and take them away; they oppress a man and his house, a man and his inheritance. (Mic. 2:2)

<span id="page-447-7"></span>In the original text, the rhyming of the last word in each line stresses this regularity. The first pair of lines ends with *u* and the second pair with *o*. The key theological word here is "covet." This stresses that the theft and the subsequent social oppression both originate in the heart. It also shows that these thieves are rebelling against the Lord's covenant, since he made very clear that his people must not covet what belongs to others (Ex. 20:17).

<span id="page-447-3"></span><span id="page-447-0"></span>Micah prefaces such nefarious activity with the interjection "Woe" (*hoy*), which was often used at times of funerary lament (1 Kings 13:30). These people, who think they can do whatever they want whenever they want to whomever they want, receive a funeral lament pronounced over them. They are literally dead men walking!

<span id="page-447-10"></span><span id="page-447-9"></span><span id="page-447-8"></span><span id="page-447-5"></span>2:3–5 The sentence passed on the greedy landowners is quite appropriate. As they "devised" (v. 1) to steal land from the poor, so Yahweh "devises" (v. 3) to take their land away from them. Their arrogance and haughtiness will give way to laments and desperation as their land is given to an "apostate" (v. 4), probably a reference to the idolatrous Assyrian troops likely ravaging the land at the time. Furthermore, they will not only have their land removed; they themselves will be removed from the "assembly of the Lord" (v. 5), a reference to the worship community in Judah (cf. Deut. 23:2–4). The reference to casting lots refers to the apportionment of land by lot in the assembly of the Lord when land was first divided among the Israelites after the conquest (Josh. 14:2; 19:51). It may also foretell the time when Judah returns from exile and land is redistributed to the people. At such a time, these wicked landowners will have no portion in the Lord's land.

## <span id="page-447-2"></span><span id="page-447-1"></span>*Response*

Theologian Sally Brown captures well the thought of a passage like this:

Imagine [prosperous landholders] gathered at a benefit gala. Bursts of laughter ripple through the room; their mood is buoyant. Their common bond, in addition to an elite social standing, is a knack for finding the upside in a volatile land market. But just as they are lifting their glasses to congratulate themselves, the party is interrupted by a messenger. Drinks are poised mid-air; all are strained to listen. The messenger bears a funeral announcement? Whose? Theirs.17

It is not difficult to connect the dots to the twenty-first century, where millions of dollars have been made by the unscrupulous and dishonest. From Yahweh's point of view, people who engage in such practices are dead men walking. In fact, Paul describes life before Christ as that of spiritual death in trespasses and sins, following the covetous desires of the heart (Eph. 2:1–3).

<span id="page-448-3"></span>The origin of these desires is covetousness. Such sin is prohibited by the last of the Ten Commandments, a commandment different from all the rest: it is the only one that cannot be politically enforced by human beings. The heart is known only to oneself and God. Thus covetousness is a type of warning system, announcing that all is not right spiritually. The all-consuming desire to possess something illicit is a sign of idolatry, of making a substitute for God (Col. 3:5). The result is injustice, the failure to love one's neighbor.

<span id="page-448-4"></span><span id="page-448-2"></span><span id="page-448-1"></span><span id="page-448-0"></span>Jesus makes this crystal clear in his teaching concerning the dangers of covetousness. The story of the rich fool, who tears down his barns to build bigger ones in order to hoard his increased wealth, is a story of a heart gripped by covetousness (Luke 12:13–21). Covetousness cannot satisfy, for it is based on a faulty understanding of what it means to be human. As Jesus remarks, "One's life does not consist in the abundance of his possessions" (Luke 12:15). Jesus tells his disciples not to fuss and fret about material things, but rather to put his kingdom first (Matt. 6:33). Then they will find a deep peace and will have all of their material needs met as well. With Christ now at the center of one's life, one can lay awake at night devising ways to bless people and empower them by serving and helping them. The life redeemed by God has God at the center and seeks to bring the divine order of shalom into society. Just as the covetous heart will find more and more ways to oppress in order to fill an infinite spiritual vacuum, the heart with God at the center will be satisfied and will seek creative ways to express generosity and kindness.

<sup>17</sup> Sally Brown, "Micah 2:1–11," *Interpretation* 57 (2003), 417.

## MICAH 2:6–11

- <span id="page-449-1"></span>**<sup>6</sup>** "Do not preach"—thus they preach— "one should not preach of such things; disgrace will not overtake us."
- **<sup>7</sup>** Should this be said, O house of Jacob? Has the Lord grown impatient?*<sup>1</sup>* Are these his deeds? Do not my words do good to him who walks uprightly?
- **<sup>8</sup>** But lately my people have risen up as an enemy; you strip the rich robe from those who pass by trustingly with no thought of war.*<sup>2</sup>*
- **<sup>9</sup>** The women of my people you drive out from their delightful houses; from their young children you take away my splendor forever.
- **<sup>10</sup>** Arise and go, for this is no place to rest, because of uncleanness that destroys with a grievous destruction.
- **<sup>11</sup>** If a man should go about and utter wind and lies, saying, "I will preach to you of wine and strong drink," he would be the preacher for this people!

1Hebrew *Has the spirit of the Lord grown short?* 2Or *returning from war*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-449-6"></span><span id="page-449-5"></span><span id="page-449-4"></span><span id="page-449-3"></span><span id="page-449-2"></span><span id="page-449-0"></span>Up to this point Micah has not encountered much opposition to his ministry, but here we are given an insight into prophetic opposition from people with theological credentials. They cannot tolerate Micah's prophesying and tell him to cease and desist (2:6a). They read Judah's theological narrative differently than Micah. They cannot imagine God's anger toward his own people ("Has the Lord grown impatient?"; 2:7b). But Micah provides a stunning theological counterattack, arguing that the covenant stipulations require a life of obedience ("him who walks uprightly"; 2:7d) and that these rich landowners have attacked helpless people and divested women and children of house and home (2:8–9). They are commanded to leave the land because they have made it unclean (2:10). In a final retort, Micah calls out such spiritual supporters of a corrupt establishment as nothing but false purveyors of a prosperity gospel (2:11). They are interested only in being popular, not in being faithful.

	- 4. Theological Polemics (2:6–11)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-450-2"></span><span id="page-450-1"></span>2:6 Micah's message of judgment did not sit well with many in his audience, including his prophetic colleagues. They tell him to stop preaching, using a word that may be a derogatory word for prophesying, implying that he is "dripping on" like an annoying nag. The word is used for droplets of moisture in many contexts (Judg. 5:4; Prov. 5:3; Joel 3:18). These prophets view Micah and people like him as needlessly bothering others with their judgment oracles. After this initial sentence, it becomes difficult to identify the speakers in the text. The best view (cf. Introduction: Interpretive Challenges for other options) is perhaps to understand Micah as immediately responding to these prophets with, "They will not preach about these things" (i.e., judgment), rather than to understand the false prophets to be saying, "One should not preach of such things."

Micah then goes on to say that "He [God] will not remove disgraces," or "Disgraces will not be removed." In other words, Micah is stating that if judgment is not preached, people will keep going on merrily along their way, assuming that everything is all right, and judgment will not be averted. (The other interpretation requires significant textual emendation to read, "Disgrace will not overtake us." With this reading, the words are those of the false prophets, who state that judgment will certainly not come.)

<span id="page-450-3"></span><span id="page-450-0"></span>2:7 This verse includes a series of four rhetorical questions, three expecting a negative answer and therefore probably the words of the false prophets. These are countered with a rhetorical question using the first person singular pronoun, referring to God, and this is therefore probably Micah contradicting the previous rhetorical questions with his own, which assumes a positive answer. "Should this be said, O house of Jacob?" is probably a response to Micah's preaching of judgment. The false prophets asking the question clearly expect the answer to be "No!" The history of Israel included a notorious attempt to curse Jacob, which God turned into a blessing (Numbers 22–24). The second question, "Has the Lord grown impatient?" literally reads in Hebrew, "Has the Spirit of the Lord become short?" and refers to having a "short temper." The answer is again negative. The last question, "Are these his deeds?" probably refers to the acts of judgment Micah is prophesying and may refer to the Assyrian soldiers outside the walls of Jerusalem at that very moment. Again a negative answer is expected. In short, the false prophets are emphasizing that the Lord's judgment will not come.

Speaking through Micah, the Lord counters these questions with one of his own: "Do not my words do good to him who walks uprightly?" Here God interrupts all of these questions by bringing his people back to the main terms of the covenant, in which righteousness and justice were expected—otherwise, curse would result (cf. Deuteronomy 28). In the Hebrew, the phrase "walks uprightly" was used to contrast those who pleased the Lord with those who were earlier condemned for walking arrogantly instead of uprightly (Mic. 2:3)

<span id="page-451-6"></span><span id="page-451-5"></span><span id="page-451-2"></span>2:8 Now Micah lambasts his unfaithful colleagues with a litany of ways in which the wealthy landowners are walking arrogantly, becoming an enemy to their own people, suddenly and unexpectedly robbing people of their garments. It is as if the people have returned from war not expecting to be attacked by their own neighbors.

<span id="page-451-7"></span><span id="page-451-3"></span>2:9 Moreover, women are driven from their domiciles, and children, here called "my splendor," have also been taken away, probably to serve in debt slavery (cf. 2 Kings 4:1–7). All three of these crimes—robbing garments, driving women from their homes, and reducing children to debt slavery—are crimes against the vulnerable. In this case the husband is probably missing because he is serving as an indentured servant; his wife has to leave her home because the land has been expropriated, and thus she is particularly vulnerable—as are her "orphaned" children.

<span id="page-451-8"></span><span id="page-451-4"></span><span id="page-451-1"></span><span id="page-451-0"></span>2:10 Micah is now very angry, essentially telling these wealthy landowners and their spiritual sycophants to "Get lost!" i.e., to "Get out of here!" He tells them to get up and leave the land, "for this is no place to rest." The word "rest" is a rich theological word, with overtones of peace and security; it emphasizes all the blessings of the Promised Land for the people of God (Ex. 33:14; Josh. 21:44; Isa. 28:12). Its verbal counterpart first occurs when God places Adam in the garden of Eden (Gen. 2:15), thus indicating a place where all human needs are to be met, both physically with the abundant fruit of the garden, and also spiritually with the presence of God. Micah later provides a perfect word picture of what "rest" will mean under the Messiah's rule: "They shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig tree, and no one shall make them afraid, for the mouth of the Lord of hosts has spoken" (Mic. 4:4).

<span id="page-451-10"></span>But Judah in Micah's time is anything but such a place. In fact, it has become unclean, and such uncleanness "destroys with a grievous destruction." "Uncleanness" is a highly charged religious word indicating that which must never come into contact with the holy. Here the entire land—which was supposed to be a place of holiness—has become defiled by the moral filth of the wealthy and their prophetic puppets. Both groups need to get out to a foreign, unclean land, where they will be better served. In this way, Israel will get the defilement and pollution out of their land.

<span id="page-451-9"></span>2:11 Micah now turns to the false prophets and uses the same potentially derogatory word they had used for his preaching at the beginning of the oracle. He <span id="page-452-7"></span><span id="page-452-6"></span>imagines a windbag (lit., one who "walks with the wind, and utters lies"), saying, in effect, "I will prophesy of wine and beer." That person is just the preacher (dripper) for this people. To prophesy only of wine and beer is to bear a message about the life of pleasure and nothing else. "Wine and strong drink" could denote the good life in a positive sense in Israel, as wine was regarded as a divine gift (Ps. 104:15), but it could also become a ruthless master if one was not careful. It was regarded as the bane of kings, since it could cloud judgment (Prov. 31:4–7). Nazirites and priests on duty were forbidden to imbibe (Lev. 10:9; Num. 6:3; Judg. 13:4, 7). Micah's contemporary Isaiah spoke of endless partying with no concern about the serious issues of life (Isa. 5:11–12). Thus these prophets are prosperity preachers. They say, "Don't worry about anything. Be happy! Everything will be fine!" They are nothing but liars.

### <span id="page-452-9"></span><span id="page-452-4"></span><span id="page-452-3"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-452-11"></span><span id="page-452-5"></span><span id="page-452-1"></span><span id="page-452-0"></span>From even a casual reading of the prophetic books, it is clear that the true prophets faced perhaps their strongest opposition from their own prophetic colleagues in ministry. Such theological opponents were often on the side of the establishment (cf. 1 Kings 22). But they should not be viewed as theologically naive or illiterate. They also read the narrative of Israel's history, but they had come to a different conclusion. The Israelite credo spoke of Yahweh's forgiving and compassionate nature, his patience and longsuffering (Ex. 34:6–7). Israel's traditions also stressed its election and special status as Yahweh's people, as well as Jerusalem and the temple as the center of the earth (Gen. 12:1–3; Deuteronomy 7; Psalms 46–48; Ezek. 38:12; Amos 3:1–2). From such a reading, Micah's opponents concluded that Israel had a "free pass." Yahweh had invested too much in his people to judge them. But this was clearly a one-sided reading of the narrative. This was theological "cherry-picking," because the credo was equally devoted to the fact that God would not acquit the guilty (Ex. 34:7b), and the purpose of election was to produce the fruit of justice and righteousness (Isa. 5:1–7), for the people to be beacons of light to the nations (Isaiah 60). On the other side of the cross, Christian believers do not get a free pass either. Jesus calls his people to "the holiness without which no one will see the Lord" (Heb. 12:14).

<span id="page-452-12"></span><span id="page-452-10"></span><span id="page-452-8"></span><span id="page-452-2"></span>Thus ministers of the gospel and believers should expect not merely nonbelievers to disagree with them. From time to time there will be opponents from within the household of faith, with a different reading of Scripture. Their reading must be challenged from the Scriptures and from experience. If their reading is that God's justice will never come on those who claim to be his people, no matter how wickedly they live, then their reading is deficient. If their reading is causing justice and mercy to be neglected, while the wealthy profit, then it is defective. Sometimes it may be necessary to tell such false teachers to "Get out!" of the church.

## <span id="page-453-3"></span>MICAH 2:12–13

**<sup>12</sup>** I will surely assemble all of you, O Jacob; I will gather the remnant of Israel; I will set them together like sheep in a fold, like a flock in its pasture, a noisy multitude of men. **<sup>13</sup>** He who opens the breach goes up before them; they break through and pass the gate, going out by it. Their king passes on before them, the Lord at their head.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-453-4"></span><span id="page-453-2"></span>This oracle suddenly and abruptly changes in theme from judgment to salvation, providing an effective conclusion to the entire first section in Micah. The theme of judgment, particularly in the form of exile, has been pervasive. Yet this oracle is an announcement of salvation for the exiles. Jacob and Israel, which have been castigated, are now saved—even if only a remnant is left (2:12). Yet they are as numerous as a flock and are gathered together behind the walls of their exilic prison (v. 13). A person named the "Breacher" (one who "opens the breach"; v. 13a) goes before them and smashes down part of the wall, and this person is none other than King Yahweh, who leads his people out of their prison (v. 13b). When the Lord went forth from his holy temple to judge the earth, creation collapsed before him and the cities of Samaria and southwest Judah were demolished (1:2–16). Now the Lord smashes down the walls of an exilic prison so that his people can escape.

<span id="page-453-5"></span><span id="page-453-0"></span>The overall aim of this oracle is to provide a positive ending—albeit a short one—to the first round of judgment oracles. These themes of salvation, a remnant, a flock, and the Lord/Shepherd-King will be developed further in the next two rounds of oracles.

<span id="page-453-1"></span>The sudden nature of this salvation oracle has prompted a significant group of scholars to wonder whether it has been misinterpreted, since it seems to be so much at odds with its context. Thus some conclude that it is an example of a "salvation" oracle from the mouths of the false prophets mentioned in 2:6–11. But the false prophets probably never saw the present predicament as divine judgment from which one needed to be saved. Other scholars interpret it as an oracle of judgment, i.e., that Yahweh is gathering the surrounding inhabitants in Jerusalem during the Assyrian crisis to lead them into exile into Assyria. Both of these maneuvers are unnecessary when one sees this oracle within the overall structure of the book of Micah (cf. Introduction: Interpretive Challenges). It is the final answer to the judgment of exile. God will not abandon his people.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-454-6"></span>I.B. The Divine Epiphany of Salvation: Breakout (2:12–13)
	- 1. The Gathering of a Remnant Flock (2:12)
	- 2. The Shepherd-King (2:13)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-454-0"></span>2:12 "I will surely assemble" is an abrupt change from third person to first person, and the Hebrew form of these words is emphatic, showing Yahweh's firm resolve to save. These references to gathering the remnant of Israel assume a long period of time in which Israel has been devastated through judgment and only a remnant of the people is left. "Remnant" is a profound theological concept, referring to survivors of a crisis. The concept is found in rescues such as Noah and his family surviving the flood (Genesis 6–9) or Lot and his family escaping the judgment of Sodom (Genesis 19). But the first use of the actual word occurs when Joseph is used by God to preserve his family through the crisis of a worldwide famine (Gen. 45:7). Similarly, the verbal form of the word ("to leave a remnant") is used in 1 Kings to indicate God's reserving of seven thousand who have not bowed the knee to Baal during the mass apostasy of Elijah's time (1 Kings 19:18).

<span id="page-454-5"></span><span id="page-454-4"></span><span id="page-454-3"></span><span id="page-454-2"></span><span id="page-454-1"></span>Isaiah uses a word built on the Hebrew root for "remnant" to name his son *Shear*-jashub: "a remnant [of the people] shall return" after the coming judgment (Isa. 7:3). In particular, the term "remnant" used here in Micah becomes a technical term in prophecy for the remainder of the nation that survives judgment and is used by God for his salvific purposes (cf. Isa 37:32; Zeph. 3:13). This determination of Yahweh to save a remnant shows his absolute commitment to his ancient promises. The change to shepherd imagery in the latter part of the verse recalls imagery from Israel's past, as Israel is like a scattered flock that will be saved by the divine Shepherd-King. The last phrase, "a noisy multitude of men," could hold a number of meanings. The Hebrew literally reads, "they [the gathered sheep] will be noisy from man." The preposition "from" can mean separation, i.e., the sheep will be far away from human beings, but this does not make much sense in the context, since presumably there are many humans around. The preposition can also have a causal meaning, for which there are two possible meanings. The sheep's bleating could be due to their fear of human beings, which would make sense in the context, since they would be afraid of harm.18 But it can also mean that the very loud uproar is due to a large number of people being present. Thus the metaphor may change here from sheep to people. The sheep are in fact Judah's exiles, who have become large in number as a result of their being gathered into one place by the work of a tender shepherd. This sense best suits the context.

<sup>18</sup> Leslie Allen, *The Books of Joel, Obadiah, Jonah, and Micah*, NICOT (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 1976), 300.

<span id="page-455-4"></span>2:13 The scene subtly shifts from sheep gathered in a pen to humans gathered behind walls of a city, imprisoned in exile. Although they have been gathered, this is not the final word. One who makes a breach goes before them to break them out. But before they break free, their King passes over them, Yahweh at their head. This is a remarkable text, bringing together a variety of powerful images: the imagery of sheep in a pen, people behind walls, and Yahweh appearing both as a Shepherd-King and as one who breaches walls to lead his people to freedom. The word for "he who opens a breach" is used in a number of contexts in Scripture and indicates the notion of "breaking through" or "breaching." Thus a baby can be named Perez ("Breacher") because he has broken out from the womb before his twin (Gen. 38:29). Servants who escape (break away) from their masters can be described with this verb (1 Sam. 25:10). In keeping with this sense, a city wall that provides safety from the enemy can be breached during war (2 Kings 14:13; 2 Chron. 26:6; 32:5). Here the word indicates King Yahweh's appearing amid the exiles and breaking them out of their exilic prison. Thus, for Judah, grace is the last word, once the people have passed through the crucible of judgment.

## <span id="page-455-3"></span><span id="page-455-2"></span><span id="page-455-1"></span><span id="page-455-0"></span>*Response*

This final oracle of the first section of Micah shows the importance of balancing judgment oracles with a final note of grace. This is a theme in most of the prophetic books. Such books include many notes of judgment, but these are frequently balanced by divine grace. Perhaps it is for this reason that Ben Sira, in a book written in the early second century BC, described the twelve prophets as bringing comfort to Israel (*Sir.* 49:10–12). This is clearly not cheap grace but costly grace.

This text is a reminder of God's pledge to keep his covenant. The people do not deserve this kindness, but God has made a covenant, and when things seem terribly bleak, he will break down whatever barrier imprisons and enslaves his people. The remnant theme is crucial to the realization of God's promises: there will always be faithful ones whom God preserves in times of crisis. This concept plays an important role in Paul's thought (Romans 9–11). God's promises will finally stand.

<span id="page-455-7"></span><span id="page-455-6"></span><span id="page-455-5"></span>The NT amplifies more of these themes: Jesus prays for shepherds to seek the lost sheep of the house of Israel (Matt. 9:35–38). He himself is the Good Shepherd who lays down his life for the flock (John 10:14–15). He is the ultimate Breaker of the prison house of death. It is because he breaches the walls of his own tomb that he can breach the walls of the tomb imprisoning humanity: "The event of resurrection breaks open the world of death."19 And in the final book of the Bible, Revelation, these themes finally "break out" in all their power. The saints escape from Babylon as its walls come crumbling down (Revelation 17–18) and they are led home, where they will enjoy eternal bliss: "The Lamb in the midst of the throne

<span id="page-455-8"></span><sup>19</sup> Walther Zimmerli, *Man and His Hope in the Old Testament*, SBT (Naperville, IL: Allenson, 1968), 148; Mitchell Chase, "Resurrection Hope in Daniel 12:2 (1)" (PhD diss., Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, 2013), 64.

<span id="page-456-10"></span>will be their shepherd, and he will guide them to springs of living water, and God will wipe away every tear from their eyes" (Rev. 7:17).

<span id="page-456-9"></span><span id="page-456-8"></span><span id="page-456-7"></span>The contrast between the corruption of the previous leaders and Yahweh's concern for liberation and empowerment is sharp. Contemporary leaders need to ask themselves if their leadership is oppressive or empowering, leading people into bondage or liberation. They need to live in light of the past liberation from the prison house of sin because of the death and resurrection of Christ, and in light of the future liberation of the planet from death, which will happen at the second coming of Christ (Romans 12–13; 1 Corinthians 15; Ephesians 4–6). It is Christ who provides the model of leadership, and his shepherds must follow in his paths (John 10:3–4; Acts 20:28; 1 Pet. 5:2). Sadly, however, not all leaders walk in God's ways (Jude 12), and the contrast between good and evil leadership will become even sharper in the next section of Micah.

## <span id="page-456-1"></span>OVERVIEW OF

## <span id="page-456-3"></span>MICAH 3:1–5:15

<span id="page-456-2"></span><span id="page-456-0"></span>The second movement of judgment and salvation develops themes from the first movement, intensifying and expanding them. The section begins on a note that contrasts radically with the last oracle. In that speech, Yahweh was at the head of the people, liberating them from the prison house of their future exile (2:13). Micah now returns to the present, to corrupt judicial and political leaders; they too are at the head of the people (3:1), but they *cannibalize* them (3:2–3). Yahweh is he who leads his people through the gate of exile and breaches the prison wall, while the current leaders spread the flesh of their victims in a pot and break their bones. But the Lord takes notice. Two more judgment oracles follow, one directed at the false prophets (3:5–8) and another directed at the entire political and religious establishment, including the most sacred institution in Israel: the temple (3:9–12).

<span id="page-456-6"></span><span id="page-456-5"></span><span id="page-456-4"></span>By the time we reach the conclusion of chapter 3, it seems like Judah is at an end. In reality, these severe judgments are the precursor to a new beginning, and a salvation oracle is placed alongside the last and most severe judgment oracle to show that in the last days, the end of history, the razed temple will be raised to the highest elevation in the whole world to be a beacon of hope and peace for the entire earth (4:1–5). Then, a new section of oracles in chiastic form shows how this goal will be achieved (the parenthetical phrases below are the opening lines of each section, signaling the links between the respective units):

- 
- <span id="page-457-5"></span><span id="page-457-4"></span>A. Yahweh the Shepherd-King (4:6–7) ("In that day, declares the Lord")
	- B. Jerusalem (4:8–5:1) ("you, O Tower of the flock, hill of . . . Zion")
	- B'. Bethlehem (5:2–9) ("But you, O Bethlehem Ephrathah")
- <span id="page-457-7"></span><span id="page-457-6"></span>A'. Yahweh the Warrior-King (5:10–15) ("And in that day, declares the Lord")

<span id="page-457-3"></span><span id="page-457-1"></span>The end of history will also coincide with the return of the ragtag remnant led by Yahweh the Shepherd-King (A; 4:6–7), resulting in the destruction of every form of idolatry and an appeal to the nations (A'; 5:10–15). But between the present and the end, Jerusalem will experience a time of intense agony likened to birth pangs, from which it will be delivered (4:8–5:1). Deliverance will eventually come from the town of Bethlehem, where a mother will give birth to a son who will eventually rule the nations (B'; 5:2–9). Thus these four units indicate the process by which the temple will be elevated as a beacon to the nations in 4:1–5. Moreover, while the oracles in chapter 3 continue and intensify the judgment found in 1:2–2:11, the oracles in chapters 4–5 amplify the oracle of salvation in 2:12–13.

## MICAH 3:1–4

- 
- <span id="page-457-2"></span><span id="page-457-0"></span>3 And I said: Hear, you heads of Jacob and rulers of the house of Israel! Is it not for you to know justice?—
- **<sup>2</sup>** you who hate the good and love the evil, who tear the skin from off my people*<sup>1</sup>* and their flesh from off their bones,
- **<sup>3</sup>** who eat the flesh of my people, and flay their skin from off them, and break their bones in pieces and chop them up like meat in a pot, like flesh in a cauldron.
- **<sup>4</sup>** Then they will cry to the Lord, but he will not answer them; he will hide his face from them at that time, because they have made their deeds evil.

1Hebrew *from off them*

## *Section Overview*

This passage is the beginning of a triad of judgment oracles, focusing on the corruption of the judicial system in Judah. It uses macabre imagery in its indictment (3:2–3) to indicate the horrific nature of injustice. Human victims crying out for justice should receive help from the courts, their last resort in society. But instead they are cannibalized. In a punishment fit for the crime, sentence is passed on the unjust: when they cry out for help to the ultimate Judge in their time of need, he will in no way answer them (v. 4).

- II. Second Movement: Judgment and Salvation II: The Judgment of Jerusalem, Its Leaders, and the Temple: The Resurrection of the Temple; the Judgment and Salvation of the Remnant and the Nations (3:1–5:15)
	- A. Judgment on the Present Jerusalem (3:1–12)
		- 1. Cannibalism in the Courts (3:1–4)
			- a. Indictment: No Help! (3:1–3)
			- b. Sentence: No Help! (3:4)

## <span id="page-458-8"></span><span id="page-458-5"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-458-2"></span>3:1–3 This new section begins with an oracle of judgment against the leadership of the nation, consisting of an indictment (3:1–3) followed by a sentence (v. 4). Although the word used here for leaders ("rulers") often has to do with political and military leadership (cf. Judg. 11:6, 11), in this context it particularly includes judicial leadership, as the responsibility of these leaders is to make legal judgments. They are entrusted with "knowing justice": what it is and how to administer it (Mic. 3:1). These leaders were to love good and hate evil, just as Yahweh required of those who love him (Ps. 97:10). In fact, when judges were first appointed in Israel, they were to be marked by fear of God, faithfulness, and hatred of bribes (Ex. 18:21). Moreover, they were to make their legal decisions impartially and practice fairness in all their dealings (Deut. 16:18, 19).

<span id="page-458-7"></span><span id="page-458-6"></span><span id="page-458-4"></span><span id="page-458-3"></span><span id="page-458-1"></span><span id="page-458-0"></span>But the exact opposite is the case with the judicial leadership in Judah. They "hate the good and love the evil" (Mic. 3:2). When the needy seek justice, they receive injustice instead (vv. 2–3). The place of help becomes the place of greater oppression. In fact, these victims of injustice seeking justice are figuratively cannibalized when they come to court! Micah paints a graphic image in which these wicked judges treat the people as animals to be slaughtered, flayed, chopped up, and consumed. "What the farmer in [Israel] routinely does to his cattle, the leaders in the capital city do to human beings."20 The prophet presents his description in this manner in order to strike the hardened conscience of the judicial officials. He prolongs the description by using wordplay to show the perverse nature of what they are doing: They should be engaged in justice (*mishpat*), but instead they strip (*hipshitu*) the skin off the people, preparing them for consumption.

3:4 Just as these judicial leaders have not provided help in the day of distress when victims of injustice have come for help, there will come a time when they themselves will cry out for help but will receive no answer. The word for "cry" suggests the kind <span id="page-459-2"></span><span id="page-459-1"></span><span id="page-459-0"></span>of desperate request for help that comes as a result of extreme oppression. The Israelites cried out because of their cruel bondage in Egypt (Ex. 2:23) or because of tyrannical coercion in the time of the judges (Judg. 3:9). Tamar cried out in agony after she was raped by Amnon (2 Sam. 13:19). Eventually there will come a time when the judicial leaders will experience the same plight experienced by the people who came to them seeking justice. These leaders will cry out to the supreme Judge, Yahweh, but there will be no answer. In fact, Yahweh will hide his face. This suggests that Yahweh will turn away in disgust from their prayers. Just as the suffering servant was one whose appearance caused people to hide their faces from him (Isa. 53:3), the requests of these oppressors will cause Yahweh to do the same.

<span id="page-459-3"></span>As if to emphasize the justness of the sentence, the text sums up the indictment in a single clause: "They have made their deeds evil."

#### *Response*

This text is one of the most macabre in the entire Bible, as it puts on graphic display the incredible corruption of the judicial system in ancient Judah. The use of the cannibalism metaphor is an attempt to shock into sensibility the seared conscience of the judges and make it healthy again. People had become commodities, to devour and digest. Thinking they could get help from the courts because of the injustice in society, the people do not merely get ripped off—they get ripped apart. Contemporary culture could learn from Micah.

A consumer society often consumes its own. Ancient Rome, depicted as Babylon, trafficked in human flesh:

<span id="page-459-5"></span>And the merchants of the earth weep and mourn for her, since no one buys their cargo anymore, cargo of gold, silver, jewels, pearls, fine linen, purple cloth, silk, scarlet cloth, all kinds of scented wood, all kinds of articles of ivory, all kinds of articles of costly wood, bronze, iron and marble, cinnamon, spice, incense, myrrh, frankincense, wine, oil, fine flour, wheat, cattle and sheep, horses and chariots, and slaves, *that is, human souls*. (Rev. 18:11–13)

The multibillion-dollar pornography and human trafficking industries, the proliferation of abortion in the West and gendercide in Asia, and abuse of workers in unsafe working conditions shows how consumption of humans runs rampant today.

Unfortunately, this happens not only in the wider culture but in churches as well, when helpless people become the victims of priests and ministers and spiritual leaders. Such people are abused not only physically but also mentally and spiritually. In a notorious example, a young woman abused by her spiritual leader complained that she felt "like a piece of hamburger somebody threw out in the street."21

<span id="page-459-4"></span>This text is a vivid reminder to the nations (Mic. 1:2)—as well as to the believing community: God will not stand idly by amid the violation of his moral order. The maxim "What goes around comes around" is not the result of an impersonal

<sup>21</sup> Leslie Berkman and Peter King, "Felt like Discarded 'Hamburger': Woman's Story of Bakker Tryst Told for First Time," *Los Angeles Times*, March 27, 1987 (http://articles.latimes.com/1987-03-27/news/mn-315\_1\_jim-bakker).

M icah 3:1–4 460

<span id="page-460-0"></span>force of history; it is grounded in the truth that "They will cry out and I will not answer them, because of their evil deeds" (cf. 3:4).

<span id="page-460-6"></span><span id="page-460-4"></span><span id="page-460-3"></span>People of faith need to be reminded that human beings are not objects; they are subjects made in the image of God. They are never resources to be used but beings to be loved. Instead of using people and loving things, the church must love people and use things. People in positions of power must never use that power to hurt or destroy but instead to serve and empower. The ultimate example is a Savior and Lord who never used people but rather served them (Mark 10:45), washing their feet (John 13:1–17) and healing their bodies and souls (Matt. 4:23–25). He himself offered his body on a tree and was wounded for human sins and iniquities (1 Pet. 2:24). Thus one of the sacraments of the Christian Church is the consumption of the bread and the wine, the symbols of the body and blood of Christ, given in love for his people, a vivid reminder of the vast difference between the leaders in Micah 3:1–4 and the ultimate Leader, Jesus Christ (1 Cor. 11:23–26). If we are his followers, we will love and serve others as he did.

## <span id="page-460-5"></span>MICAH 3:5–8

<span id="page-460-2"></span>**<sup>5</sup>** Thus says the Lord concerning the prophets who lead my people astray, who cry "Peace"

 when they have something to eat, but declare war against him

who puts nothing into their mouths.

- **<sup>6</sup>** Therefore it shall be night to you, without vision, and darkness to you, without divination. The sun shall go down on the prophets, and the day shall be black over them;
- **<sup>7</sup>** the seers shall be disgraced, and the diviners put to shame; they shall all cover their lips, for there is no answer from God.
- **<sup>8</sup>** But as for me, I am filled with power, with the Spirit of the Lord, and with justice and might, to declare to Jacob his transgression and to Israel his sin.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-460-1"></span>This new judgment oracle continues the theme of the corruption of Judah's leadership (Mic. 3:5–7), and to it is appended Micah's own definition of a true prophet <span id="page-461-3"></span><span id="page-461-2"></span>(v. 8). The leaders in view are the prophets also mentioned in the first round of Micah's oracles (2:6–11). These prophets are condemned in this indictment as religious mercenaries who lead the people astray (3:5). Thus they will be led astray when the light of their prophetic inspiration is turned off by Yahweh (vv. 6–7). The true prophet works not for money but for God (v. 8).

- <span id="page-461-5"></span>II.2. Profiteering Prophets (3:5–8)
	- a. Indictment: Religious Mercenaries (3:5)
	- b. Sentence: The Sun Sets (3:6–7)
	- c. The Sun Shines (3:8)

## <span id="page-461-7"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-461-1"></span>3:5 Micah begins with a standard prophetic formula: "Thus says the Lord." Prophets used this formula frequently to emphasize that their words were not their own but were the words of God (so also 2:3). Micah is thus making clear that he is condemning these prophets with a prophetic word.

Micah then announces that the prophets "lead [the] people astray." This is the exact opposite of a prophet's reason for being. They were called originally to give guidance of the most reliable kind: revealing God's will to the people. But Micah says that they have betrayed their calling, purposely misguiding the people. It would be like a doctor charged with healing instead using her talents to kill. The revelation continues to explain why the prophets are doing this: they are mercenaries, proclaiming peace to those who pay while declaring war against those who do not. Their greed is emphasized by the payment they are looking for: food for their voracious appetites. The end result is that these prophets are no longer speaking oracles from God. Rather, it is the audience that determines what these "prophetic" oracles are: "What comes out of the mouth of these prophets depends on what has been put into it."22

<span id="page-461-6"></span><span id="page-461-4"></span><span id="page-461-0"></span>3:6–7 While the indictment of these prophets is brief, the sentence is quite lengthy. It declares in a variety of ways, first, the "solar eclipse" of their inspiration (v. 6) and, second, the consequences of that eclipse (v. 7). The words in verse 6 are replete with "darkness." This suggests that the light of prophecy has gone out. Some commentators claim that these false prophets were never true prophets, but the text suggests otherwise. These appear to be true prophets who have become corrupt and faithless to their calling to speak for Yahweh. In a punishment fitting the crime, Yahweh has thus stopped speaking to them. The consequence of this loss of inspiration is the loss of authority and authenticity; the prophets will thus be put to shame and disgraced, covering their "lips." This phrase in Hebrew means literally to "cover their mustache"—a sign of humiliation. Lepers had to cover their faces as a sign of disgrace and mourning (Lev. 13:45), and this was the normal practice

<span id="page-462-0"></span>for mourning the dead as well (Ezek. 24:17, 22). Thus these greedy prophets will become social lepers, bywords for corruption and falsehood.

<span id="page-462-1"></span>3:8 Micah now gives a shining example of what a true prophet should be like. He is such a person because he is filled with power and justice:

- A. Power—the Spirit of Yahweh
	- B. Justice
- A'. Strength

The Spirit of Yahweh is intimately tied to power (as suggested here by the lack of a conjunction between the word "power" and the phrase "the Spirit of the Lord"). This is not just any power; it is the Spirit of Yahweh. Moreover, this power and strength are not arbitrary but are intimately tied to justice. Power and justice are both necessary, for power without justice is tyrannical (of which we have seen many examples already in Micah), while justice without power has no effect.23 Micah's statement probably means he is able to declare boldly a message of justice (B) because he is powerfully filled with the Spirit of Yahweh (A, A').

Such a message is further qualified as "to declare to Jacob his transgression, and to Israel his sin." This was not a popular message, to be sure, but it was a just and true message that needed courage supplied by divine strength to announce.

## *Response*

A perennial temptation of those leading the church is to tone down the message, to make it more palatable to the hearer. When leaders surrender to this temptation, they start down a slippery slope of pleasing people rather than God, or of trying to seek fame and fortune with a message that will be popular rather than true. Thus true inspiration is lost, as one is serving other masters. Charles Templeton writes about this in *The Third Temptation*, in which a pastor who sincerely began a ministry yielded to the third temptation—the temptation of power and money—and lost his way. Sadly, many people whom the pastor led also lost their way. This could well be a parable about people called to ministry. What once began as a sincere desire to share the truth of God's Word in order to help people can become warped over time to an interest only in money. Jim Bakker was an American pastor in the 1980s who became well known for his lavish lifestyle and preaching of a prosperity gospel. Scandals eventually led to his removal from ministry and incarceration in prison. From prison Bakker wrote about his ministry in a way that seems almost eerily familiar to Micah's assessment of the false prophets:

The more I studied the Bible, however, I had to admit that the prosperity message did not line up with the tenor of Scripture. My heart was crushed to think *that I led so many people astray*. I was appalled that I could have been so wrong, and I was deeply grateful that God had not struck me dead as *a false prophet*. 24

<sup>23</sup> Ibid., 151–52; W. J. Wessels, "Micah 1: An Apt Introduction to Power Talks," *Skrif En Kerk* 19 (1998): 446.

<sup>24</sup> Jim Bakker, *I Was Wrong* (Nashville: Thomas Nelson, 1996), 535; emphasis mine.

The religious leader must seek constant inspiration from God. It is God's Word that must be paramount, and those speaking for him require a constant dependence upon his Spirit in order to tell people what they need to hear, not what they want to hear. Charles Spurgeon once remarked that the minister must be saturated in the divine Word until it becomes part of the soul and his blood becomes "Bibline."25 But that was not enough, for when Spurgeon himself ascended to his pulpit to preach the divine Word, he used to repeat to himself, "I believe in the Holy Ghost. I believe in the Holy Ghost. I believe in the Holy Ghost.26

## MICAH 3:9–12

- <span id="page-463-2"></span>**<sup>9</sup>** Hear this, you heads of the house of Jacob and rulers of the house of Israel, who detest justice
- and make crooked all that is straight, **<sup>10</sup>** who build Zion with blood
- and Jerusalem with iniquity.
- **<sup>11</sup>** Its heads give judgment for a bribe; its priests teach for a price; its prophets practice divination for money; yet they lean on the Lord and say,

"Is not the Lord in the midst of us?

 No disaster shall come upon us." **<sup>12</sup>** Therefore because of you Zion shall be plowed as a field; Jerusalem shall become a heap of ruins, and the mountain of the house a wooded height.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-463-1"></span><span id="page-463-0"></span>This is the last of a triad of judgment oracles, and it represents the literary climax of chapter 3. It is interested not merely in political and judicial leaders (3:1–4) or in prophets (vv. 5–8) but in all of them together, including the priests. Thus in one fell swoop this oracle is a comprehensive indictment of the entire leadership of Judah. Its indictment (vv. 9–11) also intensifies previous indictments, as the judicial leaders now detest justice and pervert everything that is upright. Its sentence (v. 12) would have dropped like a bomb on its first hearers: this beloved holy city and temple would be the target of the coming judgment.

<span id="page-463-3"></span><sup>25</sup> Charles Spurgeon, quoted in John Stott, *The Preacher's Portrait: Some New Testament Word Studies* (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 1961), 31. 26 Ibid., 118.

## *Section Outline*

- II.3. Zion's Death and Bad Religion (3:9–12)
	- a. Indictment: Bloody Zion's Famous Last Words (3:9–11)
	- b. Sentence: Bloody Zion's Death (3:12)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-464-4"></span><span id="page-464-2"></span>3:9 The word "detest" suggests a reaction to that which is aesthetically or morally repulsive. For example, Proverbs lists seven sins that are morally repulsive to God (Prov. 6:16–19). Ironically, while God loves justice, these leaders are so evil that they find justice repugnant. Similarly, they take what is straight and upright and twist it into something crooked. Their character is in every way opposite to the Lord's.

<span id="page-464-7"></span><span id="page-464-5"></span><span id="page-464-0"></span>3:10 The description continues: they "build Zion with blood and Jerusalem with iniquity." The idea may be that they have ruthlessly conscripted human beings for their construction projects at great cost to human life. In the Hebrew, "blood" is plural, suggesting a great amount of blood shed through oppression, namely, the forced labor of the workers (cf. Hab. 2:12). "Iniquity" emphasizes violent deeds. It can be used to describe murderers (2 Sam. 3:34, where "wicked" is lit. "sons of iniquity"), corrupt judges who show partiality (Ps. 82:2), or dishonest merchants who cheat their customers (Ezek. 18:8, "injustice"). In this context, it could refer to the iniquity of treating human life as of little importance, perhaps especially in the context of building projects.

<span id="page-464-3"></span><span id="page-464-1"></span>It is not entirely clear which building projects are in view. From archaeological research it is known there were massive building projects in Hezekiah's time to provide some protection for the city. There was the so-called Broad Wall, which was about 20 feet (6 m) thick and 27 feet (8.2 m) high and would have probably extended a few kilometers to provide protection for growing "suburbs" on the western side of Jerusalem. There was also the construction of a tunnel nearly 100 feet (30 m) underground for about one-half mile (0.8 km), from one part of the city to another, to divert water from the Gihon Spring to another part of the city, particularly for a time of siege. Again, it is not clear if these are the projects in view, but the overall point is clear: the human effort required to build these or similar projects would have extracted a severe toll on human life, and these leaders did not care at all. They are justly condemned.

<span id="page-464-6"></span>3:11 But Micah is not finished with his indictment. He blasts and condemns the leaders for the breadth and depth of their wicked corruption. The literal translation emphasizes the money the leaders seek by placing it in an emphatic position before the verb:

 Its heads—*for a bribe*—give judgment; Its priests—*for a price*—teach; Its prophets—*for money*—practice divination. (AT)

The heads—the judicial officials—are bought with bribes, and so their verdicts are unjust; the priests likewise have "sold out" to money as well, tailoring their teaching to the monetary payments they desire. The prophets' activity has become so bankrupt that it is compared to pagan divination. Moreover, they have led the people astray with their guidance so much so that they are totally oblivious to their imminent disaster: "Yet they lean on the Lord and say, 'Is not the Lord in the midst of us? No disaster shall come upon us.'" Their belief in the presence of the Lord is probably rooted in the physical symbol of the temple, which represents the presence of Yahweh graphically and concretely. As verse 12 will go on to show, their "prophetic" speech is nothing but (in)famous last words.

<span id="page-465-1"></span><span id="page-465-0"></span>3:12 Micah often begins a sentence of punishment with the conjunction "therefore" (cf. 2:3; 3:6), providing a suitable segue from the indictment to the penalty and reminding his audience that the latter is inextricably united to the former. "Because of you" emphasizes this link by referring back to the corrupt leaders of Judah. One can almost hear and see Micah pointing at them and calling them out.

A triad of lines expresses the unthinkable and completely contradicts the false prophets' words of assurance. Whereas they preached peace, Micah declares that nothing could be farther from the truth:

Zion shall be plowed as a field; Jerusalem shall become a heap of ruins, and the mountain of the house a wooded height.

These three lines portray the absolute devastation of the holy city, particularly the temple hill. There is a gradual buildup to the final destruction of the temple. Zion was a term used for the original Jebusite city conquered by David (2 Sam. 5:7), but gradually its meaning became equivalent to the expanded city, Jerusalem. It is here plowed like a field, i.e., the city is turned into arable land. Then the name Jerusalem is used to indicate that the city has become a pile of ruins. And finally Micah zeroes in on the holiest site of the city, the Temple Mount: it will become simply overgrown with forest—as if nothing was ever built there. It has become a place for wild beasts. The devastation is final and complete.

## *Response*

This oracle concerning the destruction of the most sacred institution in Judah the temple—points to the futility of relying on structures and institutions and buildings in the absence of true worship, which promotes justice and righteousness and peace. When the city of peace is built on bloodshed, it is merely a matter of time before it becomes history. The same is true for denominations, churches, and Christian organizations. No one can truly rely on the Lord without having a true concern for justice and righteousness. The widespread phenomenon in Western culture of what Dietrich Bonhoeffer called "cheap grace" is disastrous.27

<sup>27</sup> "Cheap grace means the justification of sin without the justification of the sinner. Grace alone does everything, they say, and so everything can remain as it was before" (Dietrich Bonhoeffer, *The Cost of Discipleship* [New York: Touchstone, 1995], 43–44).

<span id="page-466-3"></span>Such a theology leads to antinomianism and the contemporary heresies associated with having Jesus Christ as Savior but not as Lord. Jesus himself makes clear that those who follow him must deny themselves and take up their cross (Matt. 16:24–26). In other words, the commitment must be total. In the Sermon on the Mount, Christ underscores that only those who *do* his will as well as listen to his words will be able to stand when the storm of judgment comes (Matt. 7:24–25). This is, of course, his true desire; believers have been made for his love, not his judgment.

<span id="page-466-2"></span><span id="page-466-1"></span><span id="page-466-0"></span>But warnings of judgment do have their place. History tells us that Micah's radical message of judgment helped avert divine judgment in his own time. It was this oracle in particular, remembered as the turning point, that caused the king and people to repent (Jer. 26:18–19). The preaching of judgment can affect change. May God raise up courageous messengers of the truth today!

## MICAH 4:1–5

4 It shall come to pass in the latter days that the mountain of the house of the Lord shall be established as the highest of the mountains, and it shall be lifted up above the hills; and peoples shall flow to it, **<sup>2</sup>** and many nations shall come, and say: "Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob, that he may teach us his ways and that we may walk in his paths." For out of Zion shall go forth the law,*<sup>1</sup>* and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem. **<sup>3</sup>** He shall judge between many peoples, and shall decide disputes for strong nations far away; and they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks; nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore; **<sup>4</sup>** but they shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig tree, and no one shall make them afraid, for the mouth of the Lord of hosts has spoken. **<sup>5</sup>** For all the peoples walk each in the name of its god, but we will walk in the name of the Lord our God

## *Section Overview*

This new salvation oracle comes immediately after the triad of judgment oracles climaxing in the destruction of the temple and the turning of the holiest mountain into a forest, a haunt for wild animals. Now there is a dramatic contrast as the temple is raised to the heights, becoming a magnet for the nations because Yahweh is there. Thus this unit stands as a beautiful transition to the next two chapters. It provides a picture of the future glory of Zion as a place of peace and not bloodshed; as a place of truth and not corruption; as a place of blessing and not curse. It stands as the future goal from which the present Zion had become radically sidetracked (3:1–12).

- II.B. The Future Glory of Jerusalem and Temple: Resurrection and Good Religion (4:1–5)
	- 1. The Magnetic Hill of Zion—A Mecca for the Nations (4:1–2)
	- 2. The Consequence: Shalom, Satiety, Security (4:3–4)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-467-4"></span><span id="page-467-0"></span>4:1 This new announcement looks to the future, to the end of history, for this is what "the latter days" means here. By the time of Micah this phrase had become a technical term for the age in which God's kingdom would break into the historical realm and eventually end it (cf. Jer. 48:47; 49:39; Dan. 10:14; Hos. 3:5). In contrast to the corruption of Micah's day, the temple will become raised to the highest height at the end of history. It will become visible all around and will be a magnet to the nations, as they will literally "river" (ESV "flow") up the mountain from which they hear the law (*torah*) proclaimed.

<span id="page-467-5"></span><span id="page-467-3"></span><span id="page-467-1"></span>4:2 Previously, the law had not been proclaimed (the priests' job), nor were revealed words from the Lord delivered (the prophets' job), nor were the Lord's laws and words administered in society (the political and judicial leaders' job) (3:1–4, 5–8, 9–11). In the "latter days," however, things will be different as Yahweh will be the teacher and the prophet; the nations will take notice and desire to hear this teaching and walk in his ways.

<span id="page-467-6"></span>4:3 When the nations come to hear Yahweh, they will be dissatisfied with their own ways, which have been caused by idolatry and have led to war. Yahweh will "judge between" them, not in terms of condemning them but in terms of correcting them. Yahweh will speak the truth to them, leading to a transformation in the most conspicuous way possible among peoples. They will give up the practice of war for the practice of peace. Instruments used for war and killing will be transformed into instruments for producing life—developing agriculture so that people might have food.28 The result is that war will become obsolete.

<sup>28</sup> A pruning hook was a tool with a sharp curved blade to remove dead tissue from plants so that they might flourish and grow more fruitfully.

<span id="page-468-4"></span><span id="page-468-2"></span><span id="page-468-0"></span>4:4 In the absence of war, every man will dwell under his own vine and fig tree in complete security, without fear. These agrarian metaphors are probably meant to echo the garden of Eden and the promised messianic age (Gen. 49:11). Centuries before, Solomon's early rule of peace and plenty for everyone had realized this reality to some degree (1 Kings 4:25), and the prophet Zechariah predicts that it will be the mark of forgiveness and healing of the land in the coming kingdom of Yahweh (Zech. 3:10). There will be no need for war because all will have followed the law and will be satisfied.

<span id="page-468-6"></span>This new situation is not just a figment of Micah's imagination: "The mouth of the Lord of hosts has spoken." This is the only time in Micah that Yahweh is called the "Lord of hosts"; the name indicates that Yahweh commands all of the heavenly armies—he is the commander-in-chief. The Septuagint sometimes translates this title with "Lord Almighty" (cf. 2 Sam. 7:8; Gk. *kyrios pantokratōr*), indicating omnipotence.29 This title guarantees the fulfillment of the announcement.

<span id="page-468-5"></span><span id="page-468-1"></span>4:5 This verse returns the audience to the present and the current practice of idolatry among the nations. Is it any wonder they are at war? They all walk in the names of their own gods. War is a result, finally, of idolatry, as is all brokenness and sin in this world. When people lose the center, all hell breaks loose: "Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold" (Yeats). In view of these facts, Micah urges Judah to get its act together so that they may be a beacon to the nations now. If they walk now in the name of Yahweh, they will be a sign of a peaceful future amid the present warring world. Perhaps when the nations see them listening to the Torah and the true prophets and putting their words into practice, they will see the divine intention for the world realized and will give up their warlike practices.

### *Response*

Micah's call to Judah to respond to the future in the present shows clearly the purpose of prophecy. It is not primarily to give abstract information about the future; it speaks, rather, to the present—rebuking, challenging, warning, comforting, healing. Thus this passage reveals God's ultimate plan for the world, against the backdrop of the worst possible nightmare for ancient Judah—the announcement of the destruction of the temple (3:12). Out of this darkness comes a brilliant flash of the sun.

<span id="page-468-7"></span><span id="page-468-3"></span>Some NT evidence suggests an analogy between the destruction of the old Zion and its temple and the birth of a new city on a hill and a new temple. For example, on the verge of his own death, Jesus purges the temple and prophesies its destruction, along with the city of Jerusalem (Matt. 21:12–16; 24:1–21). But he himself prophesied that if the temple was destroyed, he would raise it up after three days (John 2:13–22). He was speaking of the temple of his body, the final locus of God's presence, to which the temple building pointed. Further, the new Zion consists of Christ's disciples, likened to a city set on a hill, displaying the light of God's glory

<span id="page-468-8"></span><sup>29</sup> Stephen G. Dempster, "The Lord Is His Name: A Study of the Distribution of the Names and Titles of God in the Book of Amos," *Revue Biblique* 98 (1991) 170–189.

<span id="page-469-4"></span><span id="page-469-2"></span>through good works, which leads others to glorify God (Matt. 5:13–16). What is more, Paul suggests that the church, consisting of both Jew and Gentile, is the new temple, announcing God's presence to the world (Eph. 2:18–22). Finally, it may be noted that this presence is predominantly one of peace (Eph. 2:14, 15, 17).

<span id="page-469-3"></span>There are myriad examples in which the church has manifested this peace. One striking recent example comes from Mozambique. An Anglican bishop named Dinis Sengulane decided to do something about the proliferation of arms in his country near the end of a civil war that had decimated the nation. He went to every province and asked people what they thought might jeopardize peace in the future. One person responded, "Guns. We have so many guns in our hands. Both sides have been very generous in dishing out guns just like that, so when peace comes, are those guns going to be just left alone?"30 The bishop was not prepared for this question, but after much prayer and reflection on the books of Micah and Isaiah, he announced that disarmament would begin, issuing a request that guns be returned to collection centers throughout the land. Many of the guns were made into instruments for production, so that rifles became saxophones, while gunstocks were used to make chairs and other furniture. Since this program started, over one million guns and other weapons have been collected and transformed. The program was called Turning Swords into Ploughshares. If this can be done in the war-torn country of Mozambique, imagine what could happen if Christians in other countries got their act together and heard the call to be emissaries of peace so that weapons were no longer needed for protection or peace.

## MICAH 4:6–7

- <span id="page-469-0"></span>**<sup>6</sup>** In that day, declares the Lord, I will assemble the lame and gather those who have been driven away and those whom I have afflicted;
- **<sup>7</sup>** and the lame I will make the remnant, and those who were cast off, a strong nation; and the Lord will reign over them in Mount Zion from this time forth and forevermore.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-469-1"></span>This is the first of a sequence of salvation oracles (matched by one with a similar opening formula in 5:10–15; cf. comments). Yahweh transforms a group of motley survivors of the judgment into the beginning of his new kingdom on earth.

<sup>30</sup> "Mozambique: The Bishop Who Smashed Guns At the Altar," http://allafrica.com/stories/201403211253.html.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-470-3"></span>II.C. The Pathway to the Glory (4:6–5:15)
	- 1. The Future: The Weak Made Strong in Yahweh's New Kingdom (4:6–7)
		- a. The Survival of the Weakest (4:6)
		- b. The Weak Made Strong (4:7)

## <span id="page-470-4"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-470-2"></span>4:6 The introductory formula "In that day" specifies the time in which the predicted actions will take place. In this case, it refers back to the temporal formula beginning the previous oracle: "In the latter days." The gathering of the weak thus occurs in the general period that marks the end of history and the intervention of Yahweh's new world order. The clause "I will assemble . . . and gather" indicates that Yahweh will bring his remnant back from exile. The promise was already made in 2:12, but here adjectives are added: the ones gathered are the "lame . . . driven away . . . afflicted." Micah may intend for his audience to hear in the first adjective the story of Jacob—of when he struggled with God and was crippled but was made into a new man, Israel, when he returned home (Genesis 32). The same will happen to the exiles—they will become Yahweh's new people. Though they have been driven away and punished by God, they will be assembled and gathered. They are the most unlikely raw material with which to build a new nation. The Lord will not forget his covenant; he will rescue and renew his people.

<span id="page-470-1"></span><span id="page-470-0"></span>4:7 Yahweh shapes this motley group of survivors—the lame—into a remnant, that is, a core of his people who will be the recipients of his action in the world. They will become in many ways a mighty force in history. The parallel line reinforces this, as the lame are referred to as those who had been cast off but are now made into a strong nation. The word "lame" may be used again to emphasize Israel's origins, and the word "strong nation" does the same by evoking the promise to Abraham that he would become a great nation through which all the nations would be blessed (Gen. 12:1–3; 18:18). This makes clear that Yahweh has done this because of his commitment to the covenant. It is Yahweh who brings about this transformation. And it is he who will reign over them in "Mount Zion from this time forth and forevermore." The language intentionally echoes the previous oracle about Zion and Micah's exhortation to the people to walk under Yahweh's rule forever and ever. Thus this oracle probably signals the beginning of the time when Zion will be elevated. Yahweh will first bring the remnant back and restore his rule to Zion, and then he will issue the Torah to the nations.

## *Response*

This text is an OT example of Paul's statement to the Corinthians:

Consider your calling, brothers: not many of you were wise according to worldly standards, not many were powerful, not many were of noble birth. But God chose what is foolish in the world to shame the wise; God chose what is weak in the world to shame the strong; God chose what is low and despised in the world, even things that are not, to bring to nothing things that are, so that no human being might boast in the presence of God. (1 Cor. 1:26–29)

<span id="page-471-3"></span>In reading these words, it is natural to think of what we read in the Gospels as well. When Christ called the twelve disciples, he again gathered the lowly and weak to reconstitute a remnant, which would become a great nation, a new twelve tribes of Israel. Fishermen, tax collectors, prostitutes, sinners, "outsiders" were among the first members of this remnant (Mark 1:16–20; Matt. 9:1–13; Luke 7:36–50). Jesus did not choose the powerful and strong.

<span id="page-471-2"></span><span id="page-471-0"></span>In the contemporary church, the concern for status, prestige, and size, as well as for hoping to attract the "right type" of people, continues to mark many congregations, but seeking these qualities is plainly at odds with what God is doing in the building of his kingdom. The lame, the exiles, the blind, the nothings of this world constitute the stuff of which the kingdom is made. Martin Luther once remarked, on Genesis 1:1, "God created the world out of nothing. As long as you are not yet nothing, God cannot make something out of you."31 The church must never forget its roots. It constitutes the community not merely of the crippled but also of the crucified. Living out of its weakness, the church then becomes strong, a mighty nation over whom the crucified God rules.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-472-1"></span>This unit of salvation speeches consists of four oracles oriented to the present time of suffering and crisis (4:8, 9–10, 11–13; 5:1). In the first three, the crisis is resolved; in the last (5:1), the crisis is left unresolved in order to bring it into sharp contrast with the next major unit, the arrival of the Messiah and his work (5:2–9).

## <span id="page-472-4"></span>*Section Outline*
