		- b. The Present Crisis—The Birth Pangs of Redemption (4:9–10)
		- c. The Nations Defeated (4:11–13)
		- d. Judah's Leader—The House of David Humiliated (5:1)

### <span id="page-472-3"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-472-0"></span>4:8 "Tower of the flock" and "hill of the daughter of Zion" point to Jerusalem, and both phrases perhaps evoke memories of David when he first captured and ruled the city. "Daughter of Zion" is a clear reference to Jerusalem elsewhere (e.g., Isa. 10:32), and "hill"—sometimes translated by the ESV as "Ophel"—refers to the hill

<span id="page-473-1"></span><span id="page-473-0"></span>between the original Davidic city (that is, Jerusalem when it was first conquered by David) and the temple built later (2 Chron. 27:3; 33:14). "Tower of the flock" is parallel to this, perhaps referring to a tower on (or very near to) that hill. Since towers could be defensive structures (Judg. 9:51), and "flock" is easily associated with David (the shepherd-king), this may be another allusion to David and hence a reminder of the promise of an eternal Davidic King. It is no surprise, then, that the end of the verse makes clear reference to Jerusalem's being restored to a place from which kingship will be exercised. In short, these allusions to David in the past suggest hope for the future, as the former Davidic kingdom will reemerge in Zion. The little flock will be led by a new Davidic Shepherd-King.

<span id="page-473-3"></span>4:9 If the first oracle predicts future Davidic leadership, the second oracle indicates absence of leadership in the present time. This is the force of the rhetorical questions, which are an implicit criticism of King Hezekiah and the Davidic dynasty. The nation has probably been decimated by the Assyrians in 701 BC, and Jerusalem is the last holdout. The acute pain the people of the city feel is compared to birth pangs seizing a pregnant woman.

<span id="page-473-4"></span>4:10 This verse continues the image of a woman in painful labor in order to describe the pain of conquest, capture, and exile to Babylon. (The actual exile to Babylon did not occur until about a hundred years later, in 586 BC, suggesting this is a long-range prophecy for Micah.) But these pangs will give birth to new life, as the exiles will be rescued and redeemed from their enemies by the Lord, their redeemer.

<span id="page-473-5"></span>4:11 The present crisis in which Jerusalem is surrounded shows the armies' desire to destroy Zion. The phrase "Let her be defiled, and let our eyes gaze upon Zion" is well explained by Elizabeth Achtemeier: "The humiliation and defeat of Israel is often pictured in the terms of a woman stripped naked before her lovers or captors (cf. esp. Nah. 3:5, but also Isa. 47:3; Lam. 1:8; Ezek. 16:37 . . . )."32 It is humiliating and shameful defeat that these nations want to accomplish.

<span id="page-473-6"></span><span id="page-473-2"></span>4:12 But the nations—a metaphorical description of the Assyrian army and its many mercenaries—do not know that Yahweh has planned to thwart their intentions. He has actually gathered them as grain for the threshing floor. The tables will be turned!

<span id="page-473-7"></span>4:13 The prophet provides a long description of this dramatic reversal. The threshing image is continued with intensity here, as the daughter of Zion is compared to an ox with horns of iron and hooves of bronze. In antiquity—and even today such animals would help separate the wheat from the chaff by trampling the sheaves of grain on the threshing floor. Here Zion is an ox "on steroids," and the grain is the Assyrian army. At the end of this battle, the wealth of the nations will be "devoted" to the Lord. To devote the wealth of an enemy to God was often the

<sup>32</sup> Elizabeth Achtemeier, *Minor Prophets I* (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker, 1996), 335.

<span id="page-474-0"></span>last action in holy war (cf. Josh. 6:17). This crushing defeat of the enemy and the salvation of Zion may refer to the withdrawal of Sennacherib and his army from Jerusalem in 701 BC. Whatever the exact battle, it is clear that ultimate power for victory comes from the fact that Zion is protected by the "Lord of the whole earth," the ultimate King and Savior.

<span id="page-474-5"></span><span id="page-474-2"></span><span id="page-474-1"></span>5:1 The command to muster troops to Judah must have seemed like a joke, with the Assyrian armies encamped just outside the gates of Jerusalem. In fact, the Assyrian emissary outside the walls of Zion taunted the people with a boast that he would give two thousand horses to Hezekiah if he could find the men to ride them (2 Kings 18:23). The humiliation of bypassing the king and his officials and going directly to the people of Jerusalem with an appeal to surrender must also have been a great disgrace—a slap on the face—to Hezekiah (2 Kings 18:26–27). Indeed, we read here in Micah 5:1 that the "judge" (*shopet*) of the city is struck on the face with a "rod" (*shebet*). The leader in view is likely Hezekiah, who is not even given the respect of the title "king." Moreover, to strike someone on the face was an act of extreme degradation (Job 16:10; Lam. 3:30). And while this passage is speaking of a metaphorical indignity (as opposed to Hezekiah's being literally struck), it is strong way of saying that the king is being treated by the enemy with great disrespect.

### <span id="page-474-3"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-474-4"></span>This text underscores through the beginning oracle (Mic. 4:8) that the future of the new kingdom is not in doubt, yet there will be fiery trials through which the seeds of the kingdom will have to pass before they can grow into a fruitful tree that gives life to the rest of the world. The present is in some ways a crucible of suffering: attack, conquest, captivity, exile, and humiliation. But this is not the last word. All of this suffering is compared to a pregnant woman in labor—it will finally end in the birth and joy of new life.

<span id="page-474-7"></span>Christian believers are in no way exempt from this type of suffering. One merely has to read about the lives of the early Christian apostles. All except one was reputed to have been martyred. Suffering became such a badge of Christian discipleship that Paul wrote to Timothy, "All who . . . live a godly life in Christ Jesus will be persecuted" (2 Tim. 3:12). Paul in fact used the image of the birth pangs associated with labor to describe the present suffering of both the entire creation and the believer, before the final glory will be revealed:

We know that the whole creation has been groaning together in the pains of childbirth until now. And not only the creation, but we ourselves, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we wait eagerly for adoption as sons, the redemption of our bodies. (Rom. 8:22–23)

<span id="page-474-6"></span>Thus the present time, between the first and second coming of the Messiah, is often a time of suffering and exile, persecution and death. Christians often emphasize

<span id="page-475-2"></span><span id="page-475-1"></span>the victory and triumph of the Christian life, but the "already" of the kingdom should not be confused with the kingdom in all of its fullness and power. There is still the "not yet." Rather than being discouraged, believers must realize that their final victory will come, and they can hope in their faithful, covenant God in the midst of crisis. All of their enemies will one day be completely defeated, just as they are here in Micah. The suffering martyrs in the book of Revelation cry, "How long?" (Rev. 6:10), but someday their anguish will give way to a new world of God's glory, as the last adversaries—Satan, sin, and death—will be finally defeated by Jesus, the ultimate Shepherd-King (Rev. 19:11–21).

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-476-4"></span><span id="page-476-3"></span>This new section has a structure similar to the previous one: both start with "you" (4:8; 5:2), and both continue to a series of oracles. But there are important differences. While the previous section described present suffering (4:8–5:1), this section anticipates the future (note the use of "shall" in 5:2–9) and explains why salvation from the present suffering is delayed (5:3).

## *Comment*

5:2 As in the previous section (cf. 4:8), this first oracle begins with a focus on the future Davidic kingdom (5:2–4) before moving to the events that will transpire before the end arrives (vv. 4–9).

<span id="page-476-8"></span><span id="page-476-5"></span><span id="page-476-2"></span><span id="page-476-1"></span><span id="page-476-0"></span>Whereas Zion was addressed as "you" in the previous section (4:8), the small town of Bethlehem is the addressee now (5:2). Its location is further clarified by the name "Ephrathah," which specifies the district in which the town was located, thus distinguishing it from another Bethlehem in the north (cf. Josh. 19:15). The insignificance of Bethlehem in the south is emphasized ("too little to be among the clans of Judah"). A "clan" was a large group of families, which combined with other such groups to form a tribe. The term is here used poetically for the town of Bethlehem, with a focus on the smallness of the city. It was so small and insignificant, in fact, that it did not appear in the list of forty-six cities in the tribe of Judah in Joshua 15:20–63. But it bore Davidic associations, as this was David's hometown, and the tribe of Judah had messianic links, as an ancient prophecy predicted that a universal ruler would emerge from this tribe (Gen. 49:8–12). The reference to a ruler over Israel in Micah 5:2 is a direct echo of the prophecy of a future heir

<span id="page-477-2"></span><span id="page-477-1"></span>for David, who would come (2 Sam. 7:12) from his body and establish an eternal kingdom (2 Sam. 7:13–14). Thus this particular individual, whose "coming forth is from of old" is now the object of Micah's prophecy.

<span id="page-477-6"></span>5:3 But the birth of this Davidic King must wait until the nation is given over to its enemies: "He [that is, the Lord] shall give them up until the time when she who is in labor has given birth." There must be a delay. But when the King is born, there will be a new unity among the people of God.

<span id="page-477-7"></span>5:4 The might and power of this new King are emphasized, as well as his universal rule. He stands—not sits—and actively shepherds his people. This reference to the King's acting as a shepherd was a common motif in the ancient Near East. The Egyptian pharaohs were often depicted carrying a shepherd's staff; in one building inscription Pharaoh Sesostris I states, "He begat me to do what should be done for him, to accomplish what he commands to do, He appointed me shepherd of this land, knowing him who would herd it for him."33 Similarly, the prologue to the Code of Hammurabi portrays the king as a shepherd of his people:

I am the salvation-bearing shepherd, whose staff is straight, the good shadow that is spread over my city; on my breast I cherish the inhabitants of the land of Sumer and Akkad; in my shelter I have let them repose in peace; in my deep wisdom have I enclosed them.34

The shepherd was thus a symbol of power and salvation.

<span id="page-477-5"></span><span id="page-477-0"></span>Significantly, however, this King will shepherd not in his own strength but in the strength of God. The majesty of God will overwhelm any potential threats to the flock (cf. Ex. 15:7; Isa. 2:10), resulting in the security of the people. Their safety is a clear echo of the promise of a time in which the temple will be exalted in the last days and every person will dwell without fear under his own vine and fig tree (Mic. 4:4). Moreover, just as the temple was pictured as elevated to the supreme place in the world (4:1), the new King will be "great to the ends of the earth" (5:4). Thus temple and King will dominate the universe. It is clear that in some way the temple's elevation and the King's elevation will coincide, and the King's rule will extend to the rest of the world.

<span id="page-477-8"></span><span id="page-477-4"></span>5:5 "He shall be their peace" could also be translated, "He will be the one of peace." This suggests a formal title for an agent of peace, with ancient Near Eastern precedent for this use of the phrase.35 Micah's contemporary Isaiah lists a similar title for this King, calling him the "Prince of Peace" (Isa. 9:6).

<span id="page-477-3"></span>This announcement of future peace prefaces the Assyrian threat. Assyria probably refers not only to the nation of Assyria—the clear and present danger in Micah's time—but also by extension to other enemies of God. Thus these enemies

<sup>33</sup> Miriam Lichtheim et al., *Ancient Egyptian Literature: Volume I: The Old and Middle Kingdoms*, 2nd rev. ed. (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2006), 116.

<sup>34</sup> James B. Pritchard, *Ancient Near Eastern Texts Relating to the Old Testament with Supplement*, 3rd ed. (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1969), 163.

<sup>35</sup> Kevin J. Cathcart, "Notes on Micah 5:4–5," *Bib* 49 (1968): 511–514.

who have invaded Judah will have the tables turned on them, and many shepherds from Judah will be raised against them. The formula "seven shepherds . . . eight princes" is a poetic way of describing a large number of leaders. The rule of the one shepherd will produce the rule of many against his enemies.

<span id="page-478-5"></span>5:6 These shepherds will "shepherd the land of Assyria with the sword, and the land of Nimrod at its entrances." "At its entrances" should perhaps be translated "with its drawn sword" (NIV); this involves only a slight change in the Hebrew and makes for smoother parallelism. "Land of Nimrod" is another term for Assyria, highlighting that it was a land noted for titanic defiance, as Nimrod was the builder of the ancient Tower of Babel (Gen. 10:9–10). But it does not matter how strong they are; they are no match for the King of Peace, to which the text now returns. It is "he" (the King) who will deliver the people when "he" (the Assyrian) attacks the land.

<span id="page-478-6"></span><span id="page-478-4"></span><span id="page-478-0"></span>5:7 In contrast to the strength of Assyria, the scene shifts to the scattered remnant, which is lame and crippled (4:6–7) among the nations. Despite this weakness, the remnant will be a boon to the nations, like refreshing dew and showers of rain. Just as the onset of the dew and rain does not wait for human consent, nor is it delayed by human will, so this refreshment for the nations will assuredly come. Interestingly, one of the first references to dew in Scripture is found in a blessing upon the patriarch Jacob (Gen. 27:28). The dew of heaven would pour down on him, with one consequence being that he would be a blessing to those who blessed him (Gen. 27:29). The Jacob who would become a cripple was called to be a blessing. The nature of this blessing suggests that, just as dew's appearing is irrevocable, God's blessing upon his people is irrevocable.

<span id="page-478-7"></span><span id="page-478-2"></span><span id="page-478-1"></span>5:8 The remnant will also be a bane to the nations that oppose them. The survivors will be like a raging lion who will ravage and rend in ferocity and strength. This text echoes the patriarchal blessing upon Judah to be like a lion who would rule the nations (Gen. 49:8–12).

<span id="page-478-8"></span><span id="page-478-3"></span>5:9 This verse may also be translated as a prayer for the remnant: "May your hand be lifted up over your adversaries, and may all your enemies be cut off." In either case, it is clear that the Lord is the one who will do so. Indeed, "cut off" becomes the leading word in the next major oracle (v. 10); the Lord has indeed brought it to pass.

## <span id="page-478-9"></span>*Response*

The birth of the Shepherd-King is clearly a turning point, showing his lowly beginnings and his gradual dominion. His dominion does not come about all at once, yet it results in the destruction of Israel's great enemy, Assyria, which has clearly become a symbol of evil, as it is called the Land of Nimrod, a place of primeval rebellion against God. The birth of this Shepherd-King results in the sending of shepherds to this land of evil to conquer it.

<span id="page-479-3"></span><span id="page-479-2"></span>The birth of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem is seen in the NT as the clear fulfillment of this prophecy, indicating that he is the Shepherd-King who will bring peace to the world (Matt. 2:6–7). Coming amid incredible suffering and evil, Jesus' birth demonstrates that Israel's long exilic existence is finally coming to an end. Jesus reconstitutes Israel by his choice of twelve disciples, who represent the twelve tribes. This is a remnant and the nucleus of a new nation (Matt. 10:1–4). Moreover, this new King of Israel reigns from a cross, and through his death and resurrection he is the peacemaker par excellence, bringing peace between God and humanity (Rom. 5:1–2) and between races and enemies (Eph. 2:14–22). But he is not only the peacemaker; he is also the Good Shepherd who even gives his life for the sheep (John 10:1–16). He is the Chief Shepherd who will appear at the last day to bring an end to history (1 Pet. 5:4), as peace and righteousness will be established unto the ends of the earth (Mic. 5:4; 2 Pet. 3:13).

<span id="page-479-7"></span><span id="page-479-6"></span><span id="page-479-5"></span><span id="page-479-4"></span><span id="page-479-0"></span>The church needs to realize that it need not fear its enemy; as a result of the command of its Shepherd-King, even the gates of hell (e.g., Assyria) will not be able to withstand its attack. It also needs to remember that the gospel is an aroma of God to two types of people: a fragrance of death to those who continue in their sin, but one of life to those who repent (2 Cor. 2:15–16). It is the task of the church to be a dew of blessing wherever it goes among the nations, but it is also to be an implacable foe of evil. It is clear, however, that whatever success it has is a result of divine empowerment. In a very real sense the little remnant is a messianic community, in which the Spirit of the Shepherd-King is exerting his will and power.

- **<sup>10</sup>** And in that day, declares the Lord, I will cut off your horses from among you and will destroy your chariots;
- **<sup>11</sup>** and I will cut off the cities of your land and throw down all your strongholds;
- **<sup>12</sup>** and I will cut off sorceries from your hand, and you shall have no more tellers of fortunes;

- **<sup>14</sup>** and I will root out your Asherah images from among you and destroy your cities.
- **<sup>15</sup>** And in anger and wrath I will execute vengeance on the nations that did not obey.

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-480-5"></span><span id="page-480-4"></span>The formulaic beginning "In that day, declares the Lord" clearly links this oracle with its companion in 4:6–7, with exactly the same terminology beginning both sections. Thus this final oracle represents the completion of the entire section (4:6–5:15), which is essentially detailing how the temple will become the supreme and central place in the world, where the will of God will be paramount and peace will reign. Thus there is now a shift from the remnant and a prayer for the destruction of enemies, to a final answer to that prayer: the destruction of everything that is in implacable opposition to God. Indeed, the word "destroy" is the dominating theme of this entire text (5:10–15). Verbs indicating destruction occur eight times in these six verses, recurring with great rapidity and intensity in order to convey comprehensive destruction.

		- a. Demilitarization (5:10–11)
		- b. De-Idolization (5:12–14)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-480-6"></span><span id="page-480-3"></span><span id="page-480-2"></span>5:10 "That day" is connected with the general end of history (4:1, 6). The first thing "that day" ushers in is the destruction of horses and chariots, important offensive weapons in the arsenals of ancient nations. This focus on chariots recalls the military city of Lachish, which first taught Judah to sin (1:13) by spawning excessive trust in military power. Placing trust in horses and chariots was always a temptation for ancient Israel (Ps. 20:7).

<span id="page-480-7"></span><span id="page-480-1"></span>5:11 There is a shift here from offensive weapons to defensive fortifications. The "cities" here are probably fortified cities, as the parallel "strongholds" makes clear. The word for "stronghold" suggests inaccessibility, as such a place was fenced or walled off in order to provide security. Lachish was a formidable stronghold, as it boasted two surrounding walls for extra fortification. Such walls, which were sometimes 30 feet (9 m) thick and over 20 feet (6 m) high, would seem impregnable and would tempt people to trust in *them* rather than in the living God. But these will not protect anyone when *God* comes to destroy such illusions.

<span id="page-480-8"></span><span id="page-480-0"></span>5:12 There is now a shift from destroying objects of military strength to destroying objects and practices of false worship; in both cases the Lord is tearing down that in which the people are wrongly trusting. In ancient Israel, sorcerers and fortune-tellers represented illicit ways of determining the future or accessing the divine (Deut. 18:10–14). Such practices were condemned, since they demonstrated a lack of trust in God's will and his Word. Sorcerers may have manipulated devices in their hands in practicing their craft, but such instruments would be "cut off" from their hands. All such methods of false trust will come to an end.

<span id="page-481-5"></span><span id="page-481-1"></span>5:13 Yahweh will then destroy all idols. Thus the destruction of all the idols in Samaria (1:7) was but a prelude to the destruction of all idolatry. The idols may have represented male gods and their consorts. The male god ("carved images") may have been represented by an upright stone, and the female god by a wooden pole or tree ("pillars"), representing fertility.

<span id="page-481-6"></span><span id="page-481-0"></span>5:14 Asherah was the name of a female fertility goddess, often depicted by a tree (cf. Deut. 16:21) as a symbol of life. Recent archaeological evidence documents these practices from Micah's time, and these idolatrous customs are particularly linked with "cities."36

<span id="page-481-7"></span><span id="page-481-3"></span>5:15 After a complete destruction of all of the objects of false trust, the pathway will be cleared for the proclamation of peace to the nations. The temple will be exalted and Yahweh will hold supreme sway. Many of the nations will come and meet Yahweh and transform their spears and swords into pruning hooks and plows (cf. 4:3). But for those who will not, judgment awaits. The word for "vengeance" indicates a judicial decision by the sovereign Lord in accord with his character as a just ruler. Without such final action his rule would be marred by injustice and chaos.37

#### *Response*

The final work of the Messiah is depicted here. In order to bring peace to the world, he will use violence—not for the sake of violence itself but because sometimes violent injustice may be ended only with violent justice. "God's use of violence, inevitable in a violent world, is intended to subvert human violence in order to bring the creation along to a point where violence is no more."38

<span id="page-481-4"></span>This text, and this whole section in which it is embedded, also stresses the importance of complete trust in Yahweh. It describes how items of false hope, whether in terms of military might (5:10–11) or of idolatry (5:12–14), will be utterly destroyed. It also emphasizes that salvation will come only through Yahweh (4:1–5, 6–7, 8–10, 11–13; 5:1–4, 5–6, 7, 8, 9–14). It is thus complete folly to trust in anything or anyone else.39

<span id="page-481-2"></span>The Christian church is always in danger of trusting in its own strength (budgets, programs, strategies), seeking wisdom and knowledge from extrabiblical sources (pundits, politicians, and experts), or replacing the living God with idols (leaders, buildings, traditions). But these represent a failure to trust in the living God and his Holy Spirit. For the church to be an effective witness to the outside world, it always stands in need of reformation. The NT makes it clear that God disciplines his church in order to refine it, that it might be the light it needs to be, to shine amid the surrounding world. Thus, e.g., Corinthian believers were

<sup>36</sup> Knud Jeppesen, "Micah 5:13 in the Light of a Recent Archaeological Discovery," *VT* 34 (1984): 462–466. 37 George Mendenhall, *The Tenth Generation: The Origins of the Biblical Tradition* (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 1974).

<sup>38</sup> Terence E. Fretheim, "'I Was Only a Little Angry': Divine Violence in the Prophets," *Int* 58 (2004): 371.

<sup>39</sup> D. J. Bryant, "Micah 4:14–5:14: An Exegesis," *ResQ* 21 (1978): 230.

<span id="page-482-5"></span>dying because of their partaking of the Lord's Supper in an unworthy manner (1 Cor. 11:28–30).

<span id="page-482-10"></span><span id="page-482-9"></span><span id="page-482-8"></span><span id="page-482-7"></span><span id="page-482-6"></span>Discipline may not be pleasant, but it is necessary for the church and its witness to the nations (Heb. 12:5–11). Indeed, some of the last words of Jesus to his churches in Revelation are words of rebuke and discipline (Rev. 2:4, 14–16; 3:19). These churches were to be lights shining in the dark to a needy world (Rev. 1:20), but Christ threatened to remove them unless they repented (Rev. 2:5). With repentance and reformation, however, they could become beacons lighting up the darkness, waiting in hope for that day in which God's light would light up the entire world (Rev. 21:23).

## <span id="page-482-1"></span>OVERVIEW OF MICAH 6:1–7:20

This final section intensifies and amplifies Micah's central theme of judgment and salvation. The indictments are no longer aimed at individual groups within the nation but rather are directed to the people as a whole. The nation has utterly missed the entire point of being Yahweh's people. They have not realized that Yahweh has saved them for a life of relationship with him (walking with him), loving mercy and practicing justice. They have mistakenly thought they could show extraordinary faith by making one-time sacrifices instead of by living a life of love and service.

<span id="page-482-4"></span><span id="page-482-3"></span><span id="page-482-2"></span><span id="page-482-0"></span>This section contains four major units. It begins with an argument with the people to show the main point of their calling from God: fellowship with him, love, and justice (6:1–8). It then demonstrates that they have kept fellowship with notorious kings instead of with God, and their lives are marked by violence instead of love, injustice instead of justice (6:9–16). This leads to a natural consequence: the entire society is corrupt and thus ripe for judgment (7:1–7). Finally, from this lament over the totality and reality of corruption, the prophet personifies the nation as he confesses and acknowledges sin and hopes in God and his sure promises (7:8–20). This last composition contains themes from each part of the book, using them to produce a resounding crescendo of salvation.

## *Section Overview*

This text is a classic representative of what scholars call a "covenant lawsuit." A key Hebrew word marking such a genre is "case/indictment" (*rib*; 6:1–2). The prophets used this genre to show that Yahweh had a legal case against Israel. In this genre, the prophets often took the role of prosecutors, while Israel was the defendant. Here, creation itself is called as witness (vv. 1–2), and the reason for the case is laid out: God's people have become weary with him despite his being utterly

<span id="page-484-8"></span><span id="page-484-0"></span>faithful and wonderful to them (vv. 3–5). To the lawsuit is added a text fashioned like an "entrance liturgy" to the temple (vv. 6–8; cf. Psalms 15; 24), indicating the requirements of correct worship—what God really desires. These requirements are expressed both negatively, in terms of what he does not want (Mic. 6:6–7), and positively, in terms of what he desires (v. 8).

## <span id="page-484-9"></span><span id="page-484-6"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-484-3"></span>6:1 Micah is told to plead his case against the people of God, while the most enduring elements of reality, the ancient mountains and hills, are enlisted as witnesses. Micah is in the role of a prosecutor, and God is the Judge. There has been much talk of courts and corruption in Micah (3:1–4, 9–11), but here finally is the "supreme court."

<span id="page-484-4"></span><span id="page-484-1"></span>6:2 Micah now calls the mountains and the everlasting foundations of the earth to the witness stand. This stress on the mountains, which are the heights of creation, along with the everlasting foundations, which are its depths, suggests that all of inanimate creation is being called to hear Yahweh's case against his people. The Hebrew word for "contend" was last used when the nations would meet Yahweh in the temple in the last days, leading to their transformation ("shall decide"; 4:3). It is a word with a legal background, suggesting debate in court, accusation, and conviction (cf. "lodging a charge against"; 6:2, NIV).

<span id="page-484-5"></span><span id="page-484-2"></span>6:3 The vocative "O my people," positioned at the front of the sentence, shows the emotion of Yahweh for his people, as well as his love for them. It points to exasperation, which the rest of the sentence intensifies. Yahweh is presented not so much as being angry with his people but rather as being confused. He wants to know what he has done to make them feel so weary with him. Somehow, his liberating them from Egypt (cf. v. 4) has become a heavy burden for them to bear. The command "Answer me!" is an eruption of frustration.

<span id="page-484-7"></span>6:4 This sentence explicitly contradicts the people's view; the Hebrew verbal expression "I brought you up" (*heʻelitika*) sounds like "I wearied you" (*hel'etika*) but has a totally different meaning. God did not weary them (v. 3)—he liberated them (v. 4)! Moreover, he provided guidance for them in the wilderness through the political leadership of Moses, the priestly authority of Aaron, and the prophetic direction of Miriam.

<span id="page-485-9"></span><span id="page-485-5"></span><span id="page-485-3"></span><span id="page-485-2"></span>6:5 The vocative "O my people" again stresses Yahweh's emotional intensity. He commands them to remember his final actions for them, which included deliverance from the occult specialist Balaam, hired by Balak, the Moabite king, to curse them when they were on the verge of entering the Promised Land (Numbers 22– 24). "Shittim" represents the last place where Israel settled outside the Promised Land (Num. 25:1; Josh. 2:1), and "Gilgal" the point of entry into the Promised Land (Josh. 4:19). The names together are thus a "summary of sacred history, lead[ing] from Exodus to conquest, from promise to fulfillment."40 Thus God has brought about the exodus, guided and delivered them in the wilderness, and led them victoriously in the conquest of the land, all done so that Israel might know the "righteous acts of the Lord."

<span id="page-485-10"></span>6:6–7 A series of questions indicates Yahweh's expectations for his people in light of his righteous acts on their behalf. The first pair of questions asks about the proper approach to Yahweh (v. 6a). They raise the perennial question of how to worship him properly. The term "bow myself" is a rare word, used mainly for individuals' groveling on the ground as a result of unfortunate circumstances (Pss. 57:6; 145:14; 146:8). But here it means proper deference before the Creator. He is described as "God on high," which occurs only here in the Bible and stresses God's transcendence.

<span id="page-485-11"></span><span id="page-485-8"></span>The next three pairs of questions are rhetorical. They escalate in intensity and are presented as answers to the question concerning the proper approach to Yahweh (Mic. 6:6b–7). The first pair of questions addresses burnt offerings (v. 6b), which were the most costly offering, since the entire animal was consumed in the fire and the worshiper received no portion. Year-old calves were the most valuable burnt offering, since their meat was the most tender. The answer to this pair of questions is obviously negative.

<span id="page-485-12"></span><span id="page-485-7"></span>The next pair mentions "thousands of rams" (v. 7a), which is clearly hyperbole, being far more than anyone but a king could afford (cf. 1 Kings 3:4; 8:63). "Ten thousands of rivers of oil" is further hyperbole, as oil was never used as an offering on its own. It functioned as a component of offerings; e.g., it was used in grain offerings, mixed with the flour or grain (Lev. 2:1–3, 15–16), and also for anointing rites (1 Sam. 10:1; Ps. 45:7). But such vast quantities suggested here were impossible to bring. Again the answer to this set of questions is negative.

<span id="page-485-13"></span><span id="page-485-6"></span><span id="page-485-4"></span><span id="page-485-0"></span>Finally, the most valuable gift possible is envisioned in the last, climactic pair of questions (Mic. 6:7b). "Firstborn" represents the special child that breaks open the womb and is the first sign of his father's strength. It therefore had a special status in ancient Israel, and the firstborn male child held a double portion of the inheritance (Deut. 21:17). He represented the future of the worshiper. The idea of atonement for sin is introduced here, for the assumption is that no one can approach God without a sacrifice for sin. But the answer to this last set of questions is also clearly negative—as the Lord made clear on numerous occasions by condemning the sacrifice of children (Lev. 18:21; Jer. 7:31; Ezek. 16:20–21).

<span id="page-485-1"></span><sup>40</sup> Delbert R. Hillers, *Micah: A Commentary on the Prophet Micah*, Hermeneia (Philadelphia: Fortress, 1984), 78.

Moreover, as Micah now makes clear, even if the religious rites were approved by the law, they could never accomplish atonement if they were not accompanied by a heart seeking to be faithful to the Lord's commands.

<span id="page-486-7"></span><span id="page-486-6"></span><span id="page-486-5"></span>6:8 In response to the three sets of expected negative answers, Micah now gives three positive answers, each also in escalating intensity. Yahweh requires the worshiper first to "do justice." The same expression occurs in Proverbs 21:15: "When justice is done, it is a joy to the righteous but terror to evildoers." A similar phrase is found in Proverbs 21:7: "The violence of the wicked will sweep them away, because they refuse to do what is just." To do justice is often to help someone in need, i.e., to be an advocate for one whose rights are being violated. Thus God is the ultimate just one, as he champions the cause of the widow and orphan and all who are oppressed (Deut. 10:18; Ps. 146:7). Solomon practiced justice by vindicating the rights of a prostitute, returning her stolen child (1 Kings 3:27–28). Thus justice is something that one primarily *does*. The word "justice" often occurs together with the word "righteousness," and together they point to the practice of justice in society (Gen. 18:19; Ps. 33:5; Prov. 21:3).41 One must be committed to helping those in need.

<span id="page-486-4"></span><span id="page-486-3"></span><span id="page-486-1"></span>Second, one is to "love kindness." This combination of verb and noun is unique in the OT, as the pious are usually described as *having* or *doing* kindness.42 The Hebrew word translated "kindness" is difficult to translate, as it connotes a range of ideas, such as "loyalty," "mercy," "fidelity," "steadfast love," or "loving kindness." It usually signifies help provided by a stronger to a weaker partner in a covenant relationship (the covenant relationship not always being necessary). To "love kindness" thus implies that helping someone in need should occupy a central place in one's heart and affections. Practicing justice is something that one does, but a lover of kindness is something that one *is*, and being the latter will surely result in doing the former. One does not help others primarily out of a sense of duty but because of a genuine desire to help.

<span id="page-486-0"></span>Third, the greatest requirement is to walk humbly with God. This indicates genuine fellowship, as seen in the lives of others who walked with God, such as Noah (Gen. 6:9) and Abraham (Gen. 17:1). To walk with God is to accept his vision and values for life, to fellowship with him. Thus one does this humbly, recognizing one's place before God on high.

There is clearly an inextricable link between these three requirements.43 As one walks humbly with God, one begins to love kindness and then to practice justice.

#### *Response*

God clearly did not call out his people, save them from bondage in Egypt, deliver and guide them in the wilderness, and lead them into the Promised Land so that

they could live for themselves and practice injustice. He did all these things so that they would know his righteous acts and begin to embody them in their lives. One-time offerings—even outlandish ones—totally missed the point if they were not accompanied by a life of fellowship with God and love for neighbor. God did not save a people so that they could be merely outwardly religious; he saved them to walk in close fellowship with him and to be his agents of mercy and love in the world.

Christians today must reflect carefully on this. Too often, we think that simply saying a sinner's prayer—a one-time commitment to the Lord at some point in our lives—is all that matters. Past moments of decision are of course important, but what the Lord calls us to is wholehearted obedience in the present. It is faithful living, not one-time religious deeds, that the Lord requires. Jesus rejected even spectacular works for God such as prophesying in his name, casting out demons, and doing many other mighty works if they were not accompanied by obedience (Matt. 7:22). In the end, it is all about getting to know Yahweh, acquiring his heart of steadfast love and kindness, and doing justice in the world. These are not oneoff acts but a total life commitment.

<span id="page-487-2"></span>This should make us ask, "What is our church concerned with?" Some churches may be concerned with fine performances of music, eloquent homilies by distinguished orators, or the magnificent art captured in stained glass displays. For other churches, the concerns might be centered more on quality praise and worship, large numbers in attendance, the ministry of the Spirit, or the hip pastor/speaker with a glass lectern and a bottle of Sierra Springs. There is nothing wrong with these things in and of themselves, but what of the concerns mentioned in Micah 6:8? Where do these fit? If someone challenges us with a concern for social justice and the poor, are we tempted to reply, "Stick to religious topics! Don't talk about everyday matters. Remain in the sacred realm where God's name is adored"?44 Micah would rebuke us vehemently. So would Jesus!

<span id="page-487-4"></span><span id="page-487-3"></span><span id="page-487-1"></span><span id="page-487-0"></span>When Jesus Christ laid down his life for his people, he did so in order that they could be filled with his Spirit and live a new life in which love, joy, peace, and other virtues pulsate through their lives (Gal. 5:22–23). Thus his people are called to be the body of Christ in the world (1 Corinthians 12), his feet and hands that bring and minister God's grace and peace, clothe the naked, welcome the stranger, visit the prisoner, and give a cup of cold water in Jesus' name, all flowing from a deep faith in Christ and what he has done (Matt. 5:42; cf. 25:31–45).

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-488-0"></span>This judgment oracle is closely linked to the previous unit, as its indictment (6:9–12, 16a) details transgressions against the specific requirements of God (v. 8). Instead of walking with God, the people have walked with Omri and Ahab; instead of loving kindness, they have loved violence; instead of practicing justice, they have cheated and stolen. Thus they are sentenced to complete and utter futility (vv. 13–15) and the desolation of exile (v. 16b).

## *Comment*

<span id="page-489-5"></span>6:9 The new oracle begins as the previous one did, with an appeal to listen as the voice of Yahweh calls out to the "city," probably referring to Jerusalem and its inhabitants, who represent Judah as a whole. Wisdom terminology is used here, focusing on practical success as a result of fearing Yahweh and listening to correction, even if it comes with the rod. Micah is suggesting that some of the judgment the people have experienced is the rod of Yahweh (Isa. 10:5; cf. Prov. 13:24; 22:15; 23:13–14), who seeks to bring about correction in the lives of the people. Isaiah makes similar remarks but is much more explicit (Isa. 1:5–6).

<span id="page-489-6"></span><span id="page-489-3"></span><span id="page-489-2"></span><span id="page-489-1"></span>6:10 The current Hebrew text reads, "Are there still in the house of the wicked treasures of wickedness?" A slight change in the vowels of the Hebrew leads to the ESV translation, "Can I forget . . ." The result is the same: a rhetorical question pointing out the obvious, that the wicked city includes many households hoarding unjustly acquired wealth. Another rhetorical question continues, literally, "Is not the scant [lean] ephah accursed?" An ephah represented about one bushel in dry measure and was often used to measure wheat. Merchants in Israel were forbidden to have unjust measures, although unscrupulous merchants would often have a small bushel to dispense products (giving the buyer less than what they paid for) and a large measure to receive payment (taking more than what the buyer owed).

<span id="page-489-7"></span><span id="page-489-0"></span>6:11 The critique of such dishonesty is continued with a two-part rhetorical question bringing the sequence to a climax: "Shall I acquit the man with wicked scales and with a bag of deceitful weights?" The answer is clearly no; to the Lord, such measures are unjust and an outright abomination (Deut. 25:13–16). The prophet Amos referred to this practice in the northern kingdom a few years before Micah, quoting similarly unjust merchants:

 When will the new moon be over, that we may sell grain? And the Sabbath, that we may offer wheat for sale, that we may make the ephah small and the shekel great and deal deceitfully with false balances? (Amos 8:5)

<span id="page-489-4"></span>Yahweh will not exonerate those guilty of using false measures—how could he do so and still be a God of justice?

<span id="page-489-8"></span>6:12 Yahweh continues his indictment by switching from rhetorical questions to direct confrontation, demonstrating that the injustice in the marketplace is a reflection of the culture. The rich are full of violence, i.e., their wealth has been gained by cheating and hurting people. As for the residents of the city, they speak lies because their tongues—the very organs of speech—are deceitful!

<span id="page-490-4"></span>6:13 The image of the rod of correction appears again as Yahweh promises to smite his people with a sharp blow. While this text is envisioning a future judgment, the signs of judgment may have already begun in the form of initial forays of the Assyrian army into the land of Judah.

<span id="page-490-5"></span>6:14 This verse introduces the particular sentence of punishment rendered by Yahweh; verse 15 will continue it. The people are seeking to acquire wealth by unjust means but will not succeed in their goal. Thus the following judgments are often called "futility curses." The first curse deals with food: hunger will never be satisfied, nor will food stored away provide any relief, as it will finally be given to the sword. Siege conditions are likely in view here. What kind of satisfaction can there be when the city is surrounded by a foreign army?

<span id="page-490-6"></span>6:15 The source of the food now comes into view. Wheat, oil from olive trees, and grapes will not be enjoyed because most of these would have been planted outside the walls of the city, where the besieged would have had no access. Even though they planted them, they would not reap them.

<span id="page-490-7"></span><span id="page-490-2"></span>6:16 Both sentence and judgment are summarized with different words than in verses 9–15. The people have not walked with Yahweh and in his statutes; instead they have kept the statutes of Omri and the work of Ahab. These two kings, father and son, were notorious in the northern kingdom for apostasy and injustice. Although they were successful politically, they were disasters morally, introducing Baal worship into Israel through the marriage of Ahab to Jezebel, a Phoenician princess who brought with her a religious entourage of prophets of Baal and his consort, Astarte. This resulted in great persecution of Yahweh's prophets, as exemplified in some of the Elijah narratives (1 Kings 17–18); and in horrific injustice, as illustrated in the story of Naboth's vineyard (1 Kings 21). Consequently, the people will be given over to desolation (cf. Mic. 6:10) and to the derision of the nations. (Instead of "You shall bear the scorn of my people," a slight change in the Hebrew leads to "You shall bear the scorn of peoples," which perhaps makes better sense in the context.45)

## <span id="page-490-3"></span><span id="page-490-1"></span><span id="page-490-0"></span>*Response*

This oracle is inextricably linked to the previous one. The people have been redeemed by Yahweh for a life of walking in his Torah, loving mercy, and practicing justice, but it is clear that they have walked in the ways of Omri and Ahab instead, loving violence, practicing injustice, and lying. The result will be futility and desolation.

This text clarifies one concrete realm of justice and injustice: the use of money. When people cheat in their businesses and professions, they are guilty of injustice,

<sup>45</sup> The Septuagint also supports this reading.

and this functions like a plague, creating an unjust society. Thus this text speaks clearly to contemporary believers of the importance of "walking the talk," of a life of faith accompanied by good works. Paul had to warn believers in Corinth about the inconsistency of claiming salvation by Christ but living a life according to the dictates of the sinful nature, not according to the Spirit:

You yourselves wrong and defraud—even your own brothers! Or do you not know that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived: neither the sexually immoral, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor men who practice homosexuality, nor thieves, nor the greedy, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor swindlers will inherit the kingdom of God. (1 Cor. 6:8–10)

<span id="page-491-2"></span><span id="page-491-0"></span>Those who have been redeemed by Christ are to walk not in the ways of the world but in the ways of God. The law of Christ is a new commandment to love. In a sense it is the same commandment that has been given in the law, to love one's neighbor as oneself (Lev. 19:18), but it is new in the sense that there has been a new redeeming act (the love of Christ as manifested in the cross) and a new redeeming power (the gift of the Holy Spirit).

<span id="page-491-5"></span><span id="page-491-4"></span><span id="page-491-3"></span>The idea of discipline to instruct the faithful who have strayed from the path of holiness is not merely an OT truth but is also an NT reality. The children of God, says the writer to the Hebrews, are disciplined precisely because they are children. If they were not God's children, there would be no need for correction (Heb. 12:5–11). Paul had to warn the Corinthian church that many of its members were suffering because they were participating in the Lord's Supper in an unworthy manner (1 Cor. 11:30). But he also uses this as a reminder that they are to examine themselves (1 Cor. 11:28, 31), that is, to make sure that they are following Christ's commands and thus not putting themselves in a position where such discipline is required. The Lord has created us not for discipline but for walking with him in his ways and knowing the love and joy of our Father.

## MICAH 7:1–7

<span id="page-491-1"></span>7 Woe is me! For I have become as when the summer fruit has been gathered, as when the grapes have been gleaned: there is no cluster to eat, no first-ripe fig that my soul desires.

**<sup>2</sup>** The godly has perished from the earth, and there is no one upright among mankind; they all lie in wait for blood, and each hunts the other with a net.

- **<sup>3</sup>** Their hands are on what is evil, to do it well; the prince and the judge ask for a bribe, and the great man utters the evil desire of his soul; thus they weave it together.
- **<sup>4</sup>** The best of them is like a brier, the most upright of them a thorn hedge. The day of your watchmen, of your punishment, has come; now their confusion is at hand.
- **<sup>5</sup>** Put no trust in a neighbor; have no confidence in a friend; guard the doors of your mouth from her who lies in your arms;*<sup>1</sup>*
- **<sup>6</sup>** for the son treats the father with contempt, the daughter rises up against her mother, the daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law; a man's enemies are the men of his own house.
- **<sup>7</sup>** But as for me, I will look to the Lord; I will wait for the God of my salvation; my God will hear me.

1Hebrew *bosom*

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-492-2"></span>This lament uses agrarian imagery to describe the total moral desolation of the nation. It describes a society that has experienced moral and spiritual collapse (7:1–4). God had expected a rich harvest of righteousness from his people but received absolutely nothing. No one can be trusted (vv. 5–6). In response, the prophet turns in absolute despair to the only one who is worthy of trust: the Lord God (v. 7).

	- A. Yahweh's Case against Israel (6:1–7:7) . . .
		- 3. Lament for a Nation—Again! (7:1–7)
			- a. A Moral Wasteland—No Fruit on the Vine (7:1–4)
			- b. "Don't Trust Anyone!" (7:5–6)
			- c. Look to God Alone! (7:7)

## <span id="page-492-3"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-492-1"></span><span id="page-492-0"></span>7:1 The prophet represents the nation here when he laments for himself. Agrarian images are used to describe the barrenness of the land: there is no fruit to be gathered, no clusters of grapes in the vineyard, no figs on the fig trees. Although it is harvest time, there is nothing but desolation. As becomes clear in the next verse, this represents the moral barrenness of the nation. The prophet Isaiah used a similar image—God made a vineyard and looked for a harvest, but only rotten grapes were produced (Isa. 5:1–7). In Micah, there are not even rotten grapes.

<span id="page-493-7"></span><span id="page-493-6"></span><span id="page-493-3"></span>7:2 The point of the agrarian metaphor is clarified. The godly person has perished from the land. "Godly" (*hasid* ) comes from the same root that describes the quality God desires in people: kindness (*hesed*; cf. 6:8). The word "perish" suggests a negative connotation. A similar passage in Isaiah describes the righteous and the godly being swept away in a tide of evil (Isa. 57:1). The absence of the righteous leads to the proliferation of evil, as people stalk one another, seeking to hunt them down and kill them like wild animals. "Each hunts the other with a net" is literally "Each hunts his *brother* with a net." There is no idea of being a brother's keeper here, just his killer.

<span id="page-493-8"></span><span id="page-493-0"></span>7:3 Micah further describes the godless state of the land, including its corrupt leadership: the judicial and royal officials are interested not in justice and equitable rule but in making money from their positions through bribes. The "great man" may be a reference to the king (cf. 2 Sam. 3:38) or to distinguished nobility, who reveal their evil desires. Previously, they would at least keep their desires hidden because of shame; now they have no shame. "They weave it together" summarizes the situation: the leadership of the country is bound together in an intricate web of evil.

<span id="page-493-9"></span><span id="page-493-4"></span>7:4 The metaphor now reverts to the agrarian world. Instead of ripe fruit, the "best" of the nation are like thorns and briars. Instead of producing nourishment, they merely cause pain. Consequently, the nation can expect only judgment: "the day of your watchmen" indicates what the sentinels on the walls of cities see as judgment approaches. This is further defined as "your punishment," or visitation of judgment, which indicates an appointed time of divine judgment (cf. Amos 3:2, 14). Panic and confusion will ensue. The Hebrew word for "confusion" occurs only one another time in Scripture, in a telling text from Micah's contemporary, Isaiah, where it refers to the approaching demise of Jerusalem by the Assyrian army and the resultant "tumult and trampling [down] and confusion . . . a battering down of walls and a shouting" (Isa. 22:5). The panic is palpable.

<span id="page-493-10"></span><span id="page-493-5"></span><span id="page-493-2"></span>7:5 Consequently, in order to survive the coming crisis the prophet commands the people not to trust one another. Three categories of people are mentioned, in increasing level of relationship: neighbors, close friends or intimates (those who have been known a long time and therefore would normally be trusted; cf. Ps. 55:14), and wives.

<span id="page-493-11"></span><span id="page-493-1"></span>7:6 Such people can no longer be trusted because even the most intimate ties have been fractured: children despise their parents, and servants—"men of his own house"—despise masters, so that the household, which ought to be the haven of utmost security, becomes a place of danger and even war.

<span id="page-493-12"></span>7:7 In contrast to the nation, in which no one can be trusted, Yahweh is utterly reliable. "In a world where even neighbor and family are not to be trusted (vv. 5f.), <span id="page-494-0"></span>only God is left. But *he* is there."46 There is thus hope, but it is a hope beyond anyone or anything found in the nation. Micah has learned in his nation's descent to the moral abyss what the prophet Jonah experienced in his own descent to the bottom of the sea: salvation comes only from the Lord (Jonah 2:9). Micah's final words on behalf of the nation are that God would hear his prayer. This prayer will be the subject of the last passage of the book (Mic. 7:8–20).

### <span id="page-494-1"></span>*Response*

The times of Micah read like the headlines of contemporary newspapers regarding failed states, where might determines what is right. But at a deeper, spiritual level, there are many places in the so-called high society of the Western world where human beings are treated like commodities, where bribery is common, where the murder rates of cities skyrocket, where terrorists look for "soft targets" to kill as many people as possible, where human traffickers search for unsuspecting young women and children, and where some businesses exploit people for greed. The human tragedy of the mass migration of peoples to Europe in recent years is one of the saddest commentaries of modern life, as leaders struggle to determine the best way to handle both the migrant crisis and the underlying factors precipitating it. Pastors and spiritual leaders must realize that the Bible is never out of date; the prophets often hold up a mirror for societies and cultures to see their true selves.

<span id="page-494-3"></span><span id="page-494-2"></span>But even when human society has degenerated to such an extent, all hope is not lost. Micah's last word in this lament points to the ultimate solution: amid such corruption, human beings must look only to the Lord to hear their cry. Micah's "pessimism, in spite of everything, drives our prophet not to despair but into the arms of God."47 There is no safer place. Thus the prophetic message is ultimately one of hope because of the living God. In the Christian church there is a new culture founded on the cross, on the stretched-out arms of God, who has become a curse for sinners that we might receive a blessing (Gal. 3:13–14). Now, in the power of the Spirit, a new family thrives, in which "obedience is thicker than blood" (Matt. 12:48–50 MESSAGE). Love now rules in the family!

1Hebrew *he* 2That is, the Euphrates 3Hebrew *of Carmel* 4Hebrew *him* 5Hebrew *their*

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-496-3"></span><span id="page-496-2"></span>This final text, which seems to be a type of prophetical liturgy,48 is a fitting conclusion to the entire book as it moves from lament to final praise and describes the success of God's salvific plan for the world. Israel's enemies will be defeated, including, most of all, her own sin (Mic. 7:8–9, 10; cf. v. 20); the nation will be restored and will become a magnet of hope for the nations (vv. 11–13); the people will experience an exodus-like salvation and will be guided into the land by the divine Shepherd (vv. 14–15); and the nations themselves will be subdued and come to worship Yahweh (vv. 16–17). Exodus language describing the incomparability of God is used to provide a final, stunning vision of God's grace and forgiveness (7:18–20).

## <span id="page-496-6"></span><span id="page-496-5"></span><span id="page-496-4"></span>*Section Outline*

		- 1. Acceptance of Judgment, Confession, and Hope (7:8–9)
		- 2. The Demise of the Enemy (7:10)
		- 3. Jerusalem: The Metropolis of the World (7:11–13)
		- 4. The Divine Shepherd's Salvation (7:14–15)
		- 5. Defeat and Salvation of the Nations (7:16–17)
		- 6. Hymn of Praise to the Incomparable God (7:18–20)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-496-1"></span>7:8 Micah again represents the nation as he challenges his enemy not to rejoice. The identity of this enemy is not clear; it could be the Assyrians, the Babylonians, or perhaps the nations in general (cf. 4:10–13; 5:9). Assyria has been the great enemy

<span id="page-496-0"></span><sup>48</sup> Hermann Gunkel, "The Close of Micah: A Prophetic Liturgy," in Hermann Gunkel, *What Remains of the Old Testament and Other Essays* (London: Macmillan, 1928), 115–149.

The just judgment of God is not the end but the beginning of life, for though the nation falls, it will rise again. Yahweh will be its light in the darkness of exile.

<span id="page-497-9"></span><span id="page-497-5"></span>7:9 The nation accepts the just judgment of Yahweh and acknowledges its sin. But it is confident that Yahweh will not give up on it. This confidence has been rooted in Yahweh's promise to restore the remnant (2:12–13; 4:6–7), which itself is rooted in the Abrahamic covenant (7:20).

<span id="page-497-15"></span><span id="page-497-10"></span><span id="page-497-2"></span>7:10 The enemy's taunt ("Where is the Lord your God?") is virtually a refrain throughout the Scriptures, hurled at the people of God as an epithet of scorn (Pss. 42:3, 10; 79:10; 115:2; Joel 2:17). But the enemy who seems victorious will soon be trampled in the streets. This is a sign of victory for the people of God, an echo of the pulverizing of the enemy with bronze hooves in Micah 4:13, the trampling of Jezebel by Jehu (2 Kings 9:33), and the crushing of the serpent by the seed of the woman (cf. Gen. 3:15; Isa. 65:25).

<span id="page-497-11"></span><span id="page-497-8"></span><span id="page-497-1"></span><span id="page-497-0"></span>7:11 After describing the judgment of God and the demise of the enemy, this verse announces the building of Jerusalem. The walls are built, and the "boundary [*khoq*] shall be far extended." This line in the ESV forms a nice parallel with the previous one, which emphasizes the building of walls. However, the word translated "boundary" often signifies "laws" and "decrees," in which case the sense would be that Jerusalem's rule is extended far and wide. The idea would then be that the word of the Lord will go forth from Jerusalem so that even "far away" nations will come and meet the new King (cf. 4:2–3).

<span id="page-497-12"></span><span id="page-497-7"></span>7:12 As a consequence, the nations migrate to Jerusalem so that it becomes the "metropolis of the [new] world."49 The geographical references—north and south (from Assyria to Egypt, and Egypt to the River, i.e., the Euphrates) and east and west (from sea to sea)—suggest the entirety of the Near East is involved in this pilgrimage. It is possible that this text may be referring to the gathering of the exiles, but it seems to be more in harmony with 4:1–4 and the ingathering of the nations. The salvation of Assyria and Egypt are included in Isaiah's prophecy (Isa. 19:25), and also in Psalm 87. When they come to Jerusalem, they are born again!

<span id="page-497-13"></span><span id="page-497-6"></span><span id="page-497-4"></span><span id="page-497-3"></span>7:13 One of the reasons the nations migrate to Jerusalem is the destitution of their lands, which have been made desolate because of their sins. This may refer to the fruits of war and violence. A similar thought was expressed in 2:10, which describes how Judah had become corrupt because of the sins of covetous land barons.

<span id="page-497-14"></span>7:14–15 A command is given to God to shepherd his people, who dwell alone in the "forest." This may be an echo of the abandoned site of the temple, which had

<sup>49</sup> John Calvin, *Commentaries on the Twelve Minor Prophets*, 387.

<span id="page-498-4"></span><span id="page-498-2"></span>become a hill in the forest (cf. 3:12). God will lead the flock instead to Bashan and Gilead, an area renowned for its fertility and consequently its prize cattle (cf. Amos 4:1). The scattered flock will become healthy and flourishing. But beyond this physical provision, God will accomplish a salvation whose magnitude can only be compared to the exodus from Egypt, in which God displayed his wonders. Given the reference to the messianic King who would shepherd his people in the second major section of Micah (5:4), this text may refer to the King from Bethlehem, and it therefore may be a direct address to him; he may thus be the one speaking in 7:15.

<span id="page-498-8"></span><span id="page-498-7"></span><span id="page-498-6"></span>7:16 When the nations see Jerusalem and her new King, they will become ashamed of their power. It is related that Napoleon, during his later years, once remarked to his minister of education, "Do you know, Fontanes, what astonishes me most in this world? The inability of force to create anything. In the long run the sword is always beaten by the spirit."50 In the last days, the nations will see this impotence of power and will become dumb and deaf. There is nothing more to say, nothing more to hear. They have based their lives on the wrong premise.

<span id="page-498-9"></span><span id="page-498-1"></span>7:17 The nations will assume a posture of abasement and humiliation, which may well be a sign of repentance, given the context. They will "turn in dread" to Yahweh, which also has connotations of awe, as the same expression is used in relation to Israel's salvation by Yahweh in the last days (Hos. 3:5). The object of fear in "they shall be in fear of you" is ambiguous; it could be a reference to God or to Israel. The parallelism with the previous line ("they shall turn in dread to the Lord our God") suggests that God is probably the referent. Thus this text fills in more details of the nations' salvation already announced in Micah 4:1–4.

<span id="page-498-10"></span><span id="page-498-5"></span><span id="page-498-3"></span><span id="page-498-0"></span>7:18–19 This text intentionally plays on the meaning of Micah's name ("Who is like Yahweh?"), found at the beginning of the book (1:1). Thus it leaves the audience with a final answer to the rhetorical question embedded in his name. What follows are seven characteristics of Yahweh, intentionally echoing the revelation of the divine name to Moses on Mount Sinai (Ex. 34:6–7). The central attribute of the seven is "steadfast love" (*hesed* ), which provides a motive not only for the third attribute but for all of them: Yahweh delights in steadfast love. There is a general chiastic pattern used to display these qualities. Micah says that God

- A. pardons iniquity;
	- B. passes over transgression;
		- C. does not retain anger;
			- D. delights in steadfast love;
		- C'. shows compassion;
	- B'. treads down iniquities; and
- A'. casts away sins.

<sup>50</sup> Quoted in J. Christopher Herold, *The Age of Napoleon* (New York: Mariner Books, 2002), 76; cited in Abraham Heschel, *The Prophets* (Peabody, MA: Hendrickson, 2007), 204.

The first two and last two traits deal with sin, while the third and fifth stress cessation of anger and renewal of compassion, and the fourth focuses on motivation. These are all an exposition of the rhetorical question that begins the sequence: "Who is a God like you?"

<span id="page-499-5"></span><span id="page-499-4"></span>In Micah 7:18a, the divine pardoning of iniquity suggests the lifting up of sin from someone, and thus the bearing of it by another party. In Isaiah the suffering servant bears the sin of many (Isa. 53:4, 11); the word "pardoning" thus indicates suffering love. The "passing over" of transgression means the overlooking of sin (cf. Prov. 19:11), while "remnant of his inheritance" refers to those who have survived the judgment.

<span id="page-499-6"></span><span id="page-499-3"></span>In Micah 7:18b–19a we see that anger does not finally mark God; his anger is a response to sin, and he has shown his fury with the sin of his people throughout Micah, but his chief attribute is steadfast love (*hesed* ). It is not just that he practices it; he *delights* in it. It is what gets him excited! Calvin aptly remarks, "The only prop or support that can raise us up to God, when we desire to be reconciled to him, is this—that he loves mercy."51 God's renewal of compassion based on his steadfast love is one of the principal attributes found in the great explanation of God's name in Exodus 34:5–7.

<span id="page-499-7"></span><span id="page-499-2"></span><span id="page-499-0"></span>In the rest of Micah 7:19 we see that in order to deal with sins finally and conclusively, God treads them underfoot and casts them into the depths of the sea. This treading down of sin suggests triumphal victory and may be an intentional echo of the dominion that Adam and Eve were to have at the beginning of creation (Gen. 1:28). But it has now been accomplished by the Lord! Moreover, not only will sin be overcome; it will be forever removed from sight, thrown into the depths of the ocean. Just as Yahweh cast all of Pharaoh's army into the depths of the sea, drowning them forever (Ex. 15:2, 19), so will he do the same to Israel's sins.

<span id="page-499-8"></span><span id="page-499-1"></span>7:20 It is fitting that the final verse of Micah returns to the covenantal roots of Israel and emphasizes God's steadfast love (*hesed* ). The promise to the patriarchs— God's pledge to them in the distant past—still stands. The prophecy of Micah is living proof of that. Everything in the prophecy is a testimony to God's faithfulness to the patriarchal promises and his steadfast love. The word pair "faithfulness" and "steadfast love" almost always occurs as "steadfast love and faithfulness." But here they are reversed to end on a final note of steadfast love. Everything is based on this. God delights in steadfast love. This is why he made a promise to Abraham, so that steadfast love would overflow and be a blessing to the entire world.

### *Response*

The final prayer and praise of Micah is an appropriate prayer for God's people everywhere, especially on this side of the cross of Jesus Christ. It provides a blueprint for God's plan of salvation for the world, beginning with the confession of God's people and their willingness to submit to God's discipline; continuing to

<sup>51</sup> Calvin, *Commentaries on the Twelve Minor Prophets*, 403.

the challenge to the enemy, the building of the city of God into a metropolis of the world, and the call to the divine shepherd to lead his people into victory; and concluding with the salvation of the nations. The Christian church has seen the salvation to which Micah pointed. They have seen Jesus build his new city on a hill to share the good news with the nations; they have seen many peoples from many nations humble themselves and turn to God in repentance and worship. They have borne witness to the cross of Christ, which has produced forgiveness and pardon and the vanquishing of sin and death.

And yet, Micah's prophecy has been only partially fulfilled. There is still the ongoing power of death and evil, which are very much alive in the world. It seems that Micah (and many of the prophets) only prophesied one coming of the Messiah. But the NT makes clear this one coming has two phases. First he comes as the suffering servant to suffer and die and rise again. This represents the power of the new world in the old, the announcement to the nations that there is a new world order. For the nations to be saved, that new world order is proclaimed, and the nations are called to go up to "Jerusalem" to hear the word of the Lord. But in the meantime, the powers of death and sin continue to wreak havoc. The church needs to continue to confess its sin, shine its light, and pray to its Shepherd to lead and guide it into all truth. To those peoples who would taunt the church with the question, "Where is your God?" the church must respond, "The tomb is empty, Jesus Christ has been exalted to the highest place, and eventually every knee will bow before him and confess that he is Lord" (cf. Phil. 2:5–11). Repent and believe the good news; bring your spears and swords and transform them into tools that bring life! (cf. Mic. 4:3).
