## *Comment*

1:1 While many Prophetic Books provide information about the prophet's setting, usually referring to the kings who reigned at the time of the prophet's ministry, all such information is ignored here in a very brief superscription (only Obadiah's superscription is briefer). We are simply told we are reading an "oracle" that Habakkuk "saw." Not all prophetic preaching is called an "oracle," with the term occurring elsewhere in the OT eighteen times to describe a prophetic mes<span id="page-541-2"></span>sage, most commonly one concerning another nation, including eleven times in Isaiah 13–30. What is striking is that in every other instance the concern of the oracle is mentioned, but that is not the case here. Readers familiar with oracles are thus left in a state of uncertainty—does the text address them, or a foreign nation? In fact, both will be addressed, but by leaving this unstated the superscription invites readers to continue in order to discover the object of the oracle.

<span id="page-541-4"></span>Habakkuk himself is introduced as "the prophet"; only Haggai and Zechariah are similarly designated (Hag. 1:1; Zech. 1:1). Usually, prophetic superscriptions indicate that the book records the message of a prophet (e.g., "The word of the Lord came to . . ."), but such information is absent here, precisely because Habakkuk's oracle comes not in the form of a direct word but rather as a mediated conversation. Readers are thus informed that the conversation to follow is to be read as a prophetic message, although it is also something that Habakkuk "saw." The idea of a prophet seeing an oracle might seem strange, but the concept is quite common in the Prophetic Books (e.g., Isa. 1:1; 2:1) and appears to describe the process by which the prophet was able to perceive God's message. If so, it functions here to assure readers of the authenticity of what follows, and also prepares them for a range of words associated with sight that will be prominent in the remainder of this section.

<span id="page-541-3"></span><span id="page-541-1"></span><span id="page-541-0"></span>1:2–4 Most prophets begin by announcing a word from or about God; Habakkuk starts instead with a record of his own address to God. His address finds its nearest parallels in the Psalms, and some of Jeremiah's confessions are also similar. Habakkuk's opening words find an immediate parallel in Psalm 13:1, another prayer complaining about a delay in God's justice. The question of why God does not act against evil in the world is thus raised from the outset as the pivotal issue of the book. Habakkuk's point is that the issues he raises are not new concerns but rather are matters he has been presenting to God for some time. Although he has raised the issue of violence, which here describes abuse of the weak within society, it seems that God has not acted. Indeed, what particularly troubles the prophet is that God has caused him to look upon iniquity, while God himself appears untroubled to look upon oppression.

That these are not isolated experiences is made clear by the range of terms for the social decay Habakkuk describes. A world that is full of "destruction" and "violence" is also one that will be filled with "contention" and "strife." The whole of the prophet's society is decaying, and, as far as he can see, God is not troubled by it. At the heart of Habakkuk's concern is that God's justice ought to be seen—and promptly. Also central to Habakkuk's unease is that the "law is paralyzed." Since "law" (*torah*) represents Israel's instruction received from God, the implication is that the problems described are internal to Judah. Habakkuk is troubled that Israel's law appears powerless to address the problems he sees. That which was meant to guarantee the application of God's justice seems powerless in the face of violence, with the righteous unable to overcome the wicked. It is this that leads to Habakkuk's cry to God for help.

<span id="page-542-4"></span>1:5–11 It is often suggested that one reason we frequently see a shift in mood in the Psalms from complaint to hope is that the petitioner has received an oracle from God, perhaps through a prophet, that gives him hope. There is no direct evidence for this in the Psalms, but we may see something like it here, save for one important distinction: Habakkuk does indeed receive a response to his complaint from God, but he does not find it comforting. That we have a new speaker is indicated by a change to plural verbs, and the "I" who speaks has great authority. Nevertheless, as verse 5 begins, we do not know who is speaking, only that the speaker has the right to direct Habakkuk (and others) to look to the nations. Only gradually do we realize that it is Yahweh who speaks, though this is not finally confirmed until Habakkuk initiates the second dialogue in verse 12. The plural verbs used here imply that Habakkuk is part of a group, suggesting he has not been alone in his complaint, and neither will he be alone in his astonishment at what is about to be described.

<span id="page-542-8"></span><span id="page-542-2"></span><span id="page-542-0"></span>Presumably, Habakkuk is included among the righteous who are surrounded by the wicked in verse 4, and this group is collectively summoned to look to the nations and be amazed at what God is about to do, as what is about to happen is something none of them would have expected. This is because, in response to the internal problem of injustice in Judah, God announces he is raising up the Chaldeans (a term roughly equivalent to "Babylonians"; cf. Introduction: Overview) to act. This statement is closely parallel to Amos 6:14, where the Assyrians were to be raised up against Israel, suggesting that this whole response to Habakkuk is in effect a judgment against Judah. However, a description of how exactly they will judge Judah is withheld at this point. What is to amaze the righteous in Judah is that God would use a people like the Chaldeans, who by this time were already known for their militaristic and expansionist policies against other nations. It is astonishing that so violent a people would be used to address the violence occurring in Judah. If the problem is injustice, how could God use a nation whose own idea of justice is so contrary to God's?

<span id="page-542-5"></span>The Lord then describes the Chaldeans as dreaded and fearsome. Although the translation of these verses is far from easy, the ESV makes good sense of them, helping us to see how terrifying the Chaldeans would be. But their description also raises important questions for readers. This problem is exacerbated by the picture of the Chaldeans' powerful and swift horsemen, who are compared to creatures of prey, swift to enact violence (Hab. 1:8–9), the very issue Habakkuk had raised in verse 2. Habakkuk had asked God to save, but instead he is bringing a powerful nation that scoffs at kings (vv. 9–10), and that does not recognize Yahweh's authority—for their "own might is their god" (v. 11). That God should use a violent and guilty people against violence within Judah is almost certainly not the response Habakkuk had sought.

<span id="page-542-9"></span><span id="page-542-7"></span><span id="page-542-6"></span><span id="page-542-3"></span><span id="page-542-1"></span>1:12–2:1 God had declared (1:5) that his message would astonish Habakkuk (and others), and it is immediately clear that it has indeed done so. Once again, a change <span id="page-543-3"></span>in speaker is clear as Habakkuk addresses Yahweh. This address, again like many psalms, uses a range of titles to address God: he is "from everlasting," "my God," and "my Holy One" (the third one being unique to Habakkuk). These terms create a clear contrast between God and the Chaldeans, although the clause "We shall not die" (1:12) is difficult to interpret and is frequently emended. The ESV faithfully represents the Hebrew and can be defended, the sense perhaps being an exclamation of faith by Habakkuk as he prepares to "take my stand at my watchpost" (2:1). He thus recognizes Yahweh as his "Rock" (1:12), a term used for God twenty-four times in the Psalms to suggest security and stability.

<span id="page-543-10"></span><span id="page-543-5"></span><span id="page-543-4"></span><span id="page-543-2"></span>Although he recognizes the threat the Chaldeans pose, Habakkuk believes his life is safe precisely because of God's character. Yet this assurance must be balanced in verses 12b–14 by the reality of "judgment" (the same word as that translated "justice" in vv. 4, 7). Habakkuk tries to understand the Chaldean threat as reproof, presumably for the righteous as well as for the wicked, but Habakkuk's difficulty is that he knows Yahweh to be holy and therefore pure. This conflict leads to the questions of verse 13, as Habakkuk remains troubled that Yahweh does not act directly to prevent injustice, allowing treachery to continue. Yahweh has failed to act against those characterized in the Hebrew of verse 13 as *bogedim*, referring to either "traitors" (so ESV, suggesting wicked Israelites) or "the treacherous" (suggesting the Chaldeans). In either case, Habakkuk is concerned by Yahweh's seemingly delayed judgment on unfaithful Israel being meted out by even more unfaithful Babylon. Habakkuk thus wishes to hold God to account—he is holy and just, and therefore ought to act in ways that are likewise holy and just.

<span id="page-543-7"></span><span id="page-543-6"></span>That God is sovereign is clear from the fact that he is Creator, and Habakkuk (with a nod to Genesis 1) sees that God has made mankind free, comparing humans to "fish" and "crawling things" (Hab. 1:14). The comparison to fish, however, leads to the metaphor of the Chaldeans as ruthless anglers who catch more than they need through a variety of fishing techniques—"hook," "net," and "dragnet" (v. 15). They rejoice in the abundance of their catch and completely ignore the fact that they could do so only because Yahweh had raised them up. Indeed, they treat their fishing implements as gods (v. 16), celebrating their violence in battle.

<span id="page-543-9"></span><span id="page-543-8"></span><span id="page-543-0"></span>The point of Habakkuk's complaint is then driven home by the question of verse 17. He objects to the Chaldeans' relentlessly violent and aggressive conquests of other nations. His question involves a wordplay impossible to bring out in English, as the word translated "net" (*herem*) in verses 15 and 17 is a homonym of the word often translated "devoted to destruction" (e.g., Deut. 7:26), pointing to the Chaldeans' relentless destruction of others.1 Pitiless killing, says Habakkuk, surely cannot be Yahweh's way. So, having challenged God, in 2:1 Habakkuk takes his stand, portraying himself as a prophet in a watchtower, waiting to see what God will say in response to his complaint. This stance recognizes that God has made him see iniquity (1:3), and now he wants to see how God will respond to his

<span id="page-543-1"></span><sup>1</sup> The term also represents the weapon the chief Babylonian god Marduk used to kill Tiamat in Babylonian mythology. It is unclear, however, if that is being alluded to here.

<span id="page-544-4"></span>"complaint," a word related to the term translated "reproof" in verse 12. Habakkuk has challenged God to show his justice, and as a prophet he now waits for a message to bring to the people.

<span id="page-544-5"></span><span id="page-544-2"></span><span id="page-544-1"></span><span id="page-544-0"></span>2:2–5 For the first time, Yahweh is identified as the speaker as Habakkuk receives the response to his complaint. The text here draws parallels between Habakkuk and Moses: Habakkuk is told to write down his "vision" (a noun related to the verb "saw" in 1:1) and to do so plainly "on tablets." The word translated "tablets" is the same as that used for the tablets of the law seventeen times in Exodus (e.g., Ex. 24:12), while the verb translated "make it plain" occurs elsewhere only in Deuteronomy 1:5 and 27:8, the latter reference also referring to something written. The point is that what God has to say to Habakkuk is important and must be shared, just as Deuteronomy was meant to be passed on from generation to generation. It is likely that the one who "runs" (cf. Hab. 2:5) is a messenger who takes a copy of the tablets in order to read it in public. However, before the vision is revealed ("vision" functions here as a technical way of referring to the prophetic message), we are told that those who hear it are not to be disheartened by any delay in its fulfillment. Its completion is certain—it is from Yahweh, and he has set an appointed time for it.

<span id="page-544-9"></span><span id="page-544-8"></span><span id="page-544-6"></span>The content of the vision could be verse 4 (and perhaps v. 5), which would be a word of comfort, although the concern of delay (v. 3) would not seem relevant in that case. Most likely, then, the content of the vision is found in the series of woe oracles in verses 6–20, with verses 4–5 representing the attitude with which they should be read; appreciation of what God was saying required a proper attitude, one that was distinctively unlike the Chaldeans'. Verse 4 is, of course, famous because of its three citations in the NT (Rom. 1:17; Gal. 3:11; Heb. 10:37–38), as well as its role in the Reformation, but, given the rather different ways the NT applies the text, it is clear that none of them sums up the text in its entirety.

<span id="page-544-10"></span><span id="page-544-7"></span><span id="page-544-3"></span>"His" and "him" in the first half of Habakkuk 2:4 refers to the Chaldeans, following the pattern set in God's previous speech (1:5–11), where Babylon was personified (in the Hebrew) as "he," rightly translated as plurals in the ESV in terms of its sense. The downside to this translation is that readers in English might miss this reference to the Chaldeans here in verse 4, although it is true that *anyone* not submitting to God is "not upright." The Chaldeans are described as "puffed up"; they overrate their own importance and are thus not upright. In contrast the righteous, those who are right with God, will live by faith. Living "by faith" here has two aspects, both of which are equally important. First, it refers to an attitude of life lived in dependence on God. One's faith is foundational to righteousness, as Paul repeatedly makes clear. But it also involves "faithfulness" (ESV mg.), calling for a recognition of God's trustworthiness, even when circumstances are challenging. It is this sense that is taken up by the writer to the Hebrews.

Having established a pattern for the righteous, verse 5 then returns to the Chaldeans, again personifying them as an individual ("he," etc.). The interpretation of the verse is difficult and disputed, with many preferring to follow a Dead Sea Scroll manuscript and read "wealth" (ESV mg.) for the unexpected "wine." If, however, we understand "wine" as representing the luxurious and acquisitive life for which the Chaldeans strove, we can take the text as it stands, pointing to the reality that luxury never satisfies. In the same way, the Chaldeans will find no satisfaction in what they do. Their relentless drive to acquire by force will never satisfy. Just as the grave is never sated, so also the Chaldeans will never find satisfaction. Such a life is ultimately destructive. This gives the righteous another reason to live by faith, even though it does not guarantee they will see such powerful oppression cease. Thus it is important to know that God's purposes will ultimately be worked out, even if his timing is not necessarily ours (cf. 2 Pet. 3:9).

#### <span id="page-545-2"></span>*Response*

Habakkuk raises crucial questions that have bedeviled God's people through the ages, but he also provides a frame of reference by which to see their resolution. He recognizes a fundamental problem: Scripture as a whole consistently affirms that God is good, holy, and just, yet the world is evil, unholy, and unjust—the wicked prosper and the righteous suffer. How are we to understand these seemingly conflicting realities? For Habakkuk, these were not theoretical issues for armchair philosophizing. They were real issues of the world in which he lived, where injustice was rampant in Judah. Yet when he went to God for resolution, it seemed the answer was worse than the problem. He was therefore prepared to hold God to account, challenging him to show his justice.

<span id="page-545-1"></span><span id="page-545-0"></span>The desire to see God's justice still motivates believers today. When Jesus taught us to pray "your kingdom come" (Matt. 6:10), he implicitly reminded us that although the kingdom was indeed present in him and his works (Luke 11:20) it was also future, something for which we are simultaneously to strive and to pray. Faithfulness to Jesus means doing all we can to model holiness and justice while also recognizing that the full revelation of his justice is yet to come. This is a matter for prayer, as modeled to us by Habakkuk, whose message is itself enclosed in his prayers and God's response to them.

God's response to Habakkuk also provides a model for how we are to hold these issues in tension. Faith, a position from which we approach life by understanding that righteousness comes only as God's gift, is the essential starting point. But this is to be matched with a continued faithfulness that trusts God even when our experience is for a time contrary to our expectations. This is not a blind faith, for we understand that violence and injustice has the seeds of its own destruction. But it is a faith that lives in the knowledge that God's purposes have an appointed time for which we wait—waiting both for those interim moments when we see evil overcome in history and for the point at which God's victory will ultimately be seen by all. But as we wait, like Habakkuk, we continue to pray. We pray "your kingdom come," asking for the resolution to this tension and for the faith to endure it in the meantime.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-547-1"></span>After Habakkuk's struggle to understand God, and indeed to hold God to account, we now move to a series of five woe oracles flowing from the earlier discussion. They respond to Habakkuk's complaint about God's justice while also exploring the posture of faith required by 2:4. The woe oracle as a form is derived, though also considerably adapted, from funerary mourning. When addressed to a foreign nation, this funereal element is often ironic, as Israel reflects on the end of an oppressor that is still very much alive.2 The funeral background indicates that "Woe!" should be understood as "Alas!" or "How terrible!" rather than as a gloating over adversaries. If these oracles were addressed to the Chaldeans, as is often understood, then that irony would be present here. However, Habakkuk's first complaint most likely addresses the violence and oppression within Judah, while his second is concerned that Yahweh's response in sending the Chaldeans would only make matters worse. Thus Habakkuk's complaint against God goes in two directions, addressing violence both within and beyond Judah. It therefore follows that God's response must address both sources of violence.

<span id="page-547-3"></span><span id="page-547-2"></span>It is notable that we are never told whom these woe oracles actually address. After the introduction in verse 6, which also refers to an unnamed "him" as the object of what follows, each of the five "Woe" statements (vv. 6b, 9, 12, 15, 19) is followed by a masculine singular participle describing the activities of the one who stands under judgment. Thus, although the woe oracles could be understood in the first instance as being directed against the Chaldeans (as we have noted, they were personified using the Hb. masculine singular in 1:5–11), the oracles can also be understood as addressing those who perpetrated the violence within Judah prompting Habakkuk's initial complaint. To maintain this ambiguity, we shall refer only to "the oppressor" in the comment section. Although it is never stated that Yahweh is the one who will bring the punishments announced in these

<span id="page-547-0"></span><sup>2</sup> See Gary V. Smith, *Interpreting the Prophetic Books: An Exegetical Handbook* (Grand Rapids, MI: Kregel, 2014), 37–38.

oracles, they gradually work toward a greater recognition of his involvement in the world.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-548-5"></span><span id="page-548-3"></span>II. Five Woes (2:6–20)
	- A. First Woe: The Plunder of the Plunderer (2:6–8)
	- B. Second Woe: The Deviser Decried (2:9–11)
	- C. Third Woe: The Destruction of the Destroyer (2:12–14)
	- D. Fourth Woe: Shame for Glory (2:15–17)
	- E. Fifth Woe: The Folly of Idolatry (2:18–20)

### *Comment*

2:6–8 Verse 6 does not state who it is that will "take up their taunt against" the oppressor. Who is the "all" that will do so? And why does the verb introducing his/ their speech revert to the singular ("and say")? There is no "all" referred to earlier, so the reference is ambiguous. But, as noted above, Habakkuk makes use of deliberate ambiguity in these woe oracles, so we should not be surprised at such ambiguity here. Just as the identity of the oppressor needs to be left open, so does the identity of those who take up these taunts. In effect, any who has suffered from oppression may give voice to these words.

What is perhaps more surprising is that the terms used to introduce these woe oracles ("taunt," "scoffing," "riddles") are drawn from the vocabulary of wisdom literature, not prophetic speech. Just as his prayers drew on the Psalms, Habakkuk's concern with God's justice draws on the whole range of Israel's traditions. Taking the posture of faith, these oracles draw (especially) on the wisdom tradition to suggest that Yahweh's justice will be vindicated. As wisdom observations, they do not know exactly how this will happen, but they do understand that divine justice will be resolved, treating the oppressor as an object lesson of how justice is ultimately served.

<span id="page-548-4"></span><span id="page-548-2"></span><span id="page-548-1"></span>The first woe properly begins in verse 6b. The concern here is directed against those who accumulate wealth unjustly—both the wicked within Judah (v. 7; cf. 1:4) and the Chaldeans (2:8; cf. 1:6). The oppressor has claimed what is not rightly his, and so he will lose it—the only question being when (2:6b). Although the oppressor has claimed numerous pledges, Habakkuk insists a time will come when those unjustly indebted will arise against the oppressor (v. 8)—the plunderer will become the plunder. This issue is picked up again in verse 17, which repeats the closing lines of verse 8. Justice will finally be done, although it must await its appointed time.

<span id="page-548-6"></span><span id="page-548-0"></span>2:9–11 The second woe also addresses the issue of unjust gain. Such evil gain (*betsaʻ*) is typically associated with violence (e.g., Prov. 28:16; Isa. 56:11) and again reflects the actions of both the wicked within Judah and the Chaldeans in their aggression against the nations—notably, the tribute payments they demanded. The oppressor believes wealth accumulated in this way provides security, raising his house (both the building and the family or nation) beyond the reach of those who would act against it. The oppressor reasons that just as an eagle's nest is secure because of its height (cf. Deut. 32:11; Jer. 49:16; Obad. 4), so wealth accumulated through violence puts his house out of the reach of the oppressed.

<span id="page-549-11"></span><span id="page-549-8"></span><span id="page-549-0"></span>Proverbs 15:27, which perhaps lies in the background here, insists that those who are greedy for such gain bring trouble, not security, to their household. Thus this attempt to create security is actually a means of creating shame, while "cutting off many peoples" (Hab. 2:10) is to forfeit life. Justice will be served, and once again the penalty will match the crime. Indeed, instead of the house being a place of security, its stones and woodwork will "cry out." The oppressor cannot create security; instead, oppressors within Israel will be among the elite either killed or taken in exile to Babylon (Jer. 52:24–30), while Babylon will also find itself unprotected by its wealth (Daniel 5).

<span id="page-549-12"></span><span id="page-549-10"></span><span id="page-549-9"></span><span id="page-549-7"></span>2:12–14 The third woe expands the focus of the second as it considers those who build a city with bloodshed, founding it on violent "iniquity" (cf. the use of the Hb. term *ʻawlah* in 2 Sam. 7:10). Again, this applies equally to those in Jerusalem (perhaps associated with the court of Jehoiakim) who profited from the oppression of the poor and to the Chaldeans who rebuilt Babylon with resources plundered through relentlessly expansionist policies under Nabopolassar and Nebuchadnezzar.

Such actions are clearly unacceptable, but this woe-oracle goes beyond the preceding ones by introducing Yahweh for the first time. Habakkuk moves from simply observing that oppression bears the seeds of its own downfall to noting there is something about Yahweh's involvement in the world that brings about such unexpected results. Habakkuk's use of the title "Yahweh of hosts" (lit.) here is important. Although the origin of this title is disputed, its usage seems particularly concerned with Yahweh's visible control over world events. The name first occurs in the books of Samuel, where it occurs in clusters in the context of significant changes in Israel's social structure.

<span id="page-549-6"></span><span id="page-549-5"></span><span id="page-549-3"></span><span id="page-549-2"></span><span id="page-549-1"></span>For example, it occurs three times in the opening four chapters (1 Sam. 1:3, 11; 4:4) surrounding Samuel's initiation as the last judge of Israel; twice in the middle of the book in the transition from Saul to David (1 Sam. 15:2; 17:45); and then a further seven times as David is established in Jerusalem (2 Sam. 5:10; 6:2, 18; 7:8, 26, 27). It occurs nowhere else in the book. Yet each cluster is notable for the changes described: preparing for monarchy, changing monarchs, and confirming David. David's speech to Goliath particularly recognizes this reality: it was knowing that he came in the name of Yahweh of hosts that assured him Goliath would be defeated (1 Sam. 17:45–46).

<span id="page-549-4"></span>Introducing the divine title here is thus part of Habakkuk's strategy for indicating a deeper reality at work in human history, a power greater than the oppressor. The oppressors' building projects may be intended to point to their grandeur

<span id="page-550-8"></span><span id="page-550-6"></span><span id="page-550-1"></span><span id="page-550-0"></span>(a claim made by Nebuchadnezzar; Dan. 4:30), but Yahweh's sovereign hand means the oppressors will end up toiling for even the basics ("fire" and "nothing"; Hab. 2:13). Instead of the glory of the oppressor, the earth will be filled with the knowledge of Yahweh's glory (v. 14). This glory is a display of God's fundamental character, such as when he allowed Moses to see his glory and so announced himself as merciful, gracious, and just (Ex. 33:17–34:9). The declaration of Habakkuk 2:14 brings together two earlier texts: Numbers 14:21, where the Lord says, "the earth shall be filled with [my] glory"; and Isaiah 11:9, where the prophet declares, "the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord as the waters cover the sea." By bringing glory and knowledge together, Habakkuk insists that Yahweh's true character will ultimately be known by all, thus warning the oppressors of their imminent doom if they continue in their oppression.

<span id="page-550-9"></span><span id="page-550-5"></span><span id="page-550-4"></span>2:15–17 The fourth oracle builds on the expressly theological perspective introduced in the third oracle while further depicting how the oppressor belittles others. The oracle uses vivid imagery of the oppressor forcing his victims to drink its wrath shamefully. Other OT texts reflect on the shame the Chaldeans brought to conquered peoples (Isa. 54:4; Zeph. 3:19), while Jeremiah 51:7 describes this oppressive nation as a cup of drunkenness. Likewise in Judah the powerful were manipulating and controlling the experiences of others in order to exploit them in various ways.

The desire to shame others is the particular focus of this oracle. The irony is that those desiring to shame others will themselves be shamed. Whereas they had previously sought to shame others by exposing their nakedness, they themselves will now be shamed. The verb translated "show your uncircumcision" might also be translated "be reckoned as uncircumcised"; oppressors among the covenant community will be considered no longer a part of it. Yahweh, the one who holds the true cup of shame, will bring it upon them as an exact retribution for their crime. The image of Yahweh holding a cup of judgment is a common one (e.g., Ps. 75:8) and may reflect rituals performed in the temple, but the key point is that Yahweh exposes the actions of the oppressor for what they are.

<span id="page-550-2"></span>The prophet refers specifically to violence done to Lebanon as the type of violence that will overwhelm the oppressor, violence that saw murder and willful destruction of animals. The exact historical atrocity referenced here is unclear, and perhaps Habakkuk is drawing on the frequent boast of ancient Near Eastern kings of having plundered Lebanon. What is clear in any case is the wider pattern in which oppressors were attacking the weak (cf. the repetition of Hab. 2:8b in v. 17). As such, this is now one example among many of the plundering of nations, the perpetrators of which now stand under the Lord's judgment.

<span id="page-550-11"></span><span id="page-550-10"></span><span id="page-550-7"></span><span id="page-550-3"></span>2:18–20 The final woe oracle is distinct from the previous four in its emphasis on idolatry rather than oppression (although the two are often related). Moreover, the term "woe" is deferred until verse 19 instead of beginning the oracle. The OT is replete with denunciations of idolatry (e.g., Ps. 115:4–8; Isa. 40:18–20; 41:21–29;

<span id="page-551-0"></span>44:9–20), representing a major break with the dominant ancient Near Eastern culture. As is common in the OT, Habakkuk notes that idols are human creations that offer no profit. Habakkuk develops a paradox: although an idol is silent, it nevertheless is able to deceive those who trust it. Thus those trusting idols stand under divine judgment, for telling a piece of wood or stone to awaken or arise is foolish, and no amount of gold or silver overlay will give it life. By contrast, Yahweh is real and is present in his temple, and all the earth is called to silence before him. In this way, Habakkuk brings the woe oracles to a close while also preparing for the psalm of chapter 3.

<span id="page-551-5"></span><span id="page-551-2"></span>Yahweh dwells in his temple, and from there he sees all; once this reality is recognized, one understands that the temple is also the divine palace, the place from which the true king dispenses justice. Idolatry attempts to avoid Yahweh's claims by denying the reality of his existence. Yet life must be lived under his rule, and the oppressors of chapter 2 have missed this fundamental fact. Further, Yahweh's rule from his temple grounds the claim of 2:3 in a fundamental reality. The reality of his rule over all the earth means those living by faith can be sure his justice will finally be seen, even if its exact timing is not disclosed.

### <span id="page-551-4"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-551-3"></span><span id="page-551-1"></span>Habakkuk's problem in 1:1–2:5 was that he could not see God's justice being worked out in the world around him. Violence was multiplied in Judah, and God's initial solution to that problem—the Chaldeans—seemed only worse. However, 2:2–5 suggested a fundamental attitude that could help the prophet in his perplexity. He needed to understand that Yahweh's purposes did not necessarily proceed at the same pace as did those of the prophet, nor of any other human. With this realization, faith was necessary to appreciate that Yahweh would indeed act justly; oppression would be addressed.

The five woes in this passage then begin to resolve these concerns in light of the posture established by 2:2–5. How does God act justly? Will he do so within history, or only at the end? The woes insist that justice will be done, but it may be done either within history or eschatologically. The oppressors, whether they be the Chaldeans, the violent within Judah, or any others since then, stand under God's judgment.

The first two woe oracles suggest that judgment on the oppressors may come from their own actions—their oppressive violence sows the seeds of their own destruction. Sometimes no direct action from God is required as such violence eventually undoes itself. The last three woe oracles, however, explicitly mention Yahweh's involvement. There are times when God intervenes and overthrows the violent with justice measured exactly to the crime. It is difficult for those who witness such judgment to know if God's justice comes about from direct intervention or because of the way violence inherently destroys itself. Nevertheless, in whichever way justice is served, it is God who has brought it about, for he sovereignly controls even things that happen "naturally." Justice will be done.

<span id="page-552-1"></span><span id="page-552-0"></span>This reality is grounded ultimately in the character of Yahweh as the one who is supreme over all, before whom all other "gods" are shown to be petty nothings. As Yahweh is enthroned in his temple and all are to be silent before him, we can live by faith, trusting that in God's time we will see justice done when Babylon the great has finally fallen (Revelation 18).

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-553-4"></span><span id="page-553-3"></span><span id="page-553-2"></span><span id="page-553-1"></span><span id="page-553-0"></span>Chapter 3 is clearly distinct from the two previous chapters of Habakkuk, yet it is also the logical conclusion to the book. Like many of the psalms, it has a superscription, describing it as a "prayer of Habakkuk," as several psalms are similarly headed (Psalms 17; 86; 90; 102; 142). Habakkuk's prayer is "according to Shigionoth," a plural form of a term also appearing in the superscription to Psalm 7. Its meaning is unknown, although it could refer to a tune used in worship. The use of "*Selah*" (Hab. 3:3, 9, 13) is also typical of psalms, although its meaning also is unknown. Also typical of psalms is the note "to the choirmaster" (v. 19), which occurs in the superscription of fifty-five psalms; here, unusually, it occurs as a closing note. Habakkuk's prayer frequently alludes to various psalms and is either composed in archaic poetry or drawn in part from existing poems reflecting such psalms, suggesting that Habakkuk's prayer is shaped by reflection on the Psalter.

<span id="page-554-1"></span><span id="page-554-0"></span>Despite this chapter's distinct character within the book of Habakkuk, it is clearly a logical conclusion to the book as a whole, developing earlier themes. In 1:1–2:5 Habakkuk complained about the violence within Judah and then about Yahweh's response in sending the Chaldeans. That passage climaxed with the assertion that the righteous must live by faith, trusting Yahweh to do ultimately what is just. Then followed the five woes outlined in 2:6–20, which declared the downfall of the wicked and violent, both because their violence contained the seeds of their own destruction and because of Yahweh's direct action. These woes climaxed in the declaration of Yahweh's presence in the temple but did not give a timetable for when the wicked would be overthrown. These first two sections of the book have thus stressed the importance of living by faith, a key part of which is acknowledging that Yahweh's justice will ultimately be seen.

<span id="page-554-2"></span>But what does that mean for those who live in a world marked by violence and injustice? This issue is addressed in the prayer of chapter 3. Very little of the prayer can be called intercession, with the only petitions occurring in verse 2. Rather, it is a speech addressed to God in which the prophet reflects on God's actions on behalf of his people and realizes that the posture of faith involves continuing to trust, indeed to rejoice, in God as the one who comes to deliver his people. Habakkuk has not yet seen a change in his position—indeed, he understands it may well get worse before it gets better—but he knows from Israel's tradition and worship that God's justice will ultimately be experienced. This is what he finally understands in this prayer, a prayer that in turn is presented as a challenge to those who read to appreciate its reality for them as well.

	- B. Yahweh's Coming (3:2–15)
		- 1. Plea for Mercy (3:2)
		- 2. The Journey from the South (3:3–7)
