|          |                                                        |
|          |                                                        |

## SIX-WEEK SERMON SERIES

- 1:1–2:13 The Return of the Lord
- 3:1–4:14 Cleansed for Service
- 5:1–6:15 Two Ways to Build (Houses of Iniquity or a House for the Lord)
- 7:1–8:23 What Matters More Than Fasting
- 9:1–11:17 God and His King Will Triumph for His People
- 12:1–14:21 The Day God Was Pierced

#### PREACHING THE NIGHT VISIONS

While Zechariah is not strictly apocalyptic literature, an understanding of how this literary genre works will aid preaching. Apocalyptic literature paints striking pictures with words. It draws in the audience by arousing curiosity and creating something of a puzzle that calls for an explanation, similar to Jesus' parables. When things fall into place, there is an "Aha! moment," by which time the audience is drawn into the visionary world. In preaching Zechariah's night visions, it is good to ask questions about what Zechariah is reported as seeing so as to arouse curiosity and build tension before seeking to explain the important elements and the overall meaning of the vision.

<span id="page-637-0"></span>One mistake in interpreting apocalyptic literature is to seek to identify the significance of every element of the picture. Some elements simply contribute to the picture's background and have no other purpose. The important elements of the vision are the ones that are explained, and these are the ones that should be focused on in preaching. For instance, in the first vision there is no meaning given to the different colors of the horses (1:8). All the colors seem to do is distinguish between the groups of horses. What is important is what the horses do: patrol the earth as agents of the Lord and expressions of his sovereignty (1:11). Since this is explained in the vision, it is the significant element that must be focused on in preaching.

<span id="page-637-3"></span><span id="page-637-2"></span><span id="page-637-1"></span>There is also a movement through the visions that is important to recognize. Visions 1–5 portray God's returning to his people, bringing forgiveness, cleansing, and prosperity. This sequence finishes with a house (temple) built for the Lord in Jerusalem (ch. 4). In visions 6–8 there is the opposite movement. Iniquity, wickedness, and all that is opposed to God are driven from the land. In this sequence, the houses of the covenant breakers come crashing in on their heads (5:4), a house is built for wickedness in Babylon (5:11), and Babylon experiences the Lord's wrath (6:8). Recognizing this movement and the themes connecting the visions may help when preaching on more than one vision at a time.

#### <span id="page-637-4"></span>PREACHING THE SIGN-ACTIONS

Sign-actions are visible representations of the prophetic message designed not only to convey the message but also to affect the emotions. Just as seeing a play or drama on stage can have a greater impact than reading it on the page, so the preacher should try to bring the drama alive as much as possible. Like the night visions, the key elements of the prophetic drama need to be explained and their impact felt.

#### PREACHING THE ORACLES

<span id="page-637-5"></span>Like the night visions, an understanding of how apocalyptic literature works is useful also for preaching the oracles. Just as the book of Revelation pictures the same reality in a cycle of seven seals, seven trumpets, and seven bowls, so chapters 9–14 of Zechariah look at the reality of God's coming kingdom from different <span id="page-638-0"></span>perspectives. While there are a number of battles mentioned in these chapters, it is not a sequence of different battles. Rather, it is one end-time battle ushering in God's kingdom, explored from different perspectives; each perspective contributes something more to the overall picture. Chapters 9 and 12 give the "big picture" of what will happen "on that day" as God saves and delivers his people from their enemies. The focus of chapters 10–11 is what this day will mean for the leadership of God's people, while the focus in chapters 13–14 is the cleansing coming on that day as Jerusalem is cleansed of sin and made holy.

#### <span id="page-638-6"></span><span id="page-638-3"></span>PREACHING CHRIST FROM ZECHARIAH

<span id="page-638-11"></span><span id="page-638-10"></span><span id="page-638-9"></span>Followers of Jesus Christ must follow his lead in looking for ways in which the OT testifies to him (cf. Luke 24:27, 44). The NT demonstrates how the earliest Christians explored a wide range of OT passages to show their fulfillment in the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus. Christians are likewise encouraged to follow the example of Jesus, the apostles, and other NT authors in interpreting the OT in a way that proclaims Jesus as Savior and Lord (e.g., Acts 10:43; Rom. 1:1–4; 3:21–22).3 This does not mean that every OT sermon will have Jesus "tacked on" in the same predictable way, but it does mean that every OT sermon will be approached through a framework of understanding Jesus as the fulfillment of the hopes for Israel and the world. This gospel framework is like a prism refracting the light of the OT into a spectacular spectrum of color—there is no excuse for being monochromatic and predictable in each sermon. It is not that Christ is to be read back into the OT in ways that seem forced; instead, the preacher is to show how the people, laws, institutions, and events in the OT anticipate and illuminate the significance of Jesus Christ (who he is and what he has accomplished) and what it means to live as God's people now in light of the new covenant he has established (identifying elements of continuity and discontinuity). Preaching the OT in light of the gospel of Jesus Christ is essential to avoid the twin dangers of allegorizing the OT or moralizing its message by teaching "rules" and "morals" without grace.4

<span id="page-638-2"></span><span id="page-638-1"></span>The gospel of Jesus is often neglected in the preaching of Zechariah by approaching the book (esp. chs. 9–14) as if it were all about Jesus' second coming and events at the end of the world. This fails to see how the NT cites and alludes to Zechariah with reference to Jesus' first coming. For instance, all the Gospel writers report that Jesus rode a donkey into Jerusalem (Zech. 9:9). Jesus quotes 13:7 ("I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered") just before being arrested (Matt. 26:31). Judas's betrayal of Jesus for thirty pieces of silver has Zechariah 11:12–13 in the background. The piercing of Jesus' side by the soldier fulfills 12:10 (cf. Rev. 1:7). His driving out the merchants from the temple fulfills Zechariah 14:21. These references show how the kingdom prophesied in Zechariah came initially in the first coming of Jesus.

<span id="page-638-8"></span><span id="page-638-7"></span><span id="page-638-5"></span><span id="page-638-4"></span><sup>3</sup> For a brief review of approaches to preaching Christ from the OT, see David Peterson, *Christ and His People in the Book of Isaiah* (Leicester, UK: IVP, 2003), 11–25.

<sup>4</sup> On these dangers, see Edmund P. Clowney, *Preaching Christ in All of Scripture* (Wheaton, IL: Crossway, 2003), 32–34.

<span id="page-639-11"></span><span id="page-639-10"></span><span id="page-639-9"></span>At the same time, the book of Revelation connects the imagery of Zechariah with the new Jerusalem to be realized at Jesus' return. Consider, e.g., "living waters" (Zech. 14:8; cf. Rev. 21:6; 22:1, 17); Jerusalem as a place of feasting (Zech. 14:16, 19, 21; cf. Rev. 19:9); absence of night (Zech. 14:6; cf. Rev. 21:25; 22:5); the city's holiness (Zech. 14:20–21; cf. Rev. 22:11, 14); worship and tribute of the nations (Zech. 2:11; 8:22–23; 14:16; cf. Rev. 21:24, 26; 22:2); exclusion of all wickedness (Zech. 13:2–6; 14:21; cf. Rev. 21:8; 22:15); and the kingship of God (Zech. 14:9; cf. Rev. 22:1, which includes the kingship of the Lamb).

<span id="page-639-13"></span><span id="page-639-7"></span><span id="page-639-2"></span><span id="page-639-1"></span>These examples illustrate the NT's "already and not yet" time frame for the fulfillment of Zechariah's hopes for God's coming kingdom, and in both instances (the "already" and the "not yet") Christ is central. At the same time, the themes of Zechariah are directly relevant for the church today, and the application of Zechariah's message will be considered in the "Response" sections of the commentary that follows. These sections may be a stimulus for application in preaching. Some of these themes for application include the continuing call to repent from sin (Zech. 1:3; cf. Matt. 3:8; 2 Pet. 3:9); the need for cleansing, forgiveness, and holiness (Zech. 3:4, 9; 13:1; 14:20–21; cf. Eph. 5:26; Col. 1:14; 1 Pet. 1:15–16); the way in which building the temple connects with building the church (Zechariah 4; cf. Eph. 2:21–22); the expectation that God's people will be refined by suffering (Zech. 13:8; cf. 1 Pet. 1:7); and the Christian life as a battle (Zech. 9:13; 10:5, 7; 12:6–9; 14:2–3; cf. 2 Cor. 10:4–5; Col. 3:5).

### <span id="page-639-12"></span><span id="page-639-8"></span><span id="page-639-6"></span><span id="page-639-4"></span><span id="page-639-3"></span>*Interpretive Challenges*

#### THE UNITY OF THE BOOK

<span id="page-639-5"></span><span id="page-639-0"></span>Since the seventeenth century, some scholars have challenged the traditional view that Zechariah is the author of the book. While most scholars see much of chapters 1–8 as coming from Zechariah, the different literary style of chapters 9–14 and some of their historical references, such as "Greece" (9:13), are taken by some to indicate someone other than Zechariah is responsible for those chapters. Earlier scholars in this period argued that 9–14 are preexilic, but in the eighteenth century a number of scholars came to believe these chapters were composed hundreds of years after Zechariah, in the Greek period (4th to 2nd centuries BC).

Recent scholarship on Zechariah supports reading the book as a unity and taking the book as it presents itself—essentially as the product of the prophet Zechariah. The development and coherence of many themes across the book provide evidence for this, along with several literary features consistent throughout the book. The often unstated assumption that Zechariah was able to write in only one literary style cannot be sustained. The different styles may simply reflect different stages in Zechariah's prophetic ministry, with chapters 1–8 reflecting the period before the temple's completion and 9–14 the period shortly after. We will see in the commentary how references in chapters 9–14 can be understood as consistent with Zechariah's time. In addition, there is no external evidence that

the book of Zechariah ever circulated in parts. While fragmentary, Qumran manuscripts support seeing Zechariah as a single work.

## <span id="page-642-1"></span>ZECHARIAH 1:1–6

1In the eighth month, in the second year of Darius, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, son of Iddo, saying, **<sup>2</sup>** "The Lord was very angry with your fathers. **3**Therefore say to them, Thus declares the Lord of hosts: Return to me, says the Lord of hosts, and I will return to you, says the Lord of hosts. **4**Do not be like your fathers, to whom the former prophets cried out, 'Thus says the Lord of hosts, Return from your evil ways and from your evil deeds.' But they did not hear or pay attention to me, declares the Lord. **5**Your fathers, where are they? And the prophets, do they live forever? **6**But my words and my statutes, which I commanded my servants the prophets, did they not overtake your fathers? So they repented and said, 'As the Lord of hosts purposed to deal with us for our ways and deeds, so has he dealt with us.' "

### *Section Overview*

The book begins with a call to return to God in covenant obedience. If the people do so, God graciously promises to return to them.

<span id="page-642-5"></span><span id="page-642-4"></span><span id="page-642-3"></span><span id="page-642-2"></span><span id="page-642-0"></span>After a dating formula (1:1), Zechariah reviews Israel's past experience. The people refused to listen to God's word through his prophets and continued in willful rebellion (vv. 2–5). They were eventually overtaken by God's judgment, as he had warned (vv. 5–6a). In recounting this lesson from Israel's history, Zechariah calls on his contemporaries to return to the Lord in repentance (v. 3). This introductory passage concludes by recording the people's obedience to Zechariah's appeal (v. 6b).

<span id="page-643-16"></span><span id="page-643-14"></span><span id="page-643-13"></span><span id="page-643-10"></span>In relation to the rest of the book, the night visions (1:7–6:8), sign-action (6:9–15), and the prophet's reply to a query about fasting (7:1–8:23) indicate what this "return" (1:3), or repentance, should look like for God's people. The two prophetic oracles of chapters 9–14 portray vividly the impact of God's return for God's people and the entire world.

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-643-8"></span>I. Introduction: Return to Me and I Will Return to You (1:1–6)
	- A. Setting (1:1)
	- B. Do Not Be Like Your Fathers (1:2–6a)
	- C. The People Repent (1:6b)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-643-12"></span><span id="page-643-9"></span><span id="page-643-4"></span>1:1 The dating formula locates Zechariah's prophetic ministry in reference to the Persian king Darius (cf. v. 7; 7:1; cf. Introduction: Date and Occasion). Whereas earlier Prophetic Books are dated with reference to the reigns of kings of Israel and Judah (e.g., Isa. 1:1; Hos. 1:1), dating with reference to a foreign king suggests the shadow of exile still hanging over God's people (cf. comment on Zech. 1:2–6a). The dating formula also places Zechariah in relation to Jeremiah's prophecy of seventy years of desolation for Judah as punishment for not heeding God's words (Jer. 25:4–12; cf. Zech. 1:12).

<span id="page-643-6"></span><span id="page-643-1"></span><span id="page-643-0"></span>Darius succeeded Cambyses (r. 530–522 BC) and Cyrus (r. 559–530). In 539 BC, Cyrus had decreed the Judean exiles in Babylonia could return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple (cf. Ezra 1:1–4). However, an initial attempt to rebuild the temple came to a halt (Ezra 4:24). The date in this verse is some twenty years later (520 BC), and the "eighth month" is late October to late November, two months after temple building had resumed (cf. Hag. 1:14–15). This is around 66 years after the city of Jerusalem and its temple were destroyed by the Babylonians (in 586 BC).

<span id="page-643-15"></span><span id="page-643-7"></span><span id="page-643-2"></span>The phrase "the word of the Lord came to" is a messenger-reception formula indicating Zechariah's status as a prophet of God (cf. Zech. 7:1). The description "son of Berechiah, son of Iddo" places Zechariah in a priestly family (cf. Ezra 5:1; 6:14; Neh. 12:4–7, 16). This may explain the book's focus on the temple and cleansing from sin (like the prophets Jeremiah and Ezekiel, also from priestly families).

<span id="page-643-11"></span><span id="page-643-3"></span>1:2–6a Zechariah addresses his contemporaries, whose "fathers" (or "ancestors") were those on whom God's anger fell, resulting ultimately in the destruction of Jerusalem and exile. God was "very angry" because their fathers refused to obey his word repeatedly spoken by the "former prophets" (v. 4). The "former prophets" can refer to prophets like Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezekiel who called on the people to repent (e.g., Isa. 45:22; Jer. 18:11; 25:5; Ezek. 33:11), but is used also to refer to the Historical Books of Joshua—Kings, which also explain how the devastation and exile of the northern and southern kingdoms were because of God's wrath against sin.

<span id="page-643-5"></span>God is called "Lord of hosts," which can also be translated "Yahweh of armies" or "Yahweh, the Almighty." The "hosts" or "armies" are heavenly beings, such as <span id="page-644-10"></span><span id="page-644-5"></span>the horses and chariots in Zechariah 6:1–8. This title occurs fifty-three times in Zechariah and speaks of God's might as king and his universal rule. It occurs three times in 1:3 to emphasize why the people should listen to God's word through Zechariah.

Zechariah is to summon the people to "return to me"—a call to repentance and obedience to the national covenant.5 In response, God promises, "I will return to you"—a promise of full restoration of the blessings of the covenant. In the wider context of the book, this promise also speaks of God's return to the temple to dwell among his people, a key theme of Zechariah (cf. 1:16; 8:3, 15; 9:8–9; 14:16–21; cf. also Introduction: Theology of Zechariah: The Return of the Lord).

<span id="page-644-11"></span><span id="page-644-9"></span><span id="page-644-8"></span><span id="page-644-4"></span>To "return" (or "repent") involves turning to God "from your evil ways and from your evil deeds" (1:4; cf. Jer. 18:11; 25:5; 35:15). These evils the earlier prophets spoke against include idolatry, religious hypocrisy, and social injustice, which recurred among God's people in Zechariah's day (Zech. 5:3–4, 6; 7:9–10; 8:16–17; 10:2; 13:2). These evils are symptoms of a greater underlying problem God identifies when he says, "They did not hear or pay attention to me." The heart of sin is a heart that rejects the word of God. Indeed, to reject God's word is to reject God himself. This is why God was so angry with the fathers, who experienced his judgment.

<span id="page-644-6"></span>In 1:5, Zechariah asks two rhetorical questions to help his contemporaries reflect on the consequences of rejecting God's word. "Your fathers, where are they?" makes the point that the fathers have died in exile for their sins. "The prophets, do they live forever?" uses a form in Hebrew that expects the answer "no." The implication is that the prophets who provided the warning to God's people also eventually fell under his judgment and died. The people should heed God's word and return to him while there is still time.

<span id="page-644-3"></span><span id="page-644-2"></span>A third rhetorical question in verse 6a is designed to cause Zechariah's contemporaries to acknowledge that God's word achieves its purposes (cf. Isa. 55:11). The phrase "my words and my statutes" reflects Deuteronomy, where the phrase refers to the requirements of the national covenant and to the covenant itself (e.g., Deut. 28:15, 45; 29:1). The core of the prophets' task was to call Israel back to the national covenant, reminding them of blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience (e.g., Leviticus 26; Deuteronomy 28). In this context, "overtake" refers to the curses coming on the people for disobedience, climaxing in the judgment of exile (cf. Deut. 28:2, 45).

<span id="page-644-7"></span><span id="page-644-1"></span><span id="page-644-0"></span>1:6b Commentators are divided on whether it is the fathers or Zechariah's contemporaries who are reported as repenting ("they repented"). In the flow of the Hebrew, the pronoun "they" most naturally refers back to the fathers, as the ESV indicates. However, in terms of the logic of Zechariah's presentation, since judgment overtook the fathers and they are no more (v. 5), "they" is better understood as referring to Zechariah's contemporaries. What is reported in this verse is that

<sup>5</sup> The Hebrew word *shub* can be translated either "return" or "repent."

those who heard God's word proclaimed by Zechariah repented and acknowledged the rightness of God's dealings with his people. Significantly, the repentance of the returned exiles is also recounted as the response to the preaching of Haggai, Zechariah's contemporary (cf. Hag. 1:12–14).

### <span id="page-645-1"></span>*Response*

Zechariah calls on his contemporaries to heed God's word and not make the same mistake as their ancestors, who ignored God and his word and suffered his righteous judgment. Zechariah's charge to return to God remains for later readers and hearers of his book. To repent is more than merely feeling sorry for wrongdoing. It is not "doing penance" or punishing yourself for your sin. It is not a human work by which we can earn forgiveness. Repentance is turning from "evil ways . . . and evil deeds" back to God and obedience to his word. It is not a one-time act but an ongoing daily response to God's word.

<span id="page-645-0"></span>In his grace, God promises to return to his people. For Zechariah's contemporaries, this would have brought to mind God's promise in Jeremiah of restoration and forgiveness of sin after seventy years of exile, with God restoring the fortunes of the city of Jerusalem and the land, making a new covenant, and providing a righteous Davidic king (e.g., Jer. 29:10–14; 31:23–40; 33:6–26). This restoration and return of God to his people was fulfilled ultimately in the coming of Jesus. For readers and hearers of Zechariah today, the challenge of this passage is to turn to Jesus in repentance and faith with the knowledge that through his death he has won for us forgiveness and a restored relationship with God, along with the blessings of being his new covenant people. This passage also reminds us that God's word achieves its purposes in both judgment and salvation.

## <span id="page-645-2"></span>ZECHARIAH 1:7–17

**<sup>7</sup>**On the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month, which is the month of Shebat, in the second year of Darius, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, son of Iddo, saying, **<sup>8</sup>** "I saw in the night, and behold, a man riding on a red horse! He was standing among the myrtle trees in the glen, and behind him were red, sorrel, and white horses. **9**Then I said, 'What are these, my lord?' The angel who talked with me said to me, 'I will show you what they are.' **<sup>10</sup>** So the man who was standing among the myrtle trees answered, 'These are they whom the Lord has sent to patrol the earth.' **11**And they answered the angel of the Lord who was standing among the myrtle trees, and said, 'We have patrolled the earth, and behold, all the earth remains at rest.' **<sup>12</sup>**Then the angel of the Lord said, 'O Lord of hosts, how long will you have no mercy on Jerusalem and the cities of Judah, against which you

have been angry these seventy years?' **13**And the Lord answered gracious and comforting words to the angel who talked with me. **<sup>14</sup>** So the angel who talked with me said to me, 'Cry out, Thus says the Lord of hosts: I am exceedingly jealous for Jerusalem and for Zion. **15**And I am exceedingly angry with the nations that are at ease; for while I was angry but a little, they furthered the disaster. **16**Therefore, thus says the Lord, I have returned to Jerusalem with mercy; my house shall be built in it, declares the Lord of hosts, and the measuring line shall be stretched out over Jerusalem. **17**Cry out again, Thus says the Lord of hosts: My cities shall again overflow with prosperity, and the Lord will again comfort Zion and again choose Jerusalem.' "

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-646-1"></span>Zechariah 1:7–6:8 contains eight night visions given to the prophet Zechariah. While they are not explicitly called "visions," they are to be understood as such since Zechariah is given them in a conscious state, as opposed to dreams, which are given in sleep (note how Zechariah is awakened by the interpreting angel in 4:1 and then, once awakened, is shown the next vision).

<span id="page-646-3"></span><span id="page-646-2"></span><span id="page-646-0"></span>These night visions display a thematic pattern. In the first five visions (1:7– 4:14), God is portrayed as returning to his people to establish his kingdom, bringing forgiveness, cleansing, and blessing. The last three visions (5:1–6:8) picture the opposite movement—sin and sinners are judged and all that is opposed to God is driven from the land. The backdrop for these visions is God's earlier abandonment of the Jerusalem temple, his palace, in the Babylonian destruction and captivity of 586 BC. This first vision proclaims the end of the exile, God's coming judgment of the nations, the rebuilding of Jerusalem and the temple, and his return to restore abundant blessing. Theologically it emphasizes the sovereignty of God, who will establish his kingdom.

While the visions are not strictly apocalyptic literature, they share many features of this literary genre, and it is useful to interpret them in view of this (cf. Introduction: Preaching from Zechariah: Preaching the Night Visions). Sometimes aspects of the visions simply contribute to the overall picture rather than having specific significance, so it is important not to seek meaning in every detail Zechariah reports. The important elements are those identified and explained in the text.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-647-10"></span><span id="page-647-2"></span><span id="page-647-0"></span>1:7 The sequence of eight night visions is introduced with a further dating formula, this time with a specific date (cf. 1:1 and comment). The "eleventh month" is identified as "Shebat," a Babylonian name adopted by the people of Judah (cf. "Chislev"; 7:1). Dating to the reign of a foreign king (cf. 1:1) and using the language of foreign nations ("Shebat") indicates a situation that should not be: even though God's people have returned to Jerusalem, they are still experiencing elements of exile. The date corresponds to February 15, 519 BC, about three months after the date in verse 1.

<span id="page-647-1"></span>"The word of the Lord came to the prophet Zechariah" underscores again the divine origin of Zechariah's message (cf. vv. 1, 3).

<span id="page-647-3"></span>1:8 God's word comes to Zechariah as a series of night visions. All eight visions were likely received on this one night, since none of the other visions are dated, and each new vision is closely joined to the previous one by the Hebrew syntax.

<span id="page-647-11"></span>Zechariah sees a "man riding on a red horse." Horses were used for military or royal purposes and have great speed. Behind the man were "red, sorrel, and white horses." These are typical horse colors and do not seem to function symbolically here (unlike in Revelation 6). The color red could also be translated "chestnut," and sorrel could also be translated "bay," a bright color that may have a yellow, gold, or red hue.6 In Hebrew, the colors are a plural form of the adjective, suggesting multiple horses of each color. While not explicit, verse 11 suggests the horses have riders, since they speak to the angel of the Lord. The significance of the "myrtle trees in the glen" is not stated; "glen" is difficult to translate but could also be translated "by the deep," referring to a body of water, such as a river, beside which myrtles were growing. These features may contribute only to the picture portrayed in the vision, not its meaning.

<span id="page-647-4"></span>1:9–10 The angel who speaks with Zechariah is found in seven of the eight visions and explains the important features of the visions (he is often called the "interpreting angel" to distinguish him from other angelic figures). Here he promises to show Zechariah the significance of the scene.

<span id="page-647-6"></span><span id="page-647-5"></span>The man who "was standing among the myrtle trees" (v. 10) is later identified as the "angel of the Lord" (v. 11), and he explains the function of the horses: they have been "sent to patrol the earth" (v. 10). Modeled on the Persian horsemen who patrolled the empire (carrying messages and garnering intelligence like Sauron's Ringwraiths in *The Lord of the Rings*, but without sinister overtones), these horses provide surveillance for God and express his sovereign rule over the "earth" (Hb. *'erets*).7

<sup>6</sup> See further J. E. Hartley, *The Semantics of Ancient Hebrew Colour Lexemes*, ANESSup 33 (Leuven, Belgium: Peeters, 2010), 33, 34, 37, 119, 174.

<span id="page-647-9"></span><span id="page-647-8"></span><span id="page-647-7"></span><sup>7</sup> The word *'erets* occurs forty-two times in Zechariah, and its exact meaning must be determined from each context. It can mean the "land" of Israel's inheritance (e.g., 3:9; 7:5; 11:6), the "land" of the nations (e.g., 5:11; 6:6; 10:10), the "earth" as opposed to the sky or heavens (5:9), or the "ground" from which plants grow (8:12). Here it is translated "earth" since it includes the abode of the "nations" (1:15; cf. 6:6–7).

<span id="page-648-15"></span><span id="page-648-10"></span><span id="page-648-1"></span>1:11–12 The "angel of the Lord" represents God and speaks for him yet is distinct from him. In Zechariah, he appears only here and in the fourth vision (3:1, 5–6). He seems to be more than simply an angel, and elsewhere is an appearance of God in human form (e.g., Judg. 6:11–23; 13:3–23). While some therefore deduce he is an appearance of the preincarnate Christ, caution is called for in making this claim since this connection is never made in the NT.

<span id="page-648-6"></span>The riders of the horses report to the angel of the Lord (and hence also to the Lord himself) that "all the earth remains at rest" (Zech. 1:11). God had promised his people "rest" and "peace" after restoration to the land (e.g., Jer. 30:10). Presumably by the end of Darius's second year the Jewish people expected release from Persian control, but this "rest" was the experience of the nations, not of God's people. This report provokes a complaint: "O Lord of hosts, how long will you have no mercy on Jerusalem and the cities of Judah?" (Zech. 1:12).

<span id="page-648-11"></span><span id="page-648-8"></span><span id="page-648-7"></span><span id="page-648-5"></span>As in the introduction (vv. 1–6), here the exile is portrayed as an expression of God's judgment—his "anger" or "curse," prophesied by Jeremiah as lasting seventy years (cf. Jer. 25:11–12; 29:10; Zech. 7:5). The exact beginning and end points are not clear (cf. Dan. 9:2, 24–27). The seventy years could be symbolic of a lifespan or could approximate the 70-year period between the rise of Nebuchadnezzar (605 BC) and the decree of Cyrus that the exiles could return home (539). Most likely it refers to the years of temple desolation—between its destruction in 586 BC and its rebuilding in 515 (cf. Ezra 6:15). In any case, the completion of seventy years will bring an end to God's anger and usher in his return to dwell with and bless his people.

<span id="page-648-12"></span><span id="page-648-3"></span><span id="page-648-2"></span>1:13 In response to Zechariah's lament, the Lord answers with "gracious and comforting words" to the angel, who presumably communicates these words to Zechariah in verses 14–17. Comfort brings to mind Isaiah 40, which concerns the end of exile and the coming of God to save his people.

<span id="page-648-13"></span><span id="page-648-4"></span>1:14 Like the prophet Isaiah, Zechariah is also to "cry out" (cf. Isa. 40:6). He is to proclaim God's great jealousy for Jerusalem and Zion. Although jealousy can have negative associations today, there is proper jealousy, such as between a husband and wife who have pledged to share their lives and intimacy only with each other. In the OT, God's jealousy arises from his covenant relationship with his people and describes his passion for this relationship and his willingness to defend it (cf. Ex. 20:5; 34:15; Deut. 5:9).

<span id="page-648-0"></span>"Jerusalem" and "Zion" refer essentially to the same entity, though Zion may have more of a religious connotation as the Temple Mount, while Jerusalem may have a more political nuance as the city of David.

<span id="page-648-14"></span><span id="page-648-9"></span>1:15 With the seventy years of judgment coming to an end, God's anger is shifting from his people (cf. v. 2) to the nations. Although the nations are "at ease," it should be God's people who are experiencing his blessing (cf. comment on 1:11–12). That the nations "furthered the disaster" implies that while God used nations such as

<span id="page-649-2"></span>Assyria and Babylon as his agents for the punishment on his people, these nations overstepped their role as God's agents and committed evil themselves (e.g., Isa. 10:5–15; 47:6; 54:7–8). God's judgment of the nations is the theme of the second and third visions.

<span id="page-649-6"></span><span id="page-649-3"></span>1:16 "I have returned to Jerusalem with mercy" can also be translated "I have turned to Jerusalem with mercy," and is to be understood against the backdrop of Jeremiah's seventy years of judgment coming to an end. God has turned from judgment to mercy, with many returning to Jerusalem from exile in Babylon. The phrase speaks of restored relationship. The return of the glory of the Lord to Jerusalem, which Ezekiel saw depart (cf. Ezekiel 10), is still future and requires the rebuilding of the temple, which God assures his people will happen: "My house shall be built in it." So, too, the city itself will be rebuilt: "The measuring line shall be stretched out over Jerusalem," an image anticipating the third vision (Zech. 2:1–13).

<span id="page-649-8"></span><span id="page-649-7"></span>1:17 Zechariah is given a further word from the Lord to proclaim. The word "again" occurs four times in this verse to emphasize the future restoration of Jerusalem. "Cities" presumably refers to Jerusalem and her surrounding towns but could refer to all the "cities" or "towns" of Judah, of which Jerusalem is preeminent. They will "overflow with prosperity" (or "good things") as a result of God's return, experiencing his blessing (cf. 2:4).

<span id="page-649-9"></span><span id="page-649-5"></span><span id="page-649-1"></span>God "will again comfort Zion" (cf. comment on 1:13) and will "again choose Jerusalem." He will choose it "again" because in one sense he rejected it at the hands of the Babylonians when Jerusalem and the temple were destroyed in 586 BC (cf. 2 Kings 23:27). The language of choosing echoes Deuteronomy, where it expresses God's sovereignty in choosing the place where he will put his name (cf. Deut. 12:5; cf. Ps. 78:68–70). In Deuteronomy, this is associated also with where the tabernacle, and later the temple, will be located. The rebuilding of the temple will be a key theme of the fifth vision (Zech. 4:1–14).

#### <span id="page-649-10"></span><span id="page-649-0"></span>*Response*

Zechariah's first vision highlights several important themes. First, God's sovereignty is expressed in the heavenly horsemen who patrol the earth as his agents and report to him. These riders are a reminder that God knows what is happening in his world. Even though the nations may appear to be in control, God's purposes are firmly in hand—the nations are merely his instruments, accountable to him for their actions.

<span id="page-649-4"></span>Second, this passage highlights God's covenant faithfulness. The introduction (1:1–6) makes clear the exile was God's judgment on his people for refusing to obey his word. Yet, on account of his covenant promises, God has not turned his back on his people forever. He is jealous for them and promises to save them after the seventy years of punishment are completed.

<span id="page-650-3"></span><span id="page-650-2"></span>Third, this passage highlights God's kindness and grace. God hears the cry of his people ("How long?"), initiates a restored relationship by his mercy (v. 16), and promises to bless them abundantly (v. 17). The obedience called for in subsequent visions is to be in response to God's mercy, not in order to earn it (cf. Rom. 12:1).

<span id="page-650-6"></span>The promise of God's return to his people anticipates the coming of the Lord Jesus. While the people in Zechariah's day had been restored to Jerusalem, they still anticipated a greater restoration promised by the earlier prophets. The NT writers see the realization of this greater hope in the coming of the Lord Jesus Christ—Immanuel ("God with us"). It is in Jesus that God's mercy and blessing is experienced. Christians also anticipate a greater presence of God when Jesus returns on the judgment day.

<span id="page-650-5"></span><span id="page-650-0"></span>Like the situation in Zechariah's day, many in our world seem to be "at rest" and "at ease," while God is not acknowledged for who he is. Like the angel of the Lord who cries, "How long?" (Zech. 1:12; cf. Rev. 6:10), Christians are to long for the day when Jesus will return and put things right in the world and God's kingdom will be seen in all its glory. At the present time God's people have a message to declare—the gospel, announcing Jesus' sovereign rule and his coming to judge (cf. Acts 17:30–31). Like Zechariah's message, the gospel is "gracious and comforting words" for those who are being saved, but a message of God's anger and judgment on his enemies—it is both good news and bad news!

## <span id="page-650-4"></span>ZECHARIAH 1:18–21

**18** *1* And I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold, four horns! **19**And I said to the angel who talked with me, "What are these?" And he said to me, "These are the horns that have scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem." **<sup>20</sup>**Then the Lord showed me four craftsmen. **21**And I said, "What are these coming to do?" He said, "These are the horns that scattered Judah, so that no one raised his head. 1Ch 2:1 in Hebrew

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-650-1"></span>The first vision ended by proclaiming God's anger with the nations who "furthered the disaster" (1:15) and by indicating that the temple would be rebuilt in Jerusalem (v. 16). The second vision develops this by portraying the nations as four horns that will be terrified and cast down by four craftsmen involved with rebuilding the temple.

This vision underscores the significance of temple building for the postexilic community in Jerusalem. As the temple is built, God will bring judgment on nations opposed to his people.

II.B. Zechariah's Second Vision: Four Horns and Four Craftsmen (1:18–21)

- <span id="page-651-9"></span>1. Vision of Four Horns (1:18)
- <span id="page-651-11"></span>2. Explanation of the Horns (1:19)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-651-13"></span><span id="page-651-10"></span>1:18–19 The introductory phrase, "And I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold," introduces the third, sixth, and eighth visions as well (2:1; 5:1; 6:1). It provides a transition into the next scene Zechariah sees and underscores the visionary character of God's word coming to Zechariah. It might be translated colloquially as "I looked up—and what do you know! I saw . . ."8

A "horn" can refer to a musical instrument, a part of the temple altar, an iron fighting implement, or an animal horn. Since the horns are said to have "scattered" God's people (v. 19), it seems best to understand these horns as animal horns, which are a common image of military and political power (e.g., Deut. 33:17; 1 Sam. 2:1; Ps. 132:17; Jer. 48:25; Daniel 7–8).

<span id="page-651-14"></span><span id="page-651-6"></span><span id="page-651-4"></span><span id="page-651-2"></span>The number "four" elsewhere symbolizes north, south, east, and west (cf. Zech. 2:6) and is used symbolically, representing completeness. Hence the "four horns" (1:18) represent the surrounding nations that "scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem" (v. 19). Scattering is an agricultural image of grain husks blown by the wind as part of the threshing process. Here it refers to the exiles of the northern and southern kingdoms of Israel, driven from the land (cf. vv. 5–6, 15). Scattering as a curse for covenant disobedience is threatened in the Torah (cf. Lev. 26:33) and is found elsewhere in the prophets (e.g., Jer. 50:17–18; Ezek. 5:2, 10, 12; Joel 3:1–2). These nations have served as agents of God's judgment (cf. Zech. 1:6, 15)—primarily Assyria and Babylon, but also Egypt, Edom, Ammon, and Philistia.

<span id="page-651-12"></span><span id="page-651-8"></span><span id="page-651-7"></span><span id="page-651-5"></span><span id="page-651-1"></span>1:20–21 The phrase "the Lord showed me" (cf. vv. 7, 12) again emphasizes the divine origin of Zechariah's visions.

<span id="page-651-3"></span><span id="page-651-0"></span>The highest frequency of the term "craftsmen" in the OT is in reference to those involved in the construction (Ex. 35:35; 1 Kings 7:14) and repair (2 Kings 12:11; 22:6) of the tabernacle and temple. Significantly, Ezra 3:7 refers to those who rebuilt the temple under Zerubbabel as "carpenters" (craftsmen who worked with various media). The number "four" corresponds to the number of horns.

<sup>8</sup> Albert M. Wolters, *Zechariah*, HCOT (Leuven, Belgium: Peeters, 2014), 157.

<span id="page-652-0"></span>The craftsmen will "terrify" and "cast down the horns of the nations" (Zech 1:21). The craftsmen will do to the horns what the horns have done to the people of Israel—bring them into subjection. In the context of Zechariah's visions, the craftsmen are best understood as temple workers, who by their rebuilding will bring about the reversal promised in the first vision as God returns to judge the nations and dwell in the midst of his chosen people. This is worked out further in the next three visions.

#### *Response*

Zechariah's second vision portrays a great reversal, in which the foreign nations responsible for scattering in exile the northern and southern kingdoms will have their power removed and will no longer oppress God's people. The vision functions to underscore the importance of rebuilding the temple and God's power over the nations.

<span id="page-652-3"></span><span id="page-652-2"></span>Some see the craftsmen as powerful figures. Yet if the power to overcome the nations who have crushed and continue to oppress God's people comes from God's dwelling in the rebuilt temple, it is not necessary to see the craftsmen as powerful in themselves. Compared to mighty warriors, craftsmen may be seen as figures of weakness, and in this case there is a strange conjunction of power and weakness in the vision, with the weak overcoming the strong. This complements other aspects of Zechariah's prophecy, particularly 4:6, where the temple is said to be built not by the might and power of the governor Zerubbabel but by the Spirit of God (cf. also 9:9 and 10:5). It is also consistent with the NT theme of God choosing "what is weak in the world to shame the strong" (1 Cor. 1:27; cf. 2 Cor. 4:7). This serves as a great encouragement to do God's work today, knowing that God works powerfully in and through his people, often in spite of our inadequacies.

Escape to Zion, you who dwell with the daughter of Babylon. **8**For thus said the Lord of hosts, after his glory sent me*<sup>2</sup>* to the nations who plundered you, for he who touches you touches the apple of his eye: **<sup>9</sup>** "Behold, I will shake my hand over them, and they shall become plunder for those who served them. And I will dwell in your midst, and you shall know that the Lord of hosts has sent me to you. **12**And the Lord will inherit Judah as his portion in the holy land, and will again choose Jerusalem."

1Ch 2:5 in Hebrew 2Or *he sent me after glory*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-653-4"></span>The third vision of a glorious new Jerusalem overflowing on account of God's blessing (2:1–5) serves as the basis for the imperatives that follow (vv. 6–13). These imperatives include a call for exiles in Babylon to return to Jerusalem in view of impending judgment on the nations (vv. 6–9), for the inhabitants of Jerusalem to sing and rejoice in the prospect of God's dwelling among his people (vv. 10–12), and for hostile nations to be silent before the Lord (v. 13).

The main idea of this vision is a renewed Jerusalem (and implicitly a rebuilt temple) at the center of God's plans for the blessing of Israel and of those from the nations who join themselves to him.

## *Section Outline*

II.C. Zechariah's Third Vision: Measuring Jerusalem (2:1–13)

- <span id="page-653-3"></span>1. Vision of a Man with a Measuring Line (2:1–5)
	- a. Surveying the City (2:1–2)
	- b. Jerusalem as a City without Walls (2:3–5)
- <span id="page-653-8"></span><span id="page-653-7"></span><span id="page-653-6"></span><span id="page-653-5"></span>2. Charge to the Exiles to Return to Jerusalem in View of God's Return (2:6–13)
	- a. "Flee" and "Escape" from the Land of the North (2:6–9)
	- b. "Sing and Rejoice" Since the Lord Will Dwell in Your Midst (2:10–12)
	- c. "Be Silent" for the Lord Is Coming (2:13)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-653-2"></span><span id="page-653-1"></span><span id="page-653-0"></span>2:1–2 "I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold" (cf. comment on 1:18–19). Zechariah sees a "man with a measuring line in his hand" going to survey Jerusalem for its rebuilding (cf. 1:16, although the measuring instrument there is a different Hebrew term). Elsewhere in the OT, measuring is associated with building the tabernacle (e.g., Ex. 26:2, 8), Solomon's temple (e.g., 1 Kings 7:9, 11), the new temple <span id="page-654-3"></span>(Ezekiel 40–48), and the restored walls of Jerusalem (Neh. 3:11–30; Jer. 31:39). Similarly, the expression "width and . . . length" is most prominent in connection with the tabernacle (in Exodus), Solomon's temple (in 1 Kings and 2 Chronicles), and the new temple (in Ezekiel 40–48). In this vision, temple and city are to some extent merged, since God's glory is said to fill the city just as it had earlier filled the tabernacle and temple (Ex. 40:34–35; 1 Kings 8:11). This is reflected also in Zechariah 14:20–21.

<span id="page-654-14"></span><span id="page-654-2"></span>Unusually, Zechariah speaks directly to the man in his vision without any angelic mediation, creating a sense of urgency. The identity of the man is not given.

<span id="page-654-11"></span>2:3–4 The angel who had previously spoken with Zechariah to explain the visions is now present. The phrase "came forward" is better translated "was going out," since the angel is moving toward the man with the measuring line, who is going toward Jerusalem. Another angel goes out with a message for the first angel to convey to the young man, which Zechariah also hears and reports. The young man's pursuit by angels further indicates the urgency and importance of the message, as does the second angel's call to the first angel: "Run, say to that young man . . ."

<span id="page-654-10"></span>The phrase rendered "villages without walls" is difficult to translate from Hebrew. The idea from the immediate context is that the new Jerusalem will have no walls because its human and animal populations will be overflowing (cf. 1:17). This is a picture of God's blessing Jerusalem again, in contrast to the curse of the exile (cf. Jer. 33:10–11).

<span id="page-654-12"></span><span id="page-654-6"></span><span id="page-654-0"></span>2:5 Since a wall functions to protect and secure a city, the angel's call to build a city without walls would raise the question of security. God promises to be a "wall of fire all around." Fire is a common means of protection in the OT (cf. Gen. 3:24; Ex. 14:19–20, 24; Deut. 5:23–24; 2 Kings 6:17; Pss. 46; 48). A "wall of fire" would provide protection while also allowing for expansion.

<span id="page-654-9"></span><span id="page-654-7"></span><span id="page-654-1"></span>God also promises to be the "glory in her midst" (cf. Zech. 1:3, 16). In Israel's history, God's glory took up residence in the tabernacle and the temple (Ex. 40:34–35; 1 Kings 8:11). The prophet Ezekiel had a vision of God's glory departing from the temple as judgment on the nation's sin (Ezekiel 1; 8–11). Yet after Israel is punished, Ezekiel envisions God's glory returning to the temple (43:1–5). In this vision given to Zechariah, God promises his glory will return to Jerusalem; the temple and city will be merged.

<span id="page-654-13"></span><span id="page-654-8"></span><span id="page-654-5"></span><span id="page-654-4"></span>2:6–7 The word translated "Up!" can also be translated "Woe!" and often introduces a lament. Here it is a means of grabbing attention and urging the people to respond to the subsequent exhortation. In view of his return to Jerusalem, the Lord charges his people still living in exile to "flee from the land of the north," an expression, typical of Jeremiah, referring to Babylon (e.g., Jer. 3:18; 16:15; 23:8; 31:8). While Babylon lay to the east of Jerusalem, travelers to Babylon would begin their journey by heading northward, to avoid the desert that lay between the two cities.

<span id="page-655-8"></span>The phrase "I have spread you abroad" uses different vocabulary but conveys an idea similar to "scattering" in Zechariah 1:19. God's people were scattered in all directions, just as the "four winds of the heavens" blow everywhere. Indeed, Jeremiah 44:1 indicates some Jews had relocated to Egypt.

<span id="page-655-12"></span><span id="page-655-9"></span><span id="page-655-6"></span><span id="page-655-4"></span>A second imperative, "escape to Zion" (Zech. 2:7; on "Zion" cf. comment on 1:14), gives a sense of impending judgment on the nations, represented as the "daughter of Babylon."9 This expression poetically personifies the inhabitants of a land or city (cf. "daughter of Zion" in 2:10; 9:9). The expression "daughter of" also connotes identity and may function to question the identity and allegiance of Jewish people living in Babylon: to which city do they belong?

Reference to "Babylon" rather than Persia may suggest that the full realization of the earlier prophetic judgments pronounced against Babylon may still be future. Alternatively, "Babylon" may refer simply to the region (now governed by the Persians) in terms bringing to mind the exilic experience, or in terms not seen as seditious by Persia. Or "Babylon" may be symbolic of nations opposed to God (including the Persians), as it is elsewhere in the Bible (e.g., Revelation 18).

<span id="page-655-14"></span><span id="page-655-10"></span><span id="page-655-5"></span><span id="page-655-2"></span><span id="page-655-1"></span><span id="page-655-0"></span>2:8 The Hebrew of this verse is difficult. There is no evidence elsewhere that Zechariah was sent as a prophet to the nations, as might be suggested by "after *his glory* sent *me* to the nations." An alternative rendering would read, "After *glory* sent *me* to the nations that have plundered you," where "me" is God, speaking about himself. This can be understood against the background of Exodus and Ezekiel, where "glory" refers to that aspect of God's own character that compelled him to depart the defiled temple in judgment on the city and dwell with his people among the nations (cf. Ezek. 8:6; 9:3). In Exodus, God's glory is his character or name, revealed to Moses on the mountain (cf. Ex. 34:5–7), that visibly took up residence in the tabernacle (40:34–35). There is a perceived tension in God's character between his covenant mercy and love, on the one hand, and his judgment of sin, on the other. This perception is captured in the golden calf incident in Exodus 32, where God's burning anger wanted to destroy the nation, yet Moses interceded and pleaded on the basis of God's character and promises. God relented from destroying the nation, yet he still punished the people. Similarly, God punished his people for their sin many generations later when his glory departed the temple in Jerusalem and he allowed the Babylonians to destroy it. But would he again show mercy? This vision assures God's people that, in keeping with his character ("glory"), he will save them from the nations and return to dwell among them (Zech. 2:10–11). On account of his promises and purposes, they are the "apple of his eye" (cf. Deut. 32:10; Prov. 7:2). They are precious in his sight, and he will save and protect them from the nations (cf. also Ex. 19:5, where God calls his people his "treasured possession").

<span id="page-655-13"></span><span id="page-655-11"></span><span id="page-655-7"></span><span id="page-655-3"></span>2:9 "I will shake my hand over them" is a promise that God will act to judge the nations that have touched his people (cf. 1:15). There will be a great reversal—"the

<sup>9</sup> The Hebrew of "escape to Zion" omits the preposition "to." More likely, the exiles are being addressed *as* "Zion," and it is better to translate as "Up, Zion! Escape!"

<span id="page-656-1"></span>nations who plundered" God's people (2:8) will "become plunder" (v. 9). Those who were servants will be served. There are echoes here of God's salvation in the exodus, when the Israelites plundered the Egyptians (cf. Ex. 12:35–36; also Isa. 14:2). The fulfillment of this promise will underscore Zechariah's authority as a prophet (cf. Zech. 2:11; 4:9; 6:15).

<span id="page-656-15"></span><span id="page-656-14"></span><span id="page-656-12"></span><span id="page-656-10"></span><span id="page-656-6"></span><span id="page-656-2"></span>2:10 On the phrase "daughter of Zion," cf. verse 7. The inhabitants of Jerusalem are exhorted to "sing and rejoice." They are to be jubilant because of the Lord's promise to come and dwell among them (cf. comment on 1:16). The language of "dwelling" is elsewhere associated with God's presence in the tabernacle and temple (e.g., Ex. 25:8; 29:44–45; 1 Kings 6:12–13). Hence this exhortation anticipates the completion of the rebuilding of the temple and the return of God's visible glory. There is a similar exhortation to rejoice in Zechariah 9:9 when the Davidic king comes to Jerusalem (cf. also Zeph. 3:14).

<span id="page-656-18"></span><span id="page-656-9"></span><span id="page-656-5"></span><span id="page-656-0"></span>2:11 God's purpose and plan is not merely for the salvation of Israel but also for "many nations" who will "join themselves to the Lord." God's promise to Abraham includes the blessing of the nations (Gen. 12:3; 18:18; 22:18), and other prophets reiterate this, particularly Isaiah (e.g., Isa. 2:1–4; 14:1; 56:3, 6). It is also a significant theme in Zechariah (cf. Zech. 8:22–23; 14:16). To "be my people" is an immense covenant privilege (cf. Jer. 31:33).

<span id="page-656-17"></span><span id="page-656-8"></span>The phrase "in that day" occurs about twenty times across the book of Zechariah, and this is its first instance. It refers to the day when God will establish his kingdom on earth in glory, expressed here (as in 2:10) as his dwelling in the midst of his people. Fulfillment will confirm Zechariah's message (cf. comment on 2:9).

<span id="page-656-16"></span>2:12 Judah and Jerusalem have a privileged place in God's salvation plan. Judah will be the Lord's inheritance, his permanent possession. Judah is the tribe of David, and Jerusalem is the city of David and the location of the temple; the next two visions feature the future Davidic king (ch. 3) and temple (ch. 4). The phrase translated "holy land" is found only here in the OT. The land is "holy" because God will be present (cf. 2:13; 14:21; Ps. 78:54). On God's choosing Jerusalem again, cf. comment on Zech. 1:17.

<span id="page-656-11"></span><span id="page-656-4"></span>2:13 The final charge to "be silent" anticipates God's return to his people. Since the previous charge given to the inhabitants of Jerusalem was to make much noise ("sing and rejoice"), it seems best to understand "all flesh" as referring to the nations, who are to stop their raging against God and his people (cf. Psalm 2). The phrase "all flesh" also conveys a sense of impermanence or weakness in contrast to the Lord (cf. Isa. 40:6).

<span id="page-656-13"></span><span id="page-656-7"></span><span id="page-656-3"></span>Elsewhere, when God is "roused," it is to save his people and bring judgment on his enemies (e.g., Pss. 44:23; 59:5; 73:20), and this suits the context here. God's "holy dwelling" could refer to his dwelling among the exiles (cf. Zech. 2:8), "holy" by virtue of his dwelling there. Alternatively, it could refer to his heavenly abode, from which he will come to dwell with his people in Jerusalem once the temple is rebuilt.

### *Response*

<span id="page-657-3"></span><span id="page-657-2"></span>Zechariah's vision of a Jerusalem without walls, overflowing with God's blessing, finds its fulfillment in Jesus, who greatly expands the structures of Israel's faith (such as the temple, the city of Jerusalem, and the Promised Land). Jesus is the "glory" of God who "dwelt among us" (John 1:14) and brought salvation for Israel and the nations (cf. Acts 1:8; Eph. 2:13–18). In the new Jerusalem in Revelation 21– 22, temple, city, and land are merged in a way picturing the ultimate dwelling of God with his people: "I saw no temple in the city, for its temple is the Lord God the Almighty and the Lamb" (Rev. 21:22).

<span id="page-657-8"></span><span id="page-657-6"></span>In the now-and-not-yet period between Jesus' first coming and the full realization of the new Jerusalem, the imperatives in Zechariah still readily apply. First, Christians are to flee from Babylon. In the Bible, "Babylon" comes to typify human opposition to God. For instance, in Revelation 18 Babylon is a seductive prostitute who deceives the nations. She represents the glitz, glamour, and attractiveness of an anti-God world, which ultimately leads only to death. Many exiles had become wealthy in Babylon and did not want to leave. Christians must flee from her or be destroyed (Rev. 18:4).

<span id="page-657-7"></span><span id="page-657-5"></span><span id="page-657-4"></span>Second, God's people are to give voice to the joy of God's advent and salvation in Jesus Christ by singing and rejoicing with one another (e.g., Acts 16:25; Eph. 5:19; Col. 3:15; Heb. 2:12; James 5:13; Rev. 5:9). Christians should be known by our joyful song. Indeed, for many, *we* are the nations sharing the salvation of Israel of which Zechariah spoke.

<span id="page-657-1"></span><span id="page-657-0"></span>Third, just as Zechariah calls on all flesh to be silent before the Lord (Zech. 2:13), God's people today are to implore people from all nations to stop rebelling against the Lord and recognize he is coming to judge. Now is the time to repent and bow down before him (cf. Psalm 2).

The Lord who has chosen Jerusalem rebuke you! Is not this a brand*<sup>2</sup>* plucked from the fire?" **3**Now Joshua was standing before the angel, clothed with filthy garments. **4**And the angel said to those who were standing before him, "Remove the filthy garments from him." And to him he said, "Behold, I have taken your iniquity away from you, and I will clothe you with pure vestments." **5**And I said, "Let them put a clean turban on his head." So they put a clean turban on his head and clothed him with garments. And the angel of the Lord was standing by.

1Hebrew *the Accuser* or *the Adversary* 2That is, a burning stick 3Or *facets*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-658-6"></span><span id="page-658-2"></span>The fourth vision pictures a heavenly court scene (like Job 1–2), where the high priest Joshua is about to be accused by Satan on account of his iniquity and uncleanness. Rather than being condemned, he is wonderfully clothed, cleansed, and commissioned by God for service in the new temple (Zech. 3:1–7). This renewed priestly service anticipates the day of the Branch (Messiah), a day of forgiveness and prosperity for God's people (vv. 8–10).

<span id="page-658-7"></span>This vision highlights the problem of sin and defilement, and shows how God acts by his grace to cleanse and forgive so that his people might serve him. The vision also offers great hope for better things to come.

### *Section Outline*

- II.D. Zechariah's Fourth Vision: Joshua Cleansed, Clothed, and Commissioned (3:1–10)
	- 1. Joshua Accused, Then Defended (3:1–3)
	- 2. Joshua Cleansed, Clothed, and Commissioned (3:4–7)
	- 3. Signs Given of the Coming Branch (3:8–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-658-5"></span><span id="page-658-1"></span><span id="page-658-0"></span>3:1 Joshua was a key leader in the postexilic period. As high priest he represented God's people and was responsible for ensuring their purity through sacrifice (e.g., Ex. 28:38; Lev. 16:1–17; 23:26–32). Yet Joshua is "standing before the angel of the Lord," a posture indicating coming before a judge (cf. Num. 27:2). "The angel of the Lord" is a figure representing the Lord and speaking for him (cf. comment on Zech. 1:11–12).

<span id="page-658-8"></span><span id="page-658-4"></span><span id="page-658-3"></span>"Satan" is not strictly a proper name but means "the accuser." The Hebrew is definite ("*the* Satan"), implying a title (cf. Job 1:6–12; 2:1–7). From a biblicaltheological perspective, Satan can be identified as "the devil" (Rev. 12:9; 20:2), active <span id="page-659-0"></span>since the garden of Eden, where he took the form of "the serpent" (Gen. 3:1). He stands ready "to accuse" Joshua.10 In doing this, Satan is presented as opposed to both the restoration of temple sacrifice and the Lord's return to the temple.

<span id="page-659-8"></span><span id="page-659-3"></span>3:2 Before Satan can make any accusation against Joshua or present any evidence against him, he is rebuked by the Lord. Elsewhere in the OT, forces of chaos are the commonest object of God's rebuke (e.g., Pss. 9:5; 106:9). The silencing of Satan is emphatic, and the sovereign power and purposes of God are stressed in the threefold use of the divine name and the reference to God's choice of Jerusalem (cf. Zech. 2:12 and comment on 1:17). Satan will not impede God's purposes. God will not allow him to speak.

<span id="page-659-6"></span>Joshua is described as a "brand plucked from the fire," which describes a burning or smoldering stick (cf. ESV mg.) rather than a branding implement. Here "fire" is an image of judgment by exile. The vision implies that although God has delivered Joshua, he is still charred and unclean from the experience (cf. Amos 4:11).

<span id="page-659-5"></span><span id="page-659-2"></span>3:3 In Hebrew, the adjective "filthy" when used as a noun can denote "excrement" (Deut. 23:13) or "vomit" (Isa. 28:8). These are possible grounds for Satan's accusation, as Joshua is ritually unclean and unfit for temple service.

The beginning of this vision portrays a massive problem. Given Joshua's representative role as high priest, his present condition underscores how the people still stand defiled before God, even though they have returned from exile. How can the Lord return to dwell with a people who remain unclean?

<span id="page-659-9"></span>3:4–5 A command is given to remove Joshua's filthy garments.11 "Those who were standing before him" are probably other angels in the heavenly court. Joshua is to be given "pure vestments"—clean high priestly garments required for Joshua's reinstatement as high priest. The reclothing of Joshua is symbolic of the forgiveness God announces: "Behold, I have taken your iniquity away from you." "Iniquity" refers to sin and its associated guilt. No particular sin of Joshua is mentioned, but the immediate context suggests the sin associated with the exile was the cause of guilt and uncleanness for both Joshua and the people.

<span id="page-659-11"></span><span id="page-659-7"></span><span id="page-659-4"></span><span id="page-659-1"></span>Zechariah interjects and speaks into the vision (3:5; cf. 2:2). He requests that they "put a clean turban on his head" (cf. Ex. 28:39, though a different word for "turban" is used, perhaps alluding to Ezek. 21:26, where a command is given to remove the turban [same word as here] and crown from the wicked king Zedekiah before the exile—an episode seemingly in the background of Zech. 6:9–15 as well). Placing the turban on Joshua's head suggests that, after being reclothed and forgiven, Joshua is being reinstated as high priest. The angel of the Lord has observed these actions (3:5) and is reintroduced before speaking in verse 6.

<span id="page-659-10"></span><sup>10</sup> The Hebrew for "accuse" has the same root as "Satan" (*stn*).

<sup>11</sup> The Hebrew does not indicate who speaks, as it simply uses the pronoun "he." The ESV and NIV supply "the angel," but it could be that God issues the command directly, especially since the same figure also announces forgiveness later in the verse. In addition, the angel is said to be observing these things at the end of verse 5, which also suggests it is God who speaks.

Zechar iah 3:1–10 660

<span id="page-660-10"></span><span id="page-660-6"></span><span id="page-660-5"></span><span id="page-660-4"></span><span id="page-660-3"></span>3:6–7 Joshua has been cleansed and clothed and is now given a charge by the angel of the Lord. If Joshua will walk in the ways of the Lord and obey the requirements of the covenant (cf. Deut. 11:1; 28:9), God promises to grant him three responsibilities: (1) governance of the temple ("rule my house"), which includes not only management of the temple but also administration of justice (cf. Deut. 17:9–12; 19:17; Ezek. 44:15); (2) protection of the purity of the temple "courts" where the priests served (e.g., Num. 3:7–8; 18:5; 1 Chron. 23:28–32); and (3) admission to God's presence ("the right of access among those who are standing here").12 The ones "standing here" in Zechariah's vision are those standing in the divine council in God's presence. Access to God's presence was the high priest's privilege on the Day of Atonement (Leviticus 16). Hence, the honor of serving as a high priest is conditional on Joshua's covenant faithfulness.

<span id="page-660-14"></span><span id="page-660-11"></span><span id="page-660-7"></span><span id="page-660-2"></span>3:8 Joshua's "friends" are likely his fellow priests (the word can also be translated "associates"), especially as they "sit before" him, suggesting they are in his service. As they serve in the new temple, they function as a sign that God will bring "my servant the Branch." The designation "my servant" is used elsewhere of individuals like Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, David, and even Nebuchadnezzar. It is used thirty-one times of David (twice in 2 Samuel 7), most frequently in the prophets. Its combination with the term "Branch" underscores the Davidic connection here, since "Branch" and "Shoot" refer to a future Davidic king (also Zech. 6:12).13 The image lying behind this is found in the prophets Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezekiel, who all liken the house of David to a mighty tree cut down or severed in the exile and from which new growth will flourish after the exile into something vast (Isa. 11:1; Jer. 23:5–6; 33:14–18; Ezek. 17:3–6, 22–23). This new growth is a Davidic king of humble origins associated with the coming kingdom of God with all its blessings. The image expresses continuity with the past, with the future king coming from the line of David.

<span id="page-660-8"></span>Joshua is not identified as "the Branch." Rather, as Joshua and his fellow priests go about their priestly service, they will serve as a sign that God will bring this future Davidic king. This connection between sign and reality suggests the king will have a priestly function when he comes (something that is clearer in Zech. 6:13).

<span id="page-660-15"></span><span id="page-660-13"></span><span id="page-660-12"></span><span id="page-660-9"></span>3:9 Some interpreters suggest the stone placed before Joshua is a stone for the construction of the new temple, with the seven eyes of the Lord focused on it (cf. 4:10). However, it is not clear from the immediate context that the "seven eyes" are the eyes of the Lord. Alternatively, since there is a focus on the high priest's garments in 3:4–5, the "single stone with seven eyes" (or "seven facets"; cf. ESV mg.) is more likely a gemstone. This is supported by the fact that the high priestly garments had gemstones on the ephod and breastpiece (cf. Ex. 28:9–11, 21). Aaron's turban also had a gold plate engraved with the words "Holy to the Lord" (Ex. 28:36–38).

<span id="page-660-1"></span><span id="page-660-0"></span><sup>12</sup> There is a wordplay in Hebrew: if Joshua "walks" in the ways of the Lord, he will be given "walkings among those standing here" (AT).

<sup>13</sup> The Hebrew *tsemakh* refers to "new growth" and is better translated "shoot," since a "branch" is something well established. There is no article in the Hebrew, suggesting its use as a name here ("Shoot").

<span id="page-661-0"></span>This stone set before Joshua is inscribed by God and functions as a reminder of his promise to "remove the iniquity of this land in a single day." Reference to a "single day" when iniquity is removed from the land brings to mind the Day of Atonement (Leviticus 16). This day is also associated here with the coming of the "Branch" or "Shoot."

<span id="page-661-6"></span><span id="page-661-4"></span><span id="page-661-3"></span>3:10 "In that day" refers to the time when God will establish his kingdom on earth in glory (cf. comment on 2:11). The description "Lord of hosts" expresses God's sovereignty and the certainty of his word coming to pass (cf. comment on 1:2–6a). The phrase "to come under his vine and under his fig tree" conveys an image of peace, prosperity, and paradise (cf. 1 Kings 4:25; Mic. 4:4). The idea of people inviting their "neighbor" or "friend" indicates a social occasion.

### <span id="page-661-1"></span>*Response*

In this fourth vision, the high priest Joshua's defiled state and Satan's accusation against him indicate he and the people are not yet fit for God's presence and blessing, even though they have returned to Jerusalem. Yet in the vision Joshua is marvelously cleansed by God's grace and clothed with clean garments in order to serve God. This offers great hope for God's people as it anticipates their own cleansing. If Joshua and his fellow priests walk in the ways of the Lord and keep his requirements (3:6–7), they will have the privilege of serving in the new temple when it is constructed, and Joshua will have access to the very presence of God. Implicit in this is the forgiveness and blessing they will mediate to God's people through their temple worship.

<span id="page-661-5"></span><span id="page-661-2"></span>The service of Joshua and his fellow priests in the temple will also function as a sign that God will send his servant, "the Branch" (cf. Jer. 23:5; 33:15). Furthermore, an inscribed stone set before Joshua serves a similar purpose. The priesthood and the stone anticipate the coming of a future Davidic king (the Messiah), at whose arrival the iniquity of the land will be removed in a single day and a day of peace, prosperity, and paradise will be ushered in. The connection of the priesthood with "the Branch" suggests the Messiah may have a priestly role when he comes (cf. Zech. 6:13). Indeed, this is the case with Jesus, who is the Great High Priest who offered the once-for-all sacrifice of his own body to cleanse his people from sin and set them free from the accusations of Satan (Heb. 9:26).

<span id="page-661-10"></span><span id="page-661-9"></span><span id="page-661-8"></span><span id="page-661-7"></span>The sequence of actions in this vision reflects a similar pattern in the Christian life. By God's grace and through the cross, Jesus cleanses and clothes his people with a righteousness not their own in order to serve God (Rom. 3:21–26; 8:33–34; 12:1). Joshua is not accepted by God on account of his good works—he is cleansed and forgiven as an undeserved act of God. Having been cleansed, he is commanded by God to serve (cf. Rom. 12:1). A failure to appreciate the grace of God's forgiveness can lead to pride, insecurity, or ongoing feelings of guilt, paralyzing Christian service. The antidote to each of these maladies is the gospel of grace. Whatever accusation Satan can bring has been silenced for those who trust in Jesus.

<span id="page-662-1"></span><span id="page-662-0"></span>Finally, the invitation of others to paradise (Zech. 3:10) issues from a restored relationship with God and the hope of heaven. Those who know the forgiveness of sins and the blessings of God should be inviting others to share it. This is why Christians proclaim Jesus as Savior and Lord.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-662-3"></span><span id="page-662-2"></span>The fifth vision is structured as a dialogue between Zechariah and the interpreting angel; Zechariah is questioned and asks questions about what he sees, namely a golden lampstand with various accessories. At the heart of the dialogue is a message from the Lord to Zerubbabel telling him he will build the temple by the power of God's Spirit (4:6–10). Within the dialogue, Zechariah asks three times about the two olive trees (vv. 4, 11–13). While not explicit, these "two olive trees" are best

understood as representing the prophets Zechariah and Haggai, a connection that links the vision of the golden lampstand with the word from the Lord about the certain construction of the temple.

The heart of this vision is the prophetic word in the power of God's Spirit bringing about the reconstruction of the temple.
