### *Comment*

<span id="page-663-5"></span><span id="page-663-4"></span>4:1 "The angel who talked with me" (also known as the interpreting angel) had previously gone out into the visionary world (cf. comment on 2:3–4). Now he returned and "woke" (or "roused") Zechariah. The likening of this rousing to being "awakened" from sleep suggests Zechariah was not actually asleep but was being shown a vision while in a conscious state. While it is impossible to know Zechariah's exact experience, it was probably all-consuming, and Zechariah would have been left contemplating what he had seen after each vision.

<span id="page-663-6"></span><span id="page-663-3"></span><span id="page-663-2"></span>4:2–3 Zechariah now sees a gold lampstand with various accessories. The Hebrew word for "lampstand" is *menorah*, bringing to mind the golden menorah of the tabernacle or one of the ten in Solomon's temple (e.g., Ex. 25:31–40; 37:17–24; Num. 8:2; cf. 1 Kings 7:49) with tree-like qualities, evoking the garden of Eden (cf. Gen. 2:9). Fire is often associated with God's presence (e.g., Gen. 15:17; Ex. 3:2–6), suggesting the menorah with "seven lamps" represents God's presence in the temple. However, the additional elements in the vision set this menorah apart.

<span id="page-663-1"></span><span id="page-663-0"></span>The menorah in Zechariah's vision has a "bowl on the top of it" that seems to act as a receptacle for oil. Archeological discoveries of clay lamp dishes with pinched sides holding wicks have led to the translation "seven lips." However, what seems to be in view is the "all of gold" sanctuary menorah, not a clay lamp. The Hebrew is better rendered as "seven streams"—or seven "pipes" or "channels," as some translations render the phrase—which provide a mechanism for the oil to travel from the bowl to each of the seven lamps.14 Finally, there are "two olive trees" to the right and left of the bowl. Verse 12 further describes "two branches of the olive trees" and "two golden pipes from which the golden oil is poured out." While some of the Hebrew is difficult to translate, the impression seems to be that the two olive

<span id="page-663-7"></span><sup>14</sup> The phrase "on each of the lamps" is better translated "to each of the lamps" and has a distributive sense. However, it is difficult to know if it is one stream or pipe to each lamp, or seven to each lamp, in which case there would be forty-nine in total.

trees provide oil for the menorah through "two golden pipes," which presumably empty into the bowl and from there are further transported by the "seven streams" to each of the lamps.15 The additional elements in Zechariah's vision contrast the sanctuary menorah, which was supplied with oil by the priests. The menorah in Zechariah's vision has no need for priestly intervention.

<span id="page-664-12"></span><span id="page-664-8"></span>4:4–5 A dialogue between Zechariah and the interpreting angel ensues concerning the identity of the two olive trees (cf. also vv. 11–14). The angel's question ("Do you not know?") suggests Zechariah should have known what they represent, but his ignorance gives later readers some encouragement since we, too, often find the visions hard to understand!

<span id="page-664-9"></span>The angel then gives Zechariah two prophetic messages concerning Zerubbabel, in verses 6–7 and verses 8–10. These link the visionary world with the real.

<span id="page-664-1"></span><span id="page-664-0"></span>4:6 The first message is for Zerubbabel. Zerubbabel is listed among those who returned from Babylon, rebuilt the altar, and laid the foundation of the temple (Ezra 2:2; 3:2, 8; Neh. 12:1). He is the "governor of Judah" and the "son of Shealtiel," indicating his Davidic lineage and hence his qualification to rebuild the temple (Hag. 1:1, 14; 2:2, 21, 23; cf. 1 Chron. 3:17). In the first prophetic message, Zechariah must tell Zerubbabel the temple will be built "not by might, nor by power, but by my Spirit" (Zech. 4:6; cf. Ps. 33:16). Like the menorah supplied with resources outside itself, Zerubbabel will rebuild the temple in the power of God's Spirit.

<span id="page-664-10"></span><span id="page-664-6"></span><span id="page-664-5"></span><span id="page-664-4"></span><span id="page-664-3"></span>4:7 The "great mountain" seems to represent metaphorically the obstacles Zerubbabel faced in rebuilding the temple. These include hostile Samaritan authorities and the difficult spiritual and economic circumstances of the people (cf. Ezra 4; Haggai 1). God assures Zerubbabel these obstacles will be overcome (cf. the image with Isa. 40:4 and 45:2). Zerubbabel will complete the temple by bringing out and placing the "top stone" (or "capstone"), accompanied by shouts of "Grace, grace to it!" This is either a request for God to bless the building or an acclamation of God's kindness and faithfulness in keeping his promise that the temple will be rebuilt.

Some scholars argue on the basis of analogies with Mesopotamian building practices that the "top stone" is a stone removed from the ruins of the earlier temple and laid in a special ceremony as part of the new temple to provide continuity between the structures. However, the timing does not fit this suggestion. The laying of the foundation had already occurred (Hag. 2:15, 18; Zech. 4:9; 8:9), whereas this word from God says the stone will be placed in the future.16

<span id="page-664-11"></span><span id="page-664-7"></span>4:8–9 A second prophetic message for the community is an assurance that Zerubbabel will complete the temple. The statement that Zerubbabel has "laid the foundation of this house" corresponds with Ezra 3:8–13, where Zerubbabel is said

<span id="page-664-2"></span><sup>15</sup> In Hebrew, the "golden oil" is simply described by its color: "the gold." That it refers to oil is an inference from the wider context. Referring to it in this way connotes its value.

<sup>16</sup> In addition, there are fundamental differences between Mesopotamian building practices and those in Palestine, such as the use of brick rather than stone. See further Wolters, *Zechariah*, 124–128.

to have laid the foundation of the temple some twenty years earlier. In Ezra 5:16, this same work is attributed to Sheshbazzar, which probably means Zerubbabel was working under the authority of Sheshbazzar, the one mentioned in official Persian records. Alternatively, Zerubbabel's laying the foundation of "this house" could refer to a second occasion marking the recent renewal of the building work stimulated by the preaching of Haggai and Zechariah (cf. Hag. 2:15, 18; Zech. 8:9). In either case, the completion of the project by Zerubbabel will demonstrate that Zechariah is a prophet authorized by the Lord (cf. 1:16; 2:9, 11; 8:9).

<span id="page-665-9"></span><span id="page-665-5"></span><span id="page-665-4"></span>4:10 The phrase "whoever has despised the day of small things" indicates there were some in the community who were frustrated over the slow and painful progress of the rebuilding and made their frustration heard. The Lord assures the people that their present experience is only "small" compared to what lies in the future. Scorn will turn to joy when Zerubbabel completes the temple. "Plumb line" can also be translated as "chosen stone" and probably refers to the "top stone" in verse 7 that will complete the building.17 It is difficult to see how a "plumb line" would inspire joy at this point.

<span id="page-665-8"></span><span id="page-665-6"></span><span id="page-665-2"></span><span id="page-665-1"></span>The "seven" lamps (cf. v. 2) are identified as the "eyes of the Lord, which range through the whole earth." This phrase is also found in 2 Chronicles 16:9, where it refers to God's presence among his people to strengthen them (cf. also Ezra 5:5). This connects the vision of the menorah (which represents God's presence in the temple) with the message to Zerubbabel: God is with his people to strengthen them in their rebuilding project. This vision provides great encouragement to the people, who had become despondent.

<span id="page-665-11"></span><span id="page-665-10"></span><span id="page-665-7"></span>4:11–13 Zechariah asks the angel twice more about the significance of the "two olive trees" (v. 11) and "two branches of the olive trees" (v. 12). (Cf. comment on 4:2–3, where these elements are discussed.) Zechariah admits he still does not understand the significance of the olive trees in the vision (v. 13).

<span id="page-665-13"></span><span id="page-665-12"></span>4:14 The angel finally identifies the two olive trees as "two sons of new oil" (ESV mg.). This translation is preferable, as "two anointed ones" is an incorrect inference.18 The olive trees pour out oil rather than receiving it (as happens with anointing).19 While these "two" are commonly identified as Joshua and Zerubbabel, the two leaders mentioned in the fourth and fifth visions, they are better understood as the prophets Haggai and Zechariah, for the following reasons: (1) the description of their standing "by the Lord of the whole earth" indicates the prophet's privileged access to the divine council (1 Kings 22:19; Jer. 23:18–22); (2) the OT often connects the work of the Spirit with prophecy (e.g., Zech. 7:12); (3) the reconstruction of the temple is attributed to Haggai and Zechariah elsewhere

<span id="page-665-14"></span><span id="page-665-0"></span><sup>17</sup> "Chosen stone" (*ha'eben habbedil*) understands "chosen" (*habbedil*) to derive from *badal*, which means "to separate, divide," hence "to choose."

<span id="page-665-3"></span><sup>18</sup> The expression "sons of new oil" means that the olive trees produce the new oil, like the expression "sons of a flame" in the Hebrew of Job 5:7 refers to the sparks that produce a flame.

<sup>19</sup> Elsewhere, the "oil" for anointing is always the Hebrew word *shemen*. Here the word for "oil" is *yitshar*.

<span id="page-666-4"></span><span id="page-666-2"></span>(Ezra 5:1–2; 6:14–15; Zech. 8:9); (4) Revelation 11:3–4 creatively reuses this vision, depicting two prophets as olive trees; and (5) identifying them as Haggai and Zechariah connects this vision with the two prophetic messages about Zerubbabel in Zechariah 4:6–7, 8–10, where the main driving force behind the completion of the temple will be God's Spirit rousing the people to action through the preaching of his prophets. Admittedly, since the figures are never explicitly identified, it is impossible to be certain of the identity of the "two sons of new oil." However, seeing them as Haggai and Zechariah best suits the wider context of the book of Zechariah and best explains the menorah vision itself.

<span id="page-666-0"></span>This identification may also explain why Zechariah has so much difficulty understanding the identity of the two olive trees in his vision (he has to ask about them three times). Just as the prophets Moses and Jeremiah were hesitant to take on important roles (Ex. 4:10; Jer. 1:6), so Zechariah may not have fully appreciated the key role he would play as a prophet in bringing about God's purposes.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-666-5"></span><span id="page-666-3"></span><span id="page-666-1"></span>Those living in Jerusalem after returning from Babylon faced many challenges, personified in this vision as a "great mountain" (Zech. 4:7). Elsewhere these challenges are identified as financial difficulties (Hag. 1:6), opposition from the neighboring Samaritans (Ezra 4:1–6), and generally low morale (Hag. 1:14). What will enable God's people to overcome these challenges and complete the building of the temple? The answer this fifth vision gives is that God himself will do it, by his Spirit, through his prophets. Indeed, history shows that as the "two sons of oil" (Haggai and Zechariah) proclaimed God's word, God was at work by his Spirit to move the people to obey so that the temple was rebuilt.

<span id="page-666-7"></span><span id="page-666-6"></span>Crucially, since the coming of Jesus, God has built his temple—the church in exactly the same way, by the proclamation of his word in the power of his Spirit. This is captured in Ephesians 2, where God's temple is identified as the church, built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, with Christ Jesus the chief cornerstone (Eph. 2:20). This implies that the message of the apostles and prophets about Jesus (that is, the gospel) is the foundation of the church, and as people hear the message of Jesus and repent and believe, they are incorporated into it. This temple comprises both Jew and Gentile now that Jesus has come. Furthermore, as in Zechariah, God is building this temple "by the Spirit" (Eph. 2:22). God's word preached (and spoken and written about) in the power of the Spirit builds the church today. It is God's Spirit at work in people's minds and hearts when they hear the gospel and respond in repentance and faith. And it is God's Spirit at work in the lives of believers as they put off sin and live fruitful lives for God.

<span id="page-666-8"></span>Just as the people in Zechariah's day faced many challenges, so does the church today. There are challenges of persecution and martyrdom and challenges of secularism, materialism, and idolatry. Just as there were scoffers in Zechariah's day, so there are those who scoff at the lack of influence and power the church displays in the world (or at the misused power it displays at times). This vision is a great <span id="page-667-4"></span><span id="page-667-3"></span>encouragement that God's word in the power of the Spirit will accomplish its purposes. It is an encouragement to preach this word even in the "day of small things," knowing that God keeps his promises: "I will build my church, and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it" (Matt. 16:18).

## ZECHARIAH 5:1–4

5 Again I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold, a flying scroll! **2**And he said to me, "What do you see?" I answered, "I see a flying scroll. Its length is twenty cubits, and its width ten cubits."*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>3</sup>**Then he said to me, "This is the curse that goes out over the face of the whole land. For everyone who steals shall be cleaned out according to what is on one side, and everyone who swears falsely*<sup>2</sup>* shall be cleaned out according to what is on the other side. **<sup>4</sup>** I will send it out, declares the Lord of hosts, and it shall enter the house of the thief, and the house of him who swears falsely by my name. And it shall remain in his house and consume it, both timber and stones."

1A *cubit* was about 18 inches or 45 centimeters 2Hebrew lacks *falsely* (supplied from verse 4)

#### *Section Overview*

After envisioning God's return to the temple in Jerusalem in visions 1–5, visions 6 and 7 picture God's judging the wicked and driving iniquity and wickedness far from the land. Visions 6 and 7 are closely connected by structure and themes, but remain distinct.

The main idea of the sixth vision is that God will judge those who persist in breaking the national covenant but have as yet gone unpunished.

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-667-2"></span>II.F. Zechariah's Sixth Vision: A Flying Scroll (5:1–4)
	- 1. The Vision Report (5:1–2)
	- 2. Explanation of the Vision (5:3–4)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-667-1"></span><span id="page-667-0"></span>5:1–2 "Again I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold" (cf. comment on 1:18–19). Zechariah sees a "flying scroll." Scrolls are generally associated with God's written Word (cf. Ps. 40:7; Jeremiah 36; Ezekiel 2–3). This scroll is extraordinary in its activity and dimensions—it is approximately 33 by 16.5 feet (10 by 5 m), so that as it flies it is clear for all to see, like a huge banner. The dimensions also suggest the scroll is only partially unfurled, perhaps revealing a column of text. Some scholars <span id="page-668-11"></span>suggest the dimensions reflect those of the vestibule of the temple or a domestic house, but these connections seem coincidental rather than intentional. God is later identified as the one who sent out this flying scroll (Zech. 5:4), suggesting it does his work without human agents such as priests, who were responsible for teaching God's ways to the people (e.g., Lev. 10:11; Deut. 33:10; Jer. 18:18; Ezek. 7:26; Hag. 2:11) and for providing rulings at the temple for those who sought justice (e.g., Deut. 17:8–12; 19:17; Mal. 2:6–7).

<span id="page-668-10"></span><span id="page-668-7"></span><span id="page-668-6"></span><span id="page-668-4"></span><span id="page-668-2"></span><span id="page-668-1"></span>5:3 Equating the scroll with the "curse" suggests the scroll represents the "Book [scroll] of the Law of Moses" (Josh. 8:31, 34; 23:6; cf. Ex. 24:4, 7; 1 Kings 2:3; Dan. 9:11). While the crimes of stealing and swearing falsely are often understood as representative crimes of the Decalogue, the different vocabulary used for these crimes and the lack of specific curses for disobedience within the Decalogue strongly suggest the scroll contains much more than the Ten Commandments, instead representing the "Law of Moses" more broadly, perhaps as a form of the scroll of Deuteronomy. The "Law of Moses" includes covenant curses for disobedience (e.g., Leviticus 26; Deuteronomy 28–29).

<span id="page-668-3"></span>The Hebrew indicates these crimes have thus far gone unpunished (translating "everyone who steals *has been acquitted*" and "everyone who swears falsely *has been acquitted*" rather than "shall be cleaned out"). The failure (presumably by the priests) to judge these crimes within the community of God's people indicates there has been a corruption of justice. These crimes are singled out likely because they were the ones negatively impacting the postexilic community (cf. Zech. 7:8–12; 8:17). God has sent the scroll to put things right and to ensure that the guilty will not be acquitted, an action consistent with his character as the God "who will by no means clear the guilty" (Ex. 34:7; cf. Ex. 20:7).

<span id="page-668-12"></span><span id="page-668-9"></span><span id="page-668-0"></span>5:4 In contrast to God's "house" (the temple), to be built in accordance with the earlier visions (cf. 1:16; 3:7; 4:9), the curse of the scroll will enter and completely destroy the houses of the guilty, "both timber and stones." This implies the death of the inhabitants of the houses (cf. with the curse on covenant breakers in Deut. 30:15). Normally a house provides refuge, but here it brings destruction.

<span id="page-668-5"></span>It is possible also to read God's action in the past tense: "I have sent it out," especially since the scroll is already flying in Zechariah's vision. This gives readers and hearers of Zechariah assurance that God's justice is coming soon.

## *Response*

<span id="page-668-8"></span>Zechariah's vision of a giant flying scroll represents the curse of the law of Moses going out over the land to bring punishment to all who have violated its terms with impunity. It functions in two ways in the book of Zechariah. First, it comforts those who have been sinned against by perpetrators not brought to justice. It assures them God will be true to his word and bring punishment on them. Second, it warns those who continue to sin that they need to repent (cf. 1:3; <span id="page-669-5"></span>7:8–10). In the vision, the curse of the scroll has gone out—his judgment is certain and imminent.

<span id="page-669-8"></span><span id="page-669-7"></span><span id="page-669-6"></span>This vision reminds Christians of the curse of the law that fell on Jesus (Gal. 3:13). He has freed us from sin's consequences by becoming a curse for us. Yet, for all who reject Jesus as Lord and seem to get away with it in this life, this vision reminds us of another scroll in the hands of the risen Lord Jesus (cf. Rev. 5:9). As the seals of this scroll are opened, judgment will fall on his enemies, climaxing in the great day of God's wrath from which there is no hiding (Rev. 6:12–17).

And he said, "This is their iniquity*<sup>2</sup>* in all the land." **7**And behold, the leaden cover was lifted, and there was a woman sitting in the basket! **8**And he said, "This is Wickedness." ### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-669-3"></span><span id="page-669-2"></span><span id="page-669-0"></span>With close connections to the previous vision, the seventh vision pictures wickedness being removed from the land and transported to Babylon. The vision contains direct allusions to Ezekiel 1–11, where the Lord departs from his temple in Jerusalem on a throne chariot attended by winged creatures riding on the wind. He departed due to iniquity (Ezek. 4:4, ESV mg.), wickedness (Ezek. 3:18–19; 5:6), and idolatry (Ezekiel 8), and his departure meant the destruction of the city and temple and exile of the people. With the Lord's return to Jerusalem portrayed in visions 1–5, this vision portrays the removal of iniquity, wickedness, and idolatry—an "anti-ark" borne by "anti-cherubs" is put in an "anti-temple" and transported to an "anti-Jerusalem."20

## *Section Outline*

- II.G. Zechariah's Seventh Vision: A Woman in a Basket (5:5–11)
	- 1. The Woman-Idol Representing Wickedness (5:5–8)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-670-9"></span><span id="page-670-6"></span><span id="page-670-4"></span>5:5 "The angel who talked with me" (also known as the interpreting angel; cf. 1:14; 4:6) shows Zechariah another visionary object ("Lift your eyes and see what this is that is going out"). The movement "out" is significant. In the first five visions the temple is rebuilt, anticipating the Lord's return *to* Jerusalem. The opposite movement is reflected in these last two visions, where all that opposes the Lord is destroyed and driven *out from* the land (5:3, 5–6).21

<span id="page-670-10"></span><span id="page-670-8"></span><span id="page-670-2"></span><span id="page-670-0"></span>5:6 Rather than reporting what he sees, as in earlier visions, here Zechariah simply asks, "What is it?" The angel replies, "This is the basket that is going out." The Hebrew for "basket" is *'ephah*, a unit of measure for grain or flour and, by extension, the measuring vessel itself. The material of an ephah could be ceramic or woven reed. It is thought to be about 6 gallons (22 l) and is used elsewhere in worship and commerce (e.g., Lev. 5:11; 19:36). It appears in a number of passages in injunctions to use a "just" or "honest" ephah (e.g., Deut. 25:14–15; Prov. 20:10; Mic. 6:10). In Zechariah's vision it represents "their iniquity in all the land."22 "Iniquity" refers to sin and its associated guilt and can extend also to its punishment. In Zechariah 3:4, "iniquity" refers to the guilt of the high priest Joshua, taken away as he was reclothed. Here in 5:6 the "land" refers to the land of the people of Judah, contrasted with the "land of Shinar" in verse 11.

<span id="page-670-14"></span><span id="page-670-11"></span><span id="page-670-5"></span><span id="page-670-3"></span>5:7 Concealed in the basket is a woman. The "leaden cover" can also be translated "talent of lead," a "talent" being a unit of currency or weight (about 66 lb./30 kg). It does not seem to refer to a "cover," as the "leaden weight" (or "leaden stone") in verse 8 uses a different term. Instead, the "talent of lead" is lifted out of the basket and identified as a woman, namely a statuette idol.23 In Hebrew the phrase "talent of lead" (*kikkar ʻoferet*) seems like a word-play with "mercy seat" (*kapporet*), which covered the ark of the covenant. Whereas the Lord was enthroned on the mercy seat, the woman is "enthroned" in the basket, portrayed as an anti-ark, which becomes clearer as the vision is elaborated.

<span id="page-670-12"></span>5:8 The woman-idol represents "wickedness" (*harishʻah*), in Hebrew a near anagram for "Asherah," a foreign god worshiped by Israelites until the Babylonian exile

<span id="page-670-13"></span><span id="page-670-7"></span><sup>21</sup> The Hebrew also says the interpreting angel "went out" (v. 1) rather than "came forward." He speaks to Zechariah on his way to the basket that is "going out." Similarly the two women in verse 9 "were going out" rather than "coming forward."

<sup>22</sup> The translation "their iniquity" (ESV) follows the Septuagint and Syriac rather than the Hebrew Masoretic Text. The Hebrew has "their eye," but it is difficult to make sense of this, and the difference would be a simple copyist error (writing the letter *yod* [י [instead of *waw* [ו([.

<span id="page-670-15"></span><span id="page-670-1"></span><sup>23</sup> In Hebrew the woman is described as "one woman." This may be an echo of the Shema (Deut. 6:4; Zech. 14:9) to indicate the woman-idol is an anti-god figure.

<span id="page-671-4"></span>(2 Kings 23:4, 6–7). After revealing her identity, the interpreting angel restrains the woman-idol in the basket with a "leaden weight" so that she cannot escape.

<span id="page-671-10"></span><span id="page-671-7"></span>5:9 The visionary scene continues with "two women coming forward" with "wind . . . in their wings," an expression indicating flight (cf. Ezek. 1:11–12). Their wings are "like the wings of a stork"—a large bird with powerful wings known for its yearly northward migration from the land of Judah (cf. Jer. 8:7). The expression "between earth and heaven" refers to the sky.

<span id="page-671-11"></span><span id="page-671-5"></span><span id="page-671-1"></span>5:10–11 The basket is transported "to the land of Shinar," the country of God's enemies also known as Babylonia (cf. 2:7; Gen. 11:2). Here a house is built for the basket and it is set up like an idol.

<span id="page-671-6"></span>There are many elements of this vision suggesting the basket is a parody of the ark of the covenant (cf. Ezekiel 1; 8–11). In addition to the "leaden cover" sounding like "mercy seat" in Hebrew and the woman-idol being enthroned in the basket, the two cherubim of the ark are paralleled by the two women with stork-like wings. As God's house is built in Jerusalem and he returns (visions 1–5), wickedness is carried far away and a house is built for it.

## *Response*

<span id="page-671-2"></span>This vision promises the eradication from the land of all that is opposed to God and his good purposes. Wickedness will be sent back to where it belongs. There is also an echo of the Day of Atonement ritual in Leviticus 16, when, after the temple is cleansed (cf. Zechariah 3–4), the scapegoat bearing the sins of the people is sent far away (Lev. 16:22).

<span id="page-671-9"></span><span id="page-671-3"></span>This vision points to the second coming of Jesus. In his first coming, Jesus' death on the cross won forgiveness and cleansing from sin. When he returns and the final judgment takes place, iniquity, wickedness, and idolatry will be eradicated from the world. He will remove from his presence all who reject him and thereby continue in wickedness, and they will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction (cf. 2 Thess. 1:6–10). The response this vision calls for is repentance and obedience to Jesus.

<span id="page-671-12"></span><span id="page-671-8"></span><span id="page-671-0"></span>In the Bible, "Shinar" or "Babylon" comes to represent proud human ingenuity and skill expressed in opposition to God, as at the Tower of Babel in Genesis 11 (cf. Response section on Zech. 2:1–13). In Revelation 17, Babylon is a prostitute that seduces people with her glamour, but who in the end turns out to be a hideous beast that only destroys. A great threat for Christians today is the same as it was in Zechariah's day: the seductiveness of the wickedness and idols of the Babylon of our age. God's people must see through this deception and resist.

## <span id="page-672-3"></span>ZECHARIAH 6:1–8

6 Again I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold, four chariots came out from between two mountains. And the mountains were mountains of bronze. **2**The first chariot had red horses, the second black horses, **<sup>3</sup>** the third white horses, and the fourth chariot dappled horses—all of them strong.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>4</sup>**Then I answered and said to the angel who talked with me, "What are these, my lord?" **5**And the angel answered and said to me, "These are going out to the four winds of heaven, after presenting themselves before the Lord of all the earth. **6**The chariot with the black horses goes toward the north country, the white ones go after them, and the dappled ones go toward the south country." **7**When the strong horses came out, they were impatient to go and patrol the earth. And he said, "Go, patrol the earth." So they patrolled the earth. **8**Then he cried to me, "Behold, those who go toward the north country have set my Spirit at rest in the north country."

1Or *and the fourth chariot strong dappled horses*

#### *Section Overview*

The final vision rounds out the sequence of eight night visions by echoing several themes of the earlier visions. The presence of horses matches the first vision, though their role is different here. The second and third visions speak of the coming destruction of the nations, particularly Babylon ("the north country"). In this final vision, "the north country" is finally judged (6:8).

<span id="page-672-4"></span>The central idea of the final vision is that God will subdue hostile nations with his heavenly army, setting the world aright.

### *Section Outline*

- II.H. Zechariah's Eighth Vision: Four Chariots (6:1–8)
	- 1. The Vision Reported (6:1–3)
	- 2. The Vision Explained (6:4–8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-672-2"></span><span id="page-672-1"></span><span id="page-672-0"></span>6:1 Now Zechariah sees "four chariots." Chariots were primarily military vehicles used in open country for rapid flanking movements or for pursuing an enemy. They often carried an archer and shield-bearer. Chariots also symbolize the power of kingship (e.g., Gen. 41:43; 1 Kings 1:5), and were often associated with the divine in ancient Near Eastern thought. The number four seems to represent the scope of their mission to "patrol the earth," namely its four corners (Zech. 6:7; cf. 1:19–20).

<span id="page-673-11"></span>The chariots "came out from between two mountains." It is impossible for earthly chariots to travel on mountains like this, indicating these are not normal chariots. Rather, they are chariots from God's presence (6:5). They are the host (army) of the Lord of hosts. The "mountains of bronze" are best understood as the entrance to the heavens. Solomon's temple, which represented the heavens in its layout (cf. Heb. 8:5), had two bronze pillars at its entrance (1 Kings 7:15–22).

<span id="page-673-8"></span><span id="page-673-0"></span>6:2–3 Each chariot has different-colored horses, though no significance is given to the colors (cf. the horse colors with the first vision; not all are the same).24 Pictures and models from this period show chariots drawn by two to four horses, but the number is not stated here. All the horses are "strong" or valiant (v. 3, also v. 7).

<span id="page-673-10"></span><span id="page-673-9"></span><span id="page-673-4"></span>6:4–5 Zechariah's question, "What are these, my lord?" (v. 4), repeats earlier questions (1:9; 4:4) and shows the visions are all related.

There are some translation issues in verse 5. First, the chariots are said to travel "to the four winds of heaven," which is difficult to explain. A closer rendering of the Hebrew *likens* the four chariots to "four winds of heaven." As a descriptor, it suggests the chariots are swift and have wide-ranging movements, or that they ride the winds (cf. Ps. 104:4). In addition, the word for "winds" can also be translated "Spirit," which, like Zechariah 4:6, indicates God's purposes are accomplished by his Spirit. The directions the chariots travel are then given in 6:6–8.

<span id="page-673-13"></span><span id="page-673-6"></span><span id="page-673-2"></span><span id="page-673-1"></span>Second, the chariots are said to go out from God's presence (the heavenly court) "after presenting themselves before the Lord"—they go out as his army. This is certainly true, but the Hebrew is better rendered such that the chariots go out "on account of the taking of a stand against the Lord of the whole earth."25 The phrase is similar to Psalm 2:2, which refers to the rebellion of the nations against the Lord and his anointed. This translation gives a reason for the chariots' mission: the rebellion of the nations against God. This well suits the wider and immediate contexts.

<span id="page-673-12"></span><span id="page-673-7"></span><span id="page-673-5"></span>6:6 Two chariots (the ones with the black and the white horses) go "toward the north country." This phrase is used by the prophet Jeremiah typically to refer to Babylon, where God's people had been taken as captives (cf. comment on 2:6–7) and where the woman in the basket had been taken in the previous vision ("Shinar"; 5:11). Historically, this is where the most devastating opposition to God's people had originated, which may explain the need for two chariots. The chariot with the dappled horses travels "south," perhaps against Edom and/or Egypt. Some translations add horses going to the east and west, but this is unnecessary. There is no need to travel elsewhere—to the east is desert and to the west is the sea. The fourth chariot, with red horses, is possibly held in reserve.

<span id="page-673-3"></span><sup>24</sup> As with 1:8, the color "red" can also be translated "chestnut." "Dappled" refers to "Speckles, spots, or patches," which likely are "white" or "light" in color (cf. Hartley, *Semantics of Ancient Hebrew Colour Lexemes*, cited above, note 6).

<sup>25</sup> For this translation see Max Rogland, "Heavenly Chariots and Earthly Rebellion in Zechariah 6," *Bib* 85 (2014): 117–123.

<span id="page-674-10"></span><span id="page-674-9"></span><span id="page-674-8"></span><span id="page-674-4"></span>6:7–8 The horses and chariots go out at God's command to "patrol the earth" (v. 7). Whereas the horses in the first vision were involved in surveillance on behalf of the Lord, these horses and chariots subdue the nations as his heavenly army and are an expression of his sovereignty over all the earth. In the first vision, the report was that "all the earth remains at rest" (1:11) while God's people do not, and God announced he was coming to reverse this situation. This final vision pictures the Lord's heavenly army bringing judgment on the nations, particularly Babylon, with the result that God's Spirit is set at rest (6:8). God's "Spirit" (*ruakh*) can also be translated as "wind" (cf. the "four winds" in 6:5, using the same word) and could also refer to his anger or wrath (e.g., Judg. 8:3; Prov. 16:32; Eccles. 10:4). Elsewhere God's anger is said to "rest" upon his people for their sins (e.g., Ezek. 13:13; 16:42; 21:17). In this case, God's anger will rest upon his enemies, particularly those in the north country. The word "rest" also brings to mind promises for the realization of God's kingdom (e.g., Deut. 12:10; 2 Sam. 7:1, 11; 2 Chron. 6:41).

### <span id="page-674-7"></span><span id="page-674-3"></span><span id="page-674-2"></span><span id="page-674-1"></span><span id="page-674-0"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-674-5"></span>This final vision assures God's people that the Lord is sovereign over all nations and his purposes will prevail. The primary response it elicits is repentance and faith. In the wider sequence of visions, this specifically involves returning from exile (Zech. 2:6–8), rebuilding Jerusalem (1:17; 2:4), rebuilding the temple (1:16; 4:7–10), singing and rejoicing (2:10), and covenant obedience (3:7; 5:4, 8). This passage calls Christian readers today to exhibit similar trust—to live joyfully in obedience to Jesus and be devoted to building his temple, the church.

<span id="page-674-12"></span><span id="page-674-11"></span><span id="page-674-6"></span>The book of Revelation draws on the horse imagery of Zechariah's first and last visions. In Revelation 6:1–8, four colored horses ride out to bring judgment on the earth as the Lamb progressively opens seals of the scroll in his hand. These judgments are evidence of God's present activity in the world and point to his final judgment. Christians are assured that God has all things in hand, no matter how out of control our world might appear. There is also a challenge to followers of Jesus not to grow complacent or get comfortable and secure in a world coming to judgment. Revelation 19:11–16 also develops this imagery in the Lord Jesus' and the armies of heaven's riding white horses and striking down rebellious nations. Like Zechariah's final vision, Christ's certain victory gives courage to God's people today and inspires obedience to his word.

## <span id="page-675-1"></span>ZECHARIAH 6:9–15

**<sup>9</sup>**And the word of the Lord came to me: **<sup>10</sup>** "Take from the exiles Heldai, Tobijah, and Jedaiah, who have arrived from Babylon, and go the same day to the house of Josiah, the son of Zephaniah. **11**Take from them silver and gold, and make a crown, and set it on the head of Joshua, the son of Jehozadak, the high priest. **12**And say to him, 'Thus says the Lord of hosts, "Behold, the man whose name is the Branch: for he shall branch out from his place, and he shall build the temple of the Lord. **<sup>13</sup>** It is he who shall build the temple of the Lord and shall bear royal honor, and shall sit and rule on his throne. And there*<sup>1</sup>* shall be a priest on his throne, and the counsel of peace shall be between them both." ' **14**And the crown shall be in the temple of the Lord as a reminder to Helem,*<sup>2</sup>* Tobijah, Jedaiah, and Hen the son of Zephaniah.

**<sup>15</sup>** "And those who are far off shall come and help to build the temple of the Lord. And you shall know that the Lord of hosts has sent me to you. And this shall come to pass, if you will diligently obey the voice of the Lord your God."

1Or *he* 2An alternate spelling of *Heldai* (verse 10)

### *Section Overview*

Zechariah is to perform a symbolic action and speak to the high priest, Joshua. It is the first of three sign-actions in the book (the others are in ch. 11). To make a crown and set it on Joshua's head looks beyond the completion of Zerubbabel's temple to the coming Branch (or "Shoot") and the temple he will build. The passage transitions from the situation in Zechariah's day to the future Davidic king's coming to establish the kingdom that the visions anticipate. Its purpose is to generate faith, obedience, and hope among those who read it.

#### *Section Outline*

- III. A Symbolic Crown for Joshua the High Priest (6:9–15)
	- A. Make a Crown and Set It on Joshua (6:9–11)
	- B. A Word to Joshua concerning the Branch (6:12–13)
	- C. The Crown as a Memorial in the Temple (6:14)
	- D. A Promise and a Call to Obedience (6:15)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-675-2"></span><span id="page-675-0"></span>6:9–11 Zechariah is told to "take from the exiles." It is not clear until verse 11 that he is to take "silver and gold." The exiles are named, suggesting they were well Zechar iah 6:9–15 676

<span id="page-676-8"></span>known in the community. As returnees "from Babylon," they have heeded the call to "flee from the land of the north" (2:6). Many exiles returned from Babylon with wealth (cf. Ezra 2:68–69).

<span id="page-676-13"></span><span id="page-676-10"></span><span id="page-676-9"></span><span id="page-676-2"></span>Zechariah is to use the "silver and gold" to "make a crown" (Zech. 6:11).26 He is then to symbolically crown the high priest, Joshua (cf. comment on 3:1). Joshua featured centrally in the fourth vision (ch. 3), where he was cleansed, clothed, and commissioned to serve in the rebuilt temple. Joshua and his fellow priests also serve as a sign of the coming "Branch" (or "Shoot"). In the exile, the Davidic king was removed from the throne and his crown defiled in the dust (Ps. 89:39; Jer. 22:24–30; Ezek. 21:26–27). This new crown is placed on the high priest possibly in order to sanctify it in preparation for a future king to wear without defiling it.

<span id="page-676-14"></span><span id="page-676-11"></span><span id="page-676-4"></span>6:12 Zechariah is to speak to Joshua, who also represents the future "Branch" (or "Shoot") in this symbolic action (cf. comment on 3:8 concerning the messianic significance of this title).

The "Branch . . . shall branch out from his place"—this reflects a wordplay in Hebrew, which can also be translated, "Shoot . . . will shoot up in his place." The statement implies the Shoot will take the place of Joshua and claim his rightful crown, presumably as a legitimate descendant of David ("his place").27 In addition, when he comes, the future king "shall build the temple of the Lord" (this is repeated at the beginning of 6:13 for emphasis and possibly in contrast to Zerubbabel). Temple building is the task of a Davidic king (cf. 2 Samuel 7). However, the temple the future Davidic king will build will be much greater than Zerubbabel's. It is the eschatological temple of which the earlier prophets spoke (e.g., Isa. 2:2–4; Jer. 3:16–18; Ezekiel 40–42; Mic. 4:1–5). This eschatological temple is also anticipated in Zechariah 14.

<span id="page-676-17"></span><span id="page-676-15"></span><span id="page-676-12"></span><span id="page-676-5"></span><span id="page-676-0"></span>While some scholars argue Zerubbabel was the Branch, this is problematic. First, this is unstated in the text of Zechariah. Second, many of the descriptions of the Branch in 6:13 were never realized for Zerubbabel. Nor did Zerubbabel bring in the day of peace and prosperity associated with the Branch in 3:8–10. Lastly, Zechariah's claiming this would have posed great problems for his authenticity as a prophet when such a key prophecy failed to take place. Instead, the Branch (Shoot) is a future Davidic king beyond Zerubbabel, and the crown functions to anticipate his coming.

<span id="page-676-6"></span>6:13 The Branch (Shoot) will "bear royal honor" (or "be clothed with majesty"; NIV)—a status appropriate for a king (cf. Jer. 22:18). Furthermore, he "shall sit and rule on his throne," echoing Jeremiah 22:30, where these things are denied

<span id="page-676-16"></span><span id="page-676-7"></span><span id="page-676-3"></span><sup>26</sup> The Hebrew for "crown" is plural, leading some scholars to argue two crowns are made. However, the context indicates only one crown is in view, especially since a singular verb is used in verse 14 with "the crown" as its subject (cf. Job 31:36, where the same plural form refers to a single crown). Perhaps the plural form indicates a composite crown made of gold and silver rings.

<span id="page-676-1"></span><sup>27</sup> The expression translated "from his place" refers in more than eighty other instances to a king's son taking his father's place as king (e.g., 2 Sam. 10:1; 2 Chron. 1:8).

<span id="page-677-5"></span>to King Jehoiachin and his immediate offspring because of his sin. Straight after this, Jeremiah 23:5 prophesies the coming of the "righteous Branch," who will do what is just and right—a hope reaffirmed here.

<span id="page-677-6"></span><span id="page-677-2"></span><span id="page-677-1"></span>Commentators debate whether the next phrase—"There shall be a priest on his throne"—refers to the hope of Jeremiah for a Levitical priest accompanying the Davidic Branch (cf. Jer. 33:17–22) or to the Branch functioning also as a priest— "He will be a priest on his throne" (cf. ESV mg.). In Hebrew, the Branch is the most natural subject of "he will be," but if the Branch is also a priest, why does the verse refer to "them both"? Psalm 110 seems to be the conceptual background for this verse. In this psalm, the Messiah sits by the Lord's throne (v. 1) to rule (vv. 2–3) and is designated a priest in the order of Melchizedek (v. 4; cf. Heb. 5:1–10; 6:20–8:2). If this idea of a priest-king is the background, Zechariah is saying the reign of the Lord and his Messiah ("them both") will issue in "peace" (Hb. *shalom*). In this case, Jeremiah's hope for a priest and king is merged into the one figure, a co-regent with the Lord.

<span id="page-677-3"></span><span id="page-677-0"></span>6:14 After the symbolic action is performed, Zechariah is to give the crown to the returned exiles for safekeeping in Zerubbabel's temple. There it will function as a "reminder" or memorial of what these men have done. Elsewhere, memorials function as a testimony to the Lord (e.g., Ex. 28:29; 30:16; Num. 10:9–10)—the crown in the presence of the Lord in the temple assures the people that his plans to send the Branch will come to pass (cf. the symbols of Zech. 3:8–9).

<span id="page-677-12"></span><span id="page-677-11"></span><span id="page-677-10"></span>It is not clear why two of the names in 6:14 are different from those in verse 10. Perhaps they are alternative nicknames, or are changed to reflect a new meaning; for instance, "Hen" means "grace" and may refer to the kindness of the son of Zephaniah. Perhaps they are simply different individuals. We do not have enough information to be sure.

<span id="page-677-13"></span><span id="page-677-9"></span><span id="page-677-8"></span>6:15 The ones "far off" may be Gentiles (cf. 2:11; 8:20–23; 14:16–19), but they are more likely Jewish exiles living in foreign lands (cf. 6:10 and 2:6). They will come to help complete Zerubbabel's temple and thereby authenticate Zechariah's message. Since the temple was completed by the time the book of Zechariah was finished, it assures future readers and hearers that other aspects of his message will come to pass as well (such as the coming Branch and the peace he will bring) and functions as a call to obedience.

### *Response*

<span id="page-677-15"></span><span id="page-677-14"></span><span id="page-677-7"></span><span id="page-677-4"></span>This sign-action and the word accompanying it reiterate the hope of the earlier prophets for an ideal future king, the Branch or Messiah, who is instrumental in God's coming kingdom (Isa. 11:1; Jer. 23:5–6; 33:14–18; Ezek. 17:3–6, 22–23; 21:26–27). This hope is developed further in Zechariah 9–14. Christians see these hopes fulfilled in Jesus, the one for whom the descriptions of the Branch are true: he is "the man" of prophetic expectation (Matt. 11:3–6; Mark 8:27–30; John 19:5); a descendant of David (Matt. 1:1; Rom. 1:3; Rev. 5:5); the builder of the temple,

<span id="page-678-5"></span><span id="page-678-4"></span><span id="page-678-3"></span><span id="page-678-2"></span>namely his church (Matt. 16:18; 1 Cor. 3:16–17; 2 Cor. 6:16; Eph. 2:17–22; Heb. 3:3; 1 Pet. 2:5); the one who bears royal honor (Matt. 25:31; Acts 2:34–36; Heb. 1:3; 2:9; Rev. 19:12); the one who as Messiah is seated at God's right hand (Matt. 26:64; Acts 2:33; 5:31; Rom. 8:34; Col. 3:1); the one who as priest has provided cleansing for sin and sat down at the right hand of God's throne (Heb. 1:3; 5:10; 8:1; 10:12; 12:2; 1 Pet. 3:22); and the one whose "counsel" with his Father has brought peace (Eph. 2:14–18).

<span id="page-678-8"></span><span id="page-678-7"></span><span id="page-678-6"></span><span id="page-678-1"></span><span id="page-678-0"></span>Now that Messiah Jesus has come, he calls his followers to build his temple, the church, in anticipation of his return. The fact that so many of these promises have been fulfilled gives Christians even greater assurance that he is faithful to keep all his promises and underscores the challenge to diligently obey his voice (cf. Zech. 1:3).

## ZECHARIAH 7:1–14

7In the fourth year of King Darius, the word of the Lord came to Zechariah on the fourth day of the ninth month, which is Chislev. **2**Now the people of Bethel had sent Sharezer and Regem-melech and their men to entreat the favor of the Lord, **<sup>3</sup>** saying to the priests of the house of the Lord of hosts and the prophets, "Should I weep and abstain in the fifth month, as I have done for so many years?"

**<sup>4</sup>**Then the word of the Lord of hosts came to me: **<sup>5</sup>** "Say to all the people of the land and the priests, 'When you fasted and mourned in the fifth month and in the seventh, for these seventy years, was it for me that you fasted? **6**And when you eat and when you drink, do you not eat for yourselves and drink for yourselves? **7**Were not these the words that the Lord proclaimed by the former prophets, when Jerusalem was inhabited and prosperous, with her cities around her, and the South and the lowland were inhabited?' "

**<sup>8</sup>**And the word of the Lord came to Zechariah, saying, **<sup>9</sup>** "Thus says the Lord of hosts, Render true judgments, show kindness and mercy to one another, **10**do not oppress the widow, the fatherless, the sojourner, or the poor, and let none of you devise evil against another in your heart." **11**But they refused to pay attention and turned a stubborn shoulder and stopped their ears that they might not hear.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>12</sup>**They made their hearts diamondhard lest they should hear the law and the words that the Lord of hosts had sent by his Spirit through the former prophets. Therefore great anger came from the Lord of hosts. **<sup>13</sup>** "As I*<sup>2</sup>* called, and they would not hear, so they called, and I would not hear," says the Lord of hosts, **<sup>14</sup>** "and I scattered them with a whirlwind among all the nations that they had not known. Thus the land they left was desolate, so that no one went to and fro, and the pleasant land was made desolate."

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-679-4"></span><span id="page-679-3"></span>The dating formula in 7:1 marks a new section of the book (cf. 1:1 and 1:7). Chapters 7–8 form a transition between chapters 1–6 and 9–14. Since the question asked at the beginning of chapter 7 is directly addressed only at the end of chapter 8, the chapters must be seen as closely connected. They will be treated separately here simply for ease of presentation.

A delegation from Bethel poses a question to the religious leaders in Jerusalem about the need to continue fasting. This provides an occasion for Zechariah to reapply important covenant requirements to the people and restate the hope for restoration. Zechariah calls the people to covenant obedience in view of God's just judgment of the past sins of the "fathers." This chapter challenges us concerning the way we treat others, particularly the vulnerable, and warns of the danger of religious hypocrisy.

## *Section Outline*

- IV. From Fasting to Feasting (7:1–8:23)
	- A. Justice and Mercy, Not Fasting (7:1–14)
		- 1. Setting (7:1)
		- 2. Bethel's Question about Fasting (7:2–3)
		- 3. Zechariah's Questions about Motives (7:4–7)
		- 4. The Message of the Former Prophets (7:8–10)
		- 5. Learn the Lesson the Fathers Did Not Learn (7:11–14)

#### *Comment*

7:1 A third and final dating formula introduces this section (cf. 1:1, 7 and comments). Now Darius is titled "King," subtly reminding the readers and hearers that even though the temple reconstruction is under way (and was completed by the time the book of Zechariah was written), the people of God are still living under a foreign power. The "fourth year of King Darius . . . on the fourth day of the ninth month" is December 7, 518 BC. This is almost two years after the night visions of chapters 1–6 and two years before the temple is completed (cf. Ezra 6:14–16). "Chislev" is a Babylonian month name (cf. comment on Zech. 1:7).

<span id="page-679-6"></span><span id="page-679-5"></span><span id="page-679-2"></span><span id="page-679-1"></span><span id="page-679-0"></span>7:2 The city of Bethel was located about 12 miles (20 km) north of Jerusalem. Before the exile it was part of the northern kingdom (1 Kings 12:29–33; Hos. 10:15; Amos 3:14), but afterward it appears to have been part of Judah (Ezra 2:28; Neh. 7:32). A delegation headed by Sharezer and Regem-melech is sent by the people of Bethel "to entreat the favor of the Lord," that is, to seek God's favor in the aftermath of the exile. This is a foretaste of what other cities will do in Zechariah 8:20–21.

<span id="page-679-8"></span><span id="page-679-7"></span>7:3 As part of seeking the Lord's favor, the delegation also seeks an answer to an important question from the religious leaders in Jerusalem (the temple priests and the prophets). The priests were responsible for instructing the people in the Torah <span id="page-680-1"></span><span id="page-680-0"></span>(e.g., Deut. 31:9; Hag. 2:11; Mal. 2:6–7) and determining God's will (e.g., Ex. 28:30; Num. 27:21; Deut. 33:8). The prophets were also responsible for giving guidance in God's ways. Interestingly, it is the prophet Zechariah who answers the delegation's question. Reference to more than one prophet ("prophets") suggests the presence of Haggai also, though he is not named here (but cf. Ezra 6:14).

<span id="page-680-15"></span><span id="page-680-12"></span><span id="page-680-5"></span><span id="page-680-2"></span>The delegation's question concerns the need to continue to "weep and abstain in the fifth month." The verb "weep" is often associated with penitence and lamentation over sin and seeking God's favor (e.g., 2 Sam. 12:21–22). In the context of Zechariah 7:5, it is clear that "abstain" refers to fasting. Fasting "in the fifth month" is one of the four fasts mentioned in 8:19, and this one is believed to recall Nebuchadnezzar's destruction of the temple in 586 BC (2 Kings 25:8–9). With the temple reconstruction in Jerusalem nearing its completion, it was appropriate for the delegation to ask if they must continue to mourn and fast in Bethel. If God has turned to his people with mercy (Zech. 1:16), why the continued need to fast?

<span id="page-680-11"></span><span id="page-680-10"></span><span id="page-680-4"></span>7:4–5 The word of God that comes to Zechariah in response to the delegation's question cuts to the heart of their motives. The prophet poses a series of three questions "to all the people of the land and the priests" (v. 5)—their question has implications beyond the city of Bethel.

<span id="page-680-8"></span><span id="page-680-3"></span>The first question of Zechariah extends also to the fast of the "seventh" month, which apparently commemorated the assassination of Gedaliah, whom Nebuchadnezzar appointed governor (2 Kings 25:25). The reference to seventy years is to the time of exile and temple desolation prophesied by Jeremiah (Jer. 25:11–12; 29:10; cf. Zech. 1:12).28 God asks, "Was it for me that you fasted?" (7:5). This question challenges the people about their motives in fasting. Fasting without obedience to God is hypocritical (Isa. 58:3–6).

<span id="page-680-13"></span><span id="page-680-9"></span><span id="page-680-7"></span>7:6 A second question asks if they eat and drink (presumably at their religious festivals, such as Passover, Weeks, Booths/Tabernacles) for God or for their own benefit. The implication of the question is that their motives have been selfish and insincere.

<span id="page-680-14"></span><span id="page-680-6"></span>7:7 A third question asks if their behavior is consistent with the words the Lord proclaimed by the former prophets. As in 1:4, the expression "former prophets" here refers to prophets like Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezekiel who proclaimed that a relationship with God and obedience to his word is more important than religious ritual (e.g., Isa. 1:10–11; 58:3–6; Jeremiah 7; Joel 2:12–13; Mic. 6:6–8). The delegation had asked about fasting, and Zechariah reminds them that the Lord is much more interested in relationship and obedience to his word. The words of the "former prophets" are still very relevant.

Zechariah reminds the people of an earlier time, "when Jerusalem was inhabited and prosperous," a time that was lost because the people refused to listen to

<sup>28</sup> The seventy years may represent a lifetime, or the period between the destruction and reconstruction of the temple—it was destroyed in 586 BC and the rebuilding was completed in 515.

<span id="page-681-11"></span><span id="page-681-3"></span>God's word proclaimed by the "former prophets" (cf. Zech. 1:4). The prosperity was also shared by "her cities around her" and further afield. The "South" (or "Negeb") was located about 50 miles (80 km) south of Jerusalem. It was used for grazing and agriculture and was also an important trade route. Under Solomon, Israelite control extended through this region (1 Kings 9:26). The "lowland" (or "Shephelah") refers to the tract of low hills between the high central ranges of Judea and the coastal plains. Zechariah implies that these regions are not inhabited as they were in preexilic times, and that the need for obedience to God's word is as great as it was then. He effectively asks them if they have learned the needed lessons from the exilic experience.

<span id="page-681-12"></span><span id="page-681-2"></span>7:8–10 God summarizes the heart of the message of the "former prophets" (cf. 1:4) and states that he values justice more than religious rituals like fasting (e.g., 1 Sam. 15:22–23; Amos 5:21–27; Mic. 6:7–8). There are many parallels in these verses to Jeremiah's temple sermon (in Jeremiah 7), where Jeremiah repudiates the idea that temple service provides impunity from the consequences of unethical behavior.

<span id="page-681-15"></span><span id="page-681-13"></span><span id="page-681-8"></span><span id="page-681-1"></span><span id="page-681-0"></span>"Render true judgments" (Zech. 7:9) is broader than simply ruling faithfully in legal cases, though it certainly includes this (cf. 8:16–17). This phrase can also be translated "judge true justice," which is first and foremost found in God and the rightness of his ways (Deut. 32:4; Ps. 89:14). "Justice" is often paired with "righteousness," and together they constitute an ethical ideal for God's people described also as keeping "the way of the Lord" (e.g., Gen. 18:19). Justice also represents right relationships as enshrined in the covenant God made with Israel at Sinai, encompassing "kindness and mercy" (Zech. 7:9; cf. Jer. 9:24; Hos. 2:19; 12:6). Justice also means not oppressing the weak and vulnerable—"the widow, the fatherless, the sojourner, or the poor" (Zech. 7:10; cf. Isa. 1:17; Jer. 7:6). Furthermore, justice is not merely external acts but extends to thoughts and motivations: "Let none of you devise evil against another in your heart" (Zech. 7:10), where the "heart" is the seat of the will in Hebrew thought. God's people are to judge or determine what is right and true in all their relationships—and then do it!

<span id="page-681-14"></span><span id="page-681-7"></span><span id="page-681-4"></span>7:11–12 The ancestors' refusal to obey God's words is stated in four ways: (1) "they refused to pay attention" (cf. Jer. 7:24; Zech. 1:4); (2) they "turned a stubborn shoulder," using the image of an animal that refuses the yoke (e.g., Ex. 32:9; Jer. 7:24); (3) they "stopped their ears that they might not hear," indicating a willful refusal (cf. Isa. 6:10; Zech. 1:4); and (4) "they made their hearts diamond-hard" (Zech. 7:12; cf. Jer. 6:28; 17:1; Ezek. 3:7–9; 11:19).

<span id="page-681-16"></span><span id="page-681-10"></span><span id="page-681-9"></span><span id="page-681-6"></span><span id="page-681-5"></span>God's words to the community came by the law and the prophets (cf. Mal. 4:4–6). Zechariah 7:12 also clearly links the words of the prophets with the agency of God's Spirit (cf. 4:6; Ezek. 11:5; Mic. 3:8). Their fathers' rejection of God's word led to their rightly experiencing his "great anger" (Zech. 7:12). The exile as God's anger at those who continued to refuse him reiterates the introduction of the book (cf. 1:2). The consequences of this anger are elaborated in 7:13–14.

<span id="page-682-3"></span>7:13 Because the people refused to listen to God and continued in their unjust ways, God shut his ears to their prayers. The implication is that they asked God for things only when it suited them—they treated him as their servant, further insulting him.

<span id="page-682-4"></span>7:14 The result was that God "scattered them with a whirlwind among all the nations." The verb "scatter" conveys the idea of being blown by the wind of a storm. Although a different verb is used here, this echoes the covenant curse of "scattering" (Lev. 26:31–33; Deut. 28:64). It refers to exile and dispersion among the nations—those whom "they had not known."

<span id="page-682-2"></span><span id="page-682-0"></span>The prosperous situation referred to in verse 7 is undone: "the land they left was desolate, . . . the pleasant land was made desolate." That "no one went to and fro" suggests a lack of security, travel, and trade. While it was God who scattered the people in judgment, the people bore responsibility through their refusal to listen to God's word. God is sovereign in judgment, and the people bear responsibility for their sin.

### *Response*

With the near completion of the temple, a delegation comes to Jerusalem from Bethel to ask if fasting is still appropriate, since fasting was instituted in response to the destruction of the temple some seventy years earlier. Zechariah uses the occasion to challenge the delegation (and readers and hearers of his book) concerning their motives and their obedience to the word of God. The (negative) example of the fathers is used to warn of the danger of religious hypocrisy and refusal to listen to the prophets—the fathers suffered the consequences of God's wrath in the judgment of exile.

<span id="page-682-7"></span><span id="page-682-1"></span>Zechariah's key point is that repentance to God and humble obedience to his word is more important than rituals such as fasting. This theme is found elsewhere in the OT (e.g., 1 Sam. 15:22; Ps. 51:16–17). Likewise, Jesus teaches his followers that repentance and humility before God is more important than fasting (e.g., Luke 18:9–14). In several instances, Jesus indicts religious leaders who were very public in their observance of religious rituals but failed in the weightier matters of the law, such as justice, mercy, faith, and the love of God (e.g., Matt. 23:23; Luke 11:32; John 7:24). Zechariah's concern for care of the poor and love of the disadvantaged is an emphasis found across the Bible (e.g., Matt. 9:13; 1 Cor. 11:17–34; Gal. 6:10; 1 Tim. 5:8–16; 1 John 3:17).

<span id="page-682-9"></span><span id="page-682-8"></span><span id="page-682-6"></span><span id="page-682-5"></span>A real danger for modern Christians rightly concerned about injustices in many parts of the world is to call for social justice elsewhere while ignoring injustice before our very eyes—in our homes, churches, businesses, and Christian institutions. When justice and righteousness is not served in our own spheres of influence, any concern expressed for justice elsewhere rings hollow and is hypocritical. Christians must also recognize that the call for justice must first be grounded in the gospel of grace and must flow out of a relationship with God, or else we run the danger of sounding sim<span id="page-683-1"></span>ply like angry legalists. To expect people to love others genuinely (with no thought of personal gain) without being in relationship with Jesus Christ is like expecting fruit to grow apart from a tree (to use a biblical metaphor). For Zechariah and the rest of the Bible, right relationships with others (particularly seen in apt treatment of the weak and vulnerable) are evidence of a right relationship with God: "Whoever loves has been born of God and knows God" (1 John 4:7).
