### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-684-4"></span><span id="page-684-1"></span><span id="page-684-0"></span>Chapters 7–8 form a unit that begins with a question from a delegation from Bethel to Jerusalem and ends with its answer (cf. Section Overview of 7:1–14). The question gives Zechariah opportunity to restate pertinent covenant requirements to the people and reaffirm the hope for God's coming kingdom. Whereas chapter 7 focused on the failure of earlier generations, chapter 8 has a more positive tone, calling for obedience in view of future salvation and blessing; the city of Jerusalem will be filled (vv. 1–8), and the land will be fruitful (vv. 9–13). The future blessing of the nations at the end of chapter 8 functions to introduce chapters 9–14, which explore the process by which the nations will ultimately recognize the Lord in Jerusalem (a theme of ch. 14).

<span id="page-684-12"></span><span id="page-684-9"></span><span id="page-684-8"></span>Chapter 8 contains ten promises of blessing, each beginning with "Thus says the Lord (of hosts)" (vv. 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 9, 14, 19, 20, 23). Two broader sections are each introduced by the phrase, "And the word of the Lord of hosts came to me" (vv. 1–17; 18–23).

<span id="page-684-7"></span>At the heart of this section is God's desire for a restored relationship with his people. Through renewed covenant faithfulness, God's people will experience his blessing and reflect his character to the world so that the nations will be drawn to seek the Lord.

### *Section Outline*

IV.B. Jerusalem Will Be a City of Blessing (8:1–23)

- <span id="page-684-11"></span><span id="page-684-10"></span><span id="page-684-6"></span>1. The Lord Is Coming to Bless (8:1–8)
- 2. Curses Will Turn to Blessing (8:9–15)
- 3. A Renewed Call to Covenant Faithfulness (8:16–17)
- 4. Fasts Will Become Feasts (8:18–19)
- 5. The Nations Will Come (8:20–23)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-684-5"></span><span id="page-684-3"></span><span id="page-684-2"></span>8:1 In response to the question of the delegation from Bethel (7:1–3), God's word for Zechariah to the community continues (cf. 7:1, 4, 8; 8:18). The description <span id="page-685-5"></span>"Lord of hosts" occurs eighteen times in chapter 8 (cf. comment on 1:2–6a). This introduction to Zechariah's oracles indicates that they come with all the authority of God and underscores why readers and hearers should pay attention to what he says.

<span id="page-685-10"></span><span id="page-685-6"></span>8:2–3 God's jealousy for Zion was a theme of 1:14 (cf. comment there). "Jealousy" refers to God's willingness to defend what rightly belongs to him by judging "with great wrath" both those who oppose his people and those of his people who refuse him.

<span id="page-685-11"></span><span id="page-685-8"></span><span id="page-685-7"></span><span id="page-685-3"></span>God's jealousy is the grounds for his turning to his people (8:3). God's statement "I have returned" can also be translated "I have turned" (cf. 1:16; 2:10). As in 1:16, God has turned to his people with mercy (seen in the many who have returned from exile to rebuild Jerusalem). Yet the hope found in places like Ezekiel 43:4 for God's return to "dwell in the midst of Jerusalem," with his glory returning to the temple, still lies in the future, after the temple's completion (cf. Zech. 2:10–11; Mal. 3:1). When the Lord's glory returns to the city, Jerusalem "shall be called the faithful city," with its inhabitants reflecting God's character as reliable, dependable, and trustworthy. There is possibly an echo here of the transformation of Jerusalem in Isaiah (e.g., Isa. 1:21–2:5).

<span id="page-685-18"></span><span id="page-685-4"></span><span id="page-685-1"></span><span id="page-685-0"></span>The "mountain" is a reference to Mount Zion, the temple site in Jerusalem (cf. Hag. 1:8). It will be "the holy mountain" because God will dwell upon it (cf. Jer. 31:23; Ezek. 20:40). This holiness is later said to expand throughout Jerusalem and Judah from the temple (Zech. 14:20–21).

<span id="page-685-17"></span><span id="page-685-14"></span><span id="page-685-13"></span><span id="page-685-12"></span>8:4–5 These verses picture and promise the future prosperity of Jerusalem. The elderly and children were the first to perish when cities were besieged, and were forced to work in times of hardship. In contrast, here the elderly are "of great age" and have time to "sit in the streets of Jerusalem" (v. 4), and "boys and girls" are "playing in its streets" (v. 5). These streets are not transport routes (posing danger) but open places between houses (an alternative translation is "squares"). The picture is a contrast with Lamentations, where in the immediate aftermath of the destruction of Jerusalem and exile the "streets" are associated with death (e.g., Lam. 2:11–12). Now God promises to fill them with life.

<span id="page-685-15"></span><span id="page-685-2"></span>8:6 The word translated "marvelous" can carry the idea of "improbable," "incredible," "wonderful," or "miraculous." The future prosperity promised to Jerusalem in verses 4–5 may seem too good to be true ("incredible") to the "remnant of this people" (those who had survived and returned from exile), but not to God, presumably because of his infinite power to save (cf. 4:10).

<span id="page-685-16"></span><span id="page-685-9"></span>8:7–8 God will bring his people back from the lands to which they were scattered in exile. The phrase "from the east country and from the west country" can be translated more poetically (and closer to the Hebrew), "from the land where the sun rises to where it sets," denoting all the lands to which the people had been exiled. Presumably they are saved from the coming judgment of God on the <span id="page-686-16"></span><span id="page-686-12"></span>nations (cf. 1:21; 6:7–8). God "will bring them to dwell in the midst of Jerusalem" (8:8; cf. 2:6; 7:14). Normally it is the Lord who is said to "dwell in the midst of Jerusalem," but here the phrase expresses what God will do for his people to restore relationship with them. The expression "They shall be my people, and I will be their God" is classic covenant terminology expressing the close fellowship between God and his people (cf. 13:9; Ex. 6:7; Lev. 26:12). This language is also associated with the promised new covenant (e.g., Jer. 24:7; 31:33; Ezek. 11:20). The salvation and restoration of Jerusalem are expressions of God's faithfulness (keeping his word) and his righteousness (doing what is right).

<span id="page-686-17"></span><span id="page-686-15"></span><span id="page-686-7"></span><span id="page-686-6"></span><span id="page-686-5"></span><span id="page-686-2"></span><span id="page-686-1"></span><span id="page-686-0"></span>8:9 "Let your hands be strong" is a call for courage (cf. 8:13; Judg. 7:11; 2 Sam. 2:7; Ezek. 22:14) so that they can finish building the temple (cf. also Hag. 2:4–5). It is directed toward those "who in these days have been hearing these words from the mouth of the prophets," including Zechariah and his contemporary, Haggai (cf. Zech. 7:3). This seems at first to be a discrepancy, for these prophets are said to be "present on the day that the foundation of the house of the Lord of hosts was laid," while in Ezra 3:8–13 the foundation of the temple was laid twenty years before Haggai and Zechariah began their prophetic ministries (cf. Hag. 1:1; Zech. 1:1). The best solution is to see Zechariah as referring not to the laying of the foundation of the temple twenty years earlier by Zerubbabel under the patronage of Sheshbazzar (cf. 4:9), but to the foundation-laying ceremony on the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month in the second year of Darius (cf. Hag. 2:18). This marked the resumption of the work in response to the preaching of these prophets (cf. Ezra 4:24–5:2). The people Zechariah addresses were present at this occasion.

<span id="page-686-18"></span><span id="page-686-14"></span><span id="page-686-11"></span><span id="page-686-9"></span><span id="page-686-4"></span><span id="page-686-3"></span>8:10–11 These verses contain several echoes of the book of Haggai and speak of difficult times as the people suffer the curses of the covenant for disobedience. "Before those days" (cf. Hag. 2:15) refers to the period before the preaching of the prophets. At that time there was "no wage for man or any wage for beast" (Zech. 8:10; cf. Hag. 1:11)—those who worked went unpaid. "Neither was there any safety from the foe" (Zech. 8:10; cf. Ezra 4:1–5), indicating a threat for those who traveled outside Jerusalem ("for him who went out or came in"). There was also conflict within the community, with "every man against his neighbor" (Zech. 8:10). While hypothetical, this conflict could have concerned land titles between those who were exiled and those who had stayed.

<span id="page-686-19"></span><span id="page-686-13"></span>In verse 11, God again promises a great reversal of the adverse situation of the "former days" (described in v. 10) for the "remnant of this people" (cf. v. 6; Hag. 1:12, 14; 2:2). The curse of his judgment will be removed.

<span id="page-686-20"></span><span id="page-686-10"></span><span id="page-686-8"></span>8:12–13 When God turns to his people in mercy, covenant curses will be replaced with covenant blessings (cf. Hag. 1:10). "Peace" (Hb. *shalom*) is promised with an agricultural metaphor ("a sowing of peace"). This is apt, as many of the covenant blessings refer to abundant agricultural produce. "Peace" is more than the absence of warfare; it is the full experience of God's salvation and blessing (cf. <span id="page-687-13"></span><span id="page-687-11"></span><span id="page-687-8"></span><span id="page-687-2"></span>Zech. 6:13; 8:16, 19; 9:10). Three images develop this: (1) "the vine shall give its fruit" (cf. 3:10)—it took four to five years from planting for a vine to produce a usable crop, and warfare often destroyed vineyards (e.g., Jer. 12:10); (2) "the ground shall give its produce" (cf. Deut. 28:4, 11–12); and (3) "the heavens shall give their dew"—dew formed at night and provided water for plant life to flourish. These are all signs of God's favor and come by his hand: "I will cause the remnant of this people to possess all these things"—the word "possess" can also be translated "inherit" (cf. Isa. 57:13; Ezek. 47:14).

<span id="page-687-20"></span><span id="page-687-7"></span><span id="page-687-0"></span>In the exile, God's people were under his curse, which was acknowledged "among the nations" (Zech. 8:13). Again God promises to save his people, that they "shall be a blessing" to the nations, echoing the promise to Abraham (Gen. 12:3). Reference to the "house of Judah and the house of Israel" shows a concern for the restoration and reunification of the nation, a theme seen also in Zechariah 9:1, 10, 13; 10:6.

<span id="page-687-27"></span>"Let your hands be strong" (cf. comment on 8:9) is a challenge to trust God's promises and complete the work on the temple.

<span id="page-687-21"></span><span id="page-687-19"></span><span id="page-687-18"></span><span id="page-687-10"></span><span id="page-687-9"></span>8:14–15 "For" introduces a summary of verses 1–13. In the past God was angry with their forefathers and brought the "disaster" of the destruction of Jerusalem and exile on them as punishment for their sin (v. 14; cf. 1:2, 6, 12, 15). God "did not relent"; he "showed no pity" (NIV) because they did not repent (cf. 7:11–14). The appointed seventy years ran their course (cf. 1:12). But now Jerusalem and Judah will experience the "good" things of God (8:15; cf. 1:17; Josh. 24:20; Ezek. 36:11), spilling out to the nations (Zech. 8:20–23). Because of God's promise to save and bless his people, they should not fear (v. 15) but obey (vv. 16–19).

<span id="page-687-26"></span><span id="page-687-23"></span><span id="page-687-22"></span><span id="page-687-17"></span><span id="page-687-3"></span>8:16–17 The words of the earlier prophets continue to apply (cf. 7:9–10). Zechariah provides four injunctions; the commands "Speak the truth" and "Do not devise evil in your hearts" call for honesty and integrity in personal relationships, while "Render in your gates judgments that are true and make for peace" and "Love no false oath" call for right administration of justice in the community. The "gates" were where the city elders met to hear disputes and render judgments (e.g., Deut. 21:19; 25:7; Ruth 4:1, 11; Amos 5:15). The two negative commands in Zechariah 8:17 involve things God hates (cf. 5:3–4, 8). While God wants the temple to be rebuilt, this is not an end in itself. The ethical transformation of his people is critical.

<span id="page-687-25"></span><span id="page-687-24"></span><span id="page-687-14"></span><span id="page-687-12"></span><span id="page-687-1"></span>8:18–19 The longer prophetic messenger formula in verse 18 marks the final section in the wider unit of chapters 7–8 (cf. 7:1, 4, 8; 8:1). This section returns to the original question of the delegation from Bethel concerning fasting (7:2–3).

<span id="page-687-16"></span><span id="page-687-15"></span><span id="page-687-6"></span><span id="page-687-5"></span><span id="page-687-4"></span>In addition to the fasts mentioned earlier (cf. comments on 7:3; 7:4–5), God mentions two additional fasts not referred to elsewhere in the OT. The fast of the "fourth month" is thought to commemorate the Babylonian army's breaching the walls of Jerusalem (2 Kings 25:2–4). The fast of the "tenth" month recalls the beginning of the siege against Jerusalem (2 Kings 25:1). These will all become "seasons of joy and gladness" (cf. Isa. 35:10; 51:3, 11; Jer. 31:13; 33:10–11) and <span id="page-688-6"></span>"cheerful feasts" (cf. Zech. 14:18; Isa. 33:20). Solemn fasts will be replaced by joyous feasts—celebration will replace lamentation.

<span id="page-688-14"></span><span id="page-688-12"></span>The injunction to "love truth and peace" summarizes God's concern for the social dimensions of life found throughout chapters 7–8 (cf. Zech. 7:9; 8:3, 8, 10, 12, 16) and is the opposite of that which God hates in 8:17. Hence, God's turning to Jerusalem with mercy (vv. 3, 15) involves more than turning fasting into feasting; it calls for radical ethical transformation.

<span id="page-688-18"></span><span id="page-688-17"></span><span id="page-688-15"></span><span id="page-688-11"></span><span id="page-688-10"></span>8:20–21 At the beginning of chapter 7, a delegation came from Bethel to Jerusalem to "entreat the favor of the Lord" (v. 2). This journey is now a pattern for the "inhabitants of many cities" in the future (8:20), probably a reference in the first instance to cities, like Bethel, that surrounded Jerusalem (cf. 7:7). It seems they will be caught up in the excitement of what God is doing in Jerusalem and will tell others (8:21; cf. Isa. 2:2).

<span id="page-688-19"></span><span id="page-688-7"></span><span id="page-688-3"></span>8:22 This desire to pilgrimage to Jerusalem spreads beyond Judah to "many peoples and strong nations," a reference to those from foreign nations (cf. v. 23). The powerful will recognize true power and will come to Jerusalem to "seek the Lord of hosts . . . and to entreat" his favor, seeking his mercy and salvation (cf. 2:11). The theme of the pilgrimage of nations to Jerusalem is found in earlier prophets, especially Isaiah (cf. Isa. 2:2–4; 42:1–7; 49:22–23; 60:14; 66:18–24), and is an outworking of God's promise to Abraham to bless "all the families of the earth" (Gen. 12:3; 17:4–7).

<span id="page-688-22"></span><span id="page-688-20"></span><span id="page-688-16"></span><span id="page-688-13"></span><span id="page-688-8"></span><span id="page-688-4"></span><span id="page-688-1"></span><span id="page-688-0"></span>8:23 The phrase "in those days" points to a future day of salvation (cf. 2:11; 3:10), in contrast with "these days" of 8:9 and 8:15. The ratio of ten to one speaks of a great multitude "from the nations of every tongue" (cf. Rev. 7:9). At Babel, humanity united together in opposition to God. In judgment, God confused their language and scattered them (Gen. 11:7–8). This verse envisages the reversal of Babel, as all languages and nations seek God on his terms and join together in the "cheerful feasts" (Zech. 8:19) in Jerusalem. The custom of taking "hold of the robe of a Jew" lays claim to a desired relationship or outcome (cf. Ruth 3:9; 1 Sam. 15:27). A "Jew" refers to a "Judahite," one from the tribe of Judah. Chapters 9–14 of Zechariah continue to show the crucial importance of the tribe of Judah in God's salvation plan, particularly as the tribe of the house of David and the future Davidic king ("Judah" is mentioned fourteen times in these chapters).

<span id="page-688-21"></span><span id="page-688-5"></span><span id="page-688-2"></span>The nations desire to go to Jerusalem because they have heard that "God is with you" (cf. "Immanuel" in Isa. 7:14; 8:10). This idea summarizes Zechariah's hope for God to return to dwell among his people. With God's return, the nations will turn from enemies to friends.

## *Response*

<span id="page-688-9"></span>In response to a question about the need to continue to fast in view of the temple's near completion (7:1–3), Zechariah calls the people to renewed covenant obedience. <span id="page-689-6"></span><span id="page-689-3"></span>In chapter 8, the call is issued in view of God's future salvation and blessing (vv. 1– 19) and the responsibility and privilege Judah and Israel share in God's purposes for the salvation of the nations (vv. 20–23). Israel is to reflect the character of God in their lives together, with a view to the salvation of the nations. The character of God is known from the requirements of the Torah and the words of the earlier prophets. Many of the oracles in this chapter reflect themes of chapters 1–7.

<span id="page-689-1"></span>The call to covenant obedience is a response to God's turning to his people in mercy and grace now that Jeremiah's seventy years of judgment are near completion. It is important to note the sequence here. Obedience to the law is not the people's initiative to win God's blessing as a reward for their devotion. Rather, God offers his blessing to those who respond obediently to his covenant mercy—his blessing issues from his grace. Yet obedience is required to experience fully the blessings of the covenant.29 In other words, the concern with ethics (community living in obedience to Torah) and worship (the temple service) is to be an outworking of restored relationship between God and his people as they reflect his character to the world.

<span id="page-689-7"></span><span id="page-689-0"></span>Historically, this obedience proved too difficult for the nation of Israel. But where Israel failed, God succeeded through the faithful obedience of his Son, the Lord Jesus Christ (Rom. 5:19). As Israel's representative, his obedience unto death won the full blessings of the covenant—not only for Israel but also for the nations (in line with the promises to Abraham, e.g., Gen. 12:3; 17:4–7). Jesus also fulfills and expands all that the city of Jerusalem represents: the presence and rule of God (Gal. 4:25–26; Heb. 13:14). While all this may have seemed too good to be true for the remnant (Zech. 8:5), God achieved it through his sovereign power in his Son.

<span id="page-689-13"></span><span id="page-689-12"></span><span id="page-689-10"></span><span id="page-689-9"></span><span id="page-689-8"></span><span id="page-689-5"></span><span id="page-689-4"></span><span id="page-689-2"></span>Christians now have every spiritual blessing in Christ (Eph. 1:3) and are called to new covenant obedience in view of God's grace in saving us in Christ Jesus (Eph. 2:8–10). Furthermore, like Zechariah 8, with its focus on future blessing, Christians are to live in view of the future consummation of all things (Eph. 1:3– 12). New covenant obedience also involves reflecting God's character to the world, "to put on the new self, created after the likeness of God in true righteousness and holiness" (Eph. 4:24); to "be imitators of God, as beloved children" (Eph. 5:1). For a representative survey of what this looks like under the new covenant, read Ephesians 4:17–5:20, noting Paul's similarity in many ways to the old covenant (e.g., cf. Zech. 8:16 with Eph. 4:25, and Zech. 8:17 with Eph. 5:2). Yet a marked difference to Zechariah's day is that Christians now have God's resurrection power at work within them (Eph. 1:19–20).

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-691-2"></span>Zechariah 9–14 consists of two prophetic oracles dramatically portraying God's return to his people in Jerusalem. His return is depicted with many expressions and images drawn from Israel's prior history. The first prophetic oracle, in chapters 9–11, presents God's subduing enemy nations and their kings (9:1–11:3) and explains how the nation wound up in the situation they were in (11:4–17).

<span id="page-691-5"></span><span id="page-691-4"></span><span id="page-691-3"></span><span id="page-691-1"></span><span id="page-691-0"></span>The broad outline for the Lord's return is given in chapter 9, where God's coming will reclaim the land (vv. 1–8), through his king (vv. 9–10), for his people (vv. 11–17). There are at least three theories for the particular cities mentioned in verses 1–8. First, some argue they correlate to a military campaign, such as that of Alexander the Great in the fourth century BC, but the details do not match exactly. However, the broad movement from north to south does mirror his and earlier campaigns. A second view understands the cities to designate the ideal land of Israel. There is evidence that King David incorporated many of these cities into his empire, and that some paid him tribute. Furthermore, while these cities existed during Zechariah's time, they did not particularly threaten Judah. In referring to them, it seems Zechariah is drawing on Israel's past history to portray the future

<span id="page-692-3"></span>reclamation of the Israelite kingdom. A third view notes that earlier prophets prophesied the downfall of many of these cities before Israel's restoration would take place (e.g., Jeremiah 25; Ezekiel 26–28; Amos 1). On this view, Zechariah is simply restating earlier prophecies awaiting fulfillment. It is possible that elements of all three views may be part of the rationale for mentioning these particular cities.

- V. First Oracle (9:1–11:17)
	- A. The Lord's Return to Jerusalem (9:1–17)

		- 2. The Restored King (9:9–10)
		- 3. The Restored People (9:11–17)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-692-4"></span>9:1 "The oracle of the word of the Lord" can also be translated "An oracle. The word of the Lord." In that case, "an oracle" would serve as a heading to remind the reader and hearer that what follows is God's word.30 As a description, it indicates a prophecy renewing earlier prophecy, claiming it is still in effect and awaits fulfillment.31

<span id="page-692-6"></span><span id="page-692-5"></span>"The word of the Lord is against" may indicate that the prophecies of the earlier prophets against the cities and regions mentioned in verses 1–7 still stand. However, the "land of Hadrach" is not otherwise mentioned in the OT. It is probably land of the city of Hatarikka, known from Assyrian sources, where it is mentioned along with "Hamath" (cf. v. 2). This would locate it on the border of Damascus, the capital of Syria (Aram), to the north of Israel. Earlier prophecies against Damascus include Isaiah 17:1–9; Jeremiah 49:23–27; and Amos 1:3–5. Historically, King David subdued Damascus, which paid him tribute. He also set up garrisons in Damascus and established it as an administrative center for several northern districts (2 Sam. 8:6–8).

<span id="page-692-2"></span><span id="page-692-1"></span><span id="page-692-0"></span>The phrase "For the Lord has an eye on mankind and on all the tribes of Israel" is difficult to translate on account of the poetic nature of the Hebrew. An alternative translation is, "For to the Lord belongs the eye of man and all the tribes of Israel." In that case it would seem to echo Isaiah 17:7 (also a prophecy against Damascus), which says, "In that day man will look to his Maker, and his eyes will look on the Holy One of Israel." In the context of Isaiah, "man" refers to the people of the nations who will turn from their idols and acknowledge the Lord as their cities come under his judgment. This fits the context of Zechariah well, where the judgment of the nations results in their turning their eyes to Israel's God, along with "all the tribes of Israel." Referring to Israel in this way seems to envision a reunification of the tribes as in the time of David and Solomon (cf. 9:10–13; 10:6).

<span id="page-692-7"></span><sup>30</sup> The Hebrew of "oracle" is *massa'* and also appears in 12:1 (translated "burden") and Malachi 1:1 (translated "oracle").

<sup>31</sup> See further M. J. Boda, "Freeing the Burden of Prophecy: *Massa* and the Legitimacy of Prophecy in Zech 9–14," *Bib* 87 (2006): 338–357.

<span id="page-693-16"></span><span id="page-693-6"></span>9:2–4 "Hamath" is either a city or a district located between Hadrach and Damascus. It was hostile to Israel until David subdued it (2 Sam. 8:9–10); Solomon later controlled it (2 Chron. 8:4).

<span id="page-693-11"></span><span id="page-693-8"></span>Moving westward to the coast, "Tyre and Sidon" were trade ports of great wealth and security. The description of them as "wise" refers to their skill or shrewdness, probably in trade, rather than to fear of the Lord (cf. Ezek. 28:3–5). Tyre's "rampart" refers to a breakwater built as fortification against invasion. Tyre's wealth is captured in the description "heaped up silver like dust, and fine gold like the mud of the streets." While Tyre and Sidon were never incorporated into Israel, the king of Tyre helped build palaces for David and Solomon (2 Sam. 5:11; 1 Kings 9:11). In Ezekiel's vision of the idealized land, Tyre falls into Manasseh's territory and Sidon into Naphtali's (Ezek. 48:3–4).

<span id="page-693-14"></span><span id="page-693-12"></span><span id="page-693-10"></span><span id="page-693-9"></span><span id="page-693-7"></span><span id="page-693-4"></span>There are also several earlier prophetic oracles against these cities (Isaiah 23; Jer. 25:22; Ezekiel 26–28; Joel 3:4–8). Zechariah reaffirms that God will judge these cities in the northern regions (9:4; cf. 6:1–8). The word "power" (9:4) can also be translated as "army," perhaps alluding to the striking down of Pharaoh's army in the exodus (Ex. 14:28; 15:21). Destruction by fire was also common in divine warfare (cf. Amos 1:9–10).

<span id="page-693-18"></span><span id="page-693-17"></span><span id="page-693-13"></span><span id="page-693-5"></span><span id="page-693-2"></span><span id="page-693-1"></span>9:5–7 Moving south, God mentions four of the five cities associated with the Philistines (Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, Ashdod).32 These cities defined part of the borders of the territory of Judah (Josh. 15:11, 45–46), but Israel did not subdue them until David's time (2 Sam. 5:17–25; 21:15–22). Jeremiah 47:4 shows that Tyre and Sidon supported the Philistines, hence the judgment of Tyre causes these cities great fear and anguish (Zech. 9:5). God's judgment will fall on these cities, too, with Gaza's king perishing and Ashkelon losing its inhabitants. The "mixed people" (v. 6) seems to refer to people born from parents of different nations—a people who has lost any distinct national identity. God will "cut off the pride of Philistia" (v. 6), a summary of his judgment on these cities' being self-reliant ("pride") and opposed to God.

<span id="page-693-19"></span><span id="page-693-0"></span>Yet judgment is not the final word. God will also remove what is unclean: ". . . its blood from its mouth and its abominations from between its teeth." These images presumably refer to the Philistine practices of eating meat with its lifeblood still in it and eating food associated with idolatry. These are elsewhere forbidden both directly and indirectly by God (e.g., Gen. 9:4; Lev. 17:10–14; Deut. 12:23, 31). God will incorporate "a remnant" of the Philistines (Zech. 9:7) into his people, as he did with the Jebusites, inhabitants of Jerusalem before David captured it. Rather than being destroyed, the Jebusites were absorbed into Judah (2 Sam. 5:6–9; 24:18–24). Zechariah envisages God judging and saving the nations (cf. Zech. 8:22–23).

<span id="page-693-20"></span><span id="page-693-15"></span><span id="page-693-3"></span>9:8 After judging the nations on the borders of the land, God will return to "encamp" at his "house" (or "temple") and protect his people from invaders and

<sup>32</sup> The fifth city of the Philistine pentapolis was Gath. These cities posed their greatest threat to Israel in the twelfth and eleventh centuries.

<span id="page-694-15"></span>oppressors (cf. 7:14). This also brings King David to mind, as it was only in his time that God "camped" in the tabernacle tent in Jerusalem. "Now I see with my own eyes" could simply mean God is watching over his people, or that he sees the plight of his people and is about to act in their favor (as in Ex. 2:25). Reference to "eyes" also links back to the "eye" in verse 1.

<span id="page-694-18"></span><span id="page-694-17"></span><span id="page-694-12"></span><span id="page-694-10"></span><span id="page-694-9"></span><span id="page-694-8"></span><span id="page-694-7"></span><span id="page-694-5"></span><span id="page-694-2"></span><span id="page-694-1"></span>9:9–10 With the return of the Lord to Jerusalem, the inhabitants of Jerusalem are exhorted to "rejoice greatly" and "shout aloud" to welcome their king (cf. 2:10; Zeph. 3:14). The expressions "daughter of Zion" and "daughter of Jerusalem" refer poetically to the inhabitants of Jerusalem (cf. comment on Zech. 2:7). The expression "your king" suggests it is the Davidic king, expected by earlier prophets, who will come (cf. 3:8; 6:12). Unlike many previous kings, this king will be "righteous" (cf. Jer. 23:5). Second, this king is said to have "salvation." The Hebrew can also be translated with the sense that the king has been "saved" (cf. Deut. 33:29; Ps. 33:16–17). In this case, the future king has been saved by God in the context of God's defeat of the nations (Zech. 9:1–8) and he now comes to the royal city of Jerusalem. Third, the king is "humble" (alternatively, the Hebrew can be translated "afflicted"; cf. Isa. 53:4, 7, where Isaiah's suffering servant is "afflicted" not for his own sins, like David, but for the sins of others). The background to Zechariah's picture seems to be the suffering David of 2 Samuel and the Psalms, along with the suffering servant of Isaiah. These have been woven together in Zechariah's portrait of the future king here and throughout chapters 9–14.33 This explains the fourth description of the king as "mounted on a donkey." During David's exile from Jerusalem, when he was nearly defeated by his enemies, he rode a donkey (cf. 2 Sam. 16:2).34 God saved David in battle and delivered him back to Jerusalem as king. In combining these images, Zechariah speaks of the future righteous Davidic king of prophetic expectation who, having been saved by God from the affliction of exile, will return to Jerusalem on a donkey and will "speak peace to the nations" (Zech. 9:10; cf. the "peace" of 6:13). The forgiveness of sin associated with Isaiah's servant is the focus of the king's work in Zechariah 12:10–13:1 (cf. 3:9).

<span id="page-694-19"></span><span id="page-694-16"></span><span id="page-694-14"></span><span id="page-694-13"></span><span id="page-694-6"></span><span id="page-694-4"></span><span id="page-694-3"></span>The "chariot" and "war horse" were key weapons of warfare for Israel and Judah in the ninth and eighth centuries. God says he will "cut off" or destroy these weapons, along with the "battle bow" (cf. Isa. 2:4). Mentioning Ephraim (the northern kingdom of Israel) and Jerusalem (cf. Zech. 9:13) hints at a reunified kingdom, as under David (cf. 2 Sam. 2:10–11; 5:1–5). The coming king "shall speak peace to the nations"—not just the absence of war, but the peace of salvation (pictured in Zech. 9:16–17). The king's rule will extend "from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth" (v. 10), an expression capturing his universal reign over all nations (cf. Gen. 49:10–11; Ps. 72:8).

<span id="page-694-20"></span><span id="page-694-11"></span><span id="page-694-0"></span><sup>33</sup> See further M. R. Stead, "Suffering Servant, Suffering David, and Stricken Shepherd," in M. R. Stead, ed., *Christ Died for Our Sins: Essays on the Atonement* (Canberra: Barton, 2013), 62–83.

<sup>34</sup> The expression "on a colt, the foal of a donkey" can also be translated "on a donkey, namely a purebred jackass," where a "jackass" is a male donkey. See further K. C. Way, *Donkeys in the Biblical World: Ceremony and Symbol* (Winona Lake, IN: Eisenbrauns, 2011), 163.

<span id="page-695-21"></span><span id="page-695-19"></span><span id="page-695-5"></span>9:11–12 The Lord continues to address his people ("you" refers to "daughter of Zion" and "daughter of Jerusalem" in v. 9), outlining further elements of his salvation. These will come on account of the "blood of my covenant with you." The covenant with Israel at Sinai was ratified with blood, indicating God's commitment to his people (cf. Ex. 24:8). This covenant commitment means the "prisoners" will be set "free from the waterless pit," like Joseph (Gen. 37:24) and Jeremiah (Jer. 38:6). This image may refer specifically to those still living in foreign lands, or it may be a more general reference to the end of exile. To "set your prisoners free" also echoes the exodus (Ex. 5:1)—the end of exile is a new exodus.

<span id="page-695-13"></span><span id="page-695-12"></span><span id="page-695-8"></span><span id="page-695-2"></span><span id="page-695-0"></span>Once set free, the prisoners are to "return to your stronghold," best understood as Jerusalem (cf. Zech. 2:7). They are "prisoners *of hope*" because of the promises of restoration after exile built into the national covenant (cf. Deut. 30:1–6). There is wordplay in the Hebrew: when the people "return" (*shub*), God "will restore" (*'ashib*) "double" (as in Zech. 1:3—"Return to me . . . and I will return to you."). The double restoration echoes Isaiah 61:1–7 (cf. Isa. 40:2), where prisoners are set free and given a double portion in the land. Also behind this idea may be the double restoration after "exile" in the cases of Joseph (Gen. 48:22) and Job (Job 42:10).

<span id="page-695-22"></span><span id="page-695-20"></span><span id="page-695-10"></span><span id="page-695-1"></span>9:13 The means to the "peace" in verse 10 is God's using his people as weapons to overthrow opposition. God will use Judah as his "bow" and Ephraim (the northern kingdom of Israel) as his "arrow"; at the end of the verse they are likened to a "warrior's sword." Reference to Judah and Ephraim points to a reunited kingdom of Israel (cf. v. 1; 10:6–7).

<span id="page-695-16"></span><span id="page-695-15"></span>While some take the reference to "Greece" to indicate that chapters 9–14 come from a much later time, this is unnecessary. At the beginning of the fifth century BC, the Greeks had proved to be quite troublesome to the Persians. To assert God's defeat of the Greeks is a bold claim of his power. In addition, the Philistines had sold the people of Jerusalem and Judah to the Greeks (cf. Joel 3:4–6), and this prophecy envisages their being freed and returned.

<span id="page-695-23"></span><span id="page-695-14"></span><span id="page-695-11"></span><span id="page-695-3"></span>9:14–15 Like God's salvation in the exodus (Ex. 15:1–21), the Lord will appear as a warrior to save his people. He will come as an army on the "march," shooting "his arrow" and sounding "the trumpet" as part of the battle (Zech. 9:14; cf. 6:1–8; 9:1–8). The "whirlwinds of the south" may also echo exodus themes, along with the "lightning" and "trumpet," associated with God's appearance at Sinai (Ex. 19:16).

<span id="page-695-18"></span><span id="page-695-17"></span><span id="page-695-9"></span><span id="page-695-7"></span><span id="page-695-6"></span><span id="page-695-4"></span>In the battle, the Lord will "protect," or shield, his people, who "shall devour, and tread down the sling stones" (Zech. 9:15). This is a poetic way of picturing the enemies of God's people being obliterated in battle. The sound of the battle will be like the "roar" of those "drunk with wine," and the sight of it like blood at a sacrifice: "full like a bowl, drenched like the corners of the altar" (cf. Ex. 29:13; Lev. 4:7, 17, 25). Just as the foreign nations consumed blood as part of their idolatrous worship (Zech. 9:7), so their blood will be consumed by the Israelites (metaphorically speaking) in battle. Other prophets also compare God's victory over his enemies to a sacrifice (e.g., Isa. 34:6; Jer. 46:10; Ezek. 39:17–20; Zeph. 1:7).

<span id="page-696-17"></span><span id="page-696-16"></span><span id="page-696-14"></span><span id="page-696-13"></span><span id="page-696-9"></span>9:16–17 God will not only fight for and protect his people (vv. 14–15), he will also save and greatly bless them. The phrase "on that day" refers to the future day of salvation (cf. "those days" in 8:23). The Lord is called "their God," language associated with the covenant relationship (cf. 9:11; 10:6; 13:9). The people are called "the flock," introducing the shepherd imagery prominent in chapters 10–13 portraying God's relationship with Israel, and Israel's leadership. The people are also likened to "jewels of a crown" that "shall shine on his land"—precious stones in the ephod and breastplate of the high priest represented the people of Israel (Ex. 28:12, 21). Here God's people will adorn the land as jewels. It is a fitting image for God's "treasured possession" (cf. Ex. 19:5; Mal. 3:17).

<span id="page-696-8"></span><span id="page-696-5"></span><span id="page-696-2"></span><span id="page-696-1"></span><span id="page-696-0"></span>The glorious nature of this day results in the exclamation, "How great is his goodness, and how great his beauty!"35 This day of God's salvation will also bring the covenant blessings of "grain" and "new wine" (cf. Deut. 33:28; Joel 2:19; Amos 9:13). This produce will cause young men and women to "flourish" (or "bear fruit"; e.g., Ps. 92:14), perhaps implying offspring. Just as God had saved his people in the exodus, defeating their enemies and in time establishing them in the land under King David, so he will do it again, saving and establishing his people in the land under the one who will inherit David's throne.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-696-15"></span><span id="page-696-12"></span><span id="page-696-10"></span><span id="page-696-7"></span><span id="page-696-6"></span><span id="page-696-3"></span>Zechariah 9 envisages God's coming to reclaim the land once possessed by King David (vv. 1–8). He will do this for and through his future king (vv. 9–13) and for and through his people (vv. 14–17). The chapter draws on many episodes and prophecies from Israel's past to portray the future salvation of God's people. At the center is a portrait of a future king, a portrait created as a mosaic from different OT passages, particularly the suffering David of 2 Samuel and the Psalms, and Isaiah's servant. Like the hope of earlier prophets, the future king (or Messiah) will be righteous (Isa. 9:7; 11:4–5; 16:5; Jer. 23:5–6; 33:15–16). While the pride and wisdom of the nations will be reduced to nothing (Zech. 9:1–8), there is the opposite conjunction of power and weakness in the presentation of the future king: he is not a mighty warrior king who trusts in his own strength but a king who is saved by God. Like Isaiah's servant, he is afflicted; and like David in exile, he rides not on a warhorse but on a donkey. As in the prayer for David's son in Psalm 72:8, the future king will have a universal rule given to him by God (Zech. 9:10).

<span id="page-696-21"></span><span id="page-696-19"></span><span id="page-696-18"></span><span id="page-696-11"></span><span id="page-696-4"></span>All four Gospel writers record that Jesus acquired and rode a donkey into Jerusalem, claiming to be this king (Matt. 21:1–11; Mark 11:1–11; Luke 19:28–38; John 12:12–19). His righteousness and his affliction to the point of death as a servant (cf. Phil. 2:6–11) meant God "saved" him and vindicated him as Lord of all in his resurrection. Now through his gospel, Jesus proclaims "peace to the nations" (Zech. 9:10; cf. Eph. 2:14–18; Col. 1:20). The conjunction of power and weakness

<span id="page-696-20"></span><sup>35</sup> The ESV translates this exclamation to refer to the Lord. It possibly refers to the people ("How attractive and how beautiful they will be"; NIV) or to the future day of salvation ("How good it is and how beautiful it is"; AT).

seen in Messiah Jesus is the pattern for Christian ministry in the power of the gospel, a "treasure in jars of clay, to show that the surpassing power belongs to God and not to us" (2 Cor. 4:7).

<span id="page-697-5"></span><span id="page-697-2"></span><span id="page-697-0"></span>The theme of the salvation of foreign nations seen at the end of Zechariah 8 continues into this part of the book, where a "remnant" from the nations will be incorporated into God's people as the Jebusites were in David's day (9:7). There is great hope here, for if God can save the idolatrous and unclean Philistines, he can presumably save anyone from the nations who takes up the Messiah's offer of peace (v. 10).

<span id="page-697-3"></span><span id="page-697-1"></span>The picture of a "warrior God" seen in this chapter and elsewhere in chapters 9–14 is understandably not popular today, given the conflict and war around our world. Yet the reality is that force is often needed to stop violence, and the point of the image is that ultimately God will bring warfare to an end. "By testifying that God is the Divine Warrior, the Bible is saying that the ultimate destruction of evil belongs to him."36 This will finally occur when Jesus returns, not on a donkey but on a white horse, striking down all who refuse to worship him (Rev. 19:11–21).

<span id="page-697-8"></span><span id="page-697-7"></span><span id="page-697-6"></span>While God's people are used as weapons in this passage, the NT explains that for followers of Jesus, "The weapons of our warfare are not of the flesh" (2 Cor. 10:4), that is, not the weapons armies use. Instead, they are spiritual weapons, including the "belt of truth . . . breastplate of righteousness . . . [shoes of] the gospel of peace . . . shield of faith . . . helmet of salvation, and . . . sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God . . . with all prayer and supplication" (Eph. 6:14–18).

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-699-11"></span>The focus of chapters 10–11 is leadership and its consequences for God's people. The predominant leadership image in these chapters is the shepherd. Indeed, this section of Zechariah provides another perspective on the battle portrayed in chapter 9—from the viewpoint of leadership.

The main idea of 10:1–11:3 is that the Lord will save his people from the nations and bring them back to the land. God will do this by raising up new leadership for his people and by judging foreign oppressors.

<span id="page-699-16"></span><span id="page-699-15"></span><span id="page-699-14"></span><span id="page-699-12"></span>Rather than being led by false mediums, the people are to call on the Lord to give them rain for their crops (10:1–2). God promises to punish their current foreign leaders and to raise up new leadership in their place (vv. 3–4). These new leaders will defeat their foe in battle (v. 5). God promises to save and bring back those from his people who remain scattered among the nations (vv. 6–11) so that they will reflect his character (v. 12). Like 9:11–17, this passage portrays God's salvation as a new exodus. God's intention to raise up new leadership and reunite his people will have devastating consequences for oppressive foreign leaders (11:1–3).

#### <span id="page-699-17"></span><span id="page-699-10"></span>*Section Outline*

V.B. The Lord Will Care for Judah (10:1–11:3)

- 1. Afflicted for Lack of a Shepherd (10:1–2)
- 2. God Will Raise Up a New Leadership to Save His People (10:3–12)
- 3. Foreign Shepherds Will Be Judged (11:1–3)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-699-13"></span><span id="page-699-9"></span><span id="page-699-6"></span><span id="page-699-4"></span><span id="page-699-0"></span>10:1–2 The Lord, not the false gods of the nations (v. 2), controls the weather, so the people are to pray to him for rain (cf. Pss. 65:9; 68:9; 135:7). The "season of the spring rain" is considered to be March/April. These rains were crucial for crops and survival in the land. In times of drought (cf. Hag. 1:10–11), the temptation would be to turn to "household gods" or "diviners" (Zech. 10:2). The "household gods" (*teraphim*) were idols used to determine the future (e.g., Gen. 31:19, 34; 1 Sam. 19:13, 16). Similarly, "diviners" sought to predict the future (e.g., Judg. 17:5; 18:14–20) and were consulted to determine the best time for planting crops. Yet these practices deceive—the household gods "utter nonsense" (or "speak evil") and the diviners "see lies"; their dreams are "false" and "give empty consolation." Moreover, these practices are forbidden in Israel's law (cf. Deut. 5:8–9; 18:9–14). Adopting them in the past led to exile and removal of the kings of Israel and Judah. Hence Zechariah warns against them.

<span id="page-699-8"></span><span id="page-699-7"></span><span id="page-699-5"></span><span id="page-699-3"></span><span id="page-699-2"></span><span id="page-699-1"></span>"Shepherd" refers metaphorically to a leader, particularly a king. It was a wellunderstood image, as shepherding was a central part of Israel's economy. Elsewhere the Lord is the shepherd of his people, his "flock" (e.g., Gen. 49:24; Ps. 23:1; cf. Zech. 9:16). Shepherding involves guiding (Ps. 77:20), protecting (Ps. 78:52), saving (Ezek. 34:22), gathering (Isa. 40:11), and nourishing (Jer. 50:19). Human leaders, such as Moses and David, are also called shepherds (Num. 12:7; Ps. 78:70–72). Since <span id="page-700-6"></span>the people did not have a human king in the postexilic period, the people were "afflicted for lack of a shepherd" (cf. Isa. 53:6; Jer. 50:6–7; Ezek. 34:5).

<span id="page-700-19"></span><span id="page-700-14"></span><span id="page-700-4"></span>10:3 God is angry with the shepherds and announces punishment on them ("leaders"). Elsewhere the word translated "leaders" (or "male goats") refers to foreign kings (e.g., Isa. 14:9; Ezek. 39:18). It probably refers here to those same rulers, whose judgment is announced in Zechariah 11:1–3. Since the people are said to lack a shepherd of their own (10:2), these shepherds and leaders are best understood to refer to the present foreign rulers of God's people.

<span id="page-700-13"></span><span id="page-700-12"></span><span id="page-700-8"></span>On the title "Lord of hosts," cf. comment on 1:2–6a. It underscores God's might as king and gives assurance he will punish these leaders and save his people (cf. 9:16), particularly the "house of Judah," whom he "will make . . . like his majestic steed in battle." The "steed" (or "battle horse") is a magnificent animal with great speed, energy, and power. In battle it could reach speeds of over 40 miles (64 km) per hour and would trample enemy troops (cf. 10:5).

<span id="page-700-17"></span><span id="page-700-16"></span><span id="page-700-5"></span>10:4–5 God will raise up alternate leadership for his people. Three leadership metaphors are used to convey the strength and stability they will provide for the houses of Judah and Joseph (cf. v. 6). The first is "cornerstone," a crucial stone contributing to the strength and stability of a building (cf. Isa. 28:16). This image of leadership is also found in Judges 20:2; 1 Samuel 14:38; and Isaiah 19:13. The image is apt because of the support it will be to the *house* of Judah and *house* of Joseph (Zech. 10:6).

<span id="page-700-18"></span><span id="page-700-2"></span><span id="page-700-1"></span>The second leadership image is "tent peg," an image found also in Isaiah 22:22–25. Pegs were used to secure the tabernacle tent (Ex. 27:19; Num. 3:37). In Hebrew thought, "tent" is somewhat interchangeable with "house," and so this leadership image is also to be understood as providing support to the houses of Judah and Joseph (called the "tents of Judah" in Zech. 12:7 and "tents of Joseph" in Ps. 78:67).

<span id="page-700-20"></span><span id="page-700-11"></span><span id="page-700-3"></span>The third image is "battle bow." This is not used as a leadership image elsewhere in the OT, although Judah is described as the Lord's bow in Zechariah 9:13. As an image of leadership, it conveys military strength and connects with the battle these leaders will fight in 10:5.

<span id="page-700-0"></span>All these leaders are said to come "from him," but it is uncertain to whom this refers. The Hebrew syntax suggests it is the Lord himself who will provide these leaders.37 On the other hand, elsewhere in the OT the nation's leadership, particularly its king, is said to come from Judah (e.g., Gen. 49:10). While both are true, on balance the former seems more likely here. Some scholars understand these images to all refer to the future Davidic king (referred to in Zech. 9:9). However, the plurality of rulers seen in the phrase "every ruler—all of them together" weighs against this. Yet the king is probably to be included in this group (cf. Jer. 23:3–6).38

<span id="page-700-15"></span><span id="page-700-10"></span><span id="page-700-7"></span><sup>37</sup> In verse 3, "the house of Judah" is a plural entity ("them"), rather than singular ("him").

<span id="page-700-9"></span><sup>38</sup> The word translated "ruler" is elsewhere mostly translated negatively as "tyrant" or "oppressor" (e.g., Zech. 9:8). However, Wolters, *Zechariah*, 324, argues it can simply mean "ruler" without negative connotations.

<span id="page-701-18"></span><span id="page-701-16"></span>It is also uncertain whether "they" (Zech. 10:5) refers to the leaders of verse 4. If the image of trampling the enemies is connected to the activities of the "majestic steed in battle" (v. 3), then "they" refers to the house of Judah. It may be significant that the word translated "mighty men" (*gibborim*) in verse 5 is the same word translated "mighty warrior" (*gibbor*) in verse 7, where it clearly refers to "Ephraim." This would support seeing "they" in verse 5 as the house of Judah, with the wider passage indicating that all Israel (Judah and Ephraim) will be raised up to fight (cf. 9:13). Significantly, in battle, "as many warriors were killed by the crushing blows of horses' hooves landing on vital body parts as by the random wounds of arrows and spears piercing the flesh."39 The subjects of 10:5 will fight alongside the presence of the Lord, ensuring their victory (cf. 9:14–16). They "shall put to shame the riders on horses"—proud enemies of the house of Judah (including the foreign shepherds and leaders of 10:3) will be overwhelmed.

<span id="page-701-17"></span><span id="page-701-15"></span><span id="page-701-13"></span><span id="page-701-12"></span><span id="page-701-10"></span><span id="page-701-6"></span>10:6–7 God will "strengthen the house of Judah" and "save the house of Joseph." "House of Joseph" is another name for the northern tribes (also called "Ephraim" in v. 7), devastated by the Assyrians in 722 BC as judgment for their sin (cf. 2 Kings 17). Here God promises to save and reunite the northern and southern kingdoms as one nation (cf. Zech. 9:1, 13). In his "compassion" the Lord will "bring them back" to the land—a key theme of chapters 1–8 (cf. 2:7; 6:15; 8:7); the judgment of exile will be over (cf. Deut. 30:1–10). The phrase "I am the Lord their God" echoes the typical covenant language found in Zechariah 8:8 and promises restoration of relationship. In addition, prayers will again be heard: "I will answer them" (cf. 7:13; 13:9).

<span id="page-701-11"></span><span id="page-701-9"></span><span id="page-701-8"></span><span id="page-701-7"></span><span id="page-701-4"></span>Like the house of Judah, which "shall be like mighty men" (10:5), so "Ephraim shall become like a mighty warrior" (v. 7; cf. 9:13). God's commitment to strengthen and save all his people will result in joyful celebration (cf. 9:9). The benefits of this salvation will be appreciated by their children, who will also "rejoice in the Lord"—an Israelite ideal (cf. Deut. 6:2, 7).

<span id="page-701-20"></span><span id="page-701-19"></span><span id="page-701-14"></span><span id="page-701-2"></span><span id="page-701-1"></span>10:8–10 The promise of the Lord in verse 6 to bring his people back from exile is developed in the rest of the chapter (these verses echo Moses' prophecy of return in Deut. 30:1–10). God will "whistle for them" (Zech. 10:8), a sound made to gather sheep (cf. Judg. 5:16). He will "gather" the wandering flock (cf. Zech. 10:2) because he has "redeemed them" (cf. Deut. 7:8). While not explicit here, Zechariah 12–14 indicates this redemption is achieved through the death of the future Davidic king (cf. 9:9). The exiles of the northern and southern kingdoms of Israel had devastated their populations; now the Lord promises, "They shall be as many as they were before" (10:8; cf. Deut. 30:5; Jer. 23:3; Ezek. 36:11).

<span id="page-701-21"></span><span id="page-701-5"></span><span id="page-701-3"></span>God "scattered them among the nations" (Zech. 10:9), a reference to their exiles. Yet from exile "they shall remember me"—they will call to mind the reality of God and seek to return to his covenant requirements (cf. Deut. 30:1–2). This will result in life and blessing for the exiles and their children (cf. Gen. 50:23).

<span id="page-701-0"></span><sup>39</sup> Deborah O'Daniel Cantrell, *The Horsemen of Israel: Horses and Chariotry in Monarchic Israel (Ninth–Eighth Centuries B.C.E.)*, HACL 1 (Winona Lake, IN: Eisenbrauns, 2011), 29, cf. 136–141.

<span id="page-702-15"></span><span id="page-702-4"></span><span id="page-702-3"></span>God will bring them back from "the land of Egypt" and "Assyria" (Zech. 10:10). These were traditional enemies of God's people and countries to which the Ephraimites were exiled. Reference to Egypt also brings to mind God's redemption and deliverance in the exodus. God will bring them "to the land of Gilead and to Lebanon." "Gilead" is the region of Transjordanian territory through which Moses first approached the Promised Land from Egypt (Deut. 3:10, 12–13, 15) and may here refer to the home of the exiles returning from Egypt. "Lebanon" is the northernmost extent of the Promised Land (Deut. 11:24; 1 Kings 9:19), to which exiles would arrive from Assyria. The people will fill these lands "till there is no room for them." Historically these regions had been relatively empty, and filling them speaks of God's great blessing. There may also be irony, because in Joshua 17, when the Promised Land was allocated, the people of Joseph (Ephraim and Manasseh) complained there was not enough land for them, so they were given a double allotment. Here their blessing will be so great that they will encounter this problem again.

<span id="page-702-16"></span><span id="page-702-6"></span><span id="page-702-1"></span>10:11–12 The exodus imagery continues as God will "pass through the sea of troubles" (v. 11) and "strike down the waves of the sea," as he had done with the Egyptian army, bringing destruction (Ex. 14:27–28). This time, however, it will be "the Nile" rather than the Red Sea. God promises to humble the proud and powerful nations like Assyria and Egypt (Zech. 10:11; cf. Deut. 30:7). The "scepter" was a symbol of rule and power (cf. Gen. 49:10): Egypt's oppressive power will be removed.

<span id="page-702-14"></span><span id="page-702-5"></span><span id="page-702-0"></span>God promises to strengthen his people (Zech. 10:12; cf. v. 6), and "They shall walk in his name." This is a unique expression in the OT. Elsewhere, God's name represents his character and is associated with the conduct of his people (e.g., Ex. 20:7; Mal. 1:11). Restored relationship with the Lord will reshape their lives so that they reflect his character to the world (cf. Zech. 9:16–17).

<span id="page-702-17"></span><span id="page-702-13"></span><span id="page-702-12"></span><span id="page-702-8"></span><span id="page-702-2"></span>11:1–3 Kings are often portrayed in the OT as mighty trees (e.g., 2 Kings 14:9; Dan. 4:10–27). Here foreign kings or rulers are represented as "cedars" (Zech. 11:1), "cypress" (v. 2), and "oaks" (v. 2). In this taunt song, God announces his judgment on the kings or rulers of foreign nations who will be devoured by fire, felled, and ruined, so that God's people might return to the land. This is another dramatic presentation of the content of chapter 10.

<span id="page-702-11"></span><span id="page-702-7"></span>"Lebanon" (11:1; cf. 10:10) was known for its magnificent cedars and cypresses, used in the construction of the temple and the king's palace in Jerusalem (1 Kings 5:6; 7:2). "Bashan" (Zech. 11:2) had a reputation for its mighty oaks (Isa. 2:13; Ezek. 27:6) and was known for its idolatry (Amos 4:1). In the earlier prophets, Lebanon and Bashan epitomized pride (e.g., Isa. 2:12–13). Here their rulers will be destroyed by the Lord.

<span id="page-702-18"></span><span id="page-702-10"></span><span id="page-702-9"></span>Mixing metaphors, these "shepherds" of the foreign nations (Zech. 11:3; cf. 10:3) are like "lions" ravaging and feeding on God's people (cf. Jer. 25:36–38). They will "wail" and "roar" as God saves and takes away those they had oppressed

and feasted on—his people. The "thicket of the Jordan" refers to fertile territory in Israel on the lower parts of the Jordan River and seems to be another reference to the ruin of Judah's Persian overlords, who have prospered at the expense of God's people. Alternatively, because of its location in the land, it might refer to Jewish leadership in cahoots with oppressive foreign powers.

### *Response*

<span id="page-703-1"></span>Like chapter 9, this passage portrays the future battle to establish God's kingdom, now from the perspective of the leadership of God's people. God promises to raise up new leadership for his people to fight for them and save them from the nations. He also promises to save those who were exiled and bring them back to the land and prosper them, removing oppressive foreign rulers. While a future Davidic king is not directly mentioned in chapter 10, when read against the expectation of chapter 9 the future king is probably to be understood as part of the leadership God will raise up to save his people (Zech. 10:4; cf. Jer. 23:3–6).

<span id="page-703-8"></span><span id="page-703-6"></span><span id="page-703-4"></span><span id="page-703-3"></span><span id="page-703-2"></span><span id="page-703-0"></span>From the perspective of the NT, the promised battle brings salvation (Zech. 10:6), expresses God's compassion (v. 6), causes joy for those who are saved (v. 7), brings the exiles home (vv. 6, 8–10), and is the supreme act of redemption, bringing about a new exodus (vv. 8, 11). It must be understood as the spiritual battle Jesus won on the cross to bring salvation. Jesus called himself the "good shepherd" who laid down his life for the sheep (John 10:10–15). Jesus also gave his disciples authority to fight on his behalf—not against flesh and blood but against the "spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly places" (cf. Eph. 6:12). This battle climaxed in Jesus' death and resurrection but will continue to be engaged by the church until he returns. The restoration of the divided kingdom of Israel (Judah and Joseph), which this passage speaks of, is also brought about by Jesus. The book of Acts shows that the gospel is believed first in Jerusalem (the capital of Judah or "Judea"), then Samaria (the old capital of the northern kingdom), and, once Israel is reunited, the gospel then goes "to the end of the earth" (cf. Acts 1:8).

<span id="page-703-7"></span><span id="page-703-5"></span>While many of Israel's kings lead the people to follow the religious practices of the nations (including household gods and divination), this passage calls God's people to have nothing to do with these, but rather to recognize that God controls all things and to pray to him. Christians likewise are to depend on God in prayer for their daily provision (Matt. 6:11; Phil. 4:6).

Behold, I will cause each of them to fall into the hand of his neighbor, and each into the hand of his king, and they shall crush the land, and I will deliver none from their hand."

And I tended the sheep. **<sup>8</sup>** In one month I destroyed the three shepherds. And they weighed out as my wages thirty pieces of silver. **13**Then the Lord said to me, "Throw it to the potter"—the lordly price at which I was priced by them. So I took the thirty pieces of silver and threw them into the house of the Lord, to the potter. **14**Then I broke my second staff Union, annulling the brotherhood between Judah and Israel.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-704-1"></span><span id="page-704-0"></span>This passage comprises two sign-actions Zechariah is commissioned by the Lord to perform (11:4–14; 15–17). It links closely with chapter 10 and explains why God's people are currently oppressed by foreign shepherds (cf. 10:3). While some <span id="page-705-11"></span><span id="page-705-3"></span>interpret the first sign-action as a future prophecy, there is no agreement on how it is fulfilled, since it does not fit exactly with future events.40 In addition, if it is understood as future prophecy, there are elements contradicting other parts of Zechariah, such as "annulling the brotherhood between Judah and Israel" (11:14; cf. 8:13; 9:10, 13; 10:6–7; 12:12). Others interpret this passage as characterizing divisions within Zechariah's community, but this faces the same difficulties as the first interpretative approach. A third approach, which is here adopted since it coheres best with the wider message of the book, understands the first sign-action as representing the past and the second as representing the present. Zechariah is commissioned to play the role of Yahweh as shepherd in a portrayal of the nation's history to the time of the Babylonian exile in order to explain why God's people are ruled by oppressive foreign shepherds. The shepherd in the second sign-action represents contemporary oppressive leadership, against which God announces judgment.

## *Section Outline*

- V.C. Two Shepherd Sign-Actions (11:4–17)
	- 1. First Sign-Action: Division and Exile (11:4–14)
	- 2. Second Sign-Action: The Worthless Shepherd (11:15–17)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-705-5"></span><span id="page-705-1"></span>11:4 In the first sign-action, God calls Zechariah to play the role of "shepherd of the flock." In doing so he represents the Lord as "shepherd" to portray the history of his relationship with the "flock," the nation of Israel (cf. Jer. 12:3). The phrase "my God" indicates the close relationship between Zechariah and the Lord. The description of the flock as "doomed to slaughter" (also Zech. 11:7) anticipates verse 6, where God's judgment of Israel is portrayed.

<span id="page-705-9"></span><span id="page-705-8"></span><span id="page-705-7"></span><span id="page-705-4"></span>11:5–6 The reason for God's judgment of his people is given in these verses: "their own shepherds have no pity on them" (v. 5). Historically the leaders of the nation (particularly the kings) failed to rule with justice and righteousness. Rather than serving as good shepherds by guiding, protecting, saving, gathering, and nourishing the flock (cf. comment on 10:1–2), the leaders used the flock for their own advantage by selling them (11:5). This probably refers to political alliances with foreign kings that were costly and oppressive to God's people (e.g., 2 Kings 16:8; 17:3). To make matters worse, the sellers mock God by boasting, "Blessed be the Lord, I have become rich" (Zech. 11:5). Their pious words only mask greed; their actions show they have "no pity" or compassion for the flock (cf. Jer. 23:1–2; Ezekiel 34).

<span id="page-705-6"></span><span id="page-705-2"></span><span id="page-705-0"></span>The future tense in this section does not mean the sign-action represents the future; it is future only in the context of Zechariah's acting it out. The events represented in the sign-action have already happened. The same phenomenon

<span id="page-705-12"></span><span id="page-705-10"></span><sup>40</sup> Yet it is prophetic of the future in some respects, such as the "thirty pieces of silver" (v. 12) and Judas's betrayal of Jesus (Matt. 27:1–10). How this works is explored in the "Response" section.

Zechar iah 11:4–17 706

<span id="page-706-9"></span>occurs when Ezekiel is commanded to lie upon his side (future) in order to depict a period of 390 years that has already been running for centuries (cf. Ezek. 4:4–5).41

<span id="page-706-12"></span>God explains that his patience with his people and their leaders finally ran out. He declares, "I will no longer have pity on the inhabitants of this land" (Zech. 11:6). Instead, God handed them over to their enemies, described as "his neighbor, and . . . his king." The judgment depicted in verse 6 fell upon the northern kingdom of Israel at the hands of the Assyrians and their king Shalmaneser in 722 BC (2 Kings 17). It fell upon the southern kingdom of Judah at the hands of the Babylonians and their king Nebuchadnezzar in 586 BC (2 Kings 25). These events were devastating.

<span id="page-706-13"></span><span id="page-706-10"></span><span id="page-706-4"></span><span id="page-706-3"></span><span id="page-706-2"></span>11:7–9 Acting out the sign-action, Zechariah takes up two staffs to shepherd the flock.42 Shepherds used the staff to discipline sheep (e.g., Ezek. 20:37) and as a weapon against wild animals that might attack the sheep (e.g., 1 Sam. 17:43). A staff also provided stability for the shepherds as they walked (e.g., Ex. 12:11). These staffs are given the names "Favor" and "Union," explained in Zech. 11:10, 14.

<span id="page-706-16"></span><span id="page-706-0"></span>The one month in which Zechariah "destroyed the three shepherds" is difficult to determine. Some suggest "one month" represents a short space of time and refers to the removal of the last three kings of Judah (Jehoiakim, Jehoiachin, and Zedekiah) in quick succession. Another suggestion is that it refers to the one month in which Jerusalem fell and its leadership was exiled or killed (cf. Jer. 52:6, 12). In this case the "three shepherds" may represent the types of leadership that were removed at this time—king, prophets, and priests (cf. Jer. 52:10, 15, 24–27).

<span id="page-706-15"></span><span id="page-706-14"></span><span id="page-706-8"></span><span id="page-706-7"></span><span id="page-706-6"></span>Zechariah reports that the people "detested me." In doing so, they revealed their attitude toward God. After persevering with a rebellious people, God's patience eventually ran out (Zech. 11:8), so he ceased shepherding his people and handed them over to defeat by the nations and exile (v. 9). The chilling charge, "Let those who are left devour the flesh of one another," refers to what happens in the siege of a city when dead corpses are eaten for food due to desperate hunger. The book of Lamentations attests that this happened during the siege of Jerusalem before it fell (Lam. 2:20; 4:10; cf. Deut. 28:53; Jer. 19:9).

<span id="page-706-17"></span><span id="page-706-5"></span><span id="page-706-1"></span>11:10–11 Zechariah breaks the first staff, called "Favor" (this can also be translated "Grace" or "Kindness"). This staff represents the "covenant that I had made with all the peoples." While unusual, elsewhere the term "peoples" can refer to the whole nation of Israel, that is, "all the peoples" of Israel and Judah (cf. Isa. 3:13; Mic. 1:1–2). Hence, "covenant" most likely refers to the covenant God made with Israel at Sinai, mediated through Moses. Indeed, the judgment of exile was a curse threatened in the Mosaic covenant for rejecting God's covenant requirements

<span id="page-706-11"></span><sup>41</sup> See further M. R. Stead, "The Three Shepherds: Reading Zechariah 11 in the Light of Jeremiah," in J. A. Grant, Alison Lo, and G. J. Wenham, eds., *A God of Faithfulness: Essays in Honour of J. Gordon McConville on His 60th Birthday* (New York: T&T Clark, 2011), 149–165 (155–156).

<span id="page-706-18"></span><sup>42</sup> The phrase "sheep traders" follows the Septuagint. It is better to follow the MT here and translate "afflicted of the flock" (also v. 11). Cf. NIV, "So I shepherded the flock marked for slaughter, particularly the oppressed of the flock."

<span id="page-707-7"></span><span id="page-707-5"></span><span id="page-707-3"></span><span id="page-707-2"></span>(e.g., Deut. 28:36, 45–68). The breaking of the staff is explained as "annulling the covenant" (cf. Jer. 31:32; Ezek. 44:7). Elsewhere God promises never to break this covenant (Lev. 26:44; Judg. 2:1), and here he is certainly not breaking its terms. Rather, since the people have broken the covenant by detesting him and rejecting him as Lord, he declares the covenant annulled (cf. Ex. 32:19). Yet, while God handed his people over to the covenant curses, he still remained firmly committed to them—the rest of Zechariah indicates that God restored his people after exile and intends to bless them once again in a new covenant relationship.

Some of the "afflicted of the flock" (cf. note 42, above) recognize that the punishment is in accordance with the word of the Lord as set out in the covenant curses of Leviticus and Deuteronomy and reiterated by Israel's prophets.

<span id="page-707-12"></span><span id="page-707-1"></span>11:12–13 Zechariah gives the people an opportunity to pay him for his prophecies; they willingly accept, and pay him "thirty pieces of silver." In Exodus 21:32 this is the price of a slave, and it could be considered a reasonable sum. However, paying off Zechariah with any amount is an insult, indicating that the people have utterly rejected God as shepherd and are just as responsible as their leaders for God's judgment.

<span id="page-707-9"></span>Zechariah throws the money to the potter in the temple (Zech. 11:12), perhaps indicating he will not profit from his prophetic activity (cf. Amos 7:12). "Potter" can also be translated "molder" and may have been one who melted down metal to remit to Persia as taxes.

<span id="page-707-13"></span><span id="page-707-10"></span><span id="page-707-8"></span><span id="page-707-6"></span>11:14 The name of the second staff is "Union," conveying the idea of binding two parties together. Zechariah's breaking this staff represents the division of Solomon's kingdom into Israel under Jeroboam and Judah under Rehoboam (cf. 1 Kings 12). Elsewhere, Zechariah promises the reunion of Israel and Judah (e.g., Zech. 10:6–7; 12:12–14; cf. Ezek. 37:15–28). This first sign-action of breaking two staffs indicates that the division of the kingdom and the exile came about because the people persistently rejected the Lord as their shepherd. While historically these events happened the other way around, Zechariah's sign-action conveys these significant moments in the nation's history in a more general way.

<span id="page-707-14"></span><span id="page-707-11"></span><span id="page-707-4"></span><span id="page-707-0"></span>11:15–17 The second sign-action shows the people have received the leadership they deserved for their rejection of the Lord. Zechariah is instructed to "take once more the equipment of a foolish shepherd." The equipment is not specified but could be another staff or some kind of clothing (e.g., Deut. 22:5) or weapon (e.g., Gen. 49:5). The description "foolish" indicates someone who rejects the Lord and engages in evil behavior. Here the "foolish shepherd" does not care for the weak and vulnerable of the flock or feed the healthy, but instead devours and feasts on the fat sheep of the flock, tearing off their hoofs like a lion. This connects to the lions of Zechariah 11:3, who represent foreign rulers presently ravaging and feeding on God's people. This sign-action reiterates that the Lord has raised up oppressive leadership in judgment on his people for their rejection of him as shepherd.

<span id="page-708-3"></span>The description "*my* worthless shepherd" (v. 17) indicates this shepherd functions as the Lord's agent even though he is "foolish." This description readily calls to mind foreign kings like Nebuchadnezzar and Cyrus.

<span id="page-708-2"></span><span id="page-708-0"></span>The Lord's last word announces judgment on the "worthless shepherd" (v. 17). "Woe" often introduces a prophetic judgment oracle (e.g., Isa. 5:8; Jer. 23:1; Amos 5:18). This connects to Zechariah 10:3 and 11:1–3, which also announce the destruction of foreign shepherds. The coming judgment (a withered arm and blinded eye) will render the shepherd unable to continue his role.

## *Response*

The first sign-action reminds the people that the division of the kingdom of Israel and the experience of the destruction of the land and exile happened because the leaders of the nation and the people themselves rejected the Lord as their shepherd. Similarly, the second sign-action explains that their present destructive foreign leadership is their choice because of their rejection of the Lord; he has given them over to the consequences of their choices (cf. Rom. 1:18–2:11). God is a good shepherd whose concern is for the welfare of his sheep, but he will ultimately forsake in judgment those who persistently reject his care.

<span id="page-708-8"></span><span id="page-708-6"></span><span id="page-708-5"></span>Against the backdrop of foreign shepherds such as those portrayed in this chapter, Jesus claims, "I am the good shepherd" (John 10:11). In the life and ministry of Jesus, Zechariah's prophetic drama is played out on a bigger stage. Matthew's Gospel connects this sign-action with Judas's betrayal of Jesus for thirty pieces of silver (Matt. 26:14–15; 27:9–10).43 The same pattern of God's people despising and rejecting him as their shepherd is repeated in the rejection of Jesus. Jesus came to bring "Favor" and "Union" but instead was rejected, betrayed, and killed. Yet Zechariah 12–14 will reveal that the death of the future Davidic shepherd-king is part of the purpose of God to bring forgiveness and a restored covenant relationship between God and his people.

<span id="page-708-12"></span><span id="page-708-11"></span><span id="page-708-10"></span><span id="page-708-9"></span><span id="page-708-7"></span><span id="page-708-4"></span>Today Jesus shepherds his people by his Word, written in the Bible and applied to people's hearts and minds by his Spirit (John 10:27; 14:26). The word "pastor" derives from the Latin translation of "shepherd," and church pastors are to serve under the "chief Shepherd," Jesus Christ (1 Pet. 5:4). Central to the pastoral role is teaching God's Word to give guidance, protection, and nourishment to God's people. Pastors are responsible to faithfully teach the flock (e.g., James 3:1), and the flock is accountable not only to hear the Word but to do it (James 1:22–25) and to obey those who shepherd them (Heb. 13:17).

<span id="page-708-1"></span><sup>43</sup> Matthew attributes this to Jeremiah, possibly because there is a combined allusion (cf. Jer. 19:1–13) and Jeremiah is the better known of the two prophets.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-709-0"></span>A second prophetic oracle (chs. 12–14) offers another perspective on the battle against the nations that will establish God's kingdom (cf., e.g., the battle imagery <span id="page-710-4"></span><span id="page-710-3"></span>in 9:13–15; 10:5–7). The phrase "on that day" occurs seventeen times in these three chapters and refers to the day when the Lord will establish his kingdom on earth in glory. Occurring as often as it does, the phrase regularly directs the reader and hearer to the future. These chapters also indicate that central to the coming day is the future Davidic king (cf. 9:9). Yet, perhaps unexpectedly, it is through the piercing and the striking of the shepherd-king that cleansing from sin and restored covenant relationship will occur.

<span id="page-710-14"></span><span id="page-710-8"></span><span id="page-710-2"></span>Chapter 12 prophesies a future offensive by the nations against Jerusalem, yet the Lord promises to save and strengthen his people (vv. 1–9). In the aftermath of this battle, the people will mourn and grieve the one they have pierced (vv. 10–14), and God will bring cleansing (13:1). Chapter 12 is closely linked to the oracles of chapter 13.

<span id="page-710-16"></span><span id="page-710-15"></span>This section reveals that God's kingdom will not come without great cost to God's people and their king, but the final outcome will be glorious—the people will be saved and cleansed from sin. The main idea is that while God's people face a tumultuous future, at each and every point God will powerfully act to bring salvation.

- <span id="page-710-10"></span>VI. Second Oracle (12:1–14:21)
