### *Comment*

<span id="page-710-9"></span><span id="page-710-6"></span><span id="page-710-1"></span>12:1 The second prophetic oracle is titled the same as the first (cf. 9:1 and comment). This oracle concerns "Israel," which is striking against the background of chapter 11, since there Zechariah broke the "Union" staff to annul the "brotherhood between Judah and Israel" (11:14). This prophecy looks toward the time when God's people will again be united (cf. 10:6).

<span id="page-710-7"></span><span id="page-710-5"></span><span id="page-710-0"></span>Since "the Lord" translates the personal name "Yahweh," the description of the Lord as Creator is an implicit claim to the uniqueness of the God of Israel. God "stretched out the heavens" like a tent and "founded the earth" like the foundation of a building being laid. He created not only the vastness of the universe but also each person's "spirit" (cf. Gen. 2:7). God's power in creation is also a guarantee that the prophetic word will come to pass; he is well able to recreate the nation. His creative power is seen also in that he will "*make* Jerusalem a cup of staggering" (Zech. 12:2), "will *make* Jerusalem a heavy stone" (v. 3), and "will *make* the clans of Judah like a blazing pot" (v. 6)—creative actions showing his power and dominion over the nations (cf. 14:6–9).

<span id="page-710-17"></span><span id="page-710-13"></span><span id="page-710-12"></span><span id="page-710-11"></span>12:2 A future attack on Jerusalem is envisaged. Yet, when Jerusalem is under "siege," God will repel those who attack; he will "make Jerusalem a cup of stag<span id="page-711-1"></span>gering to all the surrounding peoples"—they will be knocked off balance as if drunk, possibly with fear. In Isaiah 51:17, 22, "cup of staggering" is used in parallel to "cup of his [God's] wrath," referring to the punishment upon Jerusalem when the city was destroyed by the Babylonians in 586 BC. In Zechariah this is reversed and Jerusalem will be the agent of God's wrath against those who come against it.

While difficult to translate, it seems the "cup of staggering," not "the siege," "will also be against Judah." It seems that Judah (referring to the inhabitants of the region around Jerusalem) is initially caught up with the nations in opposition to Jerusalem (possibly by coercion) and also drinks the cup (to a limited extent) that makes the surrounding peoples stagger (it is a city, not a region, that is subject to siege; cf. also Zech. 14:14). Later Judah has a change of heart (12:5) and fights *for* Jerusalem (v. 6).

<span id="page-711-8"></span><span id="page-711-6"></span><span id="page-711-5"></span><span id="page-711-4"></span>12:3–4 On the day the nations gather against Jerusalem, the Lord will defend it. God will make Jerusalem a "heavy stone" (v. 3) that injures "all who lift it." The exact nature of this stone is difficult to discern. Is it a stone dropped over the city wall on those who have laid siege to it? A stone of a partly broken city wall that injures those who try to remove it in order to break through? A stone used in ancient weightlifting competitions that often "hurt" those who tried to lift it? Or is the prophet merely making a statement that is true of any heavy stone? In any case, Jerusalem will prove to be immovable. In addition, the horses of the nation used in warfare (cf. comment on 10:3) will be put out of action (12:4). The horses will be struck with panic and blindness, and the riders will be struck with madness, thwarting their attack. These are covenant curses in Deuteronomy 28:28, but here they are afflicting Jerusalem's enemies. Yet, as God repels the attacking nations, he promises to keep his "eyes open" for the sake of the house of Judah—they will not be harmed. This statement also suggests Judah is initially caught up with the nations in this attack on Jerusalem (cf. Zech. 12:2).

<span id="page-711-7"></span><span id="page-711-3"></span><span id="page-711-0"></span>12:5–6 When the "clans of Judah" see God defending Jerusalem and presumably protecting them amid the ensuing disarray described in verse 4, they have a change of heart (v. 5).44 God now promises to make them agents of his destruction against the peoples who come against Jerusalem (v. 6). Since they have effectively infiltrated the enemy, they will attack them from the inside and consume them. Two images convey a spreading destructive presence: a "blazing pot" (alternatively "pot of fire") "in the midst of wood" and a "flaming torch among sheaves." The outcome is that "Jerusalem shall again be inhabited in its place"—it will be saved (cf. 9:9, 16; 10:6) and will occupy its proper place.

<span id="page-711-9"></span><span id="page-711-2"></span>12:7 The day of salvation will be glorious for Jerusalem and the house of David. In order for the "tents of Judah" not to miss out on this "glory" (or "fame"), they are saved "first." This also reflects Judah's pivotal role in bringing salvation to the city

<sup>44</sup> A "clan" is larger than a family but smaller than a tribe. It is defined by kinship and territory, with obligations within the "clans of Judah" to support one another.

<span id="page-712-19"></span><span id="page-712-2"></span>in verse 6. The "tents" of Judah in this martial context may refer to the dwelling of soldiers in the field (cf. 1 Sam. 17:54).

<span id="page-712-20"></span><span id="page-712-15"></span><span id="page-712-14"></span><span id="page-712-6"></span>The "house of David" is mentioned five times in Zechariah 12:7–13:1. The Davidic king was removed from the throne in Jerusalem when it was destroyed by Babylon in 586 BC (2 Kings 25:7). Zechariah earlier expresses the hope for a coming king from the house of David as central to his restoration program (Zech. 3:8; 6:12; 9:9). This is also in line with the hope of earlier prophets and the promises of the Davidic covenant, including an eternal throne for one of David's descendants (2 Sam. 7:13, 16; cf. 23:5).45 This verse indicates the house of David is a recognized entity in the postexilic period, presumably because of this hope, associated with it, for a future king.

<span id="page-712-22"></span><span id="page-712-21"></span><span id="page-712-11"></span><span id="page-712-3"></span><span id="page-712-1"></span>12:8–9 God promises to protect the inhabitants of Jerusalem, strengthening the feeblest so that they "shall be like David" (v. 8). This alludes to the strength God gave David to defeat Israel's enemies in battle, which he demonstrated many times, not least in defeating the mighty Goliath and the Philistines (1 Samuel 17). Furthermore, "The house of David shall be like God" (Zech. 12:8). This bold comparison is best understood in functional terms, particularly since it is explained that they shall be "like the angel of the Lord, going before them." The "angel of the Lord" (cf. comment on 1:11–12) led and protected God's people on many occasions, particularly in the exodus (Ex. 13:21; 14:19; 33:2). Elsewhere, David is likened to an "angel of God," enabling him to lead the Israelites (2 Sam. 14:17, 20; 19:27). Given this background, it seems the house of David's being like God means they will once again lead and protect God's people, as God himself did. Presumably this leadership of the house of David will be mediated through the future king of Zechariah 9:9 (the Messiah), underscoring a continued Davidic hope in the postexilic period.

<span id="page-712-17"></span><span id="page-712-16"></span><span id="page-712-12"></span><span id="page-712-5"></span><span id="page-712-4"></span><span id="page-712-0"></span>Verse 9 of chapter 12 summarizes God's action in verses 1–8 and functions to give assurance to God's people that he will act in their interests. The destruction of nations hostile to Jerusalem is a theme found throughout Zechariah (cf. 1:15; 2:9; 6:8; 9:1–8, 13–15; 10:5, 7, 11; 11:1–3; 14:1–3; 12–15; 17–19).

<span id="page-712-23"></span><span id="page-712-18"></span><span id="page-712-13"></span>12:10 Victory and salvation turn to bitter weeping as the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem look on one whom they have pierced, apparently in the battle described in 12:1–9. Such piercing normally led to death, which seems likely here (cf. 13:3; Isa. 13:15; Lam. 4:9).

<span id="page-712-9"></span><span id="page-712-8"></span>God says he will "pour out . . . a spirit" (*ruakh*), which could refer to a disposition he gives his people. Yet the promise in the earlier prophets that God will send his Spirit on the day of salvation (e.g., Isa. 44:3–5; Ezek. 39:29; Joel 2:28–29) makes it more likely that it is God's Spirit being poured out here to produce "grace and pleas for mercy" among God's people—signs of repentance. In either case, it is God who changes his people so that they "mourn . . . as one mourns for an only

<span id="page-712-10"></span><span id="page-712-7"></span><sup>45</sup> Cf. Isaiah 9:6–7; 11:1–10; 16:5; Jeremiah 23:3–6; 33:14–22; Ezekiel 37:21–25; Hosea 3:5; Micah 4:8–5:5; Amos 9:11–15.

child, and weep bitterly . . . as one weeps over a firstborn." These expressions convey desperate and profound anguish and sorrow at the one they have "pierced." The "firstborn" was the heir and represented the people's future.

<span id="page-713-9"></span><span id="page-713-8"></span>Who is the one they have pierced? The pronouns "me . . . him . . . him" suggest the people pierced God (metaphorically) and a closely associated third party (concretely). The immediate and wider contexts of Zechariah point to this third party intimately associated with God as the future king of the "house of David" (cf. 3:8; 6:12; 9:9), the shepherd struck in 13:7–9. The king in Israel was understood to be the agent of the Lord's rule on earth (e.g., Psalm 72). Hence to pierce the king is also in some sense to pierce God. Indeed, the close connection between God and his anointed (seen, e.g., in Ps. 45:6; Isa. 9:6) explains how the death of the Messiah also "pierced" God. The reason for the piercing becomes clearer in Zechariah 13.

<span id="page-713-12"></span><span id="page-713-10"></span><span id="page-713-6"></span><span id="page-713-5"></span><span id="page-713-4"></span>12:11 This verse alludes to the death of another Davidic king, Josiah, pierced in a battle at Megiddo (2 Kings 23:29; 2 Chron. 35:20–25). Josiah's death is a pattern of the king to come—both are pierced, and the people mourn both deeply.

<span id="page-713-14"></span>Rather than treating "Hadad-rimmon" as a reference to a pagan god (suggested by "for Hadad-rimmon"), it is better to read it as a place in the plain of Megiddo, since a reference to pagan mourning is unlikely in this context.46 Even though "Hadad-rimmon" is otherwise unknown, Zechariah 14:10 refers to a Rimmon south of Jerusalem. Since there was more than one Rimmon (cf. also Josh. 15:32; Judg. 20:45; 1 Chron. 4:32), "Hadad" functions to specify which one is meant.

<span id="page-713-11"></span><span id="page-713-3"></span><span id="page-713-2"></span>12:12–14 The extent of the mourning continues to be described, and its vast extent across the land suggests that the one who died is a royal figure. The references to the "house of David" and "house of Levi" specify the royal and priestly families. However, the references to the "house of Nathan" and "family of the Shimeites" are more difficult to determine, since they are somewhat obscure subsidiary family members (cf. Nathan in 2 Sam. 5:14 and Shimei in Num. 3:21). Yet they may have had genealogical significance (seen, e.g., in Luke 3:31, where royal descent is traced through Nathan rather than Solomon). In this case the royal and priestly families will lead the people in repentance.

<span id="page-713-15"></span><span id="page-713-0"></span>The repeated phrase "by itself, and their wives by themselves" indicates the whole community is involved. There may be a sense in which "by themselves" conveys the genuineness of the repentance. The mention of "wives" (or "women") indicates the equal responsibility they bear for sin and their equal need for repentance (cf. Jer. 44:9). It may also reflect the cultural practice of segregating male and female mourners at funerals.

<span id="page-713-13"></span><span id="page-713-7"></span><span id="page-713-1"></span>13:1 Water is used for cleansing in the Torah (e.g., Num. 8:5–14). A "fountain" or "spring" suggests an abundant and ongoing supply of water and anticipates the "living waters" Zechariah 14:8 says will flow from Jerusalem. While sacrifice is normally required for purification from sin, washing is used as an image of

<sup>46</sup> The Hebrew is a construct rather than a prepositional phrase: "of Hadad-rimmon," not "for Hadad-rimmon."

<span id="page-714-5"></span><span id="page-714-3"></span><span id="page-714-2"></span>repentance and purification from sin elsewhere in the prophets (e.g., Isa. 1:16; 4:4; Jer. 4:14; Ezek. 36:25). The close connection of this verse with Zechariah 12 implies that cleansing "from sin and uncleanness" follows the death of the Messiah and the pouring out of the Spirit (v. 10; cf. 3:8–9). It is particularly said to be for those who were responsible for the piercing in 12:10—"the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem."

#### *Response*

<span id="page-714-6"></span>Zechariah's second oracle (chs. 12–14) reveals that the coming of God's kingdom will not be without cost to God's people. Chapter 12 pictures a "day" when the nations (and initially Judah also) will lay siege to Jerusalem, yet God will act to repel the nations. He will turn the hearts of the clans of Judah so that they destroy the attacking nations and restore Jerusalem to its rightful place. This judgment on the nations reflects the promises to Abraham that "him who dishonors you I will curse" (Gen. 12:3). The emphasis of the passage falls on God's actions to strengthen his people and defend his city, giving assurance to God's people that although things may appear tumultuous, the Lord is working out his salvation purposes.

<span id="page-714-1"></span><span id="page-714-0"></span>When is this "day" when the nations and the people of Israel ("clans of Judah") gather against Jerusalem? When is the battle in which God and the Davidic king are pierced? The NT interprets it as the day God's holy servant Jesus, the Messiah, was crucified. For instance, Acts 4:24–28 cites Psalm 2, which has similar themes (the raging of the Gentiles against the Lord and his Messiah). Herod and Pontius Pilate, along with the Gentiles and the people of Israel, conspired against the anointed one, Jesus. Significantly, this happened "in this city," i.e., Jerusalem. The death of Jesus was the day of salvation for God's people and the day of judgment for God's enemies. The piercing of Jesus on the cross by a Roman soldier's spear (John 19:34–37) is seen to fulfill Zechariah 12:10, and in Revelation 1:7 Jesus is described as being "pierced." In addition, the NT explains that Jesus' death offers the ultimate cleansing from sin and uncleanness, bringing forgiveness (e.g., Matt. 26:28; Eph. 1:7; 5:26; Col. 1:14). The terrible irony is that the death that brought salvation and cleansing came at the hands of God's own people.

<span id="page-714-10"></span><span id="page-714-9"></span><span id="page-714-8"></span><span id="page-714-7"></span><span id="page-714-4"></span>After Jesus' death, God's Spirit was poured out on the God-fearing Jews in Jerusalem, who "were cut to the heart" and repented (Acts 2:32–37). While Zechariah 1–8 consistently calls the people to repentance (e.g., 1:3–6; 7:3), this passage shows that ultimately repentance is a gift of God by his Spirit, poured out as a result of the Messiah's death (note how grace precedes the people's pleas for mercy in 12:10). Similarly, the NT teaches that repentance is a result of the regeneration and rebirth God graciously works in the believer by his Spirit (cf. Titus 3:4–7). Repentance not only marks the beginning of the Christian life; it also characterizes the daily experience of the believer, turning from sin to obedience to the Lord.

## <span id="page-715-6"></span>ZECHARIAH 13:2–6

**<sup>2</sup>** "And on that day, declares the Lord of hosts, I will cut off the names of the idols from the land, so that they shall be remembered no more. And also I will remove from the land the prophets and the spirit of uncleanness. **<sup>3</sup>**And if anyone again prophesies, his father and mother who bore him will say to him, 'You shall not live, for you speak lies in the name of the Lord.' And his father and mother who bore him shall pierce him through when he prophesies.

**<sup>4</sup>** "On that day every prophet will be ashamed of his vision when he prophesies. He will not put on a hairy cloak in order to deceive, **5**but he will say, 'I am no prophet, I am a worker of the soil, for a man sold me in my youth.'*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>6</sup>**And if one asks him, 'What are these wounds on your back?'*<sup>2</sup>* he will say, 'The wounds I received in the house of my friends.' "

1Or *for the land has been my possession since my youth* 2Or *on your chest*; Hebrew *wounds between your hands*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-715-3"></span>This passage is closely connected to chapter 12. In 12:10–13:1, God promises to grant his people repentance and cleanse them from sin and uncleanness. The oracle that follows in this section promises the removal of idolatry, false prophecy, and the spirit of uncleanness in the land, with a special focus on the elimination of false prophets (13:2–6).

The main idea of this passage is that the land will be thoroughly cleansed from sin and uncleanness in the aftermath of the Messiah's death.

### *Section Outline*

VI.B. Cleansing the Land (13:2–6)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-715-5"></span><span id="page-715-4"></span>13:2 The repetition of the phrase "on that day" continues from chapter 12 (cf. Section Overview of 12:1–13:1). It is the day when God will establish his kingdom on earth in glory, and here God promises to remove things opposed to his reign.

<span id="page-715-2"></span><span id="page-715-1"></span><span id="page-715-0"></span>Idolatry and false prophecy were often associated in preexilic times (e.g., 1 Kings 22; Jer. 6:13–14) and were the chief sins that led to exile (e.g., Ezek. 22:3–15; 24:13; 39:24). While idolatry is not condemned nearly as frequently in the postexilic prophets, there are indications of its presence in the community in Zechariah's seventh night vision (5:5–11) and also in 10:2 (along with divination). God will "cut off the names of the idols from the land"—he will eliminate both the idols themselves <span id="page-716-4"></span>and also the powers attributed to them and any means of relationship or worship (cf. Hos. 2:17). God's people will have no enduring memory of the idols ("They shall be remembered no more"). Instead, they will call on the name of the Lord (cf. Zech. 13:9).

<span id="page-716-10"></span>The "prophets" to be removed are to be understood as false prophets. The OT does not use the term "false prophet"; it must be determined from the context. While some argue Zechariah is speaking about the cessation of prophecy in the contemporary and future ages, this is very unlikely.47 The removal of these prophets is elaborated upon in verses 3–6, where it is clear that they are false.

<span id="page-716-11"></span><span id="page-716-5"></span>The phrase "spirit of uncleanness" is not found elsewhere in the OT. Here it is associated with false prophecy in contrast with God's Spirit, who is associated with true prophecy in 7:12 (cf. also 4:6). The "spirit of uncleanness" also forms a contrast with the "spirit of grace" in 12:10.

<span id="page-716-8"></span><span id="page-716-6"></span><span id="page-716-1"></span>13:3 The treachery of false prophecy for God's people is underscored by the penalty that will come on those who practice it—even the parents of the false prophet, who presumably deeply love their child, will "pierce him through" when he prophesies (v. 3; cf. Deut. 13:6–11). The Hebrew for "pierce" (*daqar*) is the same verb as in Zechariah 12:10, perhaps to make a comparison between the sinful piercing of God and his king, resulting in cleansing, and the cleansing to come through the (sinful) prophet's being pierced. There may also be an echo of the priest Phinehas's bold action in Numbers 25:7–8, where he pierces (using the same verb) the Israelite and Midianite couple who blatantly sleep with each other in the Israelite camp, quickly bringing a stop to their sin. This verse claims that "on that day" God's people will no longer tolerate sin and uncleanness in their community.

<span id="page-716-9"></span><span id="page-716-3"></span><span id="page-716-0"></span>13:4–6 Every false prophet will be "ashamed of his vision" and will seek to cover up his past. He will no longer dress like a prophet with a "hairy cloak" (cf. the dress of Elijah in 1 Kings 19:13; 2 Kings 1:8). Instead he will pretend to have always been a "worker of the soil" (Zech. 13:5), or farmer, possibly as an indentured slave ("a man sold me in my youth").

<span id="page-716-2"></span>Furthermore, they will explain away the "wounds" they may have received from their false prophetic activity (v. 6; cf. Deut. 14:1; 1 Kings 18:28). They will claim to have received them "in the house of my friends." It is difficult to know exactly who these "friends" are; the phrase can also be translated "the ones who love me." Suggestions include parents, where the wounds are a result of discipline; or fellow idolaters, where the wounds result from worship together; or friends, where the wounds may result from a drunken brawl or simply an accident. In any case, the false prophet will be unmasked and removed from the land on that day.

### *Response*

<span id="page-716-7"></span>The death of the Messiah will not only result in the cleansing of those who repent from sin and uncleanness (Zech. 13:1), it will also issue in cleansing for

<sup>47</sup> See the discussion in Anthony R. Petterson, *Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi*, AOTC 25 (Nottingham, UK: Apollos, 2015), 274–275.

the land from practices that defile it (vv. 2–6). This passage shows that there is no place in God's kingdom for idolatry, false prophecy, or impurity. Idolatry seeks to manipulate God or the gods by making a representation of the god and seeking to manipulate it for a positive outcome. At the heart of idolatry is greed (cf. Eph. 5:5; Col. 3:5).48 There is no place for it in the church (cf., e.g., Rev. 2:14–16, 20–23).

<span id="page-717-5"></span><span id="page-717-4"></span><span id="page-717-3"></span><span id="page-717-2"></span><span id="page-717-0"></span>Similarly, there are false prophets today who claim to know the future but sell false comfort. When Jesus returns, the "false prophet" will be thrown into the lake of sulfur, along with the devil and the beast (Rev. 20:10). Until that time, Christians are to reject false prophecy (cf. Isa. 44:24–26; Acts 16:16–24; 19:19; Gal. 5:20; Rev. 21:8; 22:15). Guidance for God's people today comes from listening to the Word of God and seeking to live in a way that displays his justice and righteousness, obeying the commands of Jesus and his apostles (2 Tim. 3:15–17; James 1:16–25).

## <span id="page-717-1"></span>ZECHARIAH 13:7–9

**<sup>7</sup>** "Awake, O sword, against my shepherd, against the man who stands next to me," declares the Lord of hosts.

"Strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered; I will turn my hand against the little ones.

- **<sup>8</sup>** In the whole land, declares the Lord, two thirds shall be cut off and perish, and one third shall be left alive.
- **<sup>9</sup>** And I will put this third into the fire, and refine them as one refines silver, and test them as gold is tested. They will call upon my name, and I will answer them.
- I will say, 'They are my people'; and they will say, 'The Lord is my God.' "

#### *Section Overview*

This short poetic oracle is very significant in the message of Zechariah. It contains the final reference to a "shepherd" and brings together the various elements of the leadership theme developed throughout the book. Following the previous passage, which concerned the cleansing of the land (13:2–6), this oracle speaks of further adversity for God's people as they go through another exile-like experience. God commands the striking of his shepherd, resulting in great loss to the flock, but

<sup>48</sup> See Brian S. Rosner, *Beyond Greed* (Kingsford, NSW, Australia: Matthias Media, 2004).

those who emerge will be refined by fire and will enter into a restored covenant relationship with the Lord.

## *Section Outline*

VI.C. The Shepherd Struck, the Sheep Scattered (13:7–9)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-718-10"></span><span id="page-718-9"></span>13:7 The Lord commands that a sword be drawn to strike "my shepherd . . . the man who stands next to me." The verb "strike" (*nakah*) is different from the one translated "pierced" in 12:10 and "pierce" in 13:3 (*daqar*), but as in both of those contexts, striking with the sword here implies the death of the one struck. The pronoun "my" and the description of the shepherd as standing next to the Lord (which can be translated "my associate" or "my friend") indicate the shepherd's close relationship with the Lord. It is therefore a different shepherd from the "foolish" and "worthless" shepherd of 11:15–17. However, it is not immediately clear who this shepherd is or why the Lord commands his death.

<span id="page-718-8"></span><span id="page-718-3"></span>Striking the shepherd will result in the sheep being scattered, including the "little ones" coming under God's judgment. The "little ones" are most naturally the sheep that are scattered, perhaps specifically identifying the lambs of the flock under God's judgment, indicating its severity. The only king said to have been killed with the sword was Zedekiah (Jer. 21:7), and his death coincided with the scattering of God's people in exile. Just as Zechariah drew on the episode with King Josiah in 12:10, so here he may be drawing on the death of another Judahite king to portray a future judgment of God's people.

<span id="page-718-7"></span>The wider expectation raised from earlier in the book suggests this struck shepherd is the future Davidic king who was earlier said to be pierced in the battle to establish God's kingdom (Zech. 12:10; cf. 3:8; 6:12; 9:9). This oracle indicates the death of the shepherd-king will be God's intent and design. There are many similarities here with Isaiah's presentation of the suffering servant, who suffers death on behalf of God's people by God's intent (cf. Isa. 53:6, 10).49

<span id="page-718-12"></span><span id="page-718-11"></span><span id="page-718-2"></span><span id="page-718-1"></span><span id="page-718-0"></span>13:8–9 The extent of this judgment will be devastating: "Two thirds [of the flock] shall be cut off and perish" (v. 8). The "third" (vv. 8, 9) that remains will be refined and tested in fire, just like the precious metals "silver" and "gold" (cf. Isa. 1:24–26). To "refine" a metal is to subject it to high temperatures to burn off impurities. To "test" the metal is to prove or determine its quality after being refined. The notion of refining a remnant is common in the prophets (e.g., Isa. 1:8–9; Amos 3:21; Mic. 5:7–8; 7:18; Mal. 3:2–4). In many instances, refining is a metaphor for the exile, from which a purified people of God would emerge. Dividing into thirds also brings to mind Ezekiel 5:1–4, where judgment falls on God's people, with a third burned with fire, a third struck by the sword, and a third scattered to the wind and chased by an unsheathed sword (v. 2). From this third a small number is preserved,

<span id="page-718-6"></span><span id="page-718-5"></span><span id="page-718-4"></span><sup>49</sup> Cf. Stead, "Suffering Servant," 62–83; Petterson, *Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi*, 280–284.

<span id="page-719-2"></span><span id="page-719-0"></span>but they too are further refined (vv. 3–4). The same proportions are found also in 2 Samuel 8:2, where David killed two thirds of the Moabites and spared one third.

<span id="page-719-1"></span>Those who survive and emerge from the refining fire will enjoy a restored covenant relationship with God. The language "They are my people . . . The Lord is my God" is classic covenant language (cf. Zech. 2:11; 8:8; 9:16). Jeremiah 31:33 uses this language to speak of the "new covenant," which seems to be in view here in Zechariah as well—the people emerging from the future judgment will enter a new covenant relationship with the Lord. A great privilege of this relationship is answered prayer: "They will call upon my name, and I will answer them" (cf. Zech. 10:6). The wider prophetic unit (12:1–14:21) indicates the people will have to endure another exile-like experience "on that day" when the future Davidic king is struck and the people are refined, before the covenant relationship and its blessings are realized.

#### <span id="page-719-4"></span>*Response*

This prophetic oracle provides another perspective on the coming day of the Lord. It reveals that the death of the future shepherd-king is God's own purpose and design. The connection of these themes with the Messiah emerges when this oracle is read against the rest of Zechariah. The earlier promises regarding the "Branch" connect his coming with the removal of the iniquity of the land in a single day (3:8–9) and indicate he will serve as priest (6:12–13). Zechariah 12:10 and 13:7 indicate it is through the death of the king that the people and the land will be cleansed from sin and uncleanness.

<span id="page-719-6"></span><span id="page-719-5"></span><span id="page-719-3"></span>Jesus quotes this oracle and explains it in terms of his own imminent death (cf. Matt. 26:31; Mark 14:27), which will establish the new covenant (exactly the idea present in Zech. 13:9). Jesus understands the image of striking with the sword to be a metaphor for his crucifixion. In addition, the gospel writers see the scattering of the flock fulfilled when the disciples desert Jesus at his arrest (Matt. 26:31, 56; Mark 14:27, 49–50).

<span id="page-719-10"></span><span id="page-719-9"></span><span id="page-719-8"></span><span id="page-719-7"></span>The response this calls for from God's people today is to confess, "The Lord is my God!" and to pray to him as an expression of the new covenant relationship that has come in Christ Jesus (1 Thess. 5:17). Christians should also expect various trials, "so that the tested genuineness of your faith—more precious than gold that perishes though it is tested by fire—may be found to result in praise and glory and honor at the revelation of Jesus Christ" (1 Pet. 1:7).

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-721-5"></span><span id="page-721-3"></span>Chapter 14 uses well-known images from Israel's past to picture God's coming kingdom. It is closely connected to chapters 12–13, with the phrase "on that day" occurring a further seven times. Chapter 14 offers another perspective on the nations' attack of Jerusalem, in which God will fight and deliver his people. It reveals again that God's kingdom will come at great cost to his people and will refine a remnant (cf. 13:7–9). It also brings the themes of the book to a climax, as the survivors (including those from the nations) either recognize his kingship and uniqueness or else suffer his punishment. In this chapter, the return of the Lord to his people affects the whole creation.

<span id="page-721-4"></span><span id="page-721-2"></span><span id="page-721-1"></span><span id="page-721-0"></span>There are many similarities in this chapter with the battle against Gog of Magog in Ezekiel 38–39, where Gog comes with a coalition of nations to invade the "land that is restored from war" (Ezek. 38:8)—a description that to some extent fits Israel after they have been "gathered from many peoples" (i.e., postexile).50 God responds to the invasion with earthquake and plague and by turning soldiers against each other so that God's holy name is known among Israel and the nations (Ezek. 38:16, 23; 39:7).The main idea conveyed in this chapter is that God will return to Jerusalem, defeat all his enemies, be recognized as the one true King, and cleanse the land and his people so that they might worship him in all holiness. The NT applies the language and images in this chapter to both the first and second comings of Jesus. Hence there is a "now and not yet" perspective on its fulfillment. The kingdom has been inaugurated with Jesus' death and resurrection and will be fully realized at his return.

## *Comment*

<span id="page-722-18"></span>14:1–2 "Behold" introduces a new section of the second oracle (chs. 12–14) and calls attention to something newsworthy or unexpected: Jerusalem will face another exile-like experience. This passage indicates there will be an offensive by the nations against Jerusalem, resulting in great devastation to its inhabitants. This is not a battle subsequent to that of 12:2–9 but another perspective on the same battle, this time looking at what it and the coming of God's kingdom entail for the entire cosmos. The "day . . . coming" is the same "day" mentioned ten times in chapters 12–13.

<span id="page-722-19"></span><span id="page-722-17"></span><span id="page-722-14"></span><span id="page-722-12"></span><span id="page-722-2"></span>The picture in these verses replays the past, when Jerusalem was attacked and captured by the nations in battle (14:2), with "spoil taken" and "divided" in the midst of God's people (v. 1) and with many of the people being sent "into exile" (v. 2; cf. 2 Kings 25). This earlier attack happened at the hands of the Babylonians in 586 BC (cf. Zech. 11:5–6). The "spoil" refers to property captured by an invading army, including prisoners, precious metals, food, livestock, textiles, and garments (e.g., Ezek. 38:13).

<span id="page-722-15"></span><span id="page-722-11"></span><span id="page-722-4"></span>Like the earlier destruction of Jerusalem at the hands of the Babylonians, the future attack on the city is said to be at the Lord's initiative ("I will gather all the nations"). The reason is not explicit, but in the context of chapter 13 it probably functions as a refining judgment on account of sin.51 The raping of women is a common feature of warfare and here depicts its horror and sheer awfulness (cf. Isa. 13:16); it is one of the covenant curses associated with exile in Deuteronomy 28:30. Half of the inhabitants of the city will be taken into exile, but the other half will remain.

<span id="page-722-21"></span><span id="page-722-10"></span><span id="page-722-9"></span><span id="page-722-3"></span><span id="page-722-1"></span>14:3 Just when things look desperate, God will go out (presumably from heaven) and fight for his people against the nations who have come against Jerusalem (cf. again 12:2–9). God is depicted as a warrior elsewhere in Zechariah, but whereas earlier passages in chapters 9–14 describe him as using his people as instruments of his judgment (e.g., 9:13–15; 10:5, 7; 12:2–3; 6), here God fights directly (cf. also 6:5, where God sends out his heavenly chariots to bring judgment on the nations). The phrase "as when he fights on a day of battle" points to past victories the Lord won for his people (e.g., Ex. 15:1–21; Josh. 10:14, 42; 23:3; Judg. 4:15; 1 Sam. 7:10). These give assurance that God will defeat the nations again on the coming day.

<span id="page-722-22"></span><span id="page-722-8"></span><span id="page-722-7"></span><span id="page-722-6"></span><span id="page-722-0"></span>14:4 The return of the Lord to Jerusalem is a key theme of the book (cf. 1:3; 2:5, 10–11; 4:9–10; 8:3; 9:8, 14). When God comes to save his people, he will shake the heavens and the earth (cf. Hag. 2:6, 21–22). With bold anthropomorphism, God's

<span id="page-722-20"></span><span id="page-722-16"></span><span id="page-722-5"></span><sup>51</sup> The Hebrew noun that is translated "the rest" (*yeter*) in verse 2 has the same root as the verb translated "shall be left alive" (*yatar*) in 13:8, and this connects the ideas.

<span id="page-723-7"></span>"feet shall stand on the Mount of Olives," and it "shall be split in two from east to west." The Mount of Olives, to the east of Jerusalem, is a ridge about 2.5 miles (4 km) long that runs in a north/south direction. Significantly, when the glory of the Lord departed from the temple and Jerusalem in Ezekiel's vision, the glory "stood on the mountain that is on the east side of the city" (Ezek. 11:23). Here Zechariah envisages the Lord's return by way of the same path (cf. Ezek. 43:2). It is also significant that Zechariah describes the location of the mountain as "on the east," since the earlier sanctuaries of Eden, the tabernacle, and the temple were all entered from the east. The city of Jerusalem is envisaged as God's sanctuary.

<span id="page-723-8"></span>God's arrival will split the Mount of Olives in two: "One half of the Mount shall move northward, and the other half southward." This results in the formation of a "very wide valley" through which God's people will flee. The verb "split" (*baqaʻ*) is used to describe the parting of the waters of the Red Sea in Exodus 14:21, suggesting the escape from Jerusalem in Zechariah 14:5 is like another exodus-salvation.

<span id="page-723-12"></span><span id="page-723-2"></span>14:5 The valley that is formed will become an escape route that extends to Azal, the location of which is unknown, though it must lie to the east of Jerusalem. The future escape is likened to when the people "fled from the earthquake in the days of Uzziah," an event that occurred more than two hundred years earlier and clearly left a lasting impression (Amos 1:1).

<span id="page-723-10"></span><span id="page-723-9"></span>After providing salvation for the people, the Lord will return to Jerusalem. The description "my God" underscores Zechariah's personal relationship with the Lord. He will return to Jerusalem with "all the holy ones," yet it is not certain who these "holy ones" are. They could be the heavenly host of angels (e.g., Zech. 6:1–8; Deut. 33:2; Ps. 89:5, 7; Dan. 8:13) or the people who, having endured the attack on Jerusalem, are now refined, cleansed, and saved and now return to inhabit Jerusalem as "holy" (e.g., Lev. 21:7–8; Num. 16:5, 7; 2 Chron. 35:3).

<span id="page-723-5"></span><span id="page-723-4"></span><span id="page-723-3"></span>14:6–7 The Hebrew of verse 6 is difficult to translate, and the ESV follows the ancient versions: "There shall be no light, cold, or frost." An alternative translation is, "Splendid ones shall congeal," where "splendid ones" refers to the heavenly bodies (sun, moon, and stars) that become stationary on a "unique day" (v. 7).52 This may draw on the account of the Lord fighting for his people at Gibeon, when the sun stood still and the moon stopped (Josh. 10:12–14). In any case, God's return to Jerusalem will disrupt the present created order. Indeed, the language of these verses echoes the Genesis creation account (cf. Zech. 12:1). Zechariah envisages a new creation, with "neither day nor night" but instead a single day of "light." When evening comes, "there shall be light" instead of darkness (14:7; cf. Isa. 60:19–20; Rev. 21:25; 22:5).

<span id="page-723-14"></span><span id="page-723-13"></span><span id="page-723-11"></span><span id="page-723-6"></span><span id="page-723-1"></span>14:8 In the same way that life-giving water flowed from Eden (Gen. 2:10), the coming day will bring a new supply of "living waters" to the world, flowing from

<span id="page-723-0"></span><sup>52</sup> The expression "unique day" can also be translated "one day" (cf. ESV mg.), echoing the Genesis creation account (Gen. 1:5).

<span id="page-724-10"></span><span id="page-724-4"></span>Jerusalem (cf. Ps. 36:8–9; Ezek. 47:1–12; Joel 3:18).53 The phrase "living waters" connotes waters that are fresh (not stagnant or contaminated) and give life. The picture of the waters' dividing into two and flowing "to the eastern sea" (the Dead Sea) and the "western sea" (the Mediterranean) indicates a great volume of water (double that of Ezekiel's vision in 47:8–12, which flows only to the Dead Sea). Since Jerusalem's water supply often dried up in summer and it was common practice to cut off a city's water supply during a siege (cf. Isa. 7:3; 22:11), the statement that it "shall continue in summer as in winter" also speaks of a great supply of water and pictures the Lord's blessing.

<span id="page-724-15"></span><span id="page-724-6"></span>14:9 The statement that the Lord "will be king over all the earth" forms the climax of Zechariah's vision of the future—God's kingship is basic to the establishment of his kingdom. His salvation of Jerusalem will prove his reign and bring to fulfillment earlier hopes expressed in the book.

<span id="page-724-13"></span><span id="page-724-0"></span>The expression "The Lord will be one" is a citation of the Shema of Deuteronomy 6:4—"Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one"—as an expression of God's uniqueness; he is the only one who is truly God. In addition, since the names of the idols will be banished (cf. Zech. 13:2), God's "name" will be the "only name," a further expression of his uniqueness, implying that "on that day" he will be the only one worshiped in all the earth.

<span id="page-724-16"></span><span id="page-724-12"></span>14:10 The earth will be transformed and Jerusalem will be elevated from its surrounding territory. The cities of Geba and Rimmon represent, respectively, the northern and southern boundaries of the land of Judah. Following the ESV, the land will be flattened and "Jerusalem shall remain aloft."54 The phrase "on its site" is also found in 12:6, where it is translated "in its place"; in both instances it seems to mean Jerusalem shall be restored to "its rightful place." This is in keeping with the hopes of the earlier prophets for Jerusalem (e.g., Isa. 2:1–4; Ezek. 40:1–2; Mic. 4:1–5).

<span id="page-724-9"></span><span id="page-724-8"></span><span id="page-724-5"></span>Several landmarks of the preexilic city are identified, but it is not possible to determine with confidence the precise location of them all.55 The "Gate of Benjamin" was located on the northern side of the city to give access to the territory of Benjamin (cf. Jer. 37:13; 38:7). The "former gate" is not otherwise mentioned in the OT but may refer to the main gate on the east side of the city. The "Corner Gate" is thought to be on the west side of the city (cf. 2 Kings 14:13; 2 Chron. 26:9; Jer. 31:38). The location of the "Tower of Hananel" is unknown but may be west of the Benjamin Gate at the northwestern corner of the Temple Mount (cf. Neh. 3:1; 12:39; Jer. 31:38). Finally, the "king's winepresses" are not mentioned elsewhere

This suggests Jerusalem takes the role of the temple (cf. vv. 4, 20–21).

<sup>54</sup> The clause "The whole land shall be turned into a plain" can also be translated "He will surround all the land like the Arabah," the dry rift that forms the Jordan River Valley, surrounded by steep escarpments. This phrase could be saying that just as the Arabah is surrounded, so God will surround the whole land to protect it (cf. 2:4–5).

<span id="page-725-7"></span><span id="page-725-4"></span>but may be on the south of the city near the "King's Pool" and the "king's garden" (cf. Neh. 2:14; 3:15). The prophet Jeremiah also envisions Jerusalem being rebuilt "from the tower of Hananel to the Corner Gate" (Jer. 31:38). Like Zechariah, the future city of Jerusalem is said to be "sacred" or "holy to the Lord" (Jer. 31:40; cf. Zech. 14:20).

<span id="page-725-21"></span><span id="page-725-16"></span><span id="page-725-15"></span><span id="page-725-10"></span><span id="page-725-8"></span><span id="page-725-1"></span>14:11 Those who had fled the city in verse 5 shall return to dwell in it—"It shall be inhabited" (cf. 1:17; 2:4). Never again will there be a "decree of utter destruction" (Hb. *herem*, cf. ESV mg., "refers to things devoted [or set apart] to the Lord [or by the Lord] for destruction"). In Deuteronomy, *herem* is associated with the removal of the Canaanites from the Promised Land to cleanse it from the contamination associated with their idolatry (cf. Deut. 7:25–26; 20:17–18). This implies that God's action against Jerusalem in Zechariah 14:1–2 is to cleanse it from the contamination of sin. Having been cleansed, it will be inhabited by the "holy ones" (v. 5) and "shall dwell in security," implying military protection or agricultural abundance (cf. 2:5; 3:9–10; Ps. 46:5).

<span id="page-725-18"></span><span id="page-725-14"></span><span id="page-725-13"></span><span id="page-725-5"></span>14:12–13 Further details are given about how God will fight against the nations who have come to "wage war against Jerusalem" (cf. 12:4–6; 14:3). First, he will strike them with "plague" so that their "flesh . . . eyes . . . and their tongues will rot." To some extent, this recalls the plagues God sent on the Egyptians in the exodus to liberate his people (Exodus 7–12). Here the plague incapacitates the warriors, removing their ability to see and to speak. This presumably contributes to the "great panic . . . [that] shall fall on them," which is also attributed to the Lord and expresses his sovereignty in judgment. The panic results in the nations fighting' one another ("The hand of the one will be raised against the hand of the other" refers to military activity; cf. Ezek. 38:21). Earlier in Israel's history, God struck their enemies with fear so that they fought one another (e.g., Judg. 7:22; 1 Sam. 14:15–20).

<span id="page-725-19"></span><span id="page-725-12"></span><span id="page-725-9"></span><span id="page-725-3"></span><span id="page-725-2"></span>14:14 The statement "even Judah will fight at Jerusalem" is ambiguous, since the preposition "at" can also be translated "against" (cf. ESV mg.). This verse should be read against the background of 12:2–6 (cf. comments on 12:2; 12:5–6). While Judah is initially caught up with the nations gathering against Jerusalem, she sees God at work and turns to fight for Jerusalem against the nations (12:5–6).

<span id="page-725-0"></span>Just as Israel plundered the Egyptians in the exodus (Ex. 12:35–36), so God's defeat of the nations will result in their wealth being collected—"gold, silver, and garments in great abundance." This reverses the situation described in Zechariah 14:1 (cf. similarly Isa. 60:4–14; Ezek. 38:12–13; 39:10; Hag. 2:6–9).

<span id="page-725-20"></span><span id="page-725-17"></span><span id="page-725-11"></span><span id="page-725-6"></span>14:15 In addition to the plague on the peoples (v. 12), a destroying "plague" will strike the animals used in war. The "horse" was used in combat, either mounted or with chariots containing archers. Much damage was done by trampling enemy troops (cf. comments on 10:3; 10:4–5). The next three animals ("mules . . . camels . . . donkeys") were used for transporting supplies. The other "beasts" (alternatively <span id="page-726-6"></span>"cattle") probably refer to livestock used as a food resource (e.g., 2 Kings 3:9). Reference to the "camps" indicates they were animals used by an army.

<span id="page-726-11"></span>14:16 Verses 16–19 address the aftermath of the battle and the two different outcomes for "everyone who survives of all the nations that have come against Jerusalem." The first outcome is that of survivors who recognize God as king (cf. v. 9) and go "year after year" (annually) to worship the Lord of hosts and keep the "Feast of Booths" (or "Tabernacles" or *Sukkoth*). This was a seven-day festival held in the seventh month, characterized by joy and thanksgiving for the harvest and God's goodness. The "booths," or tabernacles, reminded the people of the tents the Israelites lived in when they came out of Egypt (cf. Lev. 23:33–43). The festival is elsewhere associated with the temple and includes the foreigner's sharing in the blessings of God (Deut. 16:13–15; 1 Kings 8:2, 41–43, 65; Ezra 3:1–4). Including "all the nations" in worship mirrors the end of Zechariah 8 (cf. comment on 8:23).

<span id="page-726-15"></span><span id="page-726-13"></span><span id="page-726-12"></span><span id="page-726-9"></span><span id="page-726-7"></span><span id="page-726-5"></span><span id="page-726-4"></span><span id="page-726-2"></span>14:17–19 The outcome for those who do not "worship the King" (v. 16) will be "no rain" (vv. 17–18) and the "plague" (v. 18) as "punishment" (v. 19; cf. vv. 12–15).56 Lack of rain would devastate the harvest and is a classic covenant curse (e.g., Deut. 28:22–24). The "family of Egypt" (Zech. 14:18) are singled out, possibly because they were not so directly dependent on rain because of the Nile, which flooded annually. Alternatively, they may be singled out to indicate that this salvation will be a new exodus, with Egypt representing the enemy who must recognize God's kingship or suffer his punishment.

<span id="page-726-17"></span><span id="page-726-16"></span><span id="page-726-8"></span><span id="page-726-1"></span>14:20–21 The book of Zechariah ends with a picture of holiness spreading from God's presence among his people (cf. v. 5; 2:12–13). The turban of the high priest had an inscription "Holy to the Lord" engraved on a gold plate (Ex. 28:36–38). This same holiness will extend to the "bells of the horses" (Zech. 14:20). These bells attached to the harness and had a number of functions: to ward off insects; to govern cadence; to create white noise to block out the heinous sounds of battle; to alert others to their arrival on a roadway; and, if inscribed, to identify its owner so the horse could be returned.57 Given the consistent association of the horse with war throughout the book, the bells were probably considered unclean, and this statement about their holiness perhaps speaks of the end of war (cf. 9:10). Zechariah mentions horses ten times throughout the book, beginning with the first night vision, so this is a fitting note on which to end.

<span id="page-726-18"></span><span id="page-726-10"></span><span id="page-726-3"></span><span id="page-726-0"></span>Similarly, the holiness associated with the "bowls before the altar" (cf. Ex. 27:3; Num. 4:14) will spread to the "pots in the house of the Lord" (the temple) and to "every pot in Jerusalem and Judah" (Zech. 14:21). These pots were used for sacrifice, presumably by those who came to participate in the Feast of Booths (vv. 16–19).

<span id="page-726-14"></span><sup>56</sup> The phrase "families of the earth" can also be translated "clans of the land" and may refer to Jews living in the Promised Land, who must also worship the Lord.

<sup>57</sup> Cantrell, *Horsemen of Israel*, 21–22.

<span id="page-727-2"></span><span id="page-727-0"></span>The word "trader" can have two senses. The sixth vision of the flying basket (5:5–11) indicated trade was an area in which wickedness and idolatry impacted the postexilic community, thus the removal of the "trader" indicates the community will be cleansed (cf. 13:2–6). Alternatively, the word "trader" can also be translated "Canaanite" (cf. ESV mg.). The Canaanites were renowned for their idolatry, and this promises its removal. In either case, this prophecy looks forward to the time when God will return and everything impure will be removed from the temple and the land.

#### *Response*

This chapter looks toward God's coming kingdom and reveals that it will not come without cost to God's people. Yet when the nations come against Jerusalem, the Lord will come dramatically as a warrior and fight for his people to save them. He will establish his kingship in Jerusalem and will be worshiped by those of his people and the nations who survive.

<span id="page-727-16"></span><span id="page-727-12"></span><span id="page-727-10"></span><span id="page-727-8"></span><span id="page-727-7"></span><span id="page-727-5"></span><span id="page-727-4"></span>The NT connects many of the images in this chapter with Jesus. He is the one who as king has established God's kingdom (e.g., Matt. 4:17; Mark 1:15; Luke 4:43). According to Matthew 27:51–54, when Jesus died on the cross, "The earth shook, and the rocks were split" in an "earthquake," and "many bodies of the saints [holy people] . . . were raised . . . [and] went into the holy city" (Jerusalem). Matthew connects these apocalyptic signs with the salvation that came in Jesus' death. In addition, Jesus is the "light of the world" (Zech. 14:7; John 8:12; 9:5) and the one from whom "living water" comes (Zech. 14:8; John 4:10–15; cf. Rev. 21:6; 22:17; a feature also of the new Jerusalem in Rev. 22:1–2). In John's Gospel, his work is connected with the Feast of Booths, which he fulfills (John 7:1–8:59; Col. 2:16–17). He also drove the traders out of the temple in keeping with Zechariah 14:21 (e.g., Matt. 21:12; John 2:16). While Jesus established God's kingdom in his first coming, its full reality will be experienced at his return, when he hands the kingdom to his Father (1 Cor. 15:23–28). In John's vision of the new Jerusalem, there is no temple (Rev. 21:22), for all that the temple symbolized (God's presence and rule) will be realized in the city. This seems to be anticipated in Zechariah 14, where God's holiness spreads from items normally associated with the temple to ordinary items in the city. In Revelation 21:2, this "holy city," the "new Jerusalem," is the bride of the Lamb, the church. Christians have been made holy (or "sanctified") through the death of Jesus (Zech. 14:5; 1 Cor. 6:11; Heb. 10:10) and are also called to be holy (e.g., 1 Thess. 4:3; 1 Pet. 1:15–16).

<span id="page-727-15"></span><span id="page-727-14"></span><span id="page-727-13"></span><span id="page-727-11"></span><span id="page-727-9"></span><span id="page-727-6"></span><span id="page-727-3"></span><span id="page-727-1"></span>Zechariah predicts the suffering of the Messiah (cf. Zech. 12:10; 13:7). Just as Jesus suffered, so those who follow him are to expect suffering in this age (Mark 10:30; Acts 14:22; Rom. 8:17; 2 Cor. 4:17). It is part of God's plan to refine and test his people's faith, so that it might prove genuine and result in praise and glory and honor when Jesus returns (1 Pet. 1:6–7). The power God has displayed in battles of the past, climaxing in the defeat of sin, death, and the Devil in Jesus' death and resurrection, is the same power by which God will raise up his people on the last

<span id="page-728-0"></span>day, guaranteeing our inheritance (Eph. 1:17–22). The promises of God's supreme kingship and ultimate victory over all enemies portrayed in this chapter should strengthen faith and hope amid suffering.

<span id="page-728-1"></span>This chapter also reminds God's people of the dual outcome for all, to be revealed when Jesus returns. People will either worship God as king or suffer his punishment forever. This aspect of Zechariah's prophetic vision should drive us to call on all people to recognize the triune God (Father, Son, and Spirit), as the one true King over all the earth: "The Spirit and the Bride say, 'Come.' And let the one who hears say, 'Come.' And let the one who is thirsty come; let the one who desires take the water of life without price" (Rev. 22:17).

## BIBLIOGRAPHY

Each of these commentaries seeks to explain the text of Zechariah and give careful consideration to its application today. The commentaries by Boda and Petterson offer a detailed academic treatment of the book of Zechariah that interact more directly with the Hebrew text, while those by Gregory, Webb, and Stead are more popular treatments.

# MALACHI

*Eric Ortlund*

## <span id="page-731-3"></span>INTRODUCTION TO MALACHI

## *Overview*

<span id="page-731-7"></span><span id="page-731-5"></span>Malachi addressed the covenant community of Israel during a time of great discouragement and disarray following its return from exile in Babylon. Although heirs of the prophetic promises of restoration, God's people lacked any sense of his love (1:2–5). Their worship was impure and dishonoring (1:6–2:9). Spiritual betrayal disrupted the community, especially its marriages (2:10–16). God's people neglected the tithe (3:6–12) and considered God's cause futile (2:17–3:5; 3:13–4:3). Malachi set about repairing the covenant relationship in two ways: by calling the community to renewed obedience to the Mosaic covenant, and by describing the coming "day of the Lord" (4:5; cf. 3:1–5; 4:1–3), when God would bring justice and restoration to his people.

## <span id="page-731-8"></span>*Author*

<span id="page-731-4"></span>We know nothing about Malachi except his name (1:1), which means "my messenger." Some have understood this as a title, but every other OT Prophetic Book begins with the prophet's name, so it is best to assume the same here. The book, which closes the OT prophetic canon, deflects all attention from the prophet toward the disputations between the Lord and his people.

## *Date and Occasion*

<span id="page-731-6"></span>We do not know the exact dates of Malachi's ministry. Since the Minor Prophets seem to be arranged in roughly chronological order, we can infer that he ministered after Haggai and Zechariah. The people have returned from exile and the temple has been rebuilt (cf. 1:10; the temple was rebuilt in 516 BC). The reference to a governor in 1:8 shows that the Persians were still in power. Malachi's addressing issues of concern to Ezra and Nehemiah may suggest they were contemporaries (cf. mixed marriages, Mal. 2:10–16 and Ezra 9:1–15; the tithe, Mal. 3:6–12 and Neh. 10:32; 13:10–14). However, it is also possible that these problems were perennial (Nehemiah ends with reforming mixed marriages [13:23–28], even though Ezra had already addressed this issue).

<span id="page-731-2"></span><span id="page-731-1"></span><span id="page-731-0"></span>The contents of Malachi make his motivating concerns easier to discern. Already in Nehemiah, the task of rebuilding the city physically and the people spiritually was daunting (cf. Neh. 1:3; 2:3, 17; 4:2; 5:1–5). Malachi's audience was <span id="page-732-8"></span>cynical: serving God seemed like drudgery, while spiritual rebels enjoyed the blessings God promised to his own (3:14–15). God seemed absent (2:17). Major aspects of proper worship in the old covenant were neglected, as if nothing of importance were at stake. The thought seemed to be, "If God does not care, why should we?"1 Malachi addresses this state of exhausted despair.

## *Genre and Literary Features*

Each of the six major sections of the book unfolds according to the same fourfold pattern: God lays a charge against his people concerning some failure in covenant, to which the people respond by asking how they have failed. The response always begins with "But you say" (which was perhaps not stated verbally—Malachi may be exposing only half-conscious resentment and resistance to God). The third step in this pattern shows God answering his people's question; the fourth closes each section with the Lord applying this answer, with warnings and promises for the future. For example, the first passage of the book begins with an initial statement from God, which is immediately questioned (1:2a). God answers by reaffirming his unmerited love for Israel (v. 2b) and his treatment of Edom according to his hatred of that nation (v. 3). The passage closes by promising the full outworking of this love and hatred in the future (vv. 4–5).

<span id="page-732-6"></span><span id="page-732-4"></span><span id="page-732-3"></span><span id="page-732-2"></span><span id="page-732-1"></span><span id="page-732-0"></span>Malachi does not use this form mechanically. Even in the passage mentioned above, the initial statement beginning verse 2 is not an accusation of negligence but a statement of love. Sometimes the people ask two questions (1:7; 3:7–8), while 2:10–14 shows two charges before the first question. Despite these variations, the form is consistent, because Malachi's purpose in each passage is the same. The initial charge brings to the surface the hidden sense of neglect and unfair treatment the postexilic community nursed toward God. The question-and-answer exchanges give the audience a chance to air their grievances and thus leaves them without argument, open to the surprising claims of the prophet. The final applications of each section inspire new hope by contradicting the audience's certainty. The disputation form is exactly suited to the resistance of Malachi's audience and its need of a new vision for the future.

## *Theology of Malachi*

<span id="page-732-5"></span>Malachi is a capable and practical theologian in his role of repairing the postexilic community's relationship with God according to the Mosaic covenant. For instance, in frequently addressing the priesthood, Malachi addresses them with reference to what they already know (1:8–9, 12–14; 2:5–7). Therefore, although he does not seem to advance our understanding of the priest's role in the OT, he masterfully applies it to his own setting.

<span id="page-732-7"></span>Malachi exhibits a number of significant insights into the character and action of God. As discussed in 2:10–16, Malachi explores God's intentions in, and the

<sup>1</sup> Douglas Stuart, "Malachi," in *The Minor Prophets*, ed. Thomas McComiskey, 3 vols. (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker, 2009), 3:1255.

<span id="page-733-3"></span><span id="page-733-1"></span>deeper significance of, marriage. God's grace as expressed in undeservedly good treatment of his people is a constant theme in the book. Malachi addresses none of the people's failures before first insisting on God's ancient love of his people (1:2). The book's second major section (1:6–2:9) shows that God intends his solemn warnings to establish and maintain the covenant so that the community can engage in the worship that will one day fill the earth (1:14). The day of the Lord passages show God taking the initiative to prepare his people through a messenger for his fiery appearance (3:2; 4:1). If God's people tithe, he will give everything he has in response (3:10). Indeed, even the disputation form itself is a sign of God's persistent pursuit of his people when they had given up on him (2:17; 3:13–15).

<span id="page-733-9"></span><span id="page-733-8"></span><span id="page-733-7"></span><span id="page-733-5"></span><span id="page-733-4"></span>God's action on the day of the Lord is treated in two significant passages focusing on the direct appearance of God to reestablish justice. In 2:17–3:5, the Lord spiritually refines his people by means of a messenger (3:2–4) before coming to establish justice (v. 5). The book's final passage more clearly describes the discriminating effects of God's judgment on that day (4:1–3) to show that whatever injustices his servants now suffer will be made up for abundantly on that day (3:17).

### <span id="page-733-11"></span>*Relationship to the Rest of the Bible and to Christ*

The Mosaic covenant — especially laws for priests and sacrifices — stands in the immediate background of many passages, but Malachi's engagement with these passages involves mainly their application. At a few points, however, Malachi extends or reapplies earlier texts and themes; for instance, the necessity of pure worship according to Mosaic legislation is set within the context of the worldwide worship of God in 1:8–14. The status of God's people as a "treasured possession" (Ex. 19:5) is reapplied to God-fearers within the Judahite community in Malachi 3:17.

<span id="page-733-10"></span><span id="page-733-2"></span><span id="page-733-0"></span>Malachi is clearly tied to Haggai and Zechariah as a third prophet speaking to God's people after their return from exile. While Haggai and Zechariah prophesy the rebuilding of the temple, however, Malachi addresses how the community must live as it enjoys worship there.

<span id="page-733-13"></span><span id="page-733-12"></span><span id="page-733-6"></span>Malachi suitably closes the OT prophetic corpus with his description of the day of the Lord, specifically Elijah's preparatory role (3:1; 4:5–6) before the Lord himself comes to his people (3:5; 4:2). The Gospels understand John the Baptist to have fulfilled this role of a second Elijah (Matt. 11:14; Mark 9:11; Luke 1:17). In this way, Malachi forms an important bridge between the Testaments and provides a means to appreciate fully the significance of God's coming to his people in the person of his Son.

#### *Preaching from Malachi*

Christian disciples in the new covenant occupy a redemptive-historical situation similar to that of Malachi's audience. Just as the Judahite community was heir to earlier prophetic promises of restoration, yet struggled with poverty and the difficulty of rebuilding their lives after the exile, so Christians often struggle

<span id="page-734-7"></span><span id="page-734-6"></span><span id="page-734-5"></span><span id="page-734-4"></span><span id="page-734-3"></span><span id="page-734-1"></span>with a sense of dissonance between their victory through Christ and the present reality of their lives. A sense of being unloved by God can set in (Mal. 1:2–4). Worship becomes a burden and we excuse laxness in it, forgetting God's greater purpose to fill the earth with his praise (1:6–14); giving is neglected, forgetting God's promise to bless generously (3:6–12). Pastors can (unintentionally or not) hinder and harm those under their charge (cf. v. 8 in 2:1–9). Unfaithfulness in marriage and frivolous divorce may be tolerated as a compensation for the difficulties of serving God (2:10–16). Finally, jealousy of those defying God might spark complaints of unfair treatment (2:17–3:5; 3:13–4:3). Malachi addresses each of these situations by reminding the people of what they already know (as taught by Moses) and looking forward to the day of the Lord. Christian pastors can apply Malachi's words to their own congregations by reminding them of what they already know of Jesus, who fulfills the pattern of priestly ministry and teaching established by Moses, and by directing their gaze forward, as we, "on whom the end of the ages has come" (1 Cor. 10:11), await the full flowering of God's action for us on that day.

## <span id="page-734-8"></span>*Interpretive Challenges*

Malachi does not present many interpretive challenges. Even the passages describing the day of the Lord, although naturally leaving many questions unanswered, are still clear with regard to what God will do "on the day when I act" (4:3) and what God's people can hope for.

<span id="page-734-2"></span><span id="page-734-0"></span>One ambiguity involves the relationship between priests and Levites in the book and in the postexilic period generally: although the Pentateuch separates Levitical duties from those of the priests (Numbers 3–4), Malachi speaks of them interchangeably (cf. 1:6; 2:1, 4–7). It is probably not helpful, however, to reconstruct the history of the Israelite priesthood on this difference alone. We simply do not know much about the history of the ancient Israelite priesthood.

<span id="page-736-6"></span>1 The oracle of the word of the Lord to Israel by Malachi.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>2</sup>** "I have loved you," says the Lord. But you say, "How have you loved us?" "Is not Esau Jacob's brother?" declares the Lord. "Yet I have loved Jacob **3**but Esau I have hated. I have laid waste his hill country and left his heritage to jackals of the desert." **<sup>4</sup>** If Edom says, "We are shattered but we will rebuild the ruins," the Lord of hosts says, "They may build, but I will tear down, and they will be called 'the wicked country,' and 'the people with whom the Lord is angry forever.' 1*Malachi* means *my messenger*

### *Section Overview*

God assures his people of his love for them and promises to put this love into action in his future treatment of Edom.

## *Section Outline*

- I. God's Love for Israel (1:1–5)
	- A. Charge: God's Love (1:1–2a)
	- B. Question: How Have You Loved Us? (1:2b)
	- C. Answer: God's Destruction of Edom (1:2c–3)
	- D. Application: The Future Destinies of Edom and Israel (1:4–5)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-736-8"></span><span id="page-736-5"></span><span id="page-736-2"></span><span id="page-736-0"></span>1:1 The first verse of the book does more than give information about its human author. Each word supports the divine origin and authority of the entire message. The word translated "oracle" frequently heads prophetic passages (e.g., Isa. 13:1; 15:1; 17:1) and means literally "burden" (Num. 4:47; 11:11), conveying a sense of urgency. This burden is further defined as a word from the Lord (cf. 2 Pet. 1:21) spoken by a human messenger. This word is the powerful proclamation of the King, effective in history to shape all events according to his will (Isa. 55:11; Jer. 1:9–10; 23:29). This word is addressed to Israel, even though in Malachi's day only the Judahite community remained. The postexilic community is heir to all God's promises to Israel.

<span id="page-736-7"></span><span id="page-736-4"></span><span id="page-736-3"></span><span id="page-736-1"></span>1:2a The first word God speaks through Malachi does not expose Israel's sin (unlike Isa. 1:2–3; Jer. 2:1–3; Ezek. 2:3–4) but rather declares his love (*'hb*) for <span id="page-737-9"></span><span id="page-737-5"></span><span id="page-737-1"></span>them. This word expresses both deep affection and loyalty in all types of human relationship (marriage, Gen. 24:67; parents and children, Gen. 25:28; close friends, 1 Sam. 20:17). It also recalls the Lord's ancient promises of love for Israel in the Pentateuch; God loved the earliest generations of Israelites and chose them (Deut. 4:37; 10:15), showing his love by blessing and multiplying them (Deut. 7:13). This love is sovereign and unconditional, existing for no reason beyond God's loving, faithful character. The perfect form of the verb expresses God's love as a total, complete act. God begins this book of disputations by declaring his unchanging and enduring love for his people.

<span id="page-737-14"></span><span id="page-737-0"></span>1:2b The word translated "how" sometimes refers to the external evidence that some action has happened or will have happened (Gen. 15:8; Ex. 33:16). Malachi's audience sees no visible evidence of the Lord's love for them. They feel entirely unloved—and, as we will see, this feeling was not totally without justification. But Malachi exposes their darkest suspicions about God in order to subvert those doubts.

<span id="page-737-15"></span><span id="page-737-4"></span><span id="page-737-3"></span><span id="page-737-2"></span>1:2c–3 Malachi challenges the people's claim of being unloved by returning them to the beginning of their history. Although the story of Jacob and Esau is complex (Genesis 25–36), and Esau appears spiritually insensitive on a number of occasions (25:29–34; 26:34–35; 28:6–9), Genesis shows that God's favor rested on Jacob before either boy was even born (25:23; cf. Rom. 9:10–13). Although their initial condition was the same, although the parties in question were equal (brothers), the Lord set his love on Jacob, not Esau, for no reason intrinsic to themselves. Because this love was unmerited, it is unchanging. From before their ancestor's birth, God has loved Israel. The imperfect form of the verb ending Malachi 1:2 implies God's ongoing love for Jacob, while the perfect verb beginning verse 3 shows his settled and unchanging opposition to Esau.

<span id="page-737-16"></span><span id="page-737-13"></span><span id="page-737-12"></span><span id="page-737-11"></span><span id="page-737-8"></span><span id="page-737-6"></span>Just as God's love implies both affection and loyalty, so hatred in the OT implies loathing and disgust (Ps. 119:163; Eccles. 2:18) as well as rejection and opposition (Ps. 26:5; Isa. 66:5; a wife less loved is "hated," Deut. 21:15). Israel may see no evidence of the Lord's love for her, but there was already abundant evidence of his hatred of Edom, as God made its hill country desolate. In the OT, mountains are often a symbol of fertility (Deut. 33:15; Pss. 50:10; 72:3) and strength and stability (Ps. 46:2; Isa. 54:10), yet this most solid and impressive aspect of Edom was withered, so that nothing could grow. In addition, Edom is disinherited; its inheritance (cf. Deut. 32:8–9) is given over to scavengers. The imagery of unclean animals living in a once-inhabited city or land is found elsewhere as an outcome of God's judgment (Ps. 44:19; Isa. 13:22; 34:13; Jer. 9:11; 10:22; 49:33). This image would have had sinister connotations for ancient Israelites, as if Edom had been given over to a dark spiritual power.

<span id="page-737-10"></span><span id="page-737-7"></span>It may seem strange or even offensive for God to prove his love for one nation by widespread destruction of another nation. But the Babylonian captivity was so traumatic and horrific a violation of God's people that Edom's joy at Israel's <span id="page-738-6"></span><span id="page-738-5"></span>destruction (Ps. 137:7) and its exploitation of Israel's vulnerability for its own gain (Ezek. 35:15; Obad. 10) echo across the pages of the OT prophets as profoundly perverse. (It is roughly equivalent to celebrating the rape of a family member.) God's judgment of Edom would not have been perceived as excessive.

<span id="page-738-7"></span>1:4 In seeking to convince his people of his abiding love for them, the Lord stifles a potential objection. While the Judahite economy was depressed in Malachi's day, Edom's fortunes looked to be on the rise ("we will rebuild")—it expected to recover as a nation. The Lord does not regard their capacity to rebuild as wishful thinking, but instead works out his hatred for Edom by destroying whatever progress they make. That Edom will be called "the wicked country" means that God will seal them in their sin in so public and obvious a way that no one will wonder why God judged this people.

<span id="page-738-0"></span>Edom's spiritual fate is described in two phrases: "wicked country" (lit., "wicked border") and "the people with whom the Lord is angry forever." These two phrases describe both territory and people, cause and effect in God's eternal judgment. The word for anger is parallel with "curse" in Numbers 23:7 and with God's "burning anger" in Psalm 69:24 and Zechariah 1:12. Edom forever lies under God's just and passionate anger because of its sin.

<span id="page-738-8"></span><span id="page-738-2"></span>1:5 The final verse of the passage concludes the description of God working out his hatred of Edom by turning to the way in which he works out his love for Israel. One might have expected God to assure Israel that it (in contrast to Edom) would be built up and would prosper, or that it would never be taken advantage of again. Instead, God's people are caught up in God's self-exaltation beyond their own borders.

<span id="page-738-3"></span>This short verse is deceptively simple and highly significant. That Israel will "see" reverses their earlier skepticism about God's love, when they claimed to have seen no evidence of that love (v. 2b). Now they will speak otherwise, visibly convinced. But their speech entirely concerns God and his glory, not themselves. God's greatness often is seen in his intervention on Israel's behalf (Pss. 92:5; 126:2–3) or on behalf of individuals within Israel (Pss. 35:17; 40:17; 86:11). To speak of God's greatness is to imply his glory (cf. Isa. 42:21) and exaltation (Ps. 99:2). In this brief phrase Malachi captures Israel's future astonishment at the Lord's visible glory as he works out justice in the earth.

<span id="page-738-4"></span><span id="page-738-1"></span>The worldwide implications of this exaltation should not be missed—God's greatness will be known "beyond" (lit. "above") the borders of Israel. The Lord's greatness is centered within the borders of his covenant people but is not limited to there. This is how God executes his love for his deeply discouraged and wronged people—he works out justice in the earth, to his great glory.

### *Response*

The Lord's confrontation of his people in the book of Malachi is difficult and unflinching. But before he exposes and challenges his people's many failures <span id="page-739-3"></span><span id="page-739-0"></span>before the law, he "confronts" them with the gospel of his love.2 It is possible to be unaware of being loved deeply by God. In Malachi's day, as Edom looked forward to improved national fortunes, it would have appeared as if it was getting away with ugly joy over its ancient relative's tragedy, even profiting at Judah's expense (Ps. 137:7; Ezek. 35:13; Obad. 10–14; this may partially be the background of the people's questions in Mal. 2:17 and 3:14–15), redoubling Judah's pain. God's judgment of Edom shows how seriously he takes the wrong done to his people and his commitment to justice for their sake. God's love will be seen, in part, in the eternal memorial he establishes to the wrong Edom has done to Judah ("they will be called 'the wicked country'"; 1:4). The final antidote to Judah's skepticism, however, will be a kind of self-forgetfulness as they are caught up in worship of a God who through his love and judgment demonstrates his greatness in all the world.

<span id="page-739-1"></span>In the same way, it is possible for an individual, a church, or God's people in a particular place and time to be convinced that they are unloved by God, and as a result to dishonor him through lax worship. This is especially likely to happen when God's people have suffered and God apparently does nothing about it. Malachi's words echo beyond their original context to assure us that, very soon, God's love and commitment to us will be visibly evident in a context as wide as creation. It is especially urgent for us new covenant believers to hear this assurance of God's love and of his commitment to exalt himself by working out justice, since we live in the shadow of the cross, where God displayed his perfect love and justice, pouring out on his son the wrath we deserved (v. 4). At the same time, this initial promise of the full outworking of God's love gives Malachi's warnings a weight they might not otherwise have. We, who have benefited and will benefit from God's determination to exalt himself in the earth, dare not refuse the one who is speaking to us (Heb. 12:25).
