#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-740-2"></span><span id="page-740-1"></span><span id="page-740-0"></span>The Lord challenges his people's careless and dishonoring worship (1:6–14) and the priests who lead it (2:1–9). God allows his people the opportunity to participate in his worship in all the earth (1:11, 14) by reforming their worship according to the standard of God's law.

## *Section Outline*

- II. God's Honor in Pure Worship (1:6–2:9)
	- A. Charge: The Priests Dishonor God's Name (1:6)
	- B. Question and Answer: Unclean Sacrifices (1:7–14)
		- 1. Analogy from Human Relationships (1:7–8)
- 2. Impossibility of Acceptance without Reform (1:9)
- 3. Uselessness of Further Worship (1:10)
- 4. God's Ultimate Goal in Worship (1:11)
- 5. Charge Repeated to the Whole People (1:12–14)
- C. Application: Priestly Reform (2:1–9)
	- 1. Warning of Curse Unless the Priests Repent (2:1–3)
	- 2. God's Intention in This Warning (2:4)
	- 3. God's Standards for Priests (2:5–7)
	- 4. The Priests' Present Failure (2:8–9)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-741-14"></span><span id="page-741-2"></span><span id="page-741-1"></span>1:6 Malachi argues from the lesser to the greater, beginning with what his audience would find indisputable. The honoring of fathers was written into Israel's covenant with the Lord (Ex. 20:12), and other passages suggest that to dishonor authority figures was seen as especially troubling and ugly (Ex. 21:17; 22:28). But if it is true that fathers and masters are to be honored, why is the greatest and truest Father and Master despised?

<span id="page-741-8"></span>In Malachi's context, these terms are not mere metaphors; father/son and master/servant language predominates in covenantal relationships (cf. 2 Sam. 7:14; 2 Kings 16:7). Other references to God's fatherhood and lordship within the context of his covenant relationship show how shocking this charge is.

<span id="page-741-12"></span><span id="page-741-11"></span><span id="page-741-7"></span><span id="page-741-6"></span><span id="page-741-0"></span>As Father, God is Israel's Creator (Deut. 32:6), who honors her by choosing her from all others for his own possession (vv. 8–9) and by caring for her superbly (vv. 10–14). Isaiah echoes this identification of God as Father and Creator (64:8), tying it to the role of Redeemer (63:16), who fights on Israel's behalf to liberate them from slavery and death and lead them into his *shalom* (Ex. 6:6; 15:13; repeatedly in Isaiah 40–55). This is the same Father who gently receives his penitent firstborn son (Jer. 31:9). Although references to God as Father are uncommon in the OT, the term is redolent of God's loving and abundant care for his people.

<span id="page-741-13"></span><span id="page-741-10"></span><span id="page-741-5"></span><span id="page-741-4"></span>In the OT, Yahweh is called Lord (*'adon*) much more frequently than Father. Two especially noteworthy instances are Deuteronomy 10:17 and Joshua 3:11–13. The first involves the privilege of Israel's election amid Yahweh's lordship over all creation (Deut. 10:14–15), calling for the deepest devotion on Israel's part (v. 16). It is not too much to call for the deep spiritual transformation captured in the metaphor of circumcision of the heart, because the object of that devotion is the Lord, "God of gods and Lord of lords" (v. 17). Joshua 3:11–13 speaks similarly of the ark of the covenant belonging to the "Lord of all the earth." The Lord's relation to Israel is maintained without being limited to his people.

<span id="page-741-9"></span><span id="page-741-3"></span>Since God is Father and Lord in his covenant with his people, it is appropriate that Israel fear and honor him. Fearing God is part of Israel's obeying, serving, and loving its covenant Lord (Deut. 10:12–13). Honoring God occurs amid exuberant worship (Pss. 22:23; 50:14; 86:9, 12). The Lord's confrontation of his people is far from an insecure, strutting tyrant demanding compliments from his officers.

<span id="page-742-11"></span><span id="page-742-4"></span>Nevertheless, the Lord's priests are treating him worse than they would a human authority. Although the people as a whole are guilty (cf. Mal. 1:14), the Lord singles out those who should be leading the congregation in honoring their Lord (cf. Lev. 10:3, where "those who are near" are priests protecting the sanctity of God's holiness so that his glory is not tarnished before the people). The priests are actually despising him—a strong word for the worst kind of scorn (in Num. 15:31, the person who despises God's word is to be cut off from Israel; note also how David is despised as a "worm" in Ps. 22:6). As the protectors of God's holy presence in his temple, the priests have regarded God and his presence as worthless and contemptible.

<span id="page-742-9"></span><span id="page-742-7"></span><span id="page-742-5"></span>1:7 The priests' question, "How does a defiled sacrifice defile you?" shows they have not understood the full significance of the table at which they minister and the presence before whom they stand. In the OT, the temple is God's own dwelling place, standing as a holy center amid a world corrupted by uncleanness, sin, and death. The temple is where Israel enjoys direct access to God's life-giving holiness. The altar plays an especially important role in God's gracious purposes for the temple as the place where sin is purged and atoned for (Lev. 1:4–10). The altar is Israel's escape—*from* its natural condition of deadly uncleanness *to* its participation in the Lord's holiness and in being set apart for his purposes.

<span id="page-742-3"></span><span id="page-742-2"></span>By bringing animals unfit for sacrifice (cf. Lev. 1:3; 22:22), the priests contradict and destroy the altar's atoning and sanctifying purposes. This mars God's holy presence in his temple and lessens the stature and fame found in forgiving and redeeming his people. Such worship treats as contemptible and worthless the name God made to dwell in his temple.

<span id="page-742-6"></span><span id="page-742-0"></span>The priest's despising of God's name may not have been fully conscious. Malachi's reference to the priests' "saying" the Lord's table may be despised could also be translated as "thinking" (this verb is used similarly in Gen. 17:17; 27:41; 1 Sam. 27:1; Ps. 10:6; Isa. 47:10). While it is possible the priests were broadcasting contempt for the altar, their questions make it more likely the Lord is exposing a half-conscious attitude of contempt toward their calling. Apparently Israel's sense of being unloved (Mal. 1:2) and abandoned by God (2:17) made them feel no great urgency to guard the integrity of their worship.

<span id="page-742-10"></span><span id="page-742-8"></span><span id="page-742-1"></span>Calling the altar a "table" and the animal sacrifices "bread" (ESV "food") is probably meant in part to mirror the meal offered political authorities in 1:8. It may also evoke the meals eaten to seal a covenant (e.g., Ex. 24:1–11). As with the language of "son" and "slave" in Malachi 1:6, the Mosaic covenant is present in the background and gives traction to the prophet's challenge.

1:8 Malachi now appeals to his audience's basic sense of right and wrong. Is it not obvious that blind, sick, or lame animals are insulting gifts? Not even a human authority would accept them. Malachi's question is not merely rhetorical; carved reliefs on the palace of Darius I show processions of servants bringing food and livestock to the king.

<span id="page-743-6"></span><span id="page-743-4"></span>1:9 Unlike in English, imperatives in Hebrew distinguish between individuals and groups being commanded. The command in this verse is plural, and since this passage focuses on priests, they are likely being told to intercede on the people's behalf (cf. Samuel's role in 1 Sam. 13:8–13). Strikingly, Malachi asks for intercession for "us." The prophet identifies himself with those who stand to benefit or suffer from the priests' ministry.

On its own, this command could be taken to show the great need for God's mercy amid his people's failure. The question that concludes the verse, however, shows that Malachi's command is sarcastic: when these kinds of gifts are offered, pleas for mercy will be ignored by God. Malachi implies that the sacrifices accompanying these intercessions are invalid as well. God will not meet with them until their worship is reformed.

<span id="page-743-3"></span><span id="page-743-2"></span><span id="page-743-1"></span>Even more sobering is Malachi's inversion of the Aaronic blessing (Num. 6:24–26) in this verse and elsewhere in this passage: (1) blessing from Numbers 6:24 turns to curse in Malachi 2:2; (2) the phrase "show favor" in 1:9 is literally "lift the face," echoing the Lord's uplifted face in blessing in Numbers 6:26; (3) the same term for the shining of God's face (Num. 6:25) is used for the cessation of kindling fire on the altar in Malachi 1:10.3 In these allusions, Malachi is implying that the ancient blessing that priests were privileged to pronounce has been voided by their despising of God's name. For an Israelite priest, the loss would have been severe.

<span id="page-743-7"></span><span id="page-743-5"></span>1:10 Malachi further probes the consequences of the priests' failure to honor God in their ministry. His desire in this verse would have been painful and shocking to his original audience, but it follows naturally from verses 7–9: not only is the priest's ministry useless, but the entire sacrificial system, which God commanded, might as well be shut down. Malachi leaves his audience no room for evasion, no hope that their present worship might somehow continue. The God they are to honor with their worship would rather the sanctuary doors be shut, the building unlit by any sacrificial fire, quiet and empty, in order to stop the insulting offerings.

<span id="page-743-0"></span>The Lord's rejection is total; he has no delight in the priests and will accept no offering from them. The term "accept" often signals the conditions by which an offering is pleasing to the Lord (e.g., Lev. 1:4; 7:18; 19:7), but these conditions are now absent. As worship is currently being practiced, no sacrifice is acceptable.

<span id="page-743-10"></span><span id="page-743-9"></span><span id="page-743-8"></span>1:11 The unintended consequences of the priests' careless worship are sobering and serious, but God will lay out terms of repentance in 2:1–9 by which worship can continue. Before laying out these terms, however, and before turning to the guilt of the people as a whole in 1:12–14, the Lord sets the priest's failure in the largest context possible—a context both jarring and hopeful. God reveals in this verse his determination to win the whole world for his worship, and he shows how the priests' unworthy worship impedes his ultimate purpose for all creation.

<sup>3</sup> Michael Fishbane, *Biblical Interpretation in Ancient Israel* (New York: Clarendon, 1985), 333.

<span id="page-744-19"></span>But he also hints, in connection with the terms of reformation in 2:1–9, that the priests can be included in this ever-expanding praise as God claims the nations for his worship.

<span id="page-744-7"></span><span id="page-744-4"></span><span id="page-744-0"></span>The "rising of the sun to its setting" includes all the earth (cf. Ps. 113:3) no corner of creation will be left silent. The reference to God's great name echoes the priests' despising of his name in Malachi 1:6 and includes elements of both glory and fear. God's fame and stature will be great and glorious among all the nations, and they will respond with worship superior to that of God's own priests. The "incense" and "clean offering" recall directives from the Pentateuch for pleasing worship (cf. Ex. 30:1 for incense and Leviticus 2 for the grain offering, which Malachi references here) and represent the conversion of the nations to the Lord's cause and their entering into covenant with him. The prophets portray the conversion of the nations as a final stage in the Lord's redemption of all things (Isa. 2:1–5; 66:18–24; Amos 9:11–12; Zech. 14:16–21). The priests are presently opposing this glorious vision, but God will allow them to join in as well.

<span id="page-744-15"></span><span id="page-744-14"></span><span id="page-744-11"></span><span id="page-744-10"></span><span id="page-744-9"></span><span id="page-744-8"></span><span id="page-744-6"></span><span id="page-744-5"></span>1:12–14 Malachi reapplies his charge of insulting and unworthy worship (vv. 12– 13), includes the people at large in this charge (v. 14a), and again looks to the final glorious goal of worship (v. 14b). The connection between the present dishonor of God's name and its future glory is made explicit at the beginning of verse 12, as Malachi simply speaks of "it," the name that will one day be great. Malachi fills out the charge against the priests by altering his language: while verse 7 shows the priests despising God's name by despising the Lord's table, they now defile and lessen and "de-glorify" the holiness of God's name ("profane") by regarding the Lord's table as polluted (the same term describing the polluted bread in v. 7). God's worship is, in the priests' eyes, contemptible and dirty, a chore at which they turn up their noses (v. 13). The reduced and impoverished state of the postexilic community may have informed this attitude (Ezra 3:12), but the Lord shows that such an attitude, reflected in unclean sacrifice, reflects badly on the One they are worshiping. Once again the Lord refuses such worship (Mal. 1:13).

<span id="page-744-13"></span><span id="page-744-12"></span><span id="page-744-3"></span><span id="page-744-1"></span>The reference to bringing an offering (v. 13) moves the spotlight to the ordinary worshiper (cf. the same verb in Lev. 2:8). Any Israelite who brings an unworthy offering is warned of the same curse (Mal. 1:14) as the one falling on unrepentant priests (the word is repeated in 2:2).

<span id="page-744-20"></span>Malachi finishes this section by recalling 1:11, adding that God's name will be feared (echoing v. 6) as King.

<span id="page-744-18"></span><span id="page-744-17"></span><span id="page-744-16"></span><span id="page-744-2"></span>2:1–2 Malachi returns to the present and shows the priests how they can align themselves with the future glory of 1:11, 14. The command of 2:1 could refer to covenant stipulations (as in Deut. 28:45; 30:16), following a number of other references to the Mosaic covenant in this passage. However, the exact wording of Malachi 2:1–3 does not refer back clearly to any part of the Mosaic covenant, instead calling on the priests to give glory to God's name, echoing 1:6, 11, 14. Thus this commandment most likely contains the present conditions for repentance:

<span id="page-745-3"></span>honor God's name by reforming worship practices and bringing right sacrifices. (For a construction similar to 2:2, cf. Deut. 28:15.)

<span id="page-745-2"></span>The curse of Malachi 2:2 continues the allusions to Deuteronomy 28, where the Lord lays out judgment for covenant unfaithfulness. Unless these priests attend deeply to Malachi's message, they stand to lose everything in their relationship with God. The plural "blessings" is comprehensive: whatever they enjoy in the Promised Land, redeemed from exile, they can lose. The phrasing is clipped, but this brief reminder of Deuteronomy 28 impresses upon Malachi's audience the gravity with which the Lord lays out these conditions. The verse closes with a surprise: the curses for their covenant failure are already coming into effect but are failing to break the people's stubborn refusal to reform their worship. Such reform will require an explicit warning from the Lord and an explanation of the already active curse.

<span id="page-745-11"></span><span id="page-745-4"></span>2:3 The form of this verse emphasizes the imminence of this curse (the same form is used for the messenger and his preparatory role in 3:1). The "offspring" God rebukes rightly interprets Hebrew "seed" as referring to children (cf. Deut. 28:46, 59). Without a new generation, the postexilic community itself would have disappeared. While the verbs "cut off" or "diminish" would appropriately express God's action here, "rebuke" has connotations of angry opposition (Ps. 9:5; Isa. 54:9; Zech. 3:2). Without reformation, nothing from the Lord but anger lies ahead for the postexilic community.

<span id="page-745-9"></span><span id="page-745-6"></span><span id="page-745-5"></span><span id="page-745-1"></span>The second clause of the verse is deliberately repugnant, especially to priests, as the "dung" (i.e., internal organs) of sacrifices was typically burned outside the camp (Lev. 4:11–12). This implies that the ritual purity the sacrifices provide is being reversed: God will use the priests' sacrifices to make them even dirtier. The last clause of the verse is cryptic: "You shall be taken away with it" (Mal. 2:3) could be translated more literally, "It (or possibly "He") shall bear you to it." It is not entirely clear who or what is being borne away, but as the priests are in view in this verse, the ESV is probably correct in understanding the priests as being carried off. Just as dung is brought outside the camp to be deposited far from God's holy presence, so the unresponsive priests of Malachi's day will be treated like the refuse of their offerings.

<span id="page-745-10"></span><span id="page-745-8"></span><span id="page-745-7"></span><span id="page-745-0"></span>2:4 The particular verb form beginning verse 4 (perfect consecutive) suggests that the inescapable knowledge of "this command" occurs after the judgment of verse 3. Prior to the purpose clause ("that my covenant . . . may stand"), this knowledge appears entirely negative, occurring only after the threatened curse has come into effect (cf. the knowledge of the Egyptians in Ex. 7:5; 14:4). But the end of the verse suggests the opposite: the command to give glory to God in worship intends to maintain God's covenant first made with the priests' great ancestor. In other words, since the entirety of the priesthood is under censure in this passage, the threatened curse of Malachi 2:2–3 would stop temple worship and force the priesthood out of service. But God's larger aim in issuing the command of verse 1 is a happier one.

Malach i 1:6–2:9 746

While the warning is real, God's ultimate intention is to restore the covenant with his priests so that his worship can one day spread throughout the whole world.

<span id="page-746-0"></span>The reference to a covenant with Levi raises some questions, since there is no passage explicitly narrating the making of a covenant with any of Jacob's sons. The most likely candidate is the Lord's covenant with Phineas, a descendant of Levi through Aaron (Num. 25:10–13; the wording in Mal. 2:4–5 is similar to Num. 25:12); other candidates include Jeremiah 33:21 ("my covenant with the Levitical priests") and possibly Deuteronomy 33:9.

<span id="page-746-10"></span><span id="page-746-9"></span><span id="page-746-3"></span><span id="page-746-1"></span>2:5–7 Malachi reminds the priests of God's original intentions and standards in the covenant cited in verse 4. He begins by describing God's aim to communicate life and peace to his priests (v. 5). He then speaks of how a priest ideally should speak and act toward those under his care (v. 6). Verse 7 speaks more generally of the qualities a priest needs.

<span id="page-746-12"></span><span id="page-746-7"></span>The first sentence of verse 5 might more literally be translated, "My covenant was with him—life and peace." Cause and effect are identified for rhetorical effect. God's intention in his covenant with the priests was the fullness of life and blessed peace that only he can give. Joined to these gifts is the awestruck reverence every spiritual leader needs ("fear" recalls 1:6, and "my name" recalls 1:11, 14). In fact, the syntax of the verse implies that even the priest's fear of God is a gift: the ESV appropriately expands Malachi's clipped expression, which literally reads, "And I gave them [i.e., life and peace] to him; fear, and he feared me." Fear is the final covenantal gift from God.

<span id="page-746-11"></span><span id="page-746-8"></span><span id="page-746-4"></span>Malachi then addresses the priest's teaching ministry (cf. Lev. 10:11; Deut. 33:10), his relationship with God, and its blessed consequence of saving many from sin (Mal. 2:6). "True instruction" implies factual correctness (avoiding the errors of 1:8, 13) and reliability as a basis on which those under the priest's charge could guide their lives. This teaching is also morally upright, as the contrast between the first two clauses of the verse shows. Furthermore, a priest should walk with God in integrity and thus enjoy *shalom*, the fullness and richness God intends for his creatures. Such ministry will save many from sin and the corruption and death that inevitably follow. The priests of Malachi's day had fallen far below God's standard.

<span id="page-746-2"></span>In verse 7 Malachi turns to a general affirmation of the role of the priest, its expected response, and the reason for both. In speaking of the priest's "guarding knowledge," Malachi fills out the priest's role. This verb often describes a stubborn attention to the terms of God's covenant (e.g., Deut. 4:2, 6, 9). A priest should jealously attend to the body of knowledge and practice entrusted to them in covenant for the good of God's people. The happy result will be that many will eagerly seek such a priest's instruction, for the priest is the very messenger of God.

<span id="page-746-13"></span><span id="page-746-6"></span><span id="page-746-5"></span>2:8 The priests of Malachi's day had forsaken the Lord's design for the priesthood. The verb "turn away" often signals a serious act of spiritual unfaithfulness (e.g., Jer. 5:23). Two consequences follow: the ministers God has appointed to save many from sin and to help them run in the way of God's commandments (Ps. 119:32)

<span id="page-747-1"></span><span id="page-747-0"></span>are instead causing them to stumble. This stumbling implies that the priests are actively preventing the people under their charge from obeying (the same verb describes unambiguous military defeat in 2 Chron. 25:8 and total moral defeat in Prov. 24:16; Isa. 8:15). Second, the priests are destroying the very means of grace that gave them their ministry: the covenant; the spiritual constitution of God's people. While this was not the priests' intention, it was nevertheless the consequence of their attitude toward God and the temple, reflected in the kind of sacrifices they offered.

<span id="page-747-10"></span><span id="page-747-9"></span><span id="page-747-4"></span>2:9 Although the Lord has already promised the covenant curses (vv. 2–3), the passage concludes with a description of the consequences of and justification for this curse. As the priests treat God as worthless and despised (1:7), so they themselves will be treated; their fate will be proportionate to their sin ("inasmuch as"). This judgment will not be private; as their dishonoring ministry occurs in public, so their humbling will occur before all the people. Showing partiality in instruction is a symptom of their defection from God's way.

### *Response*

<span id="page-747-3"></span>This passage is obviously relevant for pastors and all who lead Christian worship. But before turning to ourselves and our ministry, let us consider how we see in this passage an anticipation of that greater and perfect Priest, that true Son and perfect servant who fulfills every condition God lays out. It is Jesus who offers worship that fully honors God (1:6); it is Jesus who offers an utterly worthy sacrifice (v. 8) that God delightedly accepts (v. 9). He is the ultimate pastor-teacher, who saves many from sin (2:6–7). In Christ, Malachi's vision of worldwide worship (1:11, 14) comes true. And in Christ we are delivered from our natural yet irrational dissatisfaction with God that dishonors him and inevitably brings his curse (2:1–3). When we are alert to all that God has given us in his Son, it is especially difficult to find worship of him wearying or beneath our dignity (1:13).

<span id="page-747-8"></span><span id="page-747-7"></span><span id="page-747-6"></span>And yet, it may be that a pastor or worship leader is called to minister in a context that falls far below their hopes or expectations for their own career. Perhaps a difficult season of life leaves one dull and dissatisfied with God; perhaps the sheer weariness of months and years spent in service creates an unnoticed, dishonoring sloppiness in our worship. In these and other possible situations, it is easy to engage in the new covenant equivalent of offering lame and sick animals, thus tarnishing the glory of God before our congregation. Any attitude that considers God's service unworthy or not requiring our very best efforts reflects this sin.

<span id="page-747-11"></span><span id="page-747-5"></span><span id="page-747-2"></span>Malachi ministers to spiritual leaders under the new covenant in several ways in this passage. First, he exalts our weekly worship (1:11, 14), setting it in the glorious context of all creation's resounding with God's praise (Rev. 5:11–14). He also—sternly but not unlovingly—shows us God's refusal to lessen his own greatness by accepting unworthy worship (Mal. 1:9, 13). God's care for his own name—and for us—is too great (cf. Ezek. 36:22–23). Malachi warns us that God <span id="page-748-4"></span><span id="page-748-3"></span><span id="page-748-2"></span><span id="page-748-0"></span>can take away the benefits of a relationship with him if we stubbornly continue to be dissatisfied with him (2:1–3) and regard his worship as an embarrassment (1:7, 12). Malachi also gives us the opportunity to be rigorously honest about our failures in worship and in leading others in it, and shows us a God happy to reinstate us to his worship if we repent and glorify his name (2:2). Malachi assures us that God's warnings are meant to restore us (2:3–4). We see, furthermore, that God is not introducing a new, impossible standard when confronting his people's unworthy worship. Just as Malachi calls the people back to Mosaic prescriptions for worship, new covenant believers can turn again to NT descriptions of a healthy church (e.g., 1 Thess. 5:12–22; 2 Tim. 2:14–26; Titus 1:5–16). Finally, we learn the sobering truth that it is possible for God to shut down a worshiping community that continues to dishonor him (Mal. 1:10).

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-748-5"></span>Betrayal is the key word of this passage (2:10, 11, 14, 16). Malachi addresses the ways in which mixed marriages and easy divorce fracture the spiritual unity of God's people.

## *Comment*

<span id="page-749-6"></span>2:10–11 Malachi begins by contrasting the Judahites sins against each other with God's unchanging character. As in 1:6, Malachi invokes God as Father and Creator to show his attentive care, both in the present and at his people's creation. Malachi twice tells us that Judah's Father and Creator is "one," emphasizing the uniqueness and distinctiveness of Judah's God (Deut. 6:4; cf. the use of "one" in Song 6:9). The passage also creates a context in which Judahite betrayal appears all the more stark.

<span id="page-749-7"></span><span id="page-749-5"></span><span id="page-749-3"></span><span id="page-749-2"></span>"Betrayal" is not too strong a word for the verb rendered by "faithless" (Mal. 2:10–11; cf. Judg. 9:23; Prov. 11:3). The bonds of those under the covenant care of one Father should be inviolable, yet betrayal is pervasive in the postexilic community: Malachi says (lit.) "Each one betrays his brother," nationwide (Mal. 2:11). No individual in Malachi's audience can excuse himself from this rupture in which the entire community is implicated.

Finally, at the end of verse 11, we learn the nature of this betrayal: mixed marriages. Malachi has heightened his audience's expectation by delaying this information. Was it because such marriages were not regarded as problematic that Malachi overloads his expressions of covenant infidelity before revealing their source? Is Malachi helping his audience recalibrate their sensitivities before God in order to recognize an ugly betrayal where they saw none?

<span id="page-749-1"></span>Marriage with a member of another people group is problematic in the OT not because of the different race or ethnicity of the spouse but because of the competing spiritual commitments that person would bring to the marriage (cf. Deut. 7:3; Lev. 18:24–25 and its context; but note the exception of the marriage of the Moabite Ruth to Boaz because of her devotion to the Lord, Ruth 1:16). It is exactly this issue Malachi focuses on at the end of 2:11: the problem is not foreignness as such, but devotion to a foreign god. Such a spouse has a different spiritual father.

<span id="page-749-4"></span><span id="page-749-0"></span>Malachi calls such marriages a violation and sacrilege of the covenant (v. 10). The devotion and attention involved in marriage to a woman with other spiritual commitments betrays other Israelites by compromising the people's holy status as set apart for God's service and purposes. Furthermore, the sanctuary Yahweh loves, the sacred place where God and man meet, is desecrated by these marriages. This is the "abomination"; the same word describes the Canaanites' defiling the land in Leviticus 18:22, 26–30.

<span id="page-750-2"></span><span id="page-750-1"></span>The phrase "covenant of our fathers" does not distinguish a specific covenant (the phrase is used for the covenant with Abraham in Deut. 4:31; 7:12–14; 8:18; and for the covenant at Sinai in 2 Kings 17:15; Jer. 34:13). The phrase further binds the covenant community together: under one divine father, generations of Israelites have been keeping covenant with God. Thus mixed marriages damage the community's relationship not only with its God and its present members but also with its past. Spiritually faithless marriages have far-reaching consequences that Malachi's audience had probably not considered.

<span id="page-750-5"></span>Malachi includes himself in the question of 2:10 ("Why then are *we* faithless?") not because he had engaged in this betrayal but because he speaks as part of the community. It would be especially hypocritical for a prophet seeking to repair the unity of God's people to stand above and outside that community, condemning its faithlessness.

<span id="page-750-6"></span><span id="page-750-4"></span>2:12 Without an intervening question (as in 1:2, 6, etc.), Malachi moves directly to God's judgment on mixed marriages: as these Israelites have betrayed the covenant community, they will be excluded from it. The verb "cut off" (a form of *krt*) is frequently used in the Pentateuch for excommunication from the covenant community (and even for execution) for various transgressions (e.g., regarding the Passover in Ex. 12:15 or the peace offering in Lev. 7:20). The phrase "who brings an offering" shows that this curse falls on those who continue to participate in the worship of the covenant community as if no wrong has been done (this is exactly the situation in Neh. 13:23–31).

<span id="page-750-3"></span><span id="page-750-0"></span>The ESV's "any descendant" renders a confusing Hebrew phrase, "one who wakes and answers." Some understand this as a merism (a figure of speech expressing totality using contrasting parts), the point being that the Lord will cut off every last man who participates in mixed marriages; but since "wake" and "answer" are not obvious opposites, this is unlikely. Another possible translation is "protector and oppressor," another merism. A very slight change in the Hebrew (from *ʻer* to *ʻed*) would yield either "a witness or respondent" (another merism) or "a witness who answers," perhaps speaking of those who participate in such marriages. The ESV follows the Syriac and Aramaic translations here; if this is the correct reading, it fits well with Malachi 2:15. The meaning of the verse as a whole is clear whatever option one takes.

<span id="page-750-9"></span><span id="page-750-7"></span>2:13 In addition to this abomination, the Judahites commit a second sin: weeping and groaning because God no longer accepts their sacrifices. The Judahites probably thought highly of their pious grief, but the Lord rejects it as another failure in the covenant relationship. Although the people cannot seem to make the obvious connection, Malachi clarifies for them that the Lord refuses to receive covenantal worship as long as betrayal in marriage continues.

<span id="page-750-8"></span>2:14 Malachi varies the charge slightly from mixed marriages to divorce. (Although it is possible Judahite wives were being abandoned for foreign ones, the passage <span id="page-751-2"></span>does not make this connection explicit.) The divorced wife is described in three ways: "the wife of your youth," "your companion," and (lit.) "the wife of your covenant" (ESV, "your wife by covenant"). These terms intensify the betrayal involved in unnecessary divorce: it destroys a relationship with an ally and close friend that has existed for years (cf. the use of the word that is here translated "companion," in Judg. 20:11; Pss. 94:20; 119:63). The husband has entered into covenant with this woman—the most solemn formalizing of a relationship available to an ancient Israelite. The use of "covenant" echoes Malachi 2:10, and with this repetition Malachi helps his audience understand the far-reaching implications of these divorces.

<span id="page-751-4"></span><span id="page-751-0"></span>Finally, it should be noted that the Lord "was witness" on behalf of the abandoned wife. This verb is used for solemn testimony or warning when a serious wrong is alleged (cf. Deut. 8:19; Neh. 13:15; Amos 3:13). The Lord takes up the cause of these women, who had limited options to redress the wrong done to them.

<span id="page-751-7"></span><span id="page-751-5"></span>2:15–16 Malachi sets these divorces within the context of God's original intention for marriage, but the Hebrew is brief to the point of being cryptic. The first clause of verse 15 could be translated in a number of ways: "Not one acts (thus)," "Did not one make?" or "Did he not make (them) one?" The subsequent clauses could be woodenly rendered "And a portion of spirit to him [or "it"]. And what was the one seeking? Seed of God." Although the first clause might be saying that no one with a portion of God's spirit (or understanding) would act in this way regarding marriage, the ESV correctly interprets God as the subject of each clause: just as God's people as a whole are bound together by their one God and Father, so God makes a human couple one and seals their unity by giving a portion of his Spirit to "it," i.e., their oneness in marriage. God's intention is godly seed, a new generation of covenant believers. Marriage is defined by the one God in covenant with his (ideally) unified people, who (ideally) produce many offspring who continue in the spiritually unified covenant community. Divorce betrays this.

<span id="page-751-8"></span><span id="page-751-6"></span><span id="page-751-3"></span><span id="page-751-1"></span>Malachi closes the passage by calling for an end to all such frivolous divorces. The men initiating these divorces are to guard themselves in their own spirit (v. 15b). The focus changes from God's spirit to ours. Malachi warns Judahite husbands to protect themselves at the deepest level of their being against this kind of betrayal. Such great caution is needed because of God's strong opposition to divorce, aroused because of the violence caused by it (v. 16). (The point is the same regardless of which reading one accepts; cf. ESV mg.) To "cover one's garment with violence" may have a number of implications: perhaps hiding the violence committed against the wife, or completely contaminating the husband (cf. Ps. 73:6). Malachi may also be playing on the image of a man covering with his garment the woman he intends to marry (Deut. 22:30; Ruth 3:9; Ezek. 16:8), implying that an action of protection and commitment has been twisted into an act of violence. Such sin must not only stop—it is to be guarded against vigilantly.

### *Response*

In a deeply counterintuitive way, Malachi shows his audience how sins perhaps considered private fracture the community of which we are a part. Malachi connects the horizontal and vertical dimensions of our relationships within the sphere of the desired holiness of God's covenant people. When a member of the covenant commits himself to someone with a different spiritual father, or frivolously divorces his Christian spouse, he violates the covenant, betrays his Christian brothers and sisters who share in that covenant relationship, and sullies the place where we meet with God (2:10–11). God cares enough about our marriages to reject worship from his children who commit these betrayals (v. 13; cf. 1 Pet. 3:7). His judgment falls on those who do not repent of these sins (Mal. 2:12).

<span id="page-752-3"></span><span id="page-752-2"></span><span id="page-752-1"></span><span id="page-752-0"></span>In ancient Israel, the holiness of the temple and the people who worshiped there was not an abstraction. The Lord communicated his own heavenly beauty and moral uprightness to his people by sanctifying them (Lev. 19:2; 20:22–26) worship in the temple was a taste of heaven on earth! One part of that ideal vision extends to marriage within the covenant community. Although the tone of the passage is solemn and the warning serious, the intention is to guard a happy, fruitful community under the care of one Father, with undivided loyalties toward him as those who could become vulnerable to the financial, social, and emotional damage of divorce are kept safe.

<span id="page-752-6"></span><span id="page-752-5"></span>Without obscuring the severity of Malachi's warnings, it is appropriate to read them within the larger context of Scripture. The NT clarifies the greater spiritual mystery human marriage symbolizes: Christ's marriage to his church (Eph. 5:32). But unlike human husbands, Jesus Christ is perfectly faithful to his bride. Christ's perfect marriage to his church creates a context of grace within which reconciliation can be sought for a frivolous divorce that did not fall within those few situations in which the NT allows divorce (Matt. 19:9; 1 Cor. 7:10–16).

**<sup>17</sup>**You have wearied the Lord with your words. But you say, "How have we wearied him?" By saying, "Everyone who does evil is good in the sight of the Lord, and he delights in them." Or by asking, "Where is the God of justice?"

3"Behold, I send my messenger, and he will prepare the way before me. And the Lord whom you seek will suddenly come to his temple; and the messenger of the covenant in whom you delight, behold, he is coming, says the Lord of hosts. **2**But who can endure the day of his coming, and who can stand when he appears? For he is like a refiner's fire and like

fullers' soap. **3**He will sit as a refiner and purifier of silver, and he will purify the sons of Levi and refine them like gold and silver, and they will bring offerings in righteousness to the Lord. *<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>4</sup>**Then the offering of Judah and Jerusalem will be pleasing to the Lord as in the days of old and as in former years.

**<sup>5</sup>** "Then I will draw near to you for judgment. I will be a swift witness against the sorcerers, against the adulterers, against those who swear falsely, against those who oppress the hired worker in his wages, the widow and the fatherless, against those who thrust aside the sojourner, and do not fear me, says the Lord of hosts."

1Or *and they will belong to the Lord, bringers of an offering in righteousness*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-753-3"></span><span id="page-753-1"></span>The Lord responds to his people's complaint about injustice and his apparent favor for moral rebels (2:17) by promising swift and direct judgment (3:5). The bulk of the passage describes the preparation of the people for this act of judgment (vv. 1–4). On God's initiative, a messenger is sent (v. 1) to purify the priests (vv. 2–3) and the people's worship (v. 4). Only then can God draw near for justice (v. 5) without his people also being consumed (v. 2).

#### <span id="page-753-4"></span><span id="page-753-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-753-2"></span>IV. The God of Justice and the Coming Messenger (2:17–3:5)
	- A. Charge, Question, Answer: The Lord's Weariness with His People's Cynicism (2:17)
	- B. Application: The Day of the Lord (3:1–5)
		- 1. The Messenger (3:1)
		- 2. The Messenger's Refining Ministry (2:2–4)
		- 3. God's Arrival for Judgment (3:5)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-753-5"></span>2:17 Here and in 3:13–14, Malachi begins his prophecy not with a direct statement from God to his people but by expressing God's weariness and disgust toward his people's speech about him. Although texts in Job and the Psalms are refreshingly open about the problem of delayed judgment, no other doubts about divine justice are as forceful as those voiced here. The community is not just suspicious about the nature or timing of God's judgment; it is blasphemously insisting God is actively pleased with those who fearlessly oppress others and violate his commands (cf. the longer description of these sins in v. 5). The normal categories of good and evil have been inverted, with God supposedly on the wrong side. Although it is easy to imagine jealous glances toward those who ignored God and seemed much happier for it (whether inside or outside the Judahite community) amid the difficulties of rebuilding the postexilic community, it is still shocking to hear this complaint from God's own people.

<span id="page-754-7"></span><span id="page-754-6"></span>3:1–5 Having registered his disgust at his people's despair, the Lord speaks no other word against them but answers their complaint as completely as possible. He points to his messenger (vv. 1–4), who will purify the priests when he personally appears to execute justice (v. 5).

<span id="page-754-2"></span><span id="page-754-0"></span>3:1 The Lord announces the sending of his messenger to prepare his way. The phrase "Behold, I send" recalls other royal pronouncements of sending messengers, human or otherwise, to execute justice (Ex. 8:21; Isa. 6:8; Jer. 43:10; Joel 2:19). Three times the verse emphasizes the immediacy of this action, twice with "Behold!" and once with "suddenly." The question "Where is the God of justice?" (Mal. 2:17) is already being answered—but not without irony. The repetition of "delight" from 2:17 is sarcastic, as the people in 2:17 were certainly not delighting in the Lord. Their cynicism is sarcastically described as "delighting in" and "seeking after" the Lord—who, because of his people's unbelief, is coming quickly.

<span id="page-754-10"></span><span id="page-754-4"></span><span id="page-754-1"></span>The messenger's purpose is to prepare the Lord's way as he personally draws near for judgment (3:5). The exact form of this preparation is described in verses 2–4 and strongly echoes Exodus 23:20 and Isaiah 40:3. Although the context is different from these earlier passages—the former speaks of God's angelic guidance as the people enter the Promised Land; the latter of his approach to escort his people back to the land after exile—all three concern God's ultimate goal of being directly present with his people, with all the blessed effects this implies.

<span id="page-754-9"></span><span id="page-754-5"></span><span id="page-754-3"></span>In the first sentence of Malachi 3:1, the Lord and his messenger are easy to distinguish. Through the end of verse 4, however, it becomes more difficult to discern the identity or number of those being described. The word *'adon*, translated as "the Lord" in the second sentence of verse 1, could possibly refer to a human master (the same word is used in both senses in 1:6). Additionally, it is possible that "my messenger" is distinguished from "the messenger of the covenant." As a result, it is possible that there are three distinct "messengers" at work in this verse: "my messenger," the "lord" as an authority figure, and "the messenger of the covenant."

Four considerations bring the passage into focus. First, *'adon* with the definite article always refers to the Lord elsewhere, so it makes best sense to understand it thus here; further, only the Lord can come to "his" temple. Second, the "messenger of the covenant" is probably the same as "my messenger"—if two different servants are intended, it would be odd to designate them with the same term (*mal'ak*). Third, the messenger and the Lord are to be distinguished. In the world of the OT, although a royal messenger speaks in the name and authority of the king, he is always distinct from him. Fourth, since God does not speak in the first person until 3:5, and no new actor is introduced in verses 2–4, it is best to understand verses 2–4 as the work of the messenger of the covenant.

<span id="page-754-8"></span>Against this interpretation is the use of divine terms to describe the messenger's appearance and work. Taken out of context, the question of verse 2 could easily be attributed to the Lord himself. Who else could spiritually refine God's people but their God? However, significant ambiguous overlap between the Lord and his <span id="page-755-0"></span>messenger occurs often in the OT (cf. Gen. 16:7–13; Ex. 23:20). The messenger's work is so closely identified with God's that they are described in virtually synonymous ways. This is probably why this messenger is described with the unique phrase "messenger of the covenant": he comes to repair the covenant relationship.

<span id="page-755-8"></span><span id="page-755-3"></span>3:2–4 The implicit answer to the question beginning verse 2 is "No one." On his own, no one is able to withstand the day of this messenger's appearing. The prophets very frequently describe God's swift-approaching theophany to judge evil in terms of burning fire (out of many examples, cf. Isa. 5:24; 9:17–18; 66:15–16), symbolizing his intensity, inner purity, and consuming passion to obliterate evil. Far from delighting in evildoers (Mal. 2:17), the Lord implies that those complaining about the absence of divine justice will not necessarily benefit when God acts through his messenger.

<span id="page-755-7"></span><span id="page-755-6"></span><span id="page-755-4"></span><span id="page-755-2"></span>But this is a refining and cleansing fire, not a wholly destructive one (3:2b); refining judgment is a common prophetic theme (Isa. 1:25; 48:10; Jer. 9:7; Dan. 11:35; 12:10; Zech. 13:9). The second sentence of the verse provides a note of hope amid coming judgment, for without this refining, God's people could not stand in his judgment (cf. Mal. 3:5). Part of the messenger's work is to cleanse God's people spiritually.

<span id="page-755-10"></span><span id="page-755-9"></span><span id="page-755-1"></span>The messenger "sits" (v. 3) as the refining continues for some time before it is complete. Strikingly, the object of this purification is the Levites (v. 3), even though it appears that *all* the people are complaining (2:17) and that the apparently successful rebels are spread throughout the people (3:5). God's judgment and execution of justice begins with his own servants in his house (which explains the reference to the temple in v. 1). Only after the priests are cleansed (the verb translated "purify" in verse 3 often refers to ritual cleanness in Leviticus—e.g., 12:4, 6–8) will sacrificial worship again be pleasing to God. Strikingly, these offerings are then offered "in righteousness"—by implication, Judah's sloppy worship is one of the injustices complained about in Malachi 2:17. Thus the first injustice God addresses is the unworthy worship of him. Only after the restoration of fitting worship does God proceed more directly to his people's complaint. In 1:6–14, pure worship is related to the ever-spreading worship of God; here it is linked to execution of justice.

<span id="page-755-5"></span>3:5 Once his own people have been refined, the Lord executes justice on those rebelling against him (2:17)—not from a distance but by personally drawing near. The Lord's acting as a witness represents the whole process of justice; his "swift" witness resolves the complaint beginning the passage. No longer will the people ask where the God of justice is, as he judges crimes ranging from false worship to sexual sin to oppression of the poor.

### *Response*

Although some are blessed to labor in times of great and obvious blessing, many in ministry (and more broadly) are vulnerable to nursing a sense of injustice at the contrast between their own lives and the happy lives of those who live heedless of God. This passage emphatically insists that God is not slow to judge wrongdoing. When

<span id="page-756-2"></span><span id="page-756-0"></span>The gospels identify the messenger of the covenant with John the Baptist, and the Lord (Mal. 3:1) with Jesus (Matt. 11:10; Mark 1:2; Luke 7:27). It is in Jesus Christ that God works out ultimate justice for his discouraged people and judgment on those who do not fear him (Matt. 3:12). Reflection on the partial fulfillment of Malachi's prophecy in the Gospels, while looking forward to its full and complete fulfillment in the second coming, will guard us from any blasphemous resentment of God as we walk the hard road of his service.

## *Section Overview*

The Lord confronts Judah's spiritual defection through the withholding of tithes, and promises an overabundant blessing on obedient giving, extending beyond the community's borders.

## *Section Outline*

- V. Robbing God in the Tithe (3:6–12)
	- A. Charge: Return to Me (3:6–7a)
- <span id="page-757-10"></span><span id="page-757-9"></span>B. Question and Response: Robbing God in the Tithe (3:7b–8)
- C. Application: Explanation of the Present Curse (3:9) and the Promise of Future Blessing for Obedience (3:10–12)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-757-7"></span><span id="page-757-6"></span>3:6–7a Perhaps partially in response to the complaint beginning the last passage, the Lord recontextualizes the covenant relationship. Instead of unfair treatment, the history of God's people has been one of consistent defection and unfaithfulness, despite consistent goodness on God's part. The only reason God's people have not been consumed in judgment is God's stubborn goodness and mercy, rooted in his very character. In a further extension of grace to his people, God invites them to break with their past by making a suitable response to their God (cf. Zech. 1:3). As the passage proceeds, he will show them how to return. Although the covenant relationship should have been destroyed long ago, the entire history of Israel's sin and its consequences can be forgiven, replaced by a fresh intimacy with God and his blessings. At the same time, the call to return implies that God will not continue with a people who persist in defection.

<span id="page-757-8"></span>3:7b–8 The people's response at the end of verse 7 could be translated, "In what have we turned from you?" Although many statutes have been broken (v. 7), the Lord specifies the tithe—but not before asking a question to destabilize his audience, disrupting whatever justification they might have had for what they considered a meaningless omission. The question beginning verse 8 implies the impossibility of what is asked; the imperfect verb could be translated, "Could a man rob God?" Failure in tithing actualizes the impossibility—keeping something from God that is legitimately his. Human presumption of total ownership in a world in which God owns everything (Ps. 50:10–11) is deeply resistant to real worship and devotion. Little wonder God calls his people to return!

<span id="page-757-5"></span><span id="page-757-1"></span>3:9 Part of biblical prophecy is the explanation of the present decay of the covenant relationship even when its causes should have been obvious. The covenant curses have come into effect—specifically, marauding animals (v. 11; cf. Lev. 26:6, 22; Deut. 28:38–42). The entire nation is implicated in this sin and, continuing in it, they are heedless of its effects.

<span id="page-757-3"></span><span id="page-757-2"></span>3:10 While there is a testing of God that comes from hardheartedness (Deut. 6:16), God's invitation to "test" him here is an insistence on his unchanging faithfulness to his promises and goodness to his people. The command to test asserts the impossibility of God's failing to respond to his people's obedience.

<span id="page-757-11"></span><span id="page-757-4"></span><span id="page-757-0"></span>Three times verse 10 emphasizes the Lord's disproportionately generous response to Judah's obedience in tithing. First, "windows of heaven" recalls the flood that destroyed all creation (Gen. 7:11) and the unbelievable abundance of 2 Kings 7:1–2. Second, the Lord promises to "empty" (AT) the heavens of rain; he will hold nothing back. Third, the final phrase, translated "until there is no more

<span id="page-758-2"></span><span id="page-758-0"></span>need," means something stronger: "until there is a wearing out of sufficiency" (a somewhat similar phrase is found in Ps. 72:7). The Lord is promising an overwhelming blessing, more than the people are able to use (cf. Lev. 26:10). When Israel is asked to give back a fraction of what was never truly theirs, God responds with everything he has.

<span id="page-758-5"></span><span id="page-758-4"></span>3:11 The happy consequences of Judah's future obedience accrue as God promises to remove the curse (v. 9) that is destroying the fruit of their soil.

<span id="page-758-6"></span><span id="page-758-3"></span><span id="page-758-1"></span>3:12 The promised blessing will be so great that even those outside of Israel will notice. Instead of appalled shock at Israel's judgment (Lev. 26:21), the nations will call them "blessed." Although this verse does not speak of the nations' joining in worship, as in Malachi 1:14, it is difficult to separate the blessing the nations pronounce from that future hope. Malachi's audience probably had no idea that their failure to tithe was hindering a blessing that would attract the respect of foreign nations. The implications of the obedience of God's people reach beyond their borders.

Finally, the land of God's obedient people is not merely blessed, but delightful. God promises not only abundance but also the happiness and delight he gives to those who trust him enough to obey.

### *Response*

<span id="page-758-8"></span>Sometimes we are negligent in our relationship with God in ways we consider trifling but that actually amount to spiritual defection. How we spend money reveals a great deal about us. Although the NT does not insist on an exact amount to be given (2 Cor. 9:7), certain difficulties and hardships Christians experience may be due to negligence in this area—and faithfulness will be matched by God with a generosity those outside the church cannot help but notice. Even if the blessing may at times change in the new covenant from external, financial, or agricultural bounty to inward, spiritual blessing, the same God is consistently faithful to repentant people.

## <span id="page-758-7"></span>MALACHI 3:13–4:3

**<sup>13</sup>** "Your words have been hard against me, says the Lord. But you say, 'How have we spoken against you?' **14**You have said, 'It is vain to serve God. What is the profit of our keeping his charge or of walking as in mourning before the Lord of hosts? **15**And now we call the arrogant blessed. Evildoers not only prosper but they put God to the test and they escape.' "

**<sup>16</sup>**Then those who feared the Lord spoke with one another. The Lord paid attention and heard them, and a book of remembrance was written before him of those who feared the Lord and esteemed his name. **<sup>17</sup>** "They shall be mine, says the Lord of hosts, in the day when I make up my treasured possession, and I will spare them as a man spares his son who serves him. **18**Then once more you shall see the distinction between the righteous and the wicked, between one who serves God and one who does not serve him.

4 *<sup>1</sup>* "For behold, the day is coming, burning like an oven, when all the arrogant and all evildoers will be stubble. The day that is coming shall set them ablaze, says the Lord of hosts, so that it will leave them neither root nor branch. **2**But for you who fear my name, the sun of righteousness shall rise with healing in its wings. You shall go out leaping like calves from the stall. **3**And you shall tread down the wicked, for they will be ashes under the soles of your feet, on the day when I act, says the Lord of hosts."

1Ch 4:1–6 is ch 3:19–24 in Hebrew

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-759-3"></span>The book's final main oracle returns to the subject of God's apparent injustice and the day of the Lord (as in 2:17–3:5) and describes more fully God's justice on that day, which will favor those who fear him and will destroy those persisting in rebellion.

## *Section Outline*

- VI. The Great Day of the Lord (3:13–4:3)
	- A. Charge, Question, Response: The Futility of Serving God (3:13–15)
	- B. Narrative: The Book of Remembrance (3:16–18)
		- 1. The God-Fearers Repent (3:16)
		- 2. The Lord Honors Their Repentance (3:17–18)
	- C. Application: The Day of the Lord (4:1–3)
		- 1. Judgment of the Wicked (4:1)
		- 2. Salvation for God-Fearers (4:2–3)
			- a. Joy (4:2)
			- b. Participation in Judgment (4:3)

## *Comment*

<span id="page-759-4"></span><span id="page-759-1"></span><span id="page-759-0"></span>3:13 The Lord's initial charge against Judah involves more than merely rude or inconsiderate speech. The same phrase is found in 2 Samuel 24:4 and 1 Chronicles 21:4, where David overrules Joab's advice. The Judahites seem to be not only dishonoring God with their speech but also forcefully insisting on their cynical theology (confirmed by the particular phrasing beginning Mal. 3:15, which might be paraphrased, "From now on, we are calling . . ."). Their minds are made up.

<span id="page-759-7"></span><span id="page-759-6"></span><span id="page-759-5"></span><span id="page-759-2"></span>3:14–15 The charge of injustice against God is the same as in 2:17. On the one hand, they feel that serving God has made their lives worse (3:14). This is the implication of the question in verse 14: their service in God's presence causes mourning, <span id="page-760-12"></span><span id="page-760-11"></span><span id="page-760-4"></span>not joy. They have nothing to show for their labor, so their service is in vain. On the other hand, it seems to them that moral and spiritual rebels run free and prosper (v. 15), a complaint about those within the Judahite community who were defying God. Although the people's complaint is not limited to priests, verse 14 alludes to temple service. "Keeping God's charge" is frequently used of Levitical duties in the sanctuary (Num. 3:7, 28, 32; 18:3–5; Ezek. 40:45–46; 44:14–16), recalling the use of *ʻabad* ("serve") for ritual worship in the tabernacle (cf. Ex. 3:12; 4:23; 10:26; 12:31; 13:5) and the command in legal texts to rejoice before God there (Lev. 23:40; Deut. 12:7; 16:1; 27:7). As is often the case in Malachi and other parts of the OT, the people's relationship with God finds its heart in the temple—but, in contrast to other passages in the OT, here their service produces only mourning, not joy.

<span id="page-760-13"></span><span id="page-760-10"></span><span id="page-760-9"></span><span id="page-760-5"></span><span id="page-760-1"></span><span id="page-760-0"></span>3:16 For the first time in Malachi, there is a positive response to the prophet's preaching: instead of a second rebuttal from the people (as in 1:6–7 and 3:7–8), a group within the community takes counsel together. The verb for speaking in verse 16 (a form of *dbr*) is the same as in verse 13, forming a hopeful contrast: instead of continuing to complain, and without any direct command from God, they discuss their response to the prophetic word. The book written "before him" produces a similar contrast with Israel's complaint of mourning "before the Lord" in verse 14. The complaint directly before God's presence dissolves into repentance before him. Even happier is God's attention to their response before the book of remembrance is mentioned, registered with two separate verbs. Although the phrase "the Lord paid attention and heard" would fit easily at the end of the verse, its earlier location implies God's attention to his people's repentance.

<span id="page-760-8"></span><span id="page-760-7"></span><span id="page-760-6"></span><span id="page-760-3"></span><span id="page-760-2"></span>The "book of remembrance" is similar to references to a book belonging to God seen elsewhere in the OT; most often the context suggests a record of those who belong to him (Ex. 32:32–33; Dan. 12:1; cf. Rev. 20:15), while Psalm 139:16 reveals a book narrating the course of the lives of God's saints. Sometimes God's enemies are erased from his book (Ps. 69:28), while Exodus 17:14 records (in a phrase very similar to this verse) a book to remember the Lord's perpetual antipathy toward Amalek. Official public lists of Israelites were also kept (Neh. 7:5; 12:23; Ezek. 13:9), and there is a single reference to a Persian "book of remembrance" of Persian royal history (Est. 6:1). Even if this practice is not otherwise well known, these other books suggest this "book of remembrance" records a list of those within the community who publicly recommitted themselves to the Lord. (As we will see, the meaning of "treasured possession" in Mal. 3:17 and the discriminatory nature of the judgment in 4:1–3 support this.) The other OT references listed above suggest this is God's book, written "before him" in heaven by a recording angel, by which he records those within the postexilic community who have repented of their cynicism. This remnant remains within God's realm of blessing, much in contrast to the complaint voiced in the previous verses.

<span id="page-760-15"></span><span id="page-760-14"></span>The verse ends by specifying that those in this book fear God and esteem his name. Fearing God in the OT connotes basic reverence and devotion as the basis <span id="page-761-5"></span><span id="page-761-1"></span>of any relationship with him (Deut. 10:12; Job 1:1; Prov. 1:7). To "esteem" God's name is a phrase not found elsewhere in the OT, but it makes sense against the background of Malachi 3:13–15: complaining of the futility of serving God is the opposite of thinking of God's fame and reputation above one's own comfort (cf. 1:11, 14).

<span id="page-761-13"></span><span id="page-761-10"></span><span id="page-761-7"></span><span id="page-761-4"></span>3:17–18 We hear the Lord's response to the repentance of verse 16. He promises, "They will be mine—my treasured possession, on the day I am making" (AT). The constant emphasis on the day of the Lord in 4:1–3 ("on the day I am making" is exactly repeated at the end of 4:3), together with the future tense verbs in 3:17–18, suggest that God is making a promise that will come into effect at the day described in 4:1–3. A "treasured possession" (*segullah*) refers to the private property of a king amid his ownership of everything in his kingdom (1 Chron. 29:3; Eccles. 2:8). Israel as a whole is given this distinction—in explicit contrast to the other nations—in Exodus 19:5; Deuteronomy 7:6; 14:2; 26:18. Unusually within the OT, this term is applied to a faithful remnant within the larger community of God's people: those in the book of remembrance will personally belong to God on the coming day.

<span id="page-761-3"></span><span id="page-761-2"></span><span id="page-761-0"></span>The verb "spare" (Mal. 3:17) can also mean "have pity on" (Ezek. 16:5; Joel 2:18). Both senses are probably in view: God will renew his compassion on these Godfearers, as any father would, and spare them from the coming judgment. These God-fearers will see that the complaint of Malachi 3:14–15 is groundless: God will act to make evident the distinction between righteous and wicked, between the one serving God and the one serving self. In making this promise, he implies that the complaint in verses 13–15 is not entirely a problem of perception on Judah's part; the value and benefit of serving God and the distinction between the righteous and the wicked are not (yet) fully realized. At the same time, of course, the Lord's insistence on the coming distinction between these two groups should vitiate any jealousy of the wicked who prosper in this life.

<span id="page-761-9"></span><span id="page-761-6"></span>4:1 If 3:17–18 lays out the God-fearers' hope, 4:1 shows how these expectations become a reality. Although many other prophetic texts describe God's action "on that day," and God's direct appearance is often described in terms of fire, this prophetic text is unique in describing *the day itself* as burning up the wicked. In Malachi's deployment of these common prophetic themes, the fire of God's appearance reduces the arrogant and evildoers of 3:15 to ash; there is no escape, and whatever temporary gains they made before that day are forever consumed. This judgment is both swift and total: the day is twice described as "coming," and neither root nor branch is left. The coming distinction between righteous and wicked (3:18) will be unmistakable.

<span id="page-761-12"></span><span id="page-761-11"></span><span id="page-761-8"></span>4:2–3 The ESV correctly expresses the contrast between verses 1 and 2 by stating, "But for you." "Fearing God's name" (cf. v. 2) combines the two phrases in 3:16 ("feared the Lord" and "esteemed his name") for those recorded in the book of remembrance, indicating they receive this promise. The promise's imagery is consistent with that of 4:1 even while shifting it: for the God-fearers, this day holds not unquenchable fire but a shining sun. This is most likely a metaphor for the fiery theophany of the Lord on that day.

<span id="page-762-9"></span><span id="page-762-6"></span><span id="page-762-3"></span><span id="page-762-0"></span>In the OT, the Lord is explicitly compared to a sun only in Psalm 84:11, although in a few other places he "shines forth" (cf. Deut. 33:2 and Isa. 60:1–2, which use the verb translated "rise" in Mal. 4:2; Hab. 3:3 has a similar image). The context of Psalm 84 shows that the metaphor clearly connotes blessing and protection. The image of the sun means the same here: God-fearers will be protected from the judgment of Malachi 4:1 and will enjoy God's blessing, like the well-fed, carefree, playful animals of verse 2. Malachi qualifies this sun as a sun "of righteousness" to connect this blessing and judgment to the complaint of God's treatment of the just and unjust in 3:13–15. This "righteous" sun works the judgment and blessing called for earlier in the passage. The healing this sun brings should be understood in relation to blessing: healing in the OT is not limited to recovery from illness but includes restoration from all kinds of tragedy and loss (cf. 2 Chron. 7:14; Ps. 107:20; Prov. 4:22; 6:15; Jer. 8:15; 14:19; 33:6). This healing sun restores the God-fearers to fullness of life and peace.

<span id="page-762-7"></span><span id="page-762-2"></span>The reference to the sun's "wings" is strange to us, but Malachi's original audience would have been reminded of the chief Persian deity Ahura Mazda, commonly portrayed with a winged sun disk. In a Persian context, a king portrayed within this winged sun disk was under the blessing and protection of the deity. Malachi's image is not a compromise with pagan religion but a hint that the blessing and protection Persian worship promises is found actually in the Lord. There are numerous other examples of Yahweh appropriating roles or actions from pagan deities in order to convince his people that he is the only God who can actually perform the salvation other gods promise; the Lord's sending of a storm in 1 Kings 18 to humiliate the storm god Baal is one prominent instance.

<span id="page-762-10"></span><span id="page-762-8"></span><span id="page-762-1"></span>Malachi 4:3 shows what the frolicking animals are trampling on: the wicked of 3:15 and 4:1. The explanatory phrase "for they will be ashes" clarifies that the God-fearers do not themselves execute judgment; the wicked are already burned up in the coming day. But the God-fearers do participate in this judgment and the restoration of moral order. Whatever evil remains is stomped on and crushed into nothing by God's own people. The mourning of God's servants as the wicked enjoy everything good in life is resolved decisively as God's servants themselves are given a role in the restoration of all things.

<span id="page-762-5"></span><span id="page-762-4"></span>Passages of Scripture looking forward to the judgment of the wicked, and even envisioning some role for God's people in it, easily offend modern sensibilities. While modern unease with passages like this is understandable, it is worth remembering that a key characteristic of the wicked in the OT is unrepentant and violent selfishness. Limiting ourselves to the prophets, the wicked are described as preying on others (Jer. 5:26), making a habit of violence (Ezek. 7:11), enriching themselves by robbing others (Mic. 6:11), twisting justice (Hab. 1:4), and creating <span id="page-763-2"></span><span id="page-763-1"></span><span id="page-763-0"></span>moral and social chaos where everyone suffers (Isa. 1:21–23). Although God excludes no nation from his worship (Mal. 1:14), his kingdom cannot come, nor his reign be fully realized, without destroying this evil and the people who give themselves to it. In fact, without this judgment, it would truly be useless to serve God (3:14). And if the Lord gives his servants some limited role in the restoration of right on that great and final day, will we refuse? Is our sense of justice more refined that God's?

#### *Response*

<span id="page-763-3"></span>Any Christian never tempted to voice the complaint of 3:14 may need to ask himself if he is working hard enough. Before the redemption of all things, it will often appear that God's servants win only gloom for their sacrifice, while those openly defiant of God not only enjoy themselves but are "blessed" (v. 15)—enjoying the quality of life that those close to the Lord could reasonably expect. Malachi's response is not to deny the difficulties of serving God, as if there were some other benefits of which his audience was unaware, but rather to broaden their perspective. In other words, there is a sense in which Malachi agrees that serving God, before the day of the Lord, does not necessarily confer the blessed and full life each of us desires. But God's work on that great and final day will so utterly rebalance whatever loss is sustained before the end of all things that all of our complaints will vanish. God's saints will even be granted a role in that restoration. The judgment and healing of this day was inaugurated in God's work in Christ and will be completed when Christ comes again (cf. the image of the rising sun in Luke 1:78–79 with Mal. 4:2).

<span id="page-763-5"></span><span id="page-763-4"></span>It is appropriate for us, living "in between the times," to reflect on the repentance of the faithful remnant in 3:16. Before any warnings or promises are made, without any other incentive, those fearing God bind themselves publicly and unconditionally to the Lord in a way that carries great weight with God. Even amid the inequalities in which God's ministers labor, we are given an example of "early" repentance and we see how quickly God responds to such repentance, as promises to the God-fearers echo through this description of the day of the Lord.

## <span id="page-763-6"></span>MALACHI 4:4–6

**<sup>4</sup>** "Remember the law of my servant Moses, the statutes and rules*<sup>1</sup>* that I commanded him at Horeb for all Israel.

**<sup>5</sup>** "Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the great and awesome day of the Lord comes. **6**And he will turn the hearts of fathers to their children and the hearts of children to their fathers, lest I come and strike the land with a decree of utter destruction."*<sup>2</sup>*

1Or *and just decrees* 2The Hebrew term rendered *decree of utter destruction* refers to things devoted (or set apart) to the Lord (or by the Lord) for destruction

## *Section Overview*

<span id="page-764-8"></span>Malachi summarizes his message by looking to both the past and the future, guiding his audience in how to live now (4:4) as they await the coming day (vv. 5–6).

## *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-764-10"></span><span id="page-764-9"></span>VII. Conclusion: Remembering Moses, Waiting for Elijah (4:4–6)
	- A. Faithfulness to the Mosaic Covenant (4:4)
	- B. The Coming Elijah (4:5–6)
		- 1. His Anticipatory Commission (4:5)
		- 2. His Preparatory Mission (4:6)

## <span id="page-764-11"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-764-6"></span><span id="page-764-3"></span><span id="page-764-2"></span>4:4 The Mosaic covenant is in the background throughout Malachi; many of the prophet's concerns are first laid out in Exodus–Deuteronomy, such as sacrifice and worship (Mal. 1:8–10, 12–13; 2:12; 3:4), the priesthood (2:1–9); and the tithe (3:8). The law also acted as a rallying point for the spiritual reconstitution of the postexilic community (Nehemiah 8). As Malachi's audience awaits fulfillment of the promises of this book, the Lord's expectations for them have not changed since the earliest stages of the covenant relationship. In fact, Deuteronomy itself already frequently calls Israel to "remember" (Deut. 5:15; 7:18; 8:2, 18; 9:7). Although a terser command ("Remember Moses") would probably have been sufficient to communicate the continuing need for covenant faithfulness, Malachi spurs their memory by reminding them of the divine origin of these laws ("that I commanded") and the place of their giving ("Horeb"), original audience ("all Israel"), and content ("statutes and rules").

<span id="page-764-7"></span><span id="page-764-5"></span><span id="page-764-4"></span><span id="page-764-1"></span><span id="page-764-0"></span>4:5 Malachi neatly summarizes the two "day of the Lord" passages (2:17–3:5; 3:13–4:3). The phrase "Behold, I will send" in 4:5 echoes 3:1, while the reference to the coming day echoes 4:1. The close wording prompts us to understand Elijah as the coming messenger, unidentified in 3:1. In addition to his pedigree as a great servant of God, the fact that Elijah apparently avoided physical death (2 Kings 2) makes him an obvious candidate for the final prophetic figure to prepare God's people before the coming day. There seems to have been an expectation of a literal return of Elijah in Jesus' day (Matt. 17:10), but Jesus declares John the Baptist to be the fulfillment of this prophecy (Matt. 11:14).

<span id="page-764-14"></span><span id="page-764-13"></span><span id="page-764-12"></span>4:6 The description of the coming Elijah's ministry of reconciling fathers and sons may seem strange, since nothing has been said elsewhere in the book about generational strife. Malachi probably places the fundamental relationship between father and son as a synecdoche for the healing of God's people. Just as the whole law is summarized in the commandment to love one another (Gal. 5:14), so Malachi summarizes the breaches in the covenant relationship by referring to this basic relationship between father and son.

<span id="page-765-2"></span><span id="page-765-1"></span><span id="page-765-0"></span>The threat of a "decree of utter destruction" ending Malachi 4:6 translates a single Hebrew word (*herem*, translated "devote to destruction" in Deut. 7:2; Josh. 10:39; 11:12; 1 Sam. 15:3; etc.). In these earlier passages, *herem* was the final and irredeemable act of destructive judgment against evil and those who practiced it. It is tied to the "re-sanctification" of the territory where the abominable deeds were practiced (cf. Deut. 7:2 together with vv. 5–6). While this can seem a harsh way to end the book, it is not a bald threat to obey or be destroyed. Rather, God promises a messenger who will prepare his people so that judgment can be avoided. The consecutive perfect verb form beginning Malachi 4:6 is a "prophetic" perfect, showing a future certainty. Without being asked, the Lord sends a prophet to prepare his people so that his coming can be a blessing.

## *Response*

As the final Prophetic Book of the OT ends, the Lord shows us the simplicity of his requirements as we await the day of his appearing. God promises that he will send a prophet to prepare his people for that coming day. As new covenant believers, we have the benefit of seeing the fulfillment of this short passage in the work of John the Baptist, who prepared the way for Jesus. As we await the second coming of Christ, we continually look back to Jesus, our greater Moses, through whom God finally and ultimately spoke his will, and we keep ourselves ready for that great and final day.
